dialogue: A: Are you going to vote this Tuesday?
B: Yes, I am, and I am so excited.
A: Have you figured out who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I love my candidate.
A: Why is that?
response: B: My candidate is probably the dumbest.

dialogue: A: A woman after my own heart...
B: OK, Mr. Coffee Connoisseur, so what's the next step in the coffee-making process?
A: Well, step two is grinding the coffee beans. I've roasted three different types of beans.
B: Let me guess, Mocha, Mandheling, and Santos!
A: Yep, my own special blend! You can tell by just smelling them?
response: B: No, I just read the names off the packages... Ha!

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve in the library for anthropology 311.
A: Professor Gilers's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matter which one of them you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're kidding all of them?

A: I've asked professor Gilers twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for these same articles to be returned.
B: And here I went out of my way to free the whole afternoon to read.
response: A: I'm sorry, but there is a lot I can do about it. All I can suggest is that you come in first thing tomorrow morning and try again; we open at eight.

dialogue: A: Today in the studio we have Alberto Cortez, the well-known Brazilian advocate of the anti-global movement. He's here to talk about the recent report, stating that by 2050 Brazil will be the one ot the word's wealthiest and most successful countries. Alberto, what do you say to the report?
B: You know this isn't the first time that people are saying Brazil will be a great economic power. The same thing was said over a hundred year ago. But it didn't happen.
A: Yes, but you must admit the world's a very different place now.
B: Of course. In fact I believe there's maybe some truth in the prediction this time around. First of all, though, we must remember the problems facing Brazil at the moment.
A: Such as...?

B: There's an enormous gap between the rich and the poor in this country. In Sal Paulo, you can see shopping malls full of designer goods right next door to the slam areas without proper water and electricity supplies. A lot of work needs to be done to help people in those areas improve their lives.
A: What needs to be done?
response: B: Education, for example. For Brazil to be successful, we need to offer education to all Brazilians. Successful countries like South Korea and Singapore have excellent education systems. Brazil needs to learn from these countries.

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
response: B: I'm going to attend a conference on air pollution.

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
response: B: Well, there's a coffee shop on the next corner. It serves good food.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you live here?
B: Yes.
A: Oh, well, do you know where the English Language Institute is?
B: Ah, yes. I think I know where it is. Do you have a car?
A: No, I'm on foot.
B: Well, as you go out of the station, just continue along the road until you come to the second crossing and then turn left into King Street.
A: Yes.
response: B: Then walk down the stairs just a bit and take the first turning on the right. And keep walking until you come to the park.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ben. You're getting ready for tomorrow's lessons, aren't you?
B: Yes, but I'm a bit nervous. I have no idea what'll happen in class and how I'll get along with my classmates.
A: I understand how you're feeling. Just take it easy. You'll make a lot of friends very soon.
B: Thank you. I'll try my best to get used to my new school life as soon as possible. By the way, what time does the first class begin?
A: At 8 o'clock. But before that we have 10 minutes to hand in homework and then 20 minutes for morning reading.
B: So we must get to school before 7:30, right?
A: Right.
B: How long does each class last?
A: 45 minutes, I think, with a 10 or 15 minutes' break.
response: B: Well, I hear that lunchtime is nearly 12 o'clock and I'll be comfortably satiated by then.

dialogue: A: Are you okay?
B: No.
A: What's wrong?
B: I got robbed!
A: By who?
response: B: Some guy on the street just mugged me.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.
response: A: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of weak and comfortable shoes.

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
A: No, what you need is balance.
B: Could you teach me how to do it?
A: Sure, anytime when you are free.
B: Do I have to buy a pair of skates?
response: A: I think it's necessary. Why not sell them?

dialogue: A: Hi.
B: Hi, Mary, Hi, Ken I hate to bring this up, but that new stereo, system you got...
A: Yeah?
response: B: You broke it last night.

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
B: You did? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered.
A: Oh, the telephone lines were damaged by the storm. They repaired them yesterday.
B: What did David do yesterday? Did he and Judy go dancing?
A: No, they stayed home and played cards with the children.
B: And what did you do? Did you play cards, too?
response: A: No. I listened to records and studied, but I also played cards with some friends at a local bar.

dialogue: A: Beautiful weather, isn ’ t it?
B: Yes, it is. Are you here on business?
A: No, I ’ m on a vacation to see the famous Three Gorges.
B: I ’ m going there for a tour, too. Is this your first trip to China?
A: Yes, it is.
response: B: Why don ’ t we go together? I can show you around. I think you ’ ll have a better time.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
response: B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have a lot of work to do in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
A: If I were you, I'd say sorry to her first and then get her another cat.
response: B: That's a good idea. But I have plenty of money.

dialogue: A: Are you ready for a second?
B: No, I'm afraid we'll have to cancel the order. I'm not sure whether it agrees with me.
A: Would you like anything else?
B: I'd prefer swordfish steak.
response: A: I'm sorry, but we refuse to serve any of our swordfish steak.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some gloves.
A: All our gloves are here. What do you think of this pair here? It's made of silk.
B: Hm, it looks nice, but I'd like to have something warm for the winter.
response: A: Maybe you would like light plastic gloves. How about this pair?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
response: B: Everything is so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.

dialogue: A: Hello, I am calling about my cable service.
B: What's the problem?
A: For the past week my cable hasn't been working.
B: I apologize, but the cable has been down lately.
A: Do you know when it is going to start working again?
response: B: Give it a couple months , and it should be back on .

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.
response: B: I did that, and it seemed helpful when I found the batteries had charged after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
B: Well, there's a coffee shop on the next corner. It serves good food.
A: OK. I'll try it. Can I get you something?
B: No, I think I'll come with you. I'm longing for a nice salad.
A: Do you often have lunch at this coffee shop?
response: B: No, I usually bring my lunch from home and stash it for weeks in my desk.

dialogue: A: And anything to drink?
B: Yes, a red wine and a cup of coffee.
A: How do you like your coffee?
B: With milk but without sugar, please.
response: A: Then how about the wine? Is white wine OK?

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, it looks like you've got some sun this weekend.
B: Yeah, I guess so. I spent the weekend at the beach.
A: Oh, yeah, that's great. Where did you stay?
B: Some friends of my parents' live out there and they invited me for as long as I wanted to stay.
A: So what are you doing back here already?
B: Oh, I have a paper to work on, and I just couldn't do any serious studying at the beach.
A: I don't blame you. So what did you do out there? I mean besides lying out in the sun.
B: I ran slowly up and down the beach, and 1 played some volleyball. You know I never realized how hard it is to run on sand. I couldn't even get through a whole game before I had to sit down.
A: Did you go swimming?
response: B: I wanted to, but they said the water is the perfect temperature for swimming right now.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to make an appointment to look at houses.
B: Sure, would you prefer looking in the morning or afternoon?
A: I would prefer mornings.
B: Can you go during the week, or can you only go during the weekend?
A: Going to look at houses during the week is best for me.
B: Where would you like me to pick you up?
A: I will meet you at the real estate office.
B: I am thinking of looking at three houses, and it will take about two hours.
A: That sounds good to me.
response: B: Once I look at the houses, I'll contact the owners and confirm the times.

dialogue: A: Anna, that outfit looks wonderful on you! The color goes with your trousers perfectly.
B: Thanks, Carla. That's quite a compliment coming from you. You always dress so tastefully.
A: Well, that dress certainly shows your good taste. It must have cost a lot.
B: No, not much. I got it on sale at the mall - 60 % off.
response: A: Really? You're an amazing bargain hunter! Next time there's a sale, promise you'll let me tag along with you.

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
A: I have no other choice. Next month will be the most important exam of this term.
B: I can understand that. But anyway, you should take better care of yourself.
A: What should I do now?
response: B: I think you should spin around for a little while and I will call the doctor.

dialogue: A: Hello, I need to come in and see the doctor.
B: Are you scheduling a check-up, or are you ill?
A: I have really itchy skin and think I may have to have it looked at.
B: Have you been feeling any joint aches with that rash?
response: A: No, but I feel really well.

dialogue: A: Dalian is a beautiful city. Do you agree?
B: I suppose I do.
A: The climate here is pleasant.
B: You said it.
response: A: This city is really comfortable to live in.

dialogue: A: ( Before Christmas Party ) Are you ready for the Christmas party tonight
B: Almost. I have to get dressed. It's a formal party and I have special party make up!
A: Use this lipstick and it will make your lips shine!
B: Great! Uh, remember that there's a gift exchange, too. We all have to bring a gift.
A: I've already got mine.
response: B: ( At the Party ) It's New Year's Eve! Time to open presents!

dialogue: A: Are you there, Mary?
B: I'm back. My bid on the Buddha is still the highest!
A: How much is my stamp?
B: Don't you want to hear more about my statue?
response: A: Don't get ahead of yourself. Fat boy isn't yours yet.

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
A: No, I don't. I mean a general practitioner. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.
B: Really, I believe I can quit on my own. But I'll think about it. I will.
A: All fight. I won't mention it for a week. Then I want to know your decision. Because if you don't get some help, I need to rethink our plans.
response: B: You mean you'd still marry me after this? I can't believe it!

dialogue: A: Acknowledgments play a necessary part in the interview.
B: Sure. Kind acknowledgments can show one's good attainment.
A: We often ignore the acknowledgments in our daily life, and consider them as disposable.
response: B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a bad impression on others, especially in the public places.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
A: Are you renting it alone or with company?
B: I'll share it with one of my friends. What ’ s in a one-bedroom apartment?
A: A one-bedroom apartment has one bedroom, a living room, a kitchen and a bathroom.
B: Is there any furniture?
A: No, but a fridge and a stove.
response: B: It sounds wonderful . Do I have to sign a lease ? How much should I pay ?

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.
B: Actually, I like it very much.
A: I'm glad you enjoy it. Let me serve you some more fish.
response: B: No, thank you. I've had enough fish, but I'd like some soup.

dialogue: A: Excuse me,can I see the personnel manager? My name is Lucy Jordan.
B: Oh, yes. Have a scat, please.
A: Thank you. I come in answer to your ad for the saleswoman.
B: Okay, what qualifications do you have for the toy store work?
response: A: I once worked in a local toy store and my major is business administration.

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
response: A: No, what you need is clumsiness

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Have you been waiting long?
B: Twenty minutes already.
A: Did you notice whether the No. 7 bus has passed by?
response: B: Not while I've been standing here. I'm also waiting for the No. 7 bus myself.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
response: B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for autumn, but I'd like to have something cold for winter.

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
response: B: At least , it can keep you near the crowd . By the way , do you come from China ?

dialogue: A: Would you come to dinner next Sunday?
B: Sunday? No, I'm sorry. I'm busy on Sunday.
A: How about Saturday?
B: Yes, I'd love to. What time?
A: How about 7:00?
B: OK.
A: Do you know where I live?
B: Sorry, I have no idea.
A: I'm on No. 1125, Beijing Road.
B: I think I can find it. Anything I should bring along?
A: Oh, just bring yourself. We'll get everything ready.
response: B: Thank you for your rudeness.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
response: A: Why have you been studying so little?

dialogue: A: Morning. Gail. Did you enjoy your holiday in the country?
B: Yes. We had a great time. And some friends went along with us.
A: Where did you stay? In a hotel?
response: B: No, we camped in a bear cave and stayed in a hammock. We cooked all our meals over an open fire.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
response: A: Yes, they spent about five hours sparking the flames. Hm, what a strange smell!

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote?
B: I am so excited to be voting.
A: Do you know who you ’ re going to vote for?
response: B: I am so impressed with the candidate I ’ m going to vote for.

dialogue: A: Cheers! To our first night in our new apartment.
B: It's so quiet. I'm not really used to it.
A: All you hear is the crickets and the breeze.
response: B: It's a little eerie. I'm sure the silence will begin to grow on me.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
B: If you got laid off or are working a lot fewer hours, you may qualify.
A: Do I definitely get to collect unemployment?
B: Not all jobs pay into unemployment insurance, so their employees cannot collect benefits.
A: How do I check out my status to collect unemployment?
response: B: You should have noticed unemployment insurance being added to your paycheck. Check your pay stubs.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon! Dr. Perkins' office.
B: Good afternoon. I'd like to speak to the doctor. Is he in?
A: Who is that calling, please?
B: My name is Li Hong. I'm from China.
A: I'm sorry. Dr. Perkins is now at an important meeting and can't answer your call.
B: I'm an exchange scholar. Dr. Perkins asked me to give a lecture. There are some details I want to discuss with him.
response: A: I see, but you must speak to me about that.  Oh, well, if you leave your number, I'll tell him to ignore your call as soon as he is available.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.
B: Uh. I didn't have any of that when I was in middle school, and I did just fine.
A: Yeah, and there weren't any cars either. Things are a lot more progressive now.
B: Great. My daughter will be playing video games in class.
A: Dad.
response: B: Okay. How much are these things going to tickle me?

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
response: A: It's wide open right now, everything from dance teachers to center manager.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, I'll have a steak, please.
A: How would you like the steak, rare, medium, or well-done?
B: Rare, please.
A: Would you like something to drink?
response: B: Coffee, please.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, Is there an airline flying to New York this afternoon?
B: Sorry, sir. I can't sell you a ticket. Our computer is down.
A: If your computer is down, just write me a ticket.
B: Sorry, I can't. The computer is the only one allowed doing so.
A: Hmm... Then what do all you people do?
response: B: We give the computer the information about your trip, and then it tells us whether you can fly with us or not.

dialogue: A: Caroline Menzies speaking.
B: Could I speak to Diana Curzon?
A: I'm afraid she's in a meeting at the moment. Who's speaking?
B: This is John Laing from Dantons.
A: Can I take a message, Mr Laing?
response: B: Yes, please. I'm actually returning her call. So perhaps you could tell her that I called.

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
B: And the bike was run over by the car. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.
response: A: It was lucky that you already had broken legs.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
B: How about exercise?
A: Well, I often play tennis or handball.
response: B: Do you eat any cat food?

dialogue: A: Has Alan shown up yet?
B: Nope. I guess something might have come up.
A: I wonder what happened.
B: I don't know. I hope it's nothing serious.
A: Last week his sister was admitted to the hospital.
B: Oh? What happened?
A: His sister had a car accident last week.
B: Is she fine now?
response: A: She has never been in better health.

dialogue: A: Are you studying any languages here?
B: Yes, I'm studying in the Foreign Languages Department.
A: What are you majoring in?
response: B: I'm majoring in gardening.

dialogue: A: Hello, Jim. Where are you going?
B: To the cinema. What about coming with me?
A: No, thanks. I'm going home. My friend's expecting me.
B: What a pity! I believe it's a very good film.
A: Do you go to the cinema a lot?
B: Once a week. Most nights I sit at home and watch TV.
A: Oh, I see. By the way, where are you going for your holidays this year?
B: I don't know yet. My wife's going to her mother's for a couple of weeks. She lives by the sea, you know.
A: Oh, does she? That's convenient.
response: B: Yes, but I want to go to the country.

dialogue: A: He has come to life in the end.
B: Oh, thank God. We all felt frightened by the bad news about him.
A: Yes. Fortunately, an ambulance passed in the nick of time, and we got him away to hospital.
B: Right. Unless, who know what will happen.
response: A: wish him to continue being sick for long

dialogue: A: I'm not looking forward to the English lesson tomorrow.
B: Why not?
A: Because the teacher has said that we're going to have a quiz.
B: But you had a test week, didn't you?
response: A: No, we didn't.  That's why I want another one tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
B: No, never. I don't want to mark my desk.
A: Well, would you please keep my desk clean?
B: Aren't you going to sell it?
response: A: Yes, so who cares if it's a badly marked one?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Does this hotel have a fitness facility?
B: Yes, we try to accommodate all needs of our patrons, including fitness.
A: Where is your fitness facility located?
B: The gym is just below the lobby. Take the elevator or the stairs. You can't miss it.
A: Is there an additional surcharge for the gym?
response: B: No , the gym is free to guests . Take your credit card , however , so you can get in .

dialogue: A: Mr. Block, I need to take a few days off because my parents are coming over to visit.
B: But it's not really a good idea to take time off right now, you know.
A: Well, I know. But they've never been to the UK before and they don't speak English.
B: Hmm, you know there are thousands of tourists in London who can't speak English and they manage to get around.
response: A: Yes, I know but they really expect me to be there. It's culture. Chinese children expect their parents to do things like this.

dialogue: A: Are you busy with your work?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, I'm very busy, too. Sometimes I work overtime.
B: Then your salary must be high.
response: A: Just so so. But we wish we could afford to travel twice every year.

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
B: But I didn't hear it at all.
A: What time did you set it for last night?
B: Six o'clock.
A: Hurry up, or you'll be late for school. Are you feeling ill?
response: B: No. I'm not sleepy because I slept well the whole night.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. What can I do for you?
B: I want some coffee.
A: Certainly, madam. What kind of coffee do you want to have?
B: What have you got?
response: A: Well . We have coke , sprite , mountain dew , water and orange juice .

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.
response: A: You could've gotten some change in a store.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to make an appointment to look at houses.
B: Sure, would you prefer looking in the morning or afternoon?
A: I would prefer mornings.
response: B: Can you go during the week , or can you only go during the weekend ?

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
response: A: I have to take you dancing.

dialogue: A: 911. What can I do for you?
B: I am reporting a break-in.
A: When did it happen?
B: It happened last night.
A: Where did it happen?
B: It happened at my house.
A: What was taken?
B: I don't know.
A: How do you know there was a break-in?
B: Someone busted my window.
response: A: I will send a squad car to your house right now.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
response: B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
response: B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this weekend then.

dialogue: A: Today in the studio we have Alberto Cortez, the well-known Brazilian advocate of the anti-global movement. He's here to talk about the recent report, stating that by 2050 Brazil will be the one ot the word's wealthiest and most successful countries. Alberto, what do you say to the report?
B: You know this isn't the first time that people are saying Brazil will be a great economic power. The same thing was said over a hundred year ago. But it didn't happen.
A: Yes, but you must admit the world's a very different place now.
B: Of course. In fact I believe there's maybe some truth in the prediction this time around. First of all, though, we must remember the problems facing Brazil at the moment.
A: Such as...?

B: There's an enormous gap between the rich and the poor in this country. In Sal Paulo, you can see shopping malls full of designer goods right next door to the slam areas without proper water and electricity supplies. A lot of work needs to be done to help people in those areas improve their lives.
A: What needs to be done?
response: B: Rodeos, for example. For Brazil to be successful, we need to offer rodeos to all Brazilians. Successful countries like South Korea and Singapore have excellent rodeo systems. Brazil needs to learn from these countries.

dialogue: A: Marissa, if your papers continue to be late, I will have to give you a failing grade for the course.
B: I'm sorry! I've been having a really hard semester.
A: You need to try a little harder, okay?
response: B: I know, I will. There's just been a lot going on lately. I'm buying my first house, and my brother gets a good job.

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
response: B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on dry grasses too.

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
B: But I didn't hear it at all.
A: What time did you set it for last night?
B: Six o'clock.
A: Hurry up, or you'll be late for school. Are you feeling ill?
response: B: No. I'm only sleepy because I had a peaceful dream the whole night.

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
response: B: But I  have a car and I can drive. Is there any other way to travel?

dialogue: A: What topic did you finally choose for the term paper for your World Economy class?
B: After thinking about a few ideas, I finally settled on the difference between Japanese and American styles of management.
A: Hmm. Why did you choose a topic like that?
B: Well, I'm planning to study Business in graduate school next year. After that, I hope to start my own company.
A: Isn't that a coincidence! I'm also doing a paper on how Japanese management styles are being adapted by American firms for my Comparative Cultures class.
response: B: Why don't we sit down and share some of our sources after we've each been to the library?

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote this Tuesday?
B: Yes, I am, and I am so excited.
A: Have you figured out who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I love my candidate.
A: Why is that?
B: My candidate is probably the most intelligent.
A: Is that right?
response: B: But I also disagree with all his policies.

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet surfaces too.
A: Precisely, and because it's natural protein, it probably wouldn't be harmful to people like so many synthetic glues in use today.
response: B: Think of all the ways doctors and dentists could use such a glue, mending broken bones, fasting false teeth.

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
response: B: But I was told that arm exercises could drain your blood pressure.

dialogue: A: Are there other chores for us to do?
B: We also have to vacuum the house.
A: You used to do this by yourself?
B: You'd better believe it.
A: I'll do the second floor and you do the first floor.
response: B: No. You're going to do the neighbor's house.

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
B: But the money's not bad and there's plenty of fresh air.
A: If I were you, I'd take some kind of direction, like teaching law.
response: B: Teaching? Anything but that. It's so exhilarating.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
B: You're right. But I really had a happy vacation.
response: A: OK, Maybe you can move into Kelly's bathroom and share that with her for a couple of months.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
B: Buy an expensive suit.
response: A: Is a ski jacket OK?

dialogue: A: Hi, John! I'd like to invite you to dinner this evening.
B: To dinner? What for?
A: I have passed my driving test!
B: Congratulations! I'm really glad to hear that.
response: A: Thank you! I have been preparing for it for half a year, you know. And I've made it at last.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
response: B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.
A: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of strong and comfortable shoes.
B: What's your suggestion?
A: Maybe you should buy him a pair of leather shoes.
B: Tom doesn't like leather shoes.
response: A: Then, how about heels? They are strong and comfortable.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to remit 1,000 yuan to my sister in Shanghai.
A: Please fill out this form.
B: OK... Do I need to put on my sister's name for the receiver?
A: Yes. You must put on her name and address.
B: OK, I see. Here you are. Is that OK now?
response: A: Let me check . Yes . Your 1,000 remittance , please .

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few days after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?
response: B: Well, it doesn't hurt at all, doctor, especially when I eat.

dialogue: A: Have you booked the airplane tickets to spain yet?
B: Well, I thought we should go traveling by ship for a change, so I booked two ship tickets instead.
A: You should have told me or discussed it with me.
B: I wanted to give you a surprise. Don't you like the idea?
A: I like it all right, but it takes much more time to travel by ship than by plane.
response: B: We hardly have any time, don't we? Every time we went on a trip, we were always tied down by schedules. This time will be different. We will have to rush.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
response: B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Anything wrong?
B: I've been suffering from a fever since yesterday.
A: Do you have any other problems? Like a headache or cough?
B: No, I don't. I think it's only a fever.
response: A: Let me check... It's 39 degrees. I'll give you a hot towel to put on your face to keep warm.

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
A: So you could have made it. But you were still late for class.

B: The thing is, when I got off, I found I had left my bag in his car. And it was too late to get it back when I realized that. I went straight to the nearest shop and gave him a call. I waited for five minutes before Mr. Green drove back.
response: A: Finally, he gave you your bag and you came to the classroom and you were already 15 minutes late for class at that time. Is that all?

dialogue: A: Hello, Jane. This is Peter speaking.
B: Hi, how are you?
A: Fine. And I've got some great news for you.
B: Really? What's it about?
response: A: I remember you are interested in watching golf games. The Houston Open will be running from May 26 to May 30. I'm sure you will be glad to watch the game.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
response: B: No, but you can see that the point is bent a little bit.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
response: B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very lazy employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
response: B: First question: How often do you drive your car?

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.
A: Well, that's a good idea and you come to the right place. Do you know what you like?
B: Well, I don't want a racer or a touring bike or anything like that. Mostly I'll just be using it to get me back and forth from work.
A: How far is that?
B: About four miles.
A: Are there a lot of hills on the way?
B: Some, I guess. But maybe I should tell you at first that I only got 150 dollars. Can I get anything decent for that?
A: Well, you are not going to get anything on the top of the line. But we do have a few trade-ins in the back that are in good condition.
B: That sounds good.
response: A: And you are right. For the kind of ride you are going to be doing, the most important thing is toi be as uncomfortable as possible.  You want to make sure it's the right height for you? Follow me and I'll show you what we've got.

dialogue: A: What class did you have this afternoon, Kate?
B: A chemistry class. We've got a new chemistry teacher this term.
A: Who is it?
B: James Black. He told us to call Jim, not to call him Mr. Black.
A: Oh, James Black. I know him. He's a little thin man who smiles a lot.
B: Yes, but many of us are afraid of him.
response: A: Really? But I hear he's a very good teacher.

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
B: We thought we'd have that at head office and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.
A: Ok. What sort of things would you like?
response: B: Just a light lunch I think, so that people can eat while they move around and talk to each other. You did some thing similar for us last year. We'd be happy to have the same menu again.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
A: May I borrow your pen?
B: Here's a pen for you.
A: Thanks for your help.
response: B: You need to turn this in at Window B, and then they'll have you fill it out.

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
response: B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's a graduate course and I'm only a junior, but...
A: Aren't you a bit young? I've allowed qualified seniors to take the course and they usually have a hard time to keep up.
response: B: I know, but the geology of the American West is my least favorite subject and I've read almost nothing in the field. Last semester I took Professor Burman's course and I did find it challenging enough.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
response: B: I would like vegetable soup, please

dialogue: A: Why, Ann, I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been?
B: Bob, it has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year.
A: No. We talked at the Johnson's Christmas party last December. Don't you remember?
B: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the Germen company?
A: No. I changed my job about 4 months ago. I'm with the World Bank now. How about you?
B: I'm still working at the University, but I transferred from the German Department to the Spanish Department.
response: A: Don't you tell me you speak Spanish, too?

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
response: A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a dirty kitchen.

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
B: And the bike was run over by the car. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.
response: A: It was lucky that you didn't get hurt.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of beginning my own business.
A: That sounds great.
response: B: Yes, I think it over, but the problem is money. Even if I had enough money, I'd stay at the the bank.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: We'd like to take a tour to Florence.
A: That's a beautiful city. When do you want to go there?
B: We have got a 2 weeks ' vacation and we plan to leave on Thursday.
response: A: Then please don't look at the table , there are no plans .

dialogue: A: Are you free this evening, Li?
B: I ’ m afraid I ’ m busy tonight. I ’ m having dinner with friends.
A: What a pity. I wanted to go for a drink with you.
B: What about tomorrow? Are you doing anything tomorrow?
A: No, I haven ’ t got any plans.
response: B: Shall we go to work tomorrow then?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. White. I wonder if you could spare a few minutes. I'd like to ask you a few questions.
B: Well, I can spare you a few minutes, but I'm very busy preparing for our exhibition, you know.
A: Just a few questions. Where is it going to be held?
B: It's going to be held in the art gallery.
A: Who is opening it?
B: It's going to be opened by Mr.Smith.
A: It's quite a big exhibition, isn't it?
B: Quite big. Some very famous paintings will be shown.
A: I believe they're sent from different countries, aren't they?
response: B: Yes, that's right. Quite an international event for our town.

dialogue: A: Did you go out today?
B: With my bad luck? What good would it have done if I'd gone out?
A: If you'd looked for a job,you might have found one.
B: But I've been looking for one over a year. Today wouldn't have been any different.
A: I know how bad you feel, but if you don't keep on looking, you'll never get a job.
B: If I'd stayed in Puerto Rico in the first place, I wouldn't have had so much trouble.
A: What would you have done? There are more people out of work there than there are here.
response: B: I could have had a farm of my own if I'd stayed there.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
response: A: I sometimes take fruit with my ice cream, but that's all.

dialogue: A: Be careful.The floor is slippery.
B: Mom, there isn't any hot water
A: Turn on the shower.
response: B: I tried that. It's too warm.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
response: B: I caught hold of his knife, and pushed him to the floor.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
B: Yes, of course. Shall we give her some flowers?
response: A: Flowers are lovely. But I think it's better to buy her a nice box of hand guns.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Have you forgotten our drinks?
B: Sorry, I'll bring them to you right away.
A: Why is it taking so long?
B: We are short of staff today.
A: There is something wrong with this dish.
B: What's wrong?
A: I don't think this is fresh.
B: They were delivered this morning.
response: A: Would you please ask the doorman to come over ?

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
response: B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.

dialogue: A: ( Before Christmas Party ) Are you ready for the Christmas party tonight
B: Almost. I have to get dressed. It's a formal party and I have special party make up!
A: Use this lipstick and it will make your lips shine!
B: Great! Uh, remember that there's a gift exchange, too. We all have to bring a gift.
A: I've already got mine.
response: B: ( At the Party ) It's Christmas Day! Time to open presents!

dialogue: A: Hello, Jim. Where are you going?
B: To the cinema. What about coming with me?
A: No, thanks. I'm going home. My friend's expecting me.
B: What a pity! I believe it's a very good film.
A: Do you go to the cinema a lot?
B: Once a week. Most nights I sit at home and watch TV.
A: Oh, I see. By the way, where are you going for your holidays this year?
B: I don't know yet. My wife's going to her mother's for a couple of weeks. She lives by the sea, you know.
A: Oh, does she? That's convenient.
response: B: Yes, but I want to go to the moon.

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
A: I have to write you a ticket.
B: Can't you give me a warning?
A: I'm not going to be able to do that.
B: How much will the fine be?
response: A: You'll find that out at our restaurant date.

dialogue: A: Hello, Robert speaking.
B: Hi, it's Emma. I'm glad you're there. It's about our appointment on Wednesday morning. I'm afraid I can't make it now.
A: Oh, that's a shame.
B: I'm sorry. There was a change in my business partner's plan. And Wednesday is the only day she is able to see me.
response: A: That's okay. But we need to keep the same date.

dialogue: A: Why are you interested in our company?
B: Your company is world-famous. So, I think there will be better chances for persona development.
A: You're right. Do you think you have the qualifications for this job?
B: Sure. My qualifications meet your job description.
A: But you have no experience for this job.
B: That's true. But I am eager to learn, and also quick at learning.
response: A: Since you don't need further training, are you familiar with training salary?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you waiting to buy the concert tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: How long have you been here?
B: About 50 minutes. I've hardly moved forward in that time.
A: Are you kidding?
B: Not at all. There was a couple up ahead of me who got so fed up that they finally gave up and left. They said they'd been here for more than an hour.
A: My God. Does anyone know what's causing the delay?
B: It could be that there aren't enough people selling tickets this afternoon. Or maybe their computers break down.
A: I just hope they don't run out of tickets when I get up there.
response: B: That really would be pleasant, wouldn't it?

dialogue: A: Dr Stone, how did you become an expert on smell?

B: Well, I didn't intend to in the first place. But when I was in university, there was a course on senses. The other senses seem to be more concrete somehow, but smell is so personal. I found it extremely interesting.
A: Do you have any interesting information to give us about smells?

B: Well, let's see. Did you know that it's harder to forget smells than to forget facts? There have been experiments where people could pick out a particular smell thirty days after smelling it for the first time.
response: A: Really? So smells can bring back more memories than, say, music?

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
response: B: Uh, actually, you were punctual with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
response: B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's a graduate course and I'm only a junior, but...

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.
A: Well, Mr Strunk, I enjoy my work very much.
response: B: To show that I appreciate all your efforts, I'm going to demote you. I hope you don't object.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
response: B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
B: I caught hold of his knife, and he pushed me to the floor.
A: Oh, no! Why did you catch hold of his knife? That's dangerous.
B: I don't know. I didn't think.
A: And what did the other passengers do? Did they help you?
response: B: Yes, they did. Two men ran after the robber and helped him escape.

dialogue: A: We want to take a train to New York.
B: Regular or express train?
A: How much time would I save if we took the express?
B: About one hour. The next express train arrives in New York at 3:15.
A: And how much more do I have to pay for the express?
B: First class is 24 dollars more, and second class is 15 dollars more.
response: A: As long as we can arrive one hour earlier, I don't mind paying a little extra. Then give me one second class ticket on the express, please.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
A: So it doesn't really hold your interest?
response: B: No, not really. I wouldn't bother with it, to be honest, but I have to read it for fun. I'm at a university.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
response: B: I can't, I am going crazy now.

dialogue: A: Did you hear the news?
B: What happened?
A: Our cousin went into labor and had her baby last week.
B: She did? Why didn't anyone tell me?
A: I would've thought that somebody would have told you.
B: No, I had no idea.
A: Well, she did, her baby was 8 pounds 6 ounces.
B: Oh my God, that's great!
response: A: Are you going to go and visit her and the baby?

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
B: You had pretty bad scores.
A: Exactly what do you mean by bad?
B: You failed.
A: How'd I fail it?
B: There are a couple of reasons why you didn't pass.
A: What did I do wrong?
response: B: To sum it all up, you really just don't know how to dance.

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
response: B: Will you buy an library book for me?

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
response: A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a typo.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
response: B: Oh! I'm glad to hear that. What kind of problems were solved?

dialogue: A: Gosh! The water faucet is dripping badly again.
B: You are going to have a huge bill.
A: I know. I ’ Ve got to get it fixed ASAP.
B: Don't you wanna get it fixed now?
A: I wish I could, but I ’ Ve got to go now. I have an appointment in 20 minutes.
B: Well, if you need anything, just let me know.
A: Oh, by the way, could you give me a ride? My car is still in the garage.
response: B: You sure have incredible luck these days .

dialogue: A: Are you ready to move?
B: Definitely. I Ve got the hell out of the company. Anything new?
A: Yes, but there is a chance that might be suitable for you.
B: Really? Are you willing to recommend me for the position?
A: I can't say, but let me make a call and see if I can help.
response: B: I appreciate the apathy, sir.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Have you forgotten our drinks?
B: Sorry, I'll bring them to you right away.
A: Why is it taking so long?
B: We are short of staff today.
A: There is something wrong with this dish.
B: What's wrong?
A: I don't think this is fresh.
response: B: They were delivered this morning .

dialogue: A: Caroline Menzies speaking.
B: Could I speak to Diana Curzon?
A: I'm afraid she's in a meeting at the moment. Who's speaking?
B: This is John Laing from Dantons.
A: Can I take a message, Mr Laing?
B: Yes, please. I'm actually returning her call. So perhaps you could tell her that I called.
response: A: Certainly. Does she have your number?

dialogue: A: Hi, Mark. Are you in town for another job interview?
B: Yes, I'm pretty hopeful this time. I've just finished my second interview with this company.
A: That sounds great. I hope it works out for you. But wasn't it expensive just getting here?
B: No, in fact the company is paying all my expenses. They've put me up in a hotel downtown.
A: How nice! How many people are they interviewing?
B: They interviewed 16 the first time, and now four of us were chosen to go back for this interview.
A: Well, I hope it goes well. John and I would love it if you came to this area to work.
response: B: I would too. And my girlfriend is excited to leave her family. She hopes I find a job close to home.

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
response: B: But I don't have a car and I can't drive. Is there any other way to travel?

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
response: B: He works from home. He never writes letters or reports, or types.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
B: I'd like her to have a change.
response: A: Then how do you like this expensive one ?

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
response: B: I'm not planning to attend a conference on air pollution.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. What can I do for you?
A: I'd like a ticket to New York, please.
B: Round trip?
response: A: No, one way.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
response: A: Yes, they spent about five hours fanning the flames. Hm, what a strange smell!

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
response: B: I thought she'd be angry.

dialogue: A: What do you usually do in your spare time?
B: I have joined a singing group and we practice two afternoons each week.
A: That's a very interesting thing to do.
response: B: Yes. It's a small group of only fifteen girls and boys. But nobody has been late for the practice.

dialogue: A: What class did you have this afternoon, Kate?
B: A chemistry class. We've got a new chemistry teacher this term.
A: Who is it?
B: James Black. He told us to call Jim, not to call him Mr. Black.
A: Oh, James Black. I know him. He's a little thin man who smiles a lot.
B: Yes, but many of us are afraid of him.
A: Really? But I hear he's a very good teacher.
B: Yes, he is. His classes are always lively and interesting. And we all watch and listen to him very carefully in his class.
A: It's important to watch carefully when you're studying chemistry, I think.
response: B: Jim often says that too, So we are always allowed to do anything without watching.

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
response: A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
B: How about some fresh fruit?
response: A: We don't have any fresh fruit today. All we have now is chocolate cake.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
B: I hope I could get a reception at the White House some time.
response: A: Well, if you do something idiotic when you grow up, maybe you will. Who knows?

dialogue: A: Are you cold?
B: Yes, a little.
A: I wonder if we can change the temperature.
B: I tried before. There are no buttons on the air conditioning.
A: There must be buttons. How do they turn it on and off?
response: B: I think it is centrally controlled. They control it at the air conditioning buttons.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.
response: B: No, I think we must have imagined them. They must have heard us coming and got out of the bathroom window quickly.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
response: A: I have a really big geography fear and I have to study for it.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?

A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in a bit too much specialized information.
response: B: The main thing I object to is the straightforward direction.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.
response: A: I understand how you keep on with it.  It's so easy to become a doctor.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
B: I haven't been eating like I usually do. Usually, I love my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt cooking and I've eaten very little. Most unlike me.
A: Have you been to the doctor? What did she say?
B: I didn't bother going to the doctor. It's nothing serious.
response: A: You never know. If you've been feeling like this for two weeks, it's worth getting a check-up just to be sure.

dialogue: A: Today in the studio we have Alberto Cortez, the well-known Brazilian advocate of the anti-global movement. He's here to talk about the recent report, stating that by 2050 Brazil will be the one ot the word's wealthiest and most successful countries. Alberto, what do you say to the report?
B: You know this isn't the first time that people are saying Brazil will be a great economic power. The same thing was said over a hundred year ago. But it didn't happen.
A: Yes, but you must admit the world's a very different place now.
B: Of course. In fact I believe there's maybe some truth in the prediction this time around. First of all, though, we must remember the problems facing Brazil at the moment.
A: Such as...?

B: There's an enormous gap between the rich and the poor in this country. In Sal Paulo, you can see shopping malls full of designer goods right next door to the slam areas without proper water and electricity supplies. A lot of work needs to be done to help people in those areas improve their lives.
A: What needs to be done?
response: B: Education, for example. For Singapore to be successful, we need to offer education to all Singaporeans. Successful countries like South Korea and Brazil have excellent education systems. Singapore needs to learn from these countries.

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
B: Well, there's a coffee shop on the next corner. It serves good food.
A: OK. I'll try it. Can I get you something?
response: B: No, I think I'll come with you. I'm longing for a big tip.

dialogue: A: Hi, why do you look so depressed today, Mike?
B: I had a terrible quarrel with my neighbor yesterday.
A: How come?
B: It is a long story. Basically, she thought I had laughed at her while I didn't.
A: I know everyone suffers when he is misunderstood. But why not take it easy?
response: B: Yeah . It's so nice of you to comfort me .

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
response: B: I'm sorry, but I don't sell tickets. You can get one from the machine over there.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
B: I'm an English major and this is a required course. But now I'm in trouble because I'm not sure I can afford this book.
response: A: Hey, I've got an idea.  Why don't you cover the cost and share the book with me?

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: Yes, my nephew Jim is graduating from college next week and I'd like to get him a nice gift.
A: What price are you interested in? We'll need toknow that before we begin looking.
B: Well. I usually spend about twenty do Ham for a gift. Do you have anything nice for that price?
A: How about a pen?
response: B: No, my brother gave me that for my bithday last year.

dialogue: A: Any messages, Miss Grey?
B: Just one, Mr. Blank. You had a telephone call from someone called Brown, David Brown.
A: Brown? I don't seem to know anyone called Brown. What did he say?
response: B: He wouldn't say. But it sounded important. I told him you'd phone him as soon as you got back.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
response: A: However,you must show us the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
response: B: Yes, I do. It made me laugh a lot.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir.
B: Good morning.
A: How do you want it, sir?
B: Just take a little off on the top and shorten the back. But please don't make it too short.
A: How about your sideburns?
response: B: Just to the bottom of my feet . By the way , I'd like a shave , too .

dialogue: A: Hello, School of English Studies.
B: Hello, I saw your advertisement in the newspaper. Can you give me some information, please?
A: Yes, of course. What would you like to know?
B: Well, first, how long are the courses?
A: They are 6 or 9 months long and the next course begins next Monday.
B: How many students will there be in the class? Not too many, I hope.
A: Usually, there are 15. We find that a good number.
response: B: OK. Now, I saw the price of the course in the newspaper, but will I have to see anything else?

dialogue: A: Hey Jane, where are you going this weekend?
B: Hi, Bob. I'm going to the beach. 13o you want to come too?
A: Yes, that sounds like fun. Which beach are you going to?
response: B: I was thinking of going to Huangdao's Beach. I never see any sea birds or wildlife there.

dialogue: A: Come back. You haven't paid yet.
B: May, just let him go.
A: But he took some newspaper away without paying.
B: I know.
A: Why? You make me confused.
B: He lives nearby and he would just glance at the newspaper headlines, read the political sections and return them later.
A: Why does he have such a privilege?
B: He used to be a hero during the war time and everyone respect him.
A: I see. Does he live by himself?
response: B: No, he has children and married his wife when he was in the battle.

dialogue: A: Waiter, can we have the bill please?
B: Yes, madam. How will you pay for it, with cash or credit card,please?
A: With my Visa Card.
response: B: I'm awfully sorry, madam. But we only accept Visa cards.

dialogue: A: Do you feel like going to the cinema?
B: Oh, yes. What kind of films do you like?

A: Well, I like all sorts of films, but my favorite sorts are those like Star Wars. You know, the fantasy, special effect ones that you can escape into another world. I also like mystery film, do you like mystery films?
B: Yes, but I don't like horror films because they really give me nightmares.
A: I don't like horror films either. They're sort of stupid and unbelievable. I do like crime films, you know, where you can follow the detective and try to guess who the murderer is.
B: What about a comedy or musical?
A: No, I'm not interested.
B: What about ringing up the ABC and find out what's on? Then we can decide.
response: A: OK. That's definitely the best thing we ought to do because I haven't got an evening paper.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
response: A: May I borrow your pen?

dialogue: A: Have you seen the job in the newspaper?
B: Do you mean the one in Manchester?
A: Yes.
B: I saw it just now.
A: What do you think of it?
B: I think I'm not the type of man to do it.
A: Why do you think so?
B: They need an engineer to take care of the machine and I don't even know anything about that kind of machine.
A: I know you are always quick to learn. I believe when you use it you will get to know it well.
B: Are you serious about that?
response: A: Sure I am. You should have a try.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.
B: No, I think we must have disturbed them. They must have heard us coming and got out of the bathroom window quickly.
response: A: Yes, well, hurry up. We'd better phone the pizza place

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.

B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were even for sale. The last one was on sale for $9,000.
response: A: $9,000? Well, I may go and visit the exhibition tomorrow, but I'm not going to sell anything.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
response: B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a white house. The General Reading Room is miles from it.

dialogue: A: Hello, Steven. Can you do me a favor?
B: Sure. What is it?
A: My car has broken down.
B: You should telephone the garage for help.
response: A: I have done it . But now I have an urgent appointment to keep . Could you drive me to the subway station ?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you happen to have a gym here?
B: Yes, sir. I think you'll find our gym quite satisfactory.
A: So, where do I go to exercise?
B: It's only one flight down, sir. Just take the elevator or the stairs.
A: Am I going to be charged extra for using the gym?
