response: B: Sir, you can use the gym for free. All you need is your room key.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy the restaurant?
B: I didn't really like it all that much.
A: What do you think the problem was?
B: Well, they are pretty new. I just didn't feel that they were ready to open yet.
A: How did you feel about the food?
B: The food wasn't all that exciting.
response: A: I think that the service was good, too.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
response: A: And what would you like to have for the main course before that?

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
response: B: We are looking for buying a whole hotel. Are there any hotels near here?

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
response: B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.

dialogue: A: ABC company. Can I help you?
B: Can you put me through to Mr Brown in the Sales Department?
A: I'm afraid Mr Brown is at a meeting at the moment.
B: Can I leave a message?
A: Certainly.
response: B: Can you ask Mr Brown to call me at 1300-621-7865?

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
response: B: I need to review my English.

dialogue: A: Did you hear about the air crash that occurred in South America recently? It was quite a tragic accident!
B: No, I didn't see anything in the news about it. What happened?
A: A foreign airliner was attempting to land at night in a mountainous area in Argentina and flew into a hill!
B: That sounds really terrible! Did anyone survive?
response: A: Everyone aboard, including the crew, was released without injury instantly.

dialogue: A: Hello, Michelle. How are you feeling today?
B: Hi, Dr. Frank. I am not feeling very well. That is why I made an appointment with you.
A: I am sorry to hear that. What seems to be the trouble?
response: B: My head has been hurting a lot lately. I never used to feel like this.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
response: B: if you are working this week, you may qualify

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
A: Nobody to take care of her?
response: B: My mother travels a lot to many countries and she is doing business in Dubai now. I have to do nothing for my mom at home.

dialogue: A: Are you all right, Mark? Is anything wrong?
B: I'm so homesick, I could die. All this studying, all this pressure, I just can't stand it.
A: It takes time to get used to all this.
B: Yes. But, you know, I lost sleep last night.
A: It seems like you've really got the blues. Have you heard from home recently?
B: It's been almost a month since I got a letter from my mum. I'm going to write to her and explain the situation. By the way, do you have an envelope that I can borrow?
A: Sorry, I don't have any. I hardly ever send any letters.
B: The bookstore is closed today. Is there another place I can get some stamps?
response: A: You can go to the laundry on North Street to buy stamps.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
A: Let me ask the old woman in that reception office.
B: She can't answer you.
response: A: She must be deaf .

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
B: But I didn't hear it at all.
A: What time did you set it for last night?
B: Six o'clock.
A: Hurry up, or you'll be late for school. Are you feeling ill?
response: B: No. I'm only sleepy because I stayed asleep the whole night.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
response: B: I'm so glad we're in the middle of summertime. I like autumn best.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
B: Buy an expensive suit.
response: A: Is a white cape and no pants ok?

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
response: B: That sounds delightful.  I'm sure you are going to be OK.

dialogue: A: What time do you usually get up in the morning?
B: I sleep in every morning, sometimes until 11 or 12.
A: Are you serious? I get up at 5 every morning to go to the gym, and then I get to work around 7.
B: Well, I work from home, so I can set my own hours. I usually work until midnight or 1 in the morning, and then I like to sleep in.
response: A: I like to be in bed around 9 or 10 at night so I can get enough sleep. Our schedules are very different! You're unlucky that you get to set your own schedule, but I could never sleep that late. I'm definitely a morning person.

dialogue: A: Are you cold?
B: Yes, a little.
A: I wonder if we can change the temperature.
B: I tried before. There are no buttons on the air conditioning.
A: There must be buttons. How do they turn it on and off?
B: I think it is centrally controlled. They control it at the main desk.
A: Well, they have it too cold in here. I want to be warmer. I won't be able to sleep.
B: I'm going downstairs for more drinking water. I will ask them.
A: What did they say about the air conditioning?
response: B: They said it is centrally controlled. All the rooms are different. They can't change it.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
response: A: And you have a headache now?

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
response: B: She's very fond of pornographic stories ?

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
B: Well, I've been working a lot lately... more than 11 hours a day.
A: Maybe you should take a vacation and just rest for a few days.
B: Well, I can't right now. We're in the middle of some important business.
response: A: Yes, I understand, but you really need to pick up the pace. You're going to kill yourself if you go on like this.

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
response: B: I was well. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of bed.

dialogue: A: Hello! Do you have a place where I can exercise?
B: Yes, sir. We have a fine exercise facility.
A: I'm happy to hear that. Now, would you tell me where it is?
B: You're actually standing above it. Just take the elevator or stairs down one level.
A: Is the hotel going to charge me a dollar a minute for gym use?
B: No, sir. There's no extra charge. All you need is your room key to open the door.
A: And the gym hours are?
B: Sir, you'll be pleased to know that our gym never closes.
response: A: One more question, do you have a lawyer?

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
response: B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to put it away, though, but I keep drifting back in.

dialogue: A: What class did you have this afternoon, Kate?
B: A chemistry class. We've got a new chemistry teacher this term.
A: Who is it?
B: James Black. He told us to call Jim, not to call him Mr. Black.
A: Oh, James Black. I know him. He's a little thin man who smiles a lot.
B: Yes, but many of us are afraid of him.
A: Really? But I hear he's a very good teacher.
response: B: Yes, he is. His classes are always lively and interesting. And we all watch and listen to him very carefully in his class.

dialogue: A: Ann, let's go, or we will be late.
B: What time is it?
A: It is already 10:25.
B: Well, we still have about 15 minutes.
A: What time did you say the train is leaving?
B: 12:05. And it takes only 20 minutes to get to the station by bus.
A: Yes, but what will happen if the bus is late?
B: Relax, those buses run every 10 minutes, so we have plenty of time.
A: ( still on the bus. ) What time is it?
B: It is a quarter to twelve.
response: A: Oh dear, we will miss our train.

dialogue: A: Excuse me,can I see the personnel manager? My name is Lucy Jordan.
B: Oh, yes. Have a scat, please.
A: Thank you. I come in answer to your ad for the saleswoman.
B: Okay, what qualifications do you have for the toy store work?
response: A: I never worked in a local toy store and my major is business administration.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I'd like to pay my bill.
A: OK. In cash or by credit?
B: In cash. How much is the total charge?
response: A: Five hundred and thirty yuan altogether excluding charges for service .

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.
A: That's exactly why I want to borrow your notes. My notes aren't very good.
B: So what do you usually do in class?
response: A: I'm always awake at the beginning, but thirty minutes after class begins I feel even more recharged and have no trouble keeping my eyes open.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
response: A: Why is a computer so useful?

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
B: How about some fresh fruit?
A: We don't have any fresh fruit today. All we have now is chocolate cake.
response: B: Then I just have a bucket of coffee, please.

dialogue: A: What are your hobbies, Mr. Green?
B: I like collecting stamps.
A: But it's an expensive hobby, isn't it?
B: Yes, you're right. What do you like to do in your spare time?
A: I usually play chess with my friends. But I like playing basketball best.
B: Do you play basketball well?
response: A: No, I'm not very good at it. I play competitively.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
A: If I were you, I'd say sorry to her first and then get her another cat.
B: That's a good idea. But I don't have.., enough money.
response: A: Oh, don't worry. I've got some. I can lend some to you.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
response: B: Many customers wanted them.

dialogue: A: You're going to wear out that typewriter.
B: Oh, hi. What are you doing here at this time of night?
A: I should ask you that question. Do you have any idea what time it is?
B: About ten or ten-thirty?
A: It's nearly midnight.
B: Really? I didn't have any idea it was so late.
A: Don't you have an early class tomorrow morning?
B: Yes, at seven o'clock. My part-time class, for the students who go to work right after their lesson.
response: A: Then you ought to go to bed.

dialogue: A: Bob, did you see our supervisor? I need him to sign this paper.
B: He is in his office, but you'd better choose your words carefully while talking to him.
A: What's up?
response: B: Nothing. But he is in a bad mood today.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
response: B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.
response: B: I definitely can. My boss just did me a favor by putting me on evenings. And he'll hit the ceiling if I ask to change again.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve about British culture.
A: Professor Grand's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person coming in asking for those articles.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matterwhich one you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're joking, all of them?

A: Every month. I've asked professor Grand twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for those same articles to be returned.
B: And here's me. I went out of my way to free out the whole afternoon to read.
response: A: I'm sorry, but there is not a whole lot I can do about it. All I can suggest is that you come in first thing tomorrow morning and completely give up. We open at eight.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
response: B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.

dialogue: A: Acknowledgments play a necessary part in the interview.
B: Sure. Kind acknowledgments can show one's good attainment.
A: We often ignore the acknowledgments in our daily life, and consider them as disposable.
B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a good impression on others, especially in the public places.
A: We should particularly pay attention to acknowledgments in the interview.
B: In the beginning of the interview, it is best that you make acknowledgments for the opportunity of the interview.
A: Don't forget to say " Thank you " when you take a seat.
B: Make acknowledgments as well when the interviewer thinks highly of your dressing, experience, or words.
A: You can win a good impression of the interviewer in this way.
B: Acknowledgments can also help the job-hunters to show their good attainment.
A: Finally, at the end of the interview, make acknowledgments to the interviewer again.
response: B: Smiles and kind attitudes are no substitute for acknowledgments.

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
B: We thought we'd have that at head office and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.
A: Ok. What sort of things would you like?
B: Just a light lunch I think, so that people can eat while they move around and talk to each other. You did some thing similar for us last year. We'd be happy to have the same menu again.
A: Right. I'll look at my diary and see what you had last time. Oh, I nearly forgot to ask you how many should I cater for?
B: Well, I think most people will be able to come, perhaps around 30. No, let's say 35, to be sure.
response: A: Right, thank you for getting in touch, Mr. Smith. I'll send you confirmation of the payments by the end of this week.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.
A: In what ways? What has she done?
B: Oh, no, you don't really want to hear it.
A: Come on. I am a mother of two girls.
B: Ok. I'm worried because she often hides in her room and sends messages to her friends.
response: A: Come on. It's not a big deal. She needs friends at this age. You can talk with her if you are really concerned.

dialogue: A: I hear you're going home, aren't you?
B: I wanted to go on Monday, but I couldn't get a ticket for Monday, I bought a ticket for Tuesday.
A: Why are you in such a hurry?
response: B: My mother is not ill. She has been driving past the hospital.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.

B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?
response: A: Well, no. I don't think I would. I bet it costs very little money. Does it say how much it costs?

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.
response: B: I wish I could. My boss just did me a favor by putting me on evenings. And he'll hit the ceiling if I ask to change again.

dialogue: A: By the way, would you like to go to the movies this evening?
B: I'd love to. But I must write some emails.
A: Why tonight?
B: I haven't written to anyone for months. Sylvia and John must think I've forgotten them.
A: You don't have to write. You can call them tomorrow. It's half price on Sundays.
B: Yes, I could, couldn't I? All right. I'll do that. What's playing then?
A: Let's see. Here we are. The Columbia: In the World. A must for all teenagers.
B: No, thank you!
A: Central: Children's World. All parents of teenage children ought to see this picture.
B: There must be something worth seeing somewhere.
A: What about this? John Wayne in Texas, Here I Come.
B: I can't stand Westerns.
response: A: Neither can I. Listen, Joan. I've got a better idea...

dialogue: A: Hello, I am calling about my cable service.
B: What's the problem?
A: For the past week my cable hasn't been working.
B: I apologize, but the cable has been down lately.
A: Do you know when it is going to start working again?
response: B: Give it a couple days , and it should be back on .

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
B: They really started looting?
A: Yes, apparently four stores were broken into.
response: B: I hope the looters made it out without getting caught.

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
B: But you should pay special attention to your words and attitudes.
A: In the beginning of the interview, greet the interviewer with a kind smile.
B: In the interview, use polite words, such as ' Thank you ', or ' Please '.
A: That's right. Details can mean succeed or fail.
B: When talking you should focus your eyes on the interviewer in order to closely watch his or her expressions.
A: At the end of the interview, you should make your acknowledgements and say Goode.
B: Whatever the result is, you should keep your good demeanor.
response: A: Only in this way can you leave a good impression on the interviewer .

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Are you waiting to buy today's film tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: Have you been here long?
B: About 45 minutes. I've moved forward a total about 3 feet.
A: Oh...
B: Not at all. A young couple who have been waited for one hour ahead of me finally gave up and left.
A: Does anyone know what caused the delay?
B: There are just not enough people selling tickets this afternoon.
A: I guess I should have come before lunch.
response: B: Maybe you would meet the same thing because many people have been looking forward to it for a long time.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
A: How awful! Was he hurt?
B: Yes. He was taken to the hospital in an ambulance.
A: How did it happen?
B: His car was hit by an express train. It happened at the crossing just behind his house.
A: How horrible!
response: B: He ’ s having a celebration in the hospital now . Poor Hilda ! You can imagine how unhappy she is

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Do you have a reservation?
B: Yes. My name is Charles.
A: I see. We have a window table reserved for you.
B: It's very kind of you.
A: Would you like to order now or wait for a while?
response: B: Bring me the receipt , please .

dialogue: A: Good afternoon! Dr. Perkins' office.
B: Good afternoon. I'd like to speak to the doctor. Is he in?
A: Who is that calling, please?
B: My name is Li Hong. I'm from China.
A: I'm sorry. Dr. Perkins is now at an important meeting and can't answer your call.
B: I'm an exchange scholar. Dr. Perkins asked me to give a lecture. There are some details I want to discuss with him.
A: I see, but you must speak to himself about that. Oh, well, if you leave your number, I'll tell him to ring you as soon as he is available.
response: B: Thanks. My number is 7838298.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
A: No, that's fine. Do you bring your bankbook with you?
response: B: Yes , I do . Here it is , and the cash .

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
B: But I was told that arm exercises could raise your blood pressure.
A: Yes, but the article I read suggests some ways to make up for that.
B: Really? How?
A: By adding leg exercises, so that the arms don't do all the work.
B: And in return, I'm sure that there's a good chance of losing weight.
A: Sounds right to me.
B: So what exercises do the experts suggest?
response: A: They mentioned quite a few exercises, but one of the most popular ones is cycling.

dialogue: A: What are you doing here?
B: I'm preparing my fishing tools.
A: What for?
response: B: I'm going to make s'mores with some of my friends.

dialogue: A: Hello, Robert speaking.
B: Hi, it's Emma. I'm glad you're there. It's about our appointment on Wednesday morning. I'm afraid I can't make it now.
A: Oh, that's a shame.
B: I'm sorry. There was a change in my business partner's plan. And Wednesday is the only day she is able to see me.
response: A: That's okay. But we need to find another location.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I need a new identification card.
A: Why?
response: B: My ID card is lost .

dialogue: A: What are you grinning about?
B: Stephany said she would go out with me.
A: I thought mom said no dating till you are 16.
B: That ’ s in one month, and besides, this is a group date with all of our friends.
A: All of your friends, what are you planning to do?
response: B: We ’ re going fishing .

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
response: B: I hope I could get a reception at the zoo some time.

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
response: B: And the bike was run over by the car. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.
A: That's exactly why I want to borrow your notes. My notes aren't very good.
B: So what do you usually do in class?
A: I'm always awake at the beginning, but thirty minutes after class begins I feel sleepy and have trouble keeping my eyes open.
B: Well, I need someone to study with and you need someone to keep you awake. Can we be study partners?
response: A: Oh sure. That's a good idea. So give me a dollar when you see me sleeping in class.

dialogue: A: Bonjour!
B: What?
A: I said, Bonjour!
B: What ’ s wrong with you, Ted?
A: I ’ m speaking French. Don ’ t you know anything?
B: What ’ s wrong with speaking English?
response: A: Well, I just got back from England. We have to speak French all day there. No English allowed!

dialogue: A: Are you free this Saturday evening?
B: Oh, it seems there is nothing that evening.
A: Would you like to go to the concert with me?
response: B: I wouldn't like to, where should we meet?

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
B: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
response: A: No , please , Mom ! Don't make me go to the pharmacy !

dialogue: A: Hi, Nicole. Did you have a good weekend?
B: Yes, I did. But I feel tired today.
A: Really? Why?
B: Well, on Saturday I cleaned the house and played tennis. Then on Sunday I hiked in the country.
A: And I bet you studied, too.
B: Yeah. I studied on Sunday evening. What about you?
A: Well, I didn't clean the house and I didn't study. I stayed in bed and watched TV.
B: That sounds like fun, but did you exercise?
response: A: Sort of. I took a nap.

dialogue: A: Are you a happy married man?
B: Yes, I am. My wife and I understand each other.
A: You are a lucky man. How about Mr. Smith.
B: I don't know. But they say that Mrs. Smith wears the pants in the house.
A: You mean she bosses her husband around?
response: B: That's right. She is pretty, but she wants to share everything in his life.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that Susan got married?
B: Really? I remember she said if she would remain single. Is the man very rich?
A: No. That ’ s what is surprising me.
B: You means she didn ’ t marry a rich man.
response: A: He's a postman who has a wealthy family.

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
A: You must be mad. I think it's really...you know...so easy to buy everything in one place.
B: Yes, it's easy. But don't you think the food isn't...I mean small shops usually have much fresher food.
A: Maybe, but you pay for it. Small shops are more expensive, aren't they?
response: B: Yes, I agree with you, but supermarket staff are badly paid and they are really...but you get better service in small shops. They are much more friendly.

dialogue: A: Are you through with your meal?
B: Yes, we are. Could we have the check, please?
A: Here is your check, 86 dollars in all. Can I take care of it here when you are ready?
B: Do you accept checks?
A: No, I'm sorry we don't. We accept credit cards and cash.
B: Well, I don't have any cash with me, so I ’ ll have to put it on credit.
A: I'll be right back.
B: Ok, please wait a minute. Can I have my food packaged?
response: A: I see. I'll bring some to-go boxes for you.

dialogue: A: Dad, what are we doing tonight for fun?
B: We're going over to Mrs. Smith's place to help her with her yard work.
A: Yard work? I said ' what are we doing for fun ', not work!
B: It will be fun. And besides, you'll be in the best company.
A: Dad. You're so cute. What do I need to do to help get ready?
response: B: You could get the receipts for rakes and some shovels together and I'll put them in the car.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some gloves.
A: All our gloves are here. What do you think of this pair here? It's made of silk.
B: Hm, it looks nice, but I'd like to have something warm for the winter.
response: A: Maybe you would like light flimsy gloves. How about this pair?

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some gloves.
A: All our gloves are here. What do you think of this pair here? It's made of silk.
B: Hm, it looks nice, but I'd like to have something warm for the winter.
response: A: Maybe you would like heavy wool gloves. How about this pair?

dialogue: A: Tom, as the manager of a company selling green products, you are now quite a successful businessman. When did you know you wanted to have your own company?

B: My family left Budapest in 1986 and settled in Canada where a lot of my friends' parents were highly successful businessmen. It seems so cool, so in high school, I started a web-designed company and learned a lot from that experience.
A: How did you find the money for your present company then?
B: We've raised 18 million dollars from about 50 people. We're finally making money. I own 6% of the company and all employees get their shares.
A: By the way, what aspects of your life are green?
response: B: I'm only mildly green. I do simple things and I'm a huge biker. I biked cross Canada.

dialogue: A: Are you being served, sir?
B: I'd like to buy a tapestry to decorate my new room.
A: Artistic tapestry is the highest expression form of the rug weaving art. How about these ones?
B: These are beautiful! Is this the marvelous landscape in Guiling?
A: Yes, sir.
B: How fine the needlework is! What's the price?
A: Ninety dollars.
B: It's too expensive.
A: But considering the fine craftsmanship it is worth much more.
response: B: You're right. Would you please show me some weavers' biographies? I also want to buy some articles to justify the price.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
response: B: Oh, it was my mother's - my grandmother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
response: A: I'm assuming you got back home very early?

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
response: B: Then, you should dress well more casually.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
response: A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
B: I did. I called you many times, but you had your mobile phone power off.
A: Oh, I didn't bring it with me because I left it recharging at home.
response: B: I'm really sorry to have missed the film.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve in the library for anthropology 311.
A: Professor Gilers's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matter which one of them you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're kidding all of them?
response: A: I've asked professor Gilers twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them in the library's lost and found than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for these same articles to be returned.

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
B: But I was told that arm exercises could raise your blood pressure.
A: Yes, but the article I read suggests some ways to make up for that.
B: Really? How?
response: A: By adding arm curls and shoulder presses, so that the arms do more of the work.

dialogue: A: My mother got really annoyed with my father yesterday evening.
B: Why? Did she complain about his cooking?
A: Oh no. It was about watching television.
B: Don't tell me he fell asleep in front of the television.
response: A: No, he kept changing channels on the guitar.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
response: B: I'm a Physics major and this is a required course. But now I'm in trouble because I'm not sure I can afford this book.

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
A: Actually, it'll save you money.
B: Oh, really?
A: Because you can use your bus pass as many times as you want.
B: Really?
response: A: Yeah, but you still have to worry about scraping for change.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
response: A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some musical notes. Where is it?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. but I think you made a wrong turn. You are supposed to turn left on Rosen Boulevard.
B: Oh. I'm sorry. Didn't you say 1323 Willson?
A: No, 3023. It's OK though. You don't have to take me there, I can walk from here.
B: Why don't I just make a U turn at the corner?
A: Well, you shouldn't make a U turn there. It's the one-way, street. See the sign up the head?
B: Well, maybe if I turn left here I can comedown the next street,
response: A: You can't do that either during the slow hour. Really though, don't go to any trouble. Sometimes one can wait 30 minutes for a taxi. So I'm happy to get this close,

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
response: B: I guess ate a delicious meal at lunch.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
response: A: Then the truck went right past the taxi did it?

dialogue: A: How come David is always so full of energy?
B: He has a strange but highly effective way of sleeping.
A: What is that?
response: B: He takes a short sleep for an hour every six hours and has a total of four hours of sleep each day.

dialogue: A: My mother got really annoyed with my father yesterday evening.
B: Why? Did she complain about his cooking?
A: Oh no. It was about watching television.
response: B: Don't tell me he fell asleep in front of the refrigerator.

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
B: You did? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered.
A: Oh, the telephone lines were damaged by the storm. They repaired them yesterday.
B: What did David do yesterday? Did he and Judy go dancing?
A: No, they stayed home and played cards with the children.
B: And what did you do? Did you play cards, too?
response: A: No . I played cards and studied , what did you do yesterday , Donald ?

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
response: B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll start my project!

dialogue: A: Excuse me, sir, could you tell me how I can get to the railway station?
B: Sorry, I don't understand. I can speak little English.
A: Do you speak German?
B: No, I don't.
A: What is your first language, French or Spanish?
B: Spanish is my mother language. I am not good at speaking English.
A: But I think your English is very good.
response: B: I don't think so. I can speak some sophisticated words and expressions.

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
response: B: On the second line, you write the email address you are sending it to. Good, like that.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. White. I wonder if you could spare a few minutes. I'd like to ask you a few questions.
B: Well, I can spare you a few minutes, but I'm very busy preparing for our exhibition, you know.
A: Just a few questions. Where is it going to be held?
response: B: It's going to be held in the art gallery.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
response: B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on to impress and entertain me.

dialogue: A: Hello? I would like to speak to Mr. Lee.
B: This is Lee speaking.
A: This is Linda, your old friend.
B: Oh, how are you, Linda? I'm glad you called.
A: Mr. Smith wrote to me that you were coming to our city. May I see you at your hotel right away?
response: B: Please hold on a moment. I have to ask my grandma. Yes, that's all rght.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam.
B: Good morning. I wonder if you can help. I've lost my coat.
A: Where did you lose it, madam?
B: Er... I left it on a bus yesterday morning.
A: Can you describe it? Is it a raincoat?
response: B: No. It's a long white overcoat. It's got a belt, and one of those thick furry collars that keep your ears warm. It's a very nice coat, actually.

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.
A: Well whatever, can we repeat our offer to run the campaign for 4 extra weeks?

B: That's not really the point. The campaign missed two key trade affairs. Because of this, we are asking you either to repeat the campaign next year for free, or we only pay 50% of the fee for this year.
A: Could we suggest a 20% reduction to the fee together with the four week sustention to the campaign.
response: B: We are not happy. We lost business.

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
A: No, I don't. I mean a general practitioner. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.
B: Really, I believe I can quit on my own. But I'll think about it. I will.
A: All fight. I won't mention it for a week. Then I want to know your decision. Because if you don't get some help, I need to rethink our plans.
response: B: You mean you'd break our engagement over this? I can't believe it!

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.
B: And where did you leave it?
response: A: I am sure I left it in the coffee shop on the 5th floor.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
response: A: So it really holds your interest?

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.
response: A: Well, Mr Strunk, I hate my work very much.

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
response: B: I did. I never called you at all, but you had your mobile phone power off.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Please come into my office.
B: Good morning. Thank you.
A: I see that you have some impressive writing experience.
response: B: Yes . I have written for several top newspapers in the country . I'm also in the process of writing my first novel .

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?

A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in a bit too much specialized information.
response: B: The main thing I object to is the perfect direction.

dialogue: A: Can I have my money back on this skirt?
B: Anything wrong with it?
A: Yes, this is defective. See? I didn't notice this hole when I bought it.
B: Oh, I'm very sorry about that. You can change it for another one if you prefer.
response: A: If you have a different one-different color, different design, and different size, of course.

dialogue: A: Well, the salad's almost ready. How's the beef going? I'm starving.
B: So am I. The beef looks just about ready. Just one minute... ow!
A: What's the matter?
B: Oh, my finger, I burned my finger!
response: A: Oh, wait, I'll get some Icy Hot and put it on your finger.

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
response: B: I was sick. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of school.

dialogue: A: Are you a happy married man?
B: Yes, I am. My wife and I understand each other.
A: You are a lucky man. How about Mr. Smith.
B: I don't know. But they say that Mrs. Smith wears the pants in the house.
A: You mean she bosses her husband around?
response: B: That's right. She is pretty, but she wants to control everything in his life.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.
A: No. But you must admit that on the big screen, it looked great.
B: Well, I think it would have been just as good as seeing it at home.
A: Ah, But it won't be on video till next year.
response: B: That's a pretty short time to wait.

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
response: B: I'm going to try to find a library near the office.

dialogue: A: Have you got some nice apples in stock today?
B: What about these? They are very fresh and exceptionally juicy.
A: Are they sweet?
response: B: Very sour.

dialogue: A: I'd like to pay a visit to the Smiths at 3:30 p.m. Will you go with me, Mary?
B: I'd love to, but I won't be off work from my factory until 4:00 p.m. How about 4:15? I'll be free then, Jack.
A: OK. Let's meet at the bus stop and take the No.5 bus to go there.
response: B: Why not by bus? The bus would be crowded at that time.

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Where were you at lunchtime? I was looking for you in the dining hall.
B: Oh, sorry, I missed you. My English class ran late again.
A: That's been happening quite often recently. Maybe it's because the final exams are coming up.
response: B: Yes. After class, there is always a group of students who get out as soon as possible. How about you? Are yon ready for the exams?

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
B: I need to review my English.
A: So that's what keeps you so busy recently!
B: Yes, I've been tied up with my studies. Now, what worries me a lot is my English.
A: But why? Your English is very good.
B: Thank you. You are very kind.
response: A: No, I'm telling the truth. As an American, I don't understand you at all.

dialogue: A: We would be interested in having you join us, Mrs. Sharp.
B: Thank you. I have done this knid of work before.
A: I know, and that's probably the reason you've been employed. Do you prefer part-time or full-time employment?
B: Part-time.
A: OK. Some people choose part-time jobs because they want to do something else besides work, such as reading novels or playing sports. But they will not get any other benefits besides the wages.
B: I don't care about that. May I ask you if I can decide the hours I would work?
A: I can only give you the choice from 7:00 a.m. till noon or from noon till 5:00 p.m.
B: Then I'd prefer to work in the morning because I have to prepare dinner for my children.
response: A: OK, Mrs. Sharp. Just sign your name on this sheet of paper. You may start next week. Mrs. Clarkson has got something ready for you--a blackboard, some chalk, and a tape recorder. She'll show you around later.

dialogue: A: Hi, Nicole. Did you have a good weekend?
B: Yes, I did. But I feel tired today.
A: Really? Why?
B: Well, on Saturday I cleaned the house and played tennis. Then on Sunday I hiked in the country.
A: And I bet you studied, too.
response: B: Yeah . I studied on Sunday evening . What about you ?

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.
response: A: That's exactly why I want to borrow your notes. My notes aren't very good.

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Where were you at lunchtime? I was looking for you in the dining hall.
B: Oh, sorry, I missed you. My English class ran late again.
A: That's been happening quite often recently. Maybe it's because the final exams are coming up.
response: B: Yes. After class, there is always a group of students hanging around the professor asking questions. How about you? Are yon ready for the exams?

dialogue: A: Did you need help with something?
B: I need to cancel an account.
A: Do you have a problem with your account?
response: B: I still need two different accounts.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but I think you've made a wrong turn. You were supposed to turn left on Wilson Boulevard.
B: Oh, I am sorry. Didn't you say 1323 Wilson?
A: No, 3023. It is OK though. You don't have to take me there. I can walk from here.
B: Why don't I just make a U-turn there? It's a one-way street; see the sign up ahead. Maybe if I turn left here, I can come down the next street.
response: A: We can't do that during lunch hour really, though it won't be much trouble. Sometimes one can wait 30 minutes for a taxi, so I'm happy to get this close.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
response: A: If only you hadn't spent so little money on your vacation!

dialogue: A: And lightweight, too. It'll play for 20 hours on two AA batteries!
B: Cool! The sound is great. These earphones are awesome!
A: And they're really safe. They'll protect your ear from sound damage.
response: B: You certainly need that. You always turn the volume down way too low.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Could I be of any service to you?
B: Have you got any Chinese paintings?
A: Yes, we have landscape paintings, figure paintings and flower-and-bird paintings.
B: I'd like a flower-and-bird painting.
A: Good. How about this picture of cranes with pine trees? It was painted by a famous Chinese painter in King Dynasty.
B: Oh, they look just like live cranes. I like this picture very much. How much is it?
A: One thousand dollars.
response: B: It's a small amount of money. But the picture is excellent , I'll take it .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Do you have a reservation?
B: Yes. My name is Charles.
A: I see. We have a window table reserved for you.
B: It's very kind of you.
A: Would you like to order now or wait for a while?
response: B: Bring me the menu , please .

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
B: He was messing around last week in class.
A: Exactly what did he do?
B: Even though I asked him not to, he kept speaking out in class.
A: I don't know what his problem is.
B: I need you to talk to him, if you don't mind.
response: A: That won't happen again, I'm sorry.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
response: B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of cotton shoes.

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
response: A: I sprained my wrist , but the doctor says it will be fine .

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.
B: Hi, Jane.
A: What are you going to do this Saturday evening?
B: I'm going to a concert.
response: A: How disgusting! Who is going to sing at the concert?

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
A: And you have a stomachache now?
B: Yes, I think so.
A: Can you walk to the school clinic? Or shall I send for the doctor?
B: No, thanks. It doesn't matter too much. I will go to the doctor after class.
response: A: Ok. I'll finish the class in a minute. Then I'll send you to the clinic.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
response: B: It's Blue, G-R-E-E-N.

dialogue: A: Hello, Old English Restaurant. Can I help you?
B: Yes. I'd like to book a table for tonight.
A: Yes, sir. What time?
B: Eight o'clock.
A: Certainly. For how many people?
B: There are ten of us.
response: A: Ten of you! But we don't usually accept large parties, sir.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.
B: Then your two boys don't need to share a room. They are happy with it?
response: A: Yeah, they can have their own pillows. What interests me most is the small garden before the house. You know I love gardening so much.

dialogue: A: May I help you, sir?
B: Yes, please. I want to buy a personal gift for my brother. He's taking a trip to South America.
A: Is he going by ship or plane?
B: He,s flying. My gift will have to be something light in weight. What can you suggest?
A: What about this tie? It's made of pure silk.
B: My sister already gave him one. I'd like something unusual. Let me look around...oh, that clock looks nice, but...
A: Hey,here is a gift for the man who has everything.
response: B: Oh,a folding toothbrush! That's a bad idea! I'll take it.

dialogue: A: Are you busy tomorrow night? I'm going over to the Workers Club for volleyball if you'd like to come along.
B: Isn't that far away?

A: Not really. If you take the No. 3 bus, you can get there in ten minutes. And if volleyball doesn't interest you, they've got a huge indoor swimming pool, a weight room, and indoor tracks. It's a great place to meet people.

B: Now that you mentioned it, it would be nice to get away from the computer center for a change, and I really should get some more exercise. Working up a sweat in a ball game or the weight room would be nice. I've got so fat.
response: A: Look at me -You're not the only one. In high school I had a lot more time to do sports activities. Now what little spare time you have must be used in doing exercise. At least the club is open until 12 pm.

dialogue: A: What topic did you finally choose for the term paper for your World Economy class?
B: After thinking about a few ideas, I finally settled on the difference between Japanese and American styles of management.
A: Hmm. Why did you choose a topic like that?
response: B: Well, I'm planning to study Business in graduate school next year. After that, I hope to start my own company.

dialogue: A: What are you doing tonight?
B: I have to run to the grocery store.
A: Don't you hate fighting the crowds on the weekends?
B: Yes, but I am out of food and milk.
A: What store do you shop at?
B: The small one, just down the street. I like their generic brand.
A: I have been using the store across town for years.
B: I hear they have very nice stuff.
response: A: They do, and as an added bonus they're affordable.

dialogue: A: Are you leaving?
B: I ’ m going to work.
A: You have a job?
B: I ’ m going to work at the polling place.
A: You ’ re working there this year?
B: I work there every year.
A: How are you able to work at the polling place?
response: B: I finished the job online.

dialogue: A: Marissa, if your papers continue to be late, I will have to give you a failing grade for the course.
B: I'm sorry! I've been having a really hard semester.
A: You need to try a little harder, okay?
response: B: I know, I will. There's just been a lot going on lately. I'm moving out of my house, and my brother is in the hospital.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
response: B: Many customers wanted them really badly.

dialogue: A: Do you know much about computers?
B: Not a great deal. Why?
A: I've been reading an article about computers. They are strange and are being used for almost everything.
B: Yes. But have you learned how to use one?
A: No. But I'm about to take a course on computers next term.
B: That's good. You have to know about computers. Computer knowledge is a must whatever you do. You should learn quickly or you will be left behind.
A: That's true. But first I want to learn the basics. In the library, there are computers. But it's a pity that I could not make use of them.
B: Well, I can teach you the ABCs, if you like.
response: A: That's very mean of you.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
response: A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order? May I suggest a veal.
B: No, I'll have the fish please.
A: The chicken is also nice.
B: No, I want the fish.
response: A: Our special tonight is lobster fish.

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
B: I'd love to, but when?
A: How about Saturday morning? It's cooler in the morning and maybe less crowded.
B: I'm afraid I can not get up early on weekends. I'd prefer Saturday afternoon. Believe me there won't be too many people.
A: So, shall we meet at 2:00, Saturday afternoon?
response: B: OK, that would be great. But just to be clear, I won't plan to wait for you at my home.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
B: Thanks, they are rather attractive. But I think there is nothing better than seeing things In actual operation.
A: Yes, of course. Would you like to make an inspection tour of some factories?
response: B: Yes , very much , if it wouldn't add inconvenience to you . First hand information is always more valuable than reading pamphlets .

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
response: B: You're right. But I really had a happy vacation.

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
B: You can get wine and beer in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.
A: When do people go to the pubs?
response: B: Pubs are not open all day. They can decide when to open. Most are open for 3 or 4 hours at lunchtime and again from about 6:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. In busy areas, pubs may stay open from 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. Are there pubs in China?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, what did you say you would like to do, Mr Green?
B: I said I'd better go back to the hotel. I'm meeting someone this evening.
A: OK, how are you going back? By bus or taxi?
B: I think I'd take a taxi. Do you know where I can get one?
response: A: Oh, just wait for the bus. I'll wait with you.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.
B: Hi, Jane.
A: What are you going to do this Saturday evening?
B: I'm going to a concert.
A: How exciting! Who is going to sing at the concert?
B: Xu Song. He is my favorite pop singer.
response: A: Where is he going to give the concert?

dialogue: A: Good morning. Anything wrong?
B: I've been suffering from a fever since yesterday.
A: Do you have any other problems? Like a headache or cough?
B: No, I don't. I think it's only a fever.
response: A: Let me check... It's 39 degrees. I'll give you some medicine.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
response: A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
B: I'd like her to have a change.
A: Then how do you like this plum red one?
response: B: It is nice. Is it fire proof?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just graduated from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.
B: Could you tell me what you can do?
response: A: I can do whatever a secretary is expected to do, such as typing, receiving phone calls, sending faxes, and writing reports.

dialogue: A: Look. Jack! That man fell off the ladder. Come and help! He must be injured.
B: He's not moving. Shall we take him to the hospital?
A: We mustn't move him. Leave him where he is.
B: We must get help. I'll go to that phone box and call the First Aid Center.
A: Right. I'll stay here with him.
B: How is he now?
A: He's still not moving, but he's breathing. His head must be hurt.
B: The First Aid Center says they are coming soon.
response: A: Let's wait until death comes. Look, there they come!

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
response: B: The music group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?

dialogue: A: Did you ever get a parking ticket?
B: No, have you?
A: Yeah, I just got one the other day.
B: How'd you get a ticket?
response: A: The ticket was for leaving the parking lot.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
response: A: How awful ! Was he hungry?

dialogue: A: Hello, I am calling about my cable service.
B: What's the problem?
A: For the past week my cable hasn't been working.
B: I apologize, but the cable has been down lately.
A: Do you know when it is going to start working again?
B: Give it a couple days, and it should be back on.
A: Will I still have to pay for the cable while it's not working?
response: B: Since it's not working , I'm going to give you a bill.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: This is my first day here.
A: Are you a freshman in college?
B: I started school somewhere else.
response: A: What school did you transfer from?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. We will have our midterm exams next month. I plan to look for some important books and study at the library. Do you want to join me?
B: Sure. I need to return some books. They are due today. Besides, I can also read some weekly publications, magazines and newspapers.
A: Great. We can go to the swimming pool in the gymnasium after that.
response: B: Sounds a good idea. Summer is approaching. Today's temperature has reached 35 degree Centigrade. Are you good at swimming?

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Great graduation party, isn't it?
B: Yes, everyone here is having a good time. Any ideas for the future?
A: Well, I'm interested in finance and my uncle runs a company in Hong Kong, so I decided to go to Hong Kong University.
response: B: Sounds great. Hong Kong is a small and local financial center. You will surely go far there.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
B: I hope I could get a reception at the White House some time.
response: A: Well, if you do something important when you grow up, maybe you will. Who knows?

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
A: I have no other choice. Next month will be the most important exam of this term.
B: I can understand that. But anyway, you should take better care of yourself.
A: What should I do now?
response: B: I think you should stay in bed for a little while and I will call the doctor.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
response: A: So you are thinking of staying put,are you?

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
response: B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?

dialogue: A: Have you heard about the robbery?
B: I saw the whole thing happen.
A: For real?
B: I was in the bank during the robbery.
A: What went down?
B: Some dude came into the bank with a gun.
A: Are you serious?
B: When he pulled out the gun, I got so scared.
A: Tell me what else happened.
B: He got the money and tried to leave.
A: Did the cops get him?
response: B: No, the cops arrested him before he could even make it out the door .

dialogue: A: Why are you interested in our company?
B: Your company is world-famous. So, I think there will be better chances for persona development.
A: You're right. Do you think you have the qualifications for this job?
B: Sure. My qualifications meet your job description.
A: But you have no experience for this job.
B: That's true. But I am eager to learn, and also quick at learning.
A: Since you need further training, are you familiar with training salary?
B: No. What is the monthly salary?
A: 800 yuan per month.
response: B: Do you mind if I give an answer tomorrow?

dialogue: A: And lightweight, too. It'll play for 20 hours on two AA batteries!
B: Cool! The sound is great. These earphones are awesome!
A: And they're really safe. They'll protect your ear from sound damage.
response: B: You certainly need that. You never pump the volume up high.

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.
A: Well. I did think here, yes. But maybe the factory somewhere.
response: B: I think they prefer to see where our products are shipped.

dialogue: A: Have you packed our passports?
B: Not yet. Do we need to take it with us?
A: Of course. Otherwise I cannot go abroad.
B: Is that hard to get a passport?
A: Not at all. But we do need to keep it with us all the time.
response: B: It is hard to believe this little thing is so valuable to us .

dialogue: A: Do you ever eat fast food?
B: Yes, yes, I do.
A: What kind of fast food do you normally eat?
response: B: Oh, you know, whiskey, beer, well, sometimes a pizza.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
response: B: About 20 minutes at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
A: I can take you home. Would you like a ride?
response: B: Yes. Thanks a lot. Could you stop at the chemist's on the way? I need to buy some cocaine.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
response: B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.

dialogue: A: What are you doing here?
B: I'm preparing my fishing tools.
A: What for?
B: I'm going to fish with some of my friends.
A: Are you fond of fishing?
B: Yes. I like fishing after school and on Sundays.
A: When did you get such a hobby?

B: Long ago. You know, my father is fond of and very good at fishing. When I was a child, he took me to the riverside to see him fishing. I found fishing very interesting then. Well, what's your hobby?
A: I'm very interested in making home movies. But I haven't got a movie camera.
B: I also like taking photos and I have a Japanese-made camera.
response: A: I take a lot of photos, too. But I'm more interested in the history of film, so I really enjoy using a film camera. I'll paint one of my own someday.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
response: B: Yeah. Now that the weather is snowy and freezing, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
response: B: It must be old .

dialogue: A: Any interesting jobs listed on the Internet today?
B: Well, there are a lot of retail jobs-selling clothes and stuff. But you have to work Saturdays and Sundays.
A: Hmm. I hate working on weekends.
B: Hmm... so do I.
A: Oh, here's a job in sales. It's a job selling children's books to bookstores.
B: That sounds interesting.
A: Yes.
B: Let's see.
A: You need to have a driver's license. And you have to work some evenings.
response: B: I don't mind working in the evenings. And I can't drive, which is perfect. What's the phone number?

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: Could I have one more blanket?
B: I'm afraid there aren't any left at the moment. Gan you wait just a little while?
A: OK. I will.
response: B: I'll bring you one as soon as they are all being used.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
