A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
B: But he is usually correct in his weather news.
A: The temperature is 32t this afternoon. I'm sure we'll have fine weather for our picnic.
response: B: Well, I'll go, but I'll take my dog with me.

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
response: B: But I heard it loud and clear.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
response: B: I have been eating like I usually do. Usually, I don't love my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt cooking and I've eaten very little. Most unlike me.

dialogue: A: Harry, do you like the opera?
B: No, not really.
A: Why is that? It is called real art.
response: B: Well , it's very expensive and they're usually singing in another language . That kind of gets on my nerves .

dialogue: A: I need a summer job that will give me some exercise.
B: How about being a life guard?
A: Life guards don't swim that much. They usually just sit.
B: Well then, you could be a swimming coach, or a tour guide.
response: A: Tour guide is a good idea. I'd walk all day.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I go to a movie this week with Shannon?
B: Let me look at the calendar here. Hmm. When are you thinking about going to a movie?
A: Uh, we're thinking about seeing a movie on Wednesday after school.
response: B: Well, that's not going to work. You have practiced your piano for an entire week, so you don't have to catch up on that.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time every year.
A: How long will it take to cycle one way, Robin?
B: About seven to nine hours for the average cyclists. Good cyclists can do it in four hours.
A: How many people will be taking part this year?
response: B: This is our biggest year ever. We have twelve hundred cyclists registered.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
response: B: I'm in the electrical appliances .

dialogue: A: Have you seen Mr. Li?
B: No, I haven't. Is he looking for me?
A: Yes, he is. He wants to talk to you.
B: To me? About what?
A: There's an opening in the sales department. He wants to talk to you about it.
B: Oh, that's great! What kind of this job is it?
A: He hasn't told me exactly. But it will be a better job than this.
B: Thank you for your help.
response: A: Don't thank me yet! He hasn't talked to you and he has already chosen you for the job.

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
response: B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
response: B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?

dialogue: A: What are you going to have for breakfast?
B: I just have some cereal each morning.
A: You're supposed to always have a hearty breakfast.
response: B: I don't always have time to make breakfast .

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
response: B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition improved when he enjoyed himself and watched sad movies.

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
A: I sprained my wrist, but the doctor says it will be fine.
B: How many days will you be out of school?
A: The doctor said I should be good enough to return next week.
response: B: I am glad you let me know that you will be present in class . Get well !

dialogue: A: Can I help you, Madam?
B: Yes, I'd like to exchange some US dollars into RIB.
A: How much would you like to exchange?
B: What's the exchange rate for RIB?
A: It's US 100 for RIB 802 today.
B: I'd like to exchange 3,000.
response: A: Fill in this loan form, please.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Anything wrong?
B: I've been suffering from a fever since yesterday.
A: Do you have any other problems? Like a headache or cough?
B: No, I don't. I think it's only a fever.
response: A: Let me check... It's 39 degrees. I'll give you a vaccine.

dialogue: A: Are you being served, sir?
B: I'd like to buy a tapestry to decorate my new room.
A: Artistic tapestry is the highest expression form of the rug weaving art. How about these ones?
B: These are beautiful! Is this the marvelous landscape in Guiling?
A: Yes, sir.
B: How fine the needlework is! What's the price?
A: Ninety dollars.
response: B: It's too ugly and cheap.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
response: B: Do you take vitamins instead?

dialogue: A: What are you doing for Christmas this year?
B: All my relatives are getting together at my house.
A: That's great. M OST of my family is coming home too.
B: Who can't make it in your family?
response: A: My sister. She is studying at school this year.

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
A: You must be mad. I think it's really...you know...so easy to buy everything in one place.
B: Yes, it's easy. But don't you think the food isn't...I mean small shops usually have much fresher food.
A: Maybe, but you pay for it. Small shops are more expensive, aren't they?
response: B: Yes, I agree with you, but supermarket staff are badly paid and they are really...but you get better service in small shops. They are much more rude.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.
B: Uh. I didn't have any of that when I was in middle school, and I did just fine.
A: Yeah, and there weren't any cars either. Things are a lot more progressive now.
B: Great. My daughter will be playing video games in class.
A: Dad.
response: B: Great. How long are these things going to be free?

dialogue: A: Where did you put my new red tie?
B: It's right there in the cupboard with your other ties.
A: There's a green one and a couple of brown ones, but no red one.
B: Here it is in your drawer. You must have put it there when you brought it home.
A: I suppose so. We'd better hurry up or we're going to be late. The Smiths said to come at 7:00.
response: B: 24 now. The Smiths aren't here to take care of the children yet.

dialogue: A: Have you packed our passports?
B: Not yet. Do we need to take it with us?
A: Of course. Otherwise I cannot go abroad.
B: Is that hard to get a passport?
A: Not at all. But we do need to keep it with us all the time.
response: B: It is hard to believe this thing is so heavy.

dialogue: A: Did you hear about the air crash that occurred in South America recently? It was quite a tragic accident!
B: No, I didn't see anything in the news about it. What happened?
A: A foreign airliner was attempting to land at night in a mountainous area in Argentina and flew into a hill!
B: That sounds really terrible! Did anyone survive?
A: No, everyone aboard, including the crew, was killed instantly.
B: What were the circumstances? Were they bad weather, a fire, or engine failure?
A: Apparently, there were some low clouds in the area, but mostly it was just miscommunication between the pilots and the traffic controllers.
B: Weren't they both speaking in English, the official international aviation language?

A: Yes they were, but the transmit ion from poor quality radios was slightly distorted and the accents of the Spanish speaking controllers was so strong that the pilots that the pilots misunderstood a vital instruction.
B: How could a misunderstanding like that cause such a serious accident?

A: The pilots were told to descend to 2-2,000 feet. The instruction actually meant 22,000 feet, but they thought they heard descend 2,000 feet. That's a huge difference, and it should have been confirmed, but it was not. Unfortunately, the terrain of the mountains in Norweija ascends to 2,000 feet.
B: So the pilots did descend to the wrong altitude then, because they were following the air controllers instructions.
response: A: Sadly enough, no they didn't. It wasn't really a mistake. Many people died as a result of the simply understanding.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.
A: I don't know how you keep on with it. It's too hard to become a doctor.
B: Well, you study a lot too. It doesn't seem any easier to become an engineer.
response: A: But at least it takes just as long. I'll be out putting up the buildings while you're still a student here. By the way, can I help you with your study now?

dialogue: A: When do you take your winter holiday?
B: I usually take it during the second or third week of January.
A: Do you like to ski?
response: B: Yes, I love to go biking.

dialogue: A: : Hey, hey, neighbor. What are you doing with my trees? My wife planted that tree 25 years ago. Get off that ladder.

B: ghbor: Listen. Even though the trees are in your yard, some of the branches hang over into mine, and I am getting sick and tired of raking up your leaves and picking up all the branches that fall off during storms throughout the year. And the walnuts off this tree... they litter my yard and damage my lawnmower when I cut the grass. And my dog eats them, and he ends up with terrible diarrhea.
A: : Still. You can't cut off those branches.
B: ghbor: Watch me. It's completely legal. I check the city code and law regarding this issue, and I am well within my rights.
A: : I'm not sure about that. Anyway, It's just not right. You didn't say anything to us about it...
B: ghbor: I don't have to.
A: : Yeah, but you could have said something. Anything! I mean I want to stay on friendly terms with you, but the basic courtesy of informing your neighbors is the least you could have done.
B: ghbor: Okay. I'm cutting down your branches. You've been informed... now, stand back!
response: A: : Hey. Don't expect an invitation to our next barbecue or book club!

dialogue: A: What are you doing tonight?
B: I have to run to the grocery store.
A: Don't you hate fighting the crowds on the weekends?
response: B: Yes , but I am out of food and milk .

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
response: B: I haven't been drinking like I usually do. Usually, I love my diet sodas, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt thirsty and I've drank very little. Most unlike me.

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite smart, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?
response: B: Yeah. Let's see if there's a smaller size. Well, they don't seem to have anything larger.

dialogue: A: Dr Stone, how did you become an expert on smell?

B: Well, I didn't intend to in the first place. But when I was in university, there was a course on senses. The other senses seem to be more concrete somehow, but smell is so personal. I found it extremely interesting.
A: Do you have any interesting information to give us about smells?

B: Well, let's see. Did you know that it's harder to forget smells than to forget facts? There have been experiments where people could pick out a particular smell thirty days after smelling it for the first time.
response: A: Really? So smells can bring back no memories at all.  Way less than, say, music?

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
response: B: Well, my mum wants me to keep all the cans, so that we can sell them after a while.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
response: A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to be sunny. The weatherman said it will.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
response: B: Well, Ann, the tour a decade from now is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun and try to better their time every decade.

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a letter.
B: There's a mail box up the street. Have you already got a stamp on that letter?
response: A: Yes, I have to shred it. How do I walk to the post office from here?

dialogue: A: After probation, you'll find that our silk products feels more comfortable than others.
B: How about this product selling from last month on?
A: It's selling like hot cakes, and we have lots of regulars now. Would you like to place a trial order?
response: B: Well, can I have a try of the product at sale price?

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a letter.
response: B: There's a mail box up the street. Have you already got a stamp on that letter?

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
B: I caught hold of his knife, and he pushed me to the floor.
response: A: Oh, no! Why did you not hold his knife? That's dangerous.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
B: About 20 minutes at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.
response: A: I'd better go there by walking. By the way, where is the train stop, please?

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
response: B: You've been studying too little recently.

dialogue: A: Drive slowly, David. You could have an accident.
B: You can count on me. I have been driving for years.
A: Look out! Red light!
response: B: It doesn't matter. It is late. There is no one around.

dialogue: A: Mary, tomorrow is your mom's fiftieth birthday. Do you know?
B: Of course I do. How shall we celebrate it?
A: First of all a birthday present. What about buying her a beautiful skirt?
response: B: That's a good idea.  It would make her look younger.  And a big birthday cake too, with one hundred candles.

dialogue: A: Hello, Robert speaking.
B: Hi, it's Emma. I'm glad you're there. It's about our appointment on Wednesday morning. I'm afraid I can't make it now.
A: Oh, that's a shame.
response: B: I'm sorry. There was a change in my business partner's weekend plans. Luckily Wednesday is the day she is able to see me.

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a letter.
B: There's a mail box up the street. Have you already got a stamp on that letter?
response: A: Yes, I have to write it. How do I walk to the post office from here?

dialogue: A: Welcome, Miss. May I help you?
B: I hope so. I want a lipstick.
A: Do you have any particular brand in mind?
B: I like Lyfel very much.
A: We have different shades of Lyfel lipstick. May I know what color you usually wear?
response: B: Pink. But today, I'm thinking of buying one in a dark shade. You know, I will be a teacher next month. I wish to look more silly.

dialogue: A: Ahh... What a fine day! I do feel like an outdoor exercise.
B: How about taking a walk in the park?
A: OK. It's delightful to have a walk in the park with the air so fresh.
B: Oh, it's so quiet here. We have the park to ourselves, only you and me!
A: Don't you see many people over there? Just on your left.
response: B: Oh, I see them. Some are bathing, some are performing ballet inside, some are playing futsal.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
A: Are you renting it alone or with company?
B: I'll share it with one of my friends. What ’ s in a one-bedroom apartment?
A: A one-bedroom apartment has one bedroom, a living room, a kitchen and a bathroom.
B: Is there any furniture?
A: No, but a fridge and a stove.
B: It sounds wonderful. Do I have to sign a lease? How much should I pay?
response: A: Yes , it ’ s a one-year lease . And $ 200 a week with one month refundable deposit .

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.
B: Then your two boys don't need to share a room. They are happy with it?
response: A: Yeah, they can't have their own rooms. What interests me most is the small garden before the house. You know I love gardening so much.

dialogue: A: Are you okay?
B: No.
A: What's wrong?
B: I got robbed!
A: By who?
B: Some guy on the street just mugged me.
A: Are you hurt?
B: No, he just stole all of my things.
A: That's crazy.
response: B: I need to go to the police station.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve in the library for anthropology 311.
A: Professor Gilers's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matter which one of them you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're kidding all of them?

A: I've asked professor Gilers twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for these same articles to be returned.
B: And here I went out of my way to free the whole afternoon to read.
response: A: I'm sorry, but there is not a whole lot I can do about it. All I can suggest is that you come in first thing tomorrow evening and try again; we open at eight.

dialogue: A: Have you heard my good news?
B: You haven't told me anything yet.
A: I got a promotion at work earlier this week.
B: Is that right?
A: It's the truth. I am really happy.
B: Congratulations on your promotion.
A: Thank you very much.
B: I am really excited for you.
A: Are you really?
response: B: I'm serious . You didn't do a whole lot to deserve this promotion .

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
B: I'm very sorry this happened. I'll tell you what: I won't charge you for the soup today.
response: A: That's great. I can use a free lunch.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing Tasty Restaurant. What can I do for you?
B: Will you please show me a table beside the window?
A: Sorry, there's no table beside the window, only one table in the centre.
B: In the centre? OK.
A: This way,please.
B: Thank you.
response: A: Here's the menu. Could I take your order?

dialogue: A: Hello. Milton Hotel. Can I help you?
B: I want a reservation. Can I have it now?
A: Of course. What kind of taste do you like for your dinner?
B: I prefer Chinese dishes.
A: Would you like to sit in a smoking section, a non-smoking section or an open one?
B: A non-smoking section.
response: A: I'm awfully sorry, but we haven't got the food left now. Would you like to wait for a while?

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
response: A: There's also the matter of the fridge. We all assumed there would not be one in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.

dialogue: A: I need a summer job that will give me some exercise.
B: How about being a life guard?
A: Life guards don't swim that much. They usually just sit.
B: Well then, you could be a swimming coach, or a tour guide.
response: A: Tour guide is a good idea. I'd fart all day.

dialogue: A: We haven't gone out for over a month. Let's go somewhere this evening.
B: Fine, where shall we go?
A: Look in the newspaper to see what's on at the cinema or the theater.
B: I see new play opened this week.
A: I enjoy a concert.
B: According to the newspaper there aren't any tonight.
response: A: Aren't there any good concerts in town?

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
response: B: It was at my uncle's house.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
A: Are you renting it alone or with company?
B: I'll share it with one of my friends. What ’ s in a one-bedroom apartment?
A: A one-bedroom apartment has one bedroom, a living room, a kitchen and a bathroom.
B: Is there any furniture?
A: No, but a fridge and a stove.
response: B: It sounds wonderful . Do I have to sign a divorce paper ? How much should I pay ?

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
response: B: Well, my mum wants me to empty all the cans, so that we can drink them after a while.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman said it will.
response: B: I don't think he's right.  It has been raining for weeks already.

dialogue: A: Are you packing for another trip?
B: Yeah. On Saturday, I'm flying to Toronto.
A: Is this another engineering conference for work?
B: No. I'm meeting with friends. But I earned so many miles by traveling for work that the ticket was free.
A: That's impressive. You fly a lot. I've only been on a plane a few times.
B: Really? Don't you travel with your dad?
A: No. He travels a lot because he is a banker,and he has an office in Japan. When he's working in New York, we take the train to visit him.
B: Oh, I thought you drove.
response: A: No, my mom misses driving in the city. Besides, the train is super relaxing.

dialogue: A: Hello, I am calling about my cable service.
B: What's the problem?
A: For the past week my cable hasn't been working.
response: B: I apologize , but the cable has been working .

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
response: B: Not really. But when I was home, I had to start typing a literature paper that was due first thing in the morning.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
response: B: It certainly is. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.

dialogue: A: Look. Jack! That man fell off the ladder. Come and help! He must be injured.
B: He's not moving. Shall we take him to the hospital?
A: We mustn't move him. Leave him where he is.
response: B: We must get help. I'll go to that phone box and call the Superman.

dialogue: A: Are you going somewhere for your vacation?
B: Yes, I'm making plans for a tour.
A: That'll be lovely. Where are you going?
B: I start out from Long Island this Friday. I've planned a four-day drive to Salt Lake Ciy, where I'll join my brother and my family for his fortieth birthday.
response: A: Well, you've got to prepare lots of food and no sleeping bags then?

dialogue: A: Hi, Nicole. Did you have a good weekend?
B: Yes, I did. But I feel tired today.
A: Really? Why?
response: B: Well , on Saturday I cleaned the house and played tennis . Then on Sunday I hiked in the country .

dialogue: A: Hi. Mike. How did your weekend go?
B: Fine. I went back to visit my grandma in the countryside.
A: Lucky you. What did you do there?
B: I went for a walk in the hills with some of my friends.
A: Was it good?
B: Yes. the scenery was amazing. The whole hillside was very red.
A: How wonderful! Do anything else?
B: We went on a picnic on Sunday.
A: Did you like it?
response: B: Very frustrating. By the way, Lisa. what about your Weekend?

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
response: A: It was frigid . You seem to be in a hurry . Don't let me hold you up .

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
response: A: Thank goodness. They have been here long.

dialogue: A: Dad, how can we get to the zoo?
B: We can take a bus there.
A: Does this bus go there?
B: I think so.
A: Let's step in, Dad.
B: No, it's too crowded.
response: A: Dad. Here comes another bus.

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
B: But you should pay special attention to your words and attitudes.
A: In the beginning of the interview, greet the interviewer with a kind smile.
B: In the interview, use polite words, such as ' Thank you ', or ' Please '.
A: That's right. Details can mean succeed or fail.
B: When talking you should focus your eyes on the interviewer in order to closely watch his or her expressions.
A: At the end of the interview, you should make your acknowledgements and say Goode.
B: Whatever the result is, you should keep your good demeanor.
response: A: In this way, you can leave a bad impression on the interviewer.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman said it will.
response: B: I don't think he's right. It hasn't rained for a week.

dialogue: A: Bill, do you know when did the Chinese begin to celebrate Teachers ' Day?
B: I know the Chinese teachers had their first festival in 1985.
A: So, it is the 27th Teachers ' Day.
B: What will you do on Teachers ' Day?
response: A: I am going to send Mr. Li some flowers for Mother's day. What about you?

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
response: B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She would really like that.

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
B: No. Just occasionally.
A: What are your favourite dances?
response: B: I don't love dancing.

dialogue: A: What do you usually do in your spare time?
B: I have joined a singing group and we practice two afternoons each week.
A: That's a very interesting thing to do.
B: Yes. It's a small group of only fifteen girls and boys. But nobody has been late for the practice.
A: I see. How many songs can you sing now?
B: We started only three months ago, but we've practiced eight songs.
A: Are you going to perform any time?
response: B: Yes, there will be a swimming meet next month and we are going to sing a song in it. We are practicing a new song now. It's written by one of the singers in our group.

dialogue: A: What time do you usually get up in the morning?
B: I sleep in every morning, sometimes until 11 or 12.
A: Are you serious? I get up at 5 every morning to go to the gym, and then I get to work around 7.
B: Well, I work from home, so I can set my own hours. I usually work until midnight or 1 in the morning, and then I like to sleep in.

A: I like to be in bed around 9 or 10 at night so I can get enough sleep. Our schedules are very different! You're lucky that you get to set your own schedule, but I could never sleep that late. I'm definitely a morning person.
B: And I'm definitely a night person. Waking up early is so terrible.
A: Maybe we should switch schedules for a week!
B: No way! I would never want your schedule.
A: Very funny... What are you doing today?
B: Well, it's Saturday, so I was thinking of taking a hike. Would you like to come?
A: Sure. Can we go to see a movie afterwards?
B: I don't really like movies, actually. Can we do something else?
response: A: Sure, but I have no plans tomorrow even though it's Sunday, so I do need to be home around 9.

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
B: At least, it can free you from the crowd. By the way, do you come from China?
A: No, from New Zealand, sir. I visited New Zealand and saw lots of overseas people there.
B: Wow, like America. It receives a great number of visitors every year.
response: A: The more the world becomes open , the more people become isolated

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
response: A: So many people to take care of her.

dialogue: A: Did you have your television repaired?
B: Yes, but not by the place you recommended
A: Why not? The repair is very good and thecharges are so reasonable.
B: That may be, but I couldn't find it.
A: But you couldn't miss it. I told you the first right after the railroad bridge.
response: B: I took that. I went to the end of the road. There is such a place.

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
response: B: And the bike wasn't run over by the car. Both its wheels were just fine.

dialogue: A: Hi, John! I'd like to invite you to dinner this evening.
B: To dinner? What for?
A: I have passed my driving test!
B: Congratulations! I'm really glad to hear that.
response: A: Thank you! I have been really slacking for it for half a year, you know. And I've made it at last.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
A: Do they look like roses?
B: No, they look like little bells.
A: Oh, lilies of the valley. No, I am sorry. We are all out of them right now.
B: Oh, that's too bad.
A: What about roses?
B: Ok. How many do you suggest?
response: A: As many as you like , sir . They are beautiful , aren't they ?

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
B: I hope I could get a reception at the White House some time.
response: A: Well, if you do something trivial when you grow up, maybe you will. Who knows?

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
response: A: If I were you, I'd laugh at her first and then get her another dog.

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
response: B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
B: The music group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?
A: It's on the wall, madam, on the blackboard.
B: Indeed. I suppose you can't afford proper menus.
A: I'm sorry, madam, but that's what we always do.
response: B: Oh, If I weren't so hungry, I would leave immediately.

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
response: A: It would be nice to get out of the city . Do you want some company ?

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
response: B: Then, you should dress anyhow.

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
A: We ought to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.
B: We can do that tomorrow. We don't have to do it today.
A: All right. That's a good idea.
B: Talking about washing down the kitchen-where's Bob?
A: He's having lunch with Georgia.
B: What! Again?
A: He should be back soon.
B: He shouldn't spend so much time with that girl.
response: A: You must be patient, David. Nineteen's a very relaxing age.

dialogue: A: Dad, how can we get to the zoo?
B: We can take a bus there.
A: Does this bus go there?
B: I think so.
A: Let's step in, Dad.
B: No, it's too crowded.
A: Dad. Here comes another bus.
B: Fine. Let's get on. Oh, no, Judy! Get off the bus quickly!
A: Why? Dad?
response: B: We got on the wrong bus.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
response: B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another plate of spaghetti.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, I'm trying to do some work. I'm afraid your children are making a lot of noise. Don't they ever go to sleep?
B: I'm sorry. They are noisy. But you know it's difficult to keep boys quiet.
A: I couldn't work and I couldn't sleep at night. And I was woken by the noise they made early this morning.
response: B: I'm terribly sorry. You know they never listen to me. They're only afraid of their father. He's away on business, but he will be back tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
A: So it doesn't really hold your interest?
response: B: No, not really. I wouldn't bother with it, to be honest, but I have to read it for a seminar. I'm at a university.

dialogue: A: Look! It's snowing. Winter is here at last.
B: It's really cold today.
A: Yes, you have to get used to it. The weather's going to be like this for the next three months.
response: B: Then I'm going to Alaska. Can you tell me about your weather diary? Why do you make notes about the different types of weather?

dialogue: A: Brad, wait!
B: What?
A: How come you have a locker but I don't?
B: Mr. Rogers probably forgot to assign a locker to you.
A: I had to carry my backpack with me all day.
B: Remind him to give you a locker tomorrow.
A: Does it have a lock?
response: B: No. You have to buy your own. You'll have to go to a hardware store to pick one up.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
B: They really started looting?
response: A: Yes , apparently four stores were broken into .

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
response: A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a telegraph message there.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam.
B: Good morning. I wonder if you can help. I've lost my coat.
A: Where did you lose it, madam?
B: Er... I left it on a bus yesterday morning.
A: Can you describe it? Is it a raincoat?
response: B: No. It's a long white overcoat. It's got a belt, and one of those thick furry collars that keep your ears warm. It's a very ugly coat, actually.

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
B: He was messing around last week in class.
A: Exactly what did he do?
response: B: Even though I asked him not to, he kept speaking out in class.

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
response: B: But I have a car and I know how to drive. Is there any other way to travel?

dialogue: A: Are you OK?
B: Yeah. Why not?
A: Because... I heard John got married yesterday.
response: B: Oh, you went to the wedding?

dialogue: A: Hi, why do you look so depressed today, Mike?
B: I had a terrible quarrel with my neighbor yesterday.
A: How come?
response: B: It is a long story . Basically , she thought I had laughed at her while I didn't .

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
response: B: Yes, I do. It made me cry a lot.

dialogue: A: Harry, do you like the opera?
B: No, not really.
A: Why is that? It is called real art.
response: B: Well , it's free and they're usually dancing too much . That kind of gets on my nerves .

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
response: B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have been hurt or even rejuvenated?

dialogue: A: Bob, did you see our supervisor? I need him to sign this paper.
B: He is in his office, but you'd better choose your words carefully while talking to him.
A: What's up?
B: Nothing. But he is in a bad mood today.
response: A: Thanks for the warning.

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: Yes, my nephew Jim is graduating from college next week and I'd like to get him a nice gift.
A: What price are you interested in? We'll need toknow that before we begin looking.
B: Well. I usually spend about twenty do Ham for a gift. Do you have anything nice for that price?
A: How about a pen?
B: No, my brother gave him that for his bithday last year.
A: Well, then would he enjoy a chess set?
B: No, he doesn't like chess very much, but he is quite athletic.
response: A: Then you should not get him a tennis racket.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
response: B: You must be a tour guide. What do you want anyway?

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
A: You must be mad. I think it's really...you know...so easy to buy everything in one place.
B: Yes, it's easy. But don't you think the food isn't...I mean small shops usually have much fresher food.
A: Maybe, but you pay for it. Small shops are more expensive, aren't they?
response: B: Yes, I agree with you, but supermarket staff are badly paid and they are really...but you get better service in big shops. They are much more friendly.

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
B: I did. I called you many times, but you had your mobile phone power off.
response: A: Oh, I had brought it with me because I left it recharging at home.

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
response: B: You've been studying too much recently.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote?
B: I am so excited to be voting.
A: Do you know who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I am so impressed with the candidate I ’ m going to vote for.
A: What ’ s so great about him?
B: I feel that he is very intelligent.
A: Oh, really?
B: Yes, and I agree with all his policies.
A: That ’ s good to hear.
B: I think this man is going to be the next President.
A: I hope so.
response: B: I ’ m not going to get my vote in.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Uncle Smith.
B: Good morning, Cathy.
A: I want to have a dinner party to celebrate my birthday. Would you come?
B: I'd love to, Cathy. What time?
response: A: Next Monday, at 6 am.

dialogue: A: What a great day! Hey, Tom, do you want to go to the beach this weekend?
B: Yeah, that is a great idea. Maybe Sara would like to come along with us.
A: I doubt it.
B: Why? You are kidding! You know, she loves watching the sea.
A: But yesterday afternoon she told me that she would go home this Saturday.
B: What happened?
A: She said that her mother was ill and stayed in the hospital, and therefore she wanted to go home to see her.
B: I am sorry to hear that. Well, What do you think? Should we take some food?
response: A: That sounds great. Maybe we could have a picnic on the beach. Then let's take some sandwiches, chips, and uh...some salad as well.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
response: B: No, I'm feeling wonderful. Mr. Brown.

dialogue: A: Are there pets allowed in this apartment?
B: No dogs or cats or any other fur type animal, but other pets are allowed.
A: What about a boa constrictor?
B: Well... is that a pet? Isn't that something from the zoo?
A: If I had one, could I rent this apartment?
B: I was more thinking of nice little fish or frogs or turtles or a pet rock.
A: What about a Gila monster?
response: B: I'll tell you what, if your pet can fit in this little box and doesn't have fur, it is welcome here.

dialogue: A: Honey, how long have we been living here?
B: About 10 years. What's wrong?
A: I am thinking about redecorating our house.
B: That would cost a lot of money. But we do need to do some changes to the house.
response: A: Right. What about repainting the living room in its current color?

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
response: B: No, thanks. I don't like onions. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
A: Are you renting it alone or with company?
B: I'll share it with one of my friends. What ’ s in a one-bedroom apartment?
A: A one-bedroom apartment has one bedroom, a living room, a kitchen and a bathroom.
B: Is there any furniture?
A: No, but a fridge and a stove.
B: It sounds wonderful. Do I have to sign a lease? How much should I pay?
response: A: Yes, it's a one-year lease. And $200 a week with one month free cleaning.

dialogue: A: Are you really dating with Frank?
B: Yeah. But in my heart of hearts, I find he ’ s not very much to my liking.
A: Then why not keep away from him?
response: B: The problem is that I have many people to turn to right now.

dialogue: A: Hi, why do you look so depressed today, Mike?
B: I had a terrible quarrel with my neighbor yesterday.
A: How come?
B: It is a long story. Basically, she thought I had laughed at her while I didn't.
A: I know everyone suffers when he is misunderstood. But why not take it easy?
response: B: Yeah . It's not so nice of you to be mean to me .

dialogue: A: Are you sure that this bus will take us to Santa Anita mall?
B: Yes, it will.
A: You know that for a fact?
response: B: I take this bus all the time, but what do you know, I don't know!

dialogue: A: Hi, Mark. Are you in town for another job interview?
B: Yes, I'm pretty hopeful this time. I've just finished my second interview with this company.
A: That sounds great. I hope it works out for you. But wasn't it expensive just getting here?
B: No, in fact the company is paying all my expenses. They've put me up in a hotel downtown.
A: How nice! How many people are they interviewing?
B: They interviewed 16 the first time, and now four of us were chosen to go back for this interview.
response: A: Well, I hope it goes well. John and I would love it if you stayed where you are to work.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.
A: In what ways? What has she done?
B: Oh, no, you don't really want to hear it.
A: Come on. I am a mother of two girls.
B: Ok. I'm worried because she often hides in her room and sends messages to her friends.
A: Come on. It's not a big deal. She needs friends at this age. You can talk with her if you are really concerned.
response: B: I guess so. Anyway, she will always stay a toddler.

dialogue: A: Do you want to go for a picinc with me tomorrow?
B: I'd like to. How about asking Jenny to go with us?
A: Oh, no. She is busy with her dancing class. You know, there is a very big performance in just a week.
B: Yes, you're right. It is really not good for her to learn dancing. Her leg hasn't completely recovered from that accident.
response: A: But she doesn't think so. She is crazy about photography. Will you take your camera with you tomorrow?

dialogue: A: Morning. Gail. Did you enjoy your holiday in the country?
B: Yes. We had a great time. And some friends went along with us.
A: Where did you stay? In a hotel?
response: B: No, we camped in a moving RV.  We cooked all our meal over an open fire.

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
B: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
response: A: No , please , Mom ! Don't make me gargle with saltwater !

dialogue: A: What are you here for today?
B: I need to fight this ticket that I got.
A: Is the arresting officer here?
B: Yes, he is, Your Honor.
A: Plead your case.
response: B: I was told by the officer that I ran a red light . That information is valid

dialogue: A: Are you enjoying your trip to New Orleans?
B: Oh, yes. I really like it here.
A: Would you like to do something tonight?
B: Sure. I'd love to.
A: Let's see. Have you been to a jazz club yet?
B: Yes. I've already been to several clubs here.
A: OK. What about an evening riverboat tour?
B: Uh, actually, I've gone twice this week.
A: So, what do you want to do?
B: Well, I haven't been to the theater in a long time.
A: Oh, OK. I hear there's a terrific show at the Sanger Theater.
response: B: Great! Let's make a reservation for dinner.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
A: Ok, I won't keep you then.
B: Great! It's good to see you. Goodbye!
response: A: Yes , stay in touch . Bye !

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.
A: How much will you be paid?
B: Judy, I don't do it for money, but for experience. Besides, it's voluntary work.
A: You work without payment? That's really something.
B: When will you leave for home?
response: A: Tomorrow. We'll fly to Hawaii two days after. I really have to pack now.

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
response: B: We thought we'd have that at the master bedroom and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.

dialogue: A: Did you hear the thunder last night?
B: Yes. I was awake at that time. It was really loud.
A: I didn't see any lightning though. I thought thunder and lightning always occur together.
B: What makes you believe that?
response: A: A science book says, when lightning quickly beats the air, it will cause thunder.

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
A: I have no other choice. Next month will be the most important exam of this term.
response: B: I can understand that. But anyway, you should take better care of yourself.

dialogue: A: Can I have my money back on this skirt?
B: Anything wrong with it?
A: Yes, this is defective. See? I didn't notice this hole when I bought it.
B: Oh, I'm very sorry about that. You can change it for another one if you prefer.
response: A: If you have exactly the same one-same color, same design, and same size, of course.

dialogue: A: Hello, Macy Agency.
B: Good morning. I'd like to book a return ticket from London to Paris on Monday, July 14th, please.
A: Yes, Madam. We have a flight at 14: 30, Is that suitable?
B: Oh, that's fine. And how much will that cost, please?
A: The price is $ 420 for the return flight.
B: Good. Which airport does the flight leave from?
response: A: It leaves from Heathrow Airport. Check in time is one hour before departure.

dialogue: A: Am I late?
B: No, you've got an hour and a quarter. Your flight leaves at 9:30.
A: I'm so excited.
B: Have you got everything?
response: A: Yes,but I forgot my tickets and my traveler's checks.

dialogue: A: What are you hiding in your coat pocket?
B: It's a camera.
A: You want to take pictures of the inside of your pocket?
B: Not even funny, Billy. This is my new snapshot sticker camera.
A: What's that supposed to mean?
response: B: Well , there are adhesive strips on the backs . You can stick them anywhere .

dialogue: A: Be careful.The floor is slippery.
B: Mom, there isn't any hot water
A: Turn on the shower.
response: B: It's getting hotter.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
response: B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go swimming and cycling by myself.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
response: A: Well , some people decided to jog last night

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. White. I wonder if you could spare a few minutes. I'd like to ask you a few questions.
B: Well, I can spare you a few minutes, but I'm very busy preparing for our exhibition, you know.
A: Just a few questions. Where is it going to be held?
response: B: It's going to be held in a dumpster behind the grocery store.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
response: A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is in at the moment.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Anything wrong?
B: I've been suffering from a fever since yesterday.
A: Do you have any other problems? Like a headache or cough?
B: No, I don't. I think it's only a fever.
A: Let me check... It's 39 degrees. I'll give you some medicine.
B: Thank you, doctor.
response: A: You'd better keep going and don't rest at all.

dialogue: A: What are you doing here?
B: I'm preparing my fishing tools.
A: What for?
B: I'm going to fish with some of my friends.
A: Are you fond of fishing?
B: Yes. I like fishing after school and on Sundays.
A: When did you get such a hobby?

B: Long ago. You know, my father is fond of and very good at fishing. When I was a child, he took me to the riverside to see him fishing. I found fishing very interesting then. Well, what's your hobby?
A: I'm very interested in making home movies. But I haven't got a movie camera.
B: I also like taking photos and I have a Japanese-made camera.
response: A: I take a lot of photos, too. But I'm more interested in the history of film, so I really enjoy using a film camera. I'll buy one of my own someday.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
response: B: my mouth gets watery whenever I see a tragic movie

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.
A: Well, that's a good idea and you come to the right place. Do you know what you like?
response: B: Well, I don't want a racer or a touring bike or anything like that. Mostly I'll just be using it to get me back and forth from work.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some gloves.
A: All our gloves are here. What do you think of this pair here? It's made of silk.
response: B: Hm, it looks ugly, but I'd like to have something warm for the winter.

dialogue: A: Harry, do you like the opera?
B: No, not really.
A: Why is that? It is called real art.
response: B: Well , it's very inexpensive and they're usually singing in another language . That kind of gets on my nerves .

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
B: No. Just occasionally.
A: What are your favourite dances?
B: I love rumba and waltz.
A: How about samba?
B: To tell the truth, I don't like it. It's too fast.
response: A: Then I'll see you at six. Is that all right?

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
A: Why is a computer so useful?
B: It can keep much information and work very fast.
A: Then they can do a lot of work for us.
response: B: You are right. They have greatly changed our lives.

dialogue: A: Good morning. So this is the first day for you to work here, I hope you'll like your job.
B: Good morning, Ms.Wilson. I've got a lot to learn from you. I think I'll enjoy working with you.
A: I hope so. Now let me tell you your duties here. This is your desk. Please sit down.
B: Thank you.
A: Your main duty is to answer the phone calls and transfer them to the person wanted.
B: I see. What if the person wanted is out?
response: A: In that case , you are supposed to leave a message for the caller.

dialogue: A: Well, Jenny, the school year is almost over. We just have two more weeks before exams. What do you plan to do this summer?
B: I'm going to teach English to some immigrants in the university's community service program.
A: That sounds interesting. Don't you need to speak a foreign language for a job like that?
B: No, you don't. You just have to present the language simply and give the students a chance to practice speaking.
A: Come to think of it, that's the way I was taught to speak Chinese. But speaking didn't help me learn to read and write Chinese.
B: My students won't want to read and write English, at lease not now. They are more interested in speaking.
A: You sound very knowledgeable about all this. How do you know so much?
response: B: I took a Teaching English as a Second Language course last year when you were in China. I've also talked with the experienced doctors quite a lot. I think I would like to be an ESL teacher when I graduate.

dialogue: A: Can I help you, Sir?
B: Yes, I'd like to withdraw some money.
A: Fill in the slip, stating the exact amount you wish to withdraw, please.
B: OK. Here's my bank book, is that all right?
A: OK, do you want large notes or small ones?
B: In 50 Yuan or 100 Yuan would be fine.
response: A: Here's the tickets for you.

dialogue: A: Have you got some nice apples in stock today?
B: What about these? They are very fresh and exceptionally juicy.
A: Are they sweet?
response: B: Very sweet .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.
A: How much will you be paid?
B: Judy, I don't do it for money, but for experience. Besides, it's voluntary work.
A: You work without payment? That's really something.
B: When will you leave for home?
response: A: Tomorrow. We'll fly to see a movie about Hawaii two days after. I really have to pack now.

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
response: B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on fire too.

dialogue: A: Today in the studio we have Alberto Cortez, the well-known Brazilian advocate of the anti-global movement. He's here to talk about the recent report, stating that by 2050 Brazil will be the one ot the word's wealthiest and most successful countries. Alberto, what do you say to the report?
B: You know this isn't the first time that people are saying Brazil will be a great economic power. The same thing was said over a hundred year ago. But it didn't happen.
A: Yes, but you must admit the world's a very different place now.
B: Of course. In fact I believe there's maybe some truth in the prediction this time around. First of all, though, we must remember the problems facing Brazil at the moment.
A: Such as...?
response: B: There's an imperceptible gap between the rich and the poor in this country. In Sal Paulo, you can see shopping malls full of designer goods right next door to the slam areas without proper water and electricity supplies. A lot of work needs to be done to help people in those areas improve their lives.

dialogue: A: Hello. This is Amy.
B: Hello, Amy. This is Tom.
A: Yes. What can I do for you?
B: I want to go to New York by train today. Would you please look up a train time for me?
A: Certainly, Hold on, please. Um... there's one at eleven p. m. It's a little late. Why don't you go there by car?
response: B: My car is being repaired now. I don't have to go there by train.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I go to a movie this week with Shannon?
B: Let me look at the calendar here. Hmm. When are you thinking about going to a movie?
A: Uh, we're thinking about seeing a movie on Wednesday after school.
B: Well, that's not going to work. You haven't practiced your piano at all for an entire week, so you have to catch up on that.
A: What about Friday?
B: Uh uh. Forget that idea.
A: And Saturday?

B: Well, you have to take an English class in the morning. And then, we have to clean out the garage. You said you'd help. Well, that should only take a couple of hours. And then, after that, you can go to the movie.
A: Yeah. Can I go and see the nine o'clock showing?
B: The five o'clock showing!
A: How about the seven o'clock showing?
B: And why are you so concerned about the show time?
response: A: Well, I don't know if I'll get all of my homework done before then.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.
B: Uh. I didn't have any of that when I was in middle school, and I did just fine.
A: Yeah, and there weren't any cars either. Things are a lot more progressive now.
response: B: Great. My daughter will be playing video games in class.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: This is my first day here.
A: Are you a freshman in college?
B: I started school somewhere else.
response: A: What school did you graduate from?

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
response: B: She's very sick of detective stories

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. Er, I'm phoning about the job that was in the paper last night.
A: Oh, yes. Could you tell me your name?
B: Oh, Jerry Lynn.
A: Well, what exactly is it that interests you about the job?
response: B: I just thought that it was completely out of my skill set, you know.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.
A: Well, Mr Strunk, I enjoy my work very much.
response: B: To show that I appreciate all your efforts, I'm going to give you a demotion. I hope you don't object.

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
B: But I didn't hear it at all.
A: What time did you set it for last night?
B: Six o'clock.
response: A: Slow down, or you'll be too early for school. Are you feeling ill?

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
response: B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was not killed in that bombing.

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
response: A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite smart, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
B: I'd like her to have a change.
response: A: Then how do you like this extra value sized one?

dialogue: A: We want to take a train to New York.
B: Regular or express train?
A: How much time would I save if we took the express?
B: About one hour. The next express train arrives in New York at 3:15.
A: And how much more do I have to pay for the express?
B: First class is 24 dollars more, and second class is 15 dollars more.
response: A: As long as we can arrive two hours earlier, I don't mind paying a little extra. Then give me one second class ticket on the express, please.

dialogue: A: He has come to life in the end.
B: Oh, thank God. We all felt frightened by the bad news about him.
A: Yes. Fortunately, an ambulance passed in the nick of time, and we got him away to hospital.
B: Right. Unless, who know what will happen.
response: A: Wish him to be dead soon .

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
B: You did? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered.
A: Oh, the telephone lines were damaged by the storm. They repaired them yesterday.
B: What did David do yesterday? Did he and Judy go dancing?
response: A: No , they stayed home and played cards with the children .

dialogue: A: By the way, would you like to go to the movies this evening?
B: I'd love to. But I must write some emails.
A: Why tonight?
B: I haven't written to anyone for months. Sylvia and John must think I've forgotten them.
A: You don't have to write. You can call them tomorrow. It's half price on Sundays.
response: B: Yes, I could, couldn't I? All right. I'll do that. What's playing then?

dialogue: A: Bill, I must tell you the truth. You failed the English exam again.
B: Ah? Really? That stinks!
A: Haha. April Fool's! Did you forget what day it is today?
B: Wow, you were pulling my leg all along. I was really fooled.
response: A: Alright, now let's be serious. Actually, you get high marks in the exam.

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.
response: A: You could've stolen some change from a store.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.
A: Well, Mr Strunk, I enjoy my work very much.
response: B: To show that I appreciate all your efforts, I'm going to give you a warning. I hope you don't hate it.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
A: How awful! Was he hurt?
B: Yes. He was taken to the hospital in an ambulance.
A: How did it happen?
response: B: His car was completely missed an express train . It happened at the crossing just behind his house .

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
B: I'd love to, but when?
A: How about Saturday morning? It's cooler in the morning and maybe less crowded.
B: I'm afraid I can not get up early on weekends. I'd prefer Saturday afternoon. Believe me there won't be too many people.
A: So, shall we meet at 2:00, Saturday afternoon?
response: B: OK, that would be great. I'll be waiting for you at the museum.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. What can I do for you?
A: I'd like a ticket to New York, please.
response: B: All year round?

dialogue: A: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock.
B: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning.
A: Why? What's wrong with you?
B: I felt pain all over my body. Can you get me some medicine?
A: Will aspirin do?
B: No, aspirin isn't strong enough.
response: A: Then I can do nothing but call for a doctor.

dialogue: A: He has come to life in the end.
B: Oh, thank God. We all felt frightened by the bad news about him.
A: Yes. Fortunately, an ambulance passed in the nick of time, and we got him away to hospital.
B: Right. Unless, who know what will happen.
response: A: Wish him to be healthy soon .

dialogue: A: Hello! Do you have a place where I can exercise?
B: Yes, sir. We have a fine exercise facility.
A: I'm happy to hear that. Now, would you tell me where it is?
B: You're actually standing above it. Just take the elevator or stairs down one level.
A: Is the hotel going to charge me a dollar a minute for gym use?
B: No, sir. There's no extra charge. All you need is your room key to open the door.
A: And the gym hours are?
B: Sir, you'll be pleased to know that our gym never closes.
response: A: One more question , Do you have a trainer ?

dialogue: A: Are you ready?
B: Ready for what?
A: Ready for the big switch.
B: What are you talking about?
A: The nation is switching to digital TV.
B: Oh. Of course I'm ready.
response: A: Did you buy the converter?
