dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
response: A: There is a car, a house, and an airplane.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
A: So it doesn't really hold your interest?
response: B: No, not really. I wouldn't bother with it, to be honest, but I have to read it with a baby. I'm at a university.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
B: But he is usually correct in his weather news.
response: A: The temperature is 32t this afternoon. I'm sure we'll have snowy and cold weather for our picnic.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
B: You're right. But I really had a happy vacation.
A: OK, Maybe you can move into Kelly's house and share that with her for a couple of months.
B: Thank you. But I don't want to bother you too much.
A: No trouble at all.
response: B: How much should I pay for the friendship?

dialogue: A: Dad, can I have a pet? I did what you said and passed all of my exams.
B: Then I guess you get to have a pet. Do you know what you want?
A: I want a dog. My friend Mindy's dog just had puppies and she said I can have one.
response: B: You know who will be ignoring the animals and not being responsible and all of that stuff?

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
response: A: So you could have made it. But you were still late for class.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, Sir?
B: May I have the menu, please?
A: Yes, here you go.
B: I'd like to have some local specialties. Would you recommend for me, please?
A: Sure, the Huanghe carp with sugar and vinegar is famous in our restaurant.
B: OK. We'll take it.
A: Anything else?
B: A fried crisp chicken and an eggplant with chili sauce.
A: How about drink?
response: B: Rancid milk, only rancid milk.

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
B: I did. I called you many times, but you had your mobile phone power off.
A: Oh, I didn't bring it with me because I left it recharging at home.
response: B: I'm really sorry to have watched the film.

dialogue: A: Has Alan shown up yet?
B: Nope. I guess something might have come up.
A: I wonder what happened.
B: I don't know. I hope it's nothing serious.
A: Last week his sister was admitted to the hospital.
B: Oh? What happened?
A: His sister had a car accident last week.
B: Is she fine now?
response: A: She is on a road trip again.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.
A: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of strong and comfortable shoes.
B: What's your suggestion?
A: Maybe you should buy him a pair of leather shoes.
B: Tom doesn't like leather shoes.
response: A: Then, how about sports shoes? They are strong and comfortable.

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
response: B: The music group? I can't stand the quiet and out of the way places. Now where's the menu?

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
B: I get a lump in my throat whenever I see a tragic movie.
response: A: Tragic movie? I think it's a comedy.

dialogue: A: What are you working on?
B: I'm figuring out my budget.
A: What budget?
B: I'm making a shopping budget, so that I don't spend too much money.
A: How much money can you spend?
B: I can only spend $ 300 a month.
A: Why only $ 300?
B: I need to save the rest.
A: For what?
response: B: I need to pay my bills .

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?
response: A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram too little specialized information.

dialogue: A: Are you packing for another trip?
B: Yeah. On Saturday, I'm flying to Toronto.
A: Is this another engineering conference for work?
response: B: Yes - I'm meeting with my new mother-in-law. But I earned so many miles by traveling for work that the ticket was free.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, Is there an airline flying to New York this afternoon?
B: Sorry, sir. I can't sell you a ticket. Our computer is down.
A: If your computer is down, just write me a ticket.
B: Sorry, I can't. The computer is the only one allowed doing so.
A: Hmm... Then what do all you people do?
response: B: We give the government the information about your trip, and then they will tells us whether you can fly with us or not.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
response: B: But he is usually not right in his weather news.

dialogue: A: Are you ready?
B: Ready for what?
A: Ready for the big switch.
B: What are you talking about?
response: A: The nation is sticking to digital TV.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go swimming and cycling by myself.
response: A: Oh, I forgot about that. I go cycling sometimes too. And I often go swimming on vacation, but only recreational swimming.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for myself.
A: Oh? Did you talk with her about it?
response: B: I've tried, but it worked great.

dialogue: A: Hello, Jane. This is Peter speaking.
B: Hi, how are you?
A: Fine. And I've got some great news for you.
B: Really? What's it about?
response: A: I remember you are interested in watching golf games. The Houston Open will be closed from May 26 to May 30. I'm sure you will be glad to miss the game.

dialogue: A: What's going on around here? Why is everyone changing offices?
B: Haven't you heard? Where have you been anyway?
A: I just got back from visiting the plant in Chicago.
B: Well, there are a lot of changes being made here this week.
A: Yes, I see. But what are they?
B: For one thing, Martha and Jim are leaving.
A: Where are they going?Did they get a higher position?
B: Martha's going to the office in Atlanta. She is going to be in charge of the whole southern market.
A: That sounds like a good position to me. What about Jim?
B: He is going to manage the plant in California.
A: And you? What about you? Are you going to rise to a higher position?
B: Not yet, but I'm hoping I will.
A: Don't you want to get a raise? I'd like the job in California.
response: B: No, I want to go far away from the company office. This is the place to get noticed by top management.

dialogue: A: Did you hear what Fred did last night?
B: No,not yet. What happened to him?
A: I guess he was a little drunk and he had a fight with his brother. Well, he got so mad that he drove his car straight into the front of a drugstore.
B: What do you mean?
A: I mean he drove inside. The front of the store was completely destroyed. I actually saw it just now as I walked by. The car is still inside the store.
B: I'm afraid Fred is in trouble. Where is he now?
response: A: I hear he's in the police station. It's lucky no one was hurt.

dialogue: A: Hi, John. What are you doing here?
B: I'm waiting for the bus.
A: Where are you going?
response: B: I'm going to the station to meet my sister.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
response: B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my knife.

dialogue: A: Honey, how long have we been living here?
B: About 10 years. What's wrong?
A: I am thinking about redecorating our house.
B: That would cost a lot of money. But we do need to do some changes to the house.
A: Right. What about repainting the living room in yellow?
B: Good idea. I like the countryside style.
A: Great minds think the same. And we can also ask someone to draw a picture on the wall.
B: It sounds great. And the curtain should be changed too.
response: A: OK. Maybe we should make a blue software program first.

dialogue: A: Hey, I'm calling to say that I'm running late to the airport. Can you make sure that the plane doesn't take off without me?
B: I'll try.
A: Thank you. I'm just sitting here in traffic. There must be an accident or something. I've been here for 30 minutes, and I've barely made it onto the bridge.
B: Oh, that's not good.
response: A: This traffic is really making me relaxed. I don't want to have to take a later flight!

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
B: No, but you can see that the point is bent a little bit.
response: A: Yes, it is, isn't it? We'd be happy to exchange it for you. But I'm afraid we have many other purple ones. We also have this pen in black and yellow now.

dialogue: A: Do you have a driver's license?
B: No. I am going to take the test in a couple of weeks.
A: Didn't you drive in your own country?
B: Yes. But I have to be more skilled.
response: A: And you have to study the bible too.

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
response: B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet dreams too.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
A: Your son's fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.
B: Yes, that's right. As soon as you've done what's necessary for buying the land, Jerry and I will see an architect.
A: Have you found a plot yet?
response: B: Jerry was in Edinburgh last Saturday and saw a plot he likes. My wife and I went there two days ago, and we liked it, too. I'd like you to make the necessary inquiries for me.

dialogue: A: Hello, Dora, I haven't seen you for a long time. Where have you been?
B: I didn ’ t go anywhere. I stayed at home.
A: What's up? You look unhappy.
B: Nothing. I just feel very lonely in this city. I miss my family.
A: Oh, I know. Sometimes I have the same feeling with you. But you'd better not be so emotional.
response: B: Can you stay and accompany me for a while ?

dialogue: A: Hello, this is Jonason speaking.
B: Hello, Jonason, I am Kasy. I am sorry to tell you that I may not attend your birthday party this weekend.
A: Oh, what's up?
B: Nothing much.., but...
A: What's happened then?
B: I have an important exam at that time.
response: A: If so, I think we can hold the party two years from now. What do you think about it?

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
response: B: You can't get wine and beer in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.

dialogue: A: Waitress! I think there's something wrong with our bill.
B: No, I don't think so...$10 for the drinks, 15 for the small plate, and 20 for the main dish.
A: What? I knew the cheese sticks were 15. I always order cheese sticks, but I thought the main dish was $10.
B: Oh, that explains it. You think the bill should be $35.
A: Yes, exactly. I was wondering what happened to the rest of my change. I should have gotten back 15, not 5!
B: I understand. Sometimes people aren't honest, but I think this was an honest mistake. Didn't you order the sea cucumbers for dinner?
A: Yes, and they were delicious. Best cucumbers ever! I'm so glad I'm a vegetarian.
B: Sir, I am so sorry. Have you ordered sea cucumbers before? They aren't vegetables, you know.
A: Really? I thought it was a vegetable that grew in the ocean.
response: B: No. They're vegetables.

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
response: A: No, I don't. I mean a general practitioner. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, Is there an airline flying to New York this afternoon?
B: Sorry, sir. I can't sell you a ticket. Our computer is down.
A: If your computer is down, just write me a ticket.
response: B: Sorry, I can't. The computer is the only one allowed doing so.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman said it will.
B: I don't think he's right. It hasn't rained for a week.
A: But he is usually right in his weather news.
response: B: I'm sure we'll have fine weather for our picnic.

dialogue: A: Hi, honey. Do you need any help with your luggage?
B: No, thanks, dad. I just brought one carry-on in my backpack.
A: Great. I wish your mother would take some packing lessons from you. OK, let's go home.
B: Hm...It's cold here.
response: A: Yes, the weatherman says that it might snow tonight. What temperature was it when you took off from California this morning?

dialogue: A: Happy anniversary, sweetheart!
B: Yes. to our first anniversary and many more to come. Cheers!
A: I'll drink to that. Thanks for making this a night worth remembering.
response: B: Well , there isn't much that's special about the day . They say if you survive the first year , the rest is smooth sailing .

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
response: A: I have a really small geography test and I don't have to study for it.

dialogue: A: Any messages, Miss Grey?
B: Just one, Mr. Blank. You had a telephone call from someone called Brown, David Brown.
A: Brown? I don't seem to know anyone called Brown. What did he say?
B: He wouldn't say. But it sounded important. I told him you'd phone him as soon as you got back.
response: A: Well, I'd better do it then, I suppose. It's okay if you don't have his phone number.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
response: A: No, but we can get your package to England in one week for 40 dollars.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for myself.
A: Oh? Did you talk with her about it?
B: I've tried, but it didn't work.
A: Oh, so, when are you going to tell her?
B: Maybe tonight. I don't know. I don't know how to tell her.
response: A: I know she is head over heels not in love with you. She'll be badly hurt!

dialogue: A: Well, you know I had a good time tonight.
B: I'm pleased to hear that.
A: But I have to say goodbye right now.
B: Why? It's not late. Can't you stay a little longer?
response: A: No, I'm sorry, but I really must stay. I know I can catch the last bus even if I don't hurry now.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
A: However,you must show us the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?
B: OK.
A: All right. Keep your receipt. If something comes up. you can show it to us and We'll give you a refund.
response: B: Thanks. I'll put it in a careless and open place.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon. I'm looking for a second-hand car and I believe you sell cars.
B: Yes. I have one here that may interest you.
A: Ah, yes. A friend told me about it. What make is it?
B: It's a Lincoln.
A: Is it MS 560 or MF 558? I don't want either of them. I want a MF 650 one.
B: Oh, it's the one you want, and it's three years old.
A: Mmm... hmm. And what sort of condition is it in?
B: It's in very good condition and it's compact.
A: Right. And how much are you asking for it?
B: Three thousand and fifteen dollars.
A: Three thousand and fifteen dollars? That's a lot of money for a second-hand car.
B: But it's in excellent condition.
response: A: Could I try out a new car?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
B: About 20 minutes at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.
response: A: I'd better go there by bus. By the way, where is the bus stop, please?

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
B: I did. I called you many times, but you had your mobile phone power off.
A: Oh, I didn't bring it with me because I left it recharging at home.
response: B: I'm really sorry to have seen the film.

dialogue: A: What do you usually do in your spare time?
B: I have joined a singing group and we practice two afternoons each week.
A: That's a very interesting thing to do.
B: Yes. It's a small group of only fifteen girls and boys. But nobody has been late for the practice.
A: I see. How many songs can you sing now?
B: We started only three months ago, but we've practiced eight songs.
A: Are you going to perform any time?
response: B: Yes, there will be a school exam next month and we are going to volunteer in it. We are practicing a new song now. It's written by one of the singers in our group

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
A: No, what you need is balance.
B: Could you teach me how to do it?
A: Sure, anytime when you are free.
response: B: Do I have to buy a pair of high heels?

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a letter.
response: B: There's a tank up the street. Have you already got a stamp on that letter?

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
response: A: It would be nice to walk only in the city . Do you want some company ?

dialogue: A: Did you hear about the air crash that occurred in South America recently? It was quite a tragic accident!
B: No, I didn't see anything in the news about it. What happened?
A: A foreign airliner was attempting to land at night in a mountainous area in Argentina and flew into a hill!
B: That sounds really terrible! Did anyone survive?
response: A: No, everyone aboard, including the crew, was killed instantly.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
response: A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.
A: How much will you be paid?
response: B: Judy, I do it for money, but not for experience. Besides, it's voluntary work

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
B: I'd like her to have a change.
A: Then how do you like this plum red one?
response: B: It is nice . Is it full of water ?

dialogue: A: Good afternoon. I'm looking for a second-hand car and I believe you sell cars.
B: Yes. I have one here that may interest you.
A: Ah, yes. A friend told me about it. What make is it?
B: It's a Lincoln.
A: Is it MS 560 or MF 558? I don't want either of them. I want a MF 650 one.
B: Oh, it's the one you want, and it's three years old.
A: Mmm... hmm. And what sort of condition is it in?
response: B: It's in very good condition and it's not compact.

dialogue: A: What can I do for you?
B: I'd like to exchange this sweater.
A: What seems to be the matter?
B: Well, you see I got this as a birthday present, but it's the wrong size, and what's more, I really don't like the colour.
response: A: Do I already have your receipt?

dialogue: A: Betty, something is burning. Can you smell it?
B: You ’ re right.
A: Look! The iron is still on.
response: B: I should have turned it on. I ’ ll turn it off now.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
response: B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.

dialogue: A: Well, the salad's almost ready. How's the beef going? I'm starving.
B: So am I. The beef looks just about ready. Just one minute... ow!
A: What's the matter?
B: Oh, my finger, I burned my finger!
response: A: Oh, wait, I'll get some ice and put it on your finger.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.
A: How much will you be paid?
B: Judy, I don't do it for money, but for experience. Besides, it's voluntary work.
A: You work without payment? That's really something.
B: When will you leave for home?
response: A: Tomorrow. We'll fly home two days after. I really have to pack now.

dialogue: A: Did you hear how cold it got last night?
B: I heard the radio announcer say it was 18 degrees below zero.
A: It was so cold this morning. I could hardly start my car.
response: B: My car wanted to start right away too.

dialogue: A: Could I have a word with you, Madam?
B: Is that you, Janice? Just speaking.
A: I have to tell you that I can't be in today and tomorrow.
B: So sorry to hear that. What's wrong with you?
A: I feel sick and coughed a lot at night.
B: Is that serious? You ought to see a doctor.
A: Yes, I did this in the morning. And my doctor wanted me to have a rest these two days.
B: That's good. Do you suppose you will be back at company the day after tomorrow?
A: I hope so. And I will definitely tell you if I can not.
response: B: Well, take care of yourself. And hope you will be better as soon as possible.

dialogue: A: Well, Jenny, the school year is almost over. We just have two more weeks before exams. What do you plan to do this summer?
B: I'm going to teach English to some immigrants in the university's community service program.
A: That sounds interesting. Don't you need to speak a foreign language for a job like that?
B: No, you don't. You just have to present the language simply and give the students a chance to practice speaking.
A: Come to think of it, that's the way I was taught to speak Chinese. But speaking didn't help me learn to read and write Chinese.
B: My students won't want to read and write English, at lease not now. They are more interested in speaking.
A: You sound very knowledgeable about all this. How do you know so much?
response: B: I took a Teaching English as a Second Language course last year when you were in China. I've also talked with the experienced teachers quite a lot. I think I would like to be an ESL teacher when I graduate.

dialogue: A: By the way, would you like to go to the movies this evening?
B: I'd love to. But I must write some emails.
A: Why tonight?
B: I haven't written to anyone for months. Sylvia and John must think I've forgotten them.
A: You don't have to write. You can call them tomorrow. It's half price on Sundays.
response: B: Yes, I could, couldn't I? All right. I'll do that. Which band is playing then?

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
response: B: He works in an office. He dances and sings while writing letters and reports, and he types.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, could you tell me where the post office is?
B: Post office? It's not far from here. Do you know Xinhua Road?
A: I'm from the United States and this is my first trip to your city. I know nothing about the city.
response: B: Oh, welcome back to our city, I'll show you the new road. Please follow me.

dialogue: A: Fikky, what's going on? Freggis just told me that you're going to be leaving us.
B: Yes, I really feel bad out of it. But B. N. D. came up with really good offer.
A: Well, I didn't know you were going to look for a new job.
response: B: Well, just between you and me. I think we have some really great people and great successes in this department. Don't get me wrong. It has nothing to do with you, Frank. Everybody says you are an excellent manager.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, it looks like you've got some sun this weekend.
B: Yeah, I guess so. I spent the weekend at the beach.
A: Oh, yeah, that's great. Where did you stay?
B: Some friends of my parents' live out there and they invited me for as long as I wanted to stay.
A: So what are you doing back here already?
response: B: Oh, I have a paper to draw on, and I just couldn't do any serious sketching at the house.

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
B: But I don't have a car and I can't drive. Is there any other way to travel?
A: You can travel by bus. It's very cheap.
B: Can't I travel by train?
response: A: Yes, you can. The train is cheap in the States, but it's fast.

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: Yes, my nephew Jim is graduating from college next week and I'd like to get him a nice gift.
A: What price are you interested in? We'll need toknow that before we begin looking.
B: Well. I usually spend about twenty do Ham for a gift. Do you have anything nice for that price?
A: How about a pen?
B: No, my brother gave him that for his bithday last year.
A: Well, then would he enjoy a chess set?
response: B: No, he doesn't like chess very much, but he is quite athletic.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
response: B: Light pink .

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
B: Will you buy an exercise book for me?
A: I guess so. But I'll go to the post office first before I go to the supermarket.
response: B: Can you also buy me a pen? The one you gave me last week doesn't work now.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I see your boarding pass, please?
B: Here you are.
A: Excuse me, sir. This is your passport.
B: Really? Ugh... Is there any difference?
A: Yes. As a matter of fact, you can't board the plane without boarding pass.
B: Gee. I must have left it in my hotel room.
response: A: No problem sir . I can let you pass .

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
response: A: Less than two years old.

dialogue: A: Hi. May I help you?
B: Yeah. I'd like to rent these movies.
A: Okay. Do you have your membership card?
B: No I don't. Do I need one to rent videos here?
response: A: Yes, and it's free.

dialogue: A: Well, this must be the National Library.
B: I guess so. Oh, no! I don't think it's open today. Look, it says "Closed Tuesdays".
A: Well, we'll just have to come back tomorrow.
response: B: But we're supposed to go on that tour in two weeks.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Please come into my office.
B: Good morning. Thank you.
A: I see that you have some impressive writing experience.
response: B: Yes . this is my first time writing for a top newspapers in the country . I'm also having no knowledge of writing novel

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
A: May I borrow your pen?
B: Here's a pen for you.
A: Thanks for your help.
response: B: You need to turn this in at Window B, and then they'll ask you questions to prompt you to fill it out.

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
response: B: I'm going to try to find a restaurant near the office.

dialogue: A: Diana's Flowers, Diana Lin's office, may I help you?
B: Is Diana in?
A: No, she's out for lunch. May I take a message?
B: Yes, please ask her to call John Smith.
response: A: Ok, I'll make sure she doesn't get the message.

dialogue: A: Look! It's snowing. Winter is here at last.
B: It's really cold today.
A: Yes, you have to get used to it. The weather's going to be like this for the next three months.
B: Then I'm going to Florida. Can you tell me about your weather diary? Why do you make notes about the different types of weather?
response: A: Because it's interesting to see what the weather is like at different times and on different days. For example, we had very interesting weather on the 28th of April.

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.
response: A: You could've gotten some groceries in a store.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. What can I do for you?
B: I want some coffee.
A: Certainly, madam. What kind of coffee do you want to have?
B: What have you got?
A: Well. We have espresso, latte, skinny latte, fancy coffee and Americano.
B: I think I'll have a latte, please.
response: A: OK . Wait a minute , please . And the mayo is right over there .

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?
response: A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in absolutely no specialized information.

dialogue: A: When do you take your winter holiday?
B: I usually take it during the second or third week of January.
A: Do you like to ski?
B: Yes, I love to go skiing.
A: Where do you go?
B: I go to a hotel in the mountains.
A: Is it far from here?
B: It's about a hundred miles away.
A: Does it get cold?
B: Oh, yes! It gets very cold. It snows a lot.
A: Do you go alone?
B: A couple of my friends usually go with me. Do you want to come along some weekend?
A: No, not me. I don't like cold weather.
response: B: I really like it. I love snow!

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.
response: B: Then your two boys would need to share a room. They are happy with it?

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.
A: I want to be a vet.
B: A-what?
A: A vet-a veterinary surgeon.
B: Good gracious! What's that?
response: A: A vet's a man who makes animals sick. He's an animal doctor.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
response: B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for a hot summer day, but I'd like to have something warm for winter.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote this Tuesday?
B: Yes, I am, and I am so excited.
A: Have you figured out who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I love my candidate.
A: Why is that?
response: B: My candidate is probably not the most intelligent.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
response: B: I caught hold of his knife, and he pushed me to the floor.

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent three hours on it.
A: By the way, what time did you go home?
B: I left the office at nine o'clock. I got home at ten.
A: What did have for dinner?
response: B: I sent out for a sandwich and ate at home.

dialogue: A: Do you know how to play tennis?
B: Not very well. But I'd love to learn.
A: Would you like to play with me tomorrow morning?
B: Certainly, but I'm not very good.
response: A: We'll see about that. Anyway, you know that practice makes perfect.

dialogue: A: Have you any plan for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, Laura. I'm going for a ride around the Qinghai Lake on Saturday, but it depends on the weather.
A: According to the forecast, it'll be cloudy the day after tomorrow, good for a ride.
B: Great! Do you go riding often?
A: Absolutely. I go as much as I can, because we can really get in touch with nature. It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want any company?
B: Sure, but it will be a 30-mile ride. Have you been riding so long before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I even saw a bear and some monkeys on my last ride. My friend Mike and I rode more than 30 miles to a very wild part of the national forest.
response: B: Wow! You must have been right downtown in the city. Shall we invite him to go along?

dialogue: A: Where is Jimmy? Why hasn't he come down for breakfast? Needn't he go to school today?
B: He's still in bed in his room.
A: What's the matter with our dear son?
response: B: He's feeling great. I think he must have caught a bad cold.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
response: B: How nice! How many office cubicles does it have?

dialogue: A: What are you working on?
B: I'm figuring out my budget.
A: What budget?
B: I'm making a shopping budget, so that I don't spend too much money.
A: How much money can you spend?
B: I can only spend $ 300 a month.
A: Why only $ 300?
B: I need to save the rest.
A: For what?
response: B: I have already paid my bills.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
response: B: No I didn't. It made me laugh a lot

dialogue: A: Hello, I'm returning your phone call.
B: I'm glad that you could get back to me so fast.
A: No problem, but what were you calling about?
B: I needed to talk to you about your son.
A: Is he messing up in school?
B: He was acting up in class one day last week.
A: What was he doing?
response: B: He doesn't talk throughout the class.

dialogue: A: Bob, did you see our supervisor? I need him to sign this paper.
B: He is in his office, but you'd better choose your words carefully while talking to him.
A: What's up?
response: B: Nothing.  I am wondering why he is in a good mood today.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
A: However,you must show us the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?
B: OK.
A: All right. Keep your receipt. If something comes up. you can show it to us and We'll give you a refund.
response: B: Thanks. I'll put it in a safe place.

dialogue: A: What's the matter, Bill? You look kind of pale.
B: Oh, I'm just tired.
A: Why?
B: Well, I've been working until around ten every night this week.
response: A: You should go home at quitting time today and take it easy.

dialogue: A: Did you have your television repaired?
B: Yes, but not by the place you recommended
A: Why not? The repair is very good and thecharges are so reasonable.
B: That may be, but I couldn't find it.
A: But you couldn't miss it. I told you the first right after the railroad bridge.
B: I took that. I went to the end of the road. There is no such a place.
A: Wait a minute. Perhaps it is the second right. Yes. I think it is.
B: I should have known. Whenever someone says "You can't miss it", you can be sure that you won't find it.
response: A: I'm really sorry for my bad body odor.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Could I be of any service to you?
B: Have you got any Chinese paintings?
A: Yes, we have landscape paintings, figure paintings and flower-and-bird paintings.
B: I'd like a flower-and-bird painting.
A: Good. How about this picture of cranes with pine trees? It was painted by a famous Chinese painter in King Dynasty.
B: Oh, they look just like live cranes. I like this picture very much. How much is it?
A: One thousand dollars.
response: B: It's a lot of money . But the picture is excellent , I'll take it .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Could I be of any service to you?
B: Have you got any Chinese paintings?
A: Yes, we have landscape paintings, figure paintings and flower-and-bird paintings.
B: I'd like a flower-and-bird painting.
A: Good. How about this picture of cranes with pine trees? It was painted by a famous Chinese painter in King Dynasty.
B: Oh, they look just like live cranes. I like this picture very much. How much is it?
A: One thousand dollars.
response: B: It's not a lot of money . But the picture is excellent , I'll take it .

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
A: Nobody to take care of her?
response: B: My father travels a lot to many countries and he is doing business in Dubai now. I never have to care for my mom at all.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
response: A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just started Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.

dialogue: A: Do you know Tom?
B: Tom what?
A: Tom Smith.
B: No. But I know a Tim Smith.
A: Oh, yes, you are right. It was Tim Smith I meant. You know what happened to him the other day?
B: No, what happened then?
A: Well, he told me he saw his dead grandfather in London.
B: Oh, come on. You are not telling a ghost story, are you?
A: But he told me it was true. You see, his grandfather used to be an army officer during the war. And because he didn't return home after the war, everybody thought he had been killed in the war.
B: But then, he suddenly appeared alive, like in those films.
response: A: Exactly. Tom, oh no, Tim, told me that by chance he saw an old man at the railway station selling newspapers. And he was surprised to see someone like his grandfather in a picture he had seen. So naturally he went to the man and asked him whether his name was Smith. And the man, I mean, his grandfather, said yes, and after that everything happened just like a film.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
response: B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown, so I'll summarize it.

dialogue: A: Dad, when will you finish your cooking?
B: Several minutes.
A: So what should I do now?
B: Then, pass me a bowl for the soup.
A: Where's the bowl gone?
B: Look for it yourself, please! Kinda busy here, Daniel!
A: Dad?
B: Check the drawer.
A: OK, got it, but its shape is so strange. I don't like it.
response: B: Can it hold soup?

dialogue: A: My mother got really annoyed with my father yesterday evening.
B: Why? Did she complain about his cooking?
A: Oh no. It was about watching television.
B: Don't tell me he fell asleep in front of the television.
response: A: No, he kept changing channels on the computer.

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: Yes, my nephew Jim is graduating from college next week and I'd like to get him a nice gift.
A: What price are you interested in? We'll need toknow that before we begin looking.
B: Well. I usually spend about twenty do Ham for a gift. Do you have anything nice for that price?
A: How about a pen?
B: No, my brother gave him that for his bithday last year.
A: Well, then would he enjoy a chess set?
response: B: No, he likes chess very much, and he is quite athletic.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, well, I bought this tie last week for my husband's birthday, and er...well he doesn't like it. Could I change it for something else, such as a shirt or a hat?
A: Certainly, madam, provided that it hasn't been worn, and if you have the receipt.
B: Yes, here it is.
response: A: OK, er... this tie looks as if it were worn. I'm afraid I can't put that back on the shelf.

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.
response: A: You could've gotten some change in a pay phone.

dialogue: A: Haven't seen you for a long time
B: I've been away on a vacation.
A: I bet you had a wonderful time
response: B: Yeah , beautiful sunshine , pleasant scenery and many new friends

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
B: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
response: A: No , please , Mom ! Don't make me bathe with saltwater !

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
response: A: The Fools Garden no longer exists.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
B: I'm an English major and this is a required course. But now I'm in trouble because I'm not sure I can afford this book.
response: A: Hey, I've got an idea. Why don't we buy two and have our own book?

dialogue: A: What did you think of the lecture?
B: I thought it was very interesting.
A: Did you really?
B: Yes, didn't you?
A: Certainly not. I thought he talked a lot of rubbish.
B: So you think you know more than he does.
A: Well, take coal for instance.
B: What about it?
A: Coal won't become important again.
B: Why not?
response: A: It's not dirty enough. They won't have enough work for people in coal mines in the future.

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.
A: Well whatever, can we repeat our offer to run the campaign for 4 extra weeks?
response: B: That's not really the point. The campaign missed two key trade affairs. Because of this, we are asking you either to repeat the campaign in 5 years for free, or we only pay 50% of the fee for this year.

dialogue: A: Hi, John. What are you doing here?
B: I'm waiting for the bus.
A: Where are you going?
response: B: I'm going to the station to meet my dog.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that Susan got married?
B: Really? I remember she said if she would remain single. Is the man very rich?
A: No. That ’ s what is surprising me.
B: You means she didn ’ t marry a rich man.
response: A: He ’ s a postman.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you take me to the airport?
B: Which airport, ma'am?
A: Kennedy Airport.
B: All right, ma'am. Need any help with your luggage?
response: A: Thank you, but I'd rather keep this case with me.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
response: B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, carrots, celery, and broccoli, but you can't eat any bread and butter.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
B: You're right. But I really had a happy vacation.
A: OK, Maybe you can move into Kelly's house and share that with her for a couple of months.
B: Thank you. But I don't want to bother you too much.
A: No trouble at all.
response: B: How much should I steal for the rent?

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit sort of hands at present. Two waitresses are ill.

A: All right, but that's no excuse. My husband asked for goose and he was brought chicken instead. It's just unbelievable! And my beans weren't cooked properly. It wasn't a very enjoyable meal at all.
B: This is most regrettable.
A: Look at this bill. We've been overcharged. We only had one dessert, not two. Can you check the bill again, please?
B: I do apologize, Madam.
response: A: I'm still going to pay the service charge, or give a tip, as I don't feel satisfied with it. I'm quite disappointed as a matter of fact.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
A: Have you thought about camping?
response: B: Downhill skiing? I've never done that.

dialogue: A: Are we going to have dinner tonight?
B: What are you planning on making?
A: I'm not cooking dinner.
B: The only way you're eating tonight is if you cook.
A: I'm not sure what to cook for dinner.
B: I don't know. What do you want to eat?
A: I have a taste for some chicken and potatoes.
response: B: That sounds really gross.

dialogue: A: Bonjour!
B: What?
A: I said, Bonjour!
B: What ’ s wrong with you, Ted?
A: I ’ m speaking French. Don ’ t you know anything?
B: What ’ s wrong with speaking English?
A: Well, I just got back from my language school. We have to speak French all day there. No English allowed!
B: What are you doing that for?
response: A: I ’ m trying to learn new skills. It makes me more qualified for a good job.

dialogue: A: Oh, dear. My weight has gone up again.
B: I'm not surprised. You've been eating too much.
A: I wish I could lose weight. I have been to the hospital.
B: Were you given any advice?
response: A: Yeah, the doctor asked me to clean up my diet by eating more meat.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
response: B: I'm very sorry this happened. I'll tell you what: I won't charge you for the soup today.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.
A: How much will you be paid?
response: B: Judy, I don't do it for money, but for experience. Besides, it's voluntary work.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
B: I'm sorry, but I don't sell tickets. You can get one from the machine over there.
response: A: All right. By the way, what's the phone number?

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: We'd like to take a tour to Florence.
A: That's a beautiful city. When do you want to go there?
response: B: We have got a 2 weeks ' vacation and we plan to leave on Thursday .

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite smart, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?
B: Yeah. Let's see if there's a larger size. Well, they don't seem to have anything larger.
response: A: Why don't we go and ask that salesgirl over there? I think she can help us.

dialogue: A: Fikky, what's going on? Freggis just told me that you're going to be leaving us.
B: Yes, I really feel bad out of it. But B. N. D. came up with really good offer.
A: Well, I didn't know you were going to look for a new job.
response: B: Well, just between you and me. I think we have some real problems in this department. Don't get me wrong. It has nothing to do with you, Frank. Everybody says you are an excellent manager.

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet surfaces too.
response: A: Precisely, and because it's artificial protein, it probably wouldn't be harmful to people like so many synthetic glues in use today.

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
B: We thought we'd have that at head office and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.
A: Ok. What sort of things would you like?
B: Just a light lunch I think, so that people can eat while they move around and talk to each other. You did some thing similar for us last year. We'd be happy to have the same menu again.
A: Right. I'll look at my diary and see what you had last time. Oh, I nearly forgot to ask you how many should I cater for?
B: Well, I think most people will be able to come, perhaps around 30. No, let's say 35, to be sure.
response: A: Right, thank you for getting in touch, Mr. Smith. I'll send you the menu by the end of this week.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mary. Why are you standing here?
B: I'm waiting for a bus. The buses are so full at this time of the day.
A: Sure. Where are you going? I don't think this is your way home.
B: You are right. I'm going for a walk in the park.
A: Going for a walk even after along day's work?
response: B: Yes. I always enjoy walking alone in the park after work.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
response: A: If I were you, I'd just move out and never talk to her again.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I see your boarding pass, please?
B: Here you are.
A: Excuse me, sir. This is your passport.
B: Really? Ugh... Is there any difference?
response: A: Yes . As a matter of fact , you can't get in your car without a boarding pass .

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
B: I'm an English major and this is a required course. But now I'm in trouble because I'm not sure I can afford this book.
response: A: Hey, I've got an idea. Why don't we split the cost and share the book?

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet surfaces too.
response: A: Precisely, and because it's natural protein, it probably would be harmful to people like so many synthetic glues in use today.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, let me have this roast beef special.
A: You have a choice of vegetables, green peas, lima beans or spinach.
B: I will have the green peas and make sure the beef is well done.
A: Yes, sir. What would you want to drink, coffee, tea or milk?
B: A cup of coffee, please, with cream and sugar.
A: The cream and sugar are on the table, sir.
B: Oh, yes.
A: Would you like to order some dessert?
B: What comes with the special?
A: Ice cream, fresh fruit or chocolate cake.
B: I think I will have a dish of Vanilla ice cream.
A: Yes, sir.
B: Waiter, may I have my check, please?
response: A: Here you are, sir. It's free with the cashier at the door.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
response: A: It's wide open right now, everything from playground assistants to diaper changers.

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
B: Will you buy an exercise book for me?
A: I guess so. But I'll go to the post office first before I go to the supermarket.
response: B: Can you also buy me a phone? The one you gave me last week doesn't work now.

dialogue: A: Well, you know I had a good time tonight.
B: I'm pleased to hear that.
A: But I have to say goodbye right now.
B: Why? It's not late. Can't you stay a little longer?
response: A: No, I'm sorry, but I really must go. I don't know whether I can catch the last bus if I don't hurry now.

dialogue: A: What a great weekend that was!
B: My feeling's exactly.
A: I really enjoy the beach in the summer.
B: I couldn't agree with you more.
response: A: We should come here more often .

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
response: B: I'm an English major and this is a required course. But now I'm in trouble because I'm not sure I can afford this book.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
response: B: I hope I could get a reception at the museum some time.

dialogue: A: Do you know how to play tennis?
B: Not very well. But I'd love to learn.
A: Would you like to play with me tomorrow morning?
B: Certainly, but I'm not very good.
A: We'll see about that. Anyway, you know that practice makes perfect.
B: How is eight o'clock?
response: A: Ok, you won't forget to bring extra tennis ball, will you?

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
response: B: But the money's bad and there's plenty of fresh air.

dialogue: A: Dr Stone, how did you become an expert on smell?

B: Well, I didn't intend to in the first place. But when I was in university, there was a course on senses. The other senses seem to be more concrete somehow, but smell is so personal. I found it extremely interesting.
A: Do you have any interesting information to give us about smells?

B: Well, let's see. Did you know that it's harder to forget smells than to forget facts? There have been experiments where people could pick out a particular smell thirty days after smelling it for the first time.
response: A: Really? So smells can bring back no more memories than, say, music?

dialogue: A: Dad, how do you say this word?
B: Sword, say it ' sword '.
A: What does this word mean?
response: B: Look it up in the dictionary.

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so nervous.
A: Why?
B: I feel nervous every time I take examinadons.
A: Just relax. I used to feel the same way, but now I can handle exams easily.
B: How do you make it?
response: A: Well. I attended some lectures on attending lectures.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some gloves.
A: All our gloves are here. What do you think of this pair here? It's made of silk.
B: Hm, it looks nice, but I'd like to have something warm for the winter.
A: Maybe you would like heavy wool gloves. How about this pair?
B: I think that's what I want. How much is it?
A: It's... forty dollars.
response: B: It's a little expensive. Do you think it's possible to get a discount?

dialogue: A: Have you been to exhibitions in your spare time?
B: Yes, a lot of times. I like exhibitions-exhibitions about famous people: dancers, actors, you know?
A: Mm, and what about a folk concert? Have you ever been to one of them?
B: No. I don't like folk music very much.
A: What about the opera?
response: B: No, never. I don't really like the opera. It is a bit too light for me.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
response: B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.
A: That's exactly why I want to borrow your notes. My notes aren't very good.
B: So what do you usually do in class?
response: A: I'm always awake at the beginning, but thirty minutes after class begins I feel sleepy and have trouble keeping my eyes open.

dialogue: A: Ahahah! What is that thing on your couch! It just moved!
B: Did you think it wasn't real? That's my pet lizard.
A: You have a pet lizard? Somehow I never would have imagined that.
B: His name is Grunt. Come closer and I'll properly introduce you.
A: Does it bite or scratch?
B: No, he's perfectly harmless. And he's not afraid of strangers either. Here, hold him.
response: A: Wow. He's heavy! And his skin feels really cool.

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
A: We ought to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.
B: We can do that tomorrow. We don't have to do it today.
A: All right. That's a good idea.
B: Talking about washing down the kitchen-where's Bob?
A: He's having lunch with Georgia.
B: What! Again?
A: He should be back soon.
B: He shouldn't spend so much time with that girl.
A: You must be patient, David. Nineteen's a very difficult age, you know?
response: B: Yes, I know. But he ought to be partying more.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
A: No, but we can get your package to France in one week for 40 dollars.
B: Well, that sounds good. I'll take that. Is the service guaranteed?
A: Yes. We also offer a service where we can track your package. But that will cost 10 dollars extra.
response: B: Oh, I won't need the overnight service...

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.
A: Well. I did think here, yes. But maybe the factory somewhere.
response: B: I think they prefer to see where our products are sold.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
response: B: Well, I've been working a lot lately... more than 1 hour a day.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
B: Yes, of course. Shall we give her some flowers?
response: A: Flowers are lovely. But I think it's better to buy her new set of power tools.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
response: B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: I would like an alarm clock that will awaken me with soft music.
A: In that case, you'll probably be interested in this handsome electric clock radio.
response: B: Actually, I'd like a small battery-operated toaster.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
A: May I borrow your pen?
B: Here's a pen for you.
A: Thanks for your help.
response: B: You need to mail that at Window B.

dialogue: A: Bob, did you see our supervisor? I need him to sign this paper.
B: He is in his office, but you'd better choose your words carefully while talking to him.
A: What's up?
B: Nothing. But he is in a bad mood today.
response: A: Thanks for the misinformation.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
B: I'm very sorry this happened. I'll tell you what: I won't charge you for the soup today.
response: A: That's great. I also need to pay with cash.

dialogue: A: Haven't seen you for a long time
B: I've been away on a vacation.
A: I bet you had a wonderful time
response: B: Yeah , no sunshine , ugly scenery and no new friends.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
response: A: There is a lot there on that I don't want to see.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
response: A: Why is a computer so stupid?

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
B: I love green apples.
A: I don't like green apples.
B: Really? Why not?
response: A: green apples taste good

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
response: A: I can keep you here. Would you like a ride?

dialogue: A: What are you working on?
B: I'm figuring out my budget.
A: What budget?
response: B: I'm making a shopping budget , so that I am encouraged to spend money.

dialogue: A: Hello, I'm returning your phone call.
B: I'm glad that you could get back to me so fast.
A: No problem, but what were you calling about?
B: I needed to talk to you about your son.
A: Is he messing up in school?
B: He was acting up in class one day last week.
A: What was he doing?
B: He wouldn't stop talking throughout the class.
A: I don't know what's gotten into him.
response: B: If you could , would you please talk to him ?

dialogue: A: Welcome back home, darling. Did you have a good time?
B: Yes, wonderful. Why, Jack, the house looks as if you have also been away,
A: Why do you say that?
response: B: I don't see dirty plates, cups, shirts everywhere.

dialogue: A: Hello, Steven. Can you do me a favor?
B: Sure. What is it?
