A: My car has broken down.
response: B: You should mail the garage for help.

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
B: I was sick. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of bed.
A: You still look a little sick. You couldn't go back to bed.
B: I'm going now. I just came here to speak to my professor.
A: What did he tell you?
B: He said that I'd be able to take a make-up.
A: Well, that's all right then. Are you going straight home?
response: B: I have to stop at the drugstore on the way. I need some aspirin.

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have been hurt or even killed?
A: You are right! All the injured people were taken to the hospital immediately.
B: I hope so. Drivers must be careful, especially during rush hour.
response: A: I agree with you. We will all be in mortal peril if everyone obeys the traffic rules.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
response: A: Your son's teacher is fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.

dialogue: A: Great! I landed on Classic Movies.
B: I didn't know you liked old movies.
A: I love them, especially the all-time greats like Gone With the Wind.
B: You're so right! Today's movies are just too commercial!
response: A: Sometimes I think Oscars are only awarded to movies that make a lot of money .

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
B: No. Just occasionally.
A: What are your favourite dances?
B: I love rumba and waltz.
A: How about samba?
B: To tell the truth, I don't like it. It's too fast.
response: A: Then I'll see you at six in the morning.  Is that all right?

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
response: A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite expensive.

dialogue: A: Oh, dear. My weight has gone up again.
B: I'm not surprised. You've been eating too much.
A: I wish I could lose weight. I have been to the hospital.
B: Were you given any advice?
A: Yeah, the doctor asked me to clean up my diet by cutting down meat.
response: B: What's more, you had better do more exercise.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
A: And you have a stomachache now?
B: Yes, I think so.
A: Can you walk to the school clinic? Or shall I send for the doctor?
B: No, thanks. It doesn't matter too much. I will go to the doctor after class.
response: A: Ok. I'll finish the class in a minute. Then I'll send you to the theater.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
B: I hope I could get a reception at the White House some time.
response: A: Well, if you do something stupid when you grow up, maybe you will. Who knows?

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
B: I'd love to, but when?
A: How about Saturday morning? It's cooler in the morning and maybe less crowded.
B: I'm afraid I can not get up early on weekends. I'd prefer Saturday afternoon. Believe me there won't be too many people.
A: So, shall we meet at 2:00, Saturday afternoon?
response: B: OK, that would be great. I'll be waiting for you at my home.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Anything wrong?
B: I've been suffering from a fever since yesterday.
A: Do you have any other problems? Like a headache or cough?
B: No, I don't. I think it's only a fever.
response: A: Let me check... It's 20 degrees celsius. I'll give you some medicine.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go swimming and cycling by myself.
A: Oh, I forgot about that. I go cycling sometimes too. And I often go swimming on vacation, but only recreational swimming.
B: Why don't you join me at the gym sometime?
response: A: Well, maybe someday, but I'm pretty excited and motivated about things like that.

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
B: Not really. But when I was home, I had to start typing a literature paper that was due first thing in the morning.
A: Couldn't you do it today?
B: No, our professor said she wouldn't accept any late papers.
A: Then how did you manage it?
response: B: Well, I just turned my paper in, and now I'm going home to bed. See you!

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
B: Well, there's a coffee shop on the next corner. It serves good food.
A: OK. I'll try it. Can I get you something?
response: B: No, I think I'll come with you. I'm longing for a nice service.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
response: A: Then the truck completely missed the taxi, did it?

dialogue: A: Any messages, Miss Grey?
B: Just one, Mr. Blank. You had a telephone call from someone called Brown, David Brown.
A: Brown? I don't seem to know anyone called Brown. What did he say?
B: He wouldn't say. But it sounded important. I told him you'd phone him as soon as you got back.
response: A: Well, I'd better do it then, I suppose. Er...you've got his phone number, haven't you?

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
B: Oh, all right. Well, we could rent a video and watch that.
A: Neither of us has a video player.
response: B: No. But Tony's got a new DVD player. How about renting a movie to watch with him at his place?

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.
A: I got it now. On the last line, I write the city it's going to and the district, right?
B: Don't forget to write the return address in the upper - left corner in the same manner as the sending address.
response: A: Now I just need to get a proper ink stamp.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.

dialogue: A: Have you any plan for the weekend, Tom?

A: According to the forecast, it'll be cloudy the day after tomorrow, good for a ride.
B: Great! Do you go riding often?
A: Absolutely. I go as much as I can, because we can really get in touch with nature. It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want any company?
B: Sure, but it will be a 30-mile ride. Have you been riding so long before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I even saw a bear and some monkeys on my last ride. My friend Mike and I rode more than 30 miles to a very wild part of the national forest.
response: B: Wow! You must have been pretty far away from the city. Shall we invite him to go along?

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?

A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.

A: Why didn't you get one your size?

A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
response: B: No, actually, you can eat vegetables like roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.

dialogue: A: What can I do for you?

dialogue: A: Hello, Macy Agency.

A: The price is $ 420 for the return flight.

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.

response: B: It must be a cheesy house. Are you frightened?

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.

A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
B: I'm going to attend a conference on air pollution.

B: The University of Stanford. Here is the official letter of invitation.

response: B: I'd like to leave in mid-January if my passport is expired by then.

dialogue: A: I need a summer job that will give me some exercise.

A: Life guards don't swim that much. They usually just sit.

response: A: Tour guide is a good idea. I'd vomit all day.

dialogue: A: Have you heard my good news?

A: Oh, is she coming by herself?

A: How often does the bus run?
response: B: Every one hour. I missed a No. 1 bus 15 minutes ago, and the next one hasn't come yet!

dialogue: A: May I help you?

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.

A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
B: But you should pay special attention to your words and attitudes.
A: In the beginning of the interview, greet the interviewer with a kind smile.
B: In the interview, use polite words, such as ' Thank you ', or ' Please '.
A: That's right. Details can mean succeed or fail.
B: When talking you should focus your eyes on the interviewer in order to closely watch his or her expressions.
A: At the end of the interview, you should make your acknowledgements and say Goode.
B: Whatever the result is, you should keep your good demeanor.
A: Only in this way can you leave a good impression on the interviewer.

response: A: By adding arm exercises, so that the legs don't do all the work.

A: Oh, that's a shame.

response: A: That's okay. But we need to find another date.

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition improved when he enjoyed himself and watched funny movies.
A: You said Norman learned this? Do we have to learn to laugh?

B: Not necessarily. Since laughing is something people can do sitting down, costs no money, and requires no special exercise equipment or skill, it's the perfect workout for anyone who doesn't have the time or desire to participate in a regular fitness program.
A: Oh. Do you have such a program to offer to the general public?

B: Yes, we do. It's called the Smile Time-Out. You take a deep breath, smile, exhale, and say "Aaah" while visualizing all your muscles and cells smiling. Then add to that a memory of a time you felt really good and laughed and laughed.
A: What about the situation in which you aren't in a mood to laugh?
response: B: Even when you give a genuine smile or laugh, you get the same physiological benefits as when it's the real thing, because your mind is smart, but your body is stupid and can't tell the difference!

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
response: B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes next year morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?

response: B: Yes . I've already put it in my suitcase .

B: But the money's not bad and there's plenty of fresh air.
A: If I were you, I'd take some kind of direction, like teaching law.
B: Teaching? Anything but that. It's so boring.
A: Come on, you really must think of the future.
B: I'll tell you what. I'd like to be a doctor.
response: A: Well, you should not think very seriously about that. It means a lot of study, and then working minimal hours.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. White. I wonder if you could spare a few minutes. I'd like to ask you a few questions.
B: Well, I can spare you a few minutes, but I'm very busy preparing for our exhibition, you know.
A: Just a few questions. Where is it going to be held?
B: It's going to be held in the art gallery.
A: Who is opening it?
B: It's going to be opened by Mr.Smith.
A: It's quite a big exhibition, isn't it?
B: Quite big. Some very famous paintings will be shown.
A: I believe they're sent from different countries, aren't they?
response: B: Yes, that's right. An exclusively local event for our town.

dialogue: A: What time do you usually get up in the morning?
B: I sleep in every morning, sometimes until 11 or 12.
A: Are you serious? I get up at 5 every morning to go to the gym, and then I get to work around 7.
B: Well, I work from home, so I can set my own hours. I usually work until midnight or 1 in the morning, and then I like to sleep in.

A: I like to be in bed around 9 or 10 at night so I can get enough sleep. Our schedules are very different! You're lucky that you get to set your own schedule, but I could never sleep that late. I'm definitely a morning person.
B: And I'm definitely a night person. Waking up early is so terrible.
A: Maybe we should switch schedules for a week!
B: No way! I would never want your schedule.
A: Very funny... What are you doing today?
B: Well, it's Saturday, so I was thinking of taking a hike. Would you like to come?
A: Sure. Can we go to see a movie afterwards?
B: I don't really like movies, actually. Can we do something else?
response: A: Sure, but I have to work tomorrow, even though it's Sunday, so I do need to be home around 9.

B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...

response: B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have lots of busy time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?

B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
B: I'm sorry, but I don't sell tickets. You can get one from the machine over there.
A: All right. By the way, what's the gate number?
response: B: Black. Down the hall and to the left.

dialogue: A: Do you have a driver's license?
B: No. I am going to take the test in a couple of weeks.
A: Didn't you drive in your own country?
response: B: Yes. But I have to be more skilled.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
response: B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
B: I haven't been eating like I usually do. Usually, I love my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt cooking and I've eaten very little. Most unlike me.
A: Have you been to the doctor? What did she say?
B: I didn't bother going to the doctor. It's nothing serious.
response: A: You never know. If you've been feeling like this for two weeks, it's worth getting some cocaine just to be sure.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
response: A: Dance?

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
response: B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have no free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
response: B: Yes, certainly. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
A: There's also the matter of the fridge. We all assumed there would be one in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.
response: B: Ah, yes. Sorry about that. I got rid of the old fridge, and I got around to ordering a new one. I'm really sorry. I'll order one today and get it delivered to you tomorrow.

dialogue: A: What can I do for you?
B: It's about the new clerks you need for the offices. I'm wondering how many people you want to employ.
A: That depends on what you would like.
B: I think I'd need about 30 hours a week, including some Saturdays. What do you think?
A: That's what I was thinking too. We don't want someone who has never worked in the office before.
B: Yes. It might be helpful if one could speak a second language.
A: That might prevent too many people asking for the jobs. What about pay, David?
B: What do you think would be the best to offer?
response: A: I think it depends on experience. However, the lowest we could offer is about $ 9 per year

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
A: There's also the matter of the fridge. We all assumed there would be one in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.
response: B: Ah, yes. Sorry about that. I got rid of the old fridge, but I didn't get around to ordering a new one yet. I'm really sorry. I'll order one today and get it delivered to you tomorrow.

dialogue: A: What are you doing tonight?
B: I have to run to the grocery store.
A: Don't you hate fighting the crowds on the weekends?
response: B: Yes, but I have stock of food and milk .

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Have you been waiting long?
B: Twenty minutes already.
A: Did you notice whether the No. 7 bus has passed by?
response: B: Not while I've been standing here. I'm also waiting for the No. 9 bus myself.

dialogue: A: Are you there, Mary?
B: I'm back. My bid on the Buddha is still the highest!
A: How much is my stamp?
B: Don't you want to hear more about my statue?
response: A: Don't get ahead of yourself. Fat boy said it's yours.

dialogue: A: What a great day! Hey, Tom, do you want to go to the beach this weekend?
B: Yeah, that is a great idea. Maybe Sara would like to come along with us.
A: I doubt it.
B: Why? You are kidding! You know, she loves watching the sea.
A: But yesterday afternoon she told me that she would go home this Saturday.
B: What happened?
A: She said that her mother was ill and stayed in the hospital, and therefore she wanted to go home to see her.
B: I am sorry to hear that. Well, What do you think? Should we take some food?
response: A: That sounds great. Maybe we could go for a run on the beach. Then let's take some sandwiches, chips, and uh...some salad as well.

dialogue: A: Did you start your new job this week?
B: Yes, I did. I started it the day before yesterday.
A: How do you like your new job? And how about your boss?
B: Well, it's demanding, but it's very interesting. The boss seems to be very considerate. It is said that he is kind and friendly to the employees.
response: A: So you're satisfied with the job, aren't you?

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
response: A: There's also the matter of the squatter. We all assumed there would be one in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
response: A: No , that's fine . It's okay if you didn't bring your bankbook with you.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
A: And you have a stomachache now?
B: Yes, I think so.
A: Can you walk to the school clinic? Or shall I send for the doctor?
response: B: No, thanks. It doesn't matter too much. I will go to the doctor after class.

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
response: B: Will you buy a new exercise mat for me?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, what did you say you would like to do, Mr Green?
B: I said I'd better go back to the hotel. I'm meeting someone this evening.
A: OK, how are you going back? By bus or taxi?
B: I think I'd take a taxi. Do you know where I can get one?
A: Oh, just wait by the roadside. I'll wait with you.
B: OK, thanks. Are the taxis in London all black?
response: A: Well, some of them are. Is this your first time in New York City?

dialogue: A: Brad, wait!
B: What?
A: How come you have a locker but I don't?
response: B: Mr. Rogers probably forgot to assign a locker to you.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
A: There's also the matter of the fridge. We all assumed there would be one in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.
response: B: Ah, yes. Sorry about that. I kept the old fridge, but I didn't get around to ordering a new one yet. I'm really sorry. I'll order one today and get it delivered to you tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Welcome, Miss. May I help you?
B: I hope so. I want a lipstick.
A: Do you have any particular brand in mind?
B: I like Lyfel very much.
A: We have different shades of Lyfel lipstick. May I know what color you usually wear?
response: B: Pink. But today, I'm thinking of buying one in a dark shade. You know, I will be a teacher next month. I wish to look more serious.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.
A: In what ways? What has she done?
B: Oh, no, you don't really want to hear it.
A: Come on. I am a mother of two girls.
B: Ok. I'm worried because she often hides in her room and sends messages to her friends.
response: A: Come on. It's not a big deal. She needs to ditch her friends at this age. You can talk with her if you are really concerned.

dialogue: A: Has Alan shown up yet?
B: Nope. I guess something might have come up.
A: I wonder what happened.
B: I don't know. I hope it's nothing serious.
A: Last week his sister was admitted to the hospital.
B: Oh? What happened?
response: A: His sister had a car accident last week .

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
response: B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more uncomfortable.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. What can I do for you?
A: I'd like a ticket to New York, please.
B: Round trip?
response: A: No, round the world.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
response: A: This class is really just a review for me. I've been learning it for two minutes.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.
response: B: I wish I could. My boss just did me a favor by giving me a raise. And he'll hit the ceiling if I ask for raise again.

dialogue: A: Well, Jenny, the school year is almost over. We just have two more weeks before exams. What do you plan to do this summer?
B: I'm going to teach English to some immigrants in the university's community service program.
A: That sounds interesting. Don't you need to speak a foreign language for a job like that?
B: No, you don't. You just have to present the language simply and give the students a chance to practice speaking.
A: Come to think of it, that's the way I was taught to speak Chinese. But speaking didn't help me learn to read and write Chinese.
B: My students won't want to read and write English, at lease not now. They are more interested in speaking.
A: You sound very knowledgeable about all this. How do you know so much?
response: B: I took a Teaching English as a Second Language course last year when you were in China. I've also talked with the experienced clowns quite a lot. I think I would like to be an ESL teacher when I graduate.

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
B: But it's three kilometers from here to the cinema. How can we get there in such a short time?
A: I think we can walk there in twenty minutes.
B: But I am afraid I can't walk that far.
response: A: If you don't feel like walking, we can take a taxi home from the film.

dialogue: A: Hello, I am calling about my cable service.
B: What's the problem?
A: For the past week my cable hasn't been working.
response: B: I apologize , but the cable has been down lately .

dialogue: A: It's lucky that we rode our bike here instead of driving.
B: It's a good job that we got here early. Look at all those cars there. They'll never get in.
A: You'd better follow me closely. I don't want to lose you.
B: Don't worry. I'll keep up.
A: We go in over there. Gate B. Peter said they're pretty good tickets.
B: Where are they?
A: They're right behind the goal.
B: Oh,do we have to stand up all the time?
A: That's right.
B: I hope we can see the match clearly.
response: A: That's why we've come so late. The later, the better.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but I think you've made a wrong turn. You were supposed to turn left on Wilson Boulevard.
B: Oh, I am sorry. Didn't you say 1323 Wilson?
A: No, 3023. It is OK though. You don't have to take me there. I can walk from here.
B: Why don't I just make a U-turn there? It's a one-way street; see the sign up ahead. Maybe if I turn left here, I can come down the next street.
response: A: We can't do that during slow hour really, though it won't be much trouble. Sometimes one can wait 30 minutes for a taxi, so I'm happy to get this close.

dialogue: A: Bill, do you know when did the Chinese begin to celebrate Teachers ' Day?
B: I know the Chinese teachers had their first festival in 1985.
A: So, it is the 27th Teachers ' Day.
B: What will you do on Teachers ' Day?
A: I am going to send Mr. Li some flowers. What about you?
response: B: I intend to invite him to treat or trick.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
A: I can take you home. Would you like a ride?
response: B: Yes. Thanks a lot. Could you stop at the chemist's on the way? I need to buy some furniture.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
B: She's very fond of detective stories?
A: I see. Has she read any detective stories?
B: Oh, yes!
A: Do you know if she's read this one?
B: I'm not sure, but she probably won't remember if she has! She's very forgetful!
A: Ah! She has a bad memory. How old is she?
B: She's eighty-seven.
response: A: I suggest you take this book . It's not particularly exciting .

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
B: You had pretty bad scores.
A: Exactly what do you mean by bad?
B: You failed.
response: A: How did I get the best grade in the class?

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
A: No, but we can get your package to France in one week for 40 dollars.
B: Well, that sounds good. I'll take that. Is the service guaranteed?
response: A: Yes. We also offer a service where we can track your package. But that will cost 10 dollars extra.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve about British culture.
A: Professor Grand's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person coming in asking for those articles.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matterwhich one you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're joking, all of them?
response: A: Every month. I've asked professor Grand twice already to bring in fewer copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for 5 minutes for those same articles to be returned.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
response: A: Well, some people decided to have a rave last night.

dialogue: A: Honey, how long have we been living here?
B: About 10 years. What's wrong?
A: I am thinking about redecorating our house.
B: That would cost a lot of money. But we do need to do some changes to the house.
response: A: Right. What about repainting the living room in yellow?

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
B: Well, I use it to send e-mails a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself French program. And I shop online pretty often.
A: Mmm. Any other uses?
response: B: Ignoring my bank account, and there are a couple of computer games I enjoy.

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: I'm in a hurry. How long will it take?
B: About half an hour, if there's no traffic jam.
A: Do you think the traffic will be heavy?
response: B: I doubt it. It's rush hour.

dialogue: A: Beautiful weather, isn ’ t it?
B: Yes, it is. Are you here on business?
A: No, I ’ m on a vacation to see the famous Three Gorges.
response: B: I ’ m going there for a tour, too. Is this your first trip to the moon?

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
A: There's also the matter of the fridge. We all assumed there would be one in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.
response: B: Ah, yes. Sorry about that. I got rid of the new fridge, but I didn't get around to ordering a new one yet. I'm really sorry. I'll order one today and get it delivered to you tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, what did you say you would like to do, Mr Green?
B: I said I'd better go back to the hotel. I'm meeting someone this evening.
A: OK, how are you going back? By bus or taxi?
B: I think I'd take a taxi. Do you know where I can get one?
response: A: Oh, just wait by the roadside. I'll wait with you.

dialogue: A: Why, Ann, I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been?
B: Bob, it has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year.
A: No. We talked at the Johnson's Christmas party last December. Don't you remember?
B: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the Germen company?
A: No. I changed my job about 4 months ago. I'm with the World Bank now. How about you?
B: I'm still working at the University, but I transferred from the German Department to the Spanish Department.
A: Don't you tell me you speak Spanish, too?
response: B: Sure. I never spent time in Spain, you know. German was what I studied in college.

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
response: B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
response: B: Polka dots.

dialogue: A: Do you ever eat fast food?
B: Yes, yes, I do.
A: What kind of fast food do you normally eat?
B: Oh, you know, hamburgers, sandwiches, well, sometimes a pizza.
A: Well, right. And how often do you eat fast food? Every day, more than once a week or less than once a week?
B: Well, Monday to Friday when I'm working, every day, um, but not usually on weekends.
A: And when do you eat fast food of the day?
response: B: Oh, at work as I said, you know at formal meetings. Sometimes you know, if I'm going out and I've no time to cook in the evening then I'll send out for a pizza.

dialogue: A: When do you take your winter holiday?
B: I usually take it during the second or third week of January.
A: Do you like to ski?
response: B: Yes, I love to go skiing.

dialogue: A: Do you know Tom?
B: Tom what?
A: Tom Smith.
B: No. But I know a Tim Smith.
A: Oh, yes, you are right. It was Tim Smith I meant. You know what happened to him the other day?
B: No, what happened then?
A: Well, he told me he saw his dead grandfather in London.
response: B: Oh, come on. You are not telling a ghost story, are you?

dialogue: A: All right. But these are black and I don ’ t like black shoes. They ’ re dull.
B: Well, black is a better color than pink. Pink ’ s for girls.
A: Then why are you wearing black shoes?
response: B: Because... oh, all right. You win. Let ’ s pay for them and go.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
response: B: It's Green, G-R-A-A-N.

dialogue: A: What time do you usually get up in the morning?
B: I sleep in every morning, sometimes until 11 or 12.
A: Are you serious? I get up at 5 every morning to go to the gym, and then I get to work around 7.
B: Well, I work from home, so I can set my own hours. I usually work until midnight or 1 in the morning, and then I like to sleep in.
response: A: I like to be in bed around 9 or 10 at night so I can get enough sleep. Our schedules are very different! It's unfortunate that you're obligated to set your own schedule, but I could never sleep that late. I'm definitely a morning person.

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
response: B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's a middle school course and I'm only a junior, but...

dialogue: A: Would you like to come to the cinema tonight?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair tonight.
A: OK. What about tomorrow night?
B: I can't go tomorrow night, either.
A: Why not?
response: B: I've got to wash my hair at the cinema again.

dialogue: A: Be careful.The floor is slippery.
B: Mom, there isn't any hot water
A: Turn on the shower.
response: B: It's getting cold.

dialogue: A: Hello, Tom. I haven't seen you for some time. How are you doing?
B: Oh! Not too bad. I have been busy writing an article.
A: Really? Have you finished it?
B: Yes. I finished it yesterday.
A: Congratulations! Are you doing something this evening?
B: No, nothing important. Why?
A: Well, do you feel like going to a concert? I have two tickets.
response: B: Oh. Good idea. I want to do something relaxing, and I like music very much.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is not in at the moment.
B: When will he come in, do you know?
A: I suppose he won't be in until 12: 00.
response: B: May I bring him food?

dialogue: A: Are you interested in music?
B: Yes. I like classical music. Beethoven is my favourite composer. How about you?
A: I like all kinds of music, but jazz is my favourite and my wife is fond of rock music.
response: B: You play the piano, don't you?

dialogue: A: Bonjour!
B: What?
A: I said, Bonjour!
B: What ’ s wrong with you, Ted?
A: I ’ m speaking French. Don ’ t you know anything?
B: What ’ s wrong with speaking English?
response: A: Well, I just got back from my language school. We have to speak French all day there. No English allowed!

dialogue: A: And lightweight, too. It'll play for 20 hours on two AA batteries!
B: Cool! The sound is great. These earphones are awesome!
A: And they're really safe. They'll protect your ear from sound damage.
B: You certainly need that. You always pump the volume up way too high.
A: I know. And you can also hear outside noises while you listen to music.
response: B: You're right! So I can listen to music while studying!

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
response: A: No, I don't. I mean a legal practitioner. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
response: B: But he is usually never right in his weather news.

dialogue: A: Are you alright, child?
B: Hey, I still know my name.
A: What did the nurse say?
B: She said I have a fever but nothing major.
response: A: In that case, you should go to the party.

dialogue: A: Are you free this afternoon?
B: I'm afraid I'm going to the gym for a workout.
A: How long have you been there?
response: B: I began to went there last month.

dialogue: A: Today in the studio we have Alberto Cortez, the well-known Brazilian advocate of the anti-global movement. He's here to talk about the recent report, stating that by 2050 Brazil will be the one ot the word's wealthiest and most successful countries. Alberto, what do you say to the report?
B: You know this isn't the first time that people are saying Brazil will be a great economic power. The same thing was said over a hundred year ago. But it didn't happen.
A: Yes, but you must admit the world's a very different place now.
B: Of course. In fact I believe there's maybe some truth in the prediction this time around. First of all, though, we must remember the problems facing Brazil at the moment.
A: Such as...?
response: B: There's a neglectable gap between the rich and the poor in this country. In Sal Paulo, you can see shopping malls full of designer goods right next door to the slam areas with proper water and electricity supplies. Not much work needs to be done to help people in those areas improve their lives.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
A: I wonder if you can change it to one size down.
response: B: Yes , of course . No need to have the receipt.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
response: B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through dinner, but I keep drifting away.

dialogue: A: Hi, John! I'd like to invite you to dinner this evening.
B: To dinner? What for?
A: I have passed my driving test!
B: Congratulations! I'm really glad to hear that.
response: A: Thank you!  I have been putting it off for a half a year, you know.  And I've failed at last.

dialogue: A: I can't believe it! I lost.
B: It looks like you have to buy tickets for us, Jason. And we're not going to see an action movie!
A: That's not fair, you got all the easy questions.
response: B: I guess I just got unlucky.

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
B: He was messing around last week in class.
A: Exactly what did he do?
response: B: Even though I asked him not to, he kept silently meditating in class.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Could I be of any service to you?
B: Have you got any Chinese paintings?
A: Yes, we have landscape paintings, figure paintings and flower-and-bird paintings.
B: I'd like a flower-and-bird painting.
A: Good. How about this picture of cranes with pine trees? It was painted by a famous Chinese painter in King Dynasty.
B: Oh, they look just like live cranes. I like this picture very much. How much is it?
response: A: One thousand dollars .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
response: A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is studying.

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
response: B: But you should pay special attention to your skills at ping pong.

dialogue: A: Hello. Matt White speaking.
B: Hello, Dr. White, my name's Pan Johnson. My roommate, Janet Holmes, wanted me to call you.
A: Janet Holmes? Oh, that's right. She's in my Shakespearean English class. Has anything happened to her?

B: Nothing, it's just that she submitted a job application yesterday and the company asked her in for an interview today. She's afraid she won't be able to attend your class this afternoon. I'm calling to see whether it would be OK if I gave you her essay.
A: Certainly, that would be fine. Uh, you can either drop it off at my class or bring it to my office.
B: Would it be all right to come by your office around 4:00? I'm afraid I can't come any earlier because I have three classes this afternoon.
A: Uh, I won't be here when you come. I'm supposed to be at a meeting from 3:00 to 6:00, but how about leaving it with my secretary? She usually stays until 5:00.
response: B: Fine, please tell her I'll be there at 4:00. And Dr. White, one more thing, could you tell me where your office is? Janet told me where your class is, but she didn't give me directions to your gym.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.
response: B: No, I think we must have disturbed them. They must have heard us coming and got out of the bathroom window quickly.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
response: B: If you got hired or are working a lot more hours, you may qualify.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to move?
B: Definitely. I Ve got the hell out of the company. Anything new?
A: Yes, but there is a chance that might be suitable for you.
B: Really? Are you willing to recommend me for the position?
A: I can't say, but let me make a call and see if I can help.
response: B: I appreciate the lack of support, sir.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for autumn, but I'd like to have something warm for winter.
response: A: Maybe you would like a light  cotton hat. How about this one?

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
response: B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.

dialogue: A: Hi, David. I haven't seen you for ages. How are you getting along with your work?
B: Hi, Susan. Not so well as to be expected. I've left my position. I can't bear the rudeness of my boss any longer.
A: What are you going to do then?
B: No idea. Anyway, I've got to think about it seriously. And you?
A: I've been very successful as a dancer. I like this kind of life. It is so exciting.
B: You can't do that forever.
A: No. But I've decided to open a dance school once I've moved to the top. A lot of young dancers need better training.
response: B: That's not an idea.

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
A: I sprained my wrist, but the doctor says it will be fine.
B: How many days will you be out of school?
response: A: The doctor said I should be good enough to return this afternoon.

dialogue: A: What are you here for today?
B: I need to fight this ticket that I got.
A: Is the arresting officer here?
B: Yes, he is, Your Honor.
A: Plead your case.
B: I was told by the officer that I ran a red light. That information isn't true.
A: Why would the officer lie?
B: I'm not sure, but the signal had a camera on it.
response: A: Did the camera take a picture of your license plate ?

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.
A: Well. I did think here, yes. But maybe the factory somewhere.
B: I think they prefer to see where our products are made.
response: A: OK, I won't meet them at the factory.

dialogue: A: Hello, Thomas Brothers.
B: Hello, this is Mike Landon here. Is Jack Cooper there by any chance?
A: I am afraid not, he is away for a day or two, back on, let's see, Monday morning.
B: Oh, well perhaps I can live a message for him.
A: Yes, of course, just a minute. Now, let's see, to Jack Cooper from Mike London.
B: No, Landon, L-a-n-d-o-n.
A: Sorry, yes, got that, and what's the message?
B: Well it's just this: could he come to a meeting on Monday afternoon at 5:00 pm?
A: That's this coming Monday, October 12th?
response: B: Right, it's to discuss the new factory in France.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a white house. The General Reading Room is inside it.
response: A: No wonder! It's really right here! Thank you very much.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
response: A: They must have had a car or a truck.

dialogue: A: Hi, honey. Do you need any help with your luggage?
B: No, thanks, dad. I just brought one carry-on in my backpack.
A: Great. I wish your mother would take some packing lessons from you. OK, let's go home.
B: Hm...It's cold here.
A: Yes, the weatherman says that it might snow tonight. What temperature was it when you took off from California this morning?
B: Sixty degrees and sunny.
A: Don't you people miss the seasons?
response: B: Not really. It's nice to go outside everyday. And always have nice frigid weather.

dialogue: A: Hello, Robert speaking.
B: Hi, it's Emma. I'm glad you're there. It's about our appointment on Wednesday morning. I'm afraid I can't make it now.
A: Oh, that's a shame.
B: I'm sorry. There was a change in my business partner's plan. And Wednesday is the only day she is able to see me.
response: A: That's okay. But we need to keep the same date

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
response: A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite exorbitant.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: This is my first day here.
A: Are you a freshman in college?
B: I started school somewhere else.
A: What school did you transfer from?
response: B: I started at PCC, which is actually a zoo.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
response: B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.

dialogue: A: Hello, Steven. Can you do me a favor?
B: Sure. What is it?
A: My car has broken down.
B: You should telephone the garage for help.
response: A: I have done it . But now I have an urgent appointment to keep . Could you watch this movie with me first?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
response: B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a castle. The General Reading Room is inside it.

dialogue: A: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please.
B: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me.
A: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today.
B: Oh, why? Is she ill?
A: No. She's studying for an exam.
B: An exam. Is she going to school?
response: A: Yes, she is. She's learning Japanese in night school.

dialogue: A: Doctor! Doctor! Help me, please!
B: Take it easy, please! Sit here, now, what's the matter with you? And can I help you?
A: I feel sick. I have a bad stomach-ache, and my head troubles me a lot.
response: B: Well, I won't check. Open your mouth please. And say Ah.

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.
response: B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had been working fine after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
B: I haven't been eating like I usually do. Usually, I love my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt cooking and I've eaten very little. Most unlike me.
A: Have you been to the doctor? What did she say?
B: I didn't bother going to the doctor. It's nothing serious.
response: A: You never know. If you've been feeling like this for two weeks, it's worth getting checked out by a cute boy just to be sure.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
response: A: Now you're exaggerating.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
response: A: I wonder if you can change it to a tuxedo.

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
response: A: So you couldn't have made it. But you were still early for class.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
response: A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I can find a copy everywhere.

dialogue: A: Hello! Do you have a place where I can exercise?
B: Yes, sir. We have a fine exercise facility.
A: I'm happy to hear that. Now, would you tell me where it is?
B: You're actually standing above it. Just take the elevator or stairs down one level.
A: Is the hotel going to charge me a dollar a minute for gym use?
response: B: No , sir . There's no extra charge . You need a credit card and your room key to open the door .

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
response: B: But the money's pretty bad and there's plenty of fresh air.

dialogue: A: I'm losing my sleep. I feel tired and sleepy all the time. I've got to do something about it.
B: I'm so sorry for you. But what are you going to do?
A: I want to move out of the dorm and rent a small flat.
response: B: That's a good idea. It will be much more convenient for you.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
B: They really started looting?
A: Yes, apparently four stores were broken into.
B: Did the looters get caught?
response: A: There was no evidence of who did it .

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
response: B: I love purple apples

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
A: It's wide open right now, everything from playground assistants to diaper changers.
B: Oh, I might pass on the latter. But spending some time on the playground with some small kids might be fun.
response: A: Well, you're quite cold-hearted.  I haven't even mentioned the benefits but you're complaining.

dialogue: A: How come David is always so full of energy?
B: He has a strange but highly effective way of sleeping.
A: What is that?
response: B: He takes a long sleep for half an hour every six hours and has a total of four hours of sleep each day.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just graduated from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.
B: Could you tell me what you can do?
A: I can do whatever a secretary is expected to do, such as typing, receiving phone calls, sending faxes, and writing reports.
B: Well, it seems that your qualifications for the job are excellent. Could you tell me what kind of salary you are expecting?
response: A: I saw in the ad. that this position offers a salary of around 2,013 a month.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
B: Buy an expensive suit.
A: Is a white shirt OK?
response: B: Yeah, fine. And dressing leather shoes.

dialogue: B: Help. I need some help!
A: Yes sir. Can you tell me what is happening?
B: I'm at the university and a student of mine suddenly fell down, knocked her head on the step, and fainted right at this very moment.
A: Yes sir. Can you tell me exactly where you are?
response: B: On the...on the ...I'm sorry, I'm too nervous right now. We're on the second floor of Cutler Hall, Room 211.

dialogue: A: How do you pay at the shops, Mary?
B: Why? By cash or card, of course.
A: Ever thought of your mobile phone?
B: Is it possible?
response: A: This time next year, perhaps. It's tedious and takes a long time. Everything is done in 5 minutes, to be exact.

dialogue: A: Did you see today's newspaper? That building over there in Centerville was just struck by lightning for the fourth time.
B: I'm not surprised. If the conditions for lightning to strike are right one time, they might be as good another time.

A: Well, I don't take any chances. If I'm caught in a thunderstorm, I will look for a building or a closed car. Also, I was told that if you're stuck outdoors, the best thing you can do is to keep yourself close to the ground and avoid bodies of water.
B: To tell you the truth, even when I'm at home, I don't take baths or showers during a thunderstorm. And I don't use anything that works electrically. Maybe I'm too anxious.
response: A: I wouldn't say that. According to the article, lightning starts very few fires in the United States. Almost no people are injured or killed. I think you're just being sensible.

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
B: But it's three kilometers from here to the cinema. How can we get there in such a short time?
A: I think we can walk there in twenty minutes.
response: B: But I am afraid I can walk very far.

dialogue: A: Hello, Amy. Are you coming to my birthday party?
B: Yes, I am. How do I get to your house from the station?
A: Well, call me when you get to the station and I'll come and pick you up in my car.
B: Are you sure it won't be too much trouble?
A: It's no trouble at all. It only takes about 15 minutes.
response: B: Oh, I want to check your phone number. Is it 828816887?

dialogue: A: Where is Jimmy? Why hasn't he come down for breakfast? Needn't he go to school today?
B: He's still in bed in his room.
A: What's the matter with our dear son?
B: He's feeling terrible. I think he must have caught a bad cold.
response: A: Well, we must call the lawyer.

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
response: B: I would hate to go, so what time should we meet?

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.
A: Well whatever, can we repeat our offer to run the campaign for 4 extra weeks?
response: B: That's not really the point. The campaign missed two key trade affairs. Because of this, we are asking you either to retire the campaign next week for free, or we only pay 50% of the fee for this year.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mary. Why are you standing here?
B: I'm waiting for a bus. The buses are so full at this time of the day.
A: Sure. Where are you going? I don't think this is your way home.
B: You are right. I'm going for a walk in the park.
A: Going for a walk even after along day's work?
response: B: Yes. I always enjoy running a marathon in the park after work.

dialogue: A: Hello, Lucy. When are you going off to Beijing?
B: This evening.
A: How are you getting there, by air or by train?
B: By train. It leaves at 5:00 and arrives in Beijing at 7:10 tomorrow morning.
response: A: Oh, only 14 hours. Is anybody seeing you off this evening?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few days after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?
response: B: Well, it hurts so much, doctor, especially when I eat.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
response: B: I haven't been eating like I usually do. Usually, I loath my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt cooking and I've eaten very little. Most unlike me.

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
A: It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want some company?
B: Sure. But, it will be a long hike, 30 miles in three days. Have you been hiking before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike.
B: Wow! You must have been pretty far away from the city.
response: A: Not particularly , my friend and I hiked in a very wild part of the national forest that was around the city.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
response: A: I'm happy to tell you that's available, too.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: I'd like to buy a blue jacket. Do you have any blue jackets?
A: Yes. What size do you wear?
B: I want Size M.
A: Here you are. Try it on and see whether it is all right for you.
B: It's all right. I like it very much. How much is it?
A: 360 Yuan.
response: B: Oh. That's a bit expensive. Do you have any other kind? I want a cheaper one.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
response: B: I'm in the market for electrical appliances for my home.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Uncle Smith.
B: Good morning, Cathy.
A: I want to have a dinner party to celebrate my birthday. Would you come?
B: I'd love to, Cathy. What time?
response: A: Next weekend, on Saturday.

dialogue: A: Gordon, you're ever so late.
B: Yes, I am sorry. I missed the bus.
A: But there's a bus every ten minutes, and you are over 1 hour late.
response: B: Well , I missed several buses .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
A: Have you thought about camping?
response: B: Camping? In a ski lodge? I've never done that.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Madam. Can I help you?
B: Yes, er...I want to see the West End.
A: How much time do you have?
B: Just one day.
A: Well, what do you particularly want to do?
response: B: I want to visit museums, art galleries, Buckingham Palace, do some shopping, and go to the theaters.

dialogue: A: ( Before Christmas Party ) Are you ready for the Christmas party tonight
B: Almost. I have to get dressed. It's a formal party and I have special party make up!
A: Use this lipstick and it will make your lips shine!
response: B: Great! Uh, remember that there's a gift exchange, too. We all have to bring a gift.

dialogue: A: Emily, what do you do as a trendspotter?
B: Very simple. Take digital photos of youth culture and send them to my company. It's called Look-Look.
A: What kind of company is it?
B: It's a youth culture marketing and trend forecasting firm in Hollywood. I'm one of Look-Look's 65,000 trendspotters worldwide.
A: Look-Look gets a lot of information about the ever-shifting tastes of the youth market by these images.

B: Yes, its clients are mostly companies. They get information about trends from Look-Look and develop their products. They also use the images of Look-Look on their websites to impress young people and promote their newly designed products.
A: But are there any people who don't like their pictures to be used on the website?
B: I always have my subjects' permission before I take their pictures and put up their images onto Look-Look.com.
A: Where do you find your best subjects?
B: At school, in the park, at local supermarkets and near many music clubs.
A: What is difficult about this job?
response: B: To take digital photos of people because so many young people try hard to stand out. You have to be able to find the difference between someone who is copying trends and someone who is truly inventing a new look.

dialogue: A: Have you had enough time to look over the menu?
B: Yes, we are almost ready to order.
A: Let me remind you of the specials of the day, which are posted on the board.
B: Oh, that all sounds so good! Can we get the sauce on the side?
A: Yes, we would be happy to prepare the food to meet your special needs.
B: I was wondering if you have any vegetarian choices.
A: Yes, the roasted vegetable salad is good, and the portabella mushroom burger is also a good choice.
B: I think that I would like to order the broccoli noodles, please.
A: That is an excellent choice, and I could bring you your salads now or bring them with your dinner.
response: B: Please bring our salads to us later . We are hungry !

dialogue: A: What are you going to have for breakfast?
B: I just have some cereal each morning.
A: You're supposed to always have a hearty breakfast.
B: I don't always have time to make breakfast.
A: It's easy to make a quick breakfast.
B: What do you have for breakfast?
response: A: When I have lots of time to make breakfast , I just make some oatmeal , toast , and OJ .

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!
A: You're not supposed to just copy the book.
B: Oh! I think Mr. Harper won't know.
A: He will know! He asked us to write a list of all the books we'd used. Remember? That's not the point anyway.
B: What is the point then?
response: A: Well, the point is that you're supposed to write your own project--you are allowed to copy someone else's writing.

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Where were you at lunchtime? I was looking for you in the dining hall.
B: Oh, sorry, I missed you. My English class ran late again.
