A: That's been happening quite often recently. Maybe it's because the final exams are coming up.
response: B: Yes. After class, there is always a group of students who walk right out. How about you? Are yon ready for the exams?

dialogue: A: Tom, as the manager of a company selling green products, you are now quite a successful businessman. When did you know you wanted to have your own company?

B: My family left Budapest in 1986 and settled in Canada where a lot of my friends' parents were highly successful businessmen. It seems so cool, so in high school, I started a web-designed company and learned a lot from that experience.
A: How did you find the money for your present company then?
B: We've raised 18 million dollars from about 50 people. We're finally making money. I own 6% of the company and all employees get their shares.
A: By the way, what aspects of your life are green?
B: I'm only mildly green. I do simple things and I'm a huge biker. I biked cross Canada.
A: Do you think you have ever done anything wasteful?
response: B: We're always doing something wrong, but then, that will allow us to learn and grow. When I first started out, we purchased all the products ourselves, but that was a mistake. Now we work with other companies. We provide the materials, the product development and the design. They make the products then.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
response: B: Oh! I'm happy  to hear that. What kind of problems?

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.
B: No, I think we must have disturbed them. They must have heard us coming and got out of the bathroom window quickly.
response: A: Yes, well, hurry up. We'd better avoid calling the police.

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
A: Actually, it'll save you money.
B: Oh, really?
response: A: Because you can use your bus pass as many times as you want.

dialogue: A: Do you ever eat fast food?
B: Yes, yes, I do.
A: What kind of fast food do you normally eat?
B: Oh, you know, hamburgers, sandwiches, well, sometimes a pizza.
A: Well, right. And how often do you eat fast food? Every day, more than once a week or less than once a week?
B: Well, Monday to Friday when I'm working, every day, um, but not usually on weekends.
A: And when do you eat fast food of the day?
response: B: Oh, at work as I said, you know at midnight. Sometimes you know, if I'm going out and I've no time to cook in the evening then I'll send out for a pizza.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing Tasty Restaurant. What can I do for you?
B: Will you please show me a table beside the window?
A: Sorry, there's no table beside the window, only one table in the centre.
B: In the centre? OK.
A: This way,please.
B: Thank you.
response: A: Here's the menu of car dealer options. Could I take your order?

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.
A: In what ways? What has she done?
B: Oh, no, you don't really want to hear it.
A: Come on. I am a mother of two girls.
B: Ok. I'm worried because she often hides in her room and sends messages to her friends.
response: A: Come on. It's not a big deal. She needs no friends at this age. You can talk with her if you are really concerned.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. We will have our midterm exams next month. I plan to look for some important books and study at the library. Do you want to join me?
B: Sure. I need to return some books. They are due today. Besides, I can also read some weekly publications, magazines and newspapers.
A: Great. We can go to the swimming pool in the gymnasium after that.
response: B: Sounds a good idea. Summer is approaching. Today's temperature has reached negative 35 degree Centigrade. Are you good at swimming?

dialogue: A: May I help you, sir?
B: Yes, please. I want to buy a personal gift for my brother. He's taking a trip to South America.
A: Is he going by ship or plane?
B: He,s flying. My gift will have to be something light in weight. What can you suggest?
A: What about this tie? It's made of pure silk.
B: My sister already gave him one. I'd like something unusual. Let me look around...oh, that clock looks nice, but...
A: Hey,here is a gift for the man who has everything.
response: B: Oh,a folding toothbrush! That's a wonderful idea! I'll take it.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mike. What have you been up to?
B: Not much. I started exercising.
A: Trying to get in shape?
B: Yeah, and I need to start improving my health.
A: Me, too. What are you doing besides exercising?
B: That's about all.
response: A: I think if you eat better, it will also help a lot.

dialogue: A: A woman after my own heart...
B: OK, Mr. Coffee Connoisseur, so what's the next step in the coffee-making process?
A: Well, step two is grinding the coffee beans. I've roasted three different types of beans.
response: B: Let me guess, Carrots, Broccoli, and Cauliflower!

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, let me have this roast beef special.
A: You have a choice of vegetables, green peas, lima beans or spinach.
B: I will have the green peas and make sure the beef is well done.
A: Yes, sir. What would you want to drink, coffee, tea or milk?
B: A cup of coffee, please, with cream and sugar.
A: The cream and sugar are on the table, sir.
B: Oh, yes.
A: Would you like to order some dessert?
B: What comes with the special?
A: Ice cream, fresh fruit or chocolate cake.
B: I think I will have a dish of Vanilla ice cream.
A: Yes, sir.
B: Waiter, may I have my check, please?
response: A: Here you are, sir. Pay the cashier at the door.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
A: Your son's fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.
B: Yes, that's right. As soon as you've done what's necessary for buying the land, Jerry and I will see an architect.
A: Have you found a plot yet?
response: B: Jerry was in Edinburgh last Saturday and saw a plot he likes. My wife and I went there two days ago, and we liked it, too. I'd like you to build the house for me.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for autumn, but I'd like to have something warm for winter.
response: A: Maybe you would like a heavy wool hat. How about this one?

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
A: I can take you home. Would you like a ride?
response: B: Yes. Thanks a lot. Could you stop at the chemist's on the way? I need to buy some furniture.

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
response: B: i hate yellow apples.

dialogue: A: Oh, let's just go in for a minute, I'm hungry.
B: OK, but just a snack. We're eating supper at home tonight.
A: Let's get some milk and bread.
response: B: I love milk. How about a soda?

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
response: B: Yes, of course. Shall we give her some flowers?

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.
A: Is it the diet that you love but have to avoid?
response: B: That's right. Dieting is so boring. Hopefully, I won't need to wear the wedding dress again anyway.

dialogue: A: A table for two, please.
B: All right. How about this one by the window?
A: Thank you. It's fine.
B: May I take your order now, sir?
A: What do you recommend? We'd like some of your local specialities.
B: Our restaurant is famous for its seafood.
A: One cream of fish soup and two portions of prawns.
B: Shrimp salad is our speciality, took
A: No, I think it's enough.
B: What would you like to drink?
response: A: A sandwich and a burger.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
B: I need to review my English.
A: So that's what keeps you so busy recently!
B: Yes, I've been tied up with my studies. Now, what worries me a lot is my English.
A: But why? Your English is very good.
B: Thank you. You are very kind.
response: A: No, I'm lying. As an American, I can't understand you very well.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
response: A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
B: Well, there's a coffee shop on the next corner. It serves good food.
A: OK. I'll try it. Can I get you something?
B: No, I think I'll come with you. I'm longing for a nice salad.
A: Do you often have lunch at this coffee shop?
response: B: Sure, I usually bring my lunch from home and eat it at the coffee shop.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for autumn, but I'd like to have something warm for winter.
response: A: Maybe you would like a heavy metal hat. How about this one?

dialogue: A: Are you doing anything tonight?
B: No, nothing. Why?
A: Do you like western music?
B: Yes, I do, very much.
response: A: There ’ s a poetry reading tonight. Would you like to go and listen to it?

dialogue: A: Have you heard about the robbery?
B: I saw the whole thing happen.
A: For real?
B: I was in the bank during the robbery.
A: What went down?
B: Some dude came into the bank with a gun.
A: Are you serious?
B: When he pulled out the gun, I got so scared.
A: Tell me what else happened.
response: B: He got the money and tried to leave .

dialogue: A: Hello. This is Amy.
B: Hello, Amy. This is Tom.
A: Yes. What can I do for you?
B: I want to go to New York by train today. Would you please look up a train time for me?
A: Certainly, Hold on, please. Um... there's one at eleven p. m. It's a little late. Why don't you go there by car?
response: B: My car is repaired now. I don't have to go there by train.

dialogue: A: How is the weather today?
B: It's very hot and humid.
A: Quite different from the forecast.
B: The weather changes often at this time of the year. It's possible to cool down in the late afternoon.
A: How are the summers here generally?
B: They are usually hot and rainy.
A: I have been here for about a month. It's very hot and humid.
response: B: It's just June now. The rainy season hasn't arrived yet.

dialogue: A: Do you ever eat fast food?
B: Yes, yes, I do.
A: What kind of fast food do you normally eat?
response: B: Oh, you know, steak, fish, well, sometimes a pizza.

dialogue: A: Have you taken the written test yet?
B: No, I haven't.
A: You should study before you take it.
B: I have been studying.
A: Why don't you take the test?
B: Do you know if it costs any money to take it?
A: Since you already paid for your permit, you don't have to pay again.
B: All right. Do you know if the test covers the whole book?
A: No, the test skips a lot of things in the book.
B: Did you pass it the first time that you took it?
A: No, I didn't, because it was pretty hard.
response: B: Well , I hope that I do poorly since I don't really care that much .

dialogue: A: Would you like to come to the cinema tonight?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair tonight.
A: OK. What about tomorrow night?
B: I can't go tomorrow night, either.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair again.
A: Do you wash your hair every night?
B: It depends...
A: Depends on what?
response: B: It depends on when I go alone to the cinema.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you take me to the airport?
B: Which airport, ma'am?
A: Kennedy Airport.
B: All right, ma'am. Need any help with your luggage?
response: A: Thank you, but I'd rather keep this case with a complete stranger.

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.
B: And where did you leave it?
A: I am sure I left it in the coffee shop on the 5th floor.
response: B: Time to worry, Madam. I am sure we have lost it. Now could you give me your cat's name?

dialogue: A: Where do you want to go, Madam?
B: Hilton Hotel, please. Brrr! It's cold, eh? I'm freezing.
A: Come in. San Francisco is usually cold in winter, you know. It's often very rainy, which makes the weather colder and it sometimes....
B: Well, it gets very hot in summer, doesn't it?
response: A: Not really. It gets scorching hot in July and August. That's the best time to visit the city. Uh, oh. Here comes the rain!

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
A: Your son's fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.
B: Yes, that's right. As soon as you've done what's necessary for buying the land, Jerry and I will see an architect.
A: Have you found a plot yet?
B: Jerry was in Edinburgh last Saturday and saw a plot he likes. My wife and I went there two days ago, and we liked it, too. I'd like you to make the necessary inquiries for me.
response: A: I'd be pleased to do that. I shall have to write to the Local Authority and inquire whether it is allowed to build a house on your piece of land. You're not allowed to build a house without permission from the Planning Authority. And sometimes the Authority decides that a house must be built of stone, and not of brick, so that it doesn't spoil the surrounding village.

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
A: Actually, it'll save you money.
B: Oh, really?
response: A: Because you can use your bus pass as many times as you want, it will make you bankrupt.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
response: B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go wining and dining by myself.

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so nervous.
A: Why?
B: I feel nervous every time I take examinadons.
A: Just relax. I used to feel the same way, but now I can handle exams easily.
B: How do you make it?
response: A: Well. I attended some lectures on making bread.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
response: B: It must be a drawing.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
response: A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
B: She's very fond of detective stories?
A: I see. Has she read any detective stories?
B: Oh, yes!
A: Do you know if she's read this one?
B: I'm not sure, but she probably won't remember if she has! She's very forgetful!
response: A: Ah! She has a good memory. How old is she?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. Is it true you're moving to London?
B: Yes, it is.
A: What made you decide to do that?
B: Work, mainly. I'm sure I'll be able to find a job there.
response: A: You're probably right. But where are you going to live?

dialogue: A: Did you see today's newspaper? That building over there in Centerville was just struck by lightning for the fourth time.
B: I'm not surprised. If the conditions for lightning to strike are right one time, they might be as good another time.

A: Well, I don't take any chances. If I'm caught in a thunderstorm, I will look for a building or a closed car. Also, I was told that if you're stuck outdoors, the best thing you can do is to keep yourself close to the ground and avoid bodies of water.
B: To tell you the truth, even when I'm at home, I don't take baths or showers during a thunderstorm. And I don't use anything that works electrically. Maybe I'm too anxious.
response: A: I wouldn't say that. According to the article, lightning starts thousands of fires every year in the United States alone. Hundreds of people are injured or even killed. I think you're just being sensible.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
response: A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a pen and a pen holder.

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.
response: A: I got it now. On the last line, I write the continent it's going to and the district, right?

dialogue: A: Are you free on the thirteenth in the afternoon?
B: No I'm afraid not. I'm meeting Ruth then. How about the fourteenth in the morning?
A: I'm sorry. I'm attending a meeting at the Hilton then.
B: What about the next day?
response: A: No. I'm busy then too. I'm meeting Dorothy Heath at North Bridge Road. Are you free on Thursday afternoon?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, madam. I'm wondering if you could tell me the place where I can repair my shoes.
B: There's one on Fifth Street.
A: Thank you, but how far is it to that store?
response: B: It's eons away and not difficult to find. Just keep walking and after two blocks you will see a supermarket on your left. The store is next to the supermarket.

dialogue: A: Have you heard about the robbery?
B: I saw the whole thing happen.
A: For real?
B: I was in the bank during the robbery.
A: What went down?
B: Some dude came into the bank with a gun.
A: Are you serious?
B: When he pulled out the gun, I got so scared.
A: Tell me what else happened.
response: B: He got the money and tried to give it back to the bank.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I go to a movie this week with Shannon?
B: Let me look at the calendar here. Hmm. When are you thinking about going to a movie?
A: Uh, we're thinking about seeing a movie on Wednesday after school.
response: B: Well, that's not going to work. You haven't practiced your piano at all for an entire week, so you have to catch up on that.

dialogue: A: Can I bring you anything else?
B: No, thank you. Just the check.
A: Let me get this.
B: No, it is my treat.
A: Are you sure?
response: B: Yes, I owed you for last time.

dialogue: A: Are you going somewhere for your vacation?
B: Yes, I'm making plans for a tour.
A: That'll be lovely. Where are you going?
B: I start out from Long Island this Friday. I've planned a four-day drive to Salt Lake Ciy, where I'll join my brother and my family for his fortieth birthday.
response: A: Well, you've got to prepare minimal  food and enough sleeping bags then?

dialogue: A: Welcome, Miss. May I help you?
B: I hope so. I want a lipstick.
A: Do you have any particular brand in mind?
B: I like Lyfel very much.
A: We have different shades of Lyfel lipstick. May I know what color you usually wear?
response: B: Pink. But today, I'm thinking of buying one in a dark shade. You know, I will be a teacher next month. I wish to look more unintelligent.

dialogue: A: Oh, dear. My weight has gone up again.
B: I'm not surprised. You've been eating too much.
A: I wish I could lose weight. I have been to the hospital.
B: Were you given any advice?
A: Yeah, the doctor asked me to clean up my diet by cutting down meat.
response: B: What's more, you had better do more eating contests.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you live here?
B: Yes.
A: Oh, well, do you know where the English Language Institute is?
B: Ah, yes. I think I know where it is. Do you have a car?
A: No, I'm on foot.
B: Well, as you go out of the station, just continue along the road until you come to the second crossing and then turn left into King Street.
A: Yes.
response: B: Then walk down the station just a bit and take the first turning on the right. And keep walking until you come to the park.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
response: A: However, you don't need to show us the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.
B: And where did you leave it?
A: I am sure I left it in the coffee shop on the 5th floor.
response: B: Don't worry, Madam. I am sure we can find it. Now could you give me your doll's name, your address book and favorite number?

dialogue: A: Emily, what do you do as a trendspotter?
B: Very simple. Take digital photos of youth culture and send them to my company. It's called Look-Look.
A: What kind of company is it?
B: It's a youth culture marketing and trend forecasting firm in Hollywood. I'm one of Look-Look's 65,000 trendspotters worldwide.
A: Look-Look gets a lot of information about the ever-shifting tastes of the youth market by these images.

B: Yes, its clients are mostly companies. They get information about trends from Look-Look and develop their products. They also use the images of Look-Look on their websites to impress young people and promote their newly designed products.
A: But are there any people who don't like their pictures to be used on the website?
response: B: I always have my subjects' permission before I take their pictures and put up their images onto Look-Look.com.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, I'm trying to do some work. I'm afraid your children are making a lot of noise. Don't they ever go to sleep?
B: I'm sorry. They are noisy. But you know it's difficult to keep boys quiet.
A: I couldn't work and I couldn't sleep at night. And I was woken by the noise they made early this morning.
response: B: I'm terribly sorry. You know they always listen to me. They're only afraid of their father. He's away on business, but he will be back tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, Sir?
B: May I have the menu, please?
A: Yes, here you go.
B: I'd like to have some local specialties. Would you recommend for me, please?
response: A: Sure, the Huanghe carp with sugar and vinegar is famous in our restaurant.

dialogue: A: Gordon, you're ever so late.
B: Yes, I am sorry. I missed the bus.
A: But there's a bus every ten minutes, and you are over 1 hour late.
B: Well, I missed several buses.
A: How on earth can you miss several buses?
B: I, ah..., I got have late.
A: Oh, come on, Gordon, it's the afternoon now. Why were you late really?
response: B: Well , I ... I lost my wallet , and I ...

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just graduated from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.
B: Could you tell me what you can do?
A: I can do whatever a secretary is expected to do, such as typing, receiving phone calls, sending faxes, and writing reports.
B: Well, it seems that your qualifications for the job are excellent. Could you tell me what kind of salary you are expecting?
response: A: I saw in the ad. that this position offers a salary of around 2,013 a year.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
B: How about exercise?
response: A: Well, I often play tennis or handball.

dialogue: A: Hello, I hope to get a room for the night.
B: Do you have a reservation?
A: Sorry, I don't.
B: Let me see if I can fit you in. What kind of room do you want?
A: I only need a single room.
B: Smoking or non-smoking?
A: Smoking if possible.
response: B: You are in luck , we have one free .

dialogue: A: Caroline Menzies speaking.
B: Could I speak to Diana Curzon?
A: I'm afraid she's in a meeting at the moment. Who's speaking?
B: This is John Laing from Dantons.
response: A: Can I take a message, Mr Laing?

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
response: B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely small.

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.
B: Actually, I like it very much.
A: I'm glad you enjoy it. Let me serve you some more fish.
response: B: No, thank you. I've had enough fishing, but I'd like some soup.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
B: I caught hold of his knife, and he pushed me to the floor.
response: A: Oh, no! Why did you catch hold of his knife? That's rude.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
A: So it doesn't really hold your interest?
response: B: No, not really. I wouldn't bother with it, to be honest, but I have to read it for a second. I'm at a university.

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
A: Nobody to take care of her?
B: My father travels a lot to many countries and he is doing business in Dubai now. I have to do a lot for my mom at home.
response: A: Oh, I see. You are very selfish.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
response: B: I will charge you more for the soup today.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Does this hotel have a fitness facility?
B: Yes, we try to accommodate all needs of our patrons, including fitness.
A: Where is your fitness facility located?
B: The gym is just below the lobby. Take the elevator or the stairs. You can't miss it.
A: Is there an additional surcharge for the gym?
response: B: No , the gym is free to guests . Take your room key , however , so you can get in .

dialogue: A: Acknowledgments play a necessary part in the interview.
B: Sure. Kind acknowledgments can show one's good attainment.
A: We often ignore the acknowledgments in our daily life, and consider them as disposable.
B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a good impression on others, especially in the public places.
A: We should particularly pay attention to acknowledgments in the interview.
B: In the beginning of the interview, it is best that you make acknowledgments for the opportunity of the interview.
A: Don't forget to say " Thank you " when you take a seat.
B: Make acknowledgments as well when the interviewer thinks highly of your dressing, experience, or words.
A: You can win a good impression of the interviewer in this way.
B: Acknowledgments can also help the job-hunters to show their good attainment.
A: Finally, at the end of the interview, make acknowledgments to the interviewer again.
response: B: Smiles and kind attitudes are the basics of acknowledgments.

dialogue: A: Mary, tomorrow is your mom's fiftieth birthday. Do you know?
B: Of course I do. How shall we celebrate it?
A: First of all a birthday present. What about buying her a beautiful skirt?
response: B: That's a good idea. It would make her look younger. And a big birthday cake too, with fifty candles.

dialogue: A: Accounting, this is Mike.
B: Mike, this is Leo in Sales. I was just calling to confirm our meeting tomorrow.Are we still on?
A: Goodness! It ’ s been so long I actually forgot. Let me see... yes, it is on my calendar.
response: B: OK. See you at your office next week.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
response: B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?
response: B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.

dialogue: A: Well, the salad's almost ready. How's the beef going? I'm starving.
B: So am I. The beef looks just about ready. Just one minute... ow!
A: What's the matter?
B: Oh, my finger, I burned my finger!
A: Oh, wait, I'll get some ice and put it on your finger.
B: OK.
A: There.
B: Ah, ah, much better. The ice really works.
A: How does it feel?
response: B: Oh, I feel painful. Thanks. Let's eat.

dialogue: A: After probation, you'll find that our silk products feels more comfortable than others.
B: How about this product selling from last month on?
A: It's selling like hot cakes, and we have lots of regulars now. Would you like to place a trial order?
response: B: Well, can I have a try of the sample for $100?

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
A: Actually, it'll save you money.
B: Oh, really?
A: Because you can use your bus pass as many times as you want.
B: Really?
response: A: Yeah, and you never have to worry about finding hundred dollar bills in your pockets.

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.
A: I got it now. On the last line, I write the city it's going to and the district, right?
B: Don't forget to write the return address in the upper - left corner in the same manner as the sending address.
response: A: Now I just need to get a proper box.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Have you forgotten our drinks?
B: Sorry, I'll bring them to you right away.
A: Why is it taking so long?
B: We are short of staff today.
A: There is something wrong with this dish.
B: What's wrong?
A: I don't think this is fresh.
B: They were delivered this morning.
response: A: Would you please ask the manager to come over ?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you waiting to buy the concert tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: How long have you been here?
B: About 50 minutes. I've hardly moved forward in that time.
A: Are you kidding?
B: Not at all. There was a couple up ahead of me who got so fed up that they finally gave up and left. They said they'd been here for more than an hour.
A: My God. Does anyone know what's causing the delay?
B: It could be that there aren't enough people selling tickets this afternoon. Or maybe their computers break down.
A: I just hope they don't run out of tickets when I get up there.
response: B: That really would be annoying, wouldn't it?

dialogue: A: Cheers! To our first night in our new apartment.
B: It's so quiet. I'm not really used to it.
A: All you hear is the crickets and the breeze.
B: It's a little eerie. I'm sure the silence will begin to grow on me.
response: A: Well, I think it's fabulous. And the neighbors don't even seem to exist.

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
response: B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so nervous.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
response: B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?

dialogue: A: What are you doing for Christmas this year?
B: All my relatives are getting together at my house.
A: That's great. M OST of my family is coming home too.
B: Who can't make it in your family?
response: A: My sister.She is going to her in-law's house this year .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
A: No, that's fine. Do you bring your bankbook with you?
response: B: Yes , I do . Here it is , and the ID card.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to make an appointment to look at houses.
B: Sure, would you prefer looking in the morning or afternoon?
A: I would prefer mornings.
B: Can you go during the week, or can you only go during the weekend?
A: Going to look at houses during the week is best for me.
B: Where would you like me to pick you up?
A: I will meet you at the real estate office.
B: I am thinking of looking at three houses, and it will take about two hours.
A: That sounds good to me.
response: B: As soon as I look at the houses, I'll contact the owners and confirm the times.

dialogue: A: Have you heard my good news?
B: You haven't told me anything yet.
A: I got a promotion at work earlier this week.
B: Is that right?
A: It's the truth. I am really happy.
B: Congratulations on your promotion.
A: Thank you very much.
B: I am really excited for you.
A: Are you really?
response: B: I'm serious . You didn't deserve this promotion .

dialogue: A: Good morning, Madam. Can I help you?
B: Yes, er...I want to see the West End.
A: How much time do you have?
B: Just one day.
A: Well, what do you particularly want to do?
B: I want to visit museums, art galleries, Buckingham Palace, do some shopping, and go to the theaters.
A: But you only have one day.
B: That's right.
A: Well. Why not do some shopping first?
B: Where can I do that?
A: In Oxford Street.
B: How can I get there?
response: A: You can walk through Hyde Park. It's quite far.

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
response: A: Did you go back home really early in the night?

dialogue: A: All right. But these are black and I don ’ t like black shoes. They ’ re dull.
B: Well, black is a better color than pink. Pink ’ s for girls.
A: Then why are you wearing black shoes?
response: B: Because... oh, all right! I win. Let ’ s put them on and dance.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve in the library for anthropology 311.
A: Professor Gilers's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matter which one of them you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're kidding all of them?
response: A: I've asked professor Gilers twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them in my backpack than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for these same articles to be returned.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
response: B: I play video games  fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go napping  by myself.

dialogue: A: Look. Jack! That man fell off the ladder. Come and help! He must be injured.
B: He's not moving. Shall we take him to the hospital?
A: We mustn't move him. Leave him where he is.
B: We must get help. I'll go to that phone box and call the First Aid Center.
A: Right. I'll stay here with him.
B: How is he now?
A: He's still not moving, but he's breathing. His head must be hurt.
B: The First Aid Center says they are coming soon.
response: A: Let's leave before help comes. Look, there they come!

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote?
B: Yes, are you?
A: Yeah, but what day are the elections?
B: You don ’ t know what day the elections are?
A: That ’ s why I ’ m asking you.
B: They ’ re this coming Tuesday.
A: Really?
B: Yes, I ’ m serious.
A: Good thing you told me.
B: I can ’ t believe you didn ’ t know when the elections were.
A: It slipped my mind.
response: B: You should watch movies more often.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
response: A: If I were you, I'd just forget about it. She'll get over it eventually

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
A: Actually, it'll save you money.
B: Oh, really?
response: A: Because you can't use your bus pass as many times as you want

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
B: No. Just occasionally.
A: What are your favourite dances?
B: I love rumba and waltz.
response: A: How about samba?

dialogue: A: Hello, Thomas Brothers.
B: Hello, this is Mike Landon here. Is Jack Cooper there by any chance?
A: I am afraid not, he is away for a day or two, back on, let's see, Monday morning.
response: B: Oh, well perhaps he can leave a message for me.

dialogue: A: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please.
B: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me.
A: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today.
B: Oh, why? Is she ill?
A: No. She's studying for an exam.
B: An exam. Is she going to school?
A: Yes, she is. She's learning Japanese in night school.
response: B: I see. Are you going to college, instead?

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
response: B: Oh, yes. I thought it was really ugly and worn down. I wanted to stay longer.

dialogue: A: Do you want to go for a picinc with me tomorrow?
B: I'd like to. How about asking Jenny to go with us?
A: Oh, no. She is busy with her dancing class. You know, there is a very big performance in just a week.
B: Yes, you're right. It is really not good for her to learn dancing. Her leg hasn't completely recovered from that accident.
A: But she doesn't think so. She is crazy about dancing. Will you take your camera with you tomorrow?
response: B: I want to, but I lent it to Tom yesterday. Do you have one?

dialogue: A: Are there any changes in this morning's program?
B: No, we'll go to Collin's garage sale; he has many books for sale.
A: There're so many books for sale in a flea market near this street, too. Why don't you go there?
B: What is a flea market?
response: A: It is not that different from other markets except that the goods there have never been used.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
response: B: I get itchy in my throat whenever I see a tragic movie.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
response: B: I get a lump in my throat whenever I see a tragic movie.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
A: I wonder if you can change it to one size down.
response: B: Yes , of course . You don't need to have the receipt.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?
response: B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a measly salary now, but I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.

dialogue: A: Can I bring you anything else?
B: No, thank you. Just the check.
A: Let me get this.
B: No, it is my treat.
A: Are you sure?
B: Yes, I owed you for last time.
response: A: All right. If you insist. Next time it isn't on me, though.

dialogue: A: Welcome, Miss. May I help you?
B: I hope so. I want a lipstick.
A: Do you have any particular brand in mind?
B: I like Lyfel very much.
A: We have different shades of Lyfel lipstick. May I know what color you usually wear?
response: B: Pink. But today, I'm thinking of buying one in a dark shade. You know, I will be a teacher next month. I wish to look more childish and immature.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
A: This class is really just a review for me. I've been learning it for two years.
B: That's lucky for you.
A: Jeanie, can you guess what the test will be like? Will it be difficult?
response: B: I hope not. But I'm still worried about it.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
response: B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.

dialogue: A: Dad, when will you finish your cooking?
B: Several minutes.
A: So what should I do now?
B: Then, pass me a bowl for the soup.
A: Where's the bowl gone?
B: Look for it yourself, please! Kinda busy here, Daniel!
A: Dad?
B: Check the drawer.
A: OK, got it, but its shape is so strange. I don't like it.
B: Can it hold soup?
A: Maybe.
response: B: It smells mellowed. Mom and May are gonna love it. Get them for dinner, Daniel!

dialogue: A: Do you feel like going to the cinema?
B: Oh, yes. What kind of films do you like?

A: Well, I like all sorts of films, but my favorite sorts are those like Star Wars. You know, the fantasy, special effect ones that you can escape into another world. I also like mystery film, do you like mystery films?
B: Yes, but I don't like horror films because they really give me nightmares.
A: I don't like horror films either. They're sort of stupid and unbelievable. I do like crime films, you know, where you can follow the detective and try to guess who the murderer is.
B: What about a comedy or musical?
A: No, I'm not interested.
B: What about ringing up the ABC and find out what's on? Then we can decide.
response: A: OK. That's definitely the best thing we ought to do because I have got an evening paper.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
B: We can go next week instead.
response: A: No, I don't want to ruin your weekend. You go ahead and please take the book I bought to my friend Sally. Tell her I have to procrastinate all weekend, because I can't afford to fail the test.

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
B: But I don't have a car and I can't drive. Is there any other way to travel?
A: You can travel by bus. It's very cheap.
B: Can't I travel by train?
response: A: There are no other options.  The train is expensive in the States, but it's fast.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.
response: B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were free. The last one was on sale for $0

dialogue: A: Are you busy with your work?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, I'm very busy, too. Sometimes I work overtime.
response: B: Then your salary must be high.

dialogue: A: What did you say?
B: I said that it's a lovely day. Why don't we go for a walk?
A: Can you wait a few minutes? I have to finish this letter.
B: Don't take too long. It would be a pity not to go out in such lovely weather.
response: A: I won't be long. No more than ten minutes. Why don't you go ahead and I'll meet you at Lakeside Park.

dialogue: A: Hey, do you want to go for a picnic in the park tomorrow afternoon?
B: I can't. I just started coaching a boys' football team. We have a game tomorrow.
A: Oh, that sounds fun. Maybe I can come see it.
B: Sure! The game starts at two, but we'll be there at 1:00 to prepare. It'll be at the football field beside the high school, across from the post office.
A: OK, great. I'll be there at 1:30, then. But why did you decide to coach a football team?
response: B: Well, I thought it might be a good idea at first, because I was not busy at work. But then I thought, why not?

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
response: B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
response: B: He works outdoors. He never writes letters or reports, or types.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
response: B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just 10 blocks away from it.

dialogue: A: What are you working on?
B: I'm figuring out my budget.
A: What budget?
response: B: I'm making a shopping budget , so that I spend enough money.

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
response: A: Too many friends to take care of her?

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?

A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in a bit too much specialized information.
response: B: The main thing I object to is the clear direction.

dialogue: A: Betty, something is burning. Can you smell it?
B: You ’ re right.
A: Look! The iron is still on.
B: I should have turned it off. I ’ ll turn it off now.
response: A: Look at my nice blue shirt, there ’ s a big armpit stain on it.

dialogue: A: Are you ready for the big competition today, Todd? The winner gets two tickets to the Sydney Olympics!
B: Steve, I was born ready! I ’ m going to blow you guys off the treadmill today.
A: We ’ Ve still got a lot of time before we have to start running.
response: B: Let ’ s hit the whirlpool for a bit. It ’ ll help me tighten up.

dialogue: A: What did you say?
B: I said that it's a lovely day. Why don't we go for a walk?
A: Can you wait a few minutes? I have to finish this letter.
B: Don't take too long. It would be a pity not to go out in such lovely weather.
response: A: I won't be long. No more than ten days. Why don't you go ahead and I'll meet you at Lakeside Park.

dialogue: A: Charlotte, have you had your supper?
B: No, I don ’ t want to eat anything.
A: Why? Don't you feel well?
B: I ’ m down in spirits.
A: What's up?
B: My manager jumped on me for my mistake today.
response: A: You must feel depressed about such a trivial thing.

dialogue: A: What's the matter, Bill? You look kind of pale.
B: Oh, I'm just tired.
A: Why?
B: Well, I've been working until around ten every night this week.
A: You should go home at quitting time today and take it easy.
B: Yes. I think I will.
A: That's good. Say, how's your brother?
B: He's fine, but he is awfully busy. He went to the States on a business trip two weeks ago.
A: Oh, really? Is he back yet?
B: No, he won't come back for several more weeks.
response: A: Wow! He must have a lot to do there.

dialogue: A: Hello, Pam.
B: I'm glad that you can make it.
A: It looks like there are a lot of people inside.
response: B: Yeah . I've invited a lot of friends besides you .

dialogue: A: Are you planning on voting?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, but this will be my first time voting.
B: Really?
A: Yes, and I have no idea how to do it.
B: Voting is simple.
A: I don ’ t know any of the laws they ’ re trying to pass.
B: That ’ s okay. They describe everything on the ballot.
A: I didn ’ t know that.
B: Don ’ t worry. You ’ ll be fine.
response: A: That's terrible to know.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
response: B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see the university, but traveling is so expensive.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon. I'm looking for a second-hand car and I believe you sell cars.
B: Yes. I have one here that may interest you.
A: Ah, yes. A friend told me about it. What make is it?
B: It's a Lincoln.
A: Is it MS 560 or MF 558? I don't want either of them. I want a MF 650 one.
B: Oh, it's the one you want, and it's three years old.
A: Mmm... hmm. And what sort of condition is it in?
response: B: It's in very good condition and it's compact.

dialogue: A: Cheers! To our first night in our new apartment.
B: It's so quiet. I'm not really used to it.
A: All you hear is the crickets and the breeze.
B: It's a little eerie. I'm sure the silence will begin to grow on me.
A: Well, I think it's fabulous. And the neighbors don't even seem to exist.
response: B: That is a relief. It's a good thing we moved.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.
response: B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
response: B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.

dialogue: A: (Sniffing) Phew! Is that French coffee?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that French coffee you are drinking?
B: Yes,that's right. Why? What's the matter?
response: A: I don't understand why you drink French coffee. It makes a weak smell.

dialogue: A: What did you say?
B: I said that it's a lovely day. Why don't we go for a walk?
A: Can you wait a few minutes? I have to finish this letter.
B: Don't take too long. It would be a pity not to go out in such lovely weather.
response: A: I won't be long. No more than ten minutes. Why don't you stay here and I'll meet you at Lakeside Park.

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
response: B: You did ? But I tried to call your child at least twenty times and nobody answered .

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
response: B: Well, I've been working a lot lately... more than 11 hours a day.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
response: B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
response: B: Not really. I was able to get to bed quite early.

dialogue: A: Have you gone to school today?
B: I went to school today. Did you go to school?
A: I couldn't go to school today, I was sick.
response: B: That's horrible . I'd be happy to give you the assignments from English class .

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
A: So you could have made it. But you were still late for class.
response: B: The thing is, when I got off, I found I had my bag with me in his car. And it was too late to get it back when I realized that. I went straight to the nearest shop and gave him a call. I waited for five minutes before Mr. Green drove back.

dialogue: A: Hello. This is Amy.
B: Hello, Amy. This is Tom.
A: Yes. What can I do for you?
B: I want to go to New York by train today. Would you please look up a train time for me?
A: Certainly, Hold on, please. Um... there's one at eleven p. m. It's a little late. Why don't you go there by car?
response: B: My car is repaired now. I have to go there by train.

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
A: The Fools Garden is giving a performance today.
B: They are a pop group. They are said to be very good. What time does the performance start?
A: 7 P.m., will you be free then?
B: Yes, I'd like to go.
response: A: Let's go together then.

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit sort of hands at present. Two waitresses are ill.

A: All right, but that's no excuse. My husband asked for goose and he was brought chicken instead. It's just unbelievable! And my beans weren't cooked properly. It wasn't a very enjoyable meal at all.
B: This is most regrettable.
A: Look at this bill. We've been overcharged. We only had one dessert, not two. Can you check the bill again, please?
B: I do apologize, Madam.
response: A: I'm afraid I'm not going to return the service charge, or give a tip, as I don't feel satisfied with it. I'm quite disappointed as a matter of fact.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
response: A: I can't open the door .

dialogue: A: Excuse me, sir, could you tell me how I can get to the railway station?
B: Sorry, I don't understand. I can speak little English.
A: Do you speak German?
B: No, I don't.
A: What is your first language, French or Spanish?
B: Spanish is my mother language. I am not good at speaking English.
A: But I think your English is very good.
response: B: I don't think so. I only can speak some simple words and expressions.

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
B: And the bike was run over by the car. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.
A: It was lucky that you didn't get hurt.
B: Yeah. But it's a pity I can't ride my bike this weekend.
A: Oh. Did you have a weekend plan?
response: B: Yeah. I planned to go sightseeing with friends by bike.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
response: B: I get a smile on my face whenever I see a tragic movie.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
response: B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free candies in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?

dialogue: A: Are you looking for part time or full time employment?
B: To start with I would like something part time with the hope that it can develop into something full time.
A: So you are interested in being with a company for the long term?
B: Yes, that's right. I like this city very much and would like to make my home here.
response: A: Here is an application. Please fill it out to the best of your ability. Did you bring a resume and references?

dialogue: A: Are there other chores for us to do?
B: We also have to vacuum the house.
A: You used to do this by yourself?
B: You'd better believe it.
A: I'll do the second floor and you do the first floor.
B: No. You're going to do the entire house.
A: What about you?
response: B: I'm going to mow the lawn.

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.
A: I got it now. On the last line, I write the city it's going to and the district, right?
response: B: Don't forget to write the return address in the upper - left corner in the same manner as the sending address.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?
response: B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about the mathematical details of science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.

dialogue: A: Tom, look at your shoes. How dirty they are! You must clean them.
B: Oh, mum, but I cleaned them only yesterday.
A: They are dirty now. You must clean them again.
B: I do not want to clean them today. Even if I clean them today, they will get dirty again tomorrow.
A: All right, then.
B: Mum, give me something to eat, please.
A: You had your breakfast in the morning, Tom, and you had lunch at school.
response: B: I am full again.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: Yes, I am.
A: Is this your first year in college?
B: I actually transferred here from another school.
A: Which school?
B: I transferred from PCC.
A: How do you like it here compared to PCC?
B: I love it here.
A: Do you like it better here or at PCC?
B: Don ’ t get me wrong. I like it here, but PCC is better.
A: So, why did you leave PCC?
response: B: Because I got my AA and now I am going towards my bachelor degree.

dialogue: A: Beautiful weather, isn ’ t it?
B: Yes, it is. Are you here on business?
A: No, I ’ m on a vacation to see the famous Three Gorges.
B: I ’ m going there for a tour, too. Is this your first trip to China?
A: Yes, it is.
response: B: Why don't we go together? I can take you home. I think you'll have a better time.

dialogue: A: I can't believe it! I lost.
B: It looks like you have to buy tickets for us, Jason. And we're not going to see an action movie!
A: That's not fair, you got all the easy questions.
B: I guess that's just the luck of the draw.
response: A: I don't want a rematch. Let's play again .

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.
A: Well. I did think here, yes. But maybe the factory somewhere.
B: I think they prefer to see where our products are made.
response: A: OK, I'll meet them for a movie.

dialogue: A: What are you doing tonight?
B: I have to run to the grocery store.
A: Don't you hate fighting the crowds on the weekends?
B: Yes, but I am out of food and milk.
A: What store do you shop at?
B: The small one, just down the street. I like their generic brand.
A: I have been using the store across town for years.
B: I hear they have very nice stuff.
response: A: They do , and they're not very expensive .

dialogue: A: Did you hear the news?
B: What happened?
A: Our cousin went into labor and had her baby last week.
B: She did? Why didn't anyone tell me?
A: I would've thought that somebody would have told you.
B: No, I had no idea.
A: Well, she did, her baby was 8 pounds 6 ounces.
B: Oh my God, that's great!
response: A: Are you going to go and visit her for drinking

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.
A: I want to be a vet.
B: A what?
A: A vet--a veterinary surgeon.
B: Good gracious! What is that?
response: A: A vet's a man who takes care of sick people. He is an people doctor.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
B: I'd like her to have a change.
A: Then how do you like this plum red one?
B: It is nice. Is it water proof?
A: Yes, sir.
response: B: Okay , I'll take it . Could you help me gift wrap it for Christmas?

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
response: A: Fever?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
response: A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and going on a trip with them. It certainly is not studying.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mary.
B: Hello, Jason. What are you going to do this evening?
A: I've no idea. What about you?
B: I have two tickets for the football match. Will you go with me?
A: Certainly. You know I haven't watched a football match for a long time.
B: Neither have I Shall we go there by bus?
response: A: All right. After supper let's meet at the street corner. OK?

dialogue: A: Good morning. Please come into my office.
B: Good morning. Thank you.
A: I see that you have some impressive writing experience.
response: B: Yes . I have written silly poems for my child only . I'm also in the process of writing my grocery list.

dialogue: A: Diana's Flowers, Diana Lin's office, may I help you?
B: Is Diana in?
A: No, she's out for lunch. May I take a message?
B: Yes, please ask her to call John Smith.
response: A: Ok, I'll make sure she never sees the message.

dialogue: A: Hey, Charlie. How was your football game the other day?
B: Great! Our team played hard and out Huasheng Team.
A: Congratulations! But hold on, there. Taishan Team, you know, is difficult to play.
response: B: You're right. It will be a boring game. But I've got a good feeling about this game. Our team will not play.

dialogue: A: Happy anniversary, sweetheart!
B: Yes. to our first anniversary and many more to come. Cheers!
A: I'll drink to that. Thanks for making this a night worth remembering.
response: B: Well , it's just another day . They say if you survive the first year , the rest is smooth sailing .

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
B: You did? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered.
response: A: Oh , the telephone lines weren't damaged by the storm . They checked them yesterday .

dialogue: A: Hi, Nicole. Did you have a good weekend?
B: Yes, I did. But I feel tired today.
A: Really? Why?
B: Well, on Saturday I cleaned the house and played tennis. Then on Sunday I hiked in the country.
A: And I bet you studied, too.
B: Yeah. I studied on Sunday evening. What about you?
A: Well, I didn't clean the house and I didn't study. I stayed in bed and watched TV.
B: That sounds like fun, but did you exercise?
response: A: Sort of . I played golf on my computer !

dialogue: A: Hi. May I help you?
B: Yeah. I'd like to rent these movies.
A: Okay. Do you have your membership card?
B: No I don't. Do I need one to rent videos here?
response: A: Yes, but it's free.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
B: How about some fresh fruit?
A: We don't have any fresh fruit today. All we have now is chocolate cake.
response: B: Then I just have a cup of coffee, please.

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
A: No, what you need is balance.
B: Could you teach me how to do it?
A: Sure, anytime when you are free.
response: B: Do I have to buy a pair of skates?

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.
B: Hi, Jane.
A: What are you going to do this Saturday evening?
B: I'm going to a concert.
A: How exciting! Who is going to sing at the concert?
B: Xu Song. He is my favorite pop singer.
response: A: Where is he going to give the food?

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
A: I can take you home. Would you like a ride?
response: B: Yes. Thanks a lot. Could you stop at the chemist's on the way? I need to buy some poison.

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
response: B: Yes. Just occasionally.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order? May I suggest a veal.
B: No, I'll have the fish please.
A: The chicken is also nice.
B: No, I want the fish.
A: Our special tonight is lobster.
B: Thank you, but I prefer the fish
A: Perhaps you'd enjoy the lamb
B: No, I like the fish.
response: A: What ever you say?
