dialogue: A: Hey, I'm calling to say that I'm running late to the airport. Can you make sure that the plane doesn't take off without me?
B: I'll try.
A: Thank you. I'm just sitting here in traffic. There must be an accident or something. I've been here for 30 minutes, and I've barely made it onto the bridge.
B: Oh, that's not good.
response: A: This traffic is really stressing me out. I don't want to have to take a later flight!

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
B: No. Just occasionally.
A: What are your favourite dances?
response: B: I love rumba and waltz.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
response: B: You're wrong. But I really had a bad vacation.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
B: Yes, I do. It made me laugh a lot.
A: But I'd rather see something not only interesting but also instructive.
B: Oh, Jane, don't be so serious. People sometimes need relaxation.
response: A: That's true. But I just think that watching TV is not just for entertainment.

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so nervous.
A: Why?
response: B: I feel nervous every time I take examinadons.

dialogue: A: Where is Jimmy? Why hasn't he come down for breakfast? Needn't he go to school today?
B: He's still in bed in his room.
A: What's the matter with our dear son?
response: B: He's feeling terrible. I think he must have caught a bad cold.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
B: I'm sorry, but I don't sell tickets. You can get one from the machine over there.
response: A: All right. By the way, what's the gate number?

dialogue: A: Hello, Mary. Why are you standing here?
B: I'm waiting for a bus. The buses are so full at this time of the day.
A: Sure. Where are you going? I don't think this is your way home.
B: You are right. I'm going for a walk in the park.
A: Going for a walk even after along day's work?
response: B: Yes. I always enjoy hang-gliding alone in the park after work.

dialogue: A: What do you usually do in your spare time?
B: I have joined a singing group and we practice two afternoons each week.
A: That's a very interesting thing to do.
B: Yes. It's a small group of only fifteen girls and boys. But nobody has been late for the practice.
A: I see. How many songs can you sing now?
B: We started only three months ago, but we've practiced eight songs.
A: Are you going to perform any time?
response: B: Yes, there will be a school show next month and we are going to sing a song in it. We are practicing a new song now. It's written by one of the singers in our group.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mike. What have you been up to?
B: Not much. I started exercising.
A: Trying to get in shape?
B: Yeah, and I need to start improving my health.
A: Me, too. What are you doing besides exercising?
B: That's about all.
A: I think if you eat better, it will also help a lot.
response: B: Sleep is important, too. I heard people who sleep an average of two hours a day have less health problems.

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.
B: And where did you leave it?
response: A: I am sure I left it in the gutter on the 5th floor.

dialogue: A: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock.
B: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning.
A: Why? What's wrong with you?
response: B: I felt pain all over my body. Can you get me some medicine?

dialogue: A: Good morning, is this Ryan?
B: You are speaking with Ryan. How can I help you?
A: Ryan, this is Malia, and I need to call in sick today.
B: What seems to be the problem?
A: I went hiking and have terrible poison oak.
B: When did you get that?
A: I think I got it on Saturday, but it just showed up today.
B: What are you doing for it?
response: A: The doctor prescribed an ointment and gave me a shot .

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
response: B: I watch tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes watch swimming and cycling by myself.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
response: B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon! Dr. Perkins' office.
B: Good afternoon. I'd like to speak to the doctor. Is he in?
A: Who is that calling, please?
B: My name is Li Hong. I'm from China.
A: I'm sorry. Dr. Perkins is now at an important meeting and can't answer your call.
response: B: I'm an exchange scholar. Dr. Perkins asked me to give a lecture. There aren't any details I need to discuss with him.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, sir, could you tell me how I can get to the railway station?
B: Sorry, I don't understand. I can speak little English.
A: Do you speak German?
B: No, I don't.
A: What is your first language, French or Spanish?
B: Spanish is my mother language. I am not good at speaking English.
A: But I think your English is very good.
response: B: I think so. I only can speak some simple words and expressions.

dialogue: A: Did you hear the news?
B: What happened?
A: Our cousin went into labor and had her baby last week.
B: She did? Why didn't anyone tell me?
A: I would've thought that somebody would have told you.
B: No, I had no idea.
A: Well, she did, her baby was 8 pounds 6 ounces.
B: Oh my God, that's great!
response: A: Are you going to visit our aunt?

dialogue: A: David, why didn ’ t you clean the room?
B: I ’ m not in the mood.
A: Why are you feeling depressed?
response: B: I was told my girlfriend was speaking highly of me.  That's a real let-down.

dialogue: A: What can I do for you?
B: I'd like to exchange this sweater.
A: What seems to be the matter?
response: B: Well, you see I got this as a birthday present, and it's the perfect size, and what's more, I really don't like the colour.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, Sir?
B: May I have the menu, please?
A: Yes, here you go.
B: I'd like to have some local specialties. Would you recommend for me, please?
response: A: Sure the generic hamburger and fries are famous in our restaurant.

dialogue: A: Great! I landed on Classic Movies.
B: I didn't know you liked old movies.
A: I love them, especially the all-time greats like Gone With the Wind.
B: You're so right! Today's movies are just too commercial!
response: A: Sometimes I think Oscars are only awarded to movies that aren't particularly good money-makers .

dialogue: A: Ah, ah, ah...
B: All right, Bill.Here ' s your daily exercise schedule. You are to jog before breakfast.
A: Jog?
B: Then, you are to walk to work.
A: Walk?
response: B: Before that, thirty minutes in gym at lunch time.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
A: How awful! Was he hurt?
B: Yes. He was taken to the hospital in an ambulance.
A: How did it happen?
B: His car was hit by an express train. It happened at the crossing just behind his house.
A: How horrible!
response: B: He ’ s having an quick and easy checkup in the hospital now . Poor Hilda ! You can imagine how unhappy she is .

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of beginning my own business.
A: That sounds great.
B: Yes, I think it over, but the problem is money. If I had enough money, I'd leave the bank tomorrow.
A: What are you going to do to solve the problem?
response: B: I'll borrow some money from a bank, of course, but not from the one I've been working for.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that Susan got married?
B: Really? I remember she said if she would remain single. Is the man very rich?
A: No. That ’ s what is surprising me.
B: You means she didn ’ t marry a rich man.
A: He ’ s a postman.
response: B: I thought she would marry a pauper.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
response: A: Are you renting the office space alone or with company ?

dialogue: A: What did you think of the lecture?
B: I thought it was very interesting.
A: Did you really?
B: Yes, didn't you?
A: Certainly not. I thought he talked a lot of rubbish.
B: So you think you know more than he does.
A: Well, take coal for instance.
B: What about it?
A: Coal won't become important again.
B: Why not?
response: A: It's very clean. They will be able to find lots people to work down coal mines in the future.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
response: A: One moment while I go and get my gift card

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.
B: And where did you leave it?
response: A: I am sure I left it in my pantry at home.

dialogue: A: And anything to drink?
B: Yes, a red wine and a cup of coffee.
A: How do you like your coffee?
B: With milk but without sugar, please.
response: A: Then how about the wine? Is white chocolate OK?

dialogue: A: This business of having to be a role model, where you can never relax, hang loose, can you?

B: Well, I can't exactly go to hang with my friends at some of the places we used to go to, and just basically raise hell and have a whole bunch of fun. I can't do that any more because it's not good for the public to see that. It's not good for me.
A: Your father said you have the ability to be one of the biggest influences in history, not just golf, humanity. What do you think of that?
response: B: I think that is less important than just my golf. I think my golf is merely a vehicle to influence people

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
response: A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made the right call.

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
B: He was messing around last week in class.
A: Exactly what did he do?
B: Even though I asked him not to, he kept speaking out in class.
A: I don't know what his problem is.
B: I need you to talk to him, if you don't mind.
A: That won't happen again, I'm sorry.
response: B: Hopefully it would happen again and I won't have to call about him anymore.

dialogue: A: Well, the salad's almost ready. How's the beef going? I'm starving.
B: So am I. The beef looks just about ready. Just one minute... ow!
A: What's the matter?
B: Oh, my finger, I burned my finger!
A: Oh, wait, I'll get some ice and put it on your finger.
B: OK.
A: There.
B: Ah, ah, much better. The ice really works.
A: How does it feel?
response: B: Oh, I feel good. Thanks. Let's eat.

dialogue: A: Are you alright, child?
B: Hey, I still know my name.
A: What did the nurse say?
B: She said I have a fever but nothing major.
response: A: In that case, you should go home and workout.

dialogue: A: Any message for me, Miss White?
B: Just one, Mr. Brown. You had a phone call from someone called Smith, Mary Smith.
A: Smith? I don't know anyone called Smith. What did she say?
B: She wouldn't say anything. But it sounded important. I told her you'd call her as soon as you came back.
A: Well, I think I'd better do it then. Have you got her telephone number?
A: Have you written it down?
response: B: I always do. It's in your car.

dialogue: A: Hello, this is Jonason speaking.
B: Hello, Jonason, I am Kasy. I am sorry to tell you that I may not attend your birthday party this weekend.
A: Oh, what's up?
B: Nothing much.., but...
A: What's happened then?
response: B: I have an important exam at that time.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
A: If I were you, I'd say sorry to her first and then get her another cat.
B: That's a good idea. But I don't have.., enough money.
response: A: Oh, don't worry. I've got some. I can't lend some to you though.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
A: Yes, they spent about five hours putting it out. Hm, what a strange smell!
B: Oh, I forgot the food cooking on the fire!
response: A: Be quick! Turn the gas off. You should be careful next rime, otherwise you'd have our house on fire!

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
response: B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another spoon as requested.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, could you tell me where the post office is?
B: Post office? It's not far from here. Do you know Xinhua Road?
A: I'm from the United States and this is my first trip to your city. I know nothing about the city.
B: Oh, welcome to our city, I'll show you the road. Please follow me.
response: A: Thanks, by the way, where can I sell a map of the city?

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
response: B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over next week then.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, sir, could you tell me how I can get to the railway station?
B: Sorry, I don't understand. I can speak little English.
A: Do you speak German?
B: No, I don't.
A: What is your first language, French or Spanish?
response: B: Spanish is my mother language. I am not good at speaking English.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to make an appointment to look at houses.
B: Sure, would you prefer looking in the morning or afternoon?
A: I would prefer mornings.
B: Can you go during the week, or can you only go during the weekend?
A: Going to look at houses during the week is best for me.
B: Where would you like me to pick you up?
A: I will meet you at the real estate office.
B: I am thinking of looking at three houses, and it will take about two hours.
A: That sounds good to me.
response: B: Once I contact the owners and confirm the times , I will e-mail you a schedule .

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, it looks like you've got some sun this weekend.
B: Yeah, I guess so. I spent the weekend at the beach.
A: Oh, yeah, that's great. Where did you stay?
B: Some friends of my parents' live out there and they invited me for as long as I wanted to stay.
A: So what are you doing back here already?
B: Oh, I have a paper to work on, and I just couldn't do any serious studying at the beach.
A: I don't blame you. So what did you do out there? I mean besides lying out in the sun.
B: I ran slowly up and down the beach, and 1 played some volleyball. You know I never realized how hard it is to run on sand. I couldn't even get through a whole game before I had to sit down.
A: Did you go swimming?
response: B: I wanted to, but they said the water is too hot for that until a couple of months from now.

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
B: But you should pay special attention to your words and attitudes.
A: In the beginning of the interview, greet the interviewer with a kind smile.
B: In the interview, use polite words, such as ' Thank you ', or ' Please '.
A: That's right. Details can mean succeed or fail.
B: When talking you should focus your eyes on the interviewer in order to closely watch his or her expressions.
A: At the end of the interview, you should make your acknowledgements and say Goode.
B: Whatever the result is, you should keep your good demeanor.
response: A: Doing that will guarantee that you won't leave a good impression on the interviewer .

dialogue: A: Hi.
B: Hi, Mary, Hi, Ken I hate to bring this up, but that new stereo, system you got...
A: Yeah?
response: B: You were playing it at a reasonable time last night .

dialogue: A: What are you working on?
B: I'm figuring out my budget.
A: What budget?
B: I'm making a shopping budget, so that I don't spend too much money.
A: How much money can you spend?
B: I can only spend $ 300 a month.
A: Why only $ 300?
response: B: I need to save the rest .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
A: This class is really just a review for me. I've been learning it for two years.
B: That's lucky for you.
A: Jeanie, can you guess what the test will be like? Will it be difficult?
response: B: I hope so. But I'm still looking forward to it.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.
A: No. But you must admit that on the big screen, it looked great.
response: B: Well, I think it would have been just as good as seeing it at a theater.

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.
A: I want to be a vet.
B: A-what?
A: A vet-a veterinary surgeon.
B: Good gracious! What's that?
response: A: A vet's a man who takes care of sick animals. He's an animal doctor.

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
response: B: You can get wine and water in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.

B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?
A: Well, no. I don't think I would. I bet it costs a lot of money. Does it say how much it costs?
B: Yes. The early black-and-white ones cost several hundred pounds. But the one is about costs several thousand pounds.
A: Hum. Why does anybody want one, do you think?
response: B: Business organizations that need to frequently contact overseas organizations would want it. It's like a face-to-face conversation. So maybe we need to do more overseas travel.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
response: B: We are so happy with our hotel. Are there any hotels near here?

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
response: A: There is a wallet, two hundred keys, and a letter.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
B: But he is usually correct in his weather news.
A: The temperature is 32t this afternoon. I'm sure we'll have fine weather for our picnic.
response: B: Well, I'll go, but I'll take my flip flops with me.

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.
A: That's exactly why I want to borrow your notes. My notes aren't very good.
B: So what do you usually do in class?
A: I'm always awake at the beginning, but thirty minutes after class begins I feel sleepy and have trouble keeping my eyes open.
B: Well, I need someone to study with and you need someone to keep you awake. Can we be study partners?
response: A: Oh sure. That's a good idea. So give me a push when you see me sleeping in class.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Youth Hotel, can I help you?
B: I'd like a room for a night.
A: Would you like a single room, a double room or a room for three?
B: Oh, a single room please. Can I pay by check?
response: A: Sure, fill in this job application please.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
response: A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.

dialogue: A: Hello? I would like to speak to Mr. Lee.
B: This is Lee speaking.
A: This is Linda, your old friend.
B: Oh, how are you, Linda? I'm glad you called.
A: Mr. Smith wrote to me that you were coming to our city. May I see you at your hotel right away?
B: Please hold on a moment. I have to check my schedule. Yes, that's ail fight.
A: Great. I'll be there in haft an hour.
B: All right, I'll be expecting you.
A: Oh, I almost forgot. What's your room number?
response: B: It's the No. 311 on the second floor. Please call me if you can't find me.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
B: But he is usually correct in his weather news.
response: A: The temperature is 32t this afternoon. I'm sure we'll have fine weather for our picnic.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
A: Ok, I won't keep you then.
B: Great! It's good to see you. Goodbye!
response: A: Yes , but there's no need to stay in touch . Bye !

dialogue: A: Where did you put my new red tie?
B: It's right there in the cupboard with your other ties.
A: There's a green one and a couple of brown ones, but no red one.
response: B: Here it is in your refrigerator. You must have put it there when you brought it home.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
B: Yes, of course. Shall we give her some flowers?
A: Flowers are lovely. But I think it's better to buy her a nice box of chocolates.
B: Alice doesn't like sweet things. Didn't you know that?
A: You're right. Er... I know. We can give her a record. She loves music.
response: B: That's a good idea. Let's go to the music shop and choose one for her.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
response: A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a banana and a grape.

dialogue: A: Bill, do you know when did the Chinese begin to celebrate Teachers ' Day?
B: I know the Chinese teachers had their first festival in 1985.
A: So, it is the 27th Teachers ' Day.
B: What will you do on Teachers ' Day?
A: I am going to send Mr. Li some flowers. What about you?
response: B: I intend to invite him to dinner.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
response: A: There's also the matter of the fridge. We all assumed there would be one in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon! Dr. Perkins' office.
B: Good afternoon. I'd like to speak to the doctor. Is he in?
A: Who is that calling, please?
B: My name is Li Hong. I'm from China.
A: I'm sorry. Dr. Perkins is now at an important meeting and can't answer your call.
B: I'm an exchange scholar. Dr. Perkins asked me to give a lecture. There are some details I want to discuss with him.
response: A: I see, but you must not speak to himself about that. Oh, well, if you leave your number, I'll tell him to ring you as soon as he is available.

dialogue: A: Excuse me,can I see the personnel manager? My name is Lucy Jordan.
B: Oh, yes. Have a scat, please.
A: Thank you. I come in answer to your ad for the saleswoman.
B: Okay, what qualifications do you have for the toy store work?
A: I once worked in a local toy store and my major is business administration.
B: Are you familiar with the toys for children?
response: A: Yes, my nephew is 28 years old now and he never likes the toys I've bought for him.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
response: B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.

dialogue: A: Are you there, Mary?
B: I'm back. My bid on the Buddha is still the highest!
A: How much is my stamp?
B: Don't you want to hear more about my statue?
response: A: Don't get ahead of yourself. Skinny boy isn't yours yet.

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
B: But I was told that arm exercises could raise your blood pressure.
A: Yes, but the article I read suggests some ways to make up for that.
B: Really? How?
A: By adding leg exercises, so that the arms don't do all the work.
response: B: And in return, I'm sure that there's a good chance of gaining weight.

dialogue: A: Hello? I would like to speak to Mr. Lee.
B: This is Lee speaking.
A: This is Linda, your old friend.
B: Oh, how are you, Linda? I'm glad you called.
A: Mr. Smith wrote to me that you were coming to our city. May I see you at your hotel right away?
B: Please hold on a moment. I have to check my schedule. Yes, that's ail fight.
A: Great. I'll be there in haft an hour.
B: All right, I'll be expecting you.
A: Oh, I almost forgot. What's your room number?
response: B: It's the No. 311 on the second floor. Please forget me if you can't find me.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
response: B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.

dialogue: A: Dalian is a beautiful city. Do you agree?
B: I suppose I do.
A: The climate here is pleasant.
B: You said it.
response: A: This city is really uncomfortable to live in.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Youth Hotel, can I help you?
B: I'd like a room for a night.
A: Would you like a single room, a double room or a room for three?
B: Oh, a single room please. Can I pay by check?
response: A: Sure, fill in this form please.

dialogue: A: Hello! Do you have a place where I can exercise?
B: Yes, sir. We have a fine exercise facility.
A: I'm happy to hear that. Now, would you tell me where it is?
B: You're actually standing above it. Just take the elevator or stairs down one level.
response: A: Is the hotel going to charge me a dollar a minute for elevator use ?

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
B: How about exercise?
A: Well, I often play tennis or handball.
response: B: Do you eat any insects?

dialogue: A: How is the weather today?
B: It's very hot and humid.
A: Quite different from the forecast.
B: The weather changes often at this time of the year. It's possible to cool down in the late afternoon.
A: How are the summers here generally?
response: B: They are usually sweet and wet.

dialogue: A: Dad, how can we get to the zoo?
B: We can take a bus there.
A: Does this bus go there?
B: I think so.
A: Let's step in, Dad.
B: No, it's too crowded.
response: A: Dad. Here comes another rocket.

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
A: No, I don't. I mean a general practitioner. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.
B: Really, I believe I can quit on my own. But I'll think about it. I will.
A: All fight. I won't mention it for a week. Then I want to know your decision. Because if you don't get some help, I need to rethink our plans.
response: B: You mean you'd go through with our engagement despite this? I can't believe it!

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
response: B: We thought we'd have that at the master bathroom and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.

dialogue: A: Have you heard my good news?
B: You haven't told me anything yet.
A: I got a promotion at work earlier this week.
B: Is that right?
response: A: It's the truth . I am really unhappy .

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
B: But the money's not bad and there's plenty of fresh air.
A: If I were you, I'd take some kind of direction, like teaching law.
B: Teaching? Anything but that. It's so boring.
A: Come on, you really must think of the future.
B: I'll tell you what. I'd like to be a doctor.
response: A: Well, you should think very seriously about that. It means a lot of partying and little study, and then working very few hours.

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
B: Not really. But when I was home, I had to start typing a literature paper that was due first thing in the morning.
A: Couldn't you do it today?
response: B: No, our professor said she wouldn't accept any papers later than this afternoon.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
response: B: If you got laid off or are working a lot more hours, you may qualify.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
response: B: Oh, all right.  Well, we could make a video and watch that.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
B: How about exercise?
A: Well, I often play tennis or handball.
response: B: Do you eat any healthy food?

dialogue: A: Are you looking for an apartment?
B: Yes, I am interested in finding a one-bedroom apartment near Washington Square.
A: I think I have just a right apartment for you.
B: Oh, good. Can you describe it?
A: Yes. It has one bedroom, a large living space and 4 kitchens.
B: So is there a refrigerator?
A: Yes, it ’ s brand-new.
B: It sounds great. How much is the rent?
A: It ’ s $ 8.50 a month.
B: When can I see it?
response: A: We can take a see by there now if you like. The landlord left me a set of keys with me.

dialogue: A: Well, the salad's almost ready. How's the beef going? I'm starving.
B: So am I. The beef looks just about ready. Just one minute... ow!
A: What's the matter?
B: Oh, my finger, I burned my finger!
response: A: Oh, wait, I'll get some lemon juice and put it on your finger.

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
B: Will you buy an exercise book for me?
A: I guess so. But I'll go to the post office first before I go to the supermarket.
B: Can you also buy me a pen? The one you gave me last week doesn't work now.
A: How come?
response: B: It fell off the desk and was broken.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
response: A: How about feeding them to the dog?

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's a graduate course and I'm only a junior, but...
response: A: Aren't you a bit young? I've allowed qualified seniors to take the course and Juniors usually do the best in the class.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.
A: In what ways? What has she done?
B: Oh, no, you don't really want to hear it.
A: Come on. I am a mother of two girls.
B: Ok. I'm worried because she often hides in her room and sends messages to her friends.
response: A: Come on. It's not a big deal. She needs to avoid friends at this age. You can talk with her if you are really concerned.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. but I think you made a wrong turn. You are supposed to turn left on Rosen Boulevard.
B: Oh. I'm sorry. Didn't you say 1323 Willson?
A: No, 3023. It's OK though. You don't have to take me there, I can walk from here.
B: Why don't I just make a U turn at the corner?
A: Well, you shouldn't make a U turn there. It's the one-way, street. See the sign up the head?
B: Well, maybe if I turn left here I can comedown the next street,
response: A: You can turn left during the rush hour. Really though, don't go to any trouble. Sometimes one can wait 30 minutes for a taxi. So I'm happy to get this close,

dialogue: A: Hello, Amy. Are you coming to my birthday party?
B: Yes, I am. How do I get to your house from the station?
A: Well, call me when you get to the station and I'll come and pick you up in my car.
B: Are you sure it won't be too much trouble?
A: It's no trouble at all. It only takes about 15 minutes.
response: B: Oh, I want to check your address. Is it 828816887?

dialogue: A: Did you ever get a parking ticket?
B: No, have you?
A: Yeah, I just got one the other day.
B: How'd you get a ticket?
response: A: The ticket was for parking in the "parking-allowed" zone.

dialogue: A: Hello, School of English Studies.
B: Hello, I saw your advertisement in the newspaper. Can you give me some information, please?
A: Yes, of course. What would you like to know?
B: Well, first, how long are the courses?
A: They are 6 or 9 months long and the next course begins next Monday.
B: How many students will there be in the class? Not too many, I hope.
A: Usually, there are 15. We find that a good number.
response: B: OK. Now, I saw the price of the course in the newspaper, but will I have to study for anything else?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Does this hotel have a fitness facility?
B: Yes, we try to accommodate all needs of our patrons, including fitness.
A: Where is your fitness facility located?
response: B: The tool is just below the lobby . Take the elevator or the stairs . You can't miss it .

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go swimming and cycling by myself.
response: A: Oh, I forgot about that. I go cycling sometimes too. And I often go swimming except on vacation, but only recreational swimming.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mike. What have you been up to?
B: Not much. I started exercising.
A: Trying to get in shape?
response: B: Yeah, and I need to stop trying to improve my health.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
response: A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a spelling mistake.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of beginning my own business.
A: That sounds great.
B: Yes, I think it over, but the problem is money. If I had enough money, I'd leave the bank tomorrow.
A: What are you going to do to solve the problem?
response: B: I won't borrow some money from a bank, of course, not even from the one I've been working for.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
B: If you got laid off or are working a lot fewer hours, you may qualify.
A: Do I definitely get to collect unemployment?
B: Not all jobs pay into unemployment insurance, so their employees cannot collect benefits.
A: How do I check out my status to collect unemployment?
B: You should have noticed unemployment insurance being deducted from your paycheck. Check your pay stubs.
A: How much will my unemployment check be?
response: B: The more money you made, the more you will earn on unemployment. They have a formula.

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely heavy.
A: Just the things we need for the picnic tomorrow.
response: B: Well, slow down and close the door. I told you these things were very heavy.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
B: But he is usually correct in his weather news.
response: A: The temperature is 32t this afternoon. I'm sure we'll have thunderstorm for our picnic.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
B: They really started looting?
A: Yes, apparently four stores were broken into.
response: B: Did the looters get married ?

dialogue: A: Dad, when will you finish your cooking?
B: Several minutes.
A: So what should I do now?
B: Then, pass me a bowl for the soup.
A: Where's the bowl gone?
B: Look for it yourself, please! Kinda busy here, Daniel!
A: Dad?
B: Check the drawer.
A: OK, got it, but its shape is so strange. I don't like it.
response: B: Can it cook soup?

dialogue: A: When can we expect you for dinner? Can you come tonight?
B: Not tonight. I promised to go to a concert with my sister.
A: Well... How about Friday then?
B: That sounds fine.
A: Good. Shall we say seven o'clock?
B: I'll be there. You're still a fabulous cook, aren't you?
A: That'll be for you to decide. I've got a new dish that I want to try out on you.
response: B: I'm ready. I'll look forward to it all Thursday!

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I see your boarding pass, please?
B: Here you are.
A: Excuse me, sir. This is your passport.
B: Really? Ugh... Is there any difference?
A: Yes. As a matter of fact, you can't board the plane without boarding pass.
B: Gee. I must have left it in my hotel room.
response: A: I'm sorry sir . I can't let you pass .

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
response: A: You can ask someone that could switch classes with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.

dialogue: A: Hello. This is Amy.
B: Hello, Amy. This is Tom.
A: Yes. What can I do for you?
B: I want to go to New York by train today. Would you please look up a train time for me?
response: A: Certainly, Hold on, please. Um... there's one at eleven p. m. It's a little late. Why don't you go there by car?

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
B: Well, there's a coffee shop on the next corner. It serves good food.
A: OK. I'll try it. Can I get you something?
response: B: No, I think I'll come with you. I'm longing for a nice salad.

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
B: But you should pay special attention to your words and attitudes.
A: In the beginning of the interview, greet the interviewer with a kind smile.
B: In the interview, use polite words, such as ' Thank you ', or ' Please '.
A: That's right. Details can mean succeed or fail.
B: When talking you should focus your eyes on the interviewer in order to closely watch his or her expressions.
A: At the end of the interview, you should make your acknowledgements and say Goode.
B: Whatever the result is, you should keep your good demeanor.
A: Only in this way can you leave a good impression on the interviewer.
response: B: In short , you should present the best of yourself throughout the interview .

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
response: A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.

dialogue: A: Did you check the internet for next week's weather forecast?
B: I sure did. You're in luck! It's supposed to snow all week in the mountains!
A: Yes! Somebody up there loves me! I knew it wasn't too late for snow.
B: It is kind of strange though, to have snow in April, and so much of it.
A: There have been so many dry winters lately that it's about time, don't you think?
response: B: When you put it that way I guess the thunderstorms can't hold out on us forever

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
response: A: There is nothing on that I want to see.

dialogue: A: Are you planning on voting?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, but this will be my first time voting.
B: Really?
A: Yes, and I have no idea how to do it.
B: Voting is simple.
A: I don ’ t know any of the laws they ’ re trying to pass.
response: B: That ’ s okay. They describe everything on the ballot.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
B: No, but you can see that the point is bent a little bit.
A: Yes, it is, isn't it? We'd be happy to exchange it for you. But I'm afraid we don't have another purple one. We only have this pen in black and yellow now.
B: My wife doesn't care for either of those colors.
A: We have one with a red leather cover. That's three dollars more.
response: B: The children worked hard to lose the eleven dollars for this one. They would probably be upset if I paid for part of their present.

dialogue: A: Did you ever get a parking ticket?
B: No, have you?
A: Yeah, I just got one the other day.
B: How'd you get a ticket?
response: A: The ticket was for parking in the red zone.

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
response: B: You can get tea and beer in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.

dialogue: A: Dr. Steven, I am thinking about changing my major before the end of the freshman year.
B: What are you studying now?
A: I am taking three genera] requirements and American history and American literature this. semester. Last semester I took four requirements and freshman French.

B: I believe it's not too late to change your major because you've mainly taken general requirements which all freshmen have to take. Also we have twelve electives so the mo lit courses will be included in them, so you can change your major without losing any credit hours.
response: A: I am very happy to know I am still able to change my major. I am interested in selling newspaper articles, and after finishing my degree I would like to work for some newspaper firm.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jane, I wonder if you're free tomorrow night.
B: Well, George, I guess I am. Why do you ask?
A: I have just got a pair of pre-sale Star Wars movie tickets from a friend and was thinking of inviting you along for the opening show. Are you interested?
B: Of course, I am! Thanks for inviting me!
A: No problem.
B: So, what time are we going?
response: A: Well, let's see. The movie starts at 10 p.m. We should get there at least half an hour earlier because there'll be a quick moving line. I think I could pick you up at your house at 9, if that's OK with you.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
A: Let me ask the old woman in that reception office.
B: She can't answer you.
A: She must be deaf.
response: B: It must be a haunted house . Are you frightened ?

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to make an appointment to look at houses.
B: Sure, would you prefer looking in the morning or afternoon?
A: I would prefer mornings.
B: Can you go during the week, or can you only go during the weekend?
A: Going to look at houses during the week is best for me.
B: Where would you like me to pick you up?
response: A: I will meet you at the bowling alley.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
B: We can go next week instead.
response: A: No, I don't want to ruin your weekend. You go ahead and please take the book I bought to my friend Sally. Tell her I have to bum around all weekend, because I can't afford to fail the test.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
response: B: Do you take illegal drugs?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
response: A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few days after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
B: What for? For the party, of course.
A: Party? What party?
response: B: We ’ re having a food-free Valentine ’ s Day Party .

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.
A: That's exactly why I want to borrow your notes. My notes aren't very good.
B: So what do you usually do in class?
response: A: I'm always awake at the beginning, but thirty minutes after class begins I feel wired and have no trouble keeping my eyes open.

dialogue: A: Are you free this afternoon?
B: I'm afraid I'm going to the gym for a workout.
A: How long have you been there?
response: B: I just want to start going there.

dialogue: A: Have you taken the written test yet?
B: No, I haven't.
A: You should study before you take it.
B: I have been studying.
A: Why don't you take the test?
B: Do you know if it costs any money to take it?
A: Since you already paid for your permit, you don't have to pay again.
B: All right. Do you know if the test covers the whole book?
A: No, the test skips a lot of things in the book.
B: Did you pass it the first time that you took it?
A: No, I didn't, because it was pretty hard.
response: B: Well , I hope that I fail

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
A: It's wonderful. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.
B: What about the swimming pool?
A: It's very good. Would you like to go there with me next week?
B: Good idea. Every day is OK except Monday.
response: A: Well. Why not go there on Saturday? Then we can stay for a short time.

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
response: B: You did? But I tried to forget about you at least 20 times and failed.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ms Thomas. What can I do for you?
B: Well, I've been having bad stomach pains lately, doctor.
A: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. How long have you been having them?
response: B: Just in the last few weeks. I get a very sharp mind about an hour after having meals.

dialogue: A: Well, this must be the National Library.
B: I guess so. Oh, no! I don't think it's open today. Look, it says "Closed Tuesdays".
A: Well, we'll just have to come back tomorrow.
response: B: But we're supposed to ditch that tour tomorrow.

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
response: A: Well, at least we don't need to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
B: Yes, I do. It made me laugh a lot.
A: But I'd rather see something not only interesting but also instructive.
B: Oh, Jane, don't be so serious. People sometimes need relaxation.
response: A: That's true. But I just think that watching TV is  just for entertainment.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. Is it true you're moving to London?
B: Yes, it is.
A: What made you decide to do that?
B: Work, mainly. I'm sure I'll be able to find a job there.
A: You're probably right. But where are you going to live?
B: I hope I'll find a flat to share with somebody. That way it will be cheaper.
A: Yes, that's a good idea. Are you taking your dog with you?
B: No, I don't think so. My parents have offered to take care of him, and I don't think he'd be happy in the city.
A: You're probably right. But aren't you afraid of moving to such a big place, especially after living in a small village?
B: Not really. I think I'll enjoy myself. There's so much to do there; I expect I won't miss the countryside much and I can always come back and visit.
response: A: Well, I just hope you'll get settled when you invite me to stay.

dialogue: A: I'm losing my sleep. I feel tired and sleepy all the time. I've got to do something about it.
B: I'm so sorry for you. But what are you going to do?
A: I want to move out of the dorm and rent a small flat.
response: B: That's a good idea. It will be much more loud and rowdy for you.

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: I'm in a hurry. How long will it take?
B: About half an hour, if there's no traffic jam.
A: Do you think the traffic will be heavy?
response: B: I doubt it. It's rush hour.

dialogue: A: Ahh... What a fine day! I do feel like an outdoor exercise.
B: How about taking a walk in the park?
A: OK. It's delightful to have a walk in the park with the air so fresh.
B: Oh, it's so quiet here. We have the park to ourselves, only you and me!
A: Don't you see many people over there? Just on your left.
response: B: Oh, I see them. Some are doing Taijiquan, some are performing swordplay, some are practising the Chinese Wushu.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. I'd like to apply for a library card. Can you help me?
B: Yes. Please give me your ID card, a photo.
A: OK. Here you are.
B: Then you have to give me 15 dollars for the deposit. The library card is free.
A: OK. Here is the money. And If I return the card, can I get the refund?
response: B: Of course , as long as the card is completely lost.

dialogue: A: A table for two, please.
B: All right. How about this one by the window?
A: Thank you. It's fine.
B: May I take your order now, sir?
A: What do you recommend? We'd like some of your local specialities.
B: Our restaurant is famous for its seafood.
A: One cream of fish soup and two portions of prawns.
B: Shrimp salad is our speciality, took
A: No, I think it's enough.
B: What would you like to drink?
response: A: A juice and a coke.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
response: A: Are you renting it alone or with company ?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
A: Do they look like roses?
B: No, they look like little bells.
A: Oh, lilies of the valley. No, I am sorry. We are all out of them right now.
B: Oh, that's too bad.
A: What about roses?
B: Ok. How many do you suggest?
response: A: As many as you like , sir . They are really ugly , aren't they ?

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
response: A: So it doesn't really seem boring?

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition improved when he enjoyed himself and watched funny movies.
A: You said Norman learned this? Do we have to learn to laugh?

B: Not necessarily. Since laughing is something people can do sitting down, costs no money, and requires no special exercise equipment or skill, it's the perfect workout for anyone who doesn't have the time or desire to participate in a regular fitness program.
A: Oh. Do you have such a program to offer to the general public?

B: Yes, we do. It's called the Smile Time-Out. You take a deep breath, smile, exhale, and say "Aaah" while visualizing all your muscles and cells smiling. Then add to that a memory of a time you felt really good and laughed and laughed.
A: What about the situation in which you aren't in a mood to laugh?
response: B: Even when you fake a smile or laugh, you get the same physiological benefits as when it's the real thing, because your mind is smart, but your body is stupid and can't tell the difference!

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
B: What for? For the party, of course.
A: Party? What party?
B: We ’ re having a Valentine ’ s Day Party.
A: Oh, I forget. Who ’ s invited?
B: We ’ Ve invited all our sophomore friends from school.
A: Can I help you get ready?
response: B: That'll be a big help. Well, here's a list of some of the food you could buy for dinner tonight.

dialogue: A: Are you there, Mary?
B: I'm back. My bid on the Buddha is still the highest!
A: How much is my stamp?
response: B: Don't you want to hear more about my statue?

dialogue: A: Hello, Amy. Are you coming to my birthday party?
B: Yes, I am. How do I get to your house from the station?
A: Well, call me when you get to the station and I'll come and pick you up in my car.
response: B: Are you sure it won't be too much trouble?

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
response: B: I love green apple lollipops .

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
B: But I don't have a car and I can't drive. Is there any other way to travel?
A: You can travel by bus. It's very cheap.
B: Can't I travel by train?
response: A: Yes, you can. The train is cheap in the States, but it's cheaper than the bus.

dialogue: A: Can I order take-out here?
B: Yes, sir. What would you like?
A: I want a hamburger, a medium French fries, a Big Mac meal, and a double cheeseburger, please.
B: Anything else?
A: And a 6-piece chicken nuggets.
B: What kind of drink would you like?
A: A large Coke with extra ice and a milkshake. And please give me several more straws. How much do I owe you?
B: Let me calculate it, er... that comes to $ 14.30.
response: A: Here's $15. Keep the change.

dialogue: A: Bob, do you know who I saw the other day? Old Jake, looking terribly depressed. Did he get pensioned off at last?
B: Yes. They made him retire after 50 years at sea. He is pretty upset about it, but what can you do? He really is pasted.
A: He is all alone, isn't he?

B: Yes, his wife has been dead for years. They had one daughter, Dories. But she went off to town as soon as she left school. And he hasn't heard from her since. I hear she is making good money as a model.
A: Maybe someone could get in touch with her. Get her to come back for a while to help?

B: I don't suppose she come. She never got on with her father. He is bit of a tough character and she is rather selfish. Oh, I expect old Jake will get by. He is healthy at least, comes into a clinic for a check regularly.
response: A: Are you his driver?

dialogue: A: Why are you interested in our company?
B: Your company is world-famous. So, I think there will be better chances for persona development.
A: You're right. Do you think you have the qualifications for this job?
B: Sure. My qualifications meet your job description.
A: But you have no experience for this job.
B: That's true. But I am eager to learn, and also quick at learning.
A: Since you need further training, are you familiar with training salary?
B: No. What is the monthly salary?
A: 800 yuan per month.
response: B: Do you mind if I give an answer immediately?

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.
A: Well, that's a good idea and you come to the right place. Do you know what you like?
B: Well, I don't want a racer or a touring bike or anything like that. Mostly I'll just be using it to get me back and forth from work.
A: How far is that?
B: About four miles.
A: Are there a lot of hills on the way?
B: Some, I guess. But maybe I should tell you at first that I only got 150 dollars. Can I get anything decent for that?
A: Well, you are not going to get anything on the top of the line. But we do have a few trade-ins in the back that are in good condition.
B: That sounds good.
response: A: And you are right. For the kind of ride you are going to be doing, the most important thing is comfort. You want to make sure it's the right height for you? Follow me and I'll show you what we've got.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
A: This class is really just a review for me. I've been learning it for two years.
B: That's lucky for you.
A: Jeanie, can you guess what the test will be like? Will it be difficult?
response: B: I hope not. But I'm still happy about it.

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
response: B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent half an hour on it.

dialogue: A: Do you know Tom?
B: Tom what?
A: Tom Smith.
B: No. But I know a Tim Smith.
A: Oh, yes, you are right. It was Tim Smith I meant. You know what happened to him the other day?
B: No, what happened then?
A: Well, he told me he saw his dead grandfather in London.
response: B: Oh, come on. You are not watching a documentary, are you?

dialogue: A: Hey Jane, where are you going this weekend?
B: Hi, Bob. I'm going to the beach. 13o you want to come too?
A: Yes, that sounds like fun. Which beach are you going to?
response: B: I was thinking of going to Huangdao's Beach. I like to watch the sea birds and wildlife there.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just graduated from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.
B: Could you tell me what you can do?
response: A: I can do whatever a secretary is expected to do, such as typing, ignoring phone calls, sending faxes, and writing reports.

dialogue: A: Are you interested in music?
B: Yes. I like classical music. Beethoven is my favourite composer. How about you?
A: I like all kinds of music, but jazz is my favourite and my wife is fond of rock music.
response: B: You play the nintendo, don't you?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
response: A: Have you thought about eating campfire s'more ice cream?

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
response: B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very mediocre employee. All your assignments are barely finished in a timely manner, and you're hardly a team player.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
B: We can go next week instead.
response: A: No, I don't want to ruin your weekend. You go ahead and please take the book I bought to my friend Sally. Tell her I have to study all weekend, because I am not worried about failing the test.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
A: And you have a stomachache now?
B: Yes, I think so.
A: Can you walk to the school clinic? Or shall I send for the doctor?
response: B: No, thanks. It doesn't matter too much. I will go to the restaurant after class.

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
B: But you should pay special attention to your words and attitudes.
A: In the beginning of the interview, greet the interviewer with a kind smile.
B: In the interview, use polite words, such as ' Thank you ', or ' Please '.
A: That's right. Details can mean succeed or fail.
B: When talking you should focus your eyes on the interviewer in order to closely watch his or her expressions.
A: At the end of the interview, you should make your acknowledgements and say Goode.
B: Whatever the result is, you should keep your good demeanor.
response: A: If you do that you won't leave a good impression on the interviewer .

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
response: A: You mean you lied about knowing how to farm?

dialogue: A: What a great day! Hey, Tom, do you want to go to the beach this weekend?
B: Yeah, that is a great idea. Maybe Sara would like to come along with us.
A: I doubt it.
B: Why? You are kidding! You know, she loves watching the sea.
A: But yesterday afternoon she told me that she would go home this Saturday.
B: What happened?
A: She said that her mother was ill and stayed in the hospital, and therefore she wanted to go home to see her.
B: I am sorry to hear that. Well, What do you think? Should we take some food?
response: A: That sounds great. Maybe we could have a concert on the beach. Then let's take some sandwiches, chips, and uh...some salad as well.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve in the library for anthropology 311.
A: Professor Gilers's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matter which one of them you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're kidding all of them?

A: I've asked professor Gilers twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for these same articles to be returned.
B: And here I went out of my way to free the whole afternoon to read.
response: A: I'm sorry, but there is not a whole lot I can do about it. All I can suggest is that you come in first thing tomorrow morning and try again; we open at eight.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
response: B: Ah, that's a bit cheap. Do you have a three-day service?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, Is there an airline flying to New York this afternoon?
B: Sorry, sir. I can't sell you a ticket. Our computer is down.
A: If your computer is down, just write me a ticket.
response: B: Sorry, I can't. I am the only one allowed doing so.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
response: A: Thank goodness. They were probably here for days.

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's a graduate course and I'm only a junior, but...
A: Aren't you a bit young? I've allowed qualified seniors to take the course and they usually have a hard time to keep up.
response: B: I know, but the geology of the American West isn't my favorite interest and I haven't read a lot in the field. Last semester I took Professor Burman's course and I didn't find it challenging enough.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.

B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?
