response: A: Well, no. I don't think I would. I bet it costs nothing. Does it say how much it costs?

dialogue: A: Well, you know I had a good time tonight.
B: I'm pleased to hear that.
A: But I have to say goodbye right now.
B: Why? It's not late. Can't you stay a little longer?
A: No, I'm sorry, but I really must go. I don't know whether I can catch the last bus if I don't hurry now.
B: When does the bus go?
A: At ten o'clock. Oh dear! It's already a quarter past ten.
B: Don't worry, Kate. Since you have missed the bus, it is unnecessary for you to hurry. I can drive you home.
response: A: Thank you. You are so kind. But my mother will worry about me if I'm too late getting home. I must get home before next week.

dialogue: A: Is this blue too bright for me?
B: Mmm-hmm. It is a very bright blue. Try this. It's size ten.
A: But 1 wear size eleven.
B: How about black? It's size eleven.
A: Let me try it on. I'm taking too much of your time.
B: It's seven o'clock. Where's my friend Jack? I was expecting him here at six forty-five.
response: A: Don't worry. The traffic is very light at this hour.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
response: B: Well, how about buying the cinema, then?

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
A: You mean you know how to farm?
B: Yes. I did that every summer during holidays.
response: A: I didn't know that a city boy can do farm work. Can I go there with you? I'd like to learn to do some farming.

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
A: No, what you need is balance.
B: Could you teach me how to do it?
A: Sure, anytime when you are free.
B: Do I have to buy a pair of skates?
response: A: I don't think it's necessary. Why not wish for them?

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
B: I'm going to attend a conference on air pollution.
A: When and where is this conference being held?
B: It's being held in the first two weeks of February at the University of Stanford in California.
A: Who will pay your expenses?
B: The University of Stanford. Here is the official letter of invitation.
A: I see. Fine. When do you want to go?
B: I'd like to leave in mid-January if my passport is ready by then.
response: A: That shouldn't be difficult. Why don't you phone me about January 10th? I should be able to give you an answer then.

dialogue: A: Is this blue too bright for me?
B: Mmm-hmm. It is a very bright blue. Try this. It's size ten.
A: But 1 wear size eleven.
B: How about black? It's size eleven.
A: Let me try it on. I'm taking too much of your time.
B: It's seven o'clock. Where's my friend Jack? I was expecting him here at six forty-five.
A: Don't worry. The traffic is very heavy at this hour.
B: I know. But we're going to be late for tonight's party.
A: I'll take this black sweater. I like the color on me. How do you think?
response: B: I think it looks terrific on you.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Anything wrong?
B: I've been suffering from a fever since yesterday.
A: Do you have any other problems? Like a headache or cough?
B: No, I don't. I think it's only a fever.
A: Let me check... It's 39 degrees. I'll give you some medicine.
B: Thank you, doctor.
response: A: You'd better take two or three days' rest.

dialogue: A: It's lucky that we rode our bike here instead of driving.
B: It's a good job that we got here early. Look at all those cars there. They'll never get in.
A: You'd better follow me closely. I don't want to lose you.
B: Don't worry. I'll keep up.
A: We go in over there. Gate B. Peter said they're pretty good tickets.
B: Where are they?
A: They're right behind the goal.
B: Oh,do we have to stand up all the time?
A: That's right.
B: I hope we can see the match clearly.
response: A: That's why we've showed up late.  The later, the better.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the job in the newspaper?
B: Do you mean the one in Manchester?
A: Yes.
B: I saw it just now.
A: What do you think of it?
B: I think I'm not the type of man to do it.
A: Why do you think so?
B: They need an engineer to take care of the machine and I don't even know anything about that kind of machine.
A: I know you are always quick to learn. I believe when you use it you will get to know it well.
B: Are you serious about that?
response: A: No. I'm not.  You should have a try

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you show me some nail-polish?
B: Yes. We have all kinds of colors for it.
A: That's good.
B: What's your favorite color?
response: A: In my opinion, orange isn't very nice.

dialogue: A: Are you busy with your work?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, I'm very busy, too. Sometimes I work overtime.
B: Then your salary must be high.
response: A: Just so so. But we can travel zero times every year.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
response: A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I can't decide between those I find everywhere.

dialogue: A: Have you been to exhibitions in your spare time?
B: Yes, a lot of times. I like exhibitions-exhibitions about famous people: dancers, actors, you know?
A: Mm, and what about a folk concert? Have you ever been to one of them?
B: No. I don't like folk music very much.
A: What about the opera?
response: B: No, never. I don't really like the opera. It is a bit too heavy for me.

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
response: B: On the second line, you write the address you are receiving it from. Good, like that.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
A: No, but we can get your package to France in one week for 40 dollars.
B: Well, that sounds good. I'll take that. Is the service guaranteed?
A: Yes. We also offer a service where we can track your package. But that will cost 10 dollars extra.
response: B: Oh, I won't need the three-day service...

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
B: I get a lump in my throat whenever I see a tragic movie.
A: Tragic movie? I think it's a love story.
response: B: But their love is touching!

dialogue: A: Hello, Lucy. When are you going off to Beijing?
B: This evening.
A: How are you getting there, by air or by train?
B: By train. It leaves at 5:00 and arrives in Beijing at 7:10 tomorrow morning.
response: A: Oh, only 14 hours. Is anybody seeing you arrive this evening?

dialogue: A: Hello, Jim. Where are you going?
B: To the cinema. What about coming with me?
A: No, thanks. I'm going home. My friend's expecting me.
B: What a pity! I believe it's a very good film.
A: Do you go to the cinema a lot?
B: Once a week. Most nights I sit at home and watch TV.
A: Oh, I see. By the way, where are you going for your holidays this year?
B: I don't know yet. My wife's going to her mother's for a couple of weeks. She lives by the sea, you know.
A: Oh, does she? That's convenient.
response: B: Yes, but I want to go to the country store.

dialogue: A: Hello, Robert speaking.
B: Hi, it's Emma. I'm glad you're there. It's about our appointment on Wednesday morning. I'm afraid I can't make it now.
A: Oh, that's a shame.
response: B: I'm sorry. There was no change in my business partner's plan on Friday. And Friday is the only day she is able to see me.

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely heavy.
A: Just the things we need for the picnic tomorrow.
response: B: Well, hurry up and block the door. I told you these things were very heavy.

dialogue: A: Hello, this is Jonason speaking.
B: Hello, Jonason, I am Kasy. I am sorry to tell you that I may not attend your birthday party this weekend.
A: Oh, what's up?
B: Nothing much.., but...
A: What's happened then?
B: I have an important exam at that time.
response: A: If so, I think we can party harder . What do you think about it?

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
response: B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living with me most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
B: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
A: No, please, Mom! Don't make me gargle with saltwater!
response: B: It works better than any medicine , Lily . I'll make you a glass of buttered rum right now , and you'll finish it !

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.
B: Then your two boys don't need to share a room. They are happy with it?
response: A: Yeah, they can share the third bedrroom. What interests me most is the small garden before the house. You know I love gardening so much.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
response: B: I caught hold of his knife, and he left.

dialogue: A: Waitress! I think there's something wrong with our bill.
B: No, I don't think so...$10 for the drinks, 15 for the small plate, and 20 for the main dish.
A: What? I knew the cheese sticks were 15. I always order cheese sticks, but I thought the main dish was $10.
B: Oh, that explains it. You think the bill should be $35.
A: Yes, exactly. I was wondering what happened to the rest of my change. I should have gotten back 15, not 5!
B: I understand. Sometimes people aren't honest, but I think this was an honest mistake. Didn't you order the sea cucumbers for dinner?
A: Yes, and they were delicious. Best cucumbers ever! I'm so glad I'm a vegetarian.
response: B: Sir, I am so sorry. Have you ordered sea cucumbers before? They aren't vegetables, you know.

dialogue: A: Are you interested in music?
B: Yes. I like classical music. Beethoven is my favourite composer. How about you?
A: I like all kinds of music, but jazz is my favourite and my wife is fond of rock music.
B: You play the piano, don't you?
response: A: A little bit, but my wife is much better than me. She can also play the violin.

dialogue: A: Anna, that outfit looks wonderful on you! The color goes with your trousers perfectly.
B: Thanks, Carla. That's quite a compliment coming from you. You always dress so tastefully.
A: Well, that dress certainly shows your good taste. It must have cost a lot.
B: No, not much. I got it on sale at the mall - 60 % off.
response: A: Really? You're an amazing bargain hunter! Next time there's a sale, promise you'll go without me.

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
response: B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.

dialogue: A: Waiter, can we have the bill please?
B: Yes, madam. How will you pay for it, with cash or credit card,please?
A: With my Visa Card.
response: B: I'm awfully sorry, madam. But we only accept playing cards.

dialogue: A: Hello, Tom. I haven't seen you for some time. How are you doing?
B: Oh! Not too bad. I have been busy writing an article.
A: Really? Have you finished it?
B: Yes. I finished it yesterday.
A: Congratulations! Are you doing something this evening?
B: No, nothing important. Why?
A: Well, do you feel like going to a concert? I have two tickets.
response: B: Oh. Good idea. I want to do something boring, and I like music very much.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is not in at the moment.
B: When will he come in, do you know?
A: I suppose he won't be in until 12: 00.
B: May I leave a message?
A: Certainly.
response: B: Please ask him to write me a letter as soon as he returns. He has my address.

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
response: B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living with my siblings most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
response: B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
B: Thanks, they are rather attractive. But I think there is nothing better than seeing things In actual operation.
A: Yes, of course. Would you like to make an inspection tour of some factories?
B: Yes, very much, if it wouldn't add inconvenience to you. First hand information is always more valuable than reading pamphlets.
response: A: I'll make the floral arrangement and let you know the wedding time tomorrow .

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have been hurt or even killed?
A: You are right! All the injured people were taken to the hospital immediately.
response: B: I hope so. Drivers must not be careful, especially during rush hour.

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.
A: Well whatever, can we repeat our offer to run the campaign for 4 extra weeks?

B: That's not really the point. The campaign missed two key trade affairs. Because of this, we are asking you either to repeat the campaign next year for free, or we only pay 50% of the fee for this year.
A: Could we suggest a 20% reduction to the fee together with the four week sustention to the campaign.
response: B: We are not happy. We gained business.

dialogue: A: Hi, Robert, what happened to your face? It looks swollen.
B: I have to go and get my teeth filled.
A: Did it hurt?
B: I don't even want to talk about it. It killed me!
A: Well, I guess you've learned a good lesson, huh! You have to take good care of your teeth.
B: No kidding. I can't stand the pain, but the bill is too large!
A: Don't you have a dental insurance?
response: B: I don't. but it doesn't cover everything.

dialogue: A: What are you doing tonight?
B: I have to run to the grocery store.
A: Don't you hate fighting the crowds on the weekends?
B: Yes, but I am out of food and milk.
A: What store do you shop at?
B: The small one, just down the street. I like their generic brand.
A: I have been using the store across town for years.
B: I hear they have very nice stuff.
response: A: They do , but they're a little expensive on certain items .

dialogue: A: Hi, Nicole. Did you have a good weekend?
B: Yes, I did. But I feel tired today.
A: Really? Why?
B: Well, on Saturday I cleaned the house and played tennis. Then on Sunday I hiked in the country.
A: And I bet you studied, too.
response: B: Nah . I slept through Sunday evening . What about you ?

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve about British culture.
A: Professor Grand's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person coming in asking for those articles.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matterwhich one you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're joking, all of them?

A: Every month. I've asked professor Grand twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for those same articles to be returned.
B: And here's me. I went out of my way to free out the whole afternoon to read.
response: A: I'm sorry, but there is not a whole lot I can do about it. All I can suggest is that you come in first thing tomorrow morning and try again. We open at eight.

dialogue: A: Are you cold?
B: Yes, a little.
A: I wonder if we can change the temperature.
B: I tried before. There are no buttons on the air conditioning.
A: There must be buttons. How do they turn it on and off?
B: I think it is centrally controlled. They control it at the main desk.
A: Well, they have it too cold in here. I want to be warmer. I won't be able to sleep.
B: I'm going downstairs for more drinking water. I will ask them.
A: What did they say about the air conditioning?
response: B: They said it is centrally controlled. Only some of the rooms are the same. They can't change it.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
response: B: Oh, No. I have a car.

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Where were you at lunchtime? I was looking for you in the dining hall.
B: Oh, sorry, I missed you. My English class ran late again.
A: That's been happening quite often recently. Maybe it's because the final exams are coming up.
response: B: No. After class, there is never a group of students hanging around the professor asking questions. How about you? Are you ready for the exams?

dialogue: A: Hello, I need to come in and see the doctor.
B: Are you scheduling a check-up, or are you ill?
A: I have really itchy skin and think I may have to have it looked at.
B: Have you been feeling any joint aches with that rash?
A: No, but I have a low fever.
B: I have times available for Tuesday or Wednesday. Which one would work best for you?
A: I want to come in on Wednesday.
B: I can fit you in on that day at 10
A: I would prefer Dr. Smith.
response: B: You can see the doctor of your choice then, and we will see you at whatever time.

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite smart, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?
response: B: Yeah. Let's see if there's a smaller size. Well, they don't seem to have anything smaller.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wanting to stay somewhere for a few days.

A: Well, there are some good hotels. Carlton House is near the main square in the city center, but you might also be interested in the Royal Hotel-that's out in the countryside, about ten kilometers away, very peaceful. Then there's the Rainbow Hotel-it is not in the center, but it's out on the airport road.
response: B: Mmm, that might be a bit far out actually. Now the one you mentioned, in the city center. Can you tell me a bit about it?

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam.
B: Good morning. I wonder if you can help. I've lost my coat.
A: Where did you lose it, madam?
response: B: Er... I left my book on a train yesterday morning.

dialogue: A: Hey, Charlie. How was your football game the other day?
B: Great! Our team played hard and out Huasheng Team.
A: Congratulations! But hold on, there. Taishan Team, you know, is difficult to play.
response: B: You're right. It will be a close game. But I've got a good feeling about this game. Our team is sure to win!

dialogue: A: Hello! How do I get online with my laptop?
B: Just plug the Ethernet cable into your computer, and you'll be online in a heartbeat.
A: Well, I see the cable. But my computer runs on wireless only.
B: No problem. I'll tell you about our alternatives.
A: Yes, I'd love to hear what the alternatives are.
B: Our state-of-the-art computer lab is on the first floor.
A: Great! But is it free?
B: Sir, the computers are free to guests, but you do have to pay a nominal printing fee.
A: You said there were other alternatives?
B: Just use your computer here in the lobby. It's set up for wireless.
A: Okay. That sounds like a winner. Now if I need to print something in the lobby?
response: B: We might have a printer here now.  . But for now , you'll have to go to the lab

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
response: A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to keep it that way.

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.
A: Well whatever, can we repeat our offer to run the campaign for 4 extra weeks?

B: That's not really the point. The campaign missed two key trade affairs. Because of this, we are asking you either to repeat the campaign next year for free, or we only pay 50% of the fee for this year.
A: Could we suggest a 20% reduction to the fee together with the four week sustention to the campaign.
response: B: We are not happy. We lost business despite appearing in key magazines.

dialogue: A: Could I have a word with you, Madam?
B: Is that you, Janice? Just speaking.
A: I have to tell you that I can't be in today and tomorrow.
response: B: So sorry to hear that. I'm sure you'll have a blast!

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
response: B: No, but you can see that the point is perfectly pointed.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
response: B: Sorry , I've got a meeting in half an hour .

dialogue: A: Drive slowly, David. You could have an accident.
B: You can count on me. I have been driving for years.
A: Look out! Red light!
B: It doesn't matter. It is late. There is no one around.
response: A: Don't let the dog catch you. Oh, David, that's a policeman. He is waving over us

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. Er, I'm phoning about the job that was in the paper last night.
A: Oh, yes. Could you tell me your name?
B: Oh, Jerry Lynn.
A: Well, what exactly is it that interests you about the job?
response: B: I just thought that it was right up my street, you know.

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
A: I sprained my wrist, but the doctor says it will be fine.
B: How many days will you be out of school?
response: A: The doctor said I should be good enough to return next week .

dialogue: A: Hello, Pam.
B: I'm glad that you can make it.
A: It looks like there are a lot of people inside.
response: B: Yeah . I invited one other person.

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
response: A: I have to write you a ticket.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.
A: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of strong and comfortable shoes.
B: What's your suggestion?
response: A: Maybe you should buy him a pair of high heel shoes.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote?
B: I am so excited to be voting.
A: Do you know who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I am so impressed with the candidate I ’ m going to vote for.
A: What ’ s so great about him?
B: I feel that he is very intelligent.
A: Oh, really?
B: Yes, and I agree with all his policies.
A: That ’ s good to hear.
B: I think this man is going to be the next President.
A: I hope so.
response: B: I ’ m going to make sure and get my vote in.

dialogue: A: Am I late?
B: No, you've got an hour and a quarter. Your flight leaves at 9:30.
A: I'm so excited.
B: Have you got everything?
A: Yes, my tickets and my traveler's checks.
response: B: And your passport?

dialogue: A: Do you know much about computers?
B: Not a great deal. Why?
A: I've been reading an article about computers. They are strange and are being used for almost everything.
B: Yes. But have you learned how to use one?
response: A: No. But I'm about to take a course on computers next term.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
response: B: I will charge you double for the soup today.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
response: B: Sorry , I've got a meeting in five hours .

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.
B: I wish I could. My boss just did me a favor by putting me on evenings. And he'll hit the ceiling if I ask to change again.
A: Wait a minute. I have an idea. Have you checked the course over at the community college? They might offer an introductory course during the day.
B: That's a great idea. I'm free this afternoon. I'll go over and check it out.
response: A: Their courses are actually expensive.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
response: B: They really started looting ?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
response: B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three hundred blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.

dialogue: A: Mary, tomorrow is your mom's fiftieth birthday. Do you know?
B: Of course I do. How shall we celebrate it?
A: First of all a birthday present. What about buying her a beautiful skirt?
response: B: That's a good idea. It would make her look younger. And a big birthday cake too, with twelve candles.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
response: A: Yes. They are the private rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
A: Oh? Who's she calling?
B: She's calling her boyfriend.
A: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
B: He hasn't been home yet...Why? You're asking a lot of questions tonight, Paul.
response: A: Am I?...Well, I'm practicing my German.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Have you forgotten our drinks?
B: Sorry, I'll bring them to you right away.
A: Why is it taking so long?
B: We are short of staff today.
A: There is something wrong with this dish.
B: What's wrong?
A: I don't think this is fresh.
response: B: They were cooked an hour ago.

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
B: No, never. I don't want to mark my desk.
A: Well, would you please keep my desk clean?
B: Aren't you going to sell it?
response: A: Yes, but who wants a badly marked one?

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
B: Not really. But when I was home, I had to start typing a literature paper that was due first thing in the morning.
A: Couldn't you do it today?
response: B: Yes, our professor said she wouldn't accept any late papers.

dialogue: A: Where did you put my new red tie?
B: It's right there in the cupboard with your other ties.
A: There's a green one and a couple of brown ones, but no red one.
response: B: Here it is in your fridge. You must have put it there when you brought it home.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
response: A: Why have you been teaching so hard?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, could you tell me where the post office is?
B: Post office? It's not far from here. Do you know Xinhua Road?
A: I'm from the United States and this is my first trip to your city. I know nothing about the city.
response: B: Oh, welcome back to our city for the third time, I'll show you the road. Please follow me.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
response: A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and incredibly over-detailed.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some gloves.
A: All our gloves are here. What do you think of this pair here? It's made of silk.
B: Hm, it looks nice, but I'd like to have something warm for the winter.
A: Maybe you would like heavy wool gloves. How about this pair?
B: I think that's what I want. How much is it?
A: It's... forty dollars.
response: B: It's a little expensive. Do you think it's possible to increase the price?

dialogue: A: Hello, I am calling about my cable service.
B: What's the problem?
A: For the past week my cable hasn't been working.
B: I apologize, but the cable has been down lately.
A: Do you know when it is going to start working again?
B: Give it a couple days, and it should be back on.
A: Will I still have to pay for the cable while it's not working?
response: B: Since it's not working , I'm going to give you a sandwich.

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
A: I have to write you a ticket.
B: Can't you give me a warning?
A: I'm not going to be able to do that.
response: B: How much will a bribe be?

dialogue: A: Are you free this evening, Li?
B: I ’ m afraid I ’ m busy tonight. I ’ m having dinner with friends.
A: What a pity. I wanted to go for a drink with you.
B: What about tomorrow? Are you doing anything tomorrow?
response: A: No, I haven ’ t got any free time.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
response: B: Well, I use it to send souvenir postcards a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself French program. And I shop offine pretty often.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
response: B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for autumn, but I'd like to have something warm for winter.

dialogue: A: Are you okay?
B: No.
A: What's wrong?
B: I got robbed!
A: By who?
response: B: Some guy on the street just kissed me.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.
A: I don't know how you keep on with it. It's too hard to become a doctor.
B: Well, you study a lot too. It doesn't seem any easier to become an engineer.
response: A: But at least it takes forever. I'll be out putting up the buildings while you're still a student here. By the way, can I help you with your study now?

dialogue: A: Hi, Robert, what happened to your face? It looks swollen.
B: I have to go and get my teeth filled.
A: Did it hurt?
B: I don't even want to talk about it. It killed me!
response: A: Well, I guess you've learned a bad lesson, huh! You have to take all your teeth out.

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.
B: Actually, I like it very much.
A: I'm glad you enjoy it. Let me serve you some more fish.
B: No, thank you. I've had enough fish, but I'd like some soup.
A: Here it is. Help yourself!
B: Thanks. I didn't know you were so good at cooking. If only my wife could learn to cook from you.
A: Why not bring your wife next time? I haven't seen her for quite a while.
response: B: OK, I will. She will be very glad to see you, too. Thank you for the disgusting meal.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Uncle Smith.
B: Good morning, Cathy.
A: I want to have a dinner party to celebrate my birthday. Would you come?
B: I'd love to, Cathy. What time?
A: Next weekend, on Saturday.
B: Saturday do you say?
A: If that's all right with you.
response: B: I'm happy I'm busy then. I've already had plans.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
A: Then the truck hit the taxi, did it?
response: B: Yes, with much noise. Then I called the police.

dialogue: A: Are you okay?
B: No.
A: What's wrong?
B: I got robbed!
A: By who?
response: B: Some guy on the street just hugged me.

dialogue: A: What time do you usually get up in the morning?
B: I sleep in every morning, sometimes until 11 or 12.
A: Are you serious? I get up at 5 every morning to go to the gym, and then I get to work around 7.
B: Well, I work from home, so I can set my own hours. I usually work until midnight or 1 in the morning, and then I like to sleep in.

A: I like to be in bed around 9 or 10 at night so I can get enough sleep. Our schedules are very different! You're lucky that you get to set your own schedule, but I could never sleep that late. I'm definitely a morning person.
B: And I'm definitely a night person. Waking up early is so terrible.
A: Maybe we should switch schedules for a week!
B: No way! I would never want your schedule.
A: Very funny... What are you doing today?
B: Well, it's Saturday, so I was thinking of taking a hike. Would you like to come?
A: Sure. Can we go to see a movie afterwards?
B: I don't really like movies, actually. Can we do something else?
response: A: Sure, but I don't have to work tomorrow, even though it's Sunday, so I do need to be home around 9.

dialogue: A: Are you through with your meal?
B: Yes, we are. Could we have the check, please?
A: Here is your check, 86 dollars in all. Can I take care of it here when you are ready?
B: Do you accept checks?
A: No, I'm sorry we don't. We accept credit cards and cash.
B: Well, I don't have any cash with me, so I ’ ll have to put it on credit.
A: I'll be right back.
B: Ok, please wait a minute. Can I have my food packaged?
response: A: I see. I'll bring some ceramic plates for you

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
B: I get a lump in my throat whenever I see a tragic movie.
A: Tragic movie? I think it's a love story.
response: B: But their love is so funny!

dialogue: A: Hello, Thomas Brothers.
B: Hello, this is Mike Landon here. Is Jack Cooper there by any chance?
A: I am afraid not, he is away for a day or two, back on, let's see, Monday morning.
B: Oh, well perhaps I can live a message for him.
A: Yes, of course, just a minute. Now, let's see, to Jack Cooper from Mike London.
B: No, Landon, L-a-n-d-o-n.
A: Sorry, yes, got that, and what's the message?
B: Well it's just this: could he come to a meeting on Monday afternoon at 5:00 pm?
A: That's this coming Monday, October 12th?
response: B: Right, it's to discuss what I had for breakfast.

dialogue: A: Great! I landed on Classic Movies.
B: I didn't know you liked old movies.
A: I love them, especially the all-time greats like Gone With the Wind.
B: You're so right! Today's movies are just too commercial!
response: A: Sometimes I think Oscars are only awarded to movies that don't bring in money .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jane, I wonder if you're free tomorrow night.
B: Well, George, I guess I am. Why do you ask?
A: I have just got a pair of pre-sale Star Wars movie tickets from a friend and was thinking of inviting you along for the opening show. Are you interested?
B: Of course, I am! Thanks for inviting me!
A: No problem.
B: So, what time are we going?
response: A: Well, let's see. The movie starts at 10 p.m. We should get there at least half an hour earlier because there'll be a long line. I think I could pick you up at your house at 9, if that's OK with you.

dialogue: A: Dr. Steven, I am thinking about changing my major before the end of the freshman year.
B: What are you studying now?
A: I am taking three genera] requirements and American history and American literature this. semester. Last semester I took four requirements and freshman French.

B: I believe it's not too late to change your major because you've mainly taken general requirements which all freshmen have to take. Also we have twelve electives so the mo lit courses will be included in them, so you can change your major without losing any credit hours.
response: A: I am very happy to know I am still able to change my major. I am interested in writing newspaper articles, and after finishing my degree I would like to work for some newspaper firm.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Do you have a reservation?
B: Yes. My name is Charles.
A: I see. We have a window table reserved for you.
B: It's very kind of you.
A: Would you like to order now or wait for a while?
response: B: Bring me the check , please .

dialogue: A: Can I help you, Sir?
B: Yes, I'd like to withdraw some money.
A: Fill in the slip, stating the exact amount you wish to withdraw, please.
B: OK. Here's my bank book, is that all right?
A: OK, do you want large notes or small ones?
B: In 50 Yuan or 100 Yuan would be fine.
response: A: Here's the cash for you.

dialogue: A: This business of having to be a role model, where you can never relax, hang loose, can you?

B: Well, I can't exactly go to hang with my friends at some of the places we used to go to, and just basically raise hell and have a whole bunch of fun. I can't do that any more because it's not good for the public to see that. It's not good for me.
A: Your father said you have the ability to be one of the biggest influences in history, not just golf, humanity. What do you think of that?
response: B: I think that is more important than just my golf. I think my golf is merely a vehicle to influence people

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
response: A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. What can I do for you?
A: I'd like a ticket to New York, please.
response: B: Round table?

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.
response: A: You could've left some change in a store.

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
A: Where are you living now?
response: B: Out in the suburbs. It's a long trip to work every day.

dialogue: A: When did you become interested in collecting stamps?
B: Oh, when I was about ten years old.
A: Ten years old? So you have loved it for 9 years.
response: B: Yeah, it's really an boring and sleepy hobby. You know, the first postage stamps were issued in Britain in 1840.

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
B: And the bike was run over by the car. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.
A: It was lucky that you didn't get hurt.
B: Yeah. But it's a pity I can't ride my bike this weekend.
A: Oh. Did you have a weekend plan?
response: B: Yeah. I planned to go sightseeing with friends by car.

dialogue: A: Are you ready for the big competition today, Todd? The winner gets two tickets to the Sydney Olympics!
B: Steve, I was born ready! I ’ m going to blow you guys off the treadmill today.
A: We ’ Ve still got a lot of time before we have to start running.
B: Let ’ s hit the whirlpool for a bit. It ’ ll help me loosen up.
response: A: You bet. I used to take a whirlpool almost every night back home, and it made me even more tense.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go swimming and cycling by myself.
A: Oh, I forgot about that. I go cycling sometimes too. And I often go swimming on vacation, but only recreational swimming.
B: Why don't you join me at the gym sometime?
response: A: Well, maybe someday, but I'm pretty lazy about things like that.

dialogue: A: Have you booked the airplane tickets to spain yet?
B: Well, I thought we should go traveling by ship for a change, so I booked two ship tickets instead.
A: You should have told me or discussed it with me.
B: I wanted to give you a surprise. Don't you like the idea?
A: I like it all right, but it takes much more time to travel by ship than by plane.
B: We have time, don't we? Every time we went on a trip, we were always tied down by schedules. This time will be different. We don't have to rush.
A: You're right. This is our first trip since you retired. We can travel as long as we like.
B: We'll have an easy trip and enjoy every minute.
response: A: Have you paid your outstanding cheques yet?

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
response: B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
response: B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of working there til I retire.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite reasonable.
response: B: It sounds terrible. Thank you very much for your help.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
response: B: It was the high quality I expect. It was the perfect length.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kathy, it's Jason.
B: Hi, Jason. I haven't heard from you in a while.
A: Well. I've been busy. I've started my own company.
B: Wow, what kind of business is it?
response: A: Just a small on-line store. I am hiring staff and I want you to come to work for me.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Will you please book tickets to Sanya for me?
A: Yes, sir. When will you intend to leave?
B: Next Wednesday.
A: That will be July 13. There are two flight available that day: one at 9:00 a.m., the other one at 3:30 p.m.
B: Fine. I'd like the 3:30 one.
A: 3:30 p.m. How many tickets do you need?
B: Two.
A: Wish you a wonderful trip to Sanya.
response: B: They say Sanya leads the world in beautiful scenery. To tell the truth, my wife has been dying to go there.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
response: B: If you got laid off or are working a lot fewer hours, you may qualify.

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
A: So you could have made it. But you were still late for class.
response: B: The thing is, when I got off, I found I had left my bag in his car. And it was too late to get it back when I realized that. I went straight to the nearest shop and gave him a call. I waited for five minutes before Mr. Green drove back.

dialogue: A: Did you check the internet for next week's weather forecast?
B: I sure did. You're in luck! It's supposed to snow all week in the mountains!
A: Yes! Somebody up there loves me! I knew it wasn't too late for snow.
B: It is kind of strange though, to have snow in April, and so much of it.
A: There have been so many dry winters lately that it's about time, don't you think?
B: When you put it that way, I guess the skies can't hold out on us forever.
response: A: This will be the best ski trip I've ever taken. I can't wait to use my new hoard.

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!
A: You're not supposed to just copy the book.
B: Oh! I think Mr. Harper won't know.
response: A: He will know! He asked us to write a list of all the pens we'd used. Remember? That's not the point anyway.

dialogue: A: Any messages, Miss Grey?
B: Just one, Mr. Blank. You had a telephone call from someone called Brown, David Brown.
A: Brown? I don't seem to know anyone called Brown. What did he say?
response: B: He wouldn't say. But it sounded important. I told him you'd phone him later this week

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Are you waiting to buy today's film tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: Have you been here long?
B: About 45 minutes. I've moved forward a total about 3 feet.
A: Oh...
B: Not at all. A young couple who have been waited for one hour ahead of me finally gave up and left.
A: Does anyone know what caused the delay?
response: B: There are just too many people selling tickets this afternoon.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.
A: Is it the diet that you love but have to avoid?
response: B: That's right. Dieting is so boring. Hopefully, I'll need to wear the wedding dress again anyway, because I'm getting divorced.

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
A: You mean you know how to farm?
B: Yes. I did that every summer during holidays.
A: I didn't know that a city boy can do farm work. Can I go there with you? I'd like to learn to do some farming.
B: Sure, my grandparents would be very happy to see you.
A: Are you sure?
response: B: I'm sure. They are very mean and terrible people.

dialogue: A: Are you alright, child?
B: Hey, I still know my name.
A: What did the nurse say?
B: She said I have a fever but nothing major.
response: A: In that case, you should go home and hug your kids

dialogue: A: We would be interested in having you join us, Mrs. Sharp.
B: Thank you. I have done this knid of work before.
A: I know, and that's probably the reason you've been employed. Do you prefer part-time or full-time employment?
B: Part-time.
A: OK. Some people choose part-time jobs because they want to do something else besides work, such as reading novels or playing sports. But they will not get any other benefits besides the wages.
B: I don't care about that. May I ask you if I can decide the hours I would work?
A: I can only give you the choice from 7:00 a.m. till noon or from noon till 5:00 p.m.
B: Then I'd prefer to work in the morning because I have to prepare dinner for my children.
response: A: OK, Mrs. Sharp. Just erase your name from this sheet of paper. You may start next week. Mrs. Clarkson has got something ready for you--a blackboard, some chalk, and a tape recorder. She'll show you around later.

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
response: B: I am afraid not, but when?

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order, sir?
B: Yes. Can you show me the menu, please?
A: Of course. Here you are.
B: Then, what's special tonight?
response: A: Our seafood is fresh. I recommend shrimp with garlic.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
response: A: No, but we can get your package to France in one year for 40 dollars.

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
B: Will you buy an exercise book for me?
A: I guess so. But I'll go to the post office first before I go to the supermarket.
B: Can you also buy me a pen? The one you gave me last week doesn't work now.
A: How come?
response: B: It fell off the desk but it still works great.

dialogue: A: Hello. This is Amy.
B: Hello, Amy. This is Tom.
A: Yes. What can I do for you?
B: I want to go to New York by train today. Would you please look up a train time for me?
response: A: Certainly, Hold on, please. Um... there's one at eleven p. m. It's very early. Why don't you go there by car?

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
response: A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be easy to find a job, then there will be the happiness from just starting a job.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order, sir?
B: Yes. Can you show me the menu, please?
A: Of course. Here you are.
B: Then, what's special tonight?
response: A: Our napkin is fresh. I recommend shrimp with garlic.

dialogue: A: Have you packed our passports?
B: Not yet. Do we need to take it with us?
A: Of course. Otherwise I cannot go abroad.
B: Is that hard to get a passport?
A: Not at all. But we do need to keep it with us all the time.
response: B: It is hard to believe this little thing is so replaceable.

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
B: But I don't have a car and I can't drive. Is there any other way to travel?
A: You can travel by bus. It's very cheap.
B: Can't I travel by train?
response: A: Yes, you can.  The train is expensive and modern in the States, but it's very slow.

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: I'm in a hurry. How long will it take?
B: About half an hour, if there's no traffic jam.
A: Do you think the traffic will be heavy?
B: I doubt it. It's not rush hour.
response: A: That's a pain.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
A: How awful! Was he hurt?
B: Yes. He was taken to the hospital in an ambulance.
A: How did it happen?
B: His car was hit by an express train. It happened at the crossing just behind his house.
A: How horrible!
B: He ’ s having an operation in the hospital now. Poor Hilda! You can imagine how unhappy she is.
response: A: I hope he ’ ll be all right .

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, I'll have a steak, please.
A: How would you like the steak, rare, medium, or well-done?
B: Rare, please.
A: Would you like something to drink?
response: B: Potatoes, please.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, I'll have a steak, please.
A: How would you like the steak, rare, medium, or well-done?
B: Rare, please.
A: Would you like something to drink?
response: B: Coffee flavored candy, please.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
response: B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
response: B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about watching e-sports?

dialogue: A: Did you get the injury playing football, Jim?
B: Yes. One of the boys kicked my foot instead of the ball.
A: The best thing for you to do is to rest your leg for 48 hours.
response: B: When can I go back to school?

dialogue: A: Bill, I must tell you the truth. You failed the English exam again.
B: Ah? Really? That stinks!
A: Haha. April Fool's! Did you forget what day it is today?
response: B: Wow, you were pulling my leg all along. I was not fooled though.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite reasonable.
response: B: It sounds painful. Thank you very much for your help.

dialogue: A: Bob, I'm sure you know about second-hand smoke.
B: Of course, I do.
A: But have you heard about third-hand smoke?
B: Third-hand smoke? I'm afraid not. What is that then?

A: Well, it is here in today's paper. Parents may think they are protecting children from second-hand smoke when they smoke outside their home or only when the children are not there. But now researchers are warning about what they call third-hand smoke. When you smoke dangerous matter from cigarettes get into your hair and clothing. As babies are the weakest, when you come to a baby, you pass it to the baby and increase the chances of disease in the baby.
response: B: Is that so? In that case I have to say that I should never get close to a baby.

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
B: The music group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?
response: A: It's inside the wall, madam, on the blackboard.

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have been hurt or even killed?
A: You are right! All the injured people were taken to the hospital immediately.
response: B: I hope so. Drivers must be careful, especially during rush hour.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
response: A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and extremely over-detailed.

dialogue: A: Are you ready for the big competition today, Todd? The winner gets two tickets to the Sydney Olympics!
B: Steve, I was born ready! I ’ m going to blow you guys off the treadmill today.
A: We ’ Ve still got a lot of time before we have to start running.
B: Let ’ s hit the whirlpool for a bit. It ’ ll help me loosen up.
response: A: You bet. I used to take a whirlpool almost every night back home.

dialogue: A: Helen,I heard you wanted to be a gym teacher, didn't you?
B: Yes, I did think about it. But it was going to be too expensive.
A: You mean the training?
response: B: Yes. You need to pay for the use of all the equipment, you know.

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely heavy.
A: Just the things we need for the picnic tomorrow.
response: B: Well, hurry up and open the door. I told you these things were very heavy.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
A: Your son's fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.
B: Yes, that's right. As soon as you've done what's necessary for buying the land, Jerry and I will see an architect.
A: Have you found a plot yet?
response: B: Jerry was in Edinburgh last Saturday and saw a plot he likes. My wife and I went there two days ago, and we liked it, too. I will do the necessary inquiries for you.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Does this hotel have a fitness facility?
B: Yes, we try to accommodate all needs of our patrons, including fitness.
A: Where is your fitness facility located?
B: The gym is just below the lobby. Take the elevator or the stairs. You can't miss it.
A: Is there an additional surcharge for the gym?
B: No, the gym is free to guests. Take your room key, however, so you can get in.
A: What time is the gym open, and what time does it close?
B: The gym is open seven days a week, twenty-four hours a day.
A: Do you offer trainer services along with the gym?
response: B: Unfortunately , no . If you want a trainer , you'll have to use this gym .

dialogue: A: Did you hear what Fred did last night?
B: No,not yet. What happened to him?
A: I guess he was a little drunk and he had a fight with his brother. Well, he got so mad that he drove his car straight into the front of a drugstore.
B: What do you mean?
response: A: I mean he drove inside. The front of the store was completely destroyed. I actually saw it just now as I walked by. The car is still inside the store.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
A: And what would you like to have for the main course
response: B: Shrimp salad before the vegetable soup. And what kind of pie do you have?

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
response: B: Oh, so you don't need a computer, too?

dialogue: A: Did you see the news today?
B: I haven't had a chance to see it.
A: You know about the blackout last night, right?
B: The lights were out everywhere.
A: A bunch of people went looting last night.
B: They what?
response: A: They took full advantage of the lights being on.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
response: B: I caught hold of his knife, and I left.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you take me to the airport?
B: Which airport, ma'am?
A: Kennedy Airport.
B: All right, ma'am. Need any help with your luggage?
response: A: Thank you, but I'd rather keep this coat with me.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
B: They really started looting?
A: Yes, apparently four stores were broken into.
response: B: I hope the looters escaped.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
A: I wonder if you can change it to one size down.
B: Yes, of course. Will you come with receipt?
response: A: Then I ’ ll come to your place later in the evening , and how late is your home open ?

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
B: No, but you can see that the point is bent a little bit.
A: Yes, it is, isn't it? We'd be happy to exchange it for you. But I'm afraid we don't have another purple one. We only have this pen in black and yellow now.
B: My wife doesn't care for either of those colors.
A: We have one with a red leather cover. That's three dollars more.
response: B: The children worked hard to throw out the eleven dollars for this one. They would probably be upset if I paid for part of their present.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
response: B: I'm attending the Catholic church .

dialogue: A: Have you been to exhibitions in your spare time?
B: Yes, a lot of times. I like exhibitions-exhibitions about famous people: dancers, actors, you know?
A: Mm, and what about a folk concert? Have you ever been to one of them?
response: B: No. I don't like folk music very much.

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so nervous.
A: Why?
B: I feel nervous every time I take examinadons.
A: Just relax. I used to feel the same way, but now I can handle exams easily.
B: How do you make it?
response: A: Well. I attended some lectures on taking exams.

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
A: No, what you need is balance.
B: Could you teach me how to do it?
A: Sure, anytime when you are free.
B: Do I have to buy a pair of skates?
response: A: I don't think it's necessary. Why not rent them?

dialogue: A: Any interesting jobs listed on the Internet today?
B: Well, there are a lot of retail jobs-selling clothes and stuff. But you have to work Saturdays and Sundays.
A: Hmm. I hate working on weekends.
B: Hmm... so do I.
A: Oh, here's a job in sales. It's a job selling children's books to bookstores.
B: That sounds interesting.
A: Yes.
B: Let's see.
A: You need to have a driver's license. And you have to work some evenings.
response: B: I don't mind working evenings during the week. And I enjoy driving. So, what's the phone number?

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
response: B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition worsened when he enjoyed himself and watched funny movies.

dialogue: A: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please.
B: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me.
A: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today.
B: Oh, why? Is she ill?
A: No. She's studying for an exam.
B: An exam. Is she going to school?
A: Yes, she is. She's learning Japanese in night school.
response: B: I see. Are you going to morning school, too?

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
B: But I was told that arm exercises could raise your blood pressure.
A: Yes, but the article I read suggests some ways to make up for that.
B: Really? How?
A: By adding leg exercises, so that the arms don't do all the work.
B: And in return, I'm sure that there's a good chance of losing weight.
A: Sounds right to me.
B: So what exercises do the experts suggest?
response: A: They mentioned quite a few exercises, but one of the most popular ones is push-up.

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
response: B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have walked away okay though right?

dialogue: A: Good morning. Anything wrong?
B: I've been suffering from a fever since yesterday.
A: Do you have any other problems? Like a headache or cough?
B: No, I don't. I think it's only a fever.
A: Let me check... It's 39 degrees. I'll give you some medicine.
B: Thank you, doctor.
response: A: You'd better take two or three Jager shots.

dialogue: A: When do you take your winter holiday?
B: I usually take it during the second or third week of January.
A: Do you like to ski?
B: Yes, I love to go skiing.
A: Where do you go?
B: I go to a hotel in the mountains.
A: Is it far from here?
B: It's about a hundred miles away.
A: Does it get cold?
response: B: Oh, yes! It gets very cold. It snows a lot.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote?
B: Yes, are you?
A: Yeah, but what day are the elections?
B: You don ’ t know what day the elections are?
A: That ’ s why I ’ m asking you.
B: They ’ re this coming Tuesday.
A: Really?
B: Yes, I ’ m serious.
A: Good thing you told me.
B: I can ’ t believe you didn ’ t know when the elections were.
A: It slipped my mind.
response: B: You must watch too much news.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I'd like to pay my bill.
A: OK. In cash or by credit?
B: In cash. How much is the total charge?
response: A: Five hundred and thirty yuan altogether including charges for service .

dialogue: A: I can't believe it! I lost.
B: It looks like you have to buy tickets for us, Jason. And we're not going to see an action movie!
A: That's not fair, you got all the easy questions.
response: B: I guess you just got lucky.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Could you tell me if the bus goes the national history museum?
B: No. It doesn ’ t. There ’ s no through bus to the national history museum Madam..
A: I see. Where do I have to change them?
response: B: You can transfer at Cuchan Men.

dialogue: A: Dad, do you know where Mom is?
B: I think she is in her room putting a little something together for you to take to school with you.
A: She'd better not start crying like she usually does.
response: B: I know, but she is going to be glad you are gone. Have I told you how proud I am of you?

dialogue: A: Alison, would you like to have some more?
B: No, thanks. I've had enough.
A: Actually you haven't had much.
response: B: To tell you the truth, I am on a diet.

dialogue: A: Do you ever eat fast food?
B: Yes, yes, I do.
A: What kind of fast food do you normally eat?
response: B: Oh, you know, hamburgers, sandwiches, well, sometimes a lobster.

dialogue: A: Is this blue too bright for me?
B: Mmm-hmm. It is a very bright blue. Try this. It's size ten.
A: But 1 wear size eleven.
B: How about black? It's size eleven.
A: Let me try it on. I'm taking too much of your time.
B: It's seven o'clock. Where's my friend Jack? I was expecting him here at six forty-five.
A: Don't worry. The traffic is very heavy at this hour.
B: I know. But we're going to be late for tonight's party.
A: I'll take this black sweater. I like the color on me. How do you think?
response: B: I think it looks horrific on you.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
