B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
response: A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just graduated from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
response: B: I was going to, but I had too many changes for a pay phone.

dialogue: A: Ah, Michelle, hi. I was hoping to see you. How have you been? How's the family?
B: Oh, hello, Mr. Campbell. I'm fine and Jack's doing well. How are you?
A: I'm fine thanks. I got your report this morning. Thank's for that. Are you joining the conference today?
response: B: No, I'm leaving afterwards at four pm.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.

B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were even for sale. The last one was on sale for $9,000.
response: A: $9,000? Well, I may go and visit the exhibition tomorrow, but I'm not going to buy anything.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I see your boarding pass, please?
B: Here you are.
A: Excuse me, sir. This is your passport.
B: Really? Ugh... Is there any difference?
response: A: Yes . As a matter of fact , you can't board the plane without boarding pass .

dialogue: A: Tom, as the manager of a company selling green products, you are now quite a successful businessman. When did you know you wanted to have your own company?

B: My family left Budapest in 1986 and settled in Canada where a lot of my friends' parents were highly successful businessmen. It seems so cool, so in high school, I started a web-designed company and learned a lot from that experience.
A: How did you find the money for your present company then?
B: We've raised 18 million dollars from about 50 people. We're finally making money. I own 6% of the company and all employees get their shares.
A: By the way, what aspects of your life are green?
B: I'm only mildly green. I do simple things and I'm a huge biker. I biked cross Canada.
A: Do you think you have ever done anything wasteful?
response: B: We're always doing something wrong, but then, that will allow us to learn and grow. When I first started out, we made all the products ourselves, but that was a mistake. Now we work with other companies. We provide the materials, the product development and the design. They make the products then.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite reasonable.
response: B: It sounds awful. Thank you very much for your help.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to move?
B: Definitely. I Ve got the hell out of the company. Anything new?
A: Yes, but there is a chance that might be suitable for you.
B: Really? Are you willing to recommend me for the position?
A: I can't say, but let me make a call and see if I can help.
response: B: I appreciate the effort, sir.

dialogue: A: Betty, where did you go yesterday?
B: I went to visit a friend of mine in the hospital.
A: What did you talk about?
B: We talked about a lot of different things.
response: A: Did you see in bad weather?

dialogue: A: Hello, Robert speaking.
B: Hi, it's Emma. I'm glad you're there. It's about our appointment on Wednesday morning. I'm afraid I can't make it now.
A: Oh, that's a shame.
response: B: I'm sorry. There was a change in my business partner's plan. And Wednesday is the only day she is able to see me.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
response: B: I don't have a name.

dialogue: A: David, why didn ’ t you clean the room?
B: I ’ m not in the mood.
A: Why are you feeling depressed?
B: I was told my girlfriend was speaking ill of me. That ’ s a real let-down.
A: I don ’ t think she will do such a thing.
response: B: But she did and made me disappointed.

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.
A: Well. I did think here, yes. But maybe the factory somewhere.
B: I think they prefer to see where our products are made.
response: A: OK, I'll meet them there.

dialogue: A: Honey, how long have we been living here?
B: About 10 years. What's wrong?
A: I am thinking about redecorating our house.
response: B: That would hardly cost any money. But we do need to do some changes to the house.

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
response: B: And the bike was missed by inches. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.

dialogue: A: What are you doing here?
B: I'm preparing my fishing tools.
A: What for?
response: B: I'm going to bake cake with some of my friends.

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
B: Well, my mum wants me to keep all the cans, so that we can sell them after a while.
A: Aha, you are going to make a millionaire of yourself sooner or later with all those cans.

B: You bet I will. Well, that's not the point. The point is we separate reusable things from other rubbish. We have to pay the dustman for dealing with rubbish, but if we sell him these cans and other reusable material we pay less.
A: That sounds a clever idea. Now what are reused in China?
B: Metal, plastic, paper, books and the like.
A: Just as we do back home in the States.

B: And to avoid waste, the government is limiting the production of goods that can be used only once, such as bamboo chopsticks. For example, all the fast food boxes should be made of paper instead of non-reusable material.
response: A: That will surely be harmful to a once-clean environment.

dialogue: A: Any message for me, Miss White?
B: Just one, Mr. Brown. You had a phone call from someone called Smith, Mary Smith.
A: Smith? I don't know anyone called Smith. What did she say?
B: She wouldn't say anything. But it sounded important. I told her you'd call her as soon as you came back.
A: Well, I think I'd better do it then. Have you got her telephone number?
A: Have you written it down?
response: B: I always do. It's in your wallet.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you waiting to buy the concert tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: How long have you been here?
B: About 50 minutes. I've hardly moved forward in that time.
A: Are you kidding?
B: Not at all. There was a couple up ahead of me who got so fed up that they finally gave up and left. They said they'd been here for more than an hour.
A: My God. Does anyone know what's causing the delay?
response: B: It could be that there are too many people selling tickets this afternoon. Or maybe their computers stay working properly

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
response: B: I go as much as I can . I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature .

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.
B: And where did you leave it?
A: I am sure I left it in the coffee shop on the 5th floor.
response: B: Don't worry, Madam. I am sure we can find it. Now could you give me your bag?

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: Yes, my nephew Jim is graduating from college next week and I'd like to get him a nice gift.
A: What price are you interested in? We'll need toknow that before we begin looking.
B: Well. I usually spend about twenty do Ham for a gift. Do you have anything nice for that price?
A: How about a pen?
B: No, my brother gave him that for his bithday last year.
A: Well, then would he enjoy a chess set?
B: No, he doesn't like chess very much, but he is quite athletic.
response: A: Then you could get him a tennis racket.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.
B: Then your two boys don't need to share a room. They are happy with it?
response: A: Yeah, they can have their own rooms. What interests me most is the small garden before the house. You know I love gardening so much.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
response: A: And you have a nosebleed now?

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.
A: I got it now. On the last line, I write the city it's going to and the district, right?
response: B: Don't forget to write the email address in the upper - left corner in the same manner as the sending address.

dialogue: A: Dad, how can we get to the zoo?
B: We can take a bus there.
A: Does this bus go there?
B: I think so.
A: Let's step in, Dad.
B: No, it's too crowded.
A: Dad. Here comes another bus.
B: Fine. Let's get on. Oh, no, Judy! Get off the bus quickly!
A: Why? Dad?
response: B: We got on the right bus.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
A: Your son's fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.
B: Yes, that's right. As soon as you've done what's necessary for buying the land, Jerry and I will see an architect.
A: Have you found a plot yet?
B: Jerry was in Edinburgh last Saturday and saw a plot he likes. My wife and I went there two days ago, and we liked it, too. I'd like you to make the necessary inquiries for me.
response: A: I'd be pretty annoyed to do that. I shall have to write to the Local Authority and inquire whether it is allowed to build a house on your piece of land. You're not allowed to build a house without permission from the Planning Authority. And sometimes the Authority idiotically decides that a house must be built of stone, and not of brick, so that it doesn't spoil the surrounding village!

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
B: At least, it can free you from the crowd. By the way, do you come from China?
A: No, from New Zealand, sir. I visited New Zealand and saw lots of overseas people there.
B: Wow, like America. It receives a great number of visitors every year.
response: A: The more the world becomes open , the more people become local.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
response: A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet surfaces too.
response: A: Precisely, and because it's natural protein, it probably wouldn't be harmful to people like so many synthetic glues in use today.

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
A: The Fools Garden is giving a performance today.
response: B: They are a rap group.  They are said to be very scary.  What time does the performance start?

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
B: You had pretty bad scores.
A: Exactly what do you mean by bad?
B: You failed.
A: How'd I fail it?
B: There are a couple of reasons why you didn't pass.
A: What did I do wrong?
response: B: To sum it all up, you really just don't know how to drive.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I go to a movie this week with Shannon?
B: Let me look at the calendar here. Hmm. When are you thinking about going to a movie?
A: Uh, we're thinking about seeing a movie on Wednesday after school.
response: B: Well, that's going to work. You haven't practiced your piano at all for an entire week, so you have to catch up on that.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. Er, I'm phoning about the job that was in the paper last night.
A: Oh, yes. Could you tell me your name?
B: Oh, Jerry Lynn.
A: Well, what exactly is it that interests you about the job?
response: B: I just thought that it was across the country, you know.

dialogue: A: And lightweight, too. It'll play for 20 hours on two AA batteries!
B: Cool! The sound is great. These earphones are awesome!
A: And they're really safe. They'll protect your ear from sound damage.
response: B: You doubtfully need that. You always pump the volume up way too high.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
A: If I were you, I'd say sorry to her first and then get her another cat.
B: That's a good idea. But I don't have.., enough money.
response: A: Oh, don't worry. I've got some. I can throw it at you.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam.
B: Good morning. I wonder if you can help. I've lost my coat.
A: Where did you lose it, madam?
response: B: Er... I  just found it since I was wearing it.

dialogue: A: Acknowledgments play a necessary part in the interview.
B: Sure. Kind acknowledgments can show one's good attainment.
A: We often ignore the acknowledgments in our daily life, and consider them as disposable.
response: B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a good impression on others, especially in the public places.

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
response: B: Well, now I'm going to throw out  these pages and these charts and then I'll start my project!

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
B: Buy an expensive suit.
A: Is a white shirt OK?
response: B: Yeah, fine.  And destroying leather shoes.

dialogue: A: Waitress! I think there's something wrong with our bill.
B: No, I don't think so...$10 for the drinks, 15 for the small plate, and 20 for the main dish.
A: What? I knew the cheese sticks were 15. I always order cheese sticks, but I thought the main dish was $10.
B: Oh, that explains it. You think the bill should be $35.
A: Yes, exactly. I was wondering what happened to the rest of my change. I should have gotten back 15, not 5!
B: I understand. Sometimes people aren't honest, but I think this was an honest mistake. Didn't you order the sea cucumbers for dinner?
response: A: Yes, and they were vicious. Best cucumbers ever! I'm so glad I'm a vegetarian

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote tomorrow?
B: I sure am. How about you?
A: I am.
response: B: Do you know where the place to protest is?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
response: A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what led you to join your beloved family and stay here. It certainly is not studying.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a white house. The General Reading Room is inside it.
response: A: No wonder! They are right here! Thank you very much.

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
response: A: I have no other choice. Next month there won't be any important exams.

dialogue: A: What topic did you finally choose for the term paper for your World Economy class?
B: After thinking about a few ideas, I finally settled on the difference between Japanese and American styles of management.
A: Hmm. Why did you choose a topic like that?
B: Well, I'm planning to study Business in graduate school next year. After that, I hope to start my own company.
A: Isn't that a coincidence! I'm also doing a paper on how Japanese management styles are being adapted by American firms for my Comparative Cultures class.
response: B: Why don't we sit down and share some of our soup after we've each been to the library?

dialogue: A: Charlotte, have you had your supper?
B: No, I don ’ t want to eat anything.
A: Why? Don't you feel well?
B: I ’ m down in spirits.
A: What's up?
B: My manager jumped on me for my mistake today.
response: A: You must not feel depressed about such an important thing.

dialogue: A: I hear you're going home, aren't you?
B: I wanted to go on Monday, but I couldn't get a ticket for Monday, I bought a ticket for Tuesday.
A: Why are you in such a hurry?
B: My mother is ill. She has been sent to the hospital.
A: How did you get the news? Did your mother send you a letter?
response: B: My sister telephoned me this morning. She asked my father and me to go back.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
response: B: Thanks , they are rather attractive . But I think there is nothing better than seeing things In actual operation .

dialogue: A: We are going to put on a performance.
B: Really? When?
A: On May 4. We have been preparing for it for two months.
B: Where are you going to put it on? In your school?
A: No. At the People's Theatre.
B: If I remember correctly, you put it on at the Youth Square last year.
A: Yeah. But it is under repair now.
B: But why are you doing that? To collect money for repairing the Youth Square?
response: A: Yes. We want to collect money and spend it on ourselves.

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
response: B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
B: No. Just occasionally.
A: What are your favourite dances?
response: B: I love rumba dolls and waltz dance.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.
A: No. But you must admit that on the big screen, it looked great.
B: Well, I think it would have been just as good as seeing it at home.
A: Ah, But it won't be on video till next year.
response: B: Good thing this is New Years Eve and it's coming out tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Hello, Old English Restaurant. Can I help you?
B: Yes. I'd like to book a table for tonight.
A: Yes, sir. What time?
B: Eight o'clock.
A: Certainly. For how many people?
B: There are ten of us.
A: Ten of you! But we don't usually accept large parties, sir.
B: I know, but we are regular customers.
A: What's your name please, sir?
B: Michael Peterson.
response: A: Mr. Peterson...of course! That'll be all right. We'll leave the two tables separated across the room.

dialogue: A: Are you going somewhere for your vacation?
B: Yes, I'm making plans for a tour.
A: That'll be lovely. Where are you going?
B: I start out from Long Island this Friday. I've planned a four-day drive to Salt Lake Ciy, where I'll join my brother and my family for his fortieth birthday.
response: A: Well, you've got to throw out lots of food and enough sleeping bags then?

dialogue: A: Hello, Catherine. Would you like to go out tomorrow?
B: Tomorrow?
A: Yeah, I was thinking we could get a bite to eat and catch a movie.
B: That sounds great.
A: Yes. We can do something else if you like.
response: B: OK . Dinner and a movie will be perfect .

dialogue: A: Are we going to have dinner tonight?
B: What are you planning on making?
A: I'm not cooking dinner.
B: The only way you're eating tonight is if you cook.
A: I'm not sure what to cook for dinner.
B: I don't know. What do you want to eat?
A: I have a taste for some chicken and potatoes.
response: B: That wouldn't taste good.

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
A: It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want some company?
B: Sure. But, it will be a long hike, 30 miles in three days. Have you been hiking before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike.
B: Wow! You must have been pretty far away from the city.
A: Yeah, my friend and I hiked in a very wild part of the national forest.
response: B: Well , bring him along too . We ’ ll have a great time this weekend .

dialogue: A: Did you see today's newspaper? That building over there in Centerville was just struck by lightning for the fourth time.
B: I'm not surprised. If the conditions for lightning to strike are right one time, they might be as good another time.

A: Well, I don't take any chances. If I'm caught in a thunderstorm, I will look for a building or a closed car. Also, I was told that if you're stuck outdoors, the best thing you can do is to keep yourself close to the ground and avoid bodies of water.
B: To tell you the truth, even when I'm at home, I don't take baths or showers during a thunderstorm. And I don't use anything that works electrically. Maybe I'm too anxious.
response: A: I wouldn't say that. According to the article, lightning starts thousands of fires every year in the United States alone. Hundreds of people got struck and even lived. I think you're just being insensible.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
response: B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.

dialogue: A: Are there any hobbies you do?
B: When I have time, I sometimes draw and paint.
A: Oh, you actually do that?
B: Every so often, I do.
A: Did you always know how to draw and paint?
B: I was taught in high school how to draw and paint.
response: A: You had a gym class?

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
A: It's wide open right now, everything from playground assistants to diaper changers.
B: Oh, I might pass on the latter. But spending some time on the playground with some small kids might be fun.
response: A: Well, you're quite warm-hearted. I haven't even mentioned the benefits but you're volunteering.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
A: Oh? Who's she calling?
B: She's calling her boyfriend.
A: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
response: B: He hasn't been home yet...Why? You're asking a lot of questions tonight, Paul.

dialogue: A: (sniffing) Is that a French cigarette?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that a French cigarette you're smoking?
B: Yes, that's right. Why? What's the matter?
A: I don't understand why yousmoke French cigarettes. They make a terrible smell.
B: I like them very much. I prefer them to English cigarettes.
A: Have you got a lot of them?
B: Yes, about 200, why?
A: Well... er... could I buy some from you?
B: Buy some from me? But... you don't like French cigarettes!
response: A: No, I don't. But my wife does.

dialogue: A: Still feeling ill?
B: Yes. And that medicine hasn't helped. Not a good start to our vacation, I'm afraid.
A: Do you have any idea what caused it?
B: Well, I thought it might be last night's dinner.
A: But I am fine. Could it be the heat? It's enough to make anyone ill.
B: I know. But we've been here a week now. Anyway, I've been careful in the sun and I've been drinking bottled water.
response: A: Then we'd better go sightseeing today.

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
A: I have no other choice. Next month will be the most important exam of this term.
response: B: I can understand that. But anyway, you should take less care of yourself.

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet surfaces too.
A: Precisely, and because it's natural protein, it probably wouldn't be harmful to people like so many synthetic glues in use today.
response: B: Think of all the ways doctors and dentists could use such a glue, mending broken hearts, fasting false brains.

dialogue: A: Did you see the news today?
B: I haven't had a chance to see it.
A: You know about the blackout last night, right?
response: B: The lights were out everywhere.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
A: Yes, they spent about five hours putting it out. Hm, what a strange smell!
B: Oh, I forgot the food cooking on the fire!
response: A: Be quick! Turn the gas up higher. You should be careful next rime, otherwise you'd have our house on fire!

dialogue: A: Look! It's snowing. Winter is here at last.
B: It's really cold today.
A: Yes, you have to get used to it. The weather's going to be like this for the next three months.
response: B: Then I'm going to Florida. Can you tell me about your weather diary? Why do you make notes about the different types of weather?

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
response: A: Did you go back home very early?

dialogue: A: Has everything been OK with you lately?
B: I haven ’ t been able to get a good night ’ s sleep lately. I ’ m exhausted!
A: Have you been too busy to get enough sleep?
response: B: I try to go to sleep , but I just can ’ t stay asleep .

dialogue: A: How do you pay at the shops, Mary?
B: Why? By cash or card, of course.
A: Ever thought of your mobile phone?
B: Is it possible?
response: A: This time next month, perhaps. It's impossible. Everything is done in 0.2 second, to be exact.

dialogue: A: Do you ever eat fast food?
B: Yes, yes, I do.
A: What kind of fast food do you normally eat?
B: Oh, you know, hamburgers, sandwiches, well, sometimes a pizza.
A: Well, right. And how often do you eat fast food? Every day, more than once a week or less than once a week?
B: Well, Monday to Friday when I'm working, every day, um, but not usually on weekends.
A: And when do you eat fast food of the day?
response: B: Oh, at work as I said, you know at lunchtime. Sometimes you know, if I'm going out and I've no time to cook in the evening then I'll send out for a pizza.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mary.
B: Hello, Jason. What are you going to do this evening?
A: I've no idea. What about you?
B: I have two tickets for the football match. Will you go with me?
A: Certainly. You know I haven't watched a football match for a long time.
B: Neither have I Shall we go there by bus?
response: A: All right. After supper let's play at the street corner. OK?

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a letter.
B: There's a mail box up the street. Have you already got a stamp on that letter?
response: A: Yes, I have to register it. How do I walk to the zoo from here?

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
B: I thought she'd be happy.
response: A: Yeah, especially since she got fired recently.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ms Thomas. What can I do for you?
B: Well, I've been having bad stomach pains lately, doctor.
A: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. How long have you been having them?
B: Just in the last few weeks. I get a very sharp pain about an hour after having meals.
A: I see. Do you get this after every meal?
B: Let me think. No, it's usually in the afternoon, after lunch.
A: Well, what do you have for lunch?
response: B: Oh, I mostly just have a very healthy meal and rush back to the office. We aren't very busy at the moment.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
A: Why is a computer so useful?
response: B: It can keep no information and work very fast.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
response: A: For everyday, mundane affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
B: At least, it can free you from the crowd. By the way, do you come from China?
A: No, from New Zealand, sir. I visited New Zealand and saw lots of overseas people there.
B: Wow, like America. It receives a great number of visitors every year.
response: A: The more the world becomes open , the less people become international !

dialogue: A: Hello? I would like to speak to Mr. Lee.
B: This is Lee speaking.
A: This is Linda, your old friend.
B: Oh, how are you, Linda? I'm glad you called.
A: Mr. Smith wrote to me that you were coming to our city. May I see you at your hotel right away?
response: B: Please hold on a moment. I have to check in at my hotel. Yes, that's ail fight.

dialogue: A: Have you been to exhibitions in your spare time?
B: Yes, a lot of times. I like exhibitions-exhibitions about famous people: dancers, actors, you know?
A: Mm, and what about a folk concert? Have you ever been to one of them?
response: B: No. I don't like jazz music very much.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
A: Let me ask the old woman in that reception office.
B: She can't answer you.
A: She must be deaf.
B: It must be a haunted house. Are you frightened?
response: A: Frightened ? You must be joking .

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
A: You mean you know how to farm?
B: Yes. I did that every summer during holidays.
A: I didn't know that a city boy can do farm work. Can I go there with you? I'd like to learn to do some farming.
B: Sure, my grandparents would be very happy to see you.
A: Are you sure?
response: B: I'm sure. They are very kind people but uncomfortable with guests.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
response: B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's doing nothing now.

dialogue: A: : I'm not sure if I can find work this summer. There aren't many jobs out there for inexperienced workers, and I can't just sit around all day.
B: an: Have you ever heard about house-sitting? Tom is going to house sit for Mary's family this summer when they travel to China.
A: : What exactly is house-sitting?
response: B: It's kind of like house-sitting except that you're watching a kid instead of houses.

dialogue: A: Hello, I hope to get a room for the night.
B: Do you have a reservation?
A: Sorry, I don't.
B: Let me see if I can fit you in. What kind of room do you want?
A: I only need a single room.
B: Smoking or non-smoking?
A: Smoking if possible.
response: B: You are in luck , we have zero free.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
response: A: Well, it has no bedrooms, no bathrooms, no big sitting room and a modern kitchen.

dialogue: A: Do you have a driver's license?
B: No. I am going to take the test in a couple of weeks.
A: Didn't you drive in your own country?
response: B: Yes. But I'm too good at driving.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
A: How about giving them to that old man?
B: Good idea.
A: By the way, do you think it's a good idea to give free gifts to attract customers?
response: B: I'm not sure , but still it failed to attract a large crowds today .

dialogue: A: Welcome to Youth Hotel, can I help you?
B: I'd like a room for a night.
A: Would you like a single room, a double room or a room for three?
response: B: Oh, a single room please. Can I pay by checker pieces?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
response: B: I'd like her to have a beer.

dialogue: A: Dad, do you know where Mom is?
B: I think she is in her room putting a little something together for you to take to school with you.
A: She'd better not start crying like she usually does.
response: B: I know, but she is going to miss you something awful. Have I told you how proud I am of you?

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
B: But he is usually correct in his weather news.
A: The temperature is 32t this afternoon. I'm sure we'll have fine weather for our picnic.
response: B: Well, I'll go, but I'll take my mittens with me.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. White. I wonder if you could spare a few minutes. I'd like to ask you a few questions.
B: Well, I can spare you a few minutes, but I'm very busy preparing for our exhibition, you know.
A: Just a few questions. Where is it going to be held?
B: It's going to be held in the art gallery.
A: Who is opening it?
B: It's going to be opened by Mr.Smith.
A: It's quite a big exhibition, isn't it?
response: B: Not really. Only local paintings will be shown.

dialogue: A: Do you feel like going to the cinema?
B: Oh, yes. What kind of films do you like?

A: Well, I like all sorts of films, but my favorite sorts are those like Star Wars. You know, the fantasy, special effect ones that you can escape into another world. I also like mystery film, do you like mystery films?
B: Yes, but I don't like horror films because they really give me nightmares.
response: A: I don't like horror films either. They're sort of amazing and totally believable. I do like crime films, you know, where you can follow the detective and try to guess who the murderer is.

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
response: A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. Is anybody taking care of you?
B: No, not yet. Could you show me that overcoat, the silver gray one in the middle.
A: Certainly. You've got excellent taste. It's very nice and it's 100 percent wool.
B: I like it. Could I try it on?
A: Certainly. It looks good on you, madam.
B: I think so. But a slightly larger size would be better.
A: Would you like to try this one on?
B: This one fits me well. How much does it cost?
A: Only $ 170.
B: OK, I'll take it. And I'd like that blue jacket on the right. How much is it?
A: It's just $ 250.
response: B: Oh, that's too expensive, I'm afraid.

dialogue: A: Hello, I need to come in and see the doctor.
B: Are you scheduling a check-up, or are you ill?
A: I have really itchy skin and think I may have to have it looked at.
B: Have you been feeling any joint aches with that rash?
A: No, but I have a low fever.
B: I have times available for Tuesday or Wednesday. Which one would work best for you?
A: I want to come in on Wednesday.
B: I can fit you in on that day at 10
A: I would prefer Dr. Smith.
response: B: You can see the doctor of your choice then , and we will see you at your scheduled appointment time .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
response: A: Have you thought about camping?

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: This is my first day here.
A: Are you a freshman in college?
B: I started school somewhere else.
A: What school did you transfer from?
response: B: I started at PCC.

dialogue: A: Have you heard about the robbery?
B: I saw the whole thing happen.
A: For real?
B: I was in the bank during the robbery.
A: What went down?
B: Some dude came into the bank with a gun.
A: Are you serious?
B: When he pulled out the gun, I got so scared.
A: Tell me what else happened.
B: He got the money and tried to leave.
A: Did the cops get him?
response: B: The cops arrested him before he could even make it out the door .

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
B: I was sick. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of bed.
A: You still look a little sick. You couldn't go back to bed.
B: I'm going now. I just came here to speak to my professor.
A: What did he tell you?
B: He said that I'd be able to take a make-up.
A: Well, that's all right then. Are you going straight home?
B: I have to stop at the drugstore on the way. I need some aspirin.
A: Do you think that you should walk that far?
response: B: I have to walk. I didn't bring my car. 1 didn't think I'd be able to drive today.

dialogue: A: Are we going to have gym class tomorrow?
B: Are you crazy? Tomorrow's Saturday.
A: Sometimes I forget that we don't have school on Saturdays.
B: Americans also don't go to work on Saturdays.
response: A: So there are only two working days in a weekend?

dialogue: A: Brad, wait!
B: What?
A: How come you have a locker but I don't?
B: Mr. Rogers probably forgot to assign a locker to you.
response: A: I had to carry my backpack to my locker all day.

dialogue: A: Emily, what do you do as a trendspotter?
B: Very simple. Take digital photos of youth culture and send them to my company. It's called Look-Look.
A: What kind of company is it?
B: It's a youth culture marketing and trend forecasting firm in Hollywood. I'm one of Look-Look's 65,000 trendspotters worldwide.
A: Look-Look gets a lot of information about the ever-shifting tastes of the youth market by these images.

B: Yes, its clients are mostly companies. They get information about trends from Look-Look and develop their products. They also use the images of Look-Look on their websites to impress young people and promote their newly designed products.
A: But are there any people who don't like their pictures to be used on the website?
B: I always have my subjects' permission before I take their pictures and put up their images onto Look-Look.com.
A: Where do you find your best subjects?
B: At school, in the park, at local supermarkets and near many music clubs.
A: What is difficult about this job?
response: B: To catch our original styles is easy because so many young people try hard to stand out. You then are able to find the difference between someone who is copying trends and someone who is truly inventing a new look.

dialogue: A: Beautiful weather, isn ’ t it?
B: Yes, it is. Are you here on business?
A: No, I ’ m on a vacation to see the famous Three Gorges.
response: B: I'm going there for a tour, too. Is this your first trip to Mars?

dialogue: A: Are you still at that work?
B: Yes, I'm still working there. But I really find my job boring. I'd like to change my job.
A: What sort of job do you have in mind?
B: I think I'm quite fit for a driver.
response: A: But it's not different.

dialogue: A: Anything else, sir?
B: That's all for now. How much do I owe you?
A: That'll be fifty-five dollars and twenty cents.
B: Can't you make it a little cheaper?
response: A: Of course, sir. We already gave you a discount on each item.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
response: B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to study at his uncle's library.

dialogue: A: Are you leaving?
B: I ’ m going to work.
A: You have a job?
B: I ’ m going to work at the polling place.
A: You ’ re working there this year?
B: I work there every year.
A: How are you able to work at the polling place?
response: B: I did not apply for the job.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
response: B: Yes, of course. Shall we sell her some flowers?

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
response: A: Dad, I don't need any high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
B: At least, it can free you from the crowd. By the way, do you come from China?
A: No, from New Zealand, sir. I visited New Zealand and saw lots of overseas people there.
response: B: Wow , like America . It receives a great number of visitors every year .

dialogue: A: Have you heard my good news?
B: You haven't told me anything yet.
A: I got a promotion at work earlier this week.
B: Is that right?
A: It's the truth. I am really happy.
B: Congratulations on your promotion.
A: Thank you very much.
B: I am really excited for you.
A: Are you really?
response: B: I'm serious . You deserved this promotion .

dialogue: A: Could you tell me the time of the last plane to Hong Kong this evening?
B: There's one at 10:15, but it's fully booked, I think.
A: Then the time of the first plane tomorrow morning?
B: The first plane leaves at 8:15.
A: Can you tell me when it arrives so that I can ask my secretary to come and meet me?
B: It arrives at 11:15 but maybe a little late because of the bad weather.
response: A: Well, I wonder if you'd let me know if there's any food offered on that flight, I'd appreciate it.

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
B: The music group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?
response: A: It's on the wall, madam, on the blackboard.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time every year.
A: How long will it take to cycle one way, Robin?
B: About seven to nine hours for the average cyclists. Good cyclists can do it in four hours.
A: How many people will be taking part this year?
B: This is our biggest year ever. We have twelve hundred cyclists registered.
A: I doubt they'll block the road when the cyclists start out?
response: B: Don't worry, we've introduced the simultaneous starts to avoid these problems. Our first group will leave Ottawa at seven o'clock.

dialogue: A: Welcome.
B: Hi, John. Hey, you've done a good job decorating this place, really nice.
A: Thanks, I am glad you like it. Can I get you a drink?
B: No, thanks. Let's make dinner. I am getting hungry.
A: Here is the kitchen. I will wash the onions first. Could you take the meat out of the fridge? It's in a yellow plastic container.
B: Wow, this smells good.
A: Could yon pass those potatoes to me, please?
B: What are we having?
A: My special dumplings, sweet and sour pork, beef with onions and green peppers, and a few side dishes like tomatoes with sugar.
B: Sounds wonderful. What are you going to do next?
response: A: I'll start preparing the meat stuffing.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
response: A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite steep.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam.
B: Good morning. I wonder if you can help. I've lost my coat.
A: Where did you lose it, madam?
response: B: Er... I left it on a bus yesterday morning.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
B: Well, I use it to send e-mails a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself French program. And I shop online pretty often.
A: Mmm. Any other uses?
response: B: Keeping track of my garden plants, and there are a couple of fishing spots I enjoy.

dialogue: A: Well, Jenny, the school year is almost over. We just have two more weeks before exams. What do you plan to do this summer?
B: I'm going to teach English to some immigrants in the university's community service program.
A: That sounds interesting. Don't you need to speak a foreign language for a job like that?
B: No, you don't. You just have to present the language simply and give the students a chance to practice speaking.
A: Come to think of it, that's the way I was taught to speak Chinese. But speaking didn't help me learn to read and write Chinese.
B: My students won't want to read and write English, at lease not now. They are more interested in speaking.
A: You sound very knowledgeable about all this. How do you know so much?
response: B: I took a Teaching English as a Second Language course last year when you were in China. I've also talked with the inexperienced teachers quite a lot. I think I would like to be an ESL teacher when I graduate.

dialogue: A: Bob, do you know who I saw the other day? Old Jake, looking terribly depressed. Did he get pensioned off at last?
B: Yes. They made him retire after 50 years at sea. He is pretty upset about it, but what can you do? He really is pasted.
A: He is all alone, isn't he?

B: Yes, his wife has been dead for years. They had one daughter, Dories. But she went off to town as soon as she left school. And he hasn't heard from her since. I hear she is making good money as a model.
A: Maybe someone could get in touch with her. Get her to come back for a while to help?

B: I don't suppose she come. She never got on with her father. He is bit of a tough character and she is rather selfish. Oh, I expect old Jake will get by. He is healthy at least, comes into a clinic for a check regularly.
response: A: Are you his pastor?

dialogue: A: Would you like to come to the cinema tonight?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why not?
response: B: I've got to comb my hair tonight.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. I just received my telephone bill, and there's a problem with it.
B: May I see your bill, please?
A: Certainly. There it is. On July 1st, I really don't know anybody in Finland.
response: B: OK, don't worry. I'll leave the call on. Let's see...it was $42. Your bill was $ 66.10, minus $0 so your new total is $66.10. I'm don't care about the mistake.

dialogue: A: Honey, how long have we been living here?
B: About 10 years. What's wrong?
A: I am thinking about redecorating our house.
B: That would cost a lot of money. But we do need to do some changes to the house.
response: A: Right. What about keeping the living room the way it is?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Could I be of any service to you?
B: Have you got any Chinese paintings?
A: Yes, we have landscape paintings, figure paintings and flower-and-bird paintings.
B: I'd like a flower-and-bird painting.
response: A: Good . How about this sculpture of cranes with pine trees ? It was sculpted by a famous Chinese sculpture in King Dynasty

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.
A: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of strong and comfortable shoes.
B: What's your suggestion?
A: Maybe you should buy him a pair of leather shoes.
B: Tom doesn't like leather shoes.
response: A: Then, how about flip flops? They are strong and comfortable.

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
A: It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want some company?
B: Sure. But, it will be a long hike, 30 miles in three days. Have you been hiking before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike.
response: B: Wow ! You must have been pretty close from the city .

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, it looks like you've got some sun this weekend.
B: Yeah, I guess so. I spent the weekend at the beach.
A: Oh, yeah, that's great. Where did you stay?
B: Some friends of my parents' live out there and they invited me for as long as I wanted to stay.
A: So what are you doing back here already?
response: B: Oh, I have a paper to sleep on, and I just couldn't do any serious napping at the beach.

dialogue: A: What are you thinking?
B: I ’ m thinking about where we shall spend our vocation.
A: It ’ s about 7 o ’ clock. let ’ s have our breakfast first.
B: Ok, dear.We will be late.
A: What do you want?
response: B: A picture of a ham salad sandwich.

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
A: It's wonderful. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.
B: What about the swimming pool?
response: A: It's very good. Would you like to go there with me next week?

dialogue: A: Bill, I must tell you the truth. You failed the English exam again.
B: Ah? Really? That stinks!
A: Haha. April Fool's! Did you forget what day it is today?
B: Wow, you were pulling my leg all along. I was really fooled.
response: A: Alright, now let's be serious. Actually, you get low marks in the exam.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
A: This class is really just a review for me. I've been learning it for two years.
B: That's lucky for you.
A: Jeanie, can you guess what the test will be like? Will it be difficult?
response: B: I hope not. But I'm still worried I'll ace it.

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
A: It's wonderful. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.
B: What about the swimming pool?
A: It's very good. Would you like to go there with me next week?
B: Good idea. Every day is OK except Monday.
response: A: Well. Why not go there on Saturday? We can just stay for a half hour.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.

B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?
A: Well, no. I don't think I would. I bet it costs a lot of money. Does it say how much it costs?
B: Yes. The early black-and-white ones cost several hundred pounds. But the one is about costs several thousand pounds.
A: Hum. Why does anybody want one, do you think?
response: B: Business organizations that need to frequently contact overseas organizations would want it. It's like a face-to-face conversation. So maybe this doesn't cut back on overseas travel.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
response: B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of staying at the bank.

dialogue: A: Mr. Block, I need to take a few days off because my parents are coming over to visit.
B: But it's not really a good idea to take time off right now, you know.
A: Well, I know. But they've never been to the UK before and they don't speak English.
B: Hmm, you know there are thousands of tourists in London who can't speak English and they manage to get around.
A: Yes, I know but they really expect me to be there. It's culture. Chinese parents expect their children to do things like this.
B: I know, but truly if they care about your education, they'll understand.
A: Well, do you think I could take maybe just two days off?
response: B: Ok, two days but you must not catch up with all of the work and get none of the materials.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Youth Hotel, can I help you?
B: I'd like a room for a night.
A: Would you like a single room, a double room or a room for three?
response: B: Oh, a single room please. Can I pay by a barter system?

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
response: B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!

dialogue: A: Have you gone to school today?
B: I went to school today. Did you go to school?
A: I couldn't go to school today, I was sick.
B: That's horrible. I'd be happy to give you the assignments from English class.
A: Thank you very much, that's kind of you.
B: Don't mention it.
A: When you miss a day of school, I'll be happy to give you the English assignments.
response: B: That is greatly appreciated and I hope you feel well enough to go to baseball practice tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Would you like another piece of chicken?
B: Yes, please. It's delicious. Did you cook it in Qianmen. How about some sandwiches?
A: Oh, no. It's Kentucky Fried Chicken. I bought it in Qianmen. How about some sandwiches?
B: Well, just one, please. Hmm, it's nice! You bought them in Kentucky Restau-rant al- so, didn't you?
response: A: Yes, I did. Let me give you some more chicken. There's plenty more.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve about British culture.
A: Professor Grand's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person coming in asking for those articles.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matterwhich one you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're joking, all of them?
response: A: Every month. I've asked professor Grand twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for those same articles to be returned.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but I think you've made a wrong turn. You were supposed to turn left on Wilson Boulevard.
B: Oh, I am sorry. Didn't you say 1323 Wilson?
A: No, 3023. It is OK though. You don't have to take me there. I can walk from here.
B: Why don't I just make a U-turn there? It's a one-way street; see the sign up ahead. Maybe if I turn left here, I can come down the next street.
response: A: We can't do that during rush hour really, though it won't be much trouble. Sometimes one can wait 30 minutes for a taxi, so I'm happy to get this close.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to move?
B: Definitely. I Ve got the hell out of the company. Anything new?
A: Yes, but there is a chance that might be suitable for you.
B: Really? Are you willing to recommend me for the position?
response: A: I can't say, but let me make a call and see if I can order it.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
response: B: Well, I've been working a lot less lately... more than 11 hours a day.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
A: I can take you home. Would you like a ride?
response: B: Yes. Thanks a lot. Could you stop at the nursery on the way? I need to buy some plant grow-fast medicine.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
response: B: No, but you can see that the point is perfectly straight.

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
response: B: Then, you should dress well.

dialogue: A: Are you doing anything tonight?
B: No, nothing. Why?
A: Do you like western music?
B: Yes, I do, very much.
response: A: There ’ s a concert tonight. Would you like to go and listen to it?

dialogue: A: Are there any scenic spots nearby?
B: You can go to ZhongShan Park.
A: Have you ever been there?
B: Yes. The scenery there is so breathtaking
A: Really?
response: B: Yes, of course. It's really worth visiting.

dialogue: A: Are you free this afternoon?
B: I'm afraid I'm going to the gym for a workout.
A: How long have you been there?
B: I began to went there last month.
A: Is there any change?
B: Well, I think I'm in better condition now.
response: A: Really? Is it tiring?

dialogue: A: Dr. Steven, I am thinking about changing my major before the end of the freshman year.
B: What are you studying now?
A: I am taking three genera] requirements and American history and American literature this. semester. Last semester I took four requirements and freshman French.

B: I believe it's not too late to change your major because you've mainly taken general requirements which all freshmen have to take. Also we have twelve electives so the mo lit courses will be included in them, so you can change your major without losing any credit hours.
response: A: I am very happy to know I am still able to change my major. I am interested in reading newspaper articles, and after finishing my degree I would like to work for some newspaper firm.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
response: A: I do a lot of sitting for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.

dialogue: A: Welcome.
B: Hi, John. Hey, you've done a good job decorating this place, really nice.
A: Thanks, I am glad you like it. Can I get you a drink?
B: No, thanks. Let's make dinner. I am getting hungry.
A: Here is the kitchen. I will wash the onions first. Could you take the meat out of the fridge? It's in a yellow plastic container.
B: Wow, this smells good.
A: Could yon pass those potatoes to me, please?
B: What are we having?
A: My special dumplings, sweet and sour pork, beef with onions and green peppers, and a few side dishes like tomatoes with sugar.
B: Sounds wonderful. What are you going to do next?
response: A: I'll start preparing the meat supreme pizza.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
A: How awful! Was he hurt?
B: Yes. He was taken to the hospital in an ambulance.
A: How did it happen?
response: B: His car was hit by an express train . It happened at the crossing just behind his house .

dialogue: A: Where do you want to go, Madam?
B: Hilton Hotel, please. Brrr! It's cold, eh? I'm freezing.
A: Come in. San Francisco is usually cold in winter, you know. It's often very rainy, which makes the weather colder and it sometimes....
B: Well, it gets very hot in summer, doesn't it?
response: A: Not really. It gets warm in December and Janurary. That's the best time to visit the city. Uh, oh. Here comes the rain!

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
response: B: Well, my mum wants me to drink all the cans, so that we can sell them after a while.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
A: How about giving them to that old man?
B: Good idea.
A: By the way, do you think it's a good idea to give free gifts to attract customers?
B: I'm not sure, but still it did attract a large crowds today.
response: A: I think it should be more useful to hand out some Stickers which is also cheaper

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
B: Not really. But when I was home, I had to start typing a literature paper that was due first thing in the morning.
A: Couldn't you do it today?
B: No, our professor said she wouldn't accept any late papers.
A: Then how did you manage it?
response: B: Well, I just turned my paper in, and now I'm going head out on the town for a crazy long night. See you!

dialogue: A: What's going on around here? Why is everyone changing offices?
B: Haven't you heard? Where have you been anyway?
A: I just got back from visiting the plant in Chicago.
B: Well, there are a lot of changes being made here this week.
A: Yes, I see. But what are they?
B: For one thing, Martha and Jim are leaving.
A: Where are they going?Did they get a higher position?
B: Martha's going to the office in Atlanta. She is going to be in charge of the whole southern market.
A: That sounds like a good position to me. What about Jim?
B: He is going to manage the plant in California.
A: And you? What about you? Are you going to rise to a higher position?
B: Not yet, but I'm hoping I will.
A: Don't you want to get a raise? I'd like the job in California.
response: B: No, I want to stay here at the company office. This is the place to get noticed by hot women.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
A: And what would you like to have for the main course
B: Shrimp salad. And what kind of pie do you have?
A: Apple, banana and strawberry pie.
B: Then a piece of apple pie, please.
A: And what would you like for dessert?
response: B: Rare steak, please.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
response: A: It doesn't matter. I just want to cut out some figures for my paper. Where is it?

dialogue: A: Are you ready?
B: Ready for what?
A: Ready for the big switch.
B: What are you talking about?
response: A: The nation is switching to digital TV.

dialogue: A: When do you take your winter holiday?
B: I usually take it during the second or third week of January.
A: Do you like to ski?
B: Yes, I love to go skiing.
A: Where do you go?
B: I go to a hotel in the mountains.
A: Is it far from here?
B: It's about a hundred miles away.
A: Does it get cold?
B: Oh, yes! It gets very cold. It snows a lot.
A: Do you go alone?
B: A couple of my friends usually go with me. Do you want to come along some weekend?
A: No, not me. I don't like cold weather.
response: B: I don't really like it either. I love snow!

dialogue: A: Are there any scenic spots nearby?
B: You can go to ZhongShan Park.
A: Have you ever been there?
B: Yes. The scenery there is so breathtaking
A: Really?
response: B: Yes, of course. It's really not worth visiting though.

dialogue: A: : Hey, hey, neighbor. What are you doing with my trees? My wife planted that tree 25 years ago. Get off that ladder.

B: ghbor: Listen. Even though the trees are in your yard, some of the branches hang over into mine, and I am getting sick and tired of raking up your leaves and picking up all the branches that fall off during storms throughout the year. And the walnuts off this tree... they litter my yard and damage my lawnmower when I cut the grass. And my dog eats them, and he ends up with terrible diarrhea.
A: : Still. You can't cut off those branches.
B: ghbor: Watch me. It's completely legal. I check the city code and law regarding this issue, and I am well within my rights.
A: : I'm not sure about that. Anyway, It's just not right. You didn't say anything to us about it...
B: ghbor: I don't have to.
A: : Yeah, but you could have said something. Anything! I mean I want to stay on friendly terms with you, but the basic courtesy of informing your neighbors is the least you could have done.
B: ghbor: Okay. I'm cutting down your branches. You've been informed... now, stand back!
response: A: Hey. You're hosting our next barbecue or book club!

dialogue: A: Are you okay?
B: No.
A: What's wrong?
B: I got robbed!
A: By who?
B: Some guy on the street just mugged me.
A: Are you hurt?
B: No, he just stole all of my things.
A: That's crazy.
response: B: I need to go to the bus station.

dialogue: A: Why, Ann, I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been?
B: Bob, it has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year.
A: No. We talked at the Johnson's Christmas party last December. Don't you remember?
B: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the Germen company?
A: No. I changed my job about 4 months ago. I'm with the World Bank now. How about you?
B: I'm still working at the University, but I transferred from the German Department to the Spanish Department.
A: Don't you tell me you speak Spanish, too?
response: B: Sure. I grew up in Spain, you know. German was what I studied in college.

dialogue: A: Did you go out today?
B: With my bad luck? What good would it have done if I'd gone out?
A: If you'd looked for a job,you might have found one.
B: But I've been looking for one over a year. Today wouldn't have been any different.
A: I know how bad you feel, but if you don't keep on looking, you'll never get a job.
B: If I'd stayed in Puerto Rico in the first place, I wouldn't have had so much trouble.
A: What would you have done? There are more people out of work there than there are here.
B: I could have had a farm of my own if I'd stayed there.
A: You? Up the mountains, with nobody to talk to, but the children?
B: I don't like the city. There are too many people. There's too much noise, too much dust.
A: I like here.
response: B: Yes, because your brother's here. This is really your home.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
response: B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very poor employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
B: I'm sorry, but I don't sell tickets. You can get one from the machine over there.
response: A: All right. By the way, what's your home address?

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
A: I sprained my wrist, but the doctor says it will be fine.
