B: How many days will you be out of school?
A: The doctor said I should be good enough to return next week.
response: B: I am glad you let me know that you will be throwing a party in class . Get well!

dialogue: A: Have you been to exhibitions in your spare time?
B: Yes, a lot of times. I like exhibitions-exhibitions about famous people: dancers, actors, you know?
A: Mm, and what about a folk concert? Have you ever been to one of them?
B: No. I don't like folk music very much.
A: What about the opera?
B: No, never. I don't really like the opera. It is a bit too heavy for me.
A: A pop concert?
response: B: Yes. I saw Madonna once. She was fantastic-she is a really great dancer.

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
B: But I didn't hear it at all.
A: What time did you set it for last night?
B: Six o'clock.
response: A: Hurry up, or you'll be late for school. Are you feeling ill?

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
response: B: We already found a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?

dialogue: A: Betty, something is burning. Can you smell it?
B: You ’ re right.
A: Look! The iron is still on.
response: B: I should have turned it off. I ’ ll turn it off now.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
B: We can go next week instead.
response: A: No, I don't want to ruin your weekend. You go ahead and please take the book I bought to my friend Sally. Tell her I have to study all weekend, because I am very eager to fail the test.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?
response: A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in a bit too little basic information

dialogue: A: Are you ready for the big competition today, Todd? The winner gets two tickets to the Sydney Olympics!
B: Steve, I was born ready! I ’ m going to blow you guys off the treadmill today.
A: We ’ Ve still got a lot of time before we have to start running.
response: B: Let ’ s hit the whirlpool for a bit. It ’ ll help me loosen up.

dialogue: A: Are you interested in music?
B: Yes. I like classical music. Beethoven is my favourite composer. How about you?
A: I like all kinds of music, but jazz is my favourite and my wife is fond of rock music.
B: You play the piano, don't you?
response: A: A little bit, but my wife is much better than me with cats. She can also play the video game.

dialogue: A: When do you take your winter holiday?
B: I usually take it during the second or third week of January.
A: Do you like to ski?
response: B: Yes, I love to go boating.

dialogue: A: Why, Ann, I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been?
B: Bob, it has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year.
A: No. We talked at the Johnson's Christmas party last December. Don't you remember?
B: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the Germen company?
A: No. I changed my job about 4 months ago. I'm with the World Bank now. How about you?
B: I'm still working at the University, but I transferred from the German Department to the Spanish Department.
response: A: Don't you tell me you speak Chinese, too?

dialogue: A: We haven't gone out for over a month. Let's go somewhere this evening.
B: Fine, where shall we go?
A: Look in the newspaper to see what's on at the cinema or the theater.
B: I see new play opened this week.
A: I enjoy a concert.
B: According to the newspaper there aren't any tonight.
A: Aren't there any good films in town?
response: B: How about "Titanic"? That should be interesting.

dialogue: A: Good morning. So this is the first day for you to work here, I hope you'll like your job.
B: Good morning, Ms.Wilson. I've got a lot to learn from you. I think I'll enjoy working with you.
A: I hope so. Now let me tell you your duties here. This is your desk. Please sit down.
B: Thank you.
A: Your main duty is to answer the phone calls and transfer them to the person wanted.
B: I see. What if the person wanted is out?
response: A: In that case , you are supposed to pay the caller to leave a message .

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
response: A: And what would you like to have for the main course

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
B: You can get wine and beer in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.
A: When do people go to the pubs?

B: Pubs are not open all day. They can decide when to open. Most are open for 3 or 4 hours at lunchtime and again from about 6:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. In busy areas, pubs may stay open from 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. Are there pubs in China?
A: Yes. Most of the customers are young people. They like to hang out with their friends after work and have fun.
response: B: It is against the law in England to go into a pub if you are under the age of l4. So many pubs provide a special bouncer to watch out for children.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
B: About 20 minutes at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.
A: I'd better go there by bus. By the way, where is the bus stop, please?
response: B: Just across the city.

dialogue: A: Are you sure that this bus will take us to Santa Anita mall?
B: Yes, it will.
A: You know that for a fact?
response: B: I take this bus all the time, but you know what, I don't know for sure.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
response: A: I'm not going to ask the old woman in that reception office .

dialogue: A: When did you become interested in collecting stamps?
B: Oh, when I was about ten years old.
A: Ten years old? So you have loved it for 9 years.
B: Yeah, it's really an exciting hobby. You know, the first postage stamps were issued in Britain in 1840.
A: Really? I didn't know that. What's on the first postage stamps?
B: Well, look, here's a picture of the first two stamps issued.
A: Oh, they both bear a picture of Queen Victoria, don't they?
B: Yes, I wish I had the originals, then I would be a wealthy man instead of a poor stamp collector.
response: A: But I believe collecting stamps give you much street cred which not all wealthy men can enjoy.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Are you waiting to buy today's film tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: Have you been here long?
B: About 45 minutes. I've moved forward a total about 3 feet.
A: Oh...
B: Not at all. A young couple who have been waited for one hour ahead of me finally gave up and left.
A: Does anyone know what caused the delay?
response: B: There are just not enough people buying tickets this afternoon.

dialogue: A: : Dad, what will we have for dinner?
B: : I don't know. Maybe fried fish, chicken soup and...
A: : Oh, no. We've had such things since Mom's gone.
response: B: : I'm sorry. But that is the only thing I can cook. What do you want to have then?

dialogue: A: Any interesting jobs listed on the Internet today?
B: Well, there are a lot of retail jobs-selling clothes and stuff. But you have to work Saturdays and Sundays.
A: Hmm. I hate working on weekends.
B: Hmm... so do I.
A: Oh, here's a job in sales. It's a job selling children's books to bookstores.
B: That sounds interesting.
A: Yes.
B: Let's see.
response: A: You need to have a driver's license. And you have to work some evenings.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.
response: B: I'm more than willing to. My boss just did me a favor by putting me on evenings. And he'll hit the ceiling if I ask to change again.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: Yes, I am.
A: Is this your first year in college?
B: I actually transferred here from another school.
A: Which school?
response: B: I flew here on PCC.

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so nervous.
A: Why?
response: B: I feel nervous every time I passed an examination.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
response: B: Buy an expensive suit.

dialogue: A: What did you think of the lecture?
B: I thought it was very interesting.
A: Did you really?
B: Yes, didn't you?
A: Certainly not. I thought he talked a lot of rubbish.
B: So you think you know more than he does.
A: Well, take coal for instance.
B: What about it?
A: Coal won't become important again.
B: Why not?
response: A: It's too clean. They will be able to find people to work down coal mines in the future.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is not in at the moment.
B: When will he come in, do you know?
A: I suppose he won't be in until 12: 00.
B: May I leave a message?
A: Certainly.
response: B: Please ask him to give me a call as soon as he returns. He has my number.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
response: A: This class is really just an introduction for me. I've been wanting to learn it for two years.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
B: I'd like her to have a change.
A: Then how do you like this plum red one?
response: B: It is nice . Is it water proof ?

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
B: I did. I called you many times, but you had your mobile phone power off.
A: Oh, I didn't bring it with me because I left it recharging at home.
response: B: I'm really happy to have seen the film with you.

dialogue: A: Hi, honey. Do you need any help with your luggage?
B: No, thanks, dad. I just brought one carry-on in my backpack.
A: Great. I wish your mother would take some packing lessons from you. OK, let's go home.
B: Hm...It's cold here.
A: Yes, the weatherman says that it might snow tonight. What temperature was it when you took off from California this morning?
response: B: Sixty degrees and snowing.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. We will have our midterm exams next month. I plan to look for some important books and study at the library. Do you want to join me?
B: Sure. I need to return some books. They are due today. Besides, I can also read some weekly publications, magazines and newspapers.
A: Great. We can go to the swimming pool in the gymnasium after that.
response: B: Sounds a good idea. Summer is over. Today's temperature has reached 35 degree Centigrade. Are you good at swimming?

dialogue: A: Are you free this Saturday evening?
B: Oh, it seems there is nothing that evening.
A: Would you like to go to the concert with me?
B: I'd like to, where?
response: A: At the hospital

dialogue: A: What are you doing here?
B: I'm preparing my fishing tools.
A: What for?
B: I'm going to fish with some of my friends.
A: Are you fond of fishing?
B: Yes. I like fishing after school and on Sundays.
A: When did you get such a hobby?

B: Long ago. You know, my father is fond of and very good at fishing. When I was a child, he took me to the riverside to see him fishing. I found fishing very interesting then. Well, what's your hobby?
A: I'm very interested in making home movies. But I haven't got a movie camera.
B: I also like taking photos and I have a Japanese-made camera.
response: A: I take a lot of photos, too. But I'm more interested in the history of film, so I really enjoy using a film camera. I'll buy one of my own someday to make movies for work.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
response: A: Your son's fortunate.  So you want my help selling the land and tearing down the house

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
B: I'd like her to have a change.
A: Then how do you like this plum red one?
B: It is nice. Is it water proof?
A: Yes, sir.
response: B: Okay , I'll take it . Could you help me gift wrap it ?

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
response: A: One moment while I go and get my ID .

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
response: B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become nice recently.

dialogue: A: Hello, Thomas Brothers.
B: Hello, this is Mike Landon here. Is Jack Cooper there by any chance?
A: I am afraid not, he is away for a day or two, back on, let's see, Monday morning.
B: Oh, well perhaps I can live a message for him.
A: Yes, of course, just a minute. Now, let's see, to Jack Cooper from Mike London.
B: No, Landon, L-a-n-d-o-n.
A: Sorry, yes, got that, and what's the message?
B: Well it's just this: could he come to a meeting on Monday afternoon at 5:00 pm?
A: That's this coming Monday, October 12th?
response: B: Right, it's not to discuss the new factory in France.

dialogue: A: Is this blue too bright for me?
B: Mmm-hmm. It is a very bright blue. Try this. It's size ten.
A: But 1 wear size eleven.
B: How about black? It's size eleven.
A: Let me try it on. I'm taking too much of your time.
B: It's seven o'clock. Where's my friend Jack? I was expecting him here at six forty-five.
response: A: Don't worry. The weather is very hot at this hour.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you live here?
B: Yes.
A: Oh, well, do you know where the English Language Institute is?
B: Ah, yes. I think I know where it is. Do you have a car?
A: No, I'm on foot.
B: Well, as you go out of the station, just continue along the road until you come to the second crossing and then turn left into King Street.
A: Yes.
response: B: Then walk down the street just a bit and take the first turning on the right. And keep walking until you come to the park.

dialogue: A: Hello, Amy. Are you coming to my birthday party?
B: Yes, I am. How do I get to your house from the station?
A: Well, call me when you get to the station and I'll come and pick you up in my car.
B: Are you sure it won't be too much trouble?
A: It's no trouble at all. It only takes about 15 minutes.
response: B: Oh, I want to check my phone number. Is it 828816887?

dialogue: A: Good afternoon! Dr. Perkins' office.
B: Good afternoon. I'd like to speak to the doctor. Is he in?
A: Who is that calling, please?
B: My name is Li Hong. I'm from China.
A: I'm sorry. Dr. Perkins is now at an important meeting and can't answer your call.
B: I'm an exchange scholar. Dr. Perkins asked me to give a lecture. There are some details I want to discuss with him.
A: I see, but you must speak to himself about that. Oh, well, if you leave your number, I'll tell him to ring you as soon as he is available.
response: B: Thanks. My lucky number is 7.

dialogue: A: Where did you put my new red tie?
B: It's right there in the cupboard with your other ties.
A: There's a green one and a couple of brown ones, but no red one.
B: Here it is in your drawer. You must have put it there when you brought it home.
A: I suppose so. We'd better hurry up or we're going to be late. The Smiths said to come at 7:00.
response: B: 24 now. You aren't here to take care of the children yet.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I go to a movie this week with Shannon?
B: Let me look at the calendar here. Hmm. When are you thinking about going to a movie?
A: Uh, we're thinking about seeing a movie on Wednesday after school.
B: Well, that's not going to work. You haven't practiced your piano at all for an entire week, so you have to catch up on that.
A: What about Friday?
B: Uh uh. Forget that idea.
A: And Saturday?
response: B: Well, you have to take an English class in the morning. And then, we have to clean out the garage. You said you'd help. Well, that should only take a couple of hours. And then, after that, you can go to the movie.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is not in at the moment.
response: B: When will he come in, do you know?

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was killed in that bombing.
response: A: I'm sorry to hear that. War left many people joyful memories.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is not in at the moment.
response: B: When will he come out of his office, do you know?

dialogue: A: Good afternoon. I'm looking for a second-hand car and I believe you sell cars.
B: Yes. I have one here that may interest you.
A: Ah, yes. A friend told me about it. What make is it?
B: It's a Lincoln.
A: Is it MS 560 or MF 558? I don't want either of them. I want a MF 650 one.
B: Oh, it's the one you want, and it's three years old.
A: Mmm... hmm. And what sort of condition is it in?
B: It's in very good condition and it's compact.
A: Right. And how much are you asking for it?
B: Three thousand and fifteen dollars.
A: Three thousand and fifteen dollars? That's a lot of money for a second-hand car.
B: But it's in excellent condition.
response: A: Could I try it out even though I want a new car?

dialogue: A: Good morning, mom.
B: Good morning, sweetie. You finally got up.
A: I'm still sleepy.
response: B: Did you stay up late last night ?

dialogue: A: Have you seen Mr. Li?
B: No, I haven't. Is he looking for me?
A: Yes, he is. He wants to talk to you.
B: To me? About what?
A: There's an opening in the sales department. He wants to talk to you about it.
B: Oh, that's great! What kind of this job is it?
A: He hasn't told me exactly. But it will be a better job than this.
B: Thank you for your help.
response: A: Don't thank me yet! He hasn't talked to you and he hasn't chosen you for the job yet.

dialogue: A: Hello! How do I get online with my laptop?
B: Just plug the Ethernet cable into your computer, and you'll be online in a heartbeat.
A: Well, I see the cable. But my computer runs on wireless only.
B: No problem. I'll tell you about our alternatives.
A: Yes, I'd love to hear what the alternatives are.
B: Our state-of-the-art computer lab is on the first floor.
A: Great! But is it free?
B: Sir, the computers are free to guests, but you do have to pay a nominal printing fee.
A: You said there were other alternatives?
B: Just use your computer here in the lobby. It's set up for wireless.
A: Okay. That sounds like a winner. Now if I need to print something in the lobby?
response: B: We might have a printer here next month . But for now , you'll have to go to the lab .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
B: Thanks, they are rather attractive. But I think there is nothing better than seeing things In actual operation.
A: Yes, of course. Would you like to make an inspection tour of some factories?
response: B: Yes , very much , if it wouldn't add inconvenience to you . Second hand information is always more valuable than reading pamphlets .

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
A: Yes, they spent about five hours putting it out. Hm, what a strange smell!
B: Oh, I forgot the food cooking on the fire!
response: A: Be quick!  Turn the gas up higher.  You shouldn't worry next time, otherwise you'd have our house on fire!

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
response: B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
response: B: But you should pay special attention to your hair and clothes.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
A: One moment while I go and get my ID.
B: Make it quick.
A: Okay, here's my ID and the $ 27.
response: B: Thanks . Now fill this out .

dialogue: A: Would you like another piece of chicken?
B: Yes, please. It's delicious. Did you cook it in Qianmen. How about some sandwiches?
A: Oh, no. It's Kentucky Fried Chicken. I bought it in Qianmen. How about some sandwiches?
B: Well, just one, please. Hmm, it's nice! You bought them in Kentucky Restau-rant al- so, didn't you?
response: A: Yes, I did. Let me give you some more salad and fruit. There's plenty more.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
response: B: Yeah. Now that the weather is getting cold, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.
A: Well whatever, can we repeat our offer to run the campaign for 4 extra weeks?

B: That's not really the point. The campaign missed two key trade affairs. Because of this, we are asking you either to repeat the campaign next year for free, or we only pay 50% of the fee for this year.
A: Could we suggest a 20% reduction to the fee together with the four week sustention to the campaign.
response: B: We are happy. We lost business.

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
response: B: Will you buy an exercise book for me?

dialogue: A: Have you booked the airplane tickets to spain yet?
B: Well, I thought we should go traveling by ship for a change, so I booked two ship tickets instead.
A: You should have told me or discussed it with me.
B: I wanted to give you a surprise. Don't you like the idea?
A: I like it all right, but it takes much more time to travel by ship than by plane.
B: We have time, don't we? Every time we went on a trip, we were always tied down by schedules. This time will be different. We don't have to rush.
A: You're right. This is our first trip since you retired. We can travel as long as we like.
B: We'll have an easy trip and enjoy every minute.
response: A: Have you bought your home bank's scrip yet?

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
response: A: No, what you need is balance.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?
response: B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.
A: I don't know how you keep on with it. It's too hard to become a doctor.
B: Well, you study a lot too. It doesn't seem any easier to become an engineer.
response: A: But at least it takes five extra years. I'll be out putting up the buildings while you're still a student here. By the way, can I help you with your study now?

dialogue: A: Excuse me,can I see the personnel manager? My name is Lucy Jordan.
B: Oh, yes. Have a scat, please.
A: Thank you. I come in answer to your ad for the saleswoman.
B: Okay, what qualifications do you have for the toy store work?
A: I once worked in a local toy store and my major is business administration.
B: Are you familiar with the toys for children?
response: A: Well, my nephew is 8 years old now and he always likes the toys I've bought for him.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
response: B: Well, walking is never a good exercise. How about sports?

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.
A: I don't know how you keep on with it. It's too hard to become a doctor.
B: Well, you study a lot too. It doesn't seem any easier to become an engineer.
response: A: But at least it doesn't take as long. I'll be out putting up the buildings while you're still a student here. By the way, can I help you with your study now?

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
A: Actually, it'll save you money.
B: Oh, really?
A: Because you can use your bus pass as many times as you want.
B: Really?
response: A: Yeah, and you never have to worry about scraping for change.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
B: Yes, of course. Shall we give her some flowers?
response: A: Flowers are lovely. But I think it's better to buy her a nice box of chocolates.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of beginning my own business.
A: That sounds great.
B: Yes, I think it over, but the problem is money. If I had enough money, I'd leave the bank tomorrow.
A: What are you going to do to solve the problem?
response: B: I'll deposit some money to a bank, of course, but not to the one I've been working for.

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite smart, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?
B: Yeah. Let's see if there's a larger size. Well, they don't seem to have anything larger.
response: A: Why don't we go and buy this coat from that salesgirl over there? I think she can help us.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
response: A: Then the truck was too slow to hit the taxi, wasn't it?

dialogue: A: Do you feel like going to the cinema?
B: Oh, yes. What kind of films do you like?

A: Well, I like all sorts of films, but my favorite sorts are those like Star Wars. You know, the fantasy, special effect ones that you can escape into another world. I also like mystery film, do you like mystery films?
B: Yes, but I don't like horror films because they really give me nightmares.
response: A: I don't like horror films either. They're sort of stupid and unbelievable. I do like crime films, you know, where you can follow the detective and try to guess who the murderer is.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
A: Why is a computer so useful?
response: B: It can keep much information and work very fast.

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Where were you at lunchtime? I was looking for you in the dining hall.
B: Oh, sorry, I missed you. My English class ran late again.
A: That's been happening quite often recently. Maybe it's because the final exams are coming up.
response: B: Yes. After class, there is always a group of students who leaves immediately. How about you? Are yon ready for the exams?

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
B: You're right. But I really had a happy vacation.
response: A: OK, Maybe you can move into Kelly's house and share that with her for a couple of months.

dialogue: A: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock.
B: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning.
A: Why? What's wrong with you?
B: I felt pain all over my body. Can you get me some medicine?
response: A: Will cyanide do?

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, Sir?
B: May I have the menu, please?
A: Yes, here you go.
B: I'd like to have some local specialties. Would you recommend for me, please?
A: Sure, the Huanghe carp with sugar and vinegar is famous in our restaurant.
B: OK. We'll take it.
A: Anything else?
B: A fried crisp chicken and an eggplant with chili sauce.
A: How about drink?
response: B: Coffee, only black coffee,

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.
response: B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were even for sale. The last one was on sale for $9,000.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
B: What for? For the party, of course.
A: Party? What party?
response: B: We ’ re having the Valentine ’ s Day off .

dialogue: A: What did you think of the lecture?
B: I thought it was very interesting.
A: Did you really?
B: Yes, didn't you?
A: Certainly not. I thought he talked a lot of rubbish.
B: So you think you know more than he does.
A: Well, take coal for instance.
B: What about it?
A: Coal won't become important again.
B: Why not?
response: A: It's too dirty. They won't be able to find people to work down coal mines in the future.

dialogue: A: : Excuse me. I'd like to find out about flights to New York.
B: an: Well, let's see. One just left about five minutes ago; and there's another one at ten.
A: : What time is it, please?
B: an: It's five to eight.
A: : So the plane leaves in about two hours.
B: an: That's right. Have you bought your ticket?
A: : No, I haven't, Can I buy one here?
response: B: an: I'm afraid you can't. You'd better go to the hooking office.

dialogue: A: Did you start your new job this week?
B: Yes, I did. I started it the day before yesterday.
A: How do you like your new job? And how about your boss?
B: Well, it's demanding, but it's very interesting. The boss seems to be very considerate. It is said that he is kind and friendly to the employees.
response: A: So you're fed up with the job, aren't you?

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
response: A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
response: B: Well, Ann, the tour a decade from now is not a race. People do it for laziness and fun and try to better their time every decade.

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
A: The Fools Garden is giving a performance today.
B: They are a pop group. They are said to be very good. What time does the performance start?
A: 7 P.m., will you be free then?
B: Yes, I'd like to go.
response: A: Let's stay home then.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
response: A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just became CEO from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.

dialogue: A: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please.
B: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me.
A: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today.
B: Oh, why? Is she ill?
A: No. She's studying for an exam.
B: An exam. Is she going to school?
A: Yes, she is. She's learning Japanese in night school.
response: B: I see. Are you going to night school, too?

dialogue: A: Bonjour!
B: What?
A: I said, Bonjour!
B: What ’ s wrong with you, Ted?
A: I ’ m speaking French. Don ’ t you know anything?
B: What ’ s wrong with speaking English?
A: Well, I just got back from my language school. We have to speak French all day there. No English allowed!
B: What are you doing that for?
response: A: I'm trying to learn less skills. It makes me less qualified for a good job.

dialogue: A: Are you planning on voting?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, but this will be my first time voting.
B: Really?
A: Yes, and I have no idea how to do it.
B: Voting is simple.
response: A: I don ’ t know any of the laws they ’ re trying to pass.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
response: A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.

dialogue: A: Has Alan shown up yet?
B: Nope. I guess something might have come up.
A: I wonder what happened.
B: I don't know. I hope it's nothing serious.
A: Last week his sister was admitted to the hospital.
B: Oh? What happened?
A: His sister had a car accident last week.
B: Is she fine now?
response: A: She is still in a coma .

dialogue: A: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please.
B: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me.
A: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today.
B: Oh, why? Is she ill?
A: No. She's studying for an exam.
B: An exam. Is she going to school?
response: A: Yes, she is. She's learning sobriety in night school.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
response: A: Yes, they spent about five hours putting it out. Hm, what a strange smell!

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
B: Buy an expensive suit.
response: A: Is a white shirt OK?

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
B: You can get wine and beer in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.
A: When do people go to the pubs?

B: Pubs are not open all day. They can decide when to open. Most are open for 3 or 4 hours at lunchtime and again from about 6:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m. In busy areas, pubs may stay open from 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. Are there pubs in China?
A: Yes. Most of the customers are young people. They like to hang out with their friends after work and have fun.
response: B: It is against the law in England to go into a pub if you are under the age of l4. So many pubs provide a special room for children.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy the restaurant?
B: I didn't really like it all that much.
A: What do you think the problem was?
B: Well, they are pretty new. I just didn't feel that they were ready to open yet.
A: How did you feel about the food?
B: The food wasn't all that exciting.
response: A: I don't think that the service was good, either.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
response: B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the Lost and Found Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!
A: You're not supposed to just copy the book.
B: Oh! I think Mr. Harper won't know.
A: He will know! He asked us to write a list of all the books we'd used. Remember? That's not the point anyway.
B: What is the point then?
response: A: Well, the point is that you're supposed to write your own project--you can't copy someone else's writing.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
response: B: All right, I'm going to need you to solve this riddle.

dialogue: A: Bob, I'm sure you know about second-hand smoke.
B: Of course, I do.
A: But have you heard about third-hand smoke?
B: Third-hand smoke? I'm afraid not. What is that then?

A: Well, it is here in today's paper. Parents may think they are protecting children from second-hand smoke when they smoke outside their home or only when the children are not there. But now researchers are warning about what they call third-hand smoke. When you smoke dangerous matter from cigarettes get into your hair and clothing. As babies are the weakest, when you come to a baby, you pass it to the baby and increase the chances of disease in the baby.
response: B: Is that so? In that case I have to say that I should get right up close to a baby.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
response: B: How about a new pillow?

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
B: I need to review my English.
A: So that's what keeps you so busy recently!
response: B: Yes, I've been really slacking on my studies. Now, what doesn't worry me at all is my English.

dialogue: A: Good morning, is this Ryan?
B: You are speaking with Ryan. How can I help you?
A: Ryan, this is Malia, and I need to call in sick today.
B: What seems to be the problem?
A: I went hiking and have terrible poison oak.
B: When did you get that?
A: I think I got it on Saturday, but it just showed up today.
B: What are you doing for it?
response: A: The vetranarian prescribed an ointment and gave me a shot .

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go swimming and cycling by myself.
A: Oh, I forgot about that. I go cycling sometimes too. And I often go swimming on vacation, but only recreational swimming.
B: Why don't you join me at the gym sometime?
response: A: Well, maybe someday, but I'm pretty proactive about things like that.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ms Thomas. What can I do for you?
B: Well, I've been having bad stomach pains lately, doctor.
A: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. How long have you been having them?
response: B: Just in the last few weeks. I get a very sharp pain about an hour after having meals.

dialogue: A: Are you free this Saturday evening?
B: Oh, it seems there is nothing that evening.
A: Would you like to go to the concert with me?
B: I'd like to, where?
response: A: At our club.

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: I would like an alarm clock that will awaken me with soft music.
A: In that case, you'll probably be interested in this handsome electric clock radio.
response: B: Actually, I'd like a massive and loud stereo system.

dialogue: A: Ahh... What a fine day! I do feel like an outdoor exercise.
B: How about taking a walk in the park?
A: OK. It's delightful to have a walk in the park with the air so fresh.
B: Oh, it's so quiet here. We have the park to ourselves, only you and me!
A: Don't you see many people over there? Just on your left.
response: B: Oh, I see them. Some are reading books, some are performing swordplay, some are practising the Chinese language.

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!
A: You're not supposed to just copy the book.
B: Oh! I think Mr. Harper won't know.
A: He will know! He asked us to write a list of all the books we'd used. Remember? That's not the point anyway.
B: What is the point then?
response: A: Well, the point is that you're supposed to copy your project from somebody else.

dialogue: A: Anything else, sir?
B: That's all for now. How much do I owe you?
A: That'll be fifty-five dollars and twenty cents.
B: Can't you make it a little cheaper?
response: A: Oh, no, sir. We already gave you a discount on each item.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mark. Are you in town for another job interview?
B: Yes, I'm pretty hopeful this time. I've just finished my second interview with this company.
A: That sounds great. I hope it works out for you. But wasn't it expensive just getting here?
response: B: No, in fact the company is not paying all my expenses. They've put me up in a hotel downtown.

dialogue: A: Dear, can you drive me to the clinic?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why?
B: Well, my car won't start. I don't know what's the matter with it.
A: Could it be the battery?
B: No, I don't think it could be. I checked the battery two days ago. It must be other problems.
response: A: Well, I suppose it could be the side mirror.

dialogue: A: Are there pets allowed in this apartment?
B: No dogs or cats or any other fur type animal, but other pets are allowed.
A: What about a boa constrictor?
B: Well... is that a pet? Isn't that something from the zoo?
A: If I had one, could I rent this apartment?
response: B: I was thinking of nice little pythons, kimodo dragons, alligators, or a crocodile.

dialogue: A: Did you hear the thunder last night?
B: Yes. I was awake at that time. It was really loud.
A: I didn't see any lightning though. I thought thunder and lightning always occur together.
B: What makes you believe that?
response: A: A science book says, when lightning quickly beats the air, it never causes thunder.

dialogue: A: Ahahah! What is that thing on your couch! It just moved!
B: Did you think it wasn't real? That's my pet lizard.
A: You have a pet lizard? Somehow I never would have imagined that.
B: His name is Grunt. Come closer and I'll properly introduce you.
A: Does it bite or scratch?
B: No, he's perfectly harmless. And he's not afraid of strangers either. Here, hold him.
A: Wow. He's heavy! And his skin feels really cool.
response: B: Stick around and you'll get to know him better. He has a very unusual pair of gills.

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
response: A: Nobody to take care of her?

dialogue: A: Did you get the injury playing football, Jim?
B: Yes. One of the boys kicked my foot instead of the ball.
A: The best thing for you to do is to rest your leg for 48 hours.
B: When can I go back to school?
response: A: You can go back in 4 days, but you'll need to avoid girls for a month.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
response: B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some rest instead of taking the bus all the time.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?

A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in a bit too much specialized information.
response: B: The main thing I object to is the lack of direction.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
response: B: I've only stopped studying night and day this last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
response: A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent an airplane because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
response: B: Uh, actually, you were right on time with the initial proposals so you have lots of time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Does this hotel have a fitness facility?
B: Yes, we try to accommodate all needs of our patrons, including fitness.
A: Where is your fitness facility located?
B: The gym is just below the lobby. Take the elevator or the stairs. You can't miss it.
A: Is there an additional surcharge for the gym?
B: No, the gym is free to guests. Take your room key, however, so you can get in.
A: What time is the gym open, and what time does it close?
B: The gym is open seven days a week, twenty-four hours a day.
A: Do you offer trainer services along with the gym?
response: B: Unfortunately , no . If you want a trainer , you'll have to use another gym .

dialogue: A: Are you a happy married man?
B: Yes, I am. My wife and I understand each other.
A: You are a lucky man. How about Mr. Smith.
B: I don't know. But they say that Mrs. Smith wears the pants in the house.
A: You mean she bosses her husband around?
response: B: That's right. She is pretty, but she wants to completely give up all control in his life.

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Where were you at lunchtime? I was looking for you in the dining hall.
B: Oh, sorry, I missed you. My English class ran late again.
A: That's been happening quite often recently. Maybe it's because the final exams are coming up.
response: B: No. After class, there is always a group of students hanging around the school talking. How about you? Are you ready for the exams?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I'd like to pay my bill.
A: OK. In cash or by credit?
response: B: In cash . How much is the total charge ?

dialogue: A: Am I late?
B: No, you've got an hour and a quarter. Your flight leaves at 9:30.
A: I'm so excited.
B: Have you got everything?
response: A: Yes, my tickets and my traveler's checks.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some gloves.
A: All our gloves are here. What do you think of this pair here? It's made of silk.
B: Hm, it looks nice, but I'd like to have something warm for the winter.
A: Maybe you would like heavy wool gloves. How about this pair?
B: I think that's what I want. How much is it?
A: It's... forty dollars.
response: B: It's a little cheap.  Do you think it's possible to increase the price?

dialogue: A: Dad, how do you say this word?
B: Sword, say it ' sword '.
A: What does this word mean?
B: Look it up in the dictionary.
A: Dad, can you just tell me what it means? I'm too lazy.
response: B: No, honey, go and read it. You'll forget it.

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
A: You must be mad. I think it's really...you know...so easy to buy everything in one place.
B: Yes, it's easy. But don't you think the food isn't...I mean small shops usually have much fresher food.
A: Maybe, but you pay for it. Small shops are more expensive, aren't they?
response: B: Yes, I agree with you, but supermarket staff are badly paid and they are really...but you get better service in small shops. They are much more short tempered.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
A: However,you must show us the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?
B: OK.
response: A: All right. Keep your receipt. If something comes up. you can show it to us and We'll give you another one.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. Is anybody taking care of you?
B: No, not yet. Could you show me that overcoat, the silver gray one in the middle.
A: Certainly. You've got excellent taste. It's very nice and it's 100 percent wool.
B: I like it. Could I try it on?
A: Certainly. It looks good on you, madam.
B: I think so. But a slightly larger size would be better.
A: Would you like to try this one on?
B: This one fits me well. How much does it cost?
A: Only $ 170.
B: OK, I'll take it. And I'd like that blue jacket on the right. How much is it?
A: It's just $ 250.
response: B: Oh, that's too cheap, I'm afraid.

dialogue: A: Hello? I would like to speak to Mr. Lee.
B: This is Lee speaking.
A: This is Linda, your old friend.
B: Oh, how are you, Linda? I'm glad you called.
A: Mr. Smith wrote to me that you were coming to our city. May I see you at your hotel right away?
B: Please hold on a moment. I have to check my schedule. Yes, that's ail fight.
A: Great. I'll be there in haft an hour.
B: All right, I'll be expecting you.
A: Oh, I almost forgot. What's your room number?
response: B: It's the No. 311 on the second floor. Please don't bother calling me if you can't find me.

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
response: A: Actually, it'll save you money.

dialogue: A: Were you born in Los Angeles?
B: No. I was born in Chicago as a matter of fact.
A: Oh, were you?
B: Yeah, I grew up in the suburbs, in Wilmette, and then I moved out here when I was fourteen.
A: So you went to high school here?
B: Yeah, that's right. I graduated from Lincoln High.
A: And then you went to college?
B: No, not exactly. First I went to Europe.
response: A: Oh. To travel?

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
A: And what would you like to have for the main course
B: Shrimp salad. And what kind of pie do you have?
A: Apple, banana and strawberry pie.
B: Then a piece of apple pie, please.
A: And what would you like for dessert?
response: B: Icecream, please.

dialogue: A: Alison, would you like to have some more?
B: No, thanks. I've had enough.
A: Actually you haven't had much.
B: To tell you the truth, I am on a diet.
A: That sounds ridiculous. Why?
response: B: Well, I am not gaining weight these days, and I don't have to watch my calories.

dialogue: A: Are you free this Saturday evening?
B: Oh, it seems there is nothing that evening.
A: Would you like to go to the concert with me?
B: I'd like to, where?
response: A: At the police station

dialogue: A: Mr. Block, I need to take a few days off because my parents are coming over to visit.
B: But it's not really a good idea to take time off right now, you know.
A: Well, I know. But they've never been to the UK before and they don't speak English.
B: Hmm, you know there are thousands of tourists in London who can't speak English and they manage to get around.
response: A: Yes, I know but they really expect me to be there. It's culture. Chinese parents expect their children to do things like this.

dialogue: A: Can I help you, Madam?
B: Yes, I'd like to exchange some US dollars into RIB.
A: How much would you like to exchange?
B: What's the exchange rate for RIB?
A: It's US 100 for RIB 802 today.
B: I'd like to exchange 3,000.
A: Fill out this exchange memo, please.
B: Yes. Here you are.
response: A: Wait a second, please... These are 24,060 RIB and the receipt, please check them.

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
response: A: You mean you know how to farm?

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
response: B: But I didn't hear it at all.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Uncle Smith.
B: Good morning, Cathy.
A: I want to have a dinner party to celebrate my birthday. Would you come?
B: I'd love to, Cathy. What time?
A: Next weekend, on Saturday.
B: Saturday do you say?
A: If that's all right with you.
response: B: I'm afraid I'm coming early.  I have no plans.

dialogue: A: Are you enjoying your trip to New Orleans?
B: Oh, yes. I really like it here.
A: Would you like to do something tonight?
B: Sure. I'd love to.
A: Let's see. Have you been to a jazz club yet?
B: Yes. I've already been to several clubs here.
A: OK. What about an evening riverboat tour?
B: Uh, actually, I've gone twice this week.
A: So, what do you want to do?
B: Well, I haven't been to the theater in a long time.
A: Oh, OK. I hear there's a terrific show at the Sanger Theater.
response: B: Great! Let's make a reservation for the jazz club.

dialogue: A: Drive slowly, David. You could have an accident.
B: You can count on me. I have been driving for years.
A: Look out! Red light!
response: B: It doesn't matter. It is late. There are tons of people around.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy the restaurant?
B: I didn't really like it all that much.
A: What do you think the problem was?
response: B: Well, they are pretty new. But I feel they were ready to open.

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
B: You had pretty bad scores.
A: Exactly what do you mean by bad?
B: You failed.
A: How'd I fail it?
B: There are a couple of reasons why you didn't pass.
A: What did I do wrong?
response: B: To sum it all up, you are the best driver I've ever seen.

dialogue: A: Hello, Macy Agency.
B: Good morning. I'd like to book a return ticket from London to Paris on Monday, July 14th, please.
A: Yes, Madam. We have a flight at 14: 30, Is that suitable?
B: Oh, that's fine. And how much will that cost, please?
A: The price is $ 420 for the return flight.
B: Good. Which airport does the flight leave from?
response: A: It leaves from Heathrow Airport. Check in time at the hotel is one hour before departure.

dialogue: A: Welcome back home, darling. Did you have a good time?
B: Yes, wonderful. Why, Jack, the house looks as if you have also been away,
A: Why do you say that?
response: B: Look at the clean plates, cups, shirts everywhere.

dialogue: A: We are going to put on a performance.
B: Really? When?
A: On May 4. We have been preparing for it for two months.
B: Where are you going to put it on? In your school?
A: No. At the People's Theatre.
B: If I remember correctly, you put it on at the Youth Square last year.
A: Yeah. But it is under repair now.
B: But why are you doing that? To collect money for repairing the Youth Square?
response: A: No. We want to collect money and send it to Project Hope.

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
B: But you should pay special attention to your words and attitudes.
A: In the beginning of the interview, greet the interviewer with a kind smile.
B: In the interview, use polite words, such as ' Thank you ', or ' Please '.
A: That's right. Details can mean succeed or fail.
B: When talking you should focus your eyes on the interviewer in order to closely watch his or her expressions.
A: At the end of the interview, you should make your acknowledgements and say Goode.
B: Whatever the result is, you should keep your good demeanor.
response: A: This will ensure that you won't leave a good impression on the interviewer .

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
B: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
response: A: No , please , Mom ! Don't make me gargle with vinegar!

dialogue: A: Tom, look at your shoes. How dirty they are! You must clean them.
B: Oh, mum, but I cleaned them only yesterday.
A: They are dirty now. You must clean them again.
response: B: I do not want to clean them today. Even if I don't clean them today, they will be clean tomorrow

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
response: A: So it doesn't really hold your temper?

dialogue: A: Hi, Kathy, it's Jason.
B: Hi, Jason. I haven't heard from you in a while.
A: Well. I've been busy. I've started my own company.
B: Wow, what kind of business is it?
A: Just a small on-line store. I am hiring staff and I want you to come to work for me.
B: Actually, I just got started working at the old company again.
response: A: Oh, I didn't realize you were going back. Well, can you recommend some movies?

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
response: B: Then, you should dress informally.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
response: B: How nice! How many apartments does it have?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
response: B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a white house. The Kid's Reading Room is inside it.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
response: B: Thanks , they are rather attractive . But I think there is nothing better than seeing things when they're not in operation.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
response: A: I'm afraid there isn't any more tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
B: The music group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?
A: It's on the wall, madam, on the blackboard.
response: B: Indeed. I suppose you can't afford cheap menus.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
B: I caught hold of his knife, and he pushed me to the floor.
A: Oh, no! Why did you catch hold of his knife? That's dangerous.
B: I don't know. I didn't think.
A: And what did the other passengers do? Did they help you?
response: B: Yes, they did. Two men ran after the robber and held him.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
response: B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through the stormy weather, but I keep drifting away.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
A: I can take you home. Would you like a ride?
response: B: Yes. Thanks a lot. Could you stop at the chemist's on the way? I need to buy some medicine.

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
response: B: I did. I called you many times, but you had your mobile phone power off.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ms Thomas. What can I do for you?
B: Well, I've been having bad stomach pains lately, doctor.
A: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. How long have you been having them?
response: B: Just in the last few weeks. I get a quick call about an hour after having meals.

dialogue: A: Where is Jimmy? Why hasn't he come down for breakfast? Needn't he go to school today?
B: He's still in bed in his room.
A: What's the matter with our dear son?
response: B: He's feeling great. I think he must have had a nightmare.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.
A: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of strong and comfortable shoes.
B: What's your suggestion?
response: A: Maybe you should buy him a pair of tight shoes.

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
response: B: He doesn't work in an office. He never writes letters or reports, or types.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. What can I do for you?
B: I want some coffee.
A: Certainly, madam. What kind of coffee do you want to have?
B: What have you got?
response: A: Well . We have espresso , latte , skinny latte , fancy coffee and Americano .

dialogue: A: Hello, School of English Studies.
B: Hello, I saw your advertisement in the newspaper. Can you give me some information, please?
A: Yes, of course. What would you like to know?
B: Well, first, how long are the courses?
A: They are 6 or 9 months long and the next course begins next Monday.
B: How many students will there be in the class? Not too many, I hope.
A: Usually, there are 15. We find that a good number.
response: B: OK. Now, I saw the price of the course in the newspaper, but will I have to pay for anything else?

dialogue: A: Have you seen the job in the newspaper?
B: Do you mean the one in Manchester?
A: Yes.
B: I saw it just now.
A: What do you think of it?
B: I think I'm not the type of man to do it.
A: Why do you think so?
response: B: They need an engineer to take care of the machine and I don't even know anything about that kind of machine.

dialogue: A: Hi, Nicole. Did you have a good weekend?
B: Yes, I did. But I feel tired today.
A: Really? Why?
response: B: Well , on Saturday I admired the house and played tennis video games . Then on Sunday I drove in the country .

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
A: Where are you living now?
response: B: Near the office. It's a quick trip to work every day.

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
B: No. Just occasionally.
A: What are your favourite dances?
B: I love rumba and waltz.
response: A: How about violin?

dialogue: A: Could I have a word with you, Madam?
B: Is that you, Janice? Just speaking.
A: I have to tell you that I can't be in today and tomorrow.
B: So sorry to hear that. What's wrong with you?
A: I feel sick and coughed a lot at night.
B: Is that serious? You ought to see a doctor.
A: Yes, I did this in the morning. And my doctor wanted me to have a rest these two days.
B: That's good. Do you suppose you will be back at company the day after tomorrow?
A: I hope so. And I will definitely tell you if I can not.
response: B: Well, take care of yourself. And hope you will get worse as soon as possible.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
response: A: Well , some people decided to loot last night .

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
response: B: I'm glad winter is over. I like autumn best.

dialogue: A: Be careful.The floor is slippery.
B: Mom, there isn't any hot water
A: Turn on the shower.
B: It's getting cold.
response: A: Ok. I'll check the heater. Dry yourself with the towel first.

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
response: B: Well, there's an ice cream shop on the next corner. It serves good food.

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
response: B: I'm going to try to find a school near the office.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you know where I can find a pay phone?
B: There is one around the corner.
A: Can I make an international call from that pay phone?
response: B: Yes, but you have to get a phone card first.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
response: B: Oh, all right. Well, we could rent a cell phone video and watch that.

dialogue: A: Are you free this evening, Li?
B: I ’ m afraid I ’ m busy tonight. I ’ m having dinner with friends.
A: What a pity. I wanted to go for a drink with you.
B: What about tomorrow? Are you doing anything tomorrow?
response: A: No, I have some plans.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
response: B: Then I'd like to demand a pineapple pie.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: Yes, I am.
A: Is this your first year in college?
