B: I actually transferred here from another school.
A: Which school?
response: B: I transferred from PCC.

dialogue: A: Are you free this evening, Li?
B: I ’ m afraid I ’ m busy tonight. I ’ m having dinner with friends.
A: What a pity. I wanted to go for a drink with you.
B: What about tomorrow? Are you doing anything tomorrow?
A: No, I haven ’ t got any plans.
response: B: Shall we go out tomorrow then?

dialogue: A: Today in the studio we have Alberto Cortez, the well-known Brazilian advocate of the anti-global movement. He's here to talk about the recent report, stating that by 2050 Brazil will be the one ot the word's wealthiest and most successful countries. Alberto, what do you say to the report?
B: You know this isn't the first time that people are saying Brazil will be a great economic power. The same thing was said over a hundred year ago. But it didn't happen.
A: Yes, but you must admit the world's a very different place now.
B: Of course. In fact I believe there's maybe some truth in the prediction this time around. First of all, though, we must remember the problems facing Brazil at the moment.
A: Such as...?
response: B: There's an enormous gap between the rich and the poor in this country. In Sal Paulo, you can see shopping malls full of designer goods right next door to the slam areas without proper water and electricity supplies. A lot of work needs to be done to help people in those areas improve their lives.

dialogue: A: Did you have your television repaired?
B: Yes, but not by the place you recommended
A: Why not? The repair is very good and thecharges are so reasonable.
B: That may be, but I couldn't find it.
A: But you couldn't miss it. I told you the first right after the railroad bridge.
B: I took that. I went to the end of the road. There is no such a place.
response: A: Wait a minute. Perhaps it is the second right. Yes. I think it is.

dialogue: A: Hello, Jane. This is Peter speaking.
B: Hi, how are you?
A: Fine. And I've got some great news for you.
B: Really? What's it about?
A: I remember you are interested in watching golf games. The Houston Open will be running from May 26 to May 30. I'm sure you will be glad to watch the game.
B: Oh, that's great. But just a moment, let me check. Ah... It is a pity that I can't make it. I will be on business in China from May 25 to June 2.
response: A: Well, I'm sorry you have to be away on business then. Let me see. Another game, the US Open will be running from July 15 to July 18. How about that?

dialogue: A: Are you busy with your work?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, I'm very busy, too. Sometimes I work overtime.
B: Then your salary must be high.
response: A: Just so so. But we can't travel during the year.

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
A: The Fools Garden is giving a performance today.
B: They are a pop group. They are said to be very good. What time does the performance start?
A: 7 P.m., will you be free then?
B: Yes, I'd like to go.
response: A: Let's not go together then.

dialogue: A: Do you want to go for a picinc with me tomorrow?
B: I'd like to. How about asking Jenny to go with us?
A: Oh, no. She is busy with her dancing class. You know, there is a very big performance in just a week.
B: Yes, you're right. It is really not good for her to learn dancing. Her leg hasn't completely recovered from that accident.
A: But she doesn't think so. She is crazy about dancing. Will you take your camera with you tomorrow?
response: B: I want to, but I got it from Tom yesterday. Do you have one ?

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
response: B: I'm going to try to find a store near the office.

dialogue: A: Welcome to this idition of writers. Tonight we have Steven Das with us. Congratulations on your book. It's such a success.
B: Thank you.
A: This is your first time to that poetry? Did you ever try before? Did you ever take any classes in poetry?

B: Well. My only real experience was writing business plans. Other than that. I've experience. We're writing with concerned. I've always had the good grass of the writing with the English language. Thanks to my mom who studied my reading when I was very little.
A: What's the hardest thing that in the world?
B: Definitely finding the perfect words to fit what I wanted to say. There're always work word two that I might to rewrite if given the chance.
A: Was there be more collections of poetry from Daisy?
response: B: There will be more something that surprise. But maybe not poetry. I really don't see myself as a poet. Rather, I'd see what I wrote this kind of writing. that might discourage people in someway.

dialogue: A: Are you leaving?
B: I ’ m going to work.
A: You have a job?
B: I ’ m going to work at the polling place.
A: You ’ re working there this year?
B: I work there every year.
A: How are you able to work at the polling place?
response: B: I applied for the job online.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.
B: No, I think we must have disturbed them. They must have heard us coming and got out of the bathroom window quickly.
response: A: Yes, well, hurry up. We'd better phone the doctor

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a white house. The General Reading Room is inside it.
response: A: No wonder! It's always been here! Thank you very much.

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.
A: I got it now. On the last line, I write the city it's going to and the district, right?
response: B: Don't forget to write the same address in the upper - left corner in the same manner as the sending address.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
A: Your son's fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.
B: Yes, that's right. As soon as you've done what's necessary for buying the land, Jerry and I will see an architect.
A: Have you found a plot yet?
B: Jerry was in Edinburgh last Saturday and saw a plot he likes. My wife and I went there two days ago, and we liked it, too. I'd like you to make the necessary inquiries for me.
response: A: I'd be pleased to do that. I shall have to write to the Post office and inquire whether it is allowed to build a house on your piece of land. You're not allowed to build a house without permission from the Tracking Authority. And sometimes the Authority decides that a house must be built of stone, and not of brick, so that it doesn't spoil the surrounding village.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
A: Why is a computer so useful?
response: B: It can keep little information and work very slowly.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I have a pet? I did what you said and passed all of my exams.
B: Then I guess you get to have a pet. Do you know what you want?
A: I want a dog. My friend Mindy's dog just had puppies and she said I can have one.
response: B: You know who will be responsible for feeding and cleaning and all of that stuff?

dialogue: A: How come David is always so full of energy?
B: He has a strange but highly effective way of sleeping.
A: What is that?
response: B: He takes no sleep for an hour every six hours and has a total of four hours of sleep each day.

dialogue: A: I need a summer job that will give me some exercise.
B: How about being a life guard?
A: Life guards don't swim that much. They usually just sit.
B: Well then, you could be a swimming coach, or a tour guide.
response: A: Tour guide is a good idea. I'd sit all day.

dialogue: A: : Hey, hey, neighbor. What are you doing with my trees? My wife planted that tree 25 years ago. Get off that ladder.

B: ghbor: Listen. Even though the trees are in your yard, some of the branches hang over into mine, and I am getting sick and tired of raking up your leaves and picking up all the branches that fall off during storms throughout the year. And the walnuts off this tree... they litter my yard and damage my lawnmower when I cut the grass. And my dog eats them, and he ends up with terrible diarrhea.
A: : Still. You can't cut off those branches.
B: ghbor: Watch me. It's completely legal. I check the city code and law regarding this issue, and I am well within my rights.
A: : I'm not sure about that. Anyway, It's just not right. You didn't say anything to us about it...
B: ghbor: I don't have to.
A: : Yeah, but you could have said something. Anything! I mean I want to stay on friendly terms with you, but the basic courtesy of informing your neighbors is the least you could have done.
B: ghbor: Okay. I'm cutting down your branches. You've been informed... now, stand back!
response: A: Hey. Keep your eye out for an invitation to our next barbecue or book club!

dialogue: A: Have you gone to school today?
B: I went to school today. Did you go to school?
A: I couldn't go to school today, I was sick.
B: That's horrible. I'd be happy to give you the assignments from English class.
A: Thank you very much, that's kind of you.
B: Don't mention it.
A: When you miss a day of school, I'll be happy to give you the English assignments.
response: B: That is greatly appreciated and I hope you feel well enough to go to school tomorrow .

dialogue: A: Have you taken the written test yet?
B: No, I haven't.
A: You should study before you take it.
B: I have been studying.
A: Why don't you take the test?
B: Do you know if it costs any money to take it?
A: Since you already paid for your permit, you don't have to pay again.
B: All right. Do you know if the test covers the whole book?
A: No, the test skips a lot of things in the book.
B: Did you pass it the first time that you took it?
A: No, I didn't, because it was pretty hard.
response: B: Well , I hope that I do well .

dialogue: A: Hello, Lucy. When are you going off to Beijing?
B: This evening.
A: How are you getting there, by air or by train?
B: By train. It leaves at 5:00 and arrives in Beijing at 7:10 tomorrow morning.
response: A: Oh, only 14 hours. Is anybody chasing you off this evening?

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time every year.
A: How long will it take to cycle one way, Robin?
B: About seven to nine hours for the average cyclists. Good cyclists can do it in four hours.
A: How many people will be taking part this year?
response: B: This is our biggest year ever. We have twelve hundred snowboarders registered.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
B: She's very fond of detective stories?
A: I see. Has she read any detective stories?
B: Oh, yes!
A: Do you know if she's read this one?
B: I'm not sure, but she probably won't remember if she has! She's very forgetful!
response: A: Ah ! She has a great memory . How old is she ?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, what did you say you would like to do, Mr Green?
B: I said I'd better go back to the hotel. I'm meeting someone this evening.
A: OK, how are you going back? By bus or taxi?
B: I think I'd take a taxi. Do you know where I can get one?
A: Oh, just wait by the roadside. I'll wait with you.
B: OK, thanks. Are the taxis in London all black?
response: A: Well, some of them are. Is this your first time in London?

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.
A: No. But you must admit that on the big screen, it looked great.
B: Well, I think it would have been just as good as seeing it at home.
A: Ah, But it won't be on video till next year.
response: B: I can't wait that long.

dialogue: A: Did you have your television repaired?
B: Yes, but not by the place you recommended
A: Why not? The repair is very good and thecharges are so reasonable.
B: That may be, but I couldn't find it.
A: But you couldn't miss it. I told you the first right after the railroad bridge.
B: I took that. I went to the end of the road. There is no such a place.
A: Wait a minute. Perhaps it is the second right. Yes. I think it is.
B: I should have known. Whenever someone says "You can't miss it", you can be sure that you won't find it.
response: A: I'm really sorry for my bad memory.

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
response: B: Well , you do that when your nose needs blowing . I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster .

dialogue: A: Welcome to this idition of writers. Tonight we have Steven Das with us. Congratulations on your book. It's such a success.
B: Thank you.
A: This is your first time to that poetry? Did you ever try before? Did you ever take any classes in poetry?

B: Well. My only real experience was writing business plans. Other than that. I've experience. We're writing with concerned. I've always had the good grass of the writing with the English language. Thanks to my mom who studied my reading when I was very little.
A: What's the hardest thing that in the world?
B: Definitely finding the perfect words to fit what I wanted to say. There're always work word two that I might to rewrite if given the chance.
A: Was there be more collections of poetry from Daisy?
response: B: There will be more something that surprise. But maybe not poetry. I really don't see myself as a poet. Rather, I'd see what I wrote this kind of writing. that might de-motivate people in someway.

dialogue: A: My mother got really annoyed with my father yesterday evening.
B: Why? Did she complain about his cooking?
A: Oh no. It was about watching television.
response: B: Don't tell me he was wide awake in front of the television.

dialogue: A: Hello! Do you have a place where I can exercise?
B: Yes, sir. We have a fine exercise facility.
A: I'm happy to hear that. Now, would you tell me where it is?
B: You're actually standing above it. Just take the elevator or stairs down one level.
A: Is the hotel going to charge me a dollar a minute for gym use?
response: B: No , sir . There's no extra charge . All you need is your room key to open the door .

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
B: You're right. But I really had a happy vacation.
response: A: OK, Maybe you can buy Kelly's house and share that with her for a couple of months.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
A: May I borrow your pen?
B: Here's a pen for you.
A: Thanks for your help.
response: B: You need to turn that in at Window B.

dialogue: A: When did you become interested in collecting stamps?
B: Oh, when I was about ten years old.
A: Ten years old? So you have loved it for 9 years.
response: B: Yeah, it's really an exciting hobby. You know, the first postage stamps were issued in Britain in 1840.

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
B: You did? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered.
response: A: Oh , the telephone lines were damaged by the storm . They repaired them yesterday .

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
response: B: Well, I use it to send e-mails a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself French program. And I shop online pretty often.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is not in at the moment.
B: When will he come in, do you know?
A: I suppose he won't be in until 12: 00.
response: B: May I leave a message?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
response: B: I won't charge you for the tip today.

dialogue: A: What topic did you finally choose for the term paper for your World Economy class?
B: After thinking about a few ideas, I finally settled on the difference between Japanese and American styles of management.
A: Hmm. Why did you choose a topic like that?
B: Well, I'm planning to study Business in graduate school next year. After that, I hope to start my own company.
A: Isn't that a coincidence! I'm also doing a paper on how Japanese management styles are being adapted by American firms for my Comparative Cultures class.
response: B: Why don't we sit down and share some of our sandwiches after we've each been to the library?

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
B: We thought we'd have that at head office and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.
A: Ok. What sort of things would you like?
response: B: Just a lunch with steak and lobster I think, so that people can eat while they move around and talk to each other. You did some thing similar for us last year. We'd be happy to have the same menu again.

dialogue: A: Hello. Matt White speaking.
B: Hello, Dr. White, my name's Pan Johnson. My roommate, Janet Holmes, wanted me to call you.
A: Janet Holmes? Oh, that's right. She's in my Shakespearean English class. Has anything happened to her?

B: Nothing, it's just that she submitted a job application yesterday and the company asked her in for an interview today. She's afraid she won't be able to attend your class this afternoon. I'm calling to see whether it would be OK if I gave you her essay.
A: Certainly, that would be fine. Uh, you can either drop it off at my class or bring it to my office.
B: Would it be all right to come by your office around 4:00? I'm afraid I can't come any earlier because I have three classes this afternoon.
A: Uh, I won't be here when you come. I'm supposed to be at a meeting from 3:00 to 6:00, but how about leaving it with my secretary? She usually stays until 5:00.
response: B: 00. And Dr. White, one more thing, could you tell me where your office is? Janet told me where your class is, but she didn't give me directions to your mom's nursing home.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, could you tell me where the post office is?
B: Post office? It's not far from here. Do you know Xinhua Road?
A: I'm from the United States and this is my first trip to your city. I know nothing about the city.
B: Oh, welcome to our city, I'll show you the road. Please follow me.
A: Thanks, by the way, where can I buy a map of the city?
response: B: Just at the gate of the post office. Look, the post office is just across the street.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
response: B: Yes, of course.  Shall we give her a bill?

dialogue: A: How is the weather today?
B: It's very hot and humid.
A: Quite different from the forecast.
B: The weather changes often at this time of the year. It's possible to cool down in the late afternoon.
A: How are the summers here generally?
response: B: They are usually hot and rainy.

dialogue: A: Hello. Milton Hotel. Can I help you?
B: I want a reservation. Can I have it now?
A: Of course. What kind of taste do you like for your dinner?
B: I prefer Chinese dishes.
A: Would you like to sit in a smoking section, a non-smoking section or an open one?
B: A non-smoking section.
response: A: I'm awfully sorry, but we haven't got the section left now. Would you like to wait for a while?

dialogue: A: (Sniffing) Phew! Is that French coffee?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that French coffee you are drinking?
B: Yes,that's right. Why? What's the matter?
response: A: I don't understand why you drink French juice. It makes a strong smell.

dialogue: A: Are there pets allowed in this apartment?
B: No dogs or cats or any other fur type animal, but other pets are allowed.
A: What about a boa constrictor?
B: Well... is that a pet? Isn't that something from the zoo?
A: If I had one, could I rent this apartment?
response: B: I was more thinking of nice little fish or frogs or turtles or a pet rock.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote this Tuesday?
B: Yes, I am, and I am so excited.
A: Have you figured out who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I love my candidate.
A: Why is that?
response: B: My candidate is probably the most lacking in intelligence.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. but I think you made a wrong turn. You are supposed to turn left on Rosen Boulevard.
B: Oh. I'm sorry. Didn't you say 1323 Willson?
A: No, 3023. It's OK though. You don't have to take me there, I can walk from here.
B: Why don't I just make a U turn at the corner?
A: Well, you shouldn't make a U turn there. It's the one-way, street. See the sign up the head?
B: Well, maybe if I turn left here I can comedown the next street,
response: A: You can't do that either during the rush hour. Really though, don't go to any trouble. Sometimes one can wait 30 minutes for a taxi. So I'm happy to get this close,

dialogue: A: Did you check the internet for next week's weather forecast?
B: I sure did. You're in luck! It's supposed to snow all week in the mountains!
A: Yes! Somebody up there loves me! I knew it wasn't too late for snow.
B: It is kind of strange though, to have snow in April, and so much of it.
A: There have been so many dry winters lately that it's about time, don't you think?
B: When you put it that way, I guess the skies can't hold out on us forever.
response: A: This will be the best water ski trip I've ever taken. I can't wait to use my new hoard.

dialogue: A: Hi! Can I help you?
B: Hi! Have you got any records of modern guitar music?
A: We've got a lot of them. Which one are you looking for?
B: I'm looking for some records of Julian Bream. I saw them in your window last week and I had them before in Canada, but I broke them.
A: What happened?
B: They were in my bag. I sat on my bag and broke the records. My sister told me about your shop. I came here last week and saw the records.
A: Let's look for the records. Oh, yes, the records are there on the shelf.
B: How much are those three?
A: They are four pounds and fifty pence.
response: B: Here is five pounds.

dialogue: A: Are you OK?
B: Yeah. Why not?
A: Because... I heard John got married yesterday.
response: B: Oh, you went to the divorce court?

dialogue: A: What are you doing here?
B: I'm preparing my fishing tools.
A: What for?
response: B: I'm going to sing with some of my friends.

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.
B: Actually, I like it very much.
A: I'm glad you enjoy it. Let me serve you some more fish.
response: B: No, thank you. I've had enough fish, but I'd like some snapper.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
B: They really started looting?
response: A: Yes, apparently no stores were broken into.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
A: Oh? Who's she calling?
B: She's calling her boyfriend.
A: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
B: He hasn't been home yet...Why? You're asking a lot of questions tonight, Paul.
response: A: Am I?...Well, I'm practicing my Spanish.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the job in the newspaper?
B: Do you mean the one in Manchester?
A: Yes.
B: I saw it just now.
A: What do you think of it?
B: I think I'm not the type of man to do it.
A: Why do you think so?
response: B: They need a ballerina to take care of the machine and I don't even know anything about that kind of machine.

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
A: Where are you living now?
B: Out in the suburbs. It's a long trip to work every day.
A: How are you going to find an apartment?
response: B: I'm going to buy a newspaper and check the classified ads.

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
response: B: You can get wine and beer in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. I just received my telephone bill, and there's a problem with it.
B: May I see your bill, please?
A: Certainly. There it is. On July 1st, I really don't know anybody in Finland.
response: B: OK, don't worry. I'll take the call off. Let's see...it was $42. Your bill was $ 66.10, minus $42, so your new total is $24.10. I'm very happy about the mistake.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. I just received my telephone bill, and there's a problem with it.
B: May I see your bill, please?
A: Certainly. There it is. On July 1st, I really don't know anybody in Finland.
response: B: OK, don't worry. I'll take the call off. Let's see...it was $42. Your bill was $ 66.10, minus $42, so your new total is $24.10. I'm very sorry about the mistake.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order? May I suggest a veal.
B: No, I'll have the fish please.
A: The chicken is also nice.
B: No, I want the fish.
response: A: Our special tonight is lobster.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon! Dr. Perkins' office.
B: Good afternoon. I'd like to speak to the doctor. Is he in?
A: Who is that calling, please?
B: My name is Li Hong. I'm from China.
A: I'm sorry. Dr. Perkins is now at an important meeting and can't answer your call.
response: B: I'm an exchange scholar. Dr. Perkins asked me to give a lecture. There are some details I want to discuss with him.

dialogue: A: Acknowledgments play a necessary part in the interview.
B: Sure. Kind acknowledgments can show one's good attainment.
A: We often ignore the acknowledgments in our daily life, and consider them as disposable.
B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a good impression on others, especially in the public places.
A: We should particularly pay attention to acknowledgments in the interview.
B: In the beginning of the interview, it is best that you make acknowledgments for the opportunity of the interview.
A: Don't forget to say " Thank you " when you take a seat.
B: Make acknowledgments as well when the interviewer thinks highly of your dressing, experience, or words.
A: You can win a good impression of the interviewer in this way.
B: Acknowledgments can also help the job-hunters to show their good attainment.
A: Finally, at the end of the interview, make acknowledgments to the interviewer again.
response: B: Smiles and kind attitudes are the basics of deceptive interviewees.

dialogue: A: What's the matter, Bill? You look kind of pale.
B: Oh, I'm just tired.
A: Why?
response: B: Well, I've been working one hour until around ten every night this week.

dialogue: A: Hello, Michelle. How are you feeling today?
B: Hi, Dr. Frank. I am not feeling very well. That is why I made an appointment with you.
A: I am sorry to hear that. What seems to be the trouble?
response: B: My head has been generating ideas a lot lately. I never used to feel like this.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
A: If I were you, I'd say sorry to her first and then get her another cat.
response: B: That's a good idea. But I don't have.., enough money.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
response: A: How great! Was he hurt?

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
response: B: Yes, of course. I don't want to mark my desk.

dialogue: A: Drive slowly, David. You could have an accident.
B: You can count on me. I have been driving for years.
A: Look out! Red light!
B: It doesn't matter. It is late. There is no one around.
response: A: Don't let the police catch you. Oh, David, that's a policeman. He is waving over us.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. I just received my telephone bill, and there's a problem with it.
B: May I see your bill, please?
A: Certainly. There it is. On July 1st, I really don't know anybody in Finland.
response: B: OK, don't worry. I'll take the tax off. Let's see...it was $42. Your bill was $ 66.10, minus $42, so your new total is $24.10. I'm very sorry about the mistake.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
response: A: Two weeks. So you no longer have headaches!

dialogue: A: 911. What can I do for you?
B: I am reporting a break-in.
A: When did it happen?
response: B: It happened last night.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
response: B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep analyzing each page.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time every year.
A: How long will it take to cycle one way, Robin?
B: About seven to nine hours for the average cyclists. Good cyclists can do it in four hours.
A: How many people will be taking part this year?
B: This is our biggest year ever. We have twelve hundred cyclists registered.
A: I doubt they'll block the road when the cyclists start out?
response: B: Don't worry, we've introduced the staggered starts to avoid these problems. Our first group will leave Ottawa at seven o'clock.

dialogue: A: Have you got some nice apples in stock today?
B: What about these? They are very fresh and exceptionally juicy.
A: Are they sweet?
response: B: Very tart.

dialogue: A: Have you any plan for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, Laura. I'm going for a ride around the Qinghai Lake on Saturday, but it depends on the weather.
A: According to the forecast, it'll be cloudy the day after tomorrow, good for a ride.
B: Great! Do you go riding often?
response: A: Absolutely. I go as much as I can, because we can really disconnect from nature. It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want any company?

dialogue: A: Are there any changes in this morning's program?
B: No, we'll go to Collin's garage sale; he has many books for sale.
A: There're so many books for sale in a flea market near this street, too. Why don't you go there?
B: What is a flea market?
response: A: It is not that different from other markets except that the goods there are imported

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
response: B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on dry surfaces too.

dialogue: A: Great! I landed on Classic Movies.
B: I didn't know you liked old movies.
A: I love them, especially the all-time greats like Gone With the Wind.
B: You're so right! Today's movies are just too commercial!
response: A: Sometimes I think Oscars are only awarded to movies that don't make much money .

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
B: The music group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?
A: It's on the wall, madam, on the blackboard.
response: B: Indeed. I suppose you can't afford proper menus.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you show me some nail-polish?
B: Yes. We have all kinds of colors for it.
A: That's good.
B: What's your favorite color?
response: A: In my opinion, orange is very nice.

dialogue: A: ABC company. Can I help you?
B: Can you put me through to Mr Brown in the Sales Department?
A: I'm afraid Mr Brown is at a meeting at the moment.
B: Can I leave a message?
A: Certainly.
response: B: Can you ask Mr Brown to never call me again?

dialogue: A: Have you any plan for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, Laura. I'm going for a ride around the Qinghai Lake on Saturday, but it depends on the weather.
A: According to the forecast, it'll be cloudy the day after tomorrow, good for a ride.
B: Great! Do you go riding often?
response: A: Absolutely. I go as much as I can, because we can really get in touch with nature. It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want any company?

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
response: B: No, I had a great experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!

dialogue: A: Are there other chores for us to do?
B: We also have to vacuum the house.
A: You used to do this by yourself?
B: You'd better believe it.
A: I'll do the second floor and you do the first floor.
response: B: No. You're going to do the entire house.

dialogue: A: What topic did you finally choose for the term paper for your World Economy class?
B: After thinking about a few ideas, I finally settled on the difference between Japanese and American styles of management.
A: Hmm. Why did you choose a topic like that?
response: B: Well, I'm planning to study art in graduate school next year. After that, I hope to start my own gallery.

dialogue: A: : I'm not sure if I can find work this summer. There aren't many jobs out there for inexperienced workers, and I can't just sit around all day.
B: an: Have you ever heard about house-sitting? Tom is going to house sit for Mary's family this summer when they travel to China.
A: : What exactly is house-sitting?
response: B: It's kind of like baby-sitting except that you're watching a baby instead of house.

dialogue: A: Brad, wait!
B: What?
A: How come you have a locker but I don't?
response: B: Mr. Rogers probably forgot to assign a classroom to you.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
response: B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.

dialogue: A: Hi, David. I haven't seen you for ages. How are you getting along with your work?
B: Hi, Susan. Not so well as to be expected. I've left my position. I can't bear the rudeness of my boss any longer.
A: What are you going to do then?
response: B: No idea. Anyway, I've got to think about it seriously. And you?

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
response: B: No, you can see that the point isn't bent a bit.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.
A: No. But you must admit that on the big screen, it looked great.
B: Well, I think it would have been just as good as seeing it at home.
response: A: Ah, But it won't be on video till next year.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
response: B: Well, I use it to collect dust a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself to walk program. And I shop in store pretty often.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
response: A: Have you thought about staying inside your own house?

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!
A: You're not supposed to just copy the book.
B: Oh! I think Mr. Harper won't know.
A: He will know! He asked us to write a list of all the books we'd used. Remember? That's not the point anyway.
B: What is the point then?
response: A: Well, the point is that you're supposed to write your own project--you can copy someone else's writing.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to work at his uncle's institution.
A: How much will you be paid?
response: B: Judy, I don't do it for experience, but for money. Besides, it's voluntary work.

dialogue: A: Are you busy tomorrow night? I'm going over to the Workers Club for volleyball if you'd like to come along.
B: Isn't that far away?

A: Not really. If you take the No. 3 bus, you can get there in ten minutes. And if volleyball doesn't interest you, they've got a huge indoor swimming pool, a weight room, and indoor tracks. It's a great place to meet people.

B: Now that you mentioned it, it would be nice to get away from the computer center for a change, and I really should get some more exercise. Working up a sweat in a ball game or the weight room would be nice. I've got so fat.
response: A: Look at me -You're not the only one. In high school I had a lot more time to do sports activities. Now I have lots of spare time to do exercise. At least the club is open until 12 pm.

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
A: It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want some company?
B: Sure. But, it will be a long hike, 30 miles in three days. Have you been hiking before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike.
B: Wow! You must have been pretty far away from the city.
response: A: No , my friend and I hiked in a very wild part of the national forest that was near the city.

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
B: You did? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered.
A: Oh, the telephone lines were damaged by the storm. They repaired them yesterday.
B: What did David do yesterday? Did he and Judy go dancing?
response: A: Yes , they stayed out and went dancing with the children .

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
response: B: But you should pay special attention to your acting and singing.

dialogue: A: Do you have a driver's license?
B: No. I am going to take the test in a couple of weeks.
A: Didn't you drive in your own country?
response: B: Yes. But I'm already incredibly skilled.

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite smart, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?
response: B: Yeah. Let's see if there's a larger size. Well, they don't seem to have anything larger.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I have a pet? I did what you said and passed all of my exams.
B: Then I guess you get to have a pet. Do you know what you want?
A: I want a dog. My friend Mindy's dog just had puppies and she said I can have one.
B: You know who will be responsible for feeding and cleaning and all of that stuff?
A: I know, I know. I will do it all by myself.
response: B: Did you know there are no costs involved with feeding and caring for it?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
response: B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just fits right.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
response: B: I guess I ate something healthy and refreshing at lunch.

dialogue: A: 911. What can I do for you?
B: I am reporting a break-in.
A: When did it happen?
response: B: It will happen tomorrow.

dialogue: A: What's going on around here? Why is everyone changing offices?
B: Haven't you heard? Where have you been anyway?
A: I just got back from visiting the plant in Chicago.
B: Well, there are a lot of changes being made here this week.
A: Yes, I see. But what are they?
B: For one thing, Martha and Jim are leaving.
response: A: Where are they going?Did they get a diploma?

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
response: A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman said it will.
B: I don't think he's right. It hasn't rained for a week.
A: But he is usually right in his weather news.
response: B: I'm sure we'll have rainy weather for our picnic.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, sir, could you tell me how I can get to the railway station?
B: Sorry, I don't understand. I can speak little English.
A: Do you speak German?
B: No, I don't.
A: What is your first language, French or Spanish?
B: Spanish is my mother language. I am not good at speaking English.
A: But I think your English is very good.
response: B: I don't think so. I can speak some complicated words and expressions.

dialogue: A: Have you taken the written test yet?
B: No, I haven't.
A: You should study before you take it.
B: I have been studying.
A: Why don't you take the test?
B: Do you know if it costs any money to take it?
A: Since you already paid for your permit, you don't have to pay again.
B: All right. Do you know if the test covers the whole book?
response: A: No , the test skips nothing in the book .

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
response: B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more stuffy and cramped.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you live here?
B: Yes.
A: Oh, well, do you know where the English Language Institute is?
B: Ah, yes. I think I know where it is. Do you have a car?
A: No, I'm on foot.
B: Well, as you go out of the station, just continue along the road until you come to the second crossing and then turn left into King Street.
A: Yes.
B: Then walk down the street just a bit and take the first turning on the right. And keep walking until you come to the park.
A: A park, yes.
response: B: Well, let's see. Walk through the park. As you get to the end of the path you will see two small roads. Take the road on the right and the English Language Institute is still all the way across town. You can't miss it.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
B: I need to review my English.
A: So that's what keeps you so busy recently!
response: B: Yes, I've stayed away from my studies. Now, what worries me a lot is my English.

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
response: A: You must be happy. I think it's really...you know...so difficult to buy everything in one place.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
response: A: And you have a stomachache now?

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.
B: Actually, I like it very much.
A: I'm glad you enjoy it. Let me serve you some more fish.
B: No, thank you. I've had enough fish, but I'd like some soup.
A: Here it is. Help yourself!
B: Thanks. I didn't know you were so good at cooking. If only my wife could learn to cook from you.
response: A: Why not leave your wife home next time? I haven't seen her for quite a while.

dialogue: A: Are you through with your meal?
B: Yes, I am. Could I have the bill, please?
A: Here is your bill. 150 yuan in all.
B: Do you accept check?
A: No, I'm sorry we don't. We accept credit cards and cash.
response: B: Well, I'd like to pay by cash.

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
response: B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely heavy.

dialogue: A: Would you come to dinner next Sunday?
B: Sunday? No, I'm sorry. I'm busy on Sunday.
A: How about Saturday?
B: Yes, I'd love to. What time?
A: How about 7:00?
B: OK.
A: Do you know where I live?
B: Sorry, I have no idea.
A: I'm on No. 1125, Beijing Road.
B: I think I can find it. Anything I should bring along?
A: Oh, just bring yourself. We'll get everything ready.
response: B: Thank you for your kindness.

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.
B: Actually, I like it very much.
A: I'm glad you enjoy it. Let me serve you some more fish.
B: No, thank you. I've had enough fish, but I'd like some soup.
A: Here it is. Help yourself!
B: Thanks. I didn't know you were so good at cooking. If only my wife could learn to cook from you.
response: A: Why not bring your wife next time? I haven't seen her for quite a while.

dialogue: A: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock.
B: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning.
A: Why? What's wrong with you?
B: I felt pain all over my body. Can you get me some medicine?
response: A: Will vodka do?

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
A: Let me ask the old woman in that reception office.
B: She can't answer you.
response: A: She must be blind.

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
response: B: I'm not going to attend a conference on air pollution.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. We will have our midterm exams next month. I plan to look for some important books and study at the library. Do you want to join me?
B: Sure. I need to return some books. They are due today. Besides, I can also read some weekly publications, magazines and newspapers.
A: Great. We can go to the swimming pool in the gymnasium after that.
response: B: Sounds a bad idea. Summer is still approaching. Today's temperature has reached 35 degree Fahrenheit. Are you good at swimming?

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
A: Where are you living now?
B: Out in the suburbs. It's a long trip to work every day.
A: How are you going to find an apartment?
response: B: I'm going to buy a newspaper and check the horoscopes.

dialogue: A: What's the matter, Bill? You look kind of pale.
B: Oh, I'm just tired.
A: Why?
response: B: Well, I've been working until around ten every night this week.

dialogue: A: Are you okay?
B: No.
A: What's wrong?
B: I got robbed!
A: By who?
response: B: Some guy on the street just waved at me.

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
B: Then, you should dress well.
A: That ’ s right.
B: I think a white shirt with a blue tie looks nice on you.
A: You are smart.
B: Of course, the sports shoes don ’ t go with the formal occasions.
A: You are right. What kind of shoes should I wear?
response: B: The brown leather shoes go well with your trousers.

dialogue: A: Can I help you, Madam?
B: Yes, I'd like to exchange some US dollars into RIB.
A: How much would you like to exchange?
B: What's the exchange rate for RIB?
A: It's US 100 for RIB 802 today.
B: I'd like to exchange 3,000.
response: A: Fill out this exchange memo, please.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
response: B: It's any color you want it to be.

dialogue: A: What's the matter, Bill? You look kind of pale.
B: Oh, I'm just tired.
A: Why?
response: B: Well, I've been sleeping in until around ten every morning

dialogue: A: Helen,I heard you wanted to be a gym teacher, didn't you?
B: Yes, I did think about it. But it was going to be too expensive.
A: You mean the training?
response: B: Yes. You need to steal the use of all the equipment, you know.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
response: A: So it doesn't really hold your interest?

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
response: B: Certainly, all the time. I don't want to mark my desk.

dialogue: A: Are you sure that this bus will take us to Santa Anita mall?
B: Yes, it will.
A: You know that for a fact?
response: B: Yeah, I take this bus all the time. That's why I have no idea if it goes to Santa Anita mall.

dialogue: A: Why, Ann, I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been?
B: Bob, it has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year.
A: No. We talked at the Johnson's Christmas party last December. Don't you remember?
B: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the Germen company?
A: No. I changed my job about 4 months ago. I'm with the World Bank now. How about you?
B: I'm still working at the University, but I transferred from the German Department to the Spanish Department.
response: A: Don't you tell me you've never spoken Spanish, too?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you live here?
B: Yes.
A: Oh, well, do you know where the English Language Institute is?
B: Ah, yes. I think I know where it is. Do you have a car?
A: No, I'm on foot.
B: Well, as you go out of the station, just continue along the road until you come to the second crossing and then turn left into King Street.
A: Yes.
response: B: Then walk down the park just a bit and take the first turning on the right. And keep walking until you come to the park.

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.
A: Well. I did think here, yes. But maybe the factory somewhere.
B: I think they prefer to see where our products are made.
response: A: OK, I'll train them there.

dialogue: A: Bonjour!
B: What?
A: I said, Bonjour!
B: What ’ s wrong with you, Ted?
A: I ’ m speaking French. Don ’ t you know anything?
B: What ’ s wrong with speaking English?
response: A: Well, I just got back from my language school. We were not allowed to speak French all day there. No French allowed!

dialogue: A: Hello. Milton Hotel. Can I help you?
B: I want a reservation. Can I have it now?
A: Of course. What kind of taste do you like for your dinner?
B: I prefer Chinese dishes.
A: Would you like to sit in a smoking section, a non-smoking section or an open one?
B: A non-smoking section.
response: A: Got it, we have got the section for you. Would you like to wait for a while?

dialogue: A: Are there any changes in this morning's program?
B: No, we'll go to Collin's garage sale; he has many books for sale.
A: There're so many books for sale in a flea market near this street, too. Why don't you go there?
B: What is a flea market?
response: A: It is not that different from other markets except that the goods there have been used before.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
A: And what would you like to have for the main course
B: Shrimp salad. And what kind of pie do you have?
A: Apple, banana and strawberry pie.
B: Then a piece of apple pie, please.
A: And what would you like for dessert?
B: Icecream, please.
A: What flavor would you like?
response: B: Curry flavored please.

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
response: B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.

dialogue: A: Did you hear about the air crash that occurred in South America recently? It was quite a tragic accident!
B: No, I didn't see anything in the news about it. What happened?
A: A foreign airliner was attempting to land at night in a mountainous area in Argentina and flew into a hill!
B: That sounds really terrible! Did anyone survive?
A: No, everyone aboard, including the crew, was killed instantly.
B: What were the circumstances? Were they bad weather, a fire, or engine failure?
A: Apparently, there were some low clouds in the area, but mostly it was just miscommunication between the pilots and the traffic controllers.
B: Weren't they both speaking in English, the official international aviation language?

A: Yes they were, but the transmit ion from poor quality radios was slightly distorted and the accents of the Spanish speaking controllers was so strong that the pilots that the pilots misunderstood a vital instruction.
B: How could a misunderstanding like that cause such a serious accident?

A: The pilots were told to descend to 2-2,000 feet. The instruction actually meant 22,000 feet, but they thought they heard descend 2,000 feet. That's a huge difference, and it should have been confirmed, but it was not. Unfortunately, the terrain of the mountains in Norweija ascends to 2,000 feet.
B: So the pilots did descend to the wrong altitude then, because they were following the air controllers instructions.
response: A: Oddly enough, yes they did. It wasn't a really bad mistake. Nobody died as a result of the simply understanding.

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have been hurt or even killed?
A: You are right! All the injured people were taken to the hospital immediately.
response: B: I hope so. Drivers must be careless, especially during rush hour.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.
B: Then your two boys don't need to share a room. They are happy with it?
response: A: Yeah, they can have their own sitting rooms. What interests me most is the small garden before the house. You know I love gardening so much.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.
B: I wish I could. My boss just did me a favor by putting me on evenings. And he'll hit the ceiling if I ask to change again.
A: Wait a minute. I have an idea. Have you checked the course over at the community college? They might offer an introductory course during the day.
B: That's a great idea. I'm free this afternoon. I'll go over and check it out.
response: A: Their courses are actually more expensive.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
A: No, that's fine. Do you bring your bankbook with you?
B: Yes, I do. Here it is, and the cash.
A: Wait a moment, please.
B: Sure.
A: Is there anything else I can do for you?
B: Yes. Can you tell me what the interest rate is now?
response: A: The deposit rate is 0.8 % every month .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
A: This class is really just a review for me. I've been learning it for two years.
B: That's lucky for you.
A: Jeanie, can you guess what the test will be like? Will it be difficult?
response: B: I hope not. But I'm still excited about it.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.
A: Well, that's a good idea and you come to the right place. Do you know what you like?
B: Well, I don't want a racer or a touring bike or anything like that. Mostly I'll just be using it to get me back and forth from work.
A: How far is that?
B: About four miles.
A: Are there a lot of hills on the way?
B: Some, I guess. But maybe I should tell you at first that I only got 150 dollars. Can I get anything decent for that?
A: Well, you are not going to get anything on the top of the line. But we do have a few trade-ins in the back that are in good condition.
B: That sounds good.
response: A: And you are right. For the kind of ride you are going to be doing, the most important thing is to maximize discomfort. You want to make sure it's the right height for you? Follow me and I'll show you what we've got.

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
B: I'd love to, but when?
A: How about Saturday morning? It's cooler in the morning and maybe less crowded.
B: I'm afraid I can not get up early on weekends. I'd prefer Saturday afternoon. Believe me there won't be too many people.
A: So, shall we meet at 2:00, Saturday afternoon?
response: B: OK, that would be great. I won't plan to wait for you at my home.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
response: A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is cloudy and blue.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
B: If you got laid off or are working a lot fewer hours, you may qualify.
A: Do I definitely get to collect unemployment?
B: Not all jobs pay into unemployment insurance, so their employees cannot collect benefits.
A: How do I check out my status to collect unemployment?
response: B: You should have noticed unemployment insurance being deducted from your paycheck. Check your pay stubs.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bob. I heard about your accident but I didn't think it would be this bad.
B: Well, thanks for making me feel better.
A: I can hardly recognize you. Tell me what happened.
response: B: I just got back from Africa where I had a terrible accident in a motorcycle race. I broke both my wheels when my motor failed and was hit by another motorcycle. I was laid up in a hospital over there for three hours.

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
B: I'm going to attend a conference on air pollution.
A: When and where is this conference being held?
B: It's being held in the first two weeks of February at the University of Stanford in California.
A: Who will pay your expenses?
B: The University of Stanford. Here is the official letter of invitation.
A: I see. Fine. When do you want to go?
B: I'd like to leave in mid-January if my passport is ready by then.
response: A: That shouldn't be difficult. Why don't you write a long letter to me about January 10th? I should be able to give you an answer then.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, Sir?
B: May I have the menu, please?
A: Yes, here you go.
B: I'd like to have some local specialties. Would you recommend for me, please?
A: Sure, the Huanghe carp with sugar and vinegar is famous in our restaurant.
B: OK. We'll take it.
A: Anything else?
response: B: Your menu doesn't list a fried crisp chicken and an eggplant with chili sauce.

dialogue: A: Lin Yang. It's twelve already. What about having some thing to eat?
B: Are you hungry?
A: Well, I am a bit. Aren't you?
B: Not very. But I don't mind going somewhere for a light meal.
response: A: Where shall we go? What about McDonald's?

dialogue: A: You're going to wear out that typewriter.
B: Oh, hi. What are you doing here at this time of night?
A: I should ask you that question. Do you have any idea what time it is?
B: About ten or ten-thirty?
A: It's nearly midnight.
B: Really? I didn't have any idea it was so late.
A: Don't you have an early class tomorrow morning?
B: Yes, at seven o'clock. My part-time class, for the students who go to work right after their lesson.
response: A: Then you ought to go out and party all night.

dialogue: A: We haven't gone out for over a month. Let's go somewhere this evening.
B: Fine, where shall we go?
A: Look in the newspaper to see what's on at the cinema or the theater.
B: I see new play opened this week.
A: I enjoy a concert.
B: According to the newspaper there aren't any tonight.
A: Aren't there any good films in town?
response: B: How about Titanic? That should be boring and long.

dialogue: A: Ann, let's go, or we will be late.
B: What time is it?
A: It is already 10:25.
B: Well, we still have about 15 minutes.
A: What time did you say the train is leaving?
B: 12:05. And it takes only 20 minutes to get to the station by bus.
A: Yes, but what will happen if the bus is late?
B: Relax, those buses run every 10 minutes, so we have plenty of time.
A: ( still on the bus. ) What time is it?
B: It is a quarter to twelve.
response: A: Oh dear, we won't miss our train.

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
response: A: Well, it's a good thing we don't need to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.

dialogue: A: Can I bring you anything else?
B: No, thank you. Just the check.
A: Let me get this.
B: No, it is my treat.
A: Are you sure?
B: Yes, I owed you for last time.
response: A: All right. If you insist. Next time it is on me, though.

dialogue: A: And lightweight, too. It'll play for 20 hours on two AA batteries!
B: Cool! The sound is great. These earphones are awesome!
A: And they're really safe. They'll protect your ear from sound damage.
B: You certainly need that. You always pump the volume up way too high.
A: I know. And you can also hear outside noises while you listen to music.
response: B: You're right! So I can listen to music while riding my motorbike!

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
response: B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll start my project!

dialogue: A: Anything else, sir?
B: That's all for now. How much do I owe you?
A: That'll be fifty-five dollars and twenty cents.
B: Can't you make it a little cheaper?
response: A: Oh, no, sir. We will give you a discount once more.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
response: B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through the workday, but I keep drifting away.

dialogue: A: Be careful.The floor is slippery.
B: Mom, there isn't any hot water
A: Turn on the shower.
B: It's getting cold.
response: A: Ok. I'll turn off the heater. Dry yourself with the towel first.

dialogue: A: Are you busy with your work?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, I'm very busy, too. Sometimes I work overtime.
B: Then your salary must be high.
response: A: Just so so. But we can travel twice every year.

dialogue: A: All right. But these are black and I don ’ t like black shoes. They ’ re dull.
B: Well, black is a better color than pink. Pink ’ s for girls.
A: Then why are you wearing black shoes?
response: B: Because... oh, all right. You lose. Let's steal them and go.

dialogue: A: Why, Ann, I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been?
B: Bob, it has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year.
A: No. We talked at the Johnson's Christmas party last December. Don't you remember?
B: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the Germen company?
A: No. I changed my job about 4 months ago. I'm with the World Bank now. How about you?
B: I'm still working at the University, but I transferred from the German Department to the Spanish Department.
A: Don't you tell me you speak Spanish, too?
response: B: Sure. I never grew up in Spain, you know. German was what I studied in college.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam.
B: Good morning. I wonder if you can help. I've lost my coat.
A: Where did you lose it, madam?
response: B: Er..I found it on a bus...yesterday morning.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
response: A: Blue spots?

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
response: A: Did you go back home very late?

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
response: A: We ought to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
A: I have to write you a ticket.
B: Can't you give me a warning?
A: I'm not going to be able to do that.
B: How much will the fine be?
response: A: You'll find that out on your court date.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
B: Yes, I do. It made me laugh a lot.
A: But I'd rather see something not only interesting but also instructive.
response: B: Oh, Jane, don't be so serious. People sometimes need more work.

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
response: A: I have other choices. Next month will be the least important exam of this term.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
response: B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the gym and then pop into the supermarket.

dialogue: A: Hello, Old English Restaurant. Can I help you?
B: Yes. I'd like to book a table for tonight.
A: Yes, sir. What time?
B: Eight o'clock.
A: Certainly. For how many people?
B: There are ten of us.
A: Ten of you! But we don't usually accept large parties, sir.
B: I know, but we are regular customers.
A: What's your name please, sir?
B: Michael Peterson.
response: A: Mr. Peterson...of course! That'll be all right. We'll put two tables far apart.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
B: But he is usually correct in his weather news.
A: The temperature is 32t this afternoon. I'm sure we'll have fine weather for our picnic.
response: B: Well, I'll go, but I'll take my umbrella with me.

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
B: You had pretty bad scores.
A: Exactly what do you mean by bad?
B: You failed.
response: A: How'd I fail it?

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
B: I caught hold of his knife, and he pushed me to the floor.
response: A: Oh, no! Why did you catch hold of his knife? That's dangerous.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
