B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
response: B: About one day at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely heavy.
A: Just the things we need for the picnic tomorrow.
B: Well, hurry up and open the door. I told you these things were very heavy.
response: A: I can't find the key. You must have it.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
B: Yes, of course. Shall we give her some flowers?
A: Flowers are lovely. But I think it's better to buy her a nice box of chocolates.
B: Alice doesn't like sweet things. Didn't you know that?
A: You're right. Er... I know. We can give her a record. She loves music.
response: B: That's a good idea. Let's go to the auto shop and choose one for her.

dialogue: A: Where is Jimmy? Why hasn't he come down for breakfast? Needn't he go to school today?
B: He's still in bed in his room.
A: What's the matter with our dear son?
B: He's feeling terrible. I think he must have caught a bad cold.
response: A: Well, we must call the teacher.

dialogue: A: Are you quite independent of your parents now?
B: Yes. As soon as I left school, I... my studies as a nurse. I stopped asking my parents for money since I got financial support from the government. But I still stay with them a lot.
A: You're staying... very close to your parents?
B: I am. They never forced me to do anything I didn't want to do. What about you?
A: Well, I am also fond of my family. But I don't always get on very well with them. They try to control me too much.
B: But they allowed you to come to study in England on your own.
response: A: Yes, but, only after a lot of persuasion. Your parents treat you as an adult. Mine treat me as a stranger.

dialogue: A: What are you hiding in your coat pocket?
B: It's a camera.
A: You want to take pictures of the inside of your pocket?
B: Not even funny, Billy. This is my new snapshot sticker camera.
A: What's that supposed to mean?
response: B: Well , there are holes on the backs . You can nail them anywhere .

dialogue: A: Are we going to have gym class tomorrow?
B: Are you crazy? Tomorrow's Saturday.
A: Sometimes I forget that we don't have school on Saturdays.
B: Americans also don't go to work on Saturdays.
response: A: So there are only five working days in a week?

dialogue: A: Hello, Catherine. Would you like to go out tomorrow?
B: Tomorrow?
A: Yeah, I was thinking we could get a bite to eat and catch a movie.
B: That sounds great.
A: Yes. We can do something else if you like.
response: B: OK . Fasting and reading alone will be perfect .

dialogue: A: Hello, I am calling about my cable service.
B: What's the problem?
A: For the past week my cable hasn't been working.
B: I apologize, but the cable has been down lately.
A: Do you know when it is going to start working again?
B: Give it a couple days, and it should be back on.
A: Will I still have to pay for the cable while it's not working?
response: B: Since it's not working , I'm going to give you a credit .

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve in the library for anthropology 311.
A: Professor Gilers's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matter which one of them you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're kidding all of them?
response: A: I've asked professor Gilers twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for these same articles to be returned.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
response: B: No, it was as small as a cellphone and worked very slow.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
response: A: For stupid affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
response: A: Let me ask the old horse in that reception office.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
response: B: We can go next week instead.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
response: B: But he is usually wrong in his weather news.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
response: A: It's wide open right now, everything from police to diaper changers.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. What can I do for you?
B: I want some coffee.
A: Certainly, madam. What kind of coffee do you want to have?
B: What have you got?
response: A: Well. We have Coke, Pepsi, root beer and Mountain Dew

dialogue: A: Gosh! The water faucet is dripping badly again.
B: You are going to have a huge bill.
A: I know. I ’ Ve got to get it fixed ASAP.
B: Don't you wanna get it fixed now?
A: I wish I could, but I ’ Ve got to go now. I have an appointment in 20 minutes.
B: Well, if you need anything, just let me know.
response: A: Oh , by the way , could you give me a ride ? My car is still in the garage .

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote?
B: Yes, are you?
A: Yeah, but what day are the elections?
B: You don ’ t know what day the elections are?
A: That ’ s why I ’ m asking you.
B: They ’ re this coming Tuesday.
A: Really?
B: Yes, I ’ m serious.
A: Good thing you told me.
B: I can ’ t believe you didn ’ t know when the elections were.
A: It slipped my mind.
response: B: You should not watch the news

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
response: B: I'm an English major and this is a required course. But now I'm in no trouble because I can easily afford this book.

dialogue: A: Are you leaving?
B: I ’ m going to work.
A: You have a job?
B: I ’ m going to work at the polling place.
A: You ’ re working there this year?
B: I work there every year.
A: How are you able to work at the polling place?
response: B: I paid for the job in an online application

dialogue: A: Caroline Menzies speaking.
B: Could I speak to Diana Curzon?
A: I'm afraid she's in a meeting at the moment. Who's speaking?
B: This is John Laing from Dantons.
response: A: Can I transfer you to her, Mr Laing?

dialogue: A: Gordon, you're ever so late.
B: Yes, I am sorry. I missed the bus.
A: But there's a bus every ten minutes, and you are over 1 hour late.
B: Well, I missed several buses.
A: How on earth can you miss several buses?
B: I, ah..., I got have late.
A: Oh, come on, Gordon, it's the afternoon now. Why were you late really?
response: B: Well , I ... I arrived early , and I ...

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
response: B: I won't charge you for the soup tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Dad, how do you say this word?
B: Sword, say it ' sword '.
A: What does this word mean?
B: Look it up in the dictionary.
A: Dad, can you just tell me what it means? I'm too lazy.
response: B: No, honey, go and read it. You'll learn.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
response: A: Well, we have had hot and cold water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for autumn, but I'd like to have something warm for winter.
A: Maybe you would like a heavy wool hat. How about this one?
B: I think that's what I want. How much is it?
A: It's seventy dollars plus tax.
response: B: It's a little cheap looking. Do you think it's possible to get a discount?

dialogue: A: Good morning. So this is the first day for you to work here, I hope you'll like your job.
B: Good morning, Ms.Wilson. I've got a lot to learn from you. I think I'll enjoy working with you.
A: I hope so. Now let me tell you your duties here. This is your desk. Please sit down.
B: Thank you.
A: Your main duty is to answer the phone calls and transfer them to the person wanted.
B: I see. What if the person wanted is out?
response: A: In that case , you are supposed to ask the caller to leave a message .

dialogue: A: Ahahah! What is that thing on your couch! It just moved!
B: Did you think it wasn't real? That's my pet lizard.
A: You have a pet lizard? Somehow I never would have imagined that.
B: His name is Grunt. Come closer and I'll properly introduce you.
A: Does it bite or scratch?
response: B: Yes, he's perfectly harmful. And he's not afraid of strangers either. Here, hold him.

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely heavy.
A: Just the things we need for the picnic tomorrow.
B: Well, hurry up and open the door. I told you these things were very heavy.
response: A: I can't find the door handle. You must have it.

dialogue: A: Hi! Can I help you?
B: Hi! Have you got any records of modern guitar music?
A: We've got a lot of them. Which one are you looking for?
B: I'm looking for some records of Julian Bream. I saw them in your window last week and I had them before in Canada, but I broke them.
A: What happened?
response: B: They were in my bag. I sat on my bag and broke the records. My sister told me about your shop. I came here last week and saw the records.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
response: B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for Camilla.

dialogue: A: Are there any hobbies you do?
B: When I have time, I sometimes draw and paint.
A: Oh, you actually do that?
B: Every so often, I do.
A: Did you always know how to draw and paint?
B: I was taught in high school how to draw and paint.
response: A: You had an art class?

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
B: I was sick. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of bed.
A: You still look a little sick. You couldn't go back to bed.
B: I'm going now. I just came here to speak to my professor.
A: What did he tell you?
B: He said that I'd be able to take a make-up.
A: Well, that's all right then. Are you going straight home?
B: I have to stop at the drugstore on the way. I need some aspirin.
A: Do you think that you should walk that far?
response: B: I don't have to walk. I didn't bring my car. 1 didn't think I'd be able to drive today.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
A: Oh? Who's she calling?
B: She's calling her boyfriend.
A: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
B: He hasn't been home yet...Why? You're asking a lot of questions tonight, Paul.
response: A: Am I?...Well, I'm practicing my English.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I need a new identification card.
A: Why?
B: My ID card is lost.
response: A: OK , did you bring your household register or residence booklet ?

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
B: I did. I called you many times, but you had your mobile phone power off.
response: A: Oh, I didn't bring it with me because I left it recharging at home.

dialogue: A: I need a summer job that will give me some exercise.
B: How about being a life guard?
A: Life guards don't swim that much. They usually just sit.
response: B: Well then, you could sit next to your swimming coach, or a tour guide.

dialogue: A: Hello, Frank.
B: Hi, Steven. What's new with you?
A: Not too much. I'm looking to rent an apartment.
B: Why?
response: A: I dislike my roommate . He really turns me off .

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.
A: Well. I did think here, yes. But maybe the factory somewhere.
response: B: I think they prefer to see where our products are made.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, madam. I'm wondering if you could tell me the place where I can repair my shoes.
B: There's one on Fifth Street.
A: Thank you, but how far is it to that store?
response: B: It's a state away and not difficult to find. Just keep walking and after two blocks you will see a supermarket on your left. The store is next to the supermarket.

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
B: But I was told that arm exercises could raise your blood pressure.
A: Yes, but the article I read suggests some ways to make up for that.
B: Really? How?
A: By adding leg exercises, so that the arms don't do all the work.
response: B: And in return, I'm sure that there's a good chance of losing weight.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
response: A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the cash register. It's quite modern.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.
A: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of strong and comfortable shoes.
B: What's your suggestion?
response: A: Maybe you should buy him a pair of leather shoes.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
response: A: Let me avoid asking the old woman in that reception office .

dialogue: A: Hello, Dora, I haven't seen you for a long time. Where have you been?
B: I didn ’ t go anywhere. I stayed at home.
A: What's up? You look unhappy.
B: Nothing. I just feel very lonely in this city. I miss my family.
A: Oh, I know. Sometimes I have the same feeling with you. But you'd better not be so emotional.
B: Can you stay and accompany me for a while?
response: A: Sure , no problem . You can call me any time when you are here from now on .

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
B: Well, I use it to send e-mails a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself French program. And I shop online pretty often.
A: Mmm. Any other uses?
response: B: Keeping track of my bank account, and there are a couple of computer games I enjoy.

dialogue: A: Has the train come yet?
B: No, I ‘ Ve been waiting for ages.
A: It ’ s so unreliable. I ’ Ve been late for my meetings all this week.
response: B: Yes, me too. I've gained some important clients recently because of this train!

dialogue: A: Are you all right, Mark? Is anything wrong?
B: I'm so homesick, I could die. All this studying, all this pressure, I just can't stand it.
A: It takes time to get used to all this.
B: Yes. But, you know, I lost sleep last night.
A: It seems like you've really got the blues. Have you heard from home recently?
B: It's been almost a month since I got a letter from my mum. I'm going to write to her and explain the situation. By the way, do you have an envelope that I can borrow?
A: Sorry, I don't have any. I hardly ever send any letters.
B: The bookstore is closed today. Is there another place I can get some stamps?
response: A: You can go to the post office on North Street to buy stamps.

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: I'm in a hurry. How long will it take?
B: About half an hour, if there's no traffic jam.
A: Do you think the traffic will be heavy?
B: I doubt it. It's not rush hour.
response: A: That's a relief.

dialogue: A: Hello, Macy Agency.
B: Good morning. I'd like to book a return ticket from London to Paris on Monday, July 14th, please.
A: Yes, Madam. We have a flight at 14: 30, Is that suitable?
B: Oh, that's fine. And how much will that cost, please?
A: The price is $ 420 for the return flight.
B: Good. Which airport does the flight leave from?
A: It leaves from Heathrow Airport. Check in time is one hour before departure.
response: B: My name is Susan Smith. Can I give you the ticket tomorrow morning?

dialogue: A: Hi, honey. Do you need any help with your luggage?
B: No, thanks, dad. I just brought one carry-on in my backpack.
A: Great. I wish your mother would take some packing lessons from you. OK, let's go home.
B: Hm...It's cold here.
A: Yes, the weatherman says that it might snow tonight. What temperature was it when you took off from California this morning?
response: B: Sixty degrees and sunny.

dialogue: A: Gordon, you're ever so late.
B: Yes, I am sorry. I missed the bus.
A: But there's a bus every ten minutes, and you are over 1 hour late.
response: B: Well , I missed several airplanes.

dialogue: A: Hi, David. I haven't seen you for ages. How are you getting along with your work?
B: Hi, Susan. Not so well as to be expected. I've left my position. I can't bear the rudeness of my boss any longer.
A: What are you going to do then?
B: No idea. Anyway, I've got to think about it seriously. And you?
A: I've been very successful as a dancer. I like this kind of life. It is so exciting.
B: You can't do that forever.
response: A: No. But I've decided to open a dance school once I've moved to the top. A lot of young dancers need better training.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
response: A: You can ask someone that could switch years with you. Maybe just switch a couple of years since the course probably only meets two times a week.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
response: B: Then, I'd like to have the pineapple pie.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
response: A: I see . Would you be interested in seeing the hydraulic valves ? They are made by our company .

dialogue: A: Do you have a driver's license?
B: No. I am going to take the test in a couple of weeks.
A: Didn't you drive in your own country?
response: B: Yes. But I'm already so skilled.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just graduated from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.
B: Could you tell me what you can do?
response: A: I can do whatever a secretary is expected to do, except for typing, receiving phone calls, sending faxes, and writing reports.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
response: B: Thanks , they are rather attractive . But I think there is nothing better than seeing things that are out of operation.

dialogue: A: Great! I landed on Classic Movies.
B: I didn't know you liked old movies.
A: I love them, especially the all-time greats like Gone With the Wind.
response: B: You're so right ! Today's movies are just too commercial !

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
B: I'm going to attend a conference on air pollution.
A: When and where is this conference being held?
B: It's being held in the first two weeks of February at the University of Stanford in California.
response: A: Who will pay your expenses?

dialogue: A: What are your hobbies, Mr. Green?
B: I like collecting stamps.
A: But it's an expensive hobby, isn't it?
B: Yes, you're right. What do you like to do in your spare time?
response: A: I usually play chess with my friends . But I like playing basketball best .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: I'd like to buy a blue jacket. Do you have any blue jackets?
A: Yes. What size do you wear?
B: I want Size M.
A: Here you are. Try it on and see whether it is all right for you.
B: It's all right. I like it very much. How much is it?
A: 360 Yuan.
response: B: Oh. That's the perfect price. Do you have any other kind? I want a cheaper one.

dialogue: A: Are you through with your meal?
B: Yes, I am. Could I have the bill, please?
A: Here is your bill. 150 yuan in all.
B: Do you accept check?
A: No, I'm sorry we don't. We accept credit cards and cash.
response: B: Well, I'd like to throw away this cash.

dialogue: A: We want to take a train to New York.
B: Regular or express train?
A: How much time would I save if we took the express?
B: About one hour. The next express train arrives in New York at 3:15.
A: And how much more do I have to pay for the express?
B: First class is 24 dollars more, and second class is 15 dollars more.
response: A: As long as we can arrive one hour earlier, I mind paying a little extra. Then give me one second class ticket on the regular, please.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Steven?
B: I'm going to Beijing tomorrow. I'm packing my luggage.
A: What will you bring along when traveling?
B: I will take some clothes to change and cleaning items.
A: Have you packed the camera yet?
response: B: Yes. I've already put it in my garbage bin .

dialogue: A: Oh, dear. My weight has gone up again.
B: I'm not surprised. You've been eating too much.
A: I wish I could lose weight. I have been to the hospital.
B: Were you given any advice?
A: Yeah, the doctor asked me to clean up my diet by cutting down meat.
response: B: What's more, you had better cut out all exercise.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
response: A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the table. It's quite modern.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
response: B: It must be unlocked.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. I just received my telephone bill, and there's a problem with it.
B: May I see your bill, please?
A: Certainly. There it is. On July 1st, I really don't know anybody in Finland.
response: B: OK, don't worry. I'll take the call off. Let's see...it was $66.10. Your bill was $42 , minus $66.10, so your new total is $24.10. I'm very sorry about the mistake.

dialogue: A: Are you quite independent of your parents now?
B: Yes. As soon as I left school, I... my studies as a nurse. I stopped asking my parents for money since I got financial support from the government. But I still stay with them a lot.
A: You're staying... very close to your parents?
B: I am. They never forced me to do anything I didn't want to do. What about you?
A: Well, I am also fond of my family. But I don't always get on very well with them. They try to control me too much.
B: But they allowed you to come to study in England on your own.
response: A: Yes, but, only after a lot of persuasion. Your parents treat you as an adult. Mine treat me as a child.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
response: A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few years after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
response: B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you waiting to buy the concert tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: How long have you been here?
B: About 50 minutes. I've hardly moved forward in that time.
A: Are you kidding?
B: Not at all. There was a couple up ahead of me who got so fed up that they finally gave up and left. They said they'd been here for more than an hour.
A: My God. Does anyone know what's causing the delay?
response: B: It could be that there are enough people selling tickets this afternoon. Or maybe their computers speed up.

dialogue: A: Are you quite independent of your parents now?
B: Yes. As soon as I left school, I... my studies as a nurse. I stopped asking my parents for money since I got financial support from the government. But I still stay with them a lot.
A: You're staying... very close to your parents?
B: I am. They never forced me to do anything I didn't want to do. What about you?
A: Well, I am also fond of my family. But I don't always get on very well with them. They try to control me too much.
B: But they allowed you to come to study in England on your own.
response: A: Yes, but, only after a lot of persuasion. Your parents treat you as an adult. Mine treat me as an adult too.

dialogue: A: Bob, I'm sure you know about second-hand smoke.
B: Of course, I do.
A: But have you heard about third-hand smoke?
B: Third-hand smoke? I'm afraid not. What is that then?

A: Well, it is here in today's paper. Parents may think they are protecting children from second-hand smoke when they smoke outside their home or only when the children are not there. But now researchers are warning about what they call third-hand smoke. When you smoke dangerous matter from cigarettes get into your hair and clothing. As babies are the weakest, when you come to a baby, you pass it to the baby and increase the chances of disease in the baby.
response: B: Is that so? In that case I have to say that I should always be close to a baby.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, sir, could you tell me how I can get to the railway station?
B: Sorry, I don't understand. I can speak little English.
A: Do you speak German?
B: No, I don't.
A: What is your first language, French or Spanish?
response: B: English is my mother language. I am not good at speaking English

dialogue: A: What are you going to have for breakfast?
B: I just have some cereal each morning.
A: You're supposed to always have a hearty breakfast.
B: I don't always have time to make breakfast.
A: It's easy to make a quick breakfast.
B: What do you have for breakfast?
response: A: When I need to make a long sit-down breakfast , I just make some oatmeal , toast , and OJ .

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
A: It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want some company?
B: Sure. But, it will be a long hike, 30 miles in three days. Have you been hiking before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike.
B: Wow! You must have been pretty far away from the city.
A: Yeah, my friend and I hiked in a very wild part of the national forest.
response: B: Well , bring him along too . We ’ ll have a great time back at work Monday .

dialogue: A: Waitress! I think there's something wrong with our bill.
B: No, I don't think so...$10 for the drinks, 15 for the small plate, and 20 for the main dish.
A: What? I knew the cheese sticks were 15. I always order cheese sticks, but I thought the main dish was $10.
B: Oh, that explains it. You think the bill should be $35.
A: Yes, exactly. I was wondering what happened to the rest of my change. I should have gotten back 15, not 5!
B: I understand. Sometimes people aren't honest, but I think this was an honest mistake. Didn't you order the sea cucumbers for dinner?
response: A: Yes, and the seaweed were delicious. Cucumbers are nasty though! I'm still glad I'm a vegetarian.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, madam. I'm wondering if you could tell me the place where I can repair my shoes.
B: There's one on Fifth Street.
A: Thank you, but how far is it to that store?
response: B: Very far and difficult to find. Just keep walking and after 500 blocks you will see a supermarket on your left. The store is next to the supermarket.

dialogue: A: Why didn't you come to the cinema last night? I waited for you for a long time.
B: I'm sorry, but I had something more important to do yesterday evening, so I wasn't able to come.
A: But why not tell me?
B: I did. I called you many times, but you had your mobile phone power off.
response: A: Oh, I didn't bring it with me because i don't own one

dialogue: A: Hello, I need to come in and see the doctor.
B: Are you scheduling a check-up, or are you ill?
A: I have really itchy skin and think I may have to have it looked at.
B: Have you been feeling any joint aches with that rash?
response: A: No , but I have a low fever .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Could I be of any service to you?
B: Have you got any Chinese paintings?
A: Yes, we have landscape paintings, figure paintings and flower-and-bird paintings.
B: I'd like a flower-and-bird painting.
response: A: Good . How about this picture of city buildings ? It was painted by a famous Chinese painter in King Dynasty .

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
response: A: I sometimes get exercise, but that's all.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
A: And you have a stomachache now?
B: Yes, I think so.
A: Can you walk to the school clinic? Or shall I send for the doctor?
response: B: No, thanks. It doesn't matter too much. I will run a 10K race after class.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wanting to stay somewhere for a few days.

A: Well, there are some good hotels. Carlton House is near the main square in the city center, but you might also be interested in the Royal Hotel-that's out in the countryside, about ten kilometers away, very peaceful. Then there's the Rainbow Hotel-it is not in the center, but it's out on the airport road.
response: B: Mmm, that might be a bit too close actually. Now the one you mentioned, in the city center. Can you tell me a bit about it?

dialogue: A: About my driving test, did I do well?
B: You did a fabulous job.
A: Are you telling me that I passed the test?
B: That's what I'm telling you.
A: What did I mess up on?
B: You did mess up a little on one thing.
A: Tell me.
B: You had a little trouble on your parallel parking.
A: That's not easy for me.
B: That's something that you really need to work on.
response: A: Am I still going to get my license?

dialogue: A: Excuse me,can I see the personnel manager? My name is Lucy Jordan.
B: Oh, yes. Have a scat, please.
A: Thank you. I come in answer to your ad for the saleswoman.
B: Okay, what qualifications do you have for the toy store work?
response: A: I once worked in a local pet store and my major is business administration.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
response: B: I hope I could get a reception at the McDonald's some time.

dialogue: A: I need a summer job that will give me some exercise.
B: How about being a life guard?
A: Life guards don't swim that much. They usually just sit.
response: B: Well then, you could be a singing coach, or a tour guide.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
B: I get a lump in my throat whenever I see a tragic movie.
A: Tragic movie? I think it's a love story.
response: B: But their love is repulsive!

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
A: Where are you living now?
B: Out in the suburbs. It's a long trip to work every day.
A: How are you going to find an apartment?
B: I'm going to buy a newspaper and check the classified ads.
A: Apartments in the city are expensive.
response: B: I know, but I'm going to enroll in a night school to take a course in business management.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
response: A: Do they look like loaves of bread?

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
response: B: He was diligently working last week in class.

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
response: B: You had very good scores.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ben. You're getting ready for tomorrow's lessons, aren't you?
B: Yes, but I'm a bit nervous. I have no idea what'll happen in class and how I'll get along with my classmates.
A: I understand how you're feeling. Just take it easy. You'll make a lot of friends very soon.
B: Thank you. I'll try my best to get used to my new school life as soon as possible. By the way, what time does the first class begin?
A: At 8 o'clock. But before that we have 10 minutes to hand in homework and then 20 minutes for morning reading.
B: So we must get to school before 7:30, right?
A: Right.
B: How long does each class last?
A: 45 minutes, I think, with a 10 or 15 minutes' break.
response: B: Well, I hear that lunchtime is nearly 12 o'clock and I won't be hungry by then.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
response: A: Ok , I'll keep you a while longer then .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
response: A: No , that's fine . Do you bring your bankbook with you ?

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
A: One moment while I go and get my ID.
B: Make it quick.
A: Okay, here's my ID and the $ 27.
response: B: Thanks . Now take this visual test.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, Sir?
B: May I have the menu, please?
A: Yes, here you go.
B: I'd like to have some local specialties. Would you recommend for me, please?
A: Sure, the Huanghe carp with sugar and vinegar is famous in our restaurant.
B: OK. We'll take it.
A: Anything else?
response: B: If only you served a fried crisp chicken and an eggplant with chili sauce.

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's a graduate course and I'm only a junior, but...
response: A: Aren't you a bit young? I've allowed qualified seniors to take the course and they usually have a hard time to keep up.

dialogue: A: Hello. Matt White speaking.
B: Hello, Dr. White, my name's Pan Johnson. My roommate, Janet Holmes, wanted me to call you.
A: Janet Holmes? Oh, that's right. She's in my Shakespearean English class. Has anything happened to her?

B: Nothing, it's just that she submitted a job application yesterday and the company asked her in for an interview today. She's afraid she won't be able to attend your class this afternoon. I'm calling to see whether it would be OK if I gave you her essay.
A: Certainly, that would be fine. Uh, you can either drop it off at my class or bring it to my office.
B: Would it be all right to come by your office around 4:00? I'm afraid I can't come any earlier because I have three classes this afternoon.
A: Uh, I won't be here when you come. I'm supposed to be at a meeting from 3:00 to 6:00, but how about leaving it with my secretary? She usually stays until 5:00.
response: B: 00. And Dr. White, one more thing, could you tell me where your office is? Janet told me where your class is, but she didn't give me directions to your child's school.

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
B: I was sick. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of bed.
A: You still look a little sick. You couldn't go back to bed.
B: I'm going now. I just came here to speak to my professor.
A: What did he tell you?
B: He said that I'd be able to take a make-up.
A: Well, that's all right then. Are you going straight home?
B: I have to stop at the drugstore on the way. I need some aspirin.
A: Do you think that you should walk that far?
response: B: I have to walk. I have my car with me. I didn't think I'd be able to drive today.

dialogue: A: Are you free this Saturday evening?
B: Oh, it seems there is nothing that evening.
A: Would you like to go to the concert with me?
response: B: I'd like to, where?

dialogue: A: Hi, Bob. I heard about your accident but I didn't think it would be this bad.
B: Well, thanks for making me feel better.
A: I can hardly recognize you. Tell me what happened.
response: B: I just got back from Africa where I had a very minor accident in a motorcycle race. I broke both my nails when my motor failed and was hit by another motorcycle. I was laid up in a hospital over there for three minutes.

dialogue: A: Are you studying any languages here?
B: Yes, I'm studying in the Foreign Languages Department.
A: What are you majoring in?
response: B: I'm majoring in English.

dialogue: A: Has Alan shown up yet?
B: Nope. I guess something might have come up.
A: I wonder what happened.
B: I don't know. I hope it's nothing serious.
A: Last week his sister was admitted to the hospital.
B: Oh? What happened?
response: A: His sister had a car show last week.

dialogue: A: Did you have your television repaired?
B: Yes, but not by the place you recommended
A: Why not? The repair is very good and thecharges are so reasonable.
B: That may be, but I couldn't find it.
A: But you couldn't miss it. I told you the first right after the railroad bridge.
response: B: I took that. I went to the end of the road. There is no such a place.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
response: A: How about feeding them to the cat?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
response: B: I haven't been eating like I usually do. Usually, I love my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt cooking and I've eaten very little. Most unlike me.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kathy, it's Jason.
B: Hi, Jason. I haven't heard from you in a while.
A: Well. I've been busy. I've started my own company.
B: Wow, what kind of business is it?
A: Just a small on-line store. I am hiring staff and I want you to come to work for me.
response: B: Actually, I just invested in the old company again.

dialogue: A: It's lucky that we rode our bike here instead of driving.
B: It's a good job that we got here early. Look at all those cars there. They'll never get in.
A: You'd better follow me closely. I don't want to lose you.
B: Don't worry. I'll keep up.
A: We go in over there. Gate B. Peter said they're pretty good tickets.
B: Where are they?
A: They're right behind the goal.
B: Oh,do we have to stand up all the time?
A: That's right.
response: B: I hope we can see the match clearly.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, Is there an airline flying to New York this afternoon?
B: Sorry, sir. I can't sell you a ticket. Our computer is down.
A: If your computer is down, just write me a ticket.
response: B: Sure, I can. The computer is the only one allowed doing so.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
response: B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
B: What for? For the party, of course.
A: Party? What party?
B: We ’ re having a Valentine ’ s Day Party.
A: Oh, I forget. Who ’ s invited?
B: We ’ Ve invited all our sophomore friends from school.
A: Can I help you get ready?
response: B: That ’ ll be a big help . Well , here ’ s a list of some of the food you could buy .

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
B: He was messing around last week in class.
A: Exactly what did he do?
B: Even though I asked him not to, he kept speaking out in class.
A: I don't know what his problem is.
B: I need you to talk to him, if you don't mind.
A: That won't happen again, I'm sorry.
response: B: Thank you. Hopefully I will call about him soon.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order? May I suggest a veal.
B: No, I'll have the fish please.
A: The chicken is also nice.
B: No, I want the fish.
A: Our special tonight is lobster.
B: Thank you, but I prefer the fish
A: Perhaps you'd enjoy the lamb
B: No, I like the fish.
response: A: Lamb it is

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so nervous.
A: Why?
response: B: I feel nervous every time I bite my nails.

dialogue: A: Morning. Gail. Did you enjoy your holiday in the country?
B: Yes. We had a great time. And some friends went along with us.
A: Where did you stay? In a hotel?
response: B: No, we camped in the mountains. We cooked all our meals over an open fire.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some gloves.
A: All our gloves are here. What do you think of this pair here? It's made of silk.
response: B: Hm, it looks nice, but I'd like to have something warm for the winter.

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
A: It's wonderful. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.
B: What about the swimming pool?
response: A: It's very bad. Would you like to go there with me next week?

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
B: Not really. But when I was home, I had to start typing a literature paper that was due first thing in the morning.
A: Couldn't you do it today?
response: B: No, our professor said she wouldn't accept any late papers.

dialogue: A: How is the weather today?
B: It's very hot and humid.
A: Quite different from the forecast.
B: The weather changes often at this time of the year. It's possible to cool down in the late afternoon.
A: How are the summers here generally?
B: They are usually hot and rainy.
A: I have been here for about a month. It's very hot and humid.
response: B: It's just June now. The rainy season has been around for years.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
response: A: There's also the matter of the fridge. We all assumed there would be none in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
B: I thought she'd be happy.
A: Yeah, especially since she got a promotion recently.
response: B: I don't know. Maybe it ’ s some kind of personal problem.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.
response: B: Then your two boys don't need to share a room. They are happy with it?

dialogue: A: Waitress! I think there's something wrong with our bill.
B: No, I don't think so...$10 for the drinks, 15 for the small plate, and 20 for the main dish.
A: What? I knew the cheese sticks were 15. I always order cheese sticks, but I thought the main dish was $10.
B: Oh, that explains it. You think the bill should be $35.
A: Yes, exactly. I was wondering what happened to the rest of my change. I should have gotten back 15, not 5!
B: I understand. Sometimes people aren't honest, but I think this was an honest mistake. Didn't you order the sea cucumbers for dinner?
response: A: Yes, and they were delicious. Best cucumbers ever! I'm so glad I'm a vegetarian.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy the restaurant?
B: I didn't really like it all that much.
A: What do you think the problem was?
response: B: Well, they are pretty new. I just didn't feel that they were ready to open yet.

dialogue: A: Hello, John. How was your French exam yesterday?
B: Not too good.
A: Well, the term exam is always more difficult. Work harder, and you'll certainly do better next time.
B: I've worked hard enough, I think, but unluckily, I have never done well in the exam.
A: Well, it's no use worrying about the exam now. Let's talk about the football game tonight. It's much more interesting.
B: Is there a football game on TV tonight?
A: Yes it's between the Chinese team and the Japanese team.
B: ... Er I'd rather watch some other programmes.
A: Why? You're so interested in football.
response: B: The Chinese team has always played badly in the important match, just as I have done in the important exam.

dialogue: A: Any message for me, Miss White?
B: Just one, Mr. Brown. You had a phone call from someone called Smith, Mary Smith.
A: Smith? I don't know anyone called Smith. What did she say?
B: She wouldn't say anything. But it sounded important. I told her you'd call her as soon as you came back.
A: Well, I think I'd better do it then. Have you got her telephone number?
A: Have you written it down?
response: B: I always do. It's on your desk.

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely heavy.
A: Just the things we need for the picnic tomorrow.
B: Well, hurry up and open the door. I told you these things were very heavy.
response: A: I can't find the door. You must have it.

dialogue: A: Did you check the internet for next week's weather forecast?
B: I sure did. You're in luck! It's supposed to snow all week in the mountains!
A: Yes! Somebody up there loves me! I knew it wasn't too late for snow.
B: It is kind of strange though, to have snow in April, and so much of it.
A: There have been so many dry winters lately that it's about time, don't you think?
response: B: When you put it that way, I guess the skies can't hold out on us forever.

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
response: A: You mean your grandparents know how to farm, not you?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, what's the screen near your steering wheel for?
B: It's a portable TV. It's a popular thing now.
A: Oh, that's new to me. So what's on everyday?
B: News about current affairs, documentaries, music, movies, noncommercial ads and so on.
A: Is there anything interesting?
B: Yes, there are something good and informative. I think that many people underestimate the value of TV in education.
response: A: I agree. Are there any cats sitting on the TV?

dialogue: A: Good morning. What can I do for you?
B: Good morning. I want to post this letter. Can you tell me what the postage is?
A: I must weigh it. Do you want to send it by ordinary or registered mail?
response: B: I want this letter registered . There is something valuable inside .

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was killed in that bombing.
response: A: I'm sorry to hear that. War left many people thrilling memories.

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
B: I'm going to attend a conference on air pollution.
A: When and where is this conference being held?
B: It's being held in the first two weeks of February at the University of Stanford in California.
response: A: Who will count your expenses?

dialogue: A: Be careful.The floor is slippery.
B: Mom, there isn't any hot water
A: Turn on the shower.
B: It's getting cold.
response: A: Ok. I'll check the sprinkler. Dry yourself with the towel first.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote this Tuesday?
B: Yes, I am, and I am so excited.
A: Have you figured out who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I love my candidate.
A: Why is that?
response: B: My candidate is probably the biggest liar.

dialogue: A: Hi, Nicole. Did you have a good weekend?
B: Yes, I did. But I feel tired today.
A: Really? Why?
response: B: Well, on Saturday I lay around the house and watched tennis. Then on Sunday I drove to the country

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
B: You had pretty bad scores.
A: Exactly what do you mean by bad?
B: You failed.
response: A: How'd I pass it?

dialogue: A: ( Before Christmas Party ) Are you ready for the Christmas party tonight
B: Almost. I have to get dressed. It's a formal party and I have special party make up!
A: Use this lipstick and it will make your lips shine!
response: B: Great! Uh, remember that there's a rocket launch, too. We all have to bring a gift.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the party on Saturday?
B: I was thinking about it. Are you?
A: Yeah, I heard it's going to be a lot of fun.
B: Really? Well, what time does it start?
A: It starts at 8
B: Well, who all is going to be there?
response: A: Everyone from school.

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
response: B: But it's three kilometers from here to the cinema. How can we get there in such a short time?

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy the restaurant?
B: I didn't really like it all that much.
A: What do you think the problem was?
B: Well, they are pretty new. I just didn't feel that they were ready to open yet.
A: How did you feel about the food?
B: The food wasn't all that exciting.
A: I don't think that the service was good, either.
B: Yes, the service certainly didn't add to the experience.
A: Would you like to return to this restaurant?
response: B: Maybe we could try it again in a few months when things have settled down.

dialogue: A: Good morning. What can I do for you?
B: Good morning. I want to post this letter. Can you tell me what the postage is?
A: I must weigh it. Do you want to send it by ordinary or registered mail?
response: B: I want this letter registered. Nothing in it has any value.

dialogue: A: Can I help you, Madam?
B: Yes, I'd like to exchange some US dollars into RIB.
A: How much would you like to exchange?
B: What's the exchange rate for RIB?
A: It's US 100 for RIB 802 today.
B: I'd like to exchange 3,000.
A: Fill out this exchange memo, please.
B: Yes. Here you are.
response: A: Wait a second, please... These are 24,060 US dollars and the receipt, please check them.

dialogue: A: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please.
B: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me.
A: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today.
B: Oh, why? Is she ill?
response: A: No. She's working for an shift

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
response: B: I'm shopping for electrical appliances .

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Have you been waiting long?
B: Twenty minutes already.
A: Did you notice whether the No. 7 bus has passed by?
response: B: Not while I've been standing here. I'm also waiting for the No. 9 train myself.

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
response: B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition improved when he enjoyed himself and watched funny movies.

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
response: B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.

dialogue: A: What class did you have this afternoon, Kate?
B: A chemistry class. We've got a new chemistry teacher this term.
A: Who is it?
B: James Black. He told us to call Jim, not to call him Mr. Black.
A: Oh, James Black. I know him. He's a little thin man who smiles a lot.
B: Yes, but many of us are afraid of him.
A: Really? But I hear he's a very good teacher.
response: B: Yes, he is. His classes are crazy  and dangerous. And we all watch and listen to him very carefully in his class.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.
response: B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were even for sale. The last one was gifted for free.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
response: A: I wonder if you can change it to one size down .

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.
response: A: Well, Mr Strunk, I enjoy my paycheck very much.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
response: A: So do I. It's either too hot or too cold. The sky is clear and blue.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
response: B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to red. But it was yellow.

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.
response: A: That's exactly why I don't want to borrow your notes. My notes are the best in the class.

dialogue: A: Do you know much about computers?
B: Not a great deal. Why?
A: I've been reading an article about computers. They are strange and are being used for almost everything.
B: Yes. But have you learned how to use one?
response: A: No. But I'm going to take a course on short hand next term.

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.
A: Well. I did think here, yes. But maybe the factory somewhere.
B: I think they prefer to see where our products are made.
response: A: OK, I'll meet them at the office.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
B: Well, I use it to send e-mails a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself French program. And I shop online pretty often.
A: Mmm. Any other uses?
B: Keeping track of my bank account, and there are a couple of computer games I enjoy.
response: A: Now you've mentioned e-mail and online shopping. Do you use the Internet for any other purposes?

dialogue: A: Did you get the injury playing football, Jim?
B: Yes. One of the boys kicked my foot instead of the ball.
A: The best thing for you to do is to rest your leg for 48 hours.
response: B: I will go back to school tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Hello, this is Jonason speaking.
B: Hello, Jonason, I am Kasy. I am sorry to tell you that I may not attend your birthday party this weekend.
A: Oh, what's up?
B: Nothing much.., but...
A: What's happened then?
B: I have an important exam at that time.
response: A: If so, I think we can hold the party ahead of time. What do you think about it?

dialogue: A: Did you hear what Fred did last night?
B: No,not yet. What happened to him?
A: I guess he was a little drunk and he had a fight with his brother. Well, he got so mad that he drove his car straight into the front of a drugstore.
B: What do you mean?
A: I mean he drove inside. The front of the store was completely destroyed. I actually saw it just now as I walked by. The car is still inside the store.
B: I'm afraid Fred is in trouble. Where is he now?
response: A: I hear he's at a night club. It's lucky no one was hurt.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
response: A: No, but we can get your package to France in ten weeks for free.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.

B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were even for sale. The last one was on sale for $9,000.
response: A: $9,000? Well, I may go and visit the exhibition tomorrow, but I'm going to buy everything.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
B: Buy an expensive suit.
A: Is a white shirt OK?
response: B: Yeah, fine. And dressing in flip flops.

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
B: I'd love to, but when?
A: How about Saturday morning? It's cooler in the morning and maybe less crowded.
response: B: I'm afraid I get up early on weekends. I'd prefer Saturday afternoon. Believe me there won't be too many people.

dialogue: A: Do you know much about computers?
B: Not a great deal. Why?
A: I've been reading an article about computers. They are strange and are being used for almost everything.
B: Yes. But have you learned how to use one?
A: No. But I'm about to take a course on computers next term.
B: That's good. You have to know about computers. Computer knowledge is a must whatever you do. You should learn quickly or you will be left behind.
A: That's true. But first I want to learn the basics. In the library, there are computers. But it's a pity that I could not make use of them.
B: Well, I can teach you the ABCs, if you like.
response: A: That's very rude of you.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to make an appointment to look at houses.
B: Sure, would you prefer looking in the morning or afternoon?
A: I would prefer mornings.
response: B: Can you go during the day, or can you only go at midnight?

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
response: B: That sounds painful . Are you going to be OK ?

dialogue: A: Are you free this evening, Li?
B: I ’ m afraid I ’ m busy tonight. I ’ m having dinner with friends.
A: What a pity. I wanted to go for a drink with you.
B: What about tomorrow? Are you doing anything tomorrow?
response: A: No, I haven ’ t got any plans.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
response: B: I'd like her to have a change .

dialogue: A: Have you booked the airplane tickets to spain yet?
B: Well, I thought we should go traveling by ship for a change, so I booked two ship tickets instead.
A: You should have told me or discussed it with me.
B: I wanted to give you a surprise. Don't you like the idea?
A: I like it all right, but it takes much more time to travel by ship than by plane.
response: B: We have time, don't we? Every time we went on a trip, we were always tied down by schedules. This time will be different. We don't have to rush traveling by plane.

dialogue: A: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please.
B: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me.
A: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today.
B: Oh, why? Is she ill?
response: A: No. She's studying for an exam.

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
response: B: No, never. I don't want to mark my chair.

dialogue: A: Are you still at that work?
B: Yes, I'm still working there. But I really find my job boring. I'd like to change my job.
A: What sort of job do you have in mind?
B: I think I'm quite fit for a driver.
response: A: But it's very tired.

dialogue: A: Are you really dating with Frank?
B: Yeah. But in my heart of hearts, I find he ’ s not very much to my liking.
A: Then why not keep away from him?
response: B: The problem is that I just have no one to turn to right now.

dialogue: A: Look! It's snowing. Winter is here at last.
B: It's really cold today.
A: Yes, you have to get used to it. The weather's going to be like this for the next three months.
B: Then I'm going to Florida. Can you tell me about your weather diary? Why do you make notes about the different types of weather?
response: A: Because it's boring to see what the weather is like at different times and on different days. For example, we had very boring weather on the 28th of April.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
response: B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
B: Then, you should dress well.
A: That ’ s right.
B: I think a white shirt with a blue tie looks nice on you.
A: You are smart.
B: Of course, the sports shoes don ’ t go with the formal occasions.
A: You are right. What kind of shoes should I wear?
response: B: The brown leather slippers go well with your trousers.

dialogue: A: Dad, do you know where Mom is?
B: I think she is in her room putting a little something together for you to take to school with you.
A: She'd better not start crying like she usually does.
response: B: I know, but she isn't going to miss you much. Have I told you how proud I am of you?

dialogue: A: Hi, Mike. What have you been up to?
B: Not much. I started exercising.
A: Trying to get in shape?
response: B: Yeah, and I need to start eating more junk food.

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
response: B: I really like apples and grapes .

dialogue: A: What's going on around here? Why is everyone changing offices?
B: Haven't you heard? Where have you been anyway?
A: I just got back from visiting the plant in Chicago.
B: Well, there are a lot of changes being made here this week.
A: Yes, I see. But what are they?
B: For one thing, Martha and Jim are leaving.
A: Where are they going?Did they get a higher position?
B: Martha's going to the office in Atlanta. She is going to be in charge of the whole southern market.
A: That sounds like a good position to me. What about Jim?
B: He is going to manage the plant in California.
A: And you? What about you? Are you going to rise to a higher position?
B: Not yet, but I'm hoping I will.
A: Don't you want to get a raise? I'd like the job in California.
response: B: No, I want to stay here at the company office. This is the place to get noticed by top management.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
A: Oh? Who's she calling?
B: She's calling her boyfriend.
A: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
response: B: He hasn't been home yet...Why? You're answering a lot of questions tonight, Paul.

dialogue: A: Would you help me for a minute,please?
B: Of course. What do you want me to do?
A: Could you hold these packages while I look for the key to the door?
response: B: I'd be glad to. What's in these packages? They're extremely light.

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
response: A: I have no other choice. Next month will be the most important exam of this term.

dialogue: A: Did you go out today?
B: With my bad luck? What good would it have done if I'd gone out?
A: If you'd looked for a job,you might have found one.
B: But I've been looking for one over a year. Today wouldn't have been any different.
A: I know how bad you feel, but if you don't keep on looking, you'll never get a job.
B: If I'd stayed in Puerto Rico in the first place, I wouldn't have had so much trouble.
A: What would you have done? There are more people out of work there than there are here.
response: B: I would have had nothing if I stayed there.

dialogue: A: Are you cold?
B: Yes, a little.
A: I wonder if we can change the temperature.
B: I tried before. There are no buttons on the air conditioning.
response: A: There must be fans. How do they turn it on and off?

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
response: B: Exactly the same,  it was as large as a room and worked very slow.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
B: Well, I've been working a lot lately... more than 11 hours a day.
response: A: Maybe you should take a vacation and just rest for a few days.

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a letter.
response: B: There's a pizza place up the street. Have you already got a stamp on that letter?

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
response: A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite reasonable.

dialogue: A: Gordon, I'm going to Keswick in the Lake District this weekend.
B: Really?

A: Yeah, five of us. Why don't you join us? We're getting to Keswick on Friday. Then we're going boating on Saturday. And on Sunday, we're going to do some shopping. Then I will take some time to visit my aunt Lucy.
B: You're not going to camp, are you? Isn't it a bit cold?
A: No, we're not. It is a bit cold. We're staying in a country inn. It's not like five-star hotels or anything. But it's really comfortable.
B: Hmm, sounds interesting. You know, it's the boating that I don't like.
A: Well, what are you up to?
response: B: Sit on my sofa on weekdays and watch the DVDs I've just bought. And that will be a busy weekday. I may finish watching Friends.

dialogue: A: Are you there, Mary?
B: I'm back. My bid on the Buddha is still the highest!
A: How much is my stamp?
response: B: Don't you want to hear more about my religion?

dialogue: A: Am I allowed to check out at 14:00?
B: Certainly.
A: Will there be any late charge?
response: B: No.sir. If only you check out before 15:00
