dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
response: B: Well, I use it to send snail mail a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself French program. And I shop sales pretty often.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mark. Are you in town for another job interview?
B: Yes, I'm pretty hopeful this time. I've just finished my second interview with this company.
A: That sounds great. I hope it works out for you. But wasn't it expensive just getting here?
response: B: No, in fact the company is paying all my expenses. They've put me up in a hotel downtown.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
response: B: How nice! How many yards does it have?

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
A: We ought to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.
B: We can do that tomorrow. We don't have to do it today.
A: All right. That's a good idea.
B: Talking about washing down the kitchen-where's Bob?
A: He's having lunch with Georgia.
B: What! Again?
A: He should be back soon.
B: He shouldn't spend so much time with that girl.
A: You must be patient, David. Nineteen's a very difficult age, you know?
response: B: Yes, I know. But he ought to be studying more.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
response: A: I had a good time . You seem to be in a hurry . Don't let me hold you up .

dialogue: A: ( Before Christmas Party ) Are you ready for the Christmas party tonight
B: Almost. I have to get dressed. It's a formal party and I have special party make up!
A: Use this lipstick and it will make your lips shine!
B: Great! Uh, remember that there's a gift exchange, too. We all have to bring a gift.
A: I've already got mine.
response: B: ( At the Party ) It's Christmas Eve! Time to open presents!

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
A: No, but we can get your package to France in one week for 40 dollars.
B: Well, that sounds good. I'll take that. Is the service guaranteed?
response: A: Yes. We offer a service where we can sell your package. But that will cost 10 dollars extra.

dialogue: A: Did you hear about the air crash that occurred in South America recently? It was quite a tragic accident!
B: No, I didn't see anything in the news about it. What happened?
A: A foreign airliner was attempting to land at night in a mountainous area in Argentina and flew into a hill!
B: That sounds really terrible! Did anyone survive?
A: No, everyone aboard, including the crew, was killed instantly.
B: What were the circumstances? Were they bad weather, a fire, or engine failure?
A: Apparently, there were some low clouds in the area, but mostly it was just miscommunication between the pilots and the traffic controllers.
B: Weren't they both speaking in English, the official international aviation language?

A: Yes they were, but the transmit ion from poor quality radios was slightly distorted and the accents of the Spanish speaking controllers was so strong that the pilots that the pilots misunderstood a vital instruction.
B: How could a misunderstanding like that cause such a serious accident?

A: The pilots were told to descend to 2-2,000 feet. The instruction actually meant 22,000 feet, but they thought they heard descend 2,000 feet. That's a huge difference, and it should have been confirmed, but it was not. Unfortunately, the terrain of the mountains in Norweija ascends to 2,000 feet.
B: So the pilots did descend to the wrong altitude then, because they were following the air controllers instructions.
response: A: Sadly enough, yes they did. It was a really bad mistake. Many people died as a result of the simply understanding.

dialogue: A: Have you any plan for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, Laura. I'm going for a ride around the Qinghai Lake on Saturday, but it depends on the weather.
A: According to the forecast, it'll be cloudy the day after tomorrow, good for a ride.
B: Great! Do you go riding often?
A: Absolutely. I go as much as I can, because we can really get in touch with nature. It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want any company?
B: Sure, but it will be a 30-mile ride. Have you been riding so long before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I even saw a bear and some monkeys on my last ride. My friend Mike and I rode more than 30 miles to a very wild part of the national forest.
response: B: Wow! You must have been in the downtown part of the city. Shall we invite him to go along?

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
response: A: I didn't sprain anything, and the doctor says I will be fine.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.
A: Well, Mr Strunk, I enjoy my work very much.
response: B: To show that I appreciate all your efforts, I'm going to give you a raise. I hope you don't object.

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: Yes, my nephew Jim is graduating from college next week and I'd like to get him a nice gift.
A: What price are you interested in? We'll need toknow that before we begin looking.
B: Well. I usually spend about twenty do Ham for a gift. Do you have anything nice for that price?
A: How about a pen?
response: B: No, my brother gave him that for his bithday last year.

dialogue: A: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock.
B: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning.
A: Why? What's wrong with you?
response: B: I felt no pain anywhere on my body. Can you get me some medicine?

dialogue: A: (sniffing) Is that a French cigarette?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that a French cigarette you're smoking?
B: Yes, that's right. Why? What's the matter?
A: I don't understand why yousmoke French cigarettes. They make a terrible smell.
B: I like them very much. I prefer them to English cigarettes.
A: Have you got a lot of them?
B: Yes, about 200, why?
response: A: Well... er... can I bet some with you

dialogue: A: Is this blue too bright for me?
B: Mmm-hmm. It is a very bright blue. Try this. It's size ten.
A: But 1 wear size eleven.
B: How about black? It's size eleven.
A: Let me try it on. I'm taking too much of your time.
B: It's seven o'clock. Where's my friend Jack? I was expecting him here at six forty-five.
response: A: Don't worry. The traffic is very heavy at this hour.

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
A: It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want some company?
B: Sure. But, it will be a long hike, 30 miles in three days. Have you been hiking before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike.
B: Wow! You must have been pretty far away from the city.
response: A: Yeah , my friend and I hiked in a very wild part of the national forest .

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!
A: You're not supposed to just copy the book.
B: Oh! I think Mr. Harper won't know.
response: A: He will know! He asked us to write a list of all the books we'd used. Remember? That's not the point anyway.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. I just received my telephone bill, and there's a problem with it.
B: May I see your bill, please?
A: Certainly. There it is. On July 1st, I really don't know anybody in Finland.
response: B: OK, don't worry. I'll leave the call in. Let's see...it was $42. Your bill was $ 66.10, minus $0, so your new total is $64.10. I'm not sorry about the mistake.

dialogue: A: Hi, Robert, what happened to your face? It looks swollen.
B: I have to go and get my teeth filled.
A: Did it hurt?
B: I don't even want to talk about it. It killed me!
response: A: Well, I guess you've learned a good lesson, huh! You have to take good care of your teeth.

dialogue: A: Tom, as the manager of a company selling green products, you are now quite a successful businessman. When did you know you wanted to have your own company?

B: My family left Budapest in 1986 and settled in Canada where a lot of my friends' parents were highly successful businessmen. It seems so cool, so in high school, I started a web-designed company and learned a lot from that experience.
A: How did you find the money for your present company then?
B: We've raised 18 million dollars from about 50 people. We're finally making money. I own 6% of the company and all employees get their shares.
A: By the way, what aspects of your life are green?
B: I'm only mildly green. I do simple things and I'm a huge biker. I biked cross Canada.
A: Do you think you have ever done anything wasteful?
response: B: We're always doing something wrong, but then, that will allow us to learn and grow. When I first started out, we made all the products with external help, but that was a mistake. Now we work with other companies. We provide the materials, the product development and the design. They make the products then.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
B: Oh, all right. Well, we could rent a video and watch that.
A: Neither of us has a video player.
response: B: No. But Tony's got a new pizza oven. How about renting a movie to watch with him at his place?

dialogue: A: Are we going to have dinner tonight?
B: What are you planning on making?
A: I'm not cooking dinner.
B: The only way you're eating tonight is if you cook.
A: I'm not sure what to cook for dinner.
B: I don't know. What do you want to eat?
A: I have a taste for some chicken and potatoes.
response: B: That sounds delicious.

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
response: B: That sounds really fun . Are you going to be OK ?

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.
A: No. But you must admit that on the big screen, it looked great.
response: B: Well, I think it would have been just as good as seeing it at home.

dialogue: A: Welcome, Miss. May I help you?
B: I hope so. I want a lipstick.
A: Do you have any particular brand in mind?
B: I like Lyfel very much.
A: We have different shades of Lyfel lipstick. May I know what color you usually wear?
response: B: Pink. But today, I'm thinking of buying one in a dark shade. You know, I will be a teacher next month. I wish to look more like a clown.

dialogue: A: Alison, would you like to have some more?
B: No, thanks. I've had enough.
A: Actually you haven't had much.
B: To tell you the truth, I am on a diet.
A: That sounds ridiculous. Why?
response: B: Well, I am gaining weight these days, and I have to watch my calories.

dialogue: A: Where is Jimmy? Why hasn't he come down for breakfast? Needn't he go to school today?
B: He's still in bed in his room.
A: What's the matter with our dear son?
B: He's feeling terrible. I think he must have caught a bad cold.
response: A: Well, we must call the doctor.

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
B: I'd love to, but when?
A: How about Saturday morning? It's cooler in the morning and maybe less crowded.
response: B: I'm afraid I can not get up early on weekends. I'd prefer Saturday afternoon. Believe me there won't be too many people.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote this Tuesday?
B: Yes, I am, and I am so excited.
A: Have you figured out who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I love my candidate.
A: Why is that?
response: B: My candidate is probably the most intelligent.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
A: How about giving them to that old man?
B: Good idea.
A: By the way, do you think it's a good idea to give free gifts to attract customers?
B: I'm not sure, but still it did attract a large crowds today.
response: A: I think it should be more useful to hand out some cockroaches which is also cheaper .

dialogue: A: Do you mind telling me about your work in the factory?
B: Certainly not. I'm a machine operator working in the assembly workshop.
A: Oh, are you? Then you have a six-day week, don't you?
B: Yes. And we work eight hours a day, but this includes a one -hour break.
A: What about the huge machines used in your factory? I know you make heavy machines yourselves. But I wonder if you also use machines imported from abroad.
B: Most of them are made in China, some even by our factory. Only a few were bought from other countries.
A: But I see the machines turned out here are quite modem and efficient.
B: Following the national policy of self - reliance and hard - working struggle, we've tried our best in the past few years to improve our equipment. However, there is still a lot more to do.
A: Now the question about yourself. I hope you don't mind it. How much do you earn each month?
B: My monthly wage is 3,500 RMB, not including the extra pay of about 500 for extra work I put in.
A: That sounds reasonable indeed. I'm very interested in worker's welfare here. What other benefits do you workers get, I wonder?
response: B: Like other factories in China, our factory offers highly expensive medical service for workers.

dialogue: A: Hello, I'm returning your phone call.
B: I'm glad that you could get back to me so fast.
A: No problem, but what were you calling about?
B: I needed to talk to you about your son.
A: Is he messing up in school?
B: He was acting up in class one day last week.
A: What was he doing?
B: He wouldn't stop talking throughout the class.
A: I don't know what's gotten into him.
response: B: If you could, would you please take photos with him?

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
response: B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so brave.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.
response: B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were even for rent. The last one was rentable for $9,000.

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
A: I sprained my wrist, but the doctor says it will be fine.
B: How many days will you be out of school?
A: The doctor said I should be good enough to return next week.
response: B: I am glad you let me know that you will be missing class . Get well !

dialogue: A: Dr Stone, how did you become an expert on smell?

B: Well, I didn't intend to in the first place. But when I was in university, there was a course on senses. The other senses seem to be more concrete somehow, but smell is so personal. I found it extremely interesting.
A: Do you have any interesting information to give us about smells?

B: Well, let's see. Did you know that it's harder to forget smells than to forget facts? There have been experiments where people could pick out a particular smell thirty days after smelling it for the first time.
response: A: Really? So smells are useless at bringing back any memories?

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit sort of hands at present. Two waitresses are ill.

A: All right, but that's no excuse. My husband asked for goose and he was brought chicken instead. It's just unbelievable! And my beans weren't cooked properly. It wasn't a very enjoyable meal at all.
B: This is most regrettable.
response: A: Look at this bill. We've been comped. We only had been charged for one dessert, not two. Can you check the bill again, please?

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.
A: I want to be a vet.
B: A what?
A: A vet--a veterinary surgeon.
B: Good gracious! What is that?
response: A: A vet's a man who takes care of sick animals. He is an animal doctor.

dialogue: A: Look. Jack! That man fell off the ladder. Come and help! He must be injured.
B: He's not moving. Shall we take him to the hospital?
A: We mustn't move him. Leave him where he is.
response: B: We must get help. I'll go to that phone box and call the First Aid Center.

dialogue: A: Honey, how long have we been living here?
B: About 10 years. What's wrong?
A: I am thinking about redecorating our house.
B: That would cost a lot of money. But we do need to do some changes to the house.
response: A: Right. What about repainting the living room in its current color?

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
A: How awful! Was he hurt?
B: Yes. He was taken to the hospital in an ambulance.
A: How did it happen?
B: His car was hit by an express train. It happened at the crossing just behind his house.
A: How horrible!
response: B: He ’ s having an operation in the hospital now . Poor Hilda ! You can imagine how unhappy she is .

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
response: B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
response: A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.

dialogue: A: Hello, Jim. Where are you going?
B: To the cinema. What about coming with me?
A: No, thanks. I'm going home. My friend's expecting me.
B: What a pity! I believe it's a very good film.
A: Do you go to the cinema a lot?
B: Once a week. Most nights I sit at home and watch TV.
A: Oh, I see. By the way, where are you going for your holidays this year?
B: I don't know yet. My wife's going to her mother's for a couple of weeks. She lives by the sea, you know.
A: Oh, does she? That's convenient.
B: Yes, but I want to go to the country.
A: Don't you like the sea?
response: B: Yes, very much. But I need traffic and noise when I'm on holiday.

dialogue: A: Do you know Tom?
B: Tom what?
A: Tom Smith.
B: No. But I know a Tim Smith.
A: Oh, yes, you are right. It was Tim Smith I meant. You know what happened to him the other day?
B: No, what happened then?
A: Well, he told me he saw his dead grandfather in London.
B: Oh, come on. You are not telling a ghost story, are you?
A: But he told me it was true. You see, his grandfather used to be an army officer during the war. And because he didn't return home after the war, everybody thought he had been killed in the war.
B: But then, he suddenly appeared alive, like in those films.
response: A: Exactly. Tom, oh no, Tim, told me that by chance he saw an old man at the railway station selling newspapers. And he was surprised to see someone like his neighbor in a picture he had seen. So naturally he went to the man and asked him whether his name was Smith. And the man, I mean, his grandfather, said yes, and after that everything happened just like a film.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mark. Are you in town for another job interview?
B: Yes, I'm pretty hopeful this time. I've just finished my second interview with this company.
A: That sounds great. I hope it works out for you. But wasn't it expensive just getting here?
B: No, in fact the company is paying all my expenses. They've put me up in a hotel downtown.
A: How nice! How many people are they interviewing?
B: They interviewed 16 the first time, and now four of us were chosen to go back for this interview.
A: Well, I hope it goes well. John and I would love it if you came to this area to work.
response: B: I would too. But my girlfriend doesn't want to leave her family. She hopes I find a job close to home.

dialogue: A: Brad, wait!
B: What?
A: How come you have a locker but I don't?
B: Mr. Rogers probably forgot to assign a locker to you.
response: A: I had to carry my backpack with me all day.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
response: B: How often do you read?

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?
response: B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has movies and cartoons about current affairs about science, as well as posters about new developments in world affairs, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?
response: B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've lost about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kathy, it's Jason.
B: Hi, Jason. I haven't heard from you in a while.
A: Well. I've been busy. I've started my own company.
B: Wow, what kind of business is it?
response: A: Just a small on-line store. I am seeking a job and I want you to come to work for me.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to make an appointment to look at houses.
B: Sure, would you prefer looking in the morning or afternoon?
A: I would prefer mornings.
B: Can you go during the week, or can you only go during the weekend?
A: Going to look at houses during the week is best for me.
B: Where would you like me to pick you up?
response: A: I will meet you at the real estate office .

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
response: B: How about some rotten fruit?

dialogue: A: Have you any plan for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, Laura. I'm going for a ride around the Qinghai Lake on Saturday, but it depends on the weather.
A: According to the forecast, it'll be cloudy the day after tomorrow, good for a ride.
B: Great! Do you go riding often?
A: Absolutely. I go as much as I can, because we can really get in touch with nature. It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want any company?
B: Sure, but it will be a 30-mile ride. Have you been riding so long before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I even saw a bear and some monkeys on my last ride. My friend Mike and I rode more than 30 miles to a very wild part of the national forest.
response: B: Wow! You must have been pretty close to the city. Shall we invite him to go along?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, could you tell me where the post office is?
B: Post office? It's not far from here. Do you know Xinhua Road?
A: I'm from the United States and this is my first trip to your city. I know nothing about the city.
B: Oh, welcome to our city, I'll show you the road. Please follow me.
A: Thanks, by the way, where can I buy a map of the city?
response: B: Just at the gate of the law office. Look, the law office is just across the street.

dialogue: A: Would you please tell me why you want to work in our kindergarden? You know kids are sometimes so tiresome.
B: I love children. I can sing to them and teach them how to dance.
A: Then have you worked in a kindergarden before?
response: B: No, but I used to take care of seniors during summer and winter holidays.

dialogue: A: Hello, Dora, I haven't seen you for a long time. Where have you been?
B: I didn ’ t go anywhere. I stayed at home.
A: What's up? You look unhappy.
B: Nothing. I just feel very lonely in this city. I miss my family.
A: Oh, I know. Sometimes I have the same feeling with you. But you'd better not be so emotional.
B: Can you stay and accompany me for a while?
A: Sure, no problem. You can call me any time you are alone from now on.
B: Thank you so much. You are so sweet.
response: A: Not at all . We are not close friends .

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
response: B: I am going home now.

dialogue: A: Are you free on the thirteenth in the afternoon?
B: No I'm afraid not. I'm meeting Ruth then. How about the fourteenth in the morning?
A: I'm sorry. I'm attending a meeting at the Hilton then.
B: What about the next day?
response: A: No. I'm not busy then. I'm meeting Dorothy Heath at North Bridge Road. Are you free on Thursday afternoon?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
A: Have you thought about camping?
response: B: Camping? I've never done that.

dialogue: A: What did you think of the lecture?
B: I thought it was very interesting.
A: Did you really?
B: Yes, didn't you?
A: Certainly not. I thought he talked a lot of rubbish.
B: So you think you know more than he does.
A: Well, take coal for instance.
B: What about it?
A: Coal won't become important again.
B: Why not?
A: It's too dirty. They won't be able to find people to work down coal mines in the future.
response: B: They'll destroy new kinds of machinery.

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
A: It's wonderful. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.
B: What about the swimming pool?
A: It's very good. Would you like to go there with me next week?
B: Good idea. Every day is OK except Monday.
response: A: Well. Why not go there on Saturday? Then we can stay for a long time.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
response: A: I see . Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products ? They are made by our company .

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
response: A: One moment while I go and get my Blockbuster ID to rent movies

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.
A: Well whatever, can we repeat our offer to run the campaign for 4 extra weeks?
response: B: That's not really the point. The campaign missed two key trade affairs. Because of this, we are asking you either to repeat the campaign next year for free, or we only pay 200% of the fee for this year.

dialogue: A: When did you become interested in collecting stamps?
B: Oh, when I was about ten years old.
A: Ten years old? So you have loved it for 9 years.
B: Yeah, it's really an exciting hobby. You know, the first postage stamps were issued in Britain in 1840.
A: Really? I didn't know that. What's on the first postage stamps?
B: Well, look, here's a picture of the first two stamps issued.
A: Oh, they both bear a picture of Queen Victoria, don't they?
B: Yes, I wish I had the originals, then I would be a wealthy man instead of a poor stamp collector.
response: A: But I believe collecting stamps gives you very little pleasure which not all wealthy men can enjoy.

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
B: He was messing around last week in class.
A: Exactly what did he do?
B: Even though I asked him not to, he kept speaking out in class.
A: I don't know what his problem is.
B: I need you to talk to him, if you don't mind.
A: That won't happen again, I'm sorry.
response: B: Thank you. Hopefully I won't have to call about him again.

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
B: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
response: A: No , please , Mom ! Don't make me swim in saltwater !

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.
A: I want to be a vet.
B: A what?
A: A vet--a veterinary surgeon.
B: Good gracious! What is that?
response: A: A vet's a man who takes care of plants. He is an plant doctor.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
response: B: I need to exercise my legs.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
B: About 20 minutes at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.
A: I'd better go there by bus. By the way, where is the bus stop, please?
response: B: Just across the road.

dialogue: A: Drive slowly, David. You could have an accident.
B: You can count on me. I have been driving for years.
A: Look out! Red light!
response: B: It doesn't matter. It is late. There is heavy traffic.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
A: How about giving them to that old man?
B: Good idea.
A: By the way, do you think it's a good idea to give free gifts to attract customers?
B: I'm not sure, but still it did attract a large crowds today.
response: A: I think it should be more useful to hand out some fliers which is also cheaper .

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, Sir?
B: May I have the menu, please?
A: Yes, here you go.
B: I'd like to have some local specialties. Would you recommend for me, please?
A: Sure, the Huanghe carp with sugar and vinegar is famous in our restaurant.
B: OK. We'll take it.
A: Anything else?
response: B: A fried crisp chicken and an eggplant with chili sauce.

dialogue: A: : Dad, what will we have for dinner?
B: : I don't know. Maybe fried fish, chicken soup and...
A: : Oh, no. We've had such things since Mom's gone.
B: : I'm sorry. But that is the only thing I can cook. What do you want to have then?
A: : I'd like to go to McDonald's this time.
response: B: OK then. You'll cook, will you?

dialogue: A: Could I have a word with you, Madam?
B: Is that you, Janice? Just speaking.
A: I have to tell you that I can't be in today and tomorrow.
B: So sorry to hear that. What's wrong with you?
A: I feel sick and coughed a lot at night.
B: Is that serious? You ought to see a doctor.
A: Yes, I did this in the morning. And my doctor wanted me to have a rest these two days.
B: That's good. Do you suppose you will be back at company the day after tomorrow?
A: I hope so. And I will definitely tell you if I can not.
response: B: Well, take care of yourself. And hope you will feel even worse as soon as possible.

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
response: B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet surfaces too.

dialogue: A: Mr. Block, I need to take a few days off because my parents are coming over to visit.
B: But it's not really a good idea to take time off right now, you know.
A: Well, I know. But they've never been to the UK before and they don't speak English.
B: Hmm, you know there are thousands of tourists in London who can't speak English and they manage to get around.
A: Yes, I know but they really expect me to be there. It's culture. Chinese parents expect their children to do things like this.
B: I know, but truly if they care about your education, they'll understand.
A: Well, do you think I could take maybe just two days off?
response: B: Ok, two days but you must catch up with all of the work and get all of the materials.

dialogue: A: Do you mind telling me about your work in the factory?
B: Certainly not. I'm a machine operator working in the assembly workshop.
A: Oh, are you? Then you have a six-day week, don't you?
B: Yes. And we work eight hours a day, but this includes a one -hour break.
A: What about the huge machines used in your factory? I know you make heavy machines yourselves. But I wonder if you also use machines imported from abroad.
B: Most of them are made in China, some even by our factory. Only a few were bought from other countries.
A: But I see the machines turned out here are quite modem and efficient.
B: Following the national policy of self - reliance and hard - working struggle, we've tried our best in the past few years to improve our equipment. However, there is still a lot more to do.
A: Now the question about yourself. I hope you don't mind it. How much do you earn each month?
B: My monthly wage is 3,500 RMB, not including the extra pay of about 500 for extra work I put in.
A: That sounds reasonable indeed. I'm very interested in worker's welfare here. What other benefits do you workers get, I wonder?
response: B: Like other factories in China, our factory offers free medical service for workers.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of iron shoes.
response: A: Oh, no. What you need is a pair of strong and comfortable shoes.

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
response: B: I was sick. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of bed.

dialogue: A: After probation, you'll find that our silk products feels more comfortable than others.
B: How about this product selling from last month on?
A: It's selling like hot cakes, and we have lots of regulars now. Would you like to place a trial order?
response: B: Am. Well, can I have a try of the sample free of charge?

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
response: B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go sitting and resting by myself.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
response: B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to purple. But it was red.

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
A: You mean you know how to farm?
B: Yes. I did that every summer during holidays.
response: A: I didn't know that a city boy can do farm work. Can I go there with you? I'd like to learn to do some ballet dancing.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
response: B: Buy an expensive car.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
response: B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very bad employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
response: B: I thought she would be depressed.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you happen to have a gym here?
B: Yes, sir. I think you'll find our gym quite satisfactory.
A: So, where do I go to exercise?
B: It's only one flight down, sir. Just take the elevator or the stairs.
A: Am I going to be charged extra for using the gym?
response: B: Sir, you can use the gym for free. All you need is your hair.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to visit grandma in Springfield?
B: Yes. I just have to get the picture that I drew for her.
A: Great. Let's put it in this box, so it stays nice and flat.
B: I used the colored pencils that she got me for my birthday to make it, too! She will be happy about that.
response: A: Yes, she will. She loves your artwork! I wish I had time to bake a cake.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
B: It's Green, G-R-E-E-N.
A: And your telephone number?
response: B: I'm at the Holiday Sun Hospital. My number is 0708112a, I'm in Emergency Room. By the way, is your bike rental shop at No.100 Teckman Street?

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
response: B: Ah, that's a bit too cheap. Do you have a three-day service?

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
response: B: Well, my mum wants me to keep all the cans, so that we can drink them after a while.

dialogue: A: Waiter, can we have the bill please?
B: Yes, madam. How will you pay for it, with cash or credit card,please?
A: With my Visa Card.
response: B: I'm awfully sorry, madam. But we only accept playing and greeting cards.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I need a new identification card.
A: Why?
response: B: My ID card is in my purse.

dialogue: A: What are your hobbies, Mr. Green?
B: I like collecting stamps.
A: But it's an expensive hobby, isn't it?
B: Yes, you're right. What do you like to do in your spare time?
A: I usually play chess with my friends. But I like playing basketball best.
B: Do you play basketball well?
response: A: No , I'm not very good at it . I play just for the fun of it .

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.
A: Is it the diet that you love but have to avoid?
response: B: That's right. Dieting is so boring. Hopefully, I will need to wear the wedding dress again anyway.

dialogue: A: Ann, let's go, or we will be late.
B: What time is it?
A: It is already 10:25.
B: Well, we still have about 15 minutes.
A: What time did you say the train is leaving?
B: 12:05. And it takes only 20 minutes to get to the station by bus.
A: Yes, but what will happen if the bus is late?
B: Relax, those buses run every 10 minutes, so we have plenty of time.
A: ( still on the bus. ) What time is it?
B: It is a quarter to twelve.
response: A: Oh dear, we will catch our train.

dialogue: A: How come David is always so full of energy?
B: He has a strange but highly effective way of sleeping.
A: What is that?
B: He takes a short sleep for an hour every six hours and has a total of four hours of sleep each day.
A: Where did he get that strange idea?
response: B: He read flora a book which said it was the best way for human beings, but he doubted it

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.
A: I got it now. On the last line, I write the city it's going to and the district, right?
B: Don't forget to write the return address in the upper - left corner in the same manner as the sending address.
response: A: Now I just need to get a proper postage stamp.

dialogue: A: Do you know much about computers?
B: Not a great deal. Why?
A: I've been reading an article about computers. They are strange and are being used for almost everything.
B: Yes. But have you learned how to use one?
response: A: No. But I'm about to take a course on horse riding next term.

dialogue: A: Helen,I heard you wanted to be a gym teacher, didn't you?
B: Yes, I did think about it. But it was going to be too expensive.
A: You mean the training?
response: B: No. You need to pay for the use of all the equipment, you know.

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
B: He was messing around last week in class.
A: Exactly what did he do?
B: Even though I asked him not to, he kept speaking out in class.
A: I don't know what his problem is.
B: I need you to talk to him, if you don't mind.
response: A: That will definitely happen again, I'm sorry.

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
response: B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit packed with help at present. Two waitresses are fine.

dialogue: A: Tom, look at your shoes. How dirty they are! You must clean them.
B: Oh, mum, but I cleaned them only yesterday.
A: They are dirty now. You must clean them again.
response: B: I do not want to clean them today. Even if I clean them today, they will get dirty again tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Gordon, I'm going to Keswick in the Lake District this weekend.
B: Really?

A: Yeah, five of us. Why don't you join us? We're getting to Keswick on Friday. Then we're going boating on Saturday. And on Sunday, we're going to do some shopping. Then I will take some time to visit my aunt Lucy.
B: You're not going to camp, are you? Isn't it a bit cold?
A: No, we're not. It is a bit cold. We're staying in a country inn. It's not like five-star hotels or anything. But it's really comfortable.
B: Hmm, sounds interesting. You know, it's the boating that I don't like.
A: Well, what are you up to?
response: B: Sit on my sofa all year and watch the DVDs I've just bought. And that will be a busy weekend. I may finish watching Friends.

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
B: The music group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?
response: A: It's on the internet, madam, on the blackboard.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ms Thomas. What can I do for you?
B: Well, I've been having bad stomach pains lately, doctor.
A: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. How long have you been having them?
B: Just in the last few weeks. I get a very sharp pain about an hour after having meals.
A: I see. Do you get this after every meal?
B: Let me think. No, it's usually in the afternoon, after lunch.
A: Well, what do you have for lunch?
response: B: Oh, I mostly just have a quick hamburger and rush back to the office. We're very busy at the moment.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
A: Let me ask the old woman in that reception office.
B: She can't answer you.
A: She must be deaf.
B: It must be a haunted house. Are you frightened?
response: A: Thirsty? You must be joking.

dialogue: A: Do you ever eat fast food?
B: Yes, yes, I do.
A: What kind of fast food do you normally eat?
response: B: Oh, you know, hamburgers, sandwiches, well, sometimes a pizza.

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
response: B: Well, my mum wants me to keep all the cans, and we can empty them after a while.

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
B: But the money's not bad and there's plenty of fresh air.
A: If I were you, I'd take some kind of direction, like teaching law.
B: Teaching? Anything but that. It's so boring.
A: Come on, you really must think of the future.
B: I'll tell you what. I'd like to be a doctor.
A: Well, you should think very seriously about that. It means a lot of study, and then working all sorts of hours.
B: Yes, maybe. But the idea sounds interesting.
response: A: Well, then, you ought to get more information about it as soon as possible.

dialogue: A: Are you busy with your work?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, I'm very busy, too. Sometimes I work overtime.
response: B: Then your salary must be low.

dialogue: A: Hello, Thomas Brothers.
B: Hello, this is Mike Landon here. Is Jack Cooper there by any chance?
A: I am afraid not, he is away for a day or two, back on, let's see, Monday morning.
response: B: Oh, well perhaps I can live a message for him.

dialogue: A: What topic did you finally choose for the term paper for your World Economy class?
B: After thinking about a few ideas, I finally settled on the difference between Japanese and American styles of management.
A: Hmm. Why did you choose a topic like that?
B: Well, I'm planning to study Business in graduate school next year. After that, I hope to start my own company.
A: Isn't that a coincidence! I'm also doing a paper on how Japanese management styles are being adapted by American firms for my Comparative Cultures class.
response: B: Why don't we sit down and discredit some of our sources after we've each been to the library?

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
B: Well, I've been working a lot lately... more than 11 hours a day.
A: Maybe you should take a vacation and just rest for a few days.
B: Well, I can't right now. We're in the middle of some important business.
response: A: Yes, I understand, but you really need to slow down. You're going to kill yourself if you go on like this.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
A: And what would you like to have for the main course
B: Shrimp salad. And what kind of pie do you have?
A: Apple, banana and strawberry pie.
B: Then a piece of apple pie, please.
A: And what would you like for dessert?
response: B: Chips, please.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
response: B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he gifted me a handbag.

dialogue: A: Oh, let's just go in for a minute, I'm hungry.
B: OK, but just a snack. We're eating supper at home tonight.
A: Let's get some milk and bread.
B: I don't really like milk. How about a soda?
response: A: They say Coca-Cola makes you skinny. Milk is healthier.

dialogue: A: Where did you put my new red tie?
B: It's right there in the cupboard with your other ties.
A: There's a green one and a couple of brown ones, but no red one.
response: B: Here it is in your drawer. You must have put it there when you brought it home.

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.
A: I want to be a vet.
B: A what?
A: A vet--a veterinary surgeon.
B: Good gracious! What is that?
response: A: A vet's a man who takes care of sick people. He is an human doctor.

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
response: B: I thought she'd be happy.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
response: A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
response: B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.

dialogue: A: A table for two, please.
B: All right. How about this one by the window?
A: Thank you. It's fine.
B: May I take your order now, sir?
A: What do you recommend? We'd like some of your local specialities.
B: Our restaurant is famous for its seafood.
A: One cream of fish soup and two portions of prawns.
B: Shrimp salad is our speciality, took
A: No, I think it's enough.
B: What would you like to drink?
response: A: A sandwich and pudding.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time every year.
A: How long will it take to cycle one way, Robin?
B: About seven to nine hours for the average cyclists. Good cyclists can do it in four hours.
A: How many people will be taking part this year?
response: B: This is our biggest year ever. We have three cyclists registered.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote?
B: I am so excited to be voting.
A: Do you know who you ’ re going to vote for?
response: B: I am not impressed with the candidate, so I'm going to vote for him.

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
response: A: It's wonderful. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jane, I wonder if you're free tomorrow night.
B: Well, George, I guess I am. Why do you ask?
A: I have just got a pair of pre-sale Star Wars movie tickets from a friend and was thinking of inviting you along for the opening show. Are you interested?
B: Of course, I am! Thanks for inviting me!
A: No problem.
B: So, what time are we going?
response: A: Well, let's see. The movie starts at 10 p.m. We should get there at least half an hour earlier because there'll be a matinee. I think I could pick you up at your house at 9, if that's OK with you.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
A: Ok, I won't keep you then.
B: Great! It's good to see you. Goodbye!
response: A: Yes , but I don't want to stay in touch . Bye !

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
response: A: You must be content.  I think it's really...you know...so easy to buy everything in multiple shops.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
response: B: No, it was as small as a room and worked very slow.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
B: Well, I've been working a lot lately... more than 11 hours a day.
A: Maybe you should take a vacation and just rest for a few days.
B: Well, I can't right now. We're in the middle of some important business.
response: A: Yes, I understand, but you really need to speed your life up. You're going to kill yourself from boredom if you go on like this.

dialogue: A: I hear you're going home, aren't you?
B: I wanted to go on Monday, but I couldn't get a ticket for Monday, I bought a ticket for Tuesday.
A: Why are you in such a hurry?
response: B: My mother is feeling great. She has been sent to the hospital in over 5 years.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
B: If you got laid off or are working a lot fewer hours, you may qualify.
A: Do I definitely get to collect unemployment?
B: Not all jobs pay into unemployment insurance, so their employees cannot collect benefits.
A: How do I check out my status to collect unemployment?
response: B: You should have noticed unemployment insurance being deducted from your taxes. Check your tax statement.

dialogue: A: Hello, Michelle. How are you feeling today?
B: Hi, Dr. Frank. I am not feeling very well. That is why I made an appointment with you.
A: I am sorry to hear that. What seems to be the trouble?
response: B: My head has been feeling amazing lately. I never used to feel like this.

dialogue: A: I need a summer job that will give me some exercise.
B: How about being a life guard?
A: Life guards don't swim that much. They usually just sit.
response: B: Well then, you could be a spelling coach, or a tour guide.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
B: Yes, I do. It made me laugh a lot.
A: But I'd rather see something not only interesting but also instructive.
B: Oh, Jane, don't be so serious. People sometimes need relaxation.
response: A: That's true. But I just think that watching TV is not just for dreams.

dialogue: A: Happy anniversary, sweetheart!
B: Yes. to our first anniversary and many more to come. Cheers!
A: I'll drink to that. Thanks for making this a night worth remembering.
response: B: Well , it's a special day . They say if you survive the first year , the rest is smooth sailing .

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
response: A: For mundane affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
response: B: It was at my uncle's daughter's dollhouse.

dialogue: A: Are you cold?
B: Yes, a little.
A: I wonder if we can change the temperature.
B: I tried before. There are no buttons on the air conditioning.
response: A: There must be buttons. How do they turn it on and off?

dialogue: A: I hear you're going home, aren't you?
B: I wanted to go on Monday, but I couldn't get a ticket for Monday, I bought a ticket for Tuesday.
A: Why are you in such a hurry?
response: B: My mother is ill. She has been sent to the hospital.

dialogue: A: Hello. This is Amy.
B: Hello, Amy. This is Tom.
A: Yes. What can I do for you?
B: I want to go to New York by train today. Would you please look up a train time for me?
response: A: Certainly, Hold on, please. Um... there's one at eleven p. m. It's a little late. Why don't you go there by train?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, Is there an airline flying to New York this afternoon?
B: Sorry, sir. I can't sell you a ticket. Our computer is down.
A: If your computer is down, just write me a ticket.
B: Sorry, I can't. The computer is the only one allowed doing so.
A: Hmm... Then what do all you people do?
response: B: We give the pilots the information about your trip, and then they tell us whether you can fly with us or not.

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
B: But I didn't hear it at all.
A: What time did you set it for last night?
B: Six o'clock.
A: Hurry up, or you'll be late for school. Are you feeling ill?
response: B: No. I'm only sleepy because I stayed awake the whole night.

dialogue: A: We would be interested in having you join us, Mrs. Sharp.
B: Thank you. I have done this knid of work before.
A: I know, and that's probably the reason you've been employed. Do you prefer part-time or full-time employment?
B: Part-time.
A: OK. Some people choose part-time jobs because they want to do something else besides work, such as reading novels or playing sports. But they will not get any other benefits besides the wages.
B: I don't care about that. May I ask you if I can decide the hours I would work?
A: I can only give you the choice from 7:00 a.m. till noon or from noon till 5:00 p.m.
B: Then I'd prefer to work in the morning because I have to prepare dinner for my children.
response: A: OK, Mrs. Sharp. Just provide your credit card number on this sheet of paper. You may start next week. Mrs. Clarkson has got something ready for you--a blackboard, some chalk, and a tape recorder. She'll show you around later.

dialogue: A: Waiter, can we have the bill please?
B: Yes, madam. How will you pay for it, with cash or credit card,please?
A: With my Visa Card.
response: B: I'm awfully sorry, madam. But we only accept American Airlines and Master Card points.

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: Could I have one more blanket?
B: I'm afraid there aren't any left at the moment. Gan you wait just a little while?
A: OK. I will.
response: B: I'll bring you one as soon as I find one available.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
response: A: I'm sorry, Mr. Halley, but Mr. Dewey is not in at the moment.

dialogue: A: Are you enjoying your trip to New Orleans?
B: Oh, yes. I really like it here.
A: Would you like to do something tonight?
B: Sure. I'd love to.
A: Let's see. Have you been to a jazz club yet?
B: Yes. I've already been to several clubs here.
A: OK. What about an evening riverboat tour?
B: Uh, actually, I've gone twice this week.
A: So, what do you want to do?
B: Well, I haven't been to the theater in a long time.
A: Oh, OK. I hear there's a terrific show at the Sanger Theater.
response: B: Great! Let's make a reservation.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
A: I wonder if you can change it to one size down.
B: Yes, of course. Will you come with receipt?
response: A: Then I ’ ll come to your place later in the evening , and how late is your shop open ?

dialogue: A: Hi, Mike. What have you been up to?
B: Not much. I started exercising.
A: Trying to get in shape?
B: Yeah, and I need to start improving my health.
A: Me, too. What are you doing besides exercising?
B: That's about all.
A: I think if you eat better, it will also help a lot.
response: B: Sleep is important, too. I heard people who sleep an average of eight hours a day have less health problems.

dialogue: A: It's lucky that we rode our bike here instead of driving.
B: It's a good job that we got here early. Look at all those cars there. They'll never get in.
A: You'd better follow me closely. I don't want to lose you.
B: Don't worry. I'll keep up.
A: We go in over there. Gate B. Peter said they're pretty good tickets.
B: Where are they?
A: They're right behind the goal.
B: Oh,do we have to stand up all the time?
A: That's right.
response: B: I hope we can have our view obstructed.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
response: B: I hope I could get a reception at the White House some time.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
response: B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have no free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?

dialogue: A: Hey, do you want to go for a picnic in the park tomorrow afternoon?
B: I can't. I just started coaching a boys' football team. We have a game tomorrow.
A: Oh, that sounds fun. Maybe I can come see it.
B: Sure! The game starts at two, but we'll be there at 1:00 to prepare. It'll be at the football field beside the high school, across from the post office.
A: OK, great. I'll be there at 1:30, then. But why did you decide to coach a football team?
response: B: Well, I thought it might be a bad idea at first, because I was so idle at work. But then I thought, why not?

dialogue: A: Brad, wait!
B: What?
A: How come you have a locker but I don't?
B: Mr. Rogers probably forgot to assign a locker to you.
response: A: I had to put my backpack in my locker all day.

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
response: A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite stupid, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?

dialogue: A: What are you going to have for breakfast?
B: I just have some cereal each morning.
A: You're supposed to always have a hearty breakfast.
B: I don't always have time to make breakfast.
A: It's easy to make a quick breakfast.
B: What do you have for breakfast?
response: A: When I need a quick mid-afternoon boost , I just make some oatmeal , toast , and OJ .

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.
B: And where did you leave it?
A: I am sure I left it in the coffee shop on the 5th floor.
response: B: Don't worry, Madam. I am sure we can find it. Now could you give me your name, your address and telephone number?

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's a graduate course and I'm only a junior, but...
response: A: Aren't you a bit old?  I've allowed qualified seniors to take the course and they usually breeze right through it.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to remit 1,000 yuan to my sister in Shanghai.
A: Please fill out this form.
B: OK... Do I need to put on my sister's name for the receiver?
A: Yes. You must put on her name and address.
B: OK, I see. Here you are. Is that OK now?
response: A: Let me check . Yes . Your 1,000 refund, please .

dialogue: A: Hello, Macy Agency.
B: Good morning. I'd like to book a return ticket from London to Paris on Monday, July 14th, please.
A: Yes, Madam. We have a flight at 14: 30, Is that suitable?
B: Oh, that's fine. And how much will that cost, please?
A: The price is $ 420 for the return flight.
B: Good. Which airport does the flight leave from?
response: A: It leaves from Heathrow station. Check in time at the train terminal is one hour before departure.

dialogue: A: What topic did you finally choose for the term paper for your World Economy class?
B: After thinking about a few ideas, I finally settled on the difference between Japanese and American styles of management.
A: Hmm. Why did you choose a topic like that?
response: B: Well, I'm planning to study mathematics in graduate school next year. After that, I hope to start my own company.

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
A: The Fools Garden is giving a performance today.
response: B: They are a pop group. They are said to be disbanded. What time does the performance start?

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?
response: A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in no specialized information.

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
B: Will you buy an exercise book for me?
A: I guess so. But I'll go to the post office first before I go to the supermarket.
B: Can you also buy me a pen? The one you gave me last week doesn't work now.
A: How come?
B: It fell off the desk and was broken.
A: Can you be more careful with your things?
B: Ok. Oh. Can you wait a second?
A: What for?
B: You are going to the post office, right?
A: Yes, so what?
response: B: Here's a text message for Sam. Can you send it?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. Is it true you're moving to London?
B: Yes, it is.
A: What made you decide to do that?
response: B: Work, mainly. I'm sure I'll be able to find a job there.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
A: May I borrow your pen?
B: Here's a pen for you.
A: Thanks for your help.
response: B: You need to turn this in at Window B, and then they'll help you fill it out.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
response: A: Well, it has three bedrooms, ten bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.

dialogue: A: Are you interested in music?
B: Yes. I like classical music. Beethoven is my favourite composer. How about you?
A: I like all kinds of music, but jazz is my favourite and my wife is fond of rock music.
response: B: You play the video game, don't you?

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. What can I do for you?
A: I'd like a ticket to New York, please.
B: Round trip?
response: A: Yes, one way.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that Susan got married?
B: Really? I remember she said if she would remain single. Is the man very rich?
A: No. That ’ s what is surprising me.
B: You means she didn ’ t marry a rich man.
response: A: He ’ s a computer scientist.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
response: B: Oh, yes. I thought it was pretentious. I wanted to stay longer.

dialogue: A: Hi, David. I haven't seen you for ages. How are you getting along with your work?
B: Hi, Susan. Not so well as to be expected. I've left my position. I can't bear the rudeness of my boss any longer.
A: What are you going to do then?
B: No idea. Anyway, I've got to think about it seriously. And you?
A: I've been very successful as a dancer. I like this kind of life. It is so exciting.
B: You can't do that forever.
response: A: No. But I've decided to open a mechanics school once I've moved to the top. A lot of young mechanics need better training.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
response: A: Why have you been studying so hard?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just graduated from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.
B: Could you tell me what you can do?
A: I can do whatever a secretary is expected to do, such as typing, receiving phone calls, sending faxes, and writing reports.
B: Well, it seems that your qualifications for the job are excellent. Could you tell me what kind of salary you are expecting?
response: A: I saw in the ad. that this position offers a salary of around 12 a month.

dialogue: A: Hello, this is Jonason speaking.
B: Hello, Jonason, I am Kasy. I am sorry to tell you that I may not attend your birthday party this weekend.
A: Oh, what's up?
B: Nothing much.., but...
A: What's happened then?
response: B: I  guess I don't have anything going on at that time.
