dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. White. I wonder if you could spare a few minutes. I'd like to ask you a few questions.
B: Well, I can spare you a few minutes, but I'm very busy preparing for our exhibition, you know.
A: Just a few questions. Where is it going to be held?
B: It's going to be held in the art gallery.
A: Who is opening it?
B: It's going to be opened by Mr.Smith.
A: It's quite a big exhibition, isn't it?
response: B: Yes with only the works from a few high school students displayed.

dialogue: A: What can I do for you?
B: I'd like to exchange this sweater.
A: What seems to be the matter?
B: Well, you see I got this as a birthday present, but it's the wrong size, and what's more, I really don't like the colour.
response: A: Do you have the money?

dialogue: A: Have you been to exhibitions in your spare time?
B: Yes, a lot of times. I like exhibitions-exhibitions about famous people: dancers, actors, you know?
A: Mm, and what about a folk concert? Have you ever been to one of them?
B: No. I don't like folk music very much.
A: What about the opera?
B: No, never. I don't really like the opera. It is a bit too heavy for me.
A: A pop concert?
response: B: Yes. I saw Madonna once. She was fantastic-she is a really terrible dancer.

dialogue: A: Did you hear how cold it got last night?
B: I heard the radio announcer say it was 18 degrees below zero.
A: It was so cold this morning. I could hardly start my car.
B: My car didn't want to start either at first.
response: A: Don't you have a hangar for your car?

dialogue: A: Waiter, can we have the bill please?
B: Yes, madam. How will you pay for it, with cash or credit card,please?
A: With my Visa Card.
response: B: I'm awfully sorry, madam. But we only accept American Express and Master Card.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. Er, I'm phoning about the job that was in the paper last night.
A: Oh, yes. Could you tell me your name?
B: Oh, Jerry Lynn.
A: Well, what exactly is it that interests you about the job?
B: I just thought that it was right up my street, you know.
A: Really? Could you tell me a little about yourself?
B: I've been working abroad doing secretarial work. Previous to that I was at university. I've got a degree in English.
A: Do you have any special skills?
response: B: Well, I'm embarrassed to admit I don't speak any foreign languages.

dialogue: A: Would you like to come to the cinema tonight?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair tonight.
A: OK. What about tomorrow night?
B: I can't go tomorrow night, either.
A: Why not?
response: B: I've got to wash my hair again.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order? May I suggest a veal.
B: No, I'll have the fish please.
A: The chicken is also nice.
B: No, I want the fish.
A: Our special tonight is lobster.
B: Thank you, but I prefer the fish
A: Perhaps you'd enjoy the lamb
B: No, I like the fish.
response: A: You'll have whatever I say.

dialogue: A: Have you booked the airplane tickets to spain yet?
B: Well, I thought we should go traveling by ship for a change, so I booked two ship tickets instead.
A: You should have told me or discussed it with me.
B: I wanted to give you a surprise. Don't you like the idea?
A: I like it all right, but it takes much more time to travel by ship than by plane.
B: We have time, don't we? Every time we went on a trip, we were always tied down by schedules. This time will be different. We don't have to rush.
A: You're right. This is our first trip since you retired. We can travel as long as we like.
B: We'll have an easy trip and enjoy every minute.
response: A: Have you bought your loan cheques yet?

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
response: A: Why is a computer so useless?

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam.
B: Good morning. I wonder if you can help. I've lost my coat.
A: Where did you lose it, madam?
B: Er... I left it on a bus yesterday morning.
A: Can you describe it? Is it a raincoat?
response: B: No. It's a short white overcoat. It's got a zipper, and one of those thin furry collars that keep your ears warm. It's a very bad coat, actually.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for myself.
A: Oh? Did you talk with her about it?
response: B: I haven't tried, and it didn't work.

dialogue: A: Hello, Macy Agency.
B: Good morning. I'd like to book a return ticket from London to Paris on Monday, July 14th, please.
A: Yes, Madam. We have a flight at 14: 30, Is that suitable?
B: Oh, that's fine. And how much will that cost, please?
A: The price is $ 420 for the return flight.
B: Good. Which airport does the flight leave from?
A: It leaves from Heathrow Airport. Check in time is one hour before departure.
response: B: My name is Susan Smith. Can I sell the ticket tomorrow morning?

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
A: Nobody to take care of her?
response: B: My father travels a lot to many countries and he is doing business in Dubai now. I never have to do anything for my mom at home.

dialogue: A: Are you ready for the big competition today, Todd? The winner gets two tickets to the Sydney Olympics!
B: Steve, I was born ready! I ’ m going to blow you guys off the treadmill today.
A: We ’ Ve still got a lot of time before we have to start running.
response: B: Let ’ s hit the whirlpool for a bit. It ’ ll help me sleep well.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
response: A: One moment while I go and get my sunglasses.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
response: A: So you are thinking of making change for hundred-dollar bills,are you?

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
A: Let me ask the old woman in that reception office.
B: She can't answer you.
response: A: She must be zoned out.

dialogue: A: What are you going to have for breakfast?
B: I just have some cereal each morning.
A: You're supposed to always have a hearty breakfast.
B: I don't always have time to make breakfast.
A: It's easy to make a quick breakfast.
B: What do you have for breakfast?
response: A: When I need to make a quick breakfast , I just make some oatmeal , toast , and OJ .

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
response: B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun and try to better their time every twenty years.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
A: Then the truck hit the taxi, did it?
response: B: Yes, with much noise. Then I called the taxi.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
B: About 20 minutes at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.
A: I'd better go there by bus. By the way, where is the bus stop, please?
response: B: Just across the country.

dialogue: A: Do you know how to play tennis?
B: Not very well. But I'd love to learn.
A: Would you like to play with me tomorrow morning?
B: Certainly, but I'm not very good.
response: A: We'll see about that. Anyway, you know that you shouldn't practice.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you know where I can find a pay phone?
B: There is one around the corner.
A: Can I make an international call from that pay phone?
B: Yes, but you have to get a phone card first.
A: Where can I get a phone card?
response: B: You can get one in the grocery store over there.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
response: B: It's here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
response: A: You look as if you've gained weight in your rosy cheeks as well.

dialogue: A: Have you been to exhibitions in your spare time?
B: Yes, a lot of times. I like exhibitions-exhibitions about famous people: dancers, actors, you know?
A: Mm, and what about a folk concert? Have you ever been to one of them?
B: No. I don't like folk music very much.
A: What about the opera?
B: No, never. I don't really like the opera. It is a bit too heavy for me.
A: A pop concert?
response: B: Yes. I saw Madonna once. She was fantastic-she is a really great ballet dancer.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. Er, I'm phoning about the job that was in the paper last night.
A: Oh, yes. Could you tell me your name?
B: Oh, Jerry Lynn.
A: Well, what exactly is it that interests you about the job?
B: I just thought that it was right up my street, you know.
A: Really? Could you tell me a little about yourself?
B: I've been working abroad doing secretarial work. Previous to that I was at university. I've got a degree in English.
A: Do you have any special skills?
response: B: Well, I speak no foreign languages at all.

dialogue: A: I hear you're going home, aren't you?
B: I wanted to go on Monday, but I couldn't get a ticket for Monday, I bought a ticket for Tuesday.
A: Why are you in such a hurry?
B: My mother is ill. She has been sent to the hospital.
A: How did you get the news? Did your mother send you a letter?
response: B: My sister telephoned me this morning. my father and me decided we didn't want to go back.

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
B: He was messing around last week in class.
A: Exactly what did he do?
B: Even though I asked him not to, he kept speaking out in class.
A: I don't know what his problem is.
B: I need you to talk to him, if you don't mind.
A: That won't happen again, I'm sorry.
response: B: Thank you. Hopefully I will have to call about him again.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
B: Oh, all right. Well, we could rent a video and watch that.
response: A: Great, because neither of us has a video player!

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
response: A: This class is really just a review for me. I've been learning it for two years.

dialogue: A: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock.
B: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning.
A: Why? What's wrong with you?
B: I felt pain all over my body. Can you get me some medicine?
A: Will aspirin do?
B: No, aspirin isn't strong enough.
response: A: Then I can do nothing but call for a pizza.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
response: B: But he is usually correct in his weather news.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
response: B: I don't need a name.

dialogue: A: What are you thinking?
B: I ’ m thinking about where we shall spend our vocation.
A: It ’ s about 7 o ’ clock. let ’ s have our breakfast first.
B: Ok, dear.We will be late.
A: What do you want?
B: A ham salad sandwich.
A: Sorry, I didn ’ t prepare this.
response: B: Then , I ’ d like some eggs and bread for dinner instead .

dialogue: A: Do you know much about computers?
B: Not a great deal. Why?
A: I've been reading an article about computers. They are strange and are being used for almost everything.
B: Yes. But have you learned how to use one?
A: No. But I'm about to take a course on computers next term.
B: That's good. You have to know about computers. Computer knowledge is a must whatever you do. You should learn quickly or you will be left behind.
A: That's true. But first I want to learn the basics. In the library, there are computers. But it's a pity that I could not make use of them.
B: Well, I can teach you the ABCs, if you like.
response: A: That's very condescending of you.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
response: A: Well, it has three servants, two bakeries, one big sitting statue and a modern pool.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, it looks like you've got some sun this weekend.
B: Yeah, I guess so. I spent the weekend at the beach.
A: Oh, yeah, that's great. Where did you stay?
B: Some friends of my parents' live out there and they invited me for as long as I wanted to stay.
A: So what are you doing back here already?
response: B: Oh, I have a paper to work on, and I just couldn't do any serious studying at the beach.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
response: A: It's pretty narrow right now, everything from playground assistants to diaper changers.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for autumn, but I'd like to have something warm for winter.
A: Maybe you would like a heavy wool hat. How about this one?
B: I think that's what I want. How much is it?
A: It's seventy dollars plus tax.
response: B: It's a little too cheap for me. Do you think it's possible to get a discount?

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to make an appointment to look at houses.
B: Sure, would you prefer looking in the morning or afternoon?
A: I would prefer mornings.
B: Can you go during the week, or can you only go during the weekend?
A: Going to look at houses during the week is best for me.
B: Where would you like me to pick you up?
A: I will meet you at the real estate office.
B: I am thinking of looking at three houses, and it will take about two hours.
A: That sounds good to me.
response: B: Once I contact the dogs and confirm the price , I will e-mail you a schedule

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy the restaurant?
B: I didn't really like it all that much.
A: What do you think the problem was?
B: Well, they are pretty new. I just didn't feel that they were ready to open yet.
A: How did you feel about the food?
B: The food wasn't all that exciting.
response: A: I don't think that the performance was good, either.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, let me have this roast beef special.
A: You have a choice of vegetables, green peas, lima beans or spinach.
B: I will have the green peas and make sure the beef is well done.
A: Yes, sir. What would you want to drink, coffee, tea or milk?
B: A cup of coffee, please, with cream and sugar.
A: The cream and sugar are on the table, sir.
B: Oh, yes.
A: Would you like to order some dessert?
B: What comes with the special?
A: Ice cream, fresh fruit or chocolate cake.
B: I think I will have a dish of Vanilla ice cream.
A: Yes, sir.
B: Waiter, may I have my check, please?
response: A: Here you are, sir. Greet the kid at the door.

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
A: You mean you know how to farm?
B: Yes. I did that every summer during holidays.
response: A: I didn't know that a city boy can do farm work. Can I go there with you? I'd like to learn to do some urban planning.

dialogue: A: What do you usually do in your spare time?
B: I have joined a singing group and we practice two afternoons each week.
A: That's a very interesting thing to do.
response: B: Yes. It's a small group of only fifteen girls and boys. But everyone has been late for the practice.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
response: A: They must have had a toy car or a toy truck.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.
A: I don't know how you keep on with it. It's too hard to become a doctor.
B: Well, you study a lot too. It doesn't seem any easier to become an engineer.
response: A: But it does take as long. I'll be out putting up the buildings while you're still a student here. By the way, can I help you with your study now?

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is not in at the moment.
B: When will he come in, do you know?
A: I suppose he won't be in until 12: 00.
B: May I leave a message?
A: Certainly.
response: B: Please ask him to never speak to me again as soon as he returns.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
A: May I borrow your pen?
B: Here's a pen for you.
A: Thanks for your help.
response: B: You need to fill that in while sitting near Window B.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
response: A: How awful ! Was he hurt ?

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
B: But I was told that arm exercises could raise your blood pressure.
A: Yes, but the article I read suggests some ways to make up for that.
B: Really? How?
A: By adding leg exercises, so that the arms don't do all the work.
B: And in return, I'm sure that there's a good chance of losing weight.
A: Sounds right to me.
B: So what exercises do the experts suggest?
response: A: They mentioned quite a few exercises, but one of the most popular ones is pull-up.

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
response: A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be easy to find a job, then there will be the the joy from just starting a job.

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
response: B: I was going to, but I didn't have any desire for a pay phone.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of beginning my own business.
A: That sounds great.
response: B: Yes, I think it over, but the problem is money. If I had enough money, I'd ask for a raise tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.
A: Is it the diet that you love but have to avoid?
response: B: That's right. Dieting is so boring. Hopefully, I'll need to wear the wedding dress again anyway, because I'm going to be a nun.

dialogue: A: Are you looking for part time or full time employment?
B: To start with I would like something part time with the hope that it can develop into something full time.
A: So you are interested in being with a company for the long term?
B: Yes, that's right. I like this city very much and would like to make my home here.
response: A: Here is an application. Please fill it out to the best of your ability. You don't need a resume and references.

dialogue: A: Can I order take-out here?
B: Yes, sir. What would you like?
A: I want a hamburger, a medium French fries, a Big Mac meal, and a double cheeseburger, please.
B: Anything else?
A: And a 6-piece chicken nuggets.
B: What kind of drink would you like?
A: A large Coke with extra ice and a milkshake. And please give me several more straws. How much do I owe you?
B: Let me calculate it, er... that comes to $ 14.30.
response: A: Here's $15. Where's the change?

dialogue: A: I can't believe it! I lost.
B: It looks like you have to buy tickets for us, Jason. And we're not going to see an action movie!
A: That's not fair, you got all the easy questions.
response: B: I guess that's just the luck of the draw .

dialogue: A: Are you free this afternoon?
B: I'm afraid I'm going to the gym for a workout.
A: How long have you been there?
B: I began to went there last month.
A: Is there any change?
B: Well, I think I'm in better condition now.
response: A: Really? Is it tasty?

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
B: I thought she'd be happy.
A: Yeah, especially since she got a promotion recently.
response: B: I don't know. Maybe it's some kind of party.

dialogue: A: How come David is always so full of energy?
B: He has a strange but highly effective way of sleeping.
A: What is that?
response: B: He takes an eight hour sleep every night and has a total of eight hours of sleep each day.

dialogue: A: Are you planning on voting?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, but this will be my first time voting.
B: Really?
A: Yes, and I have no idea how to do it.
B: Voting is simple.
A: I don ’ t know any of the laws they ’ re trying to pass.
response: B: That ’ s okay. They describe everything on the bumper sticker.

dialogue: A: Hello, Frank.
B: Hi, Steven. What's new with you?
A: Not too much. I'm looking to rent an apartment.
B: Why?
response: A: I really like my roommate. He really turns me on .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
response: A: No , that's fine . Do you bring your bicycle with you ?

dialogue: A: I'm sending a letter to my friend by airmail. It's not insured or anything, but how do I address it, again?
B: Well, obviously you have to write the name of the person or business in the center of the envelope.
A: Okay. What next?
B: On the second line, you write the address you are sending it to. Good, like that.
response: A: I got it now. On the last line, I write the city it's going to and the district, right?

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
B: At least, it can free you from the crowd. By the way, do you come from China?
A: No, from New Zealand, sir. I visited New Zealand and saw lots of overseas people there.
B: Wow, like America. It receives a great number of visitors every year.
response: A: The more the world becomes open , the more people become tribal

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
response: B: Yes, I haven't been eating like I usually do. Usually, I portion my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't and I've eaten loads. Most unlike me.

dialogue: A: Do you feel like going to the cinema?
B: Oh, yes. What kind of films do you like?

A: Well, I like all sorts of films, but my favorite sorts are those like Star Wars. You know, the fantasy, special effect ones that you can escape into another world. I also like mystery film, do you like mystery films?
B: Yes, but I don't like horror films because they really give me nightmares.
response: A: I don't like horror films either. They're sort of smart and believable. I do like crime films, you know, where you can follow the detective and try to guess who the murderer is.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.
response: B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can show only the person you are speaking, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
response: A: Actually, it doesn't save you money.

dialogue: A: Did you hear about the air crash that occurred in South America recently? It was quite a tragic accident!
B: No, I didn't see anything in the news about it. What happened?
A: A foreign airliner was attempting to land at night in a mountainous area in Argentina and flew into a hill!
B: That sounds really terrible! Did anyone survive?
A: No, everyone aboard, including the crew, was killed instantly.
B: What were the circumstances? Were they bad weather, a fire, or engine failure?
A: Apparently, there were some low clouds in the area, but mostly it was just miscommunication between the pilots and the traffic controllers.
B: Weren't they both speaking in English, the official international aviation language?

A: Yes they were, but the transmit ion from poor quality radios was slightly distorted and the accents of the Spanish speaking controllers was so strong that the pilots that the pilots misunderstood a vital instruction.
B: How could a misunderstanding like that cause such a serious accident?

A: The pilots were told to descend to 2-2,000 feet. The instruction actually meant 22,000 feet, but they thought they heard descend 2,000 feet. That's a huge difference, and it should have been confirmed, but it was not. Unfortunately, the terrain of the mountains in Norweija ascends to 2,000 feet.
B: So the pilots did descend to the wrong altitude then, because they were following the air controllers instructions.
response: A: Sadly enough, yes they did. It was a really bad mistake. Many people survived as a result of the simply understanding.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
B: We can go next week instead.
response: A: No, I don't want to ruin your weekend. You go ahead and please take the book I bought to my friend Sally. Tell her I have to blow it off all weekend, because I can't afford to fail the test.

dialogue: A: Did you hear how cold it got last night?
B: I heard the radio announcer say it was 18 degrees below zero.
A: It was so cold this morning. I could hardly start my car.
response: B: It was crazy how quickly I was on my way.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I go to a movie this week with Shannon?
B: Let me look at the calendar here. Hmm. When are you thinking about going to a movie?
A: Uh, we're thinking about seeing a movie on Wednesday after school.
B: Well, that's not going to work. You haven't practiced your piano at all for an entire week, so you have to catch up on that.
A: What about Friday?
B: Uh uh. Forget that idea.
A: And Saturday?
response: B: Well, you have to take a nap in the morning. And then, we have to sit around and do nothing. You said you'd help. Well, that should only take a couple of hours. And then, after that, you can go to the movie.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. What can I do for you?
A: I'd like a ticket to New York, please.
response: B: Round trip?

dialogue: A: Have you heard my good news?
B: You haven't told me anything yet.
A: I got a promotion at work earlier this week.
B: Is that right?
A: It's the truth. I am really happy.
B: Congratulations on your promotion.
A: Thank you very much.
B: I am really excited for you.
A: Are you really?
response: B: I'm serious . You didn't do much to deserve this promotion .

dialogue: A: Well, you know I had a good time tonight.
B: I'm pleased to hear that.
A: But I have to say goodbye right now.
B: Why? It's not late. Can't you stay a little longer?
response: A: No, I'm sorry, but I really must go. I know I can't catch the last bus if I hurry now.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
response: B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a white house. The Special Periodicals Room is inside it.

dialogue: A: Hello, Frank.
B: Hi, Steven. What's new with you?
A: Not too much. I'm looking to rent an apartment.
B: Why?
response: A: I like my roommate. He really turns me on.

dialogue: A: And lightweight, too. It'll play for 20 hours on two AA batteries!
B: Cool! The sound is great. These earphones are awesome!
A: And they're really safe. They'll protect your ear from sound damage.
response: B: You certainly need that. You always pump the volume up way too high.

dialogue: A: Beautiful weather, isn ’ t it?
B: Yes, it is. Are you here on business?
A: No, I ’ m on a vacation to see the famous Three Gorges.
response: B: I ’ m going there for a tour, too. Is this your first trip to China?

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
response: B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun and try to worsen their time every year.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
response: B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time every year.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. What can I do for you?
B: I want some coffee.
A: Certainly, madam. What kind of coffee do you want to have?
B: What have you got?
response: A: Well. We are out of Frappuccino, latte, skiny latte, fancy coffe and Americano

dialogue: A: Ann, let's go, or we will be late.
B: What time is it?
A: It is already 10:25.
B: Well, we still have about 15 minutes.
A: What time did you say the train is leaving?
B: 12:05. And it takes only 20 minutes to get to the station by bus.
A: Yes, but what will happen if the bus is late?
B: Relax, those buses run every 10 minutes, so we have plenty of time.
A: ( still on the bus. ) What time is it?
B: It is a quarter to twelve.
response: A: Oh good, we will make our train.

dialogue: A: Mary, tomorrow is your mom's fiftieth birthday. Do you know?
B: Of course I do. How shall we celebrate it?
A: First of all a birthday present. What about buying her a beautiful skirt?
B: That's a good idea. It would make her look younger. And a big birthday cake too, with fifty candles.
response: A: That's right. Shall we have a special talk?

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.
response: B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.

dialogue: A: Emily, what do you do as a trendspotter?
B: Very simple. Take digital photos of youth culture and send them to my company. It's called Look-Look.
A: What kind of company is it?
B: It's a youth culture marketing and trend forecasting firm in Hollywood. I'm one of Look-Look's 65,000 trendspotters worldwide.
A: Look-Look gets a lot of information about the ever-shifting tastes of the youth market by these images.

B: Yes, its clients are mostly companies. They get information about trends from Look-Look and develop their products. They also use the images of Look-Look on their websites to impress young people and promote their newly designed products.
A: But are there any people who don't like their pictures to be used on the website?
response: B: I always have my subjects' permission after I take their pictures and put up their images onto Look-Look.com.

dialogue: A: Hello? I would like to speak to Mr. Lee.
B: This is Lee speaking.
A: This is Linda, your old friend.
B: Oh, how are you, Linda? I'm glad you called.
A: Mr. Smith wrote to me that you were coming to our city. May I see you at your hotel right away?
response: B: Please hold on a moment. I have to check my schedule. Yes, that's ail fight.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I go to a movie this week with Shannon?
B: Let me look at the calendar here. Hmm. When are you thinking about going to a movie?
A: Uh, we're thinking about seeing a movie on Wednesday after school.
B: Well, that's not going to work. You haven't practiced your piano at all for an entire week, so you have to catch up on that.
A: What about Friday?
B: Uh uh. Forget that idea.
A: And Saturday?

B: Well, you have to take an English class in the morning. And then, we have to clean out the garage. You said you'd help. Well, that should only take a couple of hours. And then, after that, you can go to the movie.
A: Yeah. Can I go and see the nine o'clock showing?
B: The five o'clock showing!
A: How about the seven o'clock showing?
B: And why are you so concerned about the show time?
response: A: Well, I'm sure I'll get all of my homework done before then.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
B: How about exercise?
response: A: Well, I often watch tennis or handball.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
B: They really started looting?
A: Yes, apparently four stores were broken into.
B: Did the looters get caught?
response: A: Yes, there was no evidence of who did it .

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
B: I haven't been eating like I usually do. Usually, I love my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt cooking and I've eaten very little. Most unlike me.
A: Have you been to the doctor? What did she say?
B: I didn't bother going to the doctor. It's nothing serious.
response: A: You never know. If you've been feeling like this for two weeks, it's worth getting a car check-up just to be sure.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the movie theater with me tonight?
B: Is there anything good playing?
A: Titanic is playing tonight. It's a blockbuster.
B: Really? I want to go, too.
A: OK, let's meet at the movie theater entrance tonight. Don ’ t be late.
B: No problem.
A: ( After watching the movie. ) Are you crying?
B: I get a lump in my throat whenever I see a tragic movie.
response: A: Tragic movie? I think it's a love story.

dialogue: A: Were you born in Los Angeles?
B: No. I was born in Chicago as a matter of fact.
A: Oh, were you?
B: Yeah, I grew up in the suburbs, in Wilmette, and then I moved out here when I was fourteen.
A: So you went to high school here?
B: Yeah, that's right. I graduated from Lincoln High.
A: And then you went to college?
B: No, not exactly. First I went to Europe.
response: A: Oh. To study at high school?

dialogue: A: What's the matter, Bill? You look kind of pale.
B: Oh, I'm just tired.
A: Why?
B: Well, I've been working until around ten every night this week.
response: A: You should go home at midnight today and take it easy.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
A: And you have a stomachache now?
B: Yes, I think so.
A: Can you walk to the school clinic? Or shall I send for the doctor?
B: No, thanks. It doesn't matter too much. I will go to the doctor after class.
response: A: Ok. I'll finish the class in a minute. Then I'll take you to lunch.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
response: A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.

dialogue: A: (sniffing) Is that a French cigarette?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that a French cigarette you're smoking?
B: Yes, that's right. Why? What's the matter?
A: I don't understand why yousmoke French cigarettes. They make a terrible smell.
B: I like them very much. I prefer them to English cigarettes.
A: Have you got a lot of them?
B: Yes, about 200, why?
A: Well... er... could I buy some from you?
response: B: Buy some from me? You prefer the smell of French cigarettes!

dialogue: A: Hello, Old English Restaurant. Can I help you?
B: Yes. I'd like to book a table for tonight.
A: Yes, sir. What time?
B: Eight o'clock.
A: Certainly. For how many people?
B: There are ten of us.
A: Ten of you! But we don't usually accept large parties, sir.
B: I know, but we are regular customers.
A: What's your name please, sir?
B: Michael Peterson.
response: A: Mr. Peterson...of course! That'll be all right. We'll put two tables together.

dialogue: A: Oh, dear. My weight has gone up again.
B: I'm not surprised. You've been eating too much.
A: I wish I could lose weight. I have been to the hospital.
B: Were you given any advice?
response: A: Yeah, the doctor asked me to make my diet worse by increasing my consumption of meat.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
A: I wonder if you can change it to one size down.
response: B: Yes , of course . Don't worry about coming with the receipt.

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
response: B: You can get wine and milkshakes in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
A: You must be mad. I think it's really...you know...so easy to buy everything in one place.
B: Yes, it's easy. But don't you think the food isn't...I mean small shops usually have much fresher food.
A: Maybe, but you pay for it. Small shops are more expensive, aren't they?
response: B: Yes, I agree with you, but supermarket staff are well paid and they are really...but you get comparable service in small shops. They are much more friendly.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
response: A: Are you renting the townhouse alone or with company ?

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
response: B: He was messing around last week in class.

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!
A: You're not supposed to just copy the book.
B: Oh! I think Mr. Harper won't know.
A: He will know! He asked us to write a list of all the books we'd used. Remember? That's not the point anyway.
B: What is the point then?
response: A: Well, the point is that you're supposed to copy someone else's writing--you can't write your own.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you take me to the airport?
B: Which airport, ma'am?
A: Kennedy Airport.
B: All right, ma'am. Need any help with your luggage?
response: A: Thank you, but I don't want to keep this case with me anymore.

dialogue: A: Acknowledgments play a necessary part in the interview.
B: Sure. Kind acknowledgments can show one's good attainment.
A: We often ignore the acknowledgments in our daily life, and consider them as disposable.
B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a good impression on others, especially in the public places.
A: We should particularly pay attention to acknowledgments in the interview.
B: In the beginning of the interview, it is best that you make acknowledgments for the opportunity of the interview.
A: Don't forget to say " Thank you " when you take a seat.
B: Make acknowledgments as well when the interviewer thinks highly of your dressing, experience, or words.
response: A: You can win a good impression of the interviewer in this way.

dialogue: A: Hello, Steven. Can you do me a favor?
B: Sure. What is it?
A: My car has broken down.
response: B: You should telephone the garage for help .

dialogue: A: I'm losing my sleep. I feel tired and sleepy all the time. I've got to do something about it.
B: I'm so sorry for you. But what are you going to do?
A: I want to move out of the dorm and rent a small flat.
response: B: That's a good idea. It will be much less convenient for you.

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
response: B: But it's three kilometers from here to the police station. How can we get there in such a short time?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you waiting to buy the concert tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: How long have you been here?
B: About 50 minutes. I've hardly moved forward in that time.
A: Are you kidding?
B: Not at all. There was a couple up ahead of me who got so fed up that they finally gave up and left. They said they'd been here for more than an hour.
A: My God. Does anyone know what's causing the delay?
response: B: It could be that there aren't enough people selling tickets this afternoon. Or maybe their computers break down.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
response: B: Oh, it was my father's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.

dialogue: A: How come David is always so full of energy?
B: He has a strange but highly effective way of sleeping.
A: What is that?
B: He takes a short sleep for an hour every six hours and has a total of four hours of sleep each day.
A: Where did he get that strange idea?
response: B: He read flora a book which said it was the worst way for human beings, and he believed it.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.
A: No. But you must admit that on the big screen, it looked great.
B: Well, I think it would have been just as good as seeing it at home.
A: Ah, But it won't be on video till next year.
response: B: I can't watch that long.

dialogue: A: Dear, can you drive me to the clinic?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why?
B: Well, my car won't start. I don't know what's the matter with it.
A: Could it be the battery?
B: No, I don't think it could be. I checked the battery two days ago. It must be other problems.
response: A: Well, I suppose it could be the gas.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
A: And what would you like to have for the main course
response: B: Shrimp salad. And what kind of pie do you have?

dialogue: A: Oh, dear. My weight has gone up again.
B: I'm not surprised. You've been eating too much.
A: I wish I could lose weight. I have been to the hospital.
B: Were you given any advice?
response: A: Yeah, the butcher asked me to clean up my diet by cutting down meat.

dialogue: A: Would you like to come to the cinema tonight?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair tonight.
A: OK. What about tomorrow night?
B: I can't go tomorrow night, either.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair again.
A: Do you wash your hair every night?
B: It depends...
A: Depends on what?
response: B: It depends on who turns me down to go to the cinema.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
response: B: No, it was as large as a mouse and worked very fast.

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: I'm in a hurry. How long will it take?
B: About half an hour, if there's no traffic jam.
A: Do you think the traffic will be heavy?
B: I doubt it. It's not rush hour.
response: A: That's a mess.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.
A: Well, that's a good idea and you come to the right place. Do you know what you like?
response: B: Well, I don't want a racer or a touring bike or anything like that. Mostly I'll just be using it to practice for the next cycling championship.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.
response: A: I don't know how you keep on with it. It's too hard to become a doctor.

dialogue: A: When do you take your winter holiday?
B: I usually take it during the second or third week of January.
A: Do you like to ski?
B: Yes, I love to go skiing.
A: Where do you go?
B: I go to a hotel in the mountains.
A: Is it far from here?
B: It's about a hundred miles away.
A: Does it get cold?
response: B: Oh, yes! It gets very cold. It gets heat waves a lot.

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
response: B: Yes, it's a terrible book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some boring charts and...

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
response: B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first car in 1995.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
response: A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
A: So you could have made it. But you were still late for class.

B: The thing is, when I got off, I found I had left my bag in his car. And it was too late to get it back when I realized that. I went straight to the nearest shop and gave him a call. I waited for five minutes before Mr. Green drove back.
response: A: Finally, he gave you your bag and you came to the classroom and you were already an hour early for class at that time. Is that all?

dialogue: A: Welcome to Youth Hotel, can I help you?
B: I'd like a room for a night.
A: Would you like a single room, a double room or a room for three?
response: B: Oh, a single room please. Can I pay by check?

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
response: A: If I were you, I'd say sorry to her first and then get her another cat.

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was killed in that bombing.
response: A: I'm sorry to hear that. War left many people sad memories.

dialogue: A: Would you please tell me why you want to work in our kindergarden? You know kids are sometimes so tiresome.
B: I love children. I can sing to them and teach them how to dance.
A: Then have you worked in a kindergarden before?
response: B: Yes, I used to take care of teenagers during summer and winter holidays.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
A: So it doesn't really hold your interest?
response: B: No, not really. I wouldn't bother with it, to be honest, but I have to read it with a toddler. I'm at a university.

dialogue: A: Could you tell me the time of the last plane to Hong Kong this evening?
B: There's one at 10:15, but it's fully booked, I think.
A: Then the time of the first plane tomorrow morning?
B: The first plane leaves at 8:15.
A: Can you tell me when it arrives so that I can ask my secretary to come and meet me?
B: It arrives at 11:15 but maybe a little late because of the bad weather.
response: A: Well, I wonder if you'd let me know if there's any change on that flight, I'd appreciate it.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few days after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?
B: Well, it hurts so much, doctor, especially when I eat.
A: I understand, Mrs. Jackson. It hurts in the beginning, I know. But it's really better to leave it in, except when you clean it of course.
B: Well, I did at first, doctor, but it hurt so much that I just couldn't stand it any longer.
response: A: Well, maybe we can let it rest a little more.

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have been hurt or even killed?
A: You are right! All the injured people were taken to the hospital immediately.
B: I hope so. Drivers must be careful, especially during rush hour.
response: A: I agree with you. We will all be safe if everyone obeys the traffic rules.

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition improved when he enjoyed himself and watched funny movies.
A: You said Norman learned this? Do we have to learn to laugh?

B: Not necessarily. Since laughing is something people can do sitting down, costs no money, and requires no special exercise equipment or skill, it's the perfect workout for anyone who doesn't have the time or desire to participate in a regular fitness program.
A: Oh. Do you have such a program to offer to the general public?

B: Yes, we do. It's called the Smile Time-Out. You take a deep breath, smile, exhale, and say "Aaah" while visualizing all your muscles and cells smiling. Then add to that a memory of a time you felt really good and laughed and laughed.
A: What about the situation in which you aren't in a mood to laugh?
response: B: Even when you genuinely smile or laugh, you get the same physiological benefits as when it's the real thing, because your mind is smart, but your body is stupid and can't tell the difference!

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
A: No, but we can get your package to France in one week for 40 dollars.
B: Well, that sounds good. I'll take that. Is the service guaranteed?
response: A: Yes. We offer a service where we can promote your package. But that will cost 10 dollars extra.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that Susan got married?
B: Really? I remember she said if she would remain single. Is the man very rich?
A: No. That ’ s what is surprising me.
B: You means she didn ’ t marry a rich man.
response: A: He's a postman who comes from old money.

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
B: Then, you should dress well.
A: That ’ s right.
response: B: I think a white shirt with a blue tie looks nice on you.

dialogue: A: Hello? I would like to speak to Mr. Lee.
B: This is Lee speaking.
A: This is Linda, your old friend.
B: Oh, how are you, Linda? I'm glad you called.
A: Mr. Smith wrote to me that you were coming to our city. May I see you at your hotel right away?
B: Please hold on a moment. I have to check my schedule. Yes, that's ail fight.
A: Great. I'll be there in haft an hour.
B: All right, I'll be expecting you.
A: Oh, I almost forgot. What's your room number?
response: B: It's the No. 311 on the second floor. Please slap me if you can find me.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
B: Oh, all right. Well, we could rent a video and watch that.
A: Neither of us has a video player.
response: B: No. But Tony's got a new book How about renting a book to read with him at his place?

dialogue: A: Did you need help with something?
B: I need to cancel an account.
A: Do you have a problem with your account?
response: B: I don ’ t need two different accounts anymore.

dialogue: A: Come back. You haven't paid yet.
B: May, just let him go.
A: But he took some newspaper away without paying.
B: I know.
A: Why? You make me confused.
B: He lives nearby and he would just glance at the newspaper headlines, read the political sections and return them later.
A: Why does he have such a privilege?
B: He used to be a hero during the war time and everyone respect him.
A: I see. Does he live by himself?
B: Yes, he has no children and his wife passed away when he was in the battle.
response: A: He must be busy?

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
B: But it's three kilometers from here to the cinema. How can we get there in such a short time?
A: I think we can walk there in twenty minutes.
B: But I am afraid I can't walk that far.
response: A: If you don't feel like walking, we can run instead.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
response: A: You'll be happy to know, but that's gone, too.

dialogue: A: Emily, what do you do as a trendspotter?
B: Very simple. Take digital photos of youth culture and send them to my company. It's called Look-Look.
A: What kind of company is it?
B: It's a youth culture marketing and trend forecasting firm in Hollywood. I'm one of Look-Look's 65,000 trendspotters worldwide.
A: Look-Look gets a lot of information about the ever-shifting tastes of the youth market by these images.

B: Yes, its clients are mostly companies. They get information about trends from Look-Look and develop their products. They also use the images of Look-Look on their websites to impress young people and promote their newly designed products.
A: But are there any people who don't like their pictures to be used on the website?
B: I always have my subjects' permission before I take their pictures and put up their images onto Look-Look.com.
A: Where do you find your best subjects?
B: At school, in the park, at local supermarkets and near many music clubs.
A: What is difficult about this job?
response: B: To catch our original styles because so many young people try hard to stand out. You have to be able to find the difference between someone who is copying trends and someone who is truly inventing a new look.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
response: B: I'm an English major and this is a required course. But now I'm in trouble because I'm not sure I can enjoy reading this book.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
B: How about exercise?
A: Well, I often play tennis or handball.
response: B: Do you eat any rabbit food?

dialogue: A: David, why didn ’ t you clean the room?
B: I ’ m not in the mood.
A: Why are you feeling depressed?
response: B: I was told my girlfriend was speaking highly of me. that's impressive

dialogue: A: Dad, can I have a pet? I did what you said and passed all of my exams.
B: Then I guess you get to have a pet. Do you know what you want?
A: I want a dog. My friend Mindy's dog just had puppies and she said I can have one.
B: You know who will be responsible for feeding and cleaning and all of that stuff?
A: I know, I know. I will do it all by myself.
response: B: Have you figured out the costs involved with feeding and caring for it?

dialogue: A: Acknowledgments play a necessary part in the interview.
B: Sure. Kind acknowledgments can show one's good attainment.
A: We often ignore the acknowledgments in our daily life, and consider them as disposable.
B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a good impression on others, especially in the public places.
A: We should particularly pay attention to acknowledgments in the interview.
B: In the beginning of the interview, it is best that you make acknowledgments for the opportunity of the interview.
A: Don't forget to say " Thank you " when you take a seat.
B: Make acknowledgments as well when the interviewer thinks highly of your dressing, experience, or words.
response: A: You can win a bad impression of the interviewer in this way.

dialogue: A: Hello. This is Amy.
B: Hello, Amy. This is Tom.
A: Yes. What can I do for you?
B: I want to go to New York by train today. Would you please look up a train time for me?
A: Certainly, Hold on, please. Um... there's one at eleven p. m. It's a little late. Why don't you go there by car?
response: B: My car is being repaired now. I have to go there by train.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
B: Thanks, they are rather attractive. But I think there is nothing better than seeing things In actual operation.
A: Yes, of course. Would you like to make an inspection tour of some factories?
B: Yes, very much, if it wouldn't add inconvenience to you. First hand information is always more valuable than reading pamphlets.
response: A: I'll make the arrangement and let you know the time tomorrow .

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.

B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?
A: Well, no. I don't think I would. I bet it costs a lot of money. Does it say how much it costs?
B: Yes. The early black-and-white ones cost several hundred pounds. But the one is about costs several thousand pounds.
A: Hum. Why does anybody want one, do you think?
response: B: Business organizations that need to frequently contact overseas organizations would want it. It's like a face-to-face conversation. So maybe a lot of overseas travel can be avoided.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
response: B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
A: However,you must show us the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?
B: OK.
response: A: All right. Keep your receipt. If something comes up. you can show it to us and We'll give you a refund.

dialogue: A: Are you doing anything tonight?
B: No, nothing. Why?
A: Do you like western music?
B: Yes, I do, very much.
response: A: There ’ s a speech tonight. Would you like to go and listen to it?

dialogue: A: How is the weather today?
B: It's very hot and humid.
A: Quite different from the forecast.
B: The weather changes often at this time of the year. It's possible to cool down in the late afternoon.
A: How are the summers here generally?
B: They are usually hot and rainy.
A: I have been here for about a month. It's very hot and humid.
response: B: It's just June now. The dry and cool season hasn't arrived yet.

dialogue: A: Are you ready for your big interview tomorrow?
B: What ’ s to get ready?
A: Lots! Have you done any research about the company?
B: Nope.
response: A: Have you thrown out you CV?

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
response: B: How about some fresh fruit?

dialogue: A: Good afternoon. I'm looking for a second-hand car and I believe you sell cars.
B: Yes. I have one here that may interest you.
A: Ah, yes. A friend told me about it. What make is it?
B: It's a Lincoln.
A: Is it MS 560 or MF 558? I don't want either of them. I want a MF 650 one.
B: Oh, it's the one you want, and it's three years old.
A: Mmm... hmm. And what sort of condition is it in?
B: It's in very good condition and it's compact.
A: Right. And how much are you asking for it?
B: Three thousand and fifteen dollars.
A: Three thousand and fifteen dollars? That's a lot of money for a second-hand car.
B: But it's in excellent condition.
response: A: Could I sell it now?

dialogue: A: Happy anniversary, sweetheart!
B: Yes. to our first anniversary and many more to come. Cheers!
A: I'll drink to that. Thanks for making this a night worth remembering.
response: B: Well , it's a pretty normal day . They say if you survive the first year , the rest is smooth sailing .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Will you please book tickets to Sanya for me?
A: Yes, sir. When will you intend to leave?
B: Next Wednesday.
A: That will be July 13. There are two flight available that day: one at 9:00 a.m., the other one at 3:30 p.m.
B: Fine. I'd like the 3:30 one.
A: 3:30 p.m. How many tickets do you need?
B: Two.
A: Wish you a wonderful trip to Sanya.
response: B: They say Sanya leads the world in beautiful scenery. But to tell the truth, my wife has no interest in going there.

dialogue: A: Have you packed our passports?
B: Not yet. Do we need to take it with us?
A: Of course. Otherwise I cannot go abroad.
B: Is that hard to get a passport?
A: Not at all. But we do need to keep it with us all the time.
response: B: It is hard to believe this little thing is so comical to us .

dialogue: A: Hello, Thomas Brothers.
B: Hello, this is Mike Landon here. Is Jack Cooper there by any chance?
A: I am afraid not, he is away for a day or two, back on, let's see, Monday morning.
response: B: Oh, well perhaps I can leave a mess for him.

dialogue: A: About my driving test, did I do well?
B: You did a fabulous job.
A: Are you telling me that I passed the test?
B: That's what I'm telling you.
A: What did I mess up on?
B: You did mess up a little on one thing.
A: Tell me.
B: You had a little trouble on your parallel parking.
A: That's not easy for me.
B: That's something that you really need to work on.
response: A: Am I still going to get my insurance?

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
B: Then, you should dress well.
A: That ’ s right.
B: I think a white shirt with a blue tie looks nice on you.
A: You are smart.
B: Of course, the sports shoes don ’ t go with the formal occasions.
A: You are right. What kind of shoes should I wear?
response: B: The brown leather shoes are too informal for this event.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
response: A: Your son's fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.

dialogue: A: Tom, look at your shoes. How dirty they are! You must clean them.
B: Oh, mum, but I cleaned them only yesterday.
A: They are dirty now. You must clean them again.
response: B: I do not want to clean my jeans today. However, if I clean them today, they will be clean again tomorrow.

dialogue: A: What class did you have this afternoon, Kate?
B: A chemistry class. We've got a new chemistry teacher this term.
A: Who is it?
B: James Black. He told us to call Jim, not to call him Mr. Black.
A: Oh, James Black. I know him. He's a little thin man who smiles a lot.
B: Yes, but many of us are afraid of him.
response: A: Really?  But I hear he's a very strict teacher.

dialogue: A: Hello, Pam.
B: I'm glad that you can make it.
A: It looks like there are a lot of people inside.
response: B: Yeah . I've invited one other friend besides you .

dialogue: A: Are you packing for another trip?
B: Yeah. On Saturday, I'm flying to Toronto.
A: Is this another engineering conference for work?
B: No. I'm meeting with friends. But I earned so many miles by traveling for work that the ticket was free.
A: That's impressive. You fly a lot. I've only been on a plane a few times.
B: Really? Don't you travel with your dad?
A: No. He travels a lot because he is a banker,and he has an office in Japan. When he's working in New York, we take the train to visit him.
B: Oh, I thought you drove.
response: A: No, my mom dislikes driving in the city. Besides, the train is super relaxing.

dialogue: A: Oh, let's just go in for a minute, I'm hungry.
