B: OK, but just a snack. We're eating supper at home tonight.
A: Let's get some milk and bread.
B: I don't really like milk. How about a soda?
A: They say Coca-Cola makes you fat. Milk is healthier.
response: B: Oh, if you want to be healthy, buy yoghurt. And put back those butter cookies you have in your hand.

dialogue: A: Are you doing anything tonight?
B: No, nothing. Why?
A: Do you like western music?
B: Yes, I do, very much.
response: A: There’s a rock concert tonight. Would you like to go to it?

dialogue: A: Are you going to the party on Saturday?
B: I was thinking about it. Are you?
A: Yeah, I heard it's going to be a lot of fun.
B: Really? Well, what time does it start?
A: It starts at 8
B: Well, who all is going to be there?
response: A: Only a couple of people from school.

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: I'm in a hurry. How long will it take?
B: About half an hour, if there's no traffic jam.
A: Do you think the traffic will be heavy?
response: B: I think so. It's not rush hour.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: We'd like to take a tour to Florence.
A: That's a beautiful city. When do you want to go there?
B: We have got a 2 weeks ' vacation and we plan to leave on Thursday.
response: A: Then please have a look at the table , there are so many plans .

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
response: A: I can't keep the door closed.

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
response: B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.

dialogue: A: Are you cold?
B: Yes, a little.
A: I wonder if we can change the temperature.
B: I tried before. There are no buttons on the air conditioning.
A: There must be buttons. How do they turn it on and off?
B: I think it is centrally controlled. They control it at the main desk.
A: Well, they have it too cold in here. I want to be warmer. I won't be able to sleep.
B: I'm going downstairs for more drinking water. I will ask them.
A: What did they say about the air conditioning?
response: B: They said it is centrally controlled.All the rooms are the same. They can't change it.

dialogue: A: It's lucky that we rode our bike here instead of driving.
B: It's a good job that we got here early. Look at all those cars there. They'll never get in.
A: You'd better follow me closely. I don't want to lose you.
B: Don't worry. I'll keep up.
A: We go in over there. Gate B. Peter said they're pretty good tickets.
B: Where are they?
A: They're right behind the goal.
B: Oh,do we have to stand up all the time?
A: That's right.
B: I hope we can see the match clearly.
response: A: That's why we've come early. The earlier, the better.

dialogue: A: Hello. Milton Hotel. Can I help you?
B: I want a reservation. Can I have it now?
A: Of course. What kind of taste do you like for your dinner?
B: I prefer Chinese dishes.
A: Would you like to sit in a smoking section, a non-smoking section or an open one?
B: A non-smoking section.
response: A: I'm awfully sorry, but we've got too many spots in the section left now. Would you like to wait for a while?

dialogue: A: What are you here for today?
B: I need to fight this ticket that I got.
A: Is the arresting officer here?
B: Yes, he is, Your Honor.
A: Plead your case.
response: B: I was told by the officer that I ran a red light . That information isn't true .

dialogue: A: Good afternoon. I'm looking for a second-hand car and I believe you sell cars.
B: Yes. I have one here that may interest you.
A: Ah, yes. A friend told me about it. What make is it?
B: It's a Lincoln.
A: Is it MS 560 or MF 558? I don't want either of them. I want a MF 650 one.
B: Oh, it's the one you want, and it's three years old.
A: Mmm... hmm. And what sort of condition is it in?
B: It's in very good condition and it's compact.
A: Right. And how much are you asking for it?
B: Three thousand and fifteen dollars.
A: Three thousand and fifteen dollars? That's a lot of money for a second-hand car.
B: But it's in excellent condition.
response: A: Could I try it out?

dialogue: A: Did you hear how cold it got last night?
B: I heard the radio announcer say it was 18 degrees below zero.
A: It was so cold this morning. I could hardly start my car.
response: B: My car didn't want to start either at first.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
response: A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
A: So it doesn't really hold your interest?
B: No, not really. I wouldn't bother with it, to be honest, but I have to read it for a seminar. I'm at a university.
A: It's a labor of labor then rather than a labor of love.
B: I should say, I don't like Dickens at all really, the author, indeed, I am starting to like the whole course less and less.
A: It's not just the book, it's the curse as well?
response: B: yeah, in a way, although the curse itself isn't really that bad, a lot of it is pretty good, in fact, and the lecturer is fine, as to me, I suppose, you see, I want to do English rather than philosophy, but my parents took me out of it.

dialogue: A: Look. Jack! That man fell off the ladder. Come and help! He must be injured.
B: He's not moving. Shall we take him to the hospital?
A: We mustn't move him. Leave him where he is.
B: We must get help. I'll go to that phone box and call the First Aid Center.
A: Right. I'll stay here with him.
B: How is he now?
A: He's still not moving, but he's breathing. His head must be hurt.
B: The First Aid Center says they are coming soon.
response: A: Let's wait until help comes. Look, there they come!

dialogue: A: Hello, Ben. You're getting ready for tomorrow's lessons, aren't you?
B: Yes, but I'm a bit nervous. I have no idea what'll happen in class and how I'll get along with my classmates.
A: I understand how you're feeling. Just take it easy. You'll make a lot of friends very soon.
B: Thank you. I'll try my best to get used to my new school life as soon as possible. By the way, what time does the first class begin?
A: At 8 o'clock. But before that we have 10 minutes to hand in homework and then 20 minutes for morning reading.
B: So we must get to school before 7:30, right?
A: Right.
B: How long does each class last?
A: 45 minutes, I think, with a 10 or 15 minutes' break.
response: B: Well, I hear that lunchtime is nearly 12 o'clock and I'll be full by then.

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy it?
B: Not really. I thought it was rather disappointing.
A: Oh? Why is that?
B: It wasn't really what I expected. It went on too long.
A: No. But you must admit that on the big screen, it looked great.
B: Well, I think it would have been just as good as seeing it at home.
response: A: Ah, that's great because it will be on video next year.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.
response: B: No, I think we didn't annoy or bother them at all. They must have heard us coming and got out of the bathroom window quickly.

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
response: B: But I was told that arm exercises could raise your blood pressure.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. Is it true you're moving to London?
B: Yes, it is.
A: What made you decide to do that?
response: B: Leisure, mainly. I'm sure I'll be able to find a job there.

dialogue: A: Did you go out today?
B: With my bad luck? What good would it have done if I'd gone out?
A: If you'd looked for a job,you might have found one.
B: But I've been looking for one over a year. Today wouldn't have been any different.
A: I know how bad you feel, but if you don't keep on looking, you'll never get a job.
B: If I'd stayed in Puerto Rico in the first place, I wouldn't have had so much trouble.
A: What would you have done? There are more people out of work there than there are here.
B: I could have had a farm of my own if I'd stayed there.
A: You? Up the mountains, with nobody to talk to, but the children?
B: I don't like the city. There are too many people. There's too much noise, too much dust.
A: I like here.
response: B: Yes because you're independent here. This is really your home.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ellen.
B: Hello, Helen, have you heard the news? There ’ s been a horrible accident.
A: Oh, no! What happened?
B: Hilda Harris husband, Henry had an accident on his way home from work.
A: How awful! Was he hurt?
B: Yes. He was taken to the hospital in an ambulance.
A: How did it happen?
B: His car was hit by an express train. It happened at the crossing just behind his house.
A: How horrible!
B: He ’ s having an operation in the hospital now. Poor Hilda! You can imagine how unhappy she is.
response: A: I hope the train will be all right

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
response: B: No, but you can see that the point is totally functional..

dialogue: A: Dad, when will you finish your cooking?
B: Several minutes.
A: So what should I do now?
B: Then, pass me a bowl for the soup.
A: Where's the bowl gone?
B: Look for it yourself, please! Kinda busy here, Daniel!
A: Dad?
B: Check the drawer.
A: OK, got it, but its shape is so strange. I don't like it.
response: B: Can it hold cat food?

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
response: B: But I heard it loudly.

dialogue: A: Welcome to this idition of writers. Tonight we have Steven Das with us. Congratulations on your book. It's such a success.
B: Thank you.
A: This is your first time to that poetry? Did you ever try before? Did you ever take any classes in poetry?

B: Well. My only real experience was writing business plans. Other than that. I've experience. We're writing with concerned. I've always had the good grass of the writing with the English language. Thanks to my mom who studied my reading when I was very little.
A: What's the hardest thing that in the world?
response: B: Definitely finding the worst words to fit what I wanted to say. There're always work word two that I might to rewrite if given the chance.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, well, I bought this tie last week for my husband's birthday, and er...well he doesn't like it. Could I change it for something else, such as a shirt or a hat?
A: Certainly, madam, provided that it hasn't been worn, and if you have the receipt.
B: Yes, here it is.
response: A: OK, er... this tie looks as if it were worn. I'll put it back on the shelf.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
B: No, but you can see that the point is bent a little bit.
A: Yes, it is, isn't it? We'd be happy to exchange it for you. But I'm afraid we don't have another purple one. We only have this pen in black and yellow now.
B: My wife doesn't care for either of those colors.
A: We have one with a red leather cover. That's three dollars more.
response: B: The children worked hard to throw away the eleven dollars for this one. They would probably be upset if I paid for part of their present.

dialogue: A: Are you free this evening, Li?
B: I ’ m afraid I ’ m busy tonight. I ’ m having dinner with friends.
A: What a pity. I wanted to go for a drink with you.
B: What about tomorrow? Are you doing anything tomorrow?
response: A: No, I haven ’ t got any plans I'm willing to change.

dialogue: A: Ahahah! What is that thing on your couch! It just moved!
B: Did you think it wasn't real? That's my pet lizard.
A: You have a pet lizard? Somehow I never would have imagined that.
B: His name is Grunt. Come closer and I'll properly introduce you.
A: Does it bite or scratch?
response: B: No, he's perfectly harmless. And he's not afraid of strangers either. Here, hold him.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bob. I heard about your accident but I didn't think it would be this bad.
B: Well, thanks for making me feel better.
A: I can hardly recognize you. Tell me what happened.

B: I just got back from Africa where I had a terrible accident in a motorcycle race. I broke both my legs when my motor failed and was hit by another motorcycle. I was laid up in a hospital over there for three weeks.
A: Three weeks, that's a long time. What did you do while you were in the hospital?
B: Well, if you can believe it, I read all about motorcycle racing. I love racing even if it hurts.
A: But I'm afraid you don't make it look very funny. You're lucky to be alive.
B: That's for sure. I am lucky to be alive.
A: How soon can you get well? Did the doctor tell you about it?
B: They say I still need to stay in bed for two weeks or so.
A: I think you'll get a bit fatter by then. By the way, is there anything I can do for you?
response: B: No, thank you.  Take back the beautiful flowers.  It's very useless of you to come to see me.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
response: A: However,you must tear up the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but I think you've made a wrong turn. You were supposed to turn left on Wilson Boulevard.
B: Oh, I am sorry. Didn't you say 1323 Wilson?
A: No, 3023. It is OK though. You don't have to take me there. I can walk from here.
B: Why don't I just make a U-turn there? It's a one-way street; see the sign up ahead. Maybe if I turn left here, I can come down the next street.
response: A: We can only do that during rush hour really, though it won't be much trouble. Sometimes one can wait 30 minutes for a taxi, so I'm happy to get this close.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
response: B: What for ? For the party , of course .

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
B: How about some fresh fruit?
response: A: We don't have any chocolate cake today. All we have now is fresh fruit.

dialogue: A: : I'm not sure if I can find work this summer. There aren't many jobs out there for inexperienced workers, and I can't just sit around all day.
B: an: Have you ever heard about house-sitting? Tom is going to house sit for Mary's family this summer when they travel to China.
A: : What exactly is house-sitting?
response: B: an: It's kind of like baby-sitting except that you're watching a house instead of kids.

dialogue: A: We haven't gone out for over a month. Let's go somewhere this evening.
B: Fine, where shall we go?
A: Look in the newspaper to see what's on at the cinema or the theater.
B: I see new play opened this week.
A: I enjoy a concert.
B: According to the newspaper there aren't any tonight.
A: Aren't there any good films in town?
response: B: How about TItanic?  That should be boring.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that Susan got married?
B: Really? I remember she said if she would remain single. Is the man very rich?
A: No. That ’ s what is surprising me.
B: You means she didn ’ t marry a rich man.
A: He ’ s a postman.
response: B: I thought she would marry a fortune.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bob. I heard about your accident but I didn't think it would be this bad.
B: Well, thanks for making me feel better.
A: I can hardly recognize you. Tell me what happened.
response: B: I just got back from Africa where I had a terrible accident in a motorcycle race. I broke both my legs when my motor failed and was hit by another motorcycle. I was laid up in a hospital over there for three weeks.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
B: We can go next week instead.
response: A: No, I don't want to ruin your weekend. You go ahead and please take the book I bought to my friend Sally. Tell her I have to study all weekend, because I can't afford to fail the test.

dialogue: A: Where do you want to go, Madam?
B: Hilton Hotel, please. Brrr! It's cold, eh? I'm freezing.
A: Come in. San Francisco is usually cold in winter, you know. It's often very rainy, which makes the weather colder and it sometimes....
B: Well, it gets very hot in summer, doesn't it?
A: Not really. It gets warm in July and August. That's the best time to visit the city. Uh, oh. Here comes the rain!
B: It's raining hard. By the way, how long does it take to reach the hotel, do you think?
response: A: About half a second if there is a traffic jam. Would you like to listen to some light music?

dialogue: A: Welcome.
B: Hi, John. Hey, you've done a good job decorating this place, really nice.
A: Thanks, I am glad you like it. Can I get you a drink?
B: No, thanks. Let's make dinner. I am getting hungry.
A: Here is the kitchen. I will wash the onions first. Could you take the meat out of the fridge? It's in a yellow plastic container.
B: Wow, this smells good.
A: Could yon pass those potatoes to me, please?
B: What are we having?
A: My special dumplings, sweet and sour pork, beef with onions and green peppers, and a few side dishes like tomatoes with sugar.
B: Sounds wonderful. What are you going to do next?
response: A: I'll start preparing the vegetarian dish.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
response: A: One moment while I go and get my ID for the flight.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
response: B: No, I'm feeling well. Mr. Brown.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Are you waiting to buy today's film tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: Have you been here long?
B: About 45 minutes. I've moved forward a total about 3 feet.
A: Oh...
B: Not at all. A young couple who have been waited for one hour ahead of me finally gave up and left.
A: Does anyone know what caused the delay?
response: B: There are just not enough people selling tickets this afternoon.

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
response: B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was totally fine after that bombing.

dialogue: A: 911. What can I do for you?
B: I am reporting a break-in.
A: When did it happen?
B: It happened last night.
A: Where did it happen?
B: It happened at my house.
A: What was taken?
B: I don't know.
A: How do you know there was a break-in?
B: Someone busted my window.
response: A: I will send a flower to your house right now.

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
B: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
A: No, please, Mom! Don't make me gargle with saltwater!
response: B: Lemon tea works better than any medicine , Lily . I'll make you a glass right now , and you'll finish it !

dialogue: A: Bill, I must tell you the truth. You failed the English exam again.
B: Ah? Really? That stinks!
A: Haha. April Fool's! Did you forget what day it is today?
response: B: Wow, you were pulling my leg all along. I was really fooled.

dialogue: A: Gosh! The water faucet is dripping badly again.
B: You are going to have a huge bill.
A: I know. I ’ Ve got to get it fixed ASAP.
B: Don't you wanna get it fixed now?
A: I wish I could, but I ’ Ve got to go now. I have an appointment in 20 minutes.
B: Well, if you need anything, just let me know.
response: A: Oh , by the way , No need give me a ride. My car is back from the garage .

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
response: B: Of course, I will. I want to see as few places as I can. How can I travel?

dialogue: B: Help. I need some help!
A: Yes sir. Can you tell me what is happening?
B: I'm at the university and a student of mine suddenly fell down, knocked her head on the step, and fainted right at this very moment.
A: Yes sir. Can you tell me exactly where you are?
response: B: On the...on the ...I'm sorry, I'm too angry right now. We're on the second floor of Cutler Hall, Room 211.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.
response: B: Then your two boys will need to share a room.  They are happy with it?

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
B: But I don't have a car and I can't drive. Is there any other way to travel?
A: You can travel by bus. It's very cheap.
B: Can't I travel by train?
response: A: Yes, you can. The bus is expensive in the States, but it's fast.

dialogue: A: Dad, what are we doing tonight for fun?
B: We're going over to Mrs. Smith's place to help her with her yard work.
A: Yard work? I said ' what are we doing for fun ', not work!
B: It will be fun. And besides, you'll be in the best company.
A: Dad. You're so cute. What do I need to do to help get ready?
response: B: You could get the rakes and some shovels together and I'll put them in the car.

dialogue: A: Discoveries is looking for a reporter to travel all over the world and write adventure articles.
B: Oh, it's a good job, I think.
A: So you are interested in working for Discoveries?
B: That's right. write adventure articles, but I'm sure I could. I've written lots of articles for a newspaper.
A: Oh? What newspaper have you written for?
B: Well, so far I've sold articles to the chicago Star and a few other newspaper.
response: A: Have you ever written a home decor article?

dialogue: A: Do you mind telling me about your work in the factory?
B: Certainly not. I'm a machine operator working in the assembly workshop.
A: Oh, are you? Then you have a six-day week, don't you?
B: Yes. And we work eight hours a day, but this includes a one -hour break.
A: What about the huge machines used in your factory? I know you make heavy machines yourselves. But I wonder if you also use machines imported from abroad.
B: Most of them are made in China, some even by our factory. Only a few were bought from other countries.
A: But I see the machines turned out here are quite modem and efficient.
B: Following the national policy of self - reliance and hard - working struggle, we've tried our best in the past few years to improve our equipment. However, there is still a lot more to do.
A: Now the question about yourself. I hope you don't mind it. How much do you earn each month?
B: My monthly wage is 3,500 RMB, not including the extra pay of about 500 for extra work I put in.
A: That sounds reasonable indeed. I'm very interested in worker's welfare here. What other benefits do you workers get, I wonder?
response: B: Like other factories in China, our factory charges for medical service for workers.

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
A: We ought to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.
B: We can do that tomorrow. We don't have to do it today.
A: All right. That's a good idea.
B: Talking about washing down the kitchen-where's Bob?
A: He's having lunch with Georgia.
B: What! Again?
A: He should be back soon.
B: He shouldn't spend so much time with that girl.
response: A: You must be patient, David. Nineteen's a very difficult age, you know?

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, my son and daughter bought this pen here for my wife's birthday, but it doesn't work, so I'd like to exchange it.
A: Let me see. Was it dropped or anything?
B: No, but you can see that the point is bent a little bit.
response: A: Yes, it is, isn't it? We'd be happy to exchange it for you. But I'm afraid we don't have another purple one. We only have this pen in black and yellow now.

dialogue: A: Still feeling ill?
B: Yes. And that medicine hasn't helped. Not a good start to our vacation, I'm afraid.
A: Do you have any idea what caused it?
B: Well, I thought it might be last night's dinner.
A: But I am fine. Could it be the heat? It's enough to make anyone ill.
B: I know. But we've been here a week now. Anyway, I've been careful in the sun and I've been drinking bottled water.
response: A: Then we'd better avoid the hotel today.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.
A: Well, that's a good idea and you come to the right place. Do you know what you like?
B: Well, I don't want a racer or a touring bike or anything like that. Mostly I'll just be using it to get me back and forth from work.
A: How far is that?
B: About four miles.
A: Are there a lot of hills on the way?
B: Some, I guess. But maybe I should tell you at first that I only got 150 dollars. Can I get anything decent for that?
A: Well, you are not going to get anything on the top of the line. But we do have a few trade-ins in the back that are in good condition.
B: That sounds good.
response: A: And you are right. For the kind of ride you are going to be doing, the most important thing is the price. You want to make sure it's the right height for you? Follow me and I'll show you what we've got.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you live here?
B: Yes.
A: Oh, well, do you know where the English Language Institute is?
B: Ah, yes. I think I know where it is. Do you have a car?
A: No, I'm on foot.
B: Well, as you go out of the station, just continue along the road until you come to the second crossing and then turn left into King Street.
A: Yes.
response: B: Then walk down the institute just a bit and take the first turning on the right. And keep walking until you come to the park.

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.
A: I want to be a vet.
B: A-what?
A: A vet-a veterinary surgeon.
B: Good gracious! What's that?
response: A: A vet's a man who takes care of healthy animals. He's an animal doctor.

dialogue: A: Dad, when will you finish your cooking?
B: Several minutes.
A: So what should I do now?
B: Then, pass me a bowl for the soup.
A: Where's the bowl gone?
B: Look for it yourself, please! Kinda busy here, Daniel!
A: Dad?
B: Check the drawer.
A: OK, got it, but its shape is so strange. I don't like it.
B: Can it hold soup?
A: Maybe.
response: B: It smells sweet. Mom and May are gonna love it. Get them for dinner, Daniel!

dialogue: A: Hello, John. How was your French exam yesterday?
B: Not too good.
A: Well, the term exam is always more difficult. Work harder, and you'll certainly do better next time.
B: I've worked hard enough, I think, but unluckily, I have never done well in the exam.
A: Well, it's no use worrying about the exam now. Let's talk about the football game tonight. It's much more interesting.
B: Is there a football game on TV tonight?
A: Yes it's between the Chinese team and the Japanese team.
B: ... Er I'd rather watch some other programmes.
A: Why? You're so interested in football.
response: B: The European team has always played badly in the important match, just as I have done in the important exam.

dialogue: A: Hello, Jim. Where are you going?
B: To the cinema. What about coming with me?
A: No, thanks. I'm going home. My friend's expecting me.
B: What a pity! I believe it's a very good film.
A: Do you go to the cinema a lot?
B: Once a week. Most nights I sit at home and watch TV.
A: Oh, I see. By the way, where are you going for your holidays this year?
B: I don't know yet. My wife's going to her mother's for a couple of weeks. She lives by the sea, you know.
A: Oh, does she? That's convenient.
B: Yes, but I want to go to the country.
A: Don't you like the sea?
response: B: Yes, very much. But I like busy streets and activity when I'm on holiday.

dialogue: A: Hi, John. What are you doing here?
B: I'm waiting for the bus.
A: Where are you going?
B: I'm going to the station to meet my sister.
A: Oh, is she coming by herself?
B: Yes, the train comes in about half past four, but it's twenty past four now. I have only ten minutes!
A: How often does the bus run?
response: B: Every ten minutes. I caught the No. 1 bus 15 minutes ago, and the next one hasn't come yet!

dialogue: A: What are you doing tonight?
B: I have to run to the grocery store.
A: Don't you hate fighting the crowds on the weekends?
B: Yes, but I am out of food and milk.
A: What store do you shop at?
B: The small one, just down the street. I like their generic brand.
A: I have been using the store across town for years.
B: I hear they have very nice stuff.
response: A: They do, and as an added bonus they're reasonably priced.

dialogue: A: Hello, Dora, I haven't seen you for a long time. Where have you been?
B: I didn ’ t go anywhere. I stayed at home.
A: What's up? You look unhappy.
B: Nothing. I just feel very lonely in this city. I miss my family.
A: Oh, I know. Sometimes I have the same feeling with you. But you'd better not be so emotional.
response: B: Can you leave me alone for a while?

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.
A: You could've gotten some change in a store.
response: B: But I was out on the edge of town. There wasn't any place to get change.

dialogue: A: What are you doing here?
B: I'm preparing my fishing tools.
A: What for?
response: B: I'm going to fish with some of my friends.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
B: How about some fresh fruit?
response: A: We don't have any fruit cakes today. All we have now is chocolate cake.

dialogue: A: Have you heard my good news?
B: You haven't told me anything yet.
A: I got a promotion at work earlier this week.
B: Is that right?
response: A: It's the truth . I really can't say I'm happy .

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
response: B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was unharmed in that bombing.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I'd like to pay my bill.
A: OK. In cash or by credit?
response: B: In cash . How much is the change in total ?

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
B: But it's three kilometers from here to the cinema. How can we get there in such a short time?
A: I think we can walk there in twenty minutes.
response: B: But I am afraid I can't walk that far.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, what's the screen near your steering wheel for?
B: It's a portable TV. It's a popular thing now.
A: Oh, that's new to me. So what's on everyday?
B: News about current affairs, documentaries, music, movies, noncommercial ads and so on.
A: Is there anything interesting?
B: Yes, there are something good and informative. I think that many people underestimate the value of TV in education.
response: A: I agree. Are there any commercials on the TV?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.

B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were even for sale. The last one was on sale for $9,000.
response: A: $9,000? Well, I may go and visit the exhibition tomorrow, and I'm going to buy lots of paintings.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
A: Do they look like roses?
B: No, they look like little bells.
response: A: Oh , lilies of the valley . No , I am sorry . We are all out of them right now .

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
B: We thought we'd have that at head office and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.
A: Ok. What sort of things would you like?
response: B: A very large lunch I think, so that people cannot eat while they move around and talk to each other. You did some thing similar for us last year. We'd be happy to have the same menu again.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
response: A: No , that's fine . It's not a problem if you didn't bring your bankbook with you.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.
B: Of course. I'll get someone to come around at the weekend.
A: Well, could he come around a bit sooner? I don't think we can manage until the weekend.
B: I see. Okay. I'll send someone over this afternoon then.
A: There's also the matter of the fridge. We all assumed there would be one in the flat when we moved in, because that's what we read from the advertisement in the newspaper.
response: B: Ah, yes. Thanks for that. I got rid of the old fridge, but I didn't get around to ordering a new one yet. I'm really grateful. I'll order one today and get it delivered to you tomorrow.

dialogue: A: I'd like to pay a visit to the Smiths at 3:30 p.m. Will you go with me, Mary?
B: I'd love to, but I won't be off work from my factory until 4:00 p.m. How about 4:15? I'll be free then, Jack.
A: OK. Let's meet at the bus stop and take the No.5 bus to go there.
response: B: Why not by bike? The bus would be empty at that time.

dialogue: A: Are we going to have gym class tomorrow?
B: Are you crazy? Tomorrow's Saturday.
A: Sometimes I forget that we don't have school on Saturdays.
B: Americans also don't go to work on Saturdays.
response: A: So there are only seven days to work in a week?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
response: B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to study together, but traveling is so expensive.

dialogue: A: Gosh! The water faucet is dripping badly again.
B: You are going to have a huge bill.
A: I know. I ’ Ve got to get it fixed ASAP.
B: Don't you wanna get it fixed now?
A: I wish I could, but I ’ Ve got to go now. I have an appointment in 20 minutes.
B: Well, if you need anything, just let me know.
A: Oh, by the way, could you give me a ride? My car is still in the garage.
response: B: You sure have bad luck these days .

dialogue: A: Are you ready to visit grandma in Springfield?
B: Yes. I just have to get the picture that I drew for her.
A: Great. Let's put it in this box, so it stays nice and flat.
B: I used the colored pencils that she got me for my birthday to make it, too! She will be happy about that.
response: A: No, she won't, even though she loves your artwork! I wish I had time to bake a cake.

dialogue: A: [A knock at the door.] Come in, please.
B: Hello, Kate. Where's Jane? I want her to type this letter for me.
A: I'm afraid she can't, Tom. She isn't working today.
B: Oh, why? Is she ill?
response: A: No. She's down with covid.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. What can I do for you?
A: I'd like a ticket to New York, please.
B: Round trip?
response: A: No, I changed my mind.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing Tasty Restaurant. What can I do for you?
B: Will you please show me a table beside the window?
A: Sorry, there's no table beside the window, only one table in the centre.
B: In the centre? OK.
A: This way,please.
B: Thank you.
response: A: Here's the window. Could I take your order?

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
response: B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
response: B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
A: Where are you living now?
B: Out in the suburbs. It's a long trip to work every day.
A: How are you going to find an apartment?
B: I'm going to buy a newspaper and check the classified ads.
A: Apartments in the city are expensive.
response: B: I know, but I'm going to enroll in a day school to take a course in business management.

dialogue: A: Oh, let's just go in for a minute, I'm hungry.
B: OK, but just a snack. We're eating supper at home tonight.
A: Let's get some milk and bread.
B: I don't really like milk. How about a soda?
A: They say Coca-Cola makes you fat. Milk is healthier.
response: B: Oh, if you don't want to be healthy, buy soda. And keep those butter cookies you have in your hand.

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
B: I thought she'd be happy.
response: A: Yeah, especially since she didn't get a promotion recently.

dialogue: A: I can't believe it! I lost.
B: It looks like you have to buy tickets for us, Jason. And we're not going to see an action movie!
A: That's not fair, you got all the easy questions.
response: B: I guess I was unlucky.

dialogue: A: What are you going to have for breakfast?
B: I just have some cereal each morning.
A: You're supposed to always have a hearty breakfast.
B: I don't always have time to make breakfast.
A: It's easy to make a quick breakfast.
B: What do you have for breakfast?
response: A: When I need to make a breakfast that's not very quick, I just make some oatmeal , toast , and OJ .

dialogue: A: What's going on around here? Why is everyone changing offices?
B: Haven't you heard? Where have you been anyway?
A: I just got back from visiting the plant in Chicago.
B: Well, there are a lot of changes being made here this week.
A: Yes, I see. But what are they?
B: For one thing, Martha and Jim are leaving.
response: A: Where are they going?Did they order food for lunch?

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
response: B: I'm glad it's summer. I like autumn best.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon! Dr. Perkins' office.
B: Good afternoon. I'd like to speak to the doctor. Is he in?
A: Who is that calling, please?
B: My name is Li Hong. I'm from China.
A: I'm sorry. Dr. Perkins is now at an important meeting and can't answer your call.
B: I'm an exchange scholar. Dr. Perkins asked me to give a lecture. There are some details I want to discuss with him.
response: A: I see, but you must speak to himself about that. Oh, well, if you leave your address, I'll tell him to ring you as soon as he is available.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
response: A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's the worst. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
response: A: I did, too. But we've got nothing else to see outside White House.

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
response: A: No, what you need is money

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
response: B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.

dialogue: A: Any messages, Miss Grey?
B: Just one, Mr. Blank. You had a telephone call from someone called Brown, David Brown.
A: Brown? I don't seem to know anyone called Brown. What did he say?
B: He wouldn't say. But it sounded important. I told him you'd phone him as soon as you got back.
response: A: Well, I'd better do it then, I suppose. It's not a problem if you don't have his phone number.

dialogue: A: Mr. Block, I need to take a few days off because my parents are coming over to visit.
B: But it's not really a good idea to take time off right now, you know.
A: Well, I know. But they've never been to the UK before and they don't speak English.
B: Hmm, you know there are thousands of tourists in London who can't speak English and they manage to get around.
A: Yes, I know but they really expect me to be there. It's culture. Chinese parents expect their children to do things like this.
B: I know, but truly if they care about your education, they'll understand.
A: Well, do you think I could take maybe just two days off?
response: B: Ok, two days but you must forget all of the work and throw away the materials.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
response: B: Do you know this all you can eat plan that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
A: No, I don't. I mean a general practitioner. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.
B: Really, I believe I can quit on my own. But I'll think about it. I will.
A: All fight. I won't mention it for a week. Then I want to know your decision. Because if you don't get some help, I need to rethink our plans.
response: B: You mean you'd break our car over this? I can't believe it!

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
response: A: Well, I'm thankful we don't need to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
response: B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.

dialogue: A: Betty, where did you go yesterday?
B: I went to visit a friend of mine in the hospital.
A: What did you talk about?
B: We talked about a lot of different things.
response: A: Did you talk about the weather?

dialogue: A: Are you free this evening, Li?
B: I ’ m afraid I ’ m busy tonight. I ’ m having dinner with friends.
A: What a pity. I wanted to go for a drink with you.
B: What about tomorrow? Are you doing anything tomorrow?
A: No, I haven ’ t got any plans.
response: B: Shall we stay home tomorrow then?

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
response: B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's free.

dialogue: A: Well, the salad's almost ready. How's the beef going? I'm starving.
B: So am I. The beef looks just about ready. Just one minute... ow!
A: What's the matter?
B: Oh, my finger, I burned my finger!
response: A: Oh, wait, I'll get a heating pad and put it on your finger.

dialogue: A: Betty, something is burning. Can you smell it?
B: You ’ re right.
A: Look! The iron is still on.
B: I should have turned it off. I ’ ll turn it off now.
response: A: Look at my nice blue shirt, there ’ s a big hole in it.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
response: B: They really started having a light show?

dialogue: A: Have you seen the job in the newspaper?
B: Do you mean the one in Manchester?
A: Yes.
B: I saw it just now.
A: What do you think of it?
B: I think I'm not the type of man to do it.
A: Why do you think so?
response: B: They need an engineer to take care of the machine and I knew everything about that kind of machine.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Are you waiting to buy today's film tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: Have you been here long?
B: About 45 minutes. I've moved forward a total about 3 feet.
A: Oh...
B: Not at all. A young couple who have been waited for one hour ahead of me finally gave up and left.
A: Does anyone know what caused the delay?
B: There are just not enough people selling tickets this afternoon.
A: I guess I should have come before lunch.
response: B: Maybe you would meet the same thing because few people has been looking forward to it for a long time.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
B: I'm very sorry this happened. I'll tell you what: I won't charge you for the soup today.
A: That's great. I can use a free lunch.
B: Good. I hope you come again.
response: A: I'll eat more soup. Thanks.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.
B: Uh. I didn't have any of that when I was in middle school, and I did just fine.
A: Yeah, and there weren't any cars either. Things are a lot more progressive now.
response: B: Great. My daughter will avoid playing video games in class.

dialogue: A: Hello, Thomas Brothers.
B: Hello, this is Mike Landon here. Is Jack Cooper there by any chance?
A: I am afraid not, he is away for a day or two, back on, let's see, Monday morning.
response: B: Oh, well perhaps I can just wait for him.

dialogue: A: Hello, Yang Mei. I hear you're going to the United States.
B: Yes. I'm going with my grandma. We're going to see my parents in New Jersey.
A: When are you leaving, then?
B: This Friday evening. Our plane leaves at seven fifteen.
A: How long will you be there?
B: Six months.
A: Six months! Do you go and see my grandparents in New York?
B: Of course, I will. I want to see as many places as I can. How can I travel?
A: Most people travel by car. The roads are very good.
B: But I don't have a car and I can't drive. Is there any other way to travel?
A: You can travel by bus. It's very cheap.
B: Can't I travel by train?
response: A: Yes, you can. The train is expensive in the States, but it's fast.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Does this hotel have a fitness facility?
B: Yes, we try to accommodate all needs of our patrons, including fitness.
A: Where is your fitness facility located?
response: B: The gym is just below the lobby . Take the elevator or the stairs . You can't miss it .

dialogue: A: Excuse me, madam. I'm wondering if you could tell me the place where I can repair my shoes.
B: There's one on Fifth Street.
A: Thank you, but how far is it to that store?
response: B: It's two cities away and not difficult to find. Just keep walking and after two blocks you will see a supermarket on your left. The store is next to the supermarket.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
response: A: Dad, I need some low tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
response: B: Yes , I heard the lights were out all night .

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
response: B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have been hurt or even killed?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
A: Do they look like roses?
B: No, they look like little bells.
response: A: Oh , sunflowers?  No , I am sorry . We are all out of them right now .

dialogue: A: Tom, look at your shoes. How dirty they are! You must clean them.
B: Oh, mum, but I cleaned them only yesterday.
A: They are dirty now. You must clean them again.
B: I do not want to clean them today. Even if I clean them today, they will get dirty again tomorrow.
A: All right, then.
B: Mum, give me something to eat, please.
A: You had your breakfast in the morning, Tom, and you had lunch at school.
response: B: I am thirsty again.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
A: Have you thought about camping?
B: Camping? I've never done that.
A: I think you'll really like it. You can rent the equipment you need.
B: Is it cheap?
response: A: No, it's actually more expensive than buying or staying at the hotel.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
B: I caught hold of his knife, and he pushed me to the floor.
A: Oh, no! Why did you catch hold of his knife? That's dangerous.
B: I don't know. I didn't think.
A: And what did the other passengers do? Did they help you?
response: B: Yes, they did. Two men ran from the robber and ignored him.

dialogue: A: What are you thinking?
B: I ’ m thinking about where we shall spend our vocation.
A: It ’ s about 7 o ’ clock. let ’ s have our breakfast first.
B: Ok, dear.We will be late.
A: What do you want?
B: A ham salad sandwich.
A: Sorry, I didn ’ t prepare this.
response: B: Then , I ’ d like some eggs and bread for breakfast instead .

dialogue: A: Cheers! To our first night in our new apartment.
B: It's so quiet. I'm not really used to it.
A: All you hear is the crickets and the breeze.
response: B: Since I'm deaf. I'm sure the silence will begin to grow on me.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
response: A: I won't ask the old woman in that reception office .

dialogue: A: Have you packed our passports?
B: Not yet. Do we need to take it with us?
A: Of course. Otherwise I cannot go abroad.
B: Is that hard to get a passport?
A: Not at all. But we do need to keep it with us all the time.
response: B: It is hard to believe this little thing has no value to us .

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote?
B: Yes, are you?
A: Yeah, but what day are the elections?
B: You don ’ t know what day the elections are?
A: That ’ s why I ’ m asking you.
B: They ’ re this coming Tuesday.
A: Really?
B: Yes, I ’ m serious.
A: Good thing you told me.
B: I can ’ t believe you didn ’ t know when the elections were.
A: It slipped my mind.
response: B: You should watch the news more often.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
response: A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a pedal bike because you don't need to get around faster and can go to the beach if you like.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that Susan got married?
B: Really? I remember she said if she would remain single. Is the man very rich?
A: No. That ’ s what is surprising me.
B: You means she didn ’ t marry a rich man.
response: A: He's a postman who comes from a lot of wealth.

dialogue: A: Did you hear the news?
B: What happened?
A: Our cousin went into labor and had her baby last week.
B: She did? Why didn't anyone tell me?
A: I would've thought that somebody would have told you.
B: No, I had no idea.
A: Well, she did, her baby was 8 pounds 6 ounces.
B: Oh my God, that's great!
response: A: Are you going to go and visit him and the baby?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
response: A: Do they look like roses ?

dialogue: A: Have you been to exhibitions in your spare time?
B: Yes, a lot of times. I like exhibitions-exhibitions about famous people: dancers, actors, you know?
A: Mm, and what about a folk concert? Have you ever been to one of them?
B: No. I don't like folk music very much.
A: What about the opera?
response: B: No, never. I really like the opera. It is a bit too heavy for me.

dialogue: A: What are you working on?
B: I'm figuring out my budget.
A: What budget?
B: I'm making a shopping budget, so that I don't spend too much money.
A: How much money can you spend?
B: I can only spend $ 300 a month.
A: Why only $ 300?
response: B: I need to get rid of the rest.

dialogue: A: Hello, I'm returning your phone call.
B: I'm glad that you could get back to me so fast.
A: No problem, but what were you calling about?
B: I needed to talk to you about your son.
A: Is he messing up in school?
response: B: He was doing well in class .

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
response: A: It's dreadful. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
A: Nobody to take care of her?
B: My father travels a lot to many countries and he is doing business in Dubai now. I have to do a lot for my mom at home.
response: A: Oh, I see. You are very considerate.

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a letter.
B: There's a mail box up the street. Have you already got a stamp on that letter?
response: A: Yes, I have to register it. How do I walk to the post office from here?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
A: No, that's fine. Do you bring your bankbook with you?
response: B: Yes, I do. Here it is, and the map.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.
B: I wish I could. My boss just did me a favor by putting me on evenings. And he'll hit the ceiling if I ask to change again.
A: Wait a minute. I have an idea. Have you checked the course over at the community college? They might offer an introductory course during the day.
B: That's a great idea. I'm free this afternoon. I'll go over and check it out.
response: A: Their courses are actually cheaper.

dialogue: A: Tom, look at your shoes. How dirty they are! You must clean them.
B: Oh, mum, but I cleaned them only yesterday.
A: They are dirty now. You must clean them again.
B: I do not want to clean them today. Even if I clean them today, they will get dirty again tomorrow.
A: All right, then.
B: Mum, give me something to eat, please.
A: You had your breakfast in the morning, Tom, and you had lunch at school.
response: B: I am hungry again.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
response: B: We have only first class tickets left, but we can give you a discount if you buy a second class ticket.

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
A: The Fools Garden is giving a performance today.
response: B: They are a pop group. They are said to be very good. What time does the performance start?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
response: B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a white house. The General Reading Room is inside it.

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
response: B: You had pretty impressive scores

dialogue: A: Hi, Mike. What have you been up to?
B: Not much. I started exercising.
A: Trying to get in shape?
B: Yeah, and I need to start improving my health.
A: Me, too. What are you doing besides exercising?
B: That's about all.
response: A: I think if you eat more fries, it will also help a lot.

dialogue: A: Hello, Catherine. Would you like to go out tomorrow?
B: Tomorrow?
A: Yeah, I was thinking we could get a bite to eat and catch a movie.
B: That sounds great.
A: Yes. We can do something else if you like.
response: B: sleeping on my bed all day would be perfect.

dialogue: A: Did you see the news today?
B: I haven't had a chance to see it.
A: You know about the blackout last night, right?
response: B: The lights were on everywhere around me.

dialogue: A: Bill, do you know when did the Chinese begin to celebrate Teachers ' Day?
B: I know the Chinese teachers had their first festival in 1985.
A: So, it is the 27th Teachers ' Day.
B: What will you do on Teachers ' Day?
response: A: I am going to send Mr. Li some flowers on father's Day.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
B: I'm sorry, but I don't sell tickets. You can get one from the machine over there.
response: A: All right. By the way, what's the seat number?

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.
A: You could've gotten some change in a store.
response: B: But I was out in the center of town. There wasn't any place to get change.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, it looks like you've got some sun this weekend.
B: Yeah, I guess so. I spent the weekend at the beach.
A: Oh, yeah, that's great. Where did you stay?
B: Some friends of my parents' live out there and they invited me for as long as I wanted to stay.
A: So what are you doing back here already?
B: Oh, I have a paper to work on, and I just couldn't do any serious studying at the beach.
A: I don't blame you. So what did you do out there? I mean besides lying out in the sun.
B: I ran slowly up and down the beach, and 1 played some volleyball. You know I never realized how hard it is to run on sand. I couldn't even get through a whole game before I had to sit down.
A: Did you go swimming?
response: B: I wanted to, but they said the water isn't warm enough for that until a couple of months from now.

dialogue: A: (sniffing) Is that a French cigarette?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that a French cigarette you're smoking?
B: Yes, that's right. Why? What's the matter?
A: I don't understand why yousmoke French cigarettes. They make a terrible smell.
B: I like them very much. I prefer them to English cigarettes.
A: Have you got a lot of them?
B: Yes, about 200, why?
response: A: Well... er... could I buy some from you?

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing Tasty Restaurant. What can I do for you?
B: Will you please show me a table beside the window?
A: Sorry, there's no table beside the window, only one table in the centre.
B: In the centre? OK.
A: This way,please.
B: Thank you.
response: A: Here's the online menu. Could I take your order remotely?

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.
B: Hi, Jane.
A: What are you going to do this Saturday evening?
B: I'm going to a concert.
A: How exciting! Who is going to sing at the concert?
B: Xu Song. He is my favorite pop singer.
A: Where is he going to give the concert?
B: In the gym.
A: What time is it going to start?
B: At 7:30 p. m. Would you like to go with me?
response: A: I'd love to, but I'm going to visit my uncle.

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
B: The music group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?
A: It's on the wall, madam, on the blackboard.
B: Indeed. I suppose you can't afford proper menus.
A: I'm sorry, madam, but that's what we always do.
response: B: Oh, If I weren't so hungry, I would order immediately.

dialogue: A: Ann, let's go, or we will be late.
B: What time is it?
A: It is already 10:25.
B: Well, we still have about 15 minutes.
A: What time did you say the train is leaving?
B: 12:05. And it takes only 20 minutes to get to the station by bus.
A: Yes, but what will happen if the bus is late?
B: Relax, those buses run every 10 minutes, so we have plenty of time.
A: ( still on the bus. ) What time is it?
B: It is a quarter to twelve.
response: A: Oh dear, we will be in time for our train.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.
B: Oh, yes. Everything all right?
A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
response: B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
response: B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by train.

dialogue: A: Are you really dating with Frank?
B: Yeah. But in my heart of hearts, I find he ’ s not very much to my liking.
A: Then why not keep away from him?
response: B: The problem is that I just have too many to turn to right now.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Could I be of any service to you?
B: Have you got any Chinese paintings?
A: Yes, we have landscape paintings, figure paintings and flower-and-bird paintings.
B: I'd like a flower-and-bird painting.
response: A: Good . How about this picture of cranes with pine trees ? It was painted by a famous Chinese painter in King Dynasty .

dialogue: A: Brad, wait!
B: What?
A: How come you have a locker but I don't?
B: Mr. Rogers probably forgot to assign a locker to you.
A: I had to carry my backpack with me all day.
B: Remind him to give you a locker tomorrow.
A: Does it have a lock?
response: B: No. You have to buy your own. You'll have to go to a yard sale to pick one up.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bob. I heard about your accident but I didn't think it would be this bad.
B: Well, thanks for making me feel better.
A: I can hardly recognize you. Tell me what happened.

B: I just got back from Africa where I had a terrible accident in a motorcycle race. I broke both my legs when my motor failed and was hit by another motorcycle. I was laid up in a hospital over there for three weeks.
A: Three weeks, that's a long time. What did you do while you were in the hospital?
B: Well, if you can believe it, I read all about motorcycle racing. I love racing even if it hurts.
A: But I'm afraid you don't make it look very funny. You're lucky to be alive.
B: That's for sure. I am lucky to be alive.
A: How soon can you get well? Did the doctor tell you about it?
B: They say I still need to stay in bed for two weeks or so.
A: I think you'll get a bit fatter by then. By the way, is there anything I can do for you?
response: B: No, thank you. Thank you for the beautiful flowers. It's very kind of me to come to see you.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
B: Yes, of course. Shall we give her some flowers?
A: Flowers are lovely. But I think it's better to buy her a nice box of chocolates.
B: Alice doesn't like sweet things. Didn't you know that?
A: You're right. Er... I know. We can give her a record. She loves music.
response: B: That's a good idea. Let's go to the karaoke shop and choose one for her.

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
B: But the money's not bad and there's plenty of fresh air.
A: If I were you, I'd take some kind of direction, like teaching law.
B: Teaching? Anything but that. It's so boring.
A: Come on, you really must think of the future.
B: I'll tell you what. I'd like to be a doctor.
response: A: Well, you should think very seriously about that. It means a lot of study, and then working all sorts of hours.

dialogue: A: Hello, Dora, I haven't seen you for a long time. Where have you been?
B: I didn ’ t go anywhere. I stayed at home.
A: What's up? You look unhappy.
B: Nothing. I just feel very lonely in this city. I miss my family.
A: Oh, I know. Sometimes I have the same feeling with you. But you'd better not be so emotional.
B: Can you stay and accompany me for a while?
A: Sure, no problem. You can call me any time you are alone from now on.
B: Thank you so much. You are so sweet.
response: A: Not at all . We are friends .

dialogue: A: Hello. Matt White speaking.
B: Hello, Dr. White, my name's Pan Johnson. My roommate, Janet Holmes, wanted me to call you.
A: Janet Holmes? Oh, that's right. She's in my Shakespearean English class. Has anything happened to her?

B: Nothing, it's just that she submitted a job application yesterday and the company asked her in for an interview today. She's afraid she won't be able to attend your class this afternoon. I'm calling to see whether it would be OK if I gave you her essay.
A: Certainly, that would be fine. Uh, you can either drop it off at my class or bring it to my office.
B: Would it be all right to come by your office around 4:00? I'm afraid I can't come any earlier because I have three classes this afternoon.
A: Uh, I won't be here when you come. I'm supposed to be at a meeting from 3:00 to 6:00, but how about leaving it with my secretary? She usually stays until 5:00.
response: B: Fine, please tell her I'll be there at 4:00. And Dr. White, one more thing, could you tell me where your office is? Janet told me where your class is, but she didn't give me directions to your office.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
B: She's very fond of detective stories?
A: I see. Has she read any detective stories?
B: Oh, yes!
A: Do you know if she's read this one?
B: I'm not sure, but she probably won't remember if she has! She's very forgetful!
A: Ah! She has a bad memory. How old is she?
B: She's eighty-seven.
response: A: I suggest you take this book . It's not very exciting .

dialogue: A: Hello, I am calling about my cable service.
B: What's the problem?
A: For the past week my cable hasn't been working.
response: B: I apologize , but the cable has been fast lately .

dialogue: A: I can't believe it! I lost.
B: It looks like you have to buy tickets for us, Jason. And we're not going to see an action movie!
A: That's not fair, you got all the easy questions.
B: I guess that's just the luck of the draw.
response: A: I want a rematch . Let's play again .

dialogue: A: Good afternoon! Dr. Perkins' office.
B: Good afternoon. I'd like to speak to the doctor. Is he in?
A: Who is that calling, please?
B: My name is Li Hong. I'm from China.
A: I'm sorry. Dr. Perkins is now at an important meeting and can't answer your call.
B: I'm an exchange scholar. Dr. Perkins asked me to give a lecture. There are some details I want to discuss with him.
response: A: I see, but you must speak to himself about that. Oh, well, if you leave your number, I'll tell him to ring you as soon as he is available.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
B: If you got laid off or are working a lot fewer hours, you may qualify.
A: Do I definitely get to collect unemployment?
B: Not all jobs pay into unemployment insurance, so their employees cannot collect benefits.
A: How do I check out my status to collect unemployment?
B: You should have noticed unemployment insurance being deducted from your paycheck. Check your pay stubs.
A: How much will my unemployment check be?
response: B: The more money you made, the more you will earn on unemployment. They have a lottery.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, I'll have a steak, please.
A: How would you like the steak, rare, medium, or well-done?
B: Rare, please.
A: Would you like something to drink?
response: B: Coffee cake, please.

dialogue: A: Bill, I must tell you the truth. You failed the English exam again.
B: Ah? Really? That stinks!
A: Haha. April Fool's! Did you forget what day it is today?
B: Wow, you were pulling my leg all along. I was really fooled.
response: A: Alright, now let's be serious. Actually, you did get low marks on the exam.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
response: B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need a party for myself.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.
A: In what ways? What has she done?
B: Oh, no, you don't really want to hear it.
A: Come on. I am a mother of two girls.
