B: Ok. I'm worried because she often hides in her room and sends messages to her friends.
response: A: Come on. It's not a big deal. She needs only her parents at this age. You can talk with her if you are really concerned.

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
B: I was sick. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of bed.
A: You still look a little sick. You couldn't go back to bed.
B: I'm going now. I just came here to speak to my professor.
A: What did he tell you?
B: He said that I'd be able to take a make-up.
A: Well, that's all right then. Are you going straight home?
response: B: I have to stop at the drugstore on the way.  I need some condoms.

dialogue: A: Alison, would you like to have some more?
B: No, thanks. I've had enough.
A: Actually you haven't had much.
response: B: To tell you the truth, I am not on a diet.

dialogue: A: Tom, as the manager of a company selling green products, you are now quite a successful businessman. When did you know you wanted to have your own company?

B: My family left Budapest in 1986 and settled in Canada where a lot of my friends' parents were highly successful businessmen. It seems so cool, so in high school, I started a web-designed company and learned a lot from that experience.
A: How did you find the money for your present company then?
B: We've raised 18 million dollars from about 50 people. We're finally making money. I own 6% of the company and all employees get their shares.
A: By the way, what aspects of your life are green?
response: B: I'm majorly green.  I do simple things and I own a private jet.  I flew cross Canada.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
A: I wonder if you can change it to one size down.
response: B: Yes , of course . Will you come with tomatoes?

dialogue: A: Do you know how to play tennis?
B: Not very well. But I'd love to learn.
A: Would you like to play with me tomorrow morning?
B: Certainly, but I'm not very good.
A: We'll see about that. Anyway, you know that practice makes perfect.
B: How is eight o'clock?
response: A: Ok, you won't forget to bring football, will you?

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
A: Ok, I won't keep you then.
B: Great! It's good to see you. Goodbye!
response: A: Yes , stay alert . Bye !

dialogue: A: Cheers! To our first night in our new apartment.
B: It's so quiet. I'm not really used to it.
A: All you hear is the crickets and the breeze.
response: B: It's a little loud. I'm sure the silence will begin to grow on me.

dialogue: A: Welcome.
B: Hi, John. Hey, you've done a good job decorating this place, really nice.
A: Thanks, I am glad you like it. Can I get you a drink?
B: No, thanks. Let's make dinner. I am getting hungry.
A: Here is the kitchen. I will wash the onions first. Could you take the meat out of the fridge? It's in a yellow plastic container.
B: Wow, this smells good.
A: Could yon pass those potatoes to me, please?
B: What are we having?
A: My special dumplings, sweet and sour pork, beef with onions and green peppers, and a few side dishes like tomatoes with sugar.
B: Sounds wonderful. What are you going to do next?
response: A: I'll start preparing the meat lasagna.

dialogue: A: Cheers! To our first night in our new apartment.
B: It's so quiet. I'm not really used to it.
A: All you hear is the crickets and the breeze.
B: It's a little eerie. I'm sure the silence will begin to grow on me.
A: Well, I think it's fabulous. And the neighbors don't even seem to exist.
response: B: That is a relief. It's a good thing we gave them noise warnings.

dialogue: A: Did you hear Jakie's going to work in another department? We need to have a really good party so that we can send her off really well. So, what shall we do?
B: Why don't we have a surprise party, Maggie?
A: That's a good idea. We could go to the Holiday Inn Hotel.
B: That's too expensive. Maybe we can ask Carrie to make a cake.
A: Yeah, let's do that. Perhaps we could just give the party in the office and put up some balloons.
B: That's great. I think we should also buy a really big card, a huge card, and we should get everybody to sign it.
response: A: Shall we have a silent film?

dialogue: A: Are you going to leave school at the end of the term?
B: Yes, I am.
A: What are you going to do?
B: I'm going to be a clerk.
A: What does a clerk do?
B: He works in an office. He writes letters and reports, and he types.
A: I want to be a vet.
B: A-what?
A: A vet-a veterinary surgeon.
B: Good gracious! What's that?
response: A: A vet's a man who takes care of sick people. He's a doctor.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
response: B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another towel.

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
B: Well, my mum wants me to keep all the cans, so that we can sell them after a while.
A: Aha, you are going to make a millionaire of yourself sooner or later with all those cans.

B: You bet I will. Well, that's not the point. The point is we separate reusable things from other rubbish. We have to pay the dustman for dealing with rubbish, but if we sell him these cans and other reusable material we pay less.
A: That sounds a clever idea. Now what are reused in China?
B: Metal, plastic, paper, books and the like.
A: Just as we do back home in the States.

B: And to avoid waste, the government is limiting the production of goods that can be used only once, such as bamboo chopsticks. For example, all the fast food boxes should be made of paper instead of non-reusable material.
response: A: That will surely be helpful for a polluted environment.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote tomorrow?
B: I sure am. How about you?
A: I am.
response: B: Do you know where your polling place is?

dialogue: A: Good afternoon. I'm looking for a second-hand car and I believe you sell cars.
B: Yes. I have one here that may interest you.
A: Ah, yes. A friend told me about it. What make is it?
B: It's a Lincoln.
A: Is it MS 560 or MF 558? I don't want either of them. I want a MF 650 one.
B: Oh, it's the one you want, and it's three years old.
A: Mmm... hmm. And what sort of condition is it in?
response: B: It's in very good condition and it's not particularly compact.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
response: B: Many customers didn't want them .

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit sort of hands at present. Two waitresses are ill.

A: All right, but that's no excuse. My husband asked for goose and he was brought chicken instead. It's just unbelievable! And my beans weren't cooked properly. It wasn't a very enjoyable meal at all.
B: This is most regrettable.
A: Look at this bill. We've been overcharged. We only had one dessert, not two. Can you check the bill again, please?
B: I do apologize, Madam.
response: A: I'm afraid I'm going to pay the service charge, but won't give a tip, as I don't feel satisfied with it. I'm quite disappointed as a matter of fact.

dialogue: A: Did I do well on my test?
B: Do you want to know the honest answer?
A: Why wouldn't I want to know?
response: B: You had pretty bad scores.

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
B: But it's three kilometers from here to the cinema. How can we get there in such a short time?
A: I think we can walk there in twenty minutes.
B: But I am afraid I can't walk that far.
response: A: If you don't feel like walking, we can take a taxi.

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
A: I have to write you a ticket.
B: Can't you give me a warning?
A: I'm not going to be able to do that.
response: B: How much will the repair be?

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
response: B: It's a good time to have a winter festival. Do you want to have one this weekend.

dialogue: A: Welcome to this idition of writers. Tonight we have Steven Das with us. Congratulations on your book. It's such a success.
B: Thank you.
A: This is your first time to that poetry? Did you ever try before? Did you ever take any classes in poetry?

B: Well. My only real experience was writing business plans. Other than that. I've experience. We're writing with concerned. I've always had the good grass of the writing with the English language. Thanks to my mom who studied my reading when I was very little.
A: What's the hardest thing that in the world?
response: B: Definitely finding the perfect words to fit what I wanted to say. There're always work word two that I might to rewrite if given the chance.

dialogue: A: Hi! Can I help you?
B: Hi! Have you got any records of modern guitar music?
A: We've got a lot of them. Which one are you looking for?
B: I'm looking for some records of Julian Bream. I saw them in your window last week and I had them before in Canada, but I broke them.
A: What happened?
response: B: They were in my underwear.  I sat on my underwear and broke my records.  My sister told me about your shop.  I came here last week and saw the records.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
response: B: I don't sell tickets to the movies. You can get one from the machine over there.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for myself.
A: Oh? Did you talk with her about it?
response: B: I've tried, and it worked.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mike. What have you been up to?
B: Not much. I started exercising.
A: Trying to get in shape?
response: B: Yeah, and I need to start improving my health.

dialogue: A: Waitress! I think there's something wrong with our bill.
B: No, I don't think so...$10 for the drinks, 15 for the small plate, and 20 for the main dish.
A: What? I knew the cheese sticks were 15. I always order cheese sticks, but I thought the main dish was $10.
B: Oh, that explains it. You think the bill should be $35.
A: Yes, exactly. I was wondering what happened to the rest of my change. I should have gotten back 15, not 5!
B: I understand. Sometimes people aren't honest, but I think this was an honest mistake. Didn't you order the sea cucumbers for dinner?
response: A: Yes, and they were delicious. Best cucumbers ever! I'm so glad I only eat meat.

dialogue: A: Good morning, mom.
B: Good morning, sweetie. You finally got up.
A: I'm still sleepy.
B: Did you stay up late last night?
response: A: No , I couldn't fall asleep last night .

dialogue: A: What time do you usually get up in the morning?
B: I sleep in every morning, sometimes until 11 or 12.
A: Are you serious? I get up at 5 every morning to go to the gym, and then I get to work around 7.
B: Well, I work from home, so I can set my own hours. I usually work until midnight or 1 in the morning, and then I like to sleep in.
response: A: I like to be in bed around 9 or 10 at night so I can get enough sleep. Our schedules are very different! You're lucky that you get to set your own schedule, but I could never sleep that late. I'm definitely a morning person.

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
response: B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent three minutes on it.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
response: B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: Yes, I am.
A: Is this your first year in college?
B: I actually transferred here from another school.
A: Which school?
B: I transferred from PCC.
A: How do you like it here compared to PCC?
B: I love it here.
A: Do you like it better here or at PCC?
B: Don ’ t get me wrong. I like it here, but PCC is better.
A: So, why did you leave PCC?
response: B: Because I got my AA and now I am taking a year off.

dialogue: A: Hello. Matt White speaking.
B: Hello, Dr. White, my name's Pan Johnson. My roommate, Janet Holmes, wanted me to call you.
A: Janet Holmes? Oh, that's right. She's in my Shakespearean English class. Has anything happened to her?

B: Nothing, it's just that she submitted a job application yesterday and the company asked her in for an interview today. She's afraid she won't be able to attend your class this afternoon. I'm calling to see whether it would be OK if I gave you her essay.
A: Certainly, that would be fine. Uh, you can either drop it off at my class or bring it to my office.
B: Would it be all right to come by your office around 4:00? I'm afraid I can't come any earlier because I have three classes this afternoon.
A: Uh, I won't be here when you come. I'm supposed to be at a meeting from 3:00 to 6:00, but how about leaving it with my secretary? She usually stays until 5:00.
response: B: 00. And Dr. White, one more thing, could you tell me where your office is? Janet told me where your class is, but she didn't give me directions to your house.

dialogue: A: Have you gone to school today?
B: I went to school today. Did you go to school?
A: I couldn't go to school today, I was sick.
response: B: That's horrible . Would you give me the assignments from English class?

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
B: And the bike was run over by the car. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.
A: It was lucky that you didn't get hurt.
B: Yeah. But it's a pity I can't ride my bike this weekend.
A: Oh. Did you have a weekend plan?
response: B: Yeah.  I planned to go flying with friends by bike.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
A: Have you thought about camping?
B: Camping? I've never done that.
A: I think you'll really like it. You can rent the equipment you need.
B: Is it cheap?
response: A: Yeah, much cheaper than buying or staying at the hotel.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
response: B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's been the same recently.

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
A: So you could have made it. But you were still late for class.

B: The thing is, when I got off, I found I had left my bag in his car. And it was too late to get it back when I realized that. I went straight to the nearest shop and gave him a call. I waited for five minutes before Mr. Green drove back.
response: A: Finally, he gave you your bag and you came to the classroom and you were already 15 minutes early for class at that time. Is that all?

dialogue: A: Are you ready to move?
B: Definitely. I Ve got the hell out of the company. Anything new?
A: Yes, but there is a chance that might be suitable for you.
B: Really? Are you willing to recommend me for the position?
response: A: I can't say, but let me make a call and see if I can help.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr Thompson. My name is Mary Brown.
B: Good morning, Ms Brown. Take a seat, please.
A: Thank you.
B: Well, Ms Brown, could you please tell me about yourself?
A: Yes, of course, I'm 18 years old and just graduated from Peterson Secretary School. I read your ad. in the newspaper and know that you are looking for a secretary.
B: Could you tell me what you can do?
response: A: I can do whatever an executive assistant is expected to do, such as typing, receiving phone calls, sending faxes, and writing reports.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
A: Do they look like roses?
B: No, they look like little bells.
response: A: Oh , giant sunflowers . No , I am sorry . We are all out of them right now .

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go swimming and cycling by myself.
response: A: Oh, I forgot about that. I go cycling sometimes too. And I never go swimming on vacation, even recreational swimming.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
response: A: Well, it has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.

dialogue: A: Did you hear Jakie's going to work in another department? We need to have a really good party so that we can send her off really well. So, what shall we do?
B: Why don't we have a surprise party, Maggie?
A: That's a good idea. We could go to the Holiday Inn Hotel.
B: That's too expensive. Maybe we can ask Carrie to make a cake.
A: Yeah, let's do that. Perhaps we could just give the party in the office and put up some balloons.
B: That's great. I think we should also buy a really big card, a huge card, and we should get everybody to sign it.
response: A: Shall we have some music at the party Jakie planned for herself?

dialogue: A: Did you hear Jakie's going to work in another department? We need to have a really good party so that we can send her off really well. So, what shall we do?
B: Why don't we have a surprise party, Maggie?
A: That's a good idea. We could go to the Holiday Inn Hotel.
B: That's too expensive. Maybe we can ask Carrie to make a cake.
A: Yeah, let's do that. Perhaps we could just give the party in the office and put up some balloons.
B: That's great. I think we should also buy a really big card, a huge card, and we should get everybody to sign it.
response: A: Shall we have some music?

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
A: I sprained my wrist, but the doctor says it will be fine.
B: How many days will you be out of school?
response: A: The doctor said I should be good enough to return tomorrow .

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
response: A: So you couldn't have made it. But you were still late for class.

dialogue: A: Hey, I'm calling to say that I'm running late to the airport. Can you make sure that the plane doesn't take off without me?
B: I'll try.
A: Thank you. I'm just sitting here in traffic. There must be an accident or something. I've been here for 30 minutes, and I've barely made it onto the bridge.
B: Oh, that's not good.
response: A: This traffic is really unimportant to me. I don't care if I have to take a later flight!

dialogue: A: David, why didn ’ t you clean the room?
B: I ’ m not in the mood.
A: Why are you feeling depressed?
response: B: I was told my girlfriend was speaking well of me. That made me happy.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
response: B: Well, I've been hardly working lately... more than 11 hours a day.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
response: B: No, it was as large as a room and worked faster.

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
response: A: It's boring. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
response: B: Oh, all right. Well, we could rent a video and watch that.

dialogue: A: Are you going somewhere?
B: Yes, I ’ m off to the department store. I must buy some furniture for my new flat.
A: Really? Well you ’ ll have to get there before 6pm because they close early today.
B: Ok. Thanks for that information.
A: Yeah and remember if you buy something you mustn ’ t carry it home otherwise your back will get worse.
B: Ok, do they have a delivery service?
response: A: Yes, but it ’ s not free, you have to pay.

dialogue: A: It's lucky that we rode our bike here instead of driving.
B: It's a good job that we got here early. Look at all those cars there. They'll never get in.
A: You'd better follow me closely. I don't want to lose you.
B: Don't worry. I'll keep up.
A: We go in over there. Gate B. Peter said they're pretty good tickets.
B: Where are they?
A: They're right behind the goal.
B: Oh,do we have to stand up all the time?
A: That's right.
response: B: I hope we can see the match with obstructions in the way.

dialogue: A: An interesting meeting, isn't it?
B: Yes, very. I thought the last speaker was especially good.
A: Let me introduce myself, by the way. My name's Thomas Bradley.
B: How do you do? I'm Ted Nugent.
A: Sorry, what was your last name again?
B: It's Nugent, N-U-G-E-N-T, but just call me Ted.
A: Ok, I'm Tom.
B: Glad to meet you.
A: And what do you do, Ted?
B: Me? I'm in the car business.
response: A: Salesman?

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
response: A: Yes. The farthest one all the way across town is next to the bank. It's quite dilapidated and falling apart.

dialogue: A: Would you please tell me why you want to work in our kindergarden? You know kids are sometimes so tiresome.
B: I love children. I can sing to them and teach them how to dance.
A: Then have you worked in a kindergarden before?
response: B: No, but I used to take care of children during summer and winter holidays.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, waiter, but I think there is something in my soup.
B: What's wrong?
A: Well, I think I saw an insect or something when I was spooning out the noodles. Could you please bring me another bowl?
B: Oh, I'm very sorry. I'll get you another bowl.
A: Thank you.
B: Here you are, a fresh bowl of soup.
A: Thanks a lot.
B: I'm very sorry this happened. I'll tell you what: I won't charge you for the soup today.
A: That's great. I can use a free lunch.
B: Good. I hope you come again.
response: A: I'll do that. Thanks.

dialogue: A: A woman after my own heart...
B: OK, Mr. Coffee Connoisseur, so what's the next step in the coffee-making process?
A: Well, step two is grinding the coffee beans. I've roasted three different types of beans.
B: Let me guess, Mocha, Mandheling, and Santos!
A: Yep, my own special blend! You can tell by just smelling them?
response: B: No, I just read the names of your parents off your apron... Ha!

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
B: But the money's not bad and there's plenty of fresh air.
A: If I were you, I'd take some kind of direction, like teaching law.
response: B: Teaching? Anything but that. It's so boring.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
response: A: May I borrow your invisible ink pen?

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
response: A: I had a terrible time . You seem to be in a hurry . Don't let me hold you up .

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
response: B: He was messing around last week after class.

dialogue: A: Hello, John. How was your French exam yesterday?
B: Not too good.
A: Well, the term exam is always more difficult. Work harder, and you'll certainly do better next time.
B: I've worked hard enough, I think, but unluckily, I have never done well in the exam.
A: Well, it's no use worrying about the exam now. Let's talk about the football game tonight. It's much more interesting.
B: Is there a football game on TV tonight?
A: Yes it's between the Chinese team and the Japanese team.
B: ... Er I'd rather watch some other programmes.
A: Why? You're so interested in football.
response: B: The Chinese team has always played very well in the important match, just as I have done in the important exam.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
A: No, but we can get your package to France in one week for 40 dollars.
B: Well, that sounds good. I'll take that. Is the service guaranteed?
A: Yes. We also offer a service where we can track your package. But that will cost 10 dollars extra.
response: B: Oh, I won't need the tracking service...

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.
B: Hi, Jane.
A: What are you going to do this Saturday evening?
B: I'm going to a concert.
response: A: How exciting! Who is going to sing at the concert?

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: I'm in a hurry. How long will it take?
B: About half an hour, if there's no traffic jam.
A: Do you think the traffic will be heavy?
response: B: I doubt it. It's not rush hour.

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
response: A: No, what you need is to be unathletic

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
A: I have no other choice. Next month will be the most important exam of this term.
B: I can understand that. But anyway, you should take better care of yourself.
A: What should I do now?
response: B: I think you should stay in bed for a little while and I will call the priest

dialogue: A: Are you being served, sir?
B: I'd like to buy a tapestry to decorate my new room.
A: Artistic tapestry is the highest expression form of the rug weaving art. How about these ones?
B: These are beautiful! Is this the marvelous landscape in Guiling?
A: Yes, sir.
B: How fine the needlework is! What's the price?
A: Ninety dollars.
response: B: It's too expensive.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you live here?
B: Yes.
A: Oh, well, do you know where the English Language Institute is?
B: Ah, yes. I think I know where it is. Do you have a car?
A: No, I'm on foot.
B: Well, as you go out of the station, just continue along the road until you come to the second crossing and then turn left into King Street.
A: Yes.
B: Then walk down the street just a bit and take the first turning on the right. And keep walking until you come to the park.
A: A park, yes.
response: B: Well, let's see. Walk through the park. As you get to the end of the path you will see two small roads. Take the road on the right and the English Language Institute is at the end of the road. You can't miss it.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mary. Why are you standing here?
B: I'm waiting for a bus. The buses are so full at this time of the day.
A: Sure. Where are you going? I don't think this is your way home.
B: You are right. I'm going for a walk in the park.
A: Going for a walk even after along day's work?
response: B: Yes. I always enjoy sleeping alone in the park after work.

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
A: Where are you living now?
B: Out in the suburbs. It's a long trip to work every day.
A: How are you going to find an apartment?
response: B: I'm going to buy a novel and check the classified ads.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. Is it true you're moving to London?
B: Yes, it is.
A: What made you decide to do that?
B: Work, mainly. I'm sure I'll be able to find a job there.
A: You're probably right. But where are you going to live?
B: I hope I'll find a flat to share with somebody. That way it will be cheaper.
A: Yes, that's a good idea. Are you taking your dog with you?
B: No, I don't think so. My parents have offered to take care of him, and I don't think he'd be happy in the city.
A: You're probably right. But aren't you afraid of moving to such a big place, especially after living in a small village?
B: Not really. I think I'll enjoy myself. There's so much to do there; I expect I won't miss the countryside much and I can always come back and visit.
response: A: Well, I just hope you'll move again when you get settled.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: We'd like to take a tour to Florence.
A: That's a beautiful city. When do you want to go there?
response: B: We have got a 2 weeks' business trip and we plan to leave on Thursday.

dialogue: A: Can I order take-out here?
B: Yes, sir. What would you like?
A: I want a hamburger, a medium French fries, a Big Mac meal, and a double cheeseburger, please.
B: Anything else?
A: And a 6-piece chicken nuggets.
B: What kind of drink would you like?
A: A large Coke with extra ice and a milkshake. And please give me several more straws. How much do I owe you?
B: Let me calculate it, er... that comes to $ 14.30.
response: A: Here's $15. Don't keep the change.

dialogue: A: Gosh! The water faucet is dripping badly again.
B: You are going to have a huge bill.
A: I know. I ’ Ve got to get it fixed ASAP.
B: Don't you wanna get it fixed now?
A: I wish I could, but I ’ Ve got to go now. I have an appointment in 20 minutes.
B: Well, if you need anything, just let me know.
A: Oh, by the way, could you give me a ride? My car is still in the garage.
response: B: You sure have great luck these days .

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
A: Oh? Who's she calling?
B: She's calling her boyfriend.
A: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
B: He hasn't been home yet...Why? You're asking a lot of questions tonight, Paul.
response: A: Am I?...Well, I'm practicing my Chinese.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?
response: B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my daughter. It's time she get married, and she needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to her.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.

B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?
A: Well, no. I don't think I would. I bet it costs a lot of money. Does it say how much it costs?
B: Yes. The early black-and-white ones cost several hundred pounds. But the one is about costs several thousand pounds.
A: Hum. Why does anybody want one, do you think?
response: B: Business organizations that need to frequently contact overseas organizations would want it. It's like a face-to-face conversation. So maybe we can't avoid a lot of overseas travel.

dialogue: A: Ahahah! What is that thing on your couch! It just moved!
B: Did you think it wasn't real? That's my pet lizard.
A: You have a pet lizard? Somehow I never would have imagined that.
B: His name is Grunt. Come closer and I'll properly introduce you.
A: Does it bite or scratch?
B: No, he's perfectly harmless. And he's not afraid of strangers either. Here, hold him.
response: A: Wow. He's light! And his skin is falling off!

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
response: B: It's Green, G-R-E-N.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: Yes, I am.
A: Is this your first year in college?
B: I actually transferred here from another school.
A: Which school?
response: B: I transferred from Florida.

dialogue: A: Are you going to vote this Tuesday?
B: Yes, I am, and I am so excited.
A: Have you figured out who you ’ re going to vote for?
B: I love my candidate.
A: Why is that?
response: B: My candidate is probably not qualified.

dialogue: A: Oh, let's just go in for a minute, I'm hungry.
B: OK, but just a snack. We're eating supper at home tonight.
A: Let's get some milk and bread.
B: I don't really like milk. How about a soda?
response: A: They say Coca-Cola makes you fat. Milk is healthier.

dialogue: A: Welcome back home, darling. Did you have a good time?
B: Yes, wonderful. Why, Jack, the house looks as if you have also been away,
A: Why do you say that?
response: B: Look at the dirty plates, cups, shirts everywhere.

dialogue: A: Acknowledgments play a necessary part in the interview.
B: Sure. Kind acknowledgments can show one's good attainment.
A: We often ignore the acknowledgments in our daily life, and consider them as disposable.
B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a good impression on others, especially in the public places.
A: We should particularly pay attention to acknowledgments in the interview.
B: In the beginning of the interview, it is best that you make acknowledgments for the opportunity of the interview.
A: Don't forget to say " Thank you " when you take a seat.
B: Make acknowledgments as well when the interviewer thinks highly of your dressing, experience, or words.
A: You can win a good impression of the interviewer in this way.
B: Acknowledgments can also help the job-hunters to show their good attainment.
A: Finally, at the end of the interview, make acknowledgments to the interviewer again.
response: B: Scowls and rude attitudes are the basics of acknowledgments.

dialogue: A: Hi, Robert, what happened to your face? It looks swollen.
B: I have to go and get my teeth filled.
A: Did it hurt?
B: I don't even want to talk about it. It killed me!
response: A: Well, I guess you've learned a good lesson, huh! You have to take poor care of your teeth.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to remit 1,000 yuan to my sister in Shanghai.
A: Please fill out this form.
B: OK... Do I need to put on my sister's name for the receiver?
A: Yes. You must put on her name and address.
B: OK, I see. Here you are. Is that OK now?
A: Let me check. Yes. Your 1,000 remittance, please.
response: B: Here you are . What is the time?

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
response: B: Late April, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.

dialogue: A: I can't believe it! I lost.
B: It looks like you have to buy tickets for us, Jason. And we're not going to see an action movie!
A: That's not fair, you got all the easy questions.
response: B: I guess that's just the luck of the soldier.

dialogue: A: Are you ready?
B: Ready for what?
A: Ready for the big switch.
B: What are you talking about?
A: The nation is switching to digital TV.
B: Oh. Of course I'm ready.
response: A: Did you buy the inverter?

dialogue: A: Hello, Ms Thomas. What can I do for you?
B: Well, I've been having bad stomach pains lately, doctor.
A: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. How long have you been having them?
B: Just in the last few weeks. I get a very sharp pain about an hour after having meals.
A: I see. Do you get this after every meal?
B: Let me think. No, it's usually in the afternoon, after lunch.
A: Well, what do you have for lunch?
response: B: Oh, I mostly just have a very healthy meal and leisurely stroll back to the office. We're very busy at the moment.

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
B: I would like vegetable soup, please
A: And what would you like to have for the main course
B: Shrimp salad. And what kind of pie do you have?
A: Apple, banana and strawberry pie.
B: Then a piece of apple pie, please.
A: And what would you like for dessert?
B: Icecream, please.
A: What flavor would you like?
response: B: orange

dialogue: A: Hi.
B: Hi, Mary, Hi, Ken I hate to bring this up, but that new stereo, system you got...
A: Yeah?
response: B: You were playing it very late last night .

dialogue: A: What can I do for you?
B: I'd like to exchange this sweater.
A: What seems to be the matter?
response: B: Well, you see I got this as a birthday present, but it's the correct size, and what's more, I really like the colour.

dialogue: A: Are you being served, sir?
B: I'd like to buy a tapestry to decorate my new room.
A: Artistic tapestry is the highest expression form of the rug weaving art. How about these ones?
B: These are beautiful! Is this the marvelous landscape in Guiling?
A: Yes, sir.
B: How fine the needlework is! What's the price?
A: Ninety dollars.
B: It's too expensive.
A: But considering the fine craftsmanship it is worth much more.
response: B: You're right. Would you please show me some embroidery? I also want to buy some embroidered tablecloths to match the tapestry.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
A: No, but we can get your package to France in one week for 40 dollars.
B: Well, that sounds good. I'll take that. Is the service guaranteed?
response: A: Yes. We offer a service where we can market your package. But that will cost 10 dollars extra.

dialogue: A: Are you looking for an apartment?
B: Yes, I am interested in finding a one-bedroom apartment near Washington Square.
A: I think I have just a right apartment for you.
B: Oh, good. Can you describe it?
A: Yes. It has one bedroom, a large living space and 4 kitchens.
B: So is there a refrigerator?
A: Yes, it ’ s brand-new.
B: It sounds great. How much is the rent?
A: It ’ s $ 8.50 a month.
B: When can I see it?
response: A: We can take a see by there now if you like. The landlord left me a set of application forms with me.

dialogue: A: Discoveries is looking for a reporter to travel all over the world and write adventure articles.
B: Oh, it's a good job, I think.
A: So you are interested in working for Discoveries?
B: That's right. write adventure articles, but I'm sure I could. I've written lots of articles for a newspaper.
A: Oh? What newspaper have you written for?
B: Well, so far I've sold articles to the chicago Star and a few other newspaper.
response: A: Have you ever written any articles?

dialogue: A: Has everything been OK with you lately?
B: I haven ’ t been able to get a good night ’ s sleep lately. I ’ m exhausted!
A: Have you been too busy to get enough sleep?
B: I try to go to sleep, but I just can ’ t stay asleep.
A: How late do you try to go to sleep?
B: I go to bed when I finish my work.
A: Has anything in your day-to-day life been bothering you lately?
response: B: I am worried about how I am going to pay my tuition .

dialogue: A: Did you enjoy the restaurant?
B: I didn't really like it all that much.
A: What do you think the problem was?
B: Well, they are pretty new. I just didn't feel that they were ready to open yet.
A: How did you feel about the food?
B: The food wasn't all that exciting.
A: I don't think that the service was good, either.
B: Yes, the service certainly didn't add to the experience.
A: Would you like to return to this restaurant?
response: B: Maybe we could try it again in a few months although I hardly expect things will have settled down.

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
A: You mean you know how to farm?
B: Yes. I did that every summer during holidays.
A: I didn't know that a city boy can do farm work. Can I go there with you? I'd like to learn to do some farming.
B: Sure, my grandparents would be very happy to see you.
A: Are you sure?
response: B: I'm sure. They are very kind people.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you know where I can find a pay phone?
B: There is one around the corner.
A: Can I make an international call from that pay phone?
B: Yes, but you have to get a phone card first.
A: Where can I get a phone card?
response: B: You can get one at the space station over there after calling.

dialogue: A: Are you planning on voting?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, but this will be my first time voting.
B: Really?
response: A: Yes, and I have a lot of experience on how to do it.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
response: A: If I were you,  I'd say nothing to her first and then steal her other cat.

dialogue: A: Waiter, can we have the bill please?
B: Yes, madam. How will you pay for it, with cash or credit card,please?
A: With my Visa Card.
response: B: I'm awfully sorry, madam. But we only accept credit cards other than American Express and Master Card.

dialogue: A: Pardon me. Are you familiar with this neighborhood?
B: Well, I should be. I've lived here all my life. What are you looking for?
A: The Post Office.
B: Well, the nearest one is about a mile away.
response: A: Oh. Well, I guess I could send a letter.

dialogue: A: Have you any plan for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, Laura. I'm going for a ride around the Qinghai Lake on Saturday, but it depends on the weather.
A: According to the forecast, it'll be cloudy the day after tomorrow, good for a ride.
B: Great! Do you go riding often?
response: A: Absolutely. I go as much as I can, because we can really get in touch the culture of the city. It would be nice to get out of the country. Do you want any company?

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
response: B: You can get water and pop in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to buy a lipstick for my wife because it is her birthday today.
A: Do you know what color your wife often wears?
B: Light pink.
A: Would you like this color or other colors?
B: I'd like her to have a change.
response: A: Then how do you like this plum red one ?

dialogue: A: Good morning, is this Ryan?
B: You are speaking with Ryan. How can I help you?
A: Ryan, this is Malia, and I need to call in sick today.
B: What seems to be the problem?
A: I went hiking and have terrible poison oak.
B: When did you get that?
A: I think I got it on Saturday, but it just showed up today.
B: What are you doing for it?
response: A: The teacher prescribed an ointment and gave me a shot .

dialogue: A: Hello, Jim. Where are you going?
B: To the cinema. What about coming with me?
A: No, thanks. I'm going home. My friend's expecting me.
B: What a pity! I believe it's a very good film.
A: Do you go to the cinema a lot?
B: Once a week. Most nights I sit at home and watch TV.
A: Oh, I see. By the way, where are you going for your holidays this year?
B: I don't know yet. My wife's going to her mother's for a couple of weeks. She lives by the sea, you know.
A: Oh, does she? That's convenient.
B: Yes, but I want to go to the country.
A: Don't you like the sea?
response: B: Yes, very much. But I need peace and quiet when I'm on holiday.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
response: A: Yes, they spent about five hours spreading the flames. Hm, what a strange smell!

dialogue: A: We haven't gone out for over a month. Let's go somewhere this evening.
B: Fine, where shall we go?
A: Look in the newspaper to see what's on at the cinema or the theater.
B: I see new play opened this week.
A: I enjoy a concert.
B: According to the newspaper there aren't any tonight.
response: A: Aren't there any good films in town?

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
A: I can take you home. Would you like a ride?
response: B: Yes. Thanks a lot. Could you stop at the school on the way? I need to buy some medicine.

dialogue: A: Oh, dear. My weight has gone up again.
B: I'm not surprised. You've been eating too much.
A: I wish I could lose weight. I have been to the hospital.
B: Were you given any advice?
response: A: Yeah, the doctor asked me to clean up my diet by cutting down meat.

dialogue: A: Are you a happy married man?
B: Yes, I am. My wife and I understand each other.
A: You are a lucky man. How about Mr. Smith.
B: I don't know. But they say that Mrs. Smith wears the pants in the house.
A: You mean she bosses her husband around?
response: B: That's right. She is pretty, and she doesn't want to control everything in his life.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
response: B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the gym and then pop into the supermarket.

dialogue: A: Are you free tonight?
B: Yes, I am. What's wrong?
A: Would you please go to a dancing party with me?
B: OK. No problem.
A: As a matter of fact, I haven't danced for a long time.
B: But it's said that you dance wonderfully well.
A: Thanks for flattering me. I think you dance a lot, right?
response: B: No. Just occasionally.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, what did you say you would like to do, Mr Green?
B: I said I'd better go back to the hotel. I'm meeting someone this evening.
A: OK, how are you going back? By bus or taxi?
B: I think I'd take a taxi. Do you know where I can get one?
A: Oh, just wait by the roadside. I'll wait with you.
B: OK, thanks. Are the taxis in London all black?
response: A: Well, some of them are. Is this your first time in China?

dialogue: A: Hi, David. I haven't seen you for ages. How are you getting along with your work?
B: Hi, Susan. Not so well as to be expected. I've left my position. I can't bear the rudeness of my boss any longer.
A: What are you going to do then?
response: B: No idea. Anyway, I've got to think about it not very seriously. And you?

dialogue: A: Well, you know I had a good time tonight.
B: I'm pleased to hear that.
A: But I have to say goodbye right now.
B: Why? It's not late. Can't you stay a little longer?
A: No, I'm sorry, but I really must go. I don't know whether I can catch the last bus if I don't hurry now.
B: When does the bus go?
A: At ten o'clock. Oh dear! It's already a quarter past ten.
B: Don't worry, Kate. Since you have missed the bus, it is unnecessary for you to hurry. I can drive you home.
response: A: Thank you. You are so kind. But my mother will worry about me if I'm too late getting home. I must get home before 11:00.

dialogue: A: Do you have somewhere to stay in London, Peter?
B: No, I don't. In fact, I was about to ask you if you could arrange some place for me to stay.
A: Yes, that's no problem though I am not in charge of it. I'll ask someone to arrange it for you. What kind of place were you considering?

B: Well, I don't care if I share with other people, but I'm not good at housework. Maybe a home stay would be OK, but I don't like young children, because they're noisy and it's difficult to study. Hopefully, I can live with a lady who has retired.
A: OK, that's no problem. But I must warn you that living with a family in London is very expensive. Much more expensive than other small cities.
B: That's not a big problem. I have some money saved. Besides, I can always get a part-time job. I'm working in a supermarket as a cashier now. So I don't think I will have trouble with money.
response: A: Sounds good. I'll call you if I get some information about that.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
response: B: You need to give me your ID and I will give you $ 27.

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
B: But the money's not bad and there's plenty of fresh air.
A: If I were you, I'd take some kind of direction, like teaching law.
B: Teaching? Anything but that. It's so boring.
A: Come on, you really must think of the future.
B: I'll tell you what. I'd like to be a doctor.
A: Well, you should think very seriously about that. It means a lot of study, and then working all sorts of hours.
B: Yes, maybe. But the idea sounds interesting.
response: A: Well, then, you ought to get more information about it as late as possible.

dialogue: A: Marissa, if your papers continue to be late, I will have to give you a failing grade for the course.
B: I'm sorry! I've been having a really hard semester.
A: You need to try a little harder, okay?
response: B: I know, I will. There hasn't been a lot going on lately. I'm moving out of my house, and my brother is in the hospital.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Uncle Smith.
B: Good morning, Cathy.
A: I want to have a dinner party to celebrate my birthday. Would you come?
B: I'd love to, Cathy. What time?
A: Next weekend, on Saturday.
B: Saturday do you say?
A: If that's all right with you.
response: B: I'm afraid I'm busy then. I've already had plans.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
response: B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.

dialogue: A: Hi, are you being helped?
B: No, I'm not. I'm interested in some hats.
A: All our hats are in this section. What do you think of this one here? It's made of cotton.
B: Hmm,it looks nice and is suitable for autumn, but I'd like to have something warm for winter.
A: Maybe you would like a heavy wool hat. How about this one?
B: I think that's what I want. How much is it?
A: It's seventy dollars plus tax.
response: B: It's a little expensive. Do you think it's possible to get a discount?

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
response: B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have felt better afterwards

dialogue: A: Look. Jack! That man fell off the ladder. Come and help! He must be injured.
B: He's not moving. Shall we take him to the hospital?
A: We mustn't move him. Leave him where he is.
response: B: We must get help. I'll go to that phone box and call the grocery store.

dialogue: A: Hello! Is your taxi engaged?
B: No, this taxi is free.
A: Please take me to the Honging Hotel.
response: B: OK . Please get out . You aren't welcome in my taxi.

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
B: But it's three kilometers from here to the cinema. How can we get there in such a short time?
A: I think we can walk there in twenty minutes.
response: B: But I am afraid I can't walk that little.

dialogue: A: What did you think of the lecture?
B: I thought it was very interesting.
A: Did you really?
B: Yes, didn't you?
A: Certainly not. I thought he talked a lot of rubbish.
B: So you think you know more than he does.
A: Well, take coal for instance.
B: What about it?
A: Coal won't become important again.
B: Why not?
A: It's too dirty. They won't be able to find people to work down coal mines in the future.
response: B: They'll invent new kinds of machinery.

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
B: You did? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered.
A: Oh, the telephone lines were damaged by the storm. They repaired them yesterday.
B: What did David do yesterday? Did he and Judy go dancing?
A: No, they stayed home and played cards with the children.
B: And what did you do? Did you play cards, too?
response: A: No . I listened to records and studied , what did you do yesterday , Donald ?

dialogue: A: Do you have somewhere to stay in London, Peter?
B: No, I don't. In fact, I was about to ask you if you could arrange some place for me to stay.
A: Yes, that's no problem though I am not in charge of it. I'll ask someone to arrange it for you. What kind of place were you considering?

B: Well, I don't care if I share with other people, but I'm not good at housework. Maybe a home stay would be OK, but I don't like young children, because they're noisy and it's difficult to study. Hopefully, I can live with a lady who has retired.
A: OK, that's no problem. But I must warn you that living with a family in London is very expensive. Much more expensive than other small cities.
B: That's not a big problem. I have some money saved. Besides, I can always get a part-time job. I'm working in a supermarket as a cashier now. So I don't think I will have trouble with money.
response: A: Sounds bad. I'll call you if I get some information about that.

dialogue: A: May I help you?
B: I would like an alarm clock that will awaken me with soft music.
A: In that case, you'll probably be interested in this handsome electric clock radio.
response: B: Actually, I'd like a small battery-operated clock radio.

dialogue: A: Tom, as the manager of a company selling green products, you are now quite a successful businessman. When did you know you wanted to have your own company?

B: My family left Budapest in 1986 and settled in Canada where a lot of my friends' parents were highly successful businessmen. It seems so cool, so in high school, I started a web-designed company and learned a lot from that experience.
A: How did you find the money for your present company then?
B: We've raised 18 million dollars from about 50 people. We're finally making money. I own 6% of the company and all employees get their shares.
A: By the way, what aspects of your life are green?
response: B: I'm only mildly green. I do simple things and I'm a huge baker. I baked cross Canada.

dialogue: A: Hello! Do you have a place where I can exercise?
B: Yes, sir. We have a fine exercise facility.
A: I'm happy to hear that. Now, would you tell me where it is?
B: You're actually standing above it. Just take the elevator or stairs down one level.
response: A: Is the hotel going to charge me a dollar a minute for gym use ?

dialogue: A: Caroline Menzies speaking.
B: Could I speak to Diana Curzon?
A: I'm afraid she's in a meeting at the moment. Who's speaking?
B: This is John Laing from Dantons.
A: Can I take a message, Mr Laing?
B: Yes, please. I'm actually returning her call. So perhaps you could tell her that I called.
response: A: I won't. Does she have your address?

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.
A: Is it the diet that you love but have to avoid?
response: B: That's right. Dieting is so interesting. Hopefully, I might need to wear the wedding dress again anyway.

dialogue: A: Why, Ann, I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been?
B: Bob, it has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year.
A: No. We talked at the Johnson's Christmas party last December. Don't you remember?
B: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the Germen company?
A: No. I changed my job about 4 months ago. I'm with the World Bank now. How about you?
response: B: I have left the University, but I transferred from the German Department to the Spanish Department.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon. I'm looking for a second-hand car and I believe you sell cars.
B: Yes. I have one here that may interest you.
A: Ah, yes. A friend told me about it. What make is it?
B: It's a Lincoln.
A: Is it MS 560 or MF 558? I don't want either of them. I want a MF 650 one.
B: Oh, it's the one you want, and it's three years old.
A: Mmm... hmm. And what sort of condition is it in?
response: B: It's in very good condition and it's not very compact.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?

A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in a bit too much specialized information.
response: B: The main thing I object to is the efficiency of his direction.

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
A: The Fools Garden is giving a performance today.
response: B: They are a pop group. They are said to be very boring. What time does the performance start?

dialogue: A: Hi, Kathy, it's Jason.
B: Hi, Jason. I haven't heard from you in a while.
A: Well. I've been busy. I've started my own company.
B: Wow, what kind of business is it?
A: Just a small on-line store. I am hiring staff and I want you to come to work for me.
response: B: Actually, I just got finished working at the old company again.

dialogue: A: Accounting, this is Mike.
B: Mike, this is Leo in Sales. I was just calling to confirm our meeting tomorrow.Are we still on?
A: Goodness! It ’ s been so long I actually forgot. Let me see... yes, it is on my calendar.
response: B: OK. See you at your office at 2:30.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
A: Two weeks. Do you have headaches?
B: Sometimes.
A: Fever?
B: No.
A: Are you having any family problems?
B: No, not really. We all get along pretty well.
A: And how about work?
B: Well, I've been working a lot lately... more than 11 hours a day.
response: A: Maybe you should take a vacation and just work at home for a few days.

dialogue: A: Could you tell me the time of the last plane to Hong Kong this evening?
B: There's one at 10:15, but it's fully booked, I think.
A: Then the time of the first plane tomorrow morning?
B: The first plane leaves at 8:15.
A: Can you tell me when it arrives so that I can ask my secretary to come and meet me?
B: It arrives at 11:15 but maybe a little late because of the bad weather.
response: A: Well, I wonder if you'd let me know if there's any change in my pocket, I'd appreciate it.

dialogue: A: Hi, John. What are you doing here?
B: I'm waiting for the bus.
A: Where are you going?
response: B: I'm going to the house next door to ours.

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
response: B: I love green apple flavored candy .

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
response: A: Yes. The nearest one is next door, across town from the bank. It's quite modern.

dialogue: A: Hey Jane, where are you going this weekend?
B: Hi, Bob. I'm going to the beach. 13o you want to come too?
A: Yes, that sounds like fun. Which beach are you going to?
response: B: I was thinking of going to Huangdao's Beach. I like to watch movies there.

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
B: And the bike was run over by the car. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.
A: It was lucky that you didn't get hurt.
B: Yeah. But it's a pity I can't ride my bike this weekend.
A: Oh. Did you have a weekend plan?
response: B: Yeah. I planned to go sightseeing with friends by bike, but only its wheels survived.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
response: B: Buy an expensive suit.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
response: A: Yes, they spent about five hours photographing it. Hm, what a strange smell!

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
B: You're right. But I really had a happy vacation.
A: OK, Maybe you can move into Kelly's house and share that with her for a couple of months.
B: Thank you. But I don't want to bother you too much.
A: No trouble at all.
response: B: How much should I pay for the rent?

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to remit 1,000 yuan to my sister in Shanghai.
A: Please fill out this form.
B: OK... Do I need to put on my sister's name for the receiver?
A: Yes. You must put on her name and address.
B: OK, I see. Here you are. Is that OK now?
A: Let me check. Yes. Your 1,000 remittance, please.
B: Here you are. What is the rate?
A: This rate is one percent. That will be 10 yuan.
B: OK. When will this remittance arrive?
response: A: Generally it will arrive within three months .

dialogue: A: What a great weekend that was!
B: My feeling's exactly.
A: I really enjoy the beach in the summer.
B: I couldn't agree with you more.
response: A: We should come here less often

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time every year.
A: How long will it take to cycle one way, Robin?
B: About seven to nine hours for the average cyclists. Good cyclists can do it in four hours.
A: How many people will be taking part this year?
response: B: This is our biggest year ever. We have twelve hundred miles planned.

dialogue: A: What's the matter, Bill? You look kind of pale.
B: Oh, I'm just tired.
A: Why?
B: Well, I've been working until around ten every night this week.
response: A: You should work until ten today and take it easy.

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
response: B: I see. So you're pretty energized when you come to class.

dialogue: A: Come back. You haven't paid yet.
B: May, just let him go.
A: But he took some newspaper away without paying.
B: I know.
A: Why? You make me confused.
B: He lives nearby and he would just glance at the newspaper headlines, read the political sections and return them later.
A: Why does he have such a privilege?
B: He used to be a hero during the war time and everyone respect him.
A: I see. Does he live by himself?
B: Yes, he has no children and his wife passed away when he was in the battle.
response: A: He must be lonely?

dialogue: A: We haven't gone out for over a month. Let's go somewhere this evening.
B: Fine, where shall we go?
A: Look in the newspaper to see what's on at the cinema or the theater.
B: I see new play opened this week.
A: I enjoy a concert.
B: According to the newspaper there aren't any tonight.
response: A: Aren't there any boring films in town?

dialogue: A: Honey, how long have we been living here?
B: About 10 years. What's wrong?
A: I am thinking about redecorating our house.
B: That would cost a lot of money. But we do need to do some changes to the house.
A: Right. What about repainting the living room in yellow?
B: Good idea. I like the countryside style.
A: Great minds think the same. And we can also ask someone to draw a picture on the wall.
B: It sounds great. And the curtain should be changed too.
response: A: OK. Maybe we should make a blue program first.

dialogue: A: What are you working on?
B: I'm figuring out my budget.
A: What budget?
response: B: I'm making a shopping budget , so I can spend more money .

dialogue: A: I need a summer job that will give me some exercise.
B: How about being a life guard?
A: Life guards don't swim that much. They usually just sit.
response: B: Well then, you could be a swimming coach, or a tour guide.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
response: B: Oh, she can't help you either. She ended a phone call just now.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
B: About 20 minutes at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.
response: A: I'd better go there by bus. By the way, where is the stop sign, please?

dialogue: A: Why don't you get another job for a change?
B: But I like my job.
A: Look, digging gardens is not a job for a university graduate.
response: B: But the money's not bad and there's plenty of fresh air.

dialogue: A: Are there other chores for us to do?
B: We also have to vacuum the house.
A: You used to do this by yourself?
B: You'd better believe it.
A: I'll do the second floor and you do the first floor.
B: No. You're going to do the entire house.
A: What about you?
response: B: I'm not going to mow the lawn.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
response: A: Are you renting the house alone or with company ?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
response: A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few decades after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
B: Yes, I heard the lights were out all night.
A: Well, some people decided to loot last night.
B: I don't understand.
A: They took advantage of the blackout.
B: They really started looting?
A: Yes, apparently four stores were broken into.
response: B: Did the looters get caught ?

dialogue: A: Bye for now.
B: Bye. But where are you going?
A: The bank, the supermarket and...
B: Will you buy an exercise book for me?
A: I guess so. But I'll go to the post office first before I go to the supermarket.
B: Can you also buy me a pen? The one you gave me last week doesn't work now.
A: How come?
B: It fell off the desk and was broken.
A: Can you be more careful with your things?
B: Ok. Oh. Can you wait a second?
A: What for?
B: You are going to the post office, right?
A: Yes, so what?
response: B: Here's a letter for Sam. Can you post it?

dialogue: A: Are you going somewhere for your vacation?
B: Yes, I'm making plans for a tour.
A: That'll be lovely. Where are you going?
B: I start out from Long Island this Friday. I've planned a four-day drive to Salt Lake Ciy, where I'll join my brother and my family for his fortieth birthday.
response: A: Well, you've got to prepare lots of food and enough sleeping bags then?

dialogue: A: Come on. Will you please stop biting your nails?
B: Sorry, I just can't help it.
A: But it's annoying.
response: B: I don't mean to annoy you. I feel so calm.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
A: Yes, they spent about five hours putting it out. Hm, what a strange smell!
response: B: Oh, I forgot the food sitting in the blender!

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.
B: Hi, Jane.
A: What are you going to do this Saturday evening?
B: I'm going to a concert.
A: How exciting! Who is going to sing at the concert?
B: Xu Song. He is my favorite pop singer.
response: A: Where is he going to give the speech?

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
