B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.
A: Is it the diet that you love but have to avoid?
response: B: That's wrong. Dieting is so boring. Hopefully, I won't need to wear the wedding dress again anyway.

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.
A: Is it the diet that you love but have to avoid?
response: B: That's right. Dieting is so funny. Hopefully, I won't need to wear the wedding dress again anyway.

dialogue: A: (sniffing) Is that a French cigarette?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that a French cigarette you're smoking?
B: Yes, that's right. Why? What's the matter?
A: I don't understand why yousmoke French cigarettes. They make a terrible smell.
B: I like them very much. I prefer them to English cigarettes.
A: Have you got a lot of them?
B: Yes, about 200, why?
A: Well... er... could I buy some from you?
B: Buy some from me? But... you don't like French cigarettes!
response: A: No, I don't. My family doesn't either.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
response: A: Then the truck hit the ship, did it?

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
response: A: It's wide open right now, mostly people who take care of old people.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
A: How about giving them to that old man?
B: Good idea.
A: By the way, do you think it's a good idea to give free gifts to attract customers?
response: B: I'm not sure , but still it did attract a large crowds today .

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
response: B: I don't sell tickets to the theater. You can get one from the machine over there.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.
response: A: Well, Mr Strunk, I enjoy my work very much.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
response: A: So it really holds your attention?

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
response: B: Wear an expensive swimsuit.

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
B: Then, you should dress well.
A: That ’ s right.
response: B: I think a white shirt with a blue tie looks terrible on you.

dialogue: A: Are you sure that this bus will take us to Santa Anita mall?
B: Yes, it will.
A: You know that for a fact?
response: B: Yeah, I take this bus all the time.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
B: I bought this particular computer last year. But I got my first PC in 1995.
A: I see. And what do you primarily use your computer for?
B: Well, I use it to send e-mails a lot, and... um, I have a teach-yourself French program. And I shop online pretty often.
A: Mmm. Any other uses?
B: Keeping track of my bank account, and there are a couple of computer games I enjoy.
response: A: Now you've mentioned e-mail and online shopping. Do you use the intercom for any other purposes?

dialogue: A: Hello, Old English Restaurant. Can I help you?
B: Yes. I'd like to book a table for tonight.
A: Yes, sir. What time?
B: Eight o'clock.
A: Certainly. For how many people?
B: There are ten of us.
response: A: Ten of you! But we don't usually accept small parties, sir.

dialogue: A: Have you any plan for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, Laura. I'm going for a ride around the Qinghai Lake on Saturday, but it depends on the weather.
A: According to the forecast, it'll be cloudy the day after tomorrow, good for a ride.
B: Great! Do you go riding often?
A: Absolutely. I go as much as I can, because we can really get in touch with nature. It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want any company?
B: Sure, but it will be a 30-mile ride. Have you been riding so long before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I even saw a bear and some monkeys on my last ride. My friend Mike and I rode more than 30 miles to a very wild part of the national forest.
response: B: Wow! You must have been in the middle of the city. Shall we invite him to go along?

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to remit 1,000 yuan to my sister in Shanghai.
A: Please fill out this form.
B: OK... Do I need to put on my sister's name for the receiver?
A: Yes. You must put on her name and address.
B: OK, I see. Here you are. Is that OK now?
A: Let me check. Yes. Your 1,000 remittance, please.
response: B: Here you are . What is the rate ?

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
response: B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent three hours on it.

dialogue: A: A lovely day, isn't it?
B: It is.
A: It seems it will be a fine all day.
B: I think it will be a dry day. There's hardly a cloud in the sky.
A: We'll have a heat wave in the afternoon. I'm afraid.
response: B: It's very hot today. No wind at alt.

dialogue: A: Hi, what can I do for you?
B: I'd like to send this package to France. Can it be delivered in the next five days?
A: Yes. We offer an overnight service. It'll cost 70 dollars.
B: Ah, that's a bit expensive. Do you have a three-day service?
A: No, but we can get your package to France in one week for 40 dollars.
B: Well, that sounds good. I'll take that. Is the service guaranteed?
response: A: Yes. We also offer a service where we can lose your package. But that will cost 10 dollars extra.

dialogue: A: What's going on around here? Why is everyone changing offices?
B: Haven't you heard? Where have you been anyway?
A: I just got back from visiting the plant in Chicago.
B: Well, there are a lot of changes being made here this week.
A: Yes, I see. But what are they?
B: For one thing, Martha and Jim are leaving.
response: A: Where are they going?Did they get a higher position?

dialogue: A: Gordon, I'm going to Keswick in the Lake District this weekend.
B: Really?

A: Yeah, five of us. Why don't you join us? We're getting to Keswick on Friday. Then we're going boating on Saturday. And on Sunday, we're going to do some shopping. Then I will take some time to visit my aunt Lucy.
B: You're not going to camp, are you? Isn't it a bit cold?
A: No, we're not. It is a bit cold. We're staying in a country inn. It's not like five-star hotels or anything. But it's really comfortable.
B: Hmm, sounds interesting. You know, it's the boating that I don't like.
A: Well, what are you up to?
response: B: Sit on my sofa all weekend and watch the DVDs I've just bought. And that will be a busy weekend. I may finish watching Friends.

dialogue: A: Has the train come yet?
B: No, I ‘ Ve been waiting for ages.
A: It ’ s so unreliable. I ’ Ve been late for my meetings all this week.
response: B: Yes , me too . I think I ’ Ve lost some important clients recently because of this train !

dialogue: A: Dalian is a beautiful city. Do you agree?
B: I suppose I do.
A: The climate here is pleasant.
B: You said it.
response: A: This city is really uncomfortable to live in.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I need a new identification card.
A: Why?
response: B: My ID card was lost but I just found it again .

dialogue: A: Come back. You haven't paid yet.
B: May, just let him go.
A: But he took some newspaper away without paying.
B: I know.
A: Why? You make me confused.
B: He lives nearby and he would just glance at the newspaper headlines, read the political sections and return them later.
A: Why does he have such a privilege?
B: He used to be a hero during the war time and everyone respect him.
A: I see. Does he live by himself?
response: B: Yes, he has no children and his wife passed away when he was in the battle.

dialogue: A: Hello, this is Jonason speaking.
B: Hello, Jonason, I am Kasy. I am sorry to tell you that I may not attend your birthday party this weekend.
A: Oh, what's up?
B: Nothing much.., but...
A: What's happened then?
response: B: I have an important exam two days before that time.

dialogue: A: What's the matter, Bill? You look kind of pale.
B: Oh, I'm just tired.
A: Why?
B: Well, I've been working until around ten every night this week.
A: You should go home at quitting time today and take it easy.
B: Yes. I think I will.
A: That's good. Say, how's your brother?
B: He's fine, but he is awfully busy. He went to the States on a business trip two weeks ago.
A: Oh, really? Is he back yet?
B: No, he won't come back for several more weeks.
response: A: Wow! He must have very little to do there.

dialogue: A: Good morning, mom.
B: Good morning, sweetie. You finally got up.
A: I'm still sleepy.
B: Did you stay up late last night?
response: A: Yes, I fell asleep early last night .

dialogue: A: Did you ever get your bus pass?
B: I don't think I'm going to get one.
A: Why not?
B: It's just a waste of cash, man!
response: A: Actually, it'll waste you money.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
response: B: I've only been studying for 5 minutes a day last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
B: I love green apples.
A: I don't like green apples.
B: Really? Why not?
response: A: Green apples are too sour for me .

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
response: A: You mean you never learned how to farm?

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
B: You did? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered.
A: Oh, the telephone lines were damaged by the storm. They repaired them yesterday.
B: What did David do yesterday? Did he and Judy go dancing?
response: A: Yes, they stayed home, played cards, and danced with the children .

dialogue: A: Helen, can I have a look at your newspaper?
B: Sure, go ahead.
A: I want to know what's on this weekend.
B: Is there anything interesting?
response: A: The Fools Garden is giving a performance today.

dialogue: A: Where did you put my new red tie?
B: It's right there in the cupboard with your other ties.
A: There's a green one and a couple of brown ones, but no red one.
B: Here it is in your drawer. You must have put it there when you brought it home.
A: I suppose so. We'd better hurry up or we're going to be late. The Smiths said to come at 7:00.
response: B: Oh, it's 6:24 now. Sue isn't here to take care of the children yet.

dialogue: A: Have you booked a table, madam?
B: Yes, we've booked one for two. The name is Morrison.
A: Oh, yes, we have the table for you near the group. This way, please.
response: B: The chess group? I can't stand the noisy places. Now where's the menu?

dialogue: A: What are your hobbies, Mr. Green?
B: I like collecting stamps.
A: But it's an expensive hobby, isn't it?
B: Yes, you're right. What do you like to do in your spare time?
A: I usually play chess with my friends. But I like playing basketball best.
B: Do you play basketball well?
response: A: No , I'm not very good at it . I play professionally .

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's a graduate course and I'm only a junior, but...
A: Aren't you a bit young? I've allowed qualified seniors to take the course and they usually have a hard time to keep up.
response: B: I know, but the geology of the American West is my favorite interest and I've read a lot in the field. Last semester I took Professor Burman's course and I didn't find it challenging enough.

dialogue: A: You know these people who want to visit the company?
B: Yes. You are meeting them next week, aren't you?
A: Hum. Where should I take them, the office perhaps?
response: B: I suppose you prefer this office because it is more comfortable.

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.
B: Actually, I like it very much.
A: I'm glad you enjoy it. Let me serve you some more fish.
B: No, thank you. I've had enough fish, but I'd like some soup.
A: Here it is. Help yourself!
B: Thanks. I didn't know you were so good at cooking. If only my wife could learn to cook from you.
A: Why not bring your wife next time? I haven't seen her for quite a while.
response: B: OK, I will. She will be very glad to see you, too. Thank you for the wonderful meal.

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
response: B: I really like macaroni and cheese.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Uncle Smith.
B: Good morning, Cathy.
A: I want to have a dinner party to celebrate my birthday. Would you come?
B: I'd love to, Cathy. What time?
response: A: Early in the morning, on Saturday.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
B: Thanks, they are rather attractive. But I think there is nothing better than seeing things In actual operation.
A: Yes, of course. Would you like to make an inspection tour of some factories?
B: Yes, very much, if it wouldn't add inconvenience to you. First hand information is always more valuable than reading pamphlets.
response: A: I'll make the invoice and let you know the time tomorrow .

dialogue: A: Greetings should never be ignored in the interview.
B: Sure. It is helpful to shorten the distance between you and the interviewer and create a lively atmosphere.
A: Appropriate greetings will win the interviewer's favorable impression
response: B: But you should pay special attention to your words and attitudes .

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?
response: B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get divorced, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.

dialogue: A: Did you hear what Fred did last night?
B: No,not yet. What happened to him?
A: I guess he was a little drunk and he had a fight with his brother. Well, he got so mad that he drove his car straight into the front of a drugstore.
B: What do you mean?
response: A: I mean he flew inside. The front of the store was completely destroyed. I actually saw it just now as I walked by. The plane is still inside the store.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ben. You're getting ready for tomorrow's lessons, aren't you?
B: Yes, but I'm a bit nervous. I have no idea what'll happen in class and how I'll get along with my classmates.
A: I understand how you're feeling. Just take it easy. You'll make a lot of friends very soon.
B: Thank you. I'll try my best to get used to my new school life as soon as possible. By the way, what time does the first class begin?
A: At 8 o'clock. But before that we have 10 minutes to hand in homework and then 20 minutes for morning reading.
B: So we must get to school before 7:30, right?
A: Right.
B: How long does each class last?
A: 45 minutes, I think, with a 10 or 15 minutes' break.
response: B: Well, I hear that lunchtime is nearly 12 o'clock and I'll be starving by then.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve in the library for anthropology 311.
A: Professor Gilers's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matter which one of them you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're kidding all of them?

A: I've asked professor Gilers twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for these same articles to be returned.
B: And here I went out of my way to free the whole afternoon to read.
response: A: I'm sorry, but there is not a whole lot I can do about it. All I can suggest is that you don't come in or try again.

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent three hours on it.
A: By the way, what time did you go home?
B: I left the office at nine o'clock. I got home at ten.
response: A: What did have for dinner?

dialogue: A: Hello, Lucy. When are you going off to Beijing?
B: This evening.
A: How are you getting there, by air or by train?
B: By train. It leaves at 5:00 and arrives in Beijing at 7:10 tomorrow morning.
A: Oh, only 14 hours. Is anybody seeing you off this evening?
response: B: Yes, my parents are staying home to see me off.

dialogue: A: Am I allowed to check out at 14:00?
B: Certainly.
A: Will there be any late charge?
response: B: No.sir. If only you check in before 15:00

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. Er, I'm phoning about the job that was in the paper last night.
A: Oh, yes. Could you tell me your name?
B: Oh, Jerry Lynn.
A: Well, what exactly is it that interests you about the job?
B: I just thought that it was right up my street, you know.
A: Really? Could you tell me a little about yourself?
B: I've been working abroad doing secretarial work. Previous to that I was at university. I've got a degree in English.
A: Do you have any special skills?
response: B: Well, I speak two foreign languages, French and Italian.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
response: B: I need to forget my English.

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
B: I thought she'd be happy.
response: A: Yeah, especially since she got a promotion recently.

dialogue: A: Can you believe that we've finally found a house?
B: Good for you. Tell me about the house!
A: It doesn't look good outside. but it is lovely inside.
B: How nice! How many bedrooms does it have?
response: A: Well, it has three bedrooms, no bathrooms, one big sitting room and a modern kitchen.

dialogue: A: Are you free on the weekend?
B: I haven't got any plans yet, why?
A: There is an exhibition of Chinese paintings at the public library. Would you like to go with me?
response: B: I'd love to, but when?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
response: A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.

dialogue: A: Hello, I'm returning your phone call.
B: I'm glad that you could get back to me so fast.
A: No problem, but what were you calling about?
B: I needed to talk to you about your son.
A: Is he messing up in school?
B: He was acting up in class one day last week.
A: What was he doing?
response: B: He wouldn't stop talking throughout the class .

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
response: B: I was sick. I had a fever and I could get out of bed.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.
B: Uh. I didn't have any of that when I was in middle school, and I did just fine.
A: Yeah, and there weren't any cars either. Things are a lot more progressive now.
response: B: Great. My daughter will be studying hard in class.

dialogue: A: What are you going to have for breakfast?
B: I just have some cereal each morning.
A: You're supposed to always have a hearty breakfast.
response: B: I don't always have time to make dinner.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
B: Well, Ann, the tour today is not a race. People do it for fitness and fun andtry to better their time every year.
A: How long will it take to cycle one way, Robin?
B: About seven to nine hours for the average cyclists. Good cyclists can do it in four hours.
A: How many people will be taking part this year?
B: This is our biggest year ever. We have twelve hundred cyclists registered.
A: I doubt they'll block the road when the cyclists start out?
response: B: Don't worry, we've introduced the staggered starts to create these problems. Our first group will leave Ottawa at seven o'clock.

dialogue: A: Dad, do you know where Mom is?
B: I think she is in her room putting a little something together for you to take to school with you.
A: She'd better not start crying like she usually does.
response: B: I know, but she is going with you. Have I told you how proud I am of you?

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
B: How about exercise?
response: A: Well, I often play video games or watch TV.

dialogue: A: An interesting meeting, isn't it?
B: Yes, very. I thought the last speaker was especially good.
A: Let me introduce myself, by the way. My name's Thomas Bradley.
B: How do you do? I'm Ted Nugent.
A: Sorry, what was your last name again?
B: It's Nugent, N-U-G-E-N-T, but just call me Ted.
A: Ok, I'm Tom.
B: Glad to meet you.
A: And what do you do, Ted?
B: Me? I'm in the car business.
response: A: Body Work?

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
response: B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of beginning my own business.

dialogue: A: Are you through with your meal?
B: Yes, I am. Could I have the bill, please?
A: Here is your bill. 150 yuan in all.
B: Do you accept check?
A: No, I'm sorry we don't. We accept credit cards and cash.
response: B: Well, I'd like to freeze this cash.

dialogue: A: Ahahah! What is that thing on your couch! It just moved!
B: Did you think it wasn't real? That's my pet lizard.
A: You have a pet lizard? Somehow I never would have imagined that.
B: His name is Grunt. Come closer and I'll properly introduce you.
A: Does it bite or scratch?
response: B: No he's very harmless and loves to bite and scratch. And he's not afraid of strangers either. Here, hold him.

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
B: I love green apples.
A: I don't like green apples.
B: Really? Why not?
A: Green apples are too sour for me.
response: B: So , you like green apples the best ?

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
A: Oh? Who's she calling?
B: She's calling her boyfriend.
A: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
response: B: He is home now...Why?  You're asking a lot of questions tonight, Paul.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
A: Why is a computer so useful?
B: It can keep much information and work very fast.
A: Then they can do a lot of work for us.
response: B: You aren't right. They have minimally changed our lives.

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
B: I'm going to attend a conference on air pollution.
A: When and where is this conference being held?
B: It's being held in the first two weeks of February at the University of Stanford in California.
A: Who will pay your expenses?
B: The University of Stanford. Here is the official letter of invitation.
A: I see. Fine. When do you want to go?
response: B: I'd like to leave in mid-January if my passport is ready by then.

dialogue: A: Are you busy tomorrow night? I'm going over to the Workers Club for volleyball if you'd like to come along.
B: Isn't that far away?

A: Not really. If you take the No. 3 bus, you can get there in ten minutes. And if volleyball doesn't interest you, they've got a huge indoor swimming pool, a weight room, and indoor tracks. It's a great place to meet people.

B: Now that you mentioned it, it would be nice to get away from the computer center for a change, and I really should get some more exercise. Working up a sweat in a ball game or the weight room would be nice. I've got so fat.
response: A: Look at me -You're not the only one. In high school I had a lot more time to do sports activities. Now all my work time you have must be used in doing exercise. At least the club is open until 12 pm.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
response: B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is offered 24 hours a day.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
A: May I borrow your pen?
B: Here's a pen for you.
A: Thanks for your help.
response: B: You need to copy that at Window B.

dialogue: A: Would you like to come to the cinema tonight?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair tonight.
A: OK. What about tomorrow night?
B: I can't go tomorrow night, either.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair again.
A: Do you wash your hair every night?
B: It depends...
A: Depends on what?
response: B: It depends on who asks me to eat at the cinema.

dialogue: A: David, we shouldn't sit here doing nothing.
B: Why not? It's Saturday afternoon, isn't it?
A: Yes, but there's so much to do around the house.
B: It can wait.
A: We ought to finish washing down the kitchen walls and cupboards.
B: We can do that tomorrow. We don't have to do it today.
A: All right. That's a good idea.
B: Talking about washing down the kitchen-where's Bob?
A: He's having lunch with Georgia.
B: What! Again?
A: He should be back soon.
B: He shouldn't spend so much time with that girl.
A: You must be patient, David. Nineteen's a very difficult age, you know?
response: B: Yes, I know. But he ought to be bathing more.

dialogue: A: Good morning, is this Ryan?
B: You are speaking with Ryan. How can I help you?
A: Ryan, this is Malia, and I need to call in sick today.
B: What seems to be the problem?
A: I went hiking and have terrible poison oak.
B: When did you get that?
A: I think I got it on Saturday, but it just showed up today.
B: What are you doing for it?
A: The doctor prescribed an ointment and gave me a shot.
response: B: Good . You probably should be much sicker by tomorrow .

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent three hours on it.
A: By the way, what time did you go home?
response: B: I left the office at five o'clock. I got home at six.

dialogue: A: What seems to be the matter?
B: I just can't sleep well, doctor.
A: I see. And how long have you had this problem?
B: Oh, for about two weeks now.
response: A: Two weeks. Do you feel refreshed and not sleepy at all?

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
response: B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear a new one on mine. I suffered for six months so I could afford one.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you live here?
B: Yes.
A: Oh, well, do you know where the English Language Institute is?
B: Ah, yes. I think I know where it is. Do you have a car?
A: No, I'm on foot.
B: Well, as you go out of the station, just continue along the road until you come to the second crossing and then turn left into King Street.
A: Yes.
B: Then walk down the street just a bit and take the first turning on the right. And keep walking until you come to the park.
A: A park, yes.
response: B: Well, let's see. Walk through the English Language Institute. As you get to the end of the path you will see two small roads. Take the road on the right and King Street station is at the end of the road. You can't miss it.

dialogue: A: Hi. May I help you?
B: Yeah. I'd like to rent these movies.
A: Okay. Do you have your membership card?
B: No I don't. Do I need one to rent videos here?
response: A: Yes, and it's very expensive.

dialogue: A: Are we going to have gym class tomorrow?
B: Are you crazy? Tomorrow's Saturday.
A: Sometimes I forget that we don't have school on Saturdays.
B: Americans also don't go to work on Saturdays.
response: A: So there are only seven working days in a week?

dialogue: A: Hey, I'm calling to say that I'm running late to the airport. Can you make sure that the plane doesn't take off without me?
B: I'll try.
A: Thank you. I'm just sitting here in traffic. There must be an accident or something. I've been here for 30 minutes, and I've barely made it onto the bridge.
B: Oh, that's not good.
response: A: This traffic is really not bothering me. I do want to have to take a later flight!

dialogue: A: You're going to wear out that typewriter.
B: Oh, hi. What are you doing here at this time of night?
A: I should ask you that question. Do you have any idea what time it is?
B: About ten or ten-thirty?
A: It's nearly midnight.
B: Really? I didn't have any idea it was so late.
A: Don't you have an early class tomorrow morning?
B: Yes, at seven o'clock. My part-time class, for the students who go to work right after their lesson.
response: A: Then you ought to go to review your course materials.

dialogue: A: Welcome to this idition of writers. Tonight we have Steven Das with us. Congratulations on your book. It's such a success.
B: Thank you.
A: This is your first time to that poetry? Did you ever try before? Did you ever take any classes in poetry?

B: Well. My only real experience was writing business plans. Other than that. I've experience. We're writing with concerned. I've always had the good grass of the writing with the English language. Thanks to my mom who studied my reading when I was very little.
A: What's the hardest thing that in the world?
B: Definitely finding the perfect words to fit what I wanted to say. There're always work word two that I might to rewrite if given the chance.
A: Was there be more collections of poetry from Daisy?
response: B: There will be more something that surprise. But maybe not poetry. I really don't see myself as a poet. Rather, I'd see what I wrote this kind of writing. that might inspaire people in someway.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
response: A: Then the truck flew over the taxi, did it?

dialogue: A: Hello, Jane. This is Peter speaking.
B: Hi, how are you?
A: Fine. And I've got some great news for you.
B: Really? What's it about?
A: I remember you are interested in watching golf games. The Houston Open will be running from May 26 to May 30. I'm sure you will be glad to watch the game.
B: Oh, that's great. But just a moment, let me check. Ah... It is a pity that I can't make it. I will be on business in China from May 25 to June 2.
response: A: Well, I'm glad you won't be away on business then. Let me see. Another game, the US Open will be running from July 15 to July 18. How about that?

dialogue: A: Ah, Michelle, hi. I was hoping to see you. How have you been? How's the family?
B: Oh, hello, Mr. Campbell. I'm fine and Jack's doing well. How are you?
A: I'm fine thanks. I got your report this morning. Thank's for that. Are you joining the conference today?
response: B: Yes, I'm leaving at four pm.

dialogue: A: ABC company. Can I help you?
B: Can you put me through to Mr Brown in the Sales Department?
A: I'm afraid Mr Brown is at a meeting at the moment.
B: Can I leave a message?
A: Certainly.
response: B: Can you ask Mr Brown's wife to call me at 1300-621-7865?

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
B: How about some fresh fruit?
A: We don't have any fresh fruit today. All we have now is chocolate cake.
response: B: Then I just have a cup of canola oil, please.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ben. You're getting ready for tomorrow's lessons, aren't you?
B: Yes, but I'm a bit nervous. I have no idea what'll happen in class and how I'll get along with my classmates.
A: I understand how you're feeling. Just take it easy. You'll make a lot of friends very soon.
B: Thank you. I'll try my best to get used to my new school life as soon as possible. By the way, what time does the first class begin?
A: At 8 o'clock. But before that we have 10 minutes to hand in homework and then 20 minutes for morning reading.
B: So we must get to school before 7:30, right?
A: Right.
B: How long does each class last?
A: 45 minutes, I think, with a 10 or 15 minutes' break.
response: B: Well, I hear that lunchtime is nearly 12 o'clock and I'll be full of food by then because we'll be serving food in class.

dialogue: A: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock.
B: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning.
A: Why? What's wrong with you?
B: I felt pain all over my body. Can you get me some medicine?
A: Will aspirin do?
B: No, aspirin isn't strong enough.
response: A: Then I can do nothing but call for a dentist.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite reasonable.
response: B: It sounds nice. Thank you very much for your help.

dialogue: A: Do you want to go for a picinc with me tomorrow?
B: I'd like to. How about asking Jenny to go with us?
A: Oh, no. She is busy with her dancing class. You know, there is a very big performance in just a week.
B: Yes, you're right. It is really not good for her to learn dancing. Her leg hasn't completely recovered from that accident.
response: A: But she doesn't think so. She is crazy about dancing. Will you take your camera with you tomorrow?

dialogue: A: Has the train come yet?
B: No, I ‘ Ve been waiting for ages.
A: It ’ s so unreliable. I ’ Ve been late for my meetings all this week.
B: Yes, me too. I think I ’ Ve lost some important clients recently because of this train!
response: A: Yes , my customers have started to complain too !

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
B: At least, it can free you from the crowd. By the way, do you come from China?
A: No, from New Zealand, sir. I visited New Zealand and saw lots of overseas people there.
B: Wow, like America. It receives a great number of visitors every year.
response: A: The more the world becomes open , the more people become populism!

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.
B: Hi, Jane.
A: What are you going to do this Saturday evening?
B: I'm going to a concert.
A: How exciting! Who is going to sing at the concert?
B: Xu Song. He is my favorite pop singer.
A: Where is he going to give the concert?
B: In the gym.
A: What time is it going to start?
B: At 7:30 p. m. Would you like to go with me?
response: A: I can't, but I'm going to visit my uncle.

dialogue: A: Good morning, mom.
B: Good morning, sweetie. You finally got up.
A: I'm still sleepy.
response: B: Did you sleep too much last night ?

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
response: A: One moment while I go and get my ID to go drinking.

dialogue: A: Great! I landed on Classic Movies.
B: I didn't know you liked old movies.
A: I love them, especially the all-time greats like Gone With the Wind.
response: B: You're so right! Old movies are just too commercial!

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
B: Do you know this diet that many actors are doing? I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.
A: I think meat is not allowed in your diet.
B: No, actually, you can eat things like, um, roast chicken, steak, and bacon, but you can't eat any bread and butter.
A: Is it the diet that you love but have to avoid?
response: B: That's right. Dieting is so healthy. Hopefully, I will be able to wear the wedding dress again anyway.

dialogue: A: Do you know Tom?
B: Tom what?
A: Tom Smith.
B: No. But I know a Tim Smith.
A: Oh, yes, you are right. It was Tim Smith I meant. You know what happened to him the other day?
B: No, what happened then?
A: Well, he told me he saw his dead grandfather in London.
response: B: Oh, come on. You are not telling a love story, are you?

dialogue: A: 911. What can I do for you?
B: I am reporting a break-in.
A: When did it happen?
B: It happened last night.
A: Where did it happen?
B: It happened at my house.
A: What was taken?
B: I don't know.
A: How do you know there was a break-in?
response: B: Someone busted my window.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the party on Saturday?
B: I was thinking about it. Are you?
A: Yeah, I heard it's going to be a lot of fun.
B: Really? Well, what time does it start?
A: It starts at 8
B: Well, who all is going to be there?
A: Everyone from school.
B: How do you know it's going to be so fun?
response: A: This party is going to have a DJ, food, and drinks.

dialogue: A: Dad, how do you say this word?
B: Sword, say it ' sword '.
A: What does this word mean?
response: B: Look it up in this novel.

dialogue: A: Belinda, I ’ m going to a party tonight. What shall I wear?
B: Is it formal or informal?
A: I guess it ’ s formal.
response: B: Then, you should dress down.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, could you tell me where the post office is?
B: Post office? It's not far from here. Do you know Xinhua Road?
A: I'm from the United States and this is my first trip to your city. I know nothing about the city.
response: B: Oh, welcome to our city, I'll show you the road. Please follow me.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
B: I'm an English major and this is a required course. But now I'm in trouble because I'm not sure I can afford this book.
response: A: Hey, I've got an idea. Why don't we split the book and share the cost?

dialogue: A: Excuse me, could you tell me where the post office is?
B: Post office? It's not far from here. Do you know Xinhua Road?
A: I'm from the United States and this is my first trip to your city. I know nothing about the city.
B: Oh, welcome to our city, I'll show you the road. Please follow me.
response: A: Thanks, by the way, where can I buy a map of the city?

dialogue: A: Did you have your television repaired?
B: Yes, but not by the place you recommended
A: Why not? The repair is very good and thecharges are so reasonable.
B: That may be, but I couldn't find it.
A: But you couldn't miss it. I told you the first right after the railroad bridge.
B: I took that. I went to the end of the road. There is no such a place.
response: A: Wait a minute. I found it with no problems when I looked it up on my phone.

dialogue: A: Waitress! I think there's something wrong with our bill.
B: No, I don't think so...$10 for the drinks, 15 for the small plate, and 20 for the main dish.
A: What? I knew the cheese sticks were 15. I always order cheese sticks, but I thought the main dish was $10.
B: Oh, that explains it. You think the bill should be $35.
A: Yes, exactly. I was wondering what happened to the rest of my change. I should have gotten back 15, not 5!
B: I understand. Sometimes people aren't honest, but I think this was an honest mistake. Didn't you order the sea cucumbers for dinner?
A: Yes, and they were delicious. Best cucumbers ever! I'm so glad I'm a vegetarian.
B: Sir, I am so sorry. Have you ordered sea cucumbers before? They aren't vegetables, you know.
A: Really? I thought it was a vegetable that grew in the ocean.
response: B: No. They're seafood.

dialogue: A: Hi, John. What are you doing here?
B: I'm waiting for the bus.
A: Where are you going?
B: I'm going to the station to meet my sister.
A: Oh, is she coming by herself?
B: Yes, the train comes in about half past four, but it's twenty past four now. I have only ten minutes!
A: How often does the bus run?
response: B: Every ten minutes. I caught a No. 1 bus 15 minutes ago, and the next one hasn't come yet!

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I need a new identification card.
A: Why?
B: My ID card is lost.
response: A: OK , did you bring your lunch or residence booklet ?

dialogue: A: What's the matter? Your bike is in bad shape.
B: It was hit by a car yesterday.
A: Good God! Were you hurt?
B: I'm all right. I was not riding it then.
A: Oh, good for you! But what happened?
B: I was in a hurry yesterday and I put the bike at the back of a car.
A: The driver didn't see it and...
B: And the bike was run over by the car. Both its wheels were damaged. They are being repaired now.
response: A: It was lucky that you broke 10 bones.

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
response: B: Well, my mum wants me to throw out all the cans, so that we can sell them after a while.

dialogue: A: What happened? I've been waiting for almost an hour.
B: Vm sorry, but I had car trouble.
A: Oh, that's too bad. Couldn't you have telephoned?
B: I was going to, but I didn't have any change for a pay phone.
A: You could've gotten some change in a store.
response: B: But I was in the middle of a commercial area. There were plenty of places to get change.

dialogue: A: Hello, Amy. Are you coming to my birthday party?
B: Yes, I am. How do I get to your house from the station?
A: Well, call me when you get to the station and I'll come and pick you up in my car.
response: B: Are you sure it won't be too much fun?

dialogue: A: I keep feeling dizzy, and I've got a headache.
B: How long has this been going on?
A: It started yesterday.
B: You've been studying too much recently.
A: I have no other choice. Next month will be the most important exam of this term.
B: I can understand that. But anyway, you should take better care of yourself.
A: What should I do now?
response: B: I think you should get out of bed for a little while and I will call our friends to head out and have fun.

dialogue: A: Hi, honey. Do you need any help with your luggage?
B: No, thanks, dad. I just brought one carry-on in my backpack.
A: Great. I wish your mother would take some packing lessons from you. OK, let's go home.
B: Hm...It's cold here.
A: Yes, the weatherman says that it might snow tonight. What temperature was it when you took off from California this morning?
B: Sixty degrees and sunny.
A: Don't you people miss the seasons?
response: B: Not really. It's nice to go outside everyday. And always have bitterly cold and snowy weather

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
response: B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
B: At least, it can free you from the crowd. By the way, do you come from China?
A: No, from New Zealand, sir. I visited New Zealand and saw lots of overseas people there.
response: B: Wow, like America. There are a great number of people from nearby town who come visit.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
response: A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from staying here and joining your beloved family . It certainly is not studying.

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
B: But I didn't hear it at all.
A: What time did you set it for last night?
B: Six o'clock.
A: Hurry up, or you'll be late for school. Are you feeling ill?
response: B: No. I'm only sleepy because I had a great night of sleep the whole night.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
A: I wonder if you can change it to one size down.
response: B: Yes , of course . Will you come with receipt ?

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
response: A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to be beautiful. The weatherman said it will.

dialogue: A: Have you booked the airplane tickets to spain yet?
B: Well, I thought we should go traveling by ship for a change, so I booked two ship tickets instead.
A: You should have told me or discussed it with me.
B: I wanted to give you a surprise. Don't you like the idea?
A: I like it all right, but it takes much more time to travel by ship than by plane.
response: B: We have time, don't we? Every time we went on a trip, we were always tied down by schedules. This time will be different. We don't have to rush.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.
A: In what ways? What has she done?
B: Oh, no, you don't really want to hear it.
A: Come on. I am a mother of two girls.
B: Ok. I'm worried because she often hides in her room and sends messages to her friends.
A: Come on. It's not a big deal. She needs friends at this age. You can talk with her if you are really concerned.
response: B: I guess so. Anyway, she is growing up.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
A: Do they look like roses?
B: No, they look like little bells.
response: A: Oh , irises . No , I am sorry . We are all out of those purple flowers right now .

dialogue: A: Hi, Mike. What have you been up to?
B: Not much. I started exercising.
A: Trying to get in shape?
B: Yeah, and I need to start improving my health.
A: Me, too. What are you doing besides exercising?
B: That's about all.
response: A: I think if you eat more unhealthy, it will also help a lot.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, you are not really reading it, are you?
B: Pardon?
A: The book! You haven't turned the page in the last ten minutes.
B: No, Jim, I suppose I haven't. I need to get through it, though, but I keep drifting away.
A: So it doesn't really hold your interest?
B: No, not really. I wouldn't bother with it, to be honest, but I have to read it for a seminar. I'm at a university.
A: It's a labor of labor then rather than a labor of love.
B: I should say, I don't like Dickens at all really, the author, indeed, I am starting to like the whole course less and less.
A: It's not just the book, it's the curse as well?
response: B: Yeah, in a way, although the curse itself isn't really that bad, a lot of it is pretty good, in fact, and the lecturer is fine, as to me, I suppose, you see, I want to do philosophy rather than English, but my parents took me out of it.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
response: A: Now you're understating.

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
response: A: How about giving them to that old man ?

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
response: B: What for ? For the fasting session, of course .

dialogue: A: Mary, tomorrow is your mom's fiftieth birthday. Do you know?
B: Of course I do. How shall we celebrate it?
A: First of all a birthday present. What about buying her a beautiful skirt?
B: That's a good idea. It would make her look younger. And a big birthday cake too, with fifty candles.
response: A: That's right. Shall we have a normal and everyday dinner?

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
A: Ok, I won't keep you then.
B: Great! It's good to see you. Goodbye!
A: Yes, stay in touch. Bye!
response: B: Give me your email , would you ?

dialogue: A: Hello, Kate. Have you been to the new sports center yet?
B: Not yet. Where is it?
A: On Mill Road, near Stone Street, behind Santa Station.
B: What about it?
A: It's wonderful. You can do a lot of sports there. I played table tennis last Saturday, and watched a basketball match.
B: What about the swimming pool?
response: A: It's very dirty. Would you like to go there with me next week?

dialogue: A: Hi. Mike. How did your weekend go?
B: Fine. I went back to visit my grandma in the countryside.
A: Lucky you. What did you do there?
B: I went for a walk in the hills with some of my friends.
A: Was it good?
B: Yes. the scenery was amazing. The whole hillside was very red.
A: How wonderful! Do anything else?
B: We went on a picnic on Sunday.
A: Did you like it?
response: B: Very enjoyable. By the way, Lisa. what about your Weekend?

dialogue: A: Hi, David! Mr. Harper has just asked me if you'd finished your project yet. It was supposed to be handed in yesterday.
B: I know. I'm just finishing it now.
A: He wanted to know if we'd done them together. I said no. What's yours on? It took me ages to do mine.
B: Well, I was really lucky. I found this book all about the population in New Zealand cities.
A: Is it good?
B: Yes, it's a great book! I photocopied three chapters. There are some brilliant charts and...
A: What are you going to do with all that?
B: Well, now I'm going to copy these pages and these charts and then I'll finish my project!
A: You're not supposed to just copy the book.
B: Oh! I think Mr. Harper won't know.
response: A: He will know! He asked us to write a list of all the words we'd used. Remember? That's not the point anyway.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
response: A: It's wide open right now, everything from lawyers to diaper changers.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you waiting to buy the concert tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: How long have you been here?
B: About 50 minutes. I've hardly moved forward in that time.
A: Are you kidding?
B: Not at all. There was a couple up ahead of me who got so fed up that they finally gave up and left. They said they'd been here for more than an hour.
A: My God. Does anyone know what's causing the delay?
B: It could be that there aren't enough people selling tickets this afternoon. Or maybe their computers break down.
A: I just hope they don't run out of tickets when I get up there.
response: B: That really would be fantastic, wouldn't it?

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
response: B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's free to help.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
A: However,you must show us the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?
B: OK.
response: A: All right.  Give me your receipt.  If something comes up, you can't show it to us and you get nothing.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Madam. Can I help you?
B: Yes, er...I want to see the West End.
A: How much time do you have?
B: Just one day.
A: Well, what do you particularly want to do?
response: B: I want to visit Mars, French galleries, Versailles, do some shopping, and go to the theaters.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
response: A: Let me ask the computer in that reception office

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
response: A: You must be mad. I think it's really...you know...so easy to buy everything in one place.

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
A: I do a lot of walking for exercise and enjoyment-sometimes ten to twenty kilometers at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.
B: Well, walking is a good exercise. How about sports?
A: Not since my school days. I used to love playing baseball, but it's impossible to get enough people together for a game now. Mostly I just watch sports on TV
B: I play tennis fairly regularly with my friends and sometimes go swimming and cycling by myself.
A: Oh, I forgot about that. I go cycling sometimes too. And I often go swimming on vacation, but only recreational swimming.
B: Why don't you join me at the gym sometime?
response: A: Well, maybe someday, but I'm pretty motivated about things like that.

dialogue: A: Waitress! I think there's something wrong with our bill.
B: No, I don't think so...$10 for the drinks, 15 for the small plate, and 20 for the main dish.
A: What? I knew the cheese sticks were 15. I always order cheese sticks, but I thought the main dish was $10.
B: Oh, that explains it. You think the bill should be $35.
A: Yes, exactly. I was wondering what happened to the rest of my change. I should have gotten back 15, not 5!
B: I understand. Sometimes people aren't honest, but I think this was an honest mistake. Didn't you order the sea cucumbers for dinner?
A: Yes, and they were delicious. Best cucumbers ever! I'm so glad I'm a vegetarian.
response: B: Sir, I am so sorry. Have you ordered sea cucumbers before? They aren't meats, you know.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.
response: A: I don't know how you keep on with it. It's too hard to become a college drop-out.

dialogue: A: May I help you, sir?
B: Yes, please. I want to buy a personal gift for my brother. He's taking a trip to South America.
A: Is he going by ship or plane?
B: He,s flying. My gift will have to be something light in weight. What can you suggest?
A: What about this tie? It's made of pure silk.
B: My sister already gave him one. I'd like something unusual. Let me look around...oh, that clock looks nice, but...
A: Hey,here is a gift for the man who has everything.
response: B: Oh,a folding toothbrush! That's a mundane idea he'll hate! I'll take it.

dialogue: A: Do you know much about computers?
B: Not a great deal. Why?
A: I've been reading an article about computers. They are strange and are being used for almost everything.
B: Yes. But have you learned how to use one?
A: No. But I'm about to take a course on computers next term.
B: That's good. You have to know about computers. Computer knowledge is a must whatever you do. You should learn quickly or you will be left behind.
A: That's true. But first I want to learn the basics. In the library, there are computers. But it's a pity that I could not make use of them.
B: Well, I can teach you the ABCs, if you like.
response: A: That's very selfish of you.

dialogue: A: What are you thinking?
B: I ’ m thinking about where we shall spend our vocation.
A: It ’ s about 7 o ’ clock. let ’ s have our breakfast first.
B: Ok, dear.We will be late.
A: What do you want?
response: B: A ham salad sandwich .

dialogue: A: Bob, do you know who I saw the other day? Old Jake, looking terribly depressed. Did he get pensioned off at last?
B: Yes. They made him retire after 50 years at sea. He is pretty upset about it, but what can you do? He really is pasted.
A: He is all alone, isn't he?

B: Yes, his wife has been dead for years. They had one daughter, Dories. But she went off to town as soon as she left school. And he hasn't heard from her since. I hear she is making good money as a model.
A: Maybe someone could get in touch with her. Get her to come back for a while to help?

B: I don't suppose she come. She never got on with her father. He is bit of a tough character and she is rather selfish. Oh, I expect old Jake will get by. He is healthy at least, comes into a clinic for a check regularly.
response: A: Are you his doctor?

dialogue: A: Did you hear how cold it got last night?
B: I heard the radio announcer say it was 18 degrees below zero.
A: It was so cold this morning. I could hardly start my car.
B: My car didn't want to start either at first.
response: A: Don't you have a garage?

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
response: B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition improved when he enjoyed himself and watched scary movies.

dialogue: A: Why are you interested in our company?
B: Your company is world-famous. So, I think there will be better chances for persona development.
A: You're right. Do you think you have the qualifications for this job?
B: Sure. My qualifications meet your job description.
A: But you have no experience for this job.
B: That's true. But I am eager to learn, and also quick at learning.
response: A: Since you need further training, are you familiar with training salary?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
A: Do they look like roses?
B: No, they look like little bells.
A: Oh, lilies of the valley. No, I am sorry. We are all out of them right now.
B: Oh, that's too bad.
A: What about roses?
B: Ok. How many do you suggest?
response: A: As many as you like, sir. They are hideous, aren't they?

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.
B: Uh. I didn't have any of that when I was in middle school, and I did just fine.
A: Yeah, and there weren't any cars either. Things are a lot more progressive now.
B: Great. My daughter will be playing video games in class.
A: Dad.
response: B: Okay. How much are these things going to make me laugh?

dialogue: A: Betty, something is burning. Can you smell it?
B: You ’ re right.
A: Look! The iron is still on.
response: B: I should have turned it on. I ’ ll turn it on now.

dialogue: A: Are you cold?
B: Yes, a little.
A: I wonder if we can change the temperature.
B: I tried before. There are no buttons on the air conditioning.
A: There must be buttons. How do they turn it on and off?
response: B: I think it is centrally controlled. They have snacks at the main desk.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
response: A: Ok , I won't keep you then .

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
response: B: Yes, always. I don't want to mark my desk.

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent three hours on it.
A: By the way, what time did you go home?
B: I left the office at nine o'clock. I got home at ten.
response: A: What did you have for breakfast?

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit sort of hands at present. Two waitresses are ill.

A: All right, but that's no excuse. My husband asked for goose and he was brought chicken instead. It's just unbelievable! And my beans weren't cooked properly. It wasn't a very enjoyable meal at all.
B: This is most regrettable.
response: A: Look at this bill. We've been undercharged. We  had two desserts, not only one. Can you check the bill again, please?

dialogue: A: Any interesting jobs listed on the Internet today?
B: Well, there are a lot of retail jobs-selling clothes and stuff. But you have to work Saturdays and Sundays.
A: Hmm. I hate working on weekends.
B: Hmm... so do I.
A: Oh, here's a job in sales. It's a job selling children's books to bookstores.
B: That sounds interesting.
A: Yes.
B: Let's see.
A: You need to have a driver's license. And you have to work some evenings.
response: B: I don't mind working evenings during the week. And I enjoy sitting behind a desk. So, what's the phone number?

dialogue: A: Do you have a driver's license?
B: No. I am going to take the test in a couple of weeks.
A: Didn't you drive in your own country?
response: B: Yes. But I'm already the most skilled.

dialogue: A: Hello, Amy. Are you coming to my birthday party?
B: Yes, I am. How do I get to your house from the station?
A: Well, call me when you get to the station and I'll come and pick you up in my car.
B: Are you sure it won't be too much trouble?
A: It's no trouble at all. It only takes about 15 minutes.
response: B: Oh, I don't need your phone number. Is it 828816887?

dialogue: A: : Dad, what will we have for dinner?
B: : I don't know. Maybe fried fish, chicken soup and...
A: : Oh, no. We've had such things since Mom's gone.
B: : I'm sorry. But that is the only thing I can cook. What do you want to have then?
A: : I'd like to go to McDonald's this time.
response: B: : OK then. You'll drive, will you?

dialogue: A: Did you see May today?
B: Yes, but why does she have such a long face?
A: I don't have the foggiest idea.
response: B: I thought she'd be disturbed.

dialogue: A: Well, I'm afraid my cooking isn't to your taste.
B: Actually, I like it very much.
A: I'm glad you enjoy it. Let me serve you some more fish.
B: No, thank you. I've had enough fish, but I'd like some soup.
A: Here it is. Help yourself!
B: Thanks. I didn't know you were so good at cooking. If only my wife could learn to cook from you.
response: A: Why not bring your wife next time? I've seen her for quite a bit lately

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
B: We thought we'd have that at head office and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.
A: Ok. What sort of things would you like?
B: Just a light lunch I think, so that people can eat while they move around and talk to each other. You did some thing similar for us last year. We'd be happy to have the same menu again.
A: Right. I'll look at my diary and see what you had last time. Oh, I nearly forgot to ask you how many should I cater for?
B: Well, I think most people will be able to come, perhaps around 30. No, let's say 35, to be sure.
response: A: Right, thank you for getting in touch, Mr. Smith. I'll send you confirmation of the arrangements by the end of this week.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
B: Buy an expensive suit.
response: A: Is going in only a white tank top OK?

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
A: Then the truck hit the taxi, did it?
response: B: Yes, with much noise. Then I called the beautician

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite reasonable.
response: B: It sounds annoying. Thank you very much for your help.

dialogue: A: Oh, let's just go in for a minute, I'm hungry.
B: OK, but just a snack. We're eating supper at home tonight.
A: Let's get some milk and bread.
response: B: I don't really like milk. How about a soda?

dialogue: A: Anything else, sir?
B: That's all for now. How much do I owe you?
A: That'll be fifty-five dollars and twenty cents.
B: Can't you make it a little cheaper?
response: A: Oh, no, sir. We already gave you a mark-up on each item.

dialogue: A: By the way, would you like to go to the movies this evening?
B: I'd love to. But I must write some emails.
A: Why tonight?
B: I haven't written to anyone for months. Sylvia and John must think I've forgotten them.
A: You don't have to write. You can call them tomorrow. It's half price on Sundays.
B: Yes, I could, couldn't I? All right. I'll do that. What's playing then?
A: Let's see. Here we are. The Columbia: In the World. A must for all teenagers.
B: No, thank you!
A: Central: Children's World. All parents of teenage children ought to see this picture.
B: There must be something worth seeing somewhere.
A: What about this? John Wayne in Texas, Here I Come.
B: I can't stand Westerns.
response: A: Neither can I. Listen, Joan. I've got a modern Western to watch.

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
response: B: We can go this weekend instead.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
A: One moment while I go and get my ID.
B: Make it quick.
A: Okay, here's my ID and the $ 27.
B: Thanks. Now fill this out.
response: A: Do you have a car that I can use ?

dialogue: A: My mother got really annoyed with my father yesterday evening.
B: Why? Did she complain about his cooking?
A: Oh no. It was about watching television.
B: Don't tell me he fell asleep in front of the television.
response: A: No, he kept changing channels on the remote.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
response: B: How about playing video games?

dialogue: A: Do you collect cola cans, Steve?
B: No. Why do you ask?
A: You have so many empty cans here.
B: Well, my mum wants me to keep all the cans, so that we can sell them after a while.
A: Aha, you are going to make a millionaire of yourself sooner or later with all those cans.

B: You bet I will. Well, that's not the point. The point is we separate reusable things from other rubbish. We have to pay the dustman for dealing with rubbish, but if we sell him these cans and other reusable material we pay less.
A: That sounds a clever idea. Now what are reused in China?
B: Metal, plastic, paper, books and the like.
A: Just as we do back home in the States.

B: And to avoid waste, the government is limiting the production of goods that can be used only once, such as bamboo chopsticks. For example, all the fast food boxes should be made of paper instead of non-reusable material.
response: A: That will surely be helpful for a clean environment.

dialogue: A: Did you have your television repaired?
B: Yes, but not by the place you recommended
A: Why not? The repair is very good and thecharges are so reasonable.
