response: B: That may be, but I couldn't find it.

dialogue: A: Any messages, Miss Grey?
B: Just one, Mr. Blank. You had a telephone call from someone called Brown, David Brown.
A: Brown? I don't seem to know anyone called Brown. What did he say?
B: He wouldn't say. But it sounded important. I told him you'd phone him as soon as you got back.
response: A: Well, I'd better do it then, I suppose. It's not an issue if you don't have his phone number.

dialogue: A: A lovely day, isn't it?
B: It is.
A: It seems it will be a fine all day.
B: I think it will be a dry day. There's hardly a cloud in the sky.
A: We'll have a heat wave in the afternoon. I'm afraid.
response: B: It's very frigid and snowy today. No wind at alt.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mary.
B: Hello, Jason. What are you going to do this evening?
A: I've no idea. What about you?
B: I have two tickets for the football match. Will you go with me?
A: Certainly. You know I haven't watched a football match for a long time.
B: Neither have I Shall we go there by bus?
response: A: All right. After supper let's eat at the street corner. OK?

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
response: B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.

dialogue: A: David, why didn ’ t you clean the room?
B: I ’ m not in the mood.
A: Why are you feeling depressed?
response: B: I was told my girlfriend was speaking ill of me. That ’ s a real let-down.

dialogue: A: Are you new here?
B: This is my first day here.
A: Are you a freshman in college?
B: I started school somewhere else.
response: A: What job did you transfer from?

dialogue: A: Did you see the large crowd on the street corner when you came to school this morning?
B: Yes, I did. What was that all about?
A: A serious accident happened. A drunk driver hit a bus full of passengers.
B: Oh dear! A lot of people must have been hurt or even killed?
A: You are right! All the injured people were taken to the hospital immediately.
response: B: I hope so. Drivers must be reckless, especially during rush hour.

dialogue: A: Hello! How can I help you, sir?
B: I want to take out a loan for school. What kind of interest rate do you offer?
A: Do you qualify for any of the Federal loan programs?
B: Yes, but I need to borrow some more money.
A: Well. In that case we can offer you a private educational loan.
B: What's the interest rate?
A: It's 7.2 %, fixed-rate loan.
B: How do I go about taking it out?
response: A: Just leave the application blank. We can let you know right away if you qualify .

dialogue: A: Are you enjoying your trip to New Orleans?
B: Oh, yes. I really like it here.
A: Would you like to do something tonight?
B: Sure. I'd love to.
A: Let's see. Have you been to a jazz club yet?
B: Yes. I've already been to several clubs here.
A: OK. What about an evening riverboat tour?
B: Uh, actually, I've gone twice this week.
A: So, what do you want to do?
B: Well, I haven't been to the theater in a long time.
A: Oh, OK. I hear there's a terrific show at the Sanger Theater.
response: B: Great! Let's make a reservation for a riverboat cruise.

dialogue: A: Have you booked the airplane tickets to spain yet?
B: Well, I thought we should go traveling by ship for a change, so I booked two ship tickets instead.
A: You should have told me or discussed it with me.
B: I wanted to give you a surprise. Don't you like the idea?
A: I like it all right, but it takes much more time to travel by ship than by plane.
B: We have time, don't we? Every time we went on a trip, we were always tied down by schedules. This time will be different. We don't have to rush.
A: You're right. This is our first trip since you retired. We can travel as long as we like.
B: We'll have an easy trip and enjoy every minute.
response: A: Have you bought traveler's cheques yet?

dialogue: A: Welcome to Beijing, Mary. This time you will see the New Beijing.
B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
response: B: You're right. But I really had a boring and terrible vacation.

dialogue: A: A woman after my own heart...
B: OK, Mr. Coffee Connoisseur, so what's the next step in the coffee-making process?
A: Well, step two is grinding the coffee beans. I've roasted three different types of beans.
response: B: Let me guess, Mocha, Latte, and Cappuccino!

dialogue: A: Would you like to come to the cinema tonight?
B: I'm afraid I can't.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair tonight.
A: OK. What about tomorrow night?
B: I can't go tomorrow night, either.
A: Why not?
B: I've got to wash my hair again.
A: Do you wash your hair every night?
B: It depends...
A: Depends on what?
response: B: It depends on who asks me to go to the cinema.

dialogue: A: What's your favourite game?
B: I like to play table tennis. How about you?
A: I like swimming and skating.
B: Isn't it hard to learn skating?
A: No, what you need is balance.
B: Could you teach me how to do it?
A: Sure, anytime when you are free.
response: B: Do I have to buy a pair of skis?

dialogue: A: Did you call me?
B: Thank you for returning my call.
A: What was your call about?
B: I wanted to have a talk with you about your son.
A: What did he do?
response: B: He was doing great last week in class.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. What did you do today?

B: Hi, Mark! I've just got back from the Art Gallery. They had a wonderful art exhibition today. You shouldn't have stayed home and worked on that paper. I think you would have been inspired by some of the paintings.
A: Oh, I don't know. I don't really care for modern art.

B: I think you should think of modern art like food. You need to taste things to see if you like them. You know, some of the pieces at the exhibition were even for sale. The last one was on sale for $9,000.
response: A: $9,000? Well, I may go and visit the exhibition tomorrow, but I'm going to buy everything.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
B: Do you take vitamins?
A: No, I never do.
response: B: How about exercise?

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
B: What for? For the party, of course.
A: Party? What party?
response: B: We ’ re having a Valentine ’ s Day Party .

dialogue: A: Hi, John. What are you doing here?
B: I'm waiting for the bus.
A: Where are you going?
B: I'm going to the station to meet my sister.
A: Oh, is she coming by herself?
B: Yes, the train comes in about half past four, but it's twenty past four now. I have only ten minutes!
A: How often does the bus run?
response: B: Every ten minutes. I missed a No. 1 bus 15 minutes ago, and the next one hasn't come yet!

dialogue: A: Fikky, what's going on? Freggis just told me that you're going to be leaving us.
B: Yes, I really feel bad out of it. But B. N. D. came up with really good offer.
A: Well, I didn't know you were going to look for a new job.
response: B: Well, just between you and me. I think we have some really good people in this department. Don't get me wrong. It has nothing to do with you, Frank. Everybody says you are an excellent manager.

dialogue: A: When did you become interested in collecting stamps?
B: Oh, when I was about ten years old.
A: Ten years old? So you have loved it for 9 years.
B: Yeah, it's really an exciting hobby. You know, the first postage stamps were issued in Britain in 1840.
A: Really? I didn't know that. What's on the first postage stamps?
B: Well, look, here's a picture of the first two stamps issued.
A: Oh, they both bear a picture of Queen Victoria, don't they?
B: Yes, I wish I had the originals, then I would be a wealthy man instead of a poor stamp collector.
response: A: But I believe collecting stamps gives you much pleasure which not all wealthy men can enjoy.

dialogue: A: Hi, Robert, what happened to your face? It looks swollen.
B: I have to go and get my teeth filled.
A: Did it hurt?
B: I don't even want to talk about it. It killed me!
A: Well, I guess you've learned a good lesson, huh! You have to take good care of your teeth.
B: No kidding. I can't stand the pain, but the bill is too large!
A: Don't you have a dental insurance?
response: B: I do. but it doesn't cover everything.

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
B: Buy an expensive suit.
response: A: Is a white undershirt OK?

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
response: A: No, I don't. I mean a general psychiatrist. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Where were you at lunchtime? I was looking for you in the dining hall.
B: Oh, sorry, I missed you. My English class ran late again.
A: That's been happening quite often recently. Maybe it's because the final exams are coming up.
response: B: No. After class, there is always a group of students hanging around the cafeteria. How about you? Are you ready for the exams?

dialogue: A: Where is Jimmy? Why hasn't he come down for breakfast? Needn't he go to school today?
B: He's still in bed in his room.
A: What's the matter with our dear son?
response: B: He's feeling terrible. I think he must have won the lottery.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bob. I heard about your accident but I didn't think it would be this bad.
B: Well, thanks for making me feel better.
A: I can hardly recognize you. Tell me what happened.

B: I just got back from Africa where I had a terrible accident in a motorcycle race. I broke both my legs when my motor failed and was hit by another motorcycle. I was laid up in a hospital over there for three weeks.
A: Three weeks, that's a long time. What did you do while you were in the hospital?
B: Well, if you can believe it, I read all about motorcycle racing. I love racing even if it hurts.
A: But I'm afraid you don't make it look very funny. You're lucky to be alive.
B: That's for sure. I am lucky to be alive.
A: How soon can you get well? Did the doctor tell you about it?
B: They say I still need to stay in bed for two weeks or so.
A: I think you'll get a bit fatter by then. By the way, is there anything I can do for you?
response: B: No, thank you. Thank you for the ugly flowers. It's very kind of you to come to see me.

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
response: B: Sure, I love chocolate.  I'd rather have pineapple pie.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mrs. Smith. Nice to see you here.
B: Hi, Mr. White. I'm here to buy a pair of shoes for Tom again.
A: He wore out the pair you bought last month?
response: B: Yes. Sometimes I think I should buy him a pair of linen shoes.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
response: A: For trivial affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
B: Well, there's a coffee shop on the next corner. It serves good food.
A: OK. I'll try it. Can I get you something?
B: No, I think I'll come with you. I'm longing for a nice salad.
A: Do you often have lunch at this coffee shop?
response: B: No, I usually bring my lunch from home and eat at my desk.

dialogue: A: Are you sure that this bus will take us to Santa Anita mall?
B: Yes, it will.
A: You know that for a fact?
response: B: I take this bus all the time, but you know what, I'm not sure.

dialogue: A: Well, this must be the National Library.
B: I guess so. Oh, no! I don't think it's open today. Look, it says "Closed Tuesdays".
A: Well, we'll just have to come back tomorrow.
response: B: But we're supposed to go on that tour tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Bill, do you know when did the Chinese begin to celebrate Teachers ' Day?
B: I know the Chinese teachers had their first festival in 1985.
A: So, it is the 27th Teachers ' Day.
B: What will you do on Teachers ' Day?
response: A: I am going to send Mr. Li some flowers. What about you?

dialogue: B: Help. I need some help!
A: Yes sir. Can you tell me what is happening?
B: I'm at the university and a student of mine suddenly fell down, knocked her head on the step, and fainted right at this very moment.
A: Yes sir. Can you tell me exactly where you are?
response: B: On the...on the ...I'm sorry, I'm too happy right now. We're on the second floor of Cutler Hall, Room 211.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Is there anything I can do for you?
B: I would like to buy two bottles of brandy.
A: How about this one? It's the special local product.
B: Can I buy these tax free?
response: A: Yes . This is not a duty-free shop .

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
B: She's very fond of detective stories?
A: I see. Has she read any detective stories?
B: Oh, yes!
A: Do you know if she's read this one?
B: I'm not sure, but she probably won't remember if she has! She's very forgetful!
response: A: Ah ! She has a bad memory . How old is she ?

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman said it will.
response: B: I don't think he's right. It just rained a lot this morning.

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
response: B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was killed in that bombing.

dialogue: A: Are you going somewhere?
B: Yes, I ’ m off to the department store. I must buy some furniture for my new flat.
A: Really? Well you ’ ll have to get there before 6pm because they close early today.
B: Ok. Thanks for that information.
A: Yeah and remember if you buy something you mustn ’ t carry it home otherwise your back will get worse.
B: Ok, do they have a delivery service?
response: A: Yes, but it’s free, you don't have to pay.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bob. I heard about your accident but I didn't think it would be this bad.
B: Well, thanks for making me feel better.
A: I can hardly recognize you. Tell me what happened.

B: I just got back from Africa where I had a terrible accident in a motorcycle race. I broke both my legs when my motor failed and was hit by another motorcycle. I was laid up in a hospital over there for three weeks.
A: Three weeks, that's a long time. What did you do while you were in the hospital?
B: Well, if you can believe it, I read all about motorcycle racing. I love racing even if it hurts.
A: But I'm afraid you don't make it look very funny. You're lucky to be alive.
B: That's for sure. I am lucky to be alive.
A: How soon can you get well? Did the doctor tell you about it?
B: They say I still need to stay in bed for two weeks or so.
A: I think you'll get a bit fatter by then. By the way, is there anything I can do for you?
response: B: No, thank you. Thank you for the beautiful flowers. It's very kind of you to come to see me.

dialogue: A: How do you pay at the shops, Mary?
B: Why? By cash or card, of course.
A: Ever thought of your mobile phone?
B: Is it possible?
response: A: This time next year, perhaps.  It's time-consuming.  Everything is done in 2 hours, to be exact.

dialogue: A: Where did you put my new red tie?
B: It's right there in the cupboard with your other ties.
A: There's a green one and a couple of brown ones, but no red one.
B: Here it is in your drawer. You must have put it there when you brought it home.
A: I suppose so. We'd better hurry up or we're going to be late. The Smiths said to come at 7:00.
response: B: 24 now. Sue isn't here to take care of the children yet.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
response: B: I hope I could get a reception at the British Embassy some time.

dialogue: A: Come in, come in! Can I help you?
B: Professor Turner, are you giving your Advanced Geology course again next semester?
A: Yes.
response: B: I wonder if I could enroll in it, I know it's an introductory course and I'm only a junior, but...

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
response: A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives there.

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wanting to stay somewhere for a few days.

A: Well, there are some good hotels. Carlton House is near the main square in the city center, but you might also be interested in the Royal Hotel-that's out in the countryside, about ten kilometers away, very peaceful. Then there's the Rainbow Hotel-it is not in the center, but it's out on the airport road.
response: B: Mmm, that might be right in the center where I want to be actually. Now the one you mentioned, in the city center. Can you tell me a bit about it?

dialogue: A: Happy anniversary, sweetheart!
B: Yes. to our first anniversary and many more to come. Cheers!
A: I'll drink to that. Thanks for making this a night worth remembering.
response: B: Well , it's not much of a special day . They say if you survive the first year , the rest is smooth sailing .

dialogue: A: Bill, do you know when did the Chinese begin to celebrate Teachers ' Day?
B: I know the Chinese teachers had their first festival in 1985.
A: So, it is the 27th Teachers ' Day.
B: What will you do on Teachers ' Day?
response: A: I am not going to send Mr. Li some flowers on Teacher's Day.

dialogue: A: Are you there, Mary?
B: I'm back. My bid on the Buddha is still the highest!
A: How much is my stamp?
response: B: Don't you want to hear more about my stamp?

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
A: It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want some company?
B: Sure. But, it will be a long hike, 30 miles in three days. Have you been hiking before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike.
B: Wow! You must have been pretty far away from the city.
response: A: Not really , my friend and I hiked in a very wild part of the national forest that was close by to the city.

dialogue: A: Can I apply for a permit today?
B: I need to see your ID.
A: I think I forgot it in the car.
B: You need to give me your ID and $ 27.
A: I'm going to go and get my ID from the car right now.
B: Go get it.
A: Here you go.
B: All right, I'm going to need you to fill this out.
response: A: Can I borrow your screwdriver?

dialogue: A: Are you planning on voting?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, but this will be my first time voting.
B: Really?
A: Yes, and I have no idea how to do it.
B: Voting is simple.
A: I don ’ t know any of the laws they ’ re trying to pass.
B: That ’ s okay. They describe everything on the ballot.
A: I didn ’ t know that.
B: Don ’ t worry. You ’ ll be fine.
response: A: That ’ s good to know.

dialogue: A: Am I late?
B: No, you've got an hour and a quarter. Your flight leaves at 9:30.
A: I'm so excited.
B: Have you got everything?
A: Yes, my tickets and my traveler's checks.
response: B: And your library card?

dialogue: A: (sniffing) Is that a French cigarette?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that a French cigarette you're smoking?
B: Yes, that's right. Why? What's the matter?
A: I don't understand why yousmoke French cigarettes. They make a terrible smell.
B: I like them very much. I prefer them to English cigarettes.
A: Have you got a lot of them?
B: Yes, about 200, why?
A: Well... er... could I buy some from you?
response: B: Buy some from me? But... you don't like French cigarettes!

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
A: At least more than 100 years old.
B: Let's enter it!
A: I can't open the door.
B: It must be locked.
A: Let me ask the old woman in that reception office.
B: She can't answer you.
response: A: She must be mute.

dialogue: A: We are going to put on a performance.
B: Really? When?
A: On May 4. We have been preparing for it for two months.
B: Where are you going to put it on? In your school?
A: No. At the People's Theatre.
B: If I remember correctly, you put it on at the Youth Square last year.
A: Yeah. But it is under repair now.
response: B: But why are you doing that? To collect money for repairing the Youth Square?

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of beginning my own business.
A: That sounds great.
response: B: Yes, I think it over, but the problem is money. If I had enough money, I'd leave the bank tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bob. I heard about your accident but I didn't think it would be this bad.
B: Well, thanks for making me feel better.
A: I can hardly recognize you. Tell me what happened.

B: I just got back from Africa where I had a terrible accident in a motorcycle race. I broke both my legs when my motor failed and was hit by another motorcycle. I was laid up in a hospital over there for three weeks.
A: Three weeks, that's a long time. What did you do while you were in the hospital?
B: Well, if you can believe it, I read all about motorcycle racing. I love racing even if it hurts.
A: But I'm afraid you don't make it look very funny. You're lucky to be alive.
B: That's for sure. I am lucky to be alive.
A: How soon can you get well? Did the doctor tell you about it?
B: They say I still need to stay in bed for two weeks or so.
A: I think you'll get a bit fatter by then. By the way, is there anything I can do for you?
response: B: No, thank you. Thank you for the beautiful flowers. It's very annoying of you to come to see me.

dialogue: A: Cheers! To our first night in our new apartment.
B: It's so quiet. I'm not really used to it.
A: All you hear is the crickets and the breeze.
B: It's a little eerie. I'm sure the silence will begin to grow on me.
response: A: Well, I think it's fabulous. And the neighbors are so loud all the time.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for myself.
A: Oh? Did you talk with her about it?
B: I've tried, but it didn't work.
A: Oh, so, when are you going to tell her?
B: Maybe tonight. I don't know. I don't know how to tell her.
response: A: I know she is head over heels in love with you.  She will celebrate!

dialogue: A: Ahahah! What is that thing on your couch! It just moved!
B: Did you think it wasn't real? That's my pet lizard.
A: You have a pet lizard? Somehow I never would have imagined that.
B: His name is Grunt. Come closer and I'll properly introduce you.
A: Does it bite or scratch?
B: No, he's perfectly harmless. And he's not afraid of strangers either. Here, hold him.
A: Wow. He's heavy! And his skin feels really cool.
response: B: Stick around and you'll get to know him better. He has a very unusual personality.

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
response: B: Oh, all right. Well, we could rent an iPhone video and watch that.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
B: I need to review my English.
A: So that's what keeps you so busy recently!
B: Yes, I've been tied up with my studies. Now, what worries me a lot is my English.
A: But why? Your English is very good.
B: Thank you. You are very kind.
response: A: No, I'm telling the truth. As an American, I understand you quite well.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
response: B: Yes, I do. Sometimes I want to throw all of them right out of the window.

dialogue: A: Hi, honey. Do you need any help with your luggage?
B: No, thanks, dad. I just brought one carry-on in my backpack.
A: Great. I wish your mother would take some packing lessons from you. OK, let's go home.
B: Hm...It's cold here.
response: A: Yes, the weatherman says there might be a heat wave tonight.  What temperature was it when you took off from California this morning?

dialogue: A: Hello, I'm returning your phone call.
B: I'm glad that you could get back to me so fast.
A: No problem, but what were you calling about?
B: I needed to talk to you about your son.
A: Is he messing up in school?
response: B: He was acting up in class one day last week .

dialogue: A: Brandy, I am supposed to participate in an interview tomorrow.
B: That's great. You need to prepare for it.
A: How?
response: B: Buy an expensive wallet.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Anything wrong?
B: I've been suffering from a fever since yesterday.
A: Do you have any other problems? Like a headache or cough?
B: No, I don't. I think it's only a fever.
response: A: Let me check... It's only 89 degrees fahrenheit! I'll give you some medicine.

dialogue: A: Hello! Is your taxi engaged?
B: No, this taxi is free.
A: Please take me to the Honging Hotel.
response: B: OK . Please get out . I'm glad I served you .

dialogue: A: Lin Yang. It's twelve already. What about having some thing to eat?
B: Are you hungry?
A: Well, I am a bit. Aren't you?
B: Not very. But I don't mind going somewhere for a light meal.
response: A: Where shall we go? What about an all you can eat buffet?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
response: A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.

dialogue: A: What do you think of Professor Potter's course, Jane?
B: Not much.
A: Why, what's wrong with it?

B: Oh, I don't know. It's just that he overloads it with details. The course he gave on town planning last year, it was just the same-a load of details, which you could have got from a book anyway. There was no overall...
A: No general overview you mean?
B: Yes. I suppose you could call it that. I couldn't see the town for the buildings.
A: But you've got to have the details in this kind of subject. Anyway I think he's good. You take his first lecture for instance. I thought that was very interesting, and not at all over-detailed.
B: Well, he starts off all right, but then he just piles on the details.
A: Now you're exaggerating.
B: Well, the way he dealt with the Western developments, that wasn't bad, I suppose.
A: You seem to have got something. Perhaps Potter is a little disorganized, but I think he's good.
B: Do you really think so?
response: A: He does do most of his teaching to the postgraduates. He only does the one undergraduate course each year. After all, I think he tends to forget where he is. He starts off being nice and general and then tries to cram in a bit too much specialized information.

dialogue: A: Hi! Can I help you?
B: Hi! Have you got any records of modern guitar music?
A: We've got a lot of them. Which one are you looking for?
B: I'm looking for some records of Julian Bream. I saw them in your window last week and I had them before in Canada, but I broke them.
A: What happened?
B: They were in my bag. I sat on my bag and broke the records. My sister told me about your shop. I came here last week and saw the records.
A: Let's look for the records. Oh, yes, the records are there on the shelf.
B: How much are those three?
A: They are four pounds and fifty pence.
response: B: Here are five envelopes.

dialogue: A: Are you alright, child?
B: Hey, I still know my name.
A: What did the nurse say?
B: She said I have a fever but nothing major.
response: A: In that case, you should go home and start training for a marathon.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
B: It's Green, G-R-E-E-N.
A: And your telephone number?
response: B: I'm at the Holiday Sun Hotel. My number is 0708112, I'm in Room 1203. By the way, is your bike rental shop at No.100 Teckman Street?

dialogue: A: Welcome.
B: Hi, John. Hey, you've done a good job decorating this place, really nice.
A: Thanks, I am glad you like it. Can I get you a drink?
B: No, thanks. Let's make dinner. I am getting hungry.
A: Here is the kitchen. I will wash the onions first. Could you take the meat out of the fridge? It's in a yellow plastic container.
B: Wow, this smells good.
A: Could yon pass those potatoes to me, please?
B: What are we having?
A: My special dumplings, sweet and sour pork, beef with onions and green peppers, and a few side dishes like tomatoes with sugar.
B: Sounds wonderful. What are you going to do next?
response: A: I'll start preparing the meat Bolognese.

dialogue: A: (Sniffing) Phew! Is that French coffee?
B: Pardon?
A: Is that French coffee you are drinking?
B: Yes,that's right. Why? What's the matter?
response: A: I don't understand why you drink French coffee. It makes a strong smell.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: We'd like to take a tour to Florence.
A: That's a beautiful city. When do you want to go there?
response: B: We have got a long business trip and we plan to leave on Thursday .

dialogue: A: Did you get the injury playing football, Jim?
B: Yes. One of the boys kicked my foot instead of the ball.
A: The best thing for you to do is to rest your leg for 48 hours.
B: When can I go back to school?
response: A: You can go back in 4 days, but you'll need to avoid sports for a month.

dialogue: A: We are going to put on a performance.
B: Really? When?
A: On May 4. We have been preparing for it for two months.
B: Where are you going to put it on? In your school?
A: No. At the People's Theatre.
B: If I remember correctly, you put it on at the Youth Square last year.
A: Yeah. But it is under repair now.
B: But why are you doing that? To collect money for repairing the Youth Square?
response: A: No. We want to collect money and send it to demolish Youth Square.

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite smart, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?
response: B: Yeah. Let's see if there's the same size. Well, they don't seem to have anything larger.

dialogue: A: Hi, would you like some free candies?
B: Sure. What are you handing these out for?
A: Well, we're trying to gather some volunteers for the day care center.
B: Uh...
A: It's OK. You don't have to volunteer if you eat the candies.
B: I'm just playing around. Actually, I have some free time in the mornings after I go jogging. What exactly do you need?
A: It's wide open right now, everything from playground assistants to diaper changers.
B: Oh, I might pass on the latter. But spending some time on the playground with some small kids might be fun.
response: A: Well, you're quite cold-hearted. I haven't even mentioned the benefits but you've declined volunteering.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
response: B: I hope I could get a reception at my house some time.

dialogue: A: Are there pets allowed in this apartment?
B: No dogs or cats or any other fur type animal, but other pets are allowed.
A: What about a boa constrictor?
B: Well... is that a pet? Isn't that something from the zoo?
A: If I had one, could I rent this apartment?
B: I was more thinking of nice little fish or frogs or turtles or a pet rock.
A: What about a Gila monster?
response: B: I'll tell you what, if your pet is larger than this little box and doesn't have fur, it is welcome here.

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
B: No, never. I don't want to mark my desk.
A: Well, would you please keep my desk clean?
B: Aren't you going to sell it?
response: A: Yes, but who wants a happily married one?

dialogue: A: 911. What can I do for you?
B: I am reporting a break-in.
A: When did it happen?
B: It happened last night.
A: Where did it happen?
B: It happened at my house.
A: What was taken?
B: I don't know.
A: How do you know there was a break-in?
response: B: Someone knocked on my window.

dialogue: A: Harry, do you like the opera?
B: No, not really.
A: Why is that? It is called real art.
response: B: Well , it's very inexpensive and they're usually speaking in another language . That kind of gets on my nerves .

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
response: B: Yes, I had a wonderful experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
response: B: First question: How often do you take medicine?

dialogue: A: Are you free this afternoon?
B: I'm afraid I'm going to the gym for a workout.
A: How long have you been there?
response: B: I just signed up there last night.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, are you going to buy that book?
B: Well, I need it for a class but it's awfully expensive.
A: Oh, we must be in the same class. Introduction to British Literature?
B: Yes, that's the one. Were you there yesterday for the first class?
A: I sure was. Professor Robert really seems to know his subject.
B: Yes, I took his Shakespeare course last semester and it was very good. He likes listening to his students.
A: That's a relief. I'm a biology major and I was a little uncertain about taking an English course.
response: B: I'm an English major and this is a required course. But now I'm in trouble because I,  easily,  can afford this book.

dialogue: A: Hi, honey. Do you need any help with your luggage?
B: No, thanks, dad. I just brought one carry-on in my backpack.
A: Great. I wish your mother would take some packing lessons from you. OK, let's go home.
B: Hm...It's cold here.
A: Yes, the weatherman says that it might snow tonight. What temperature was it when you took off from California this morning?
B: Sixty degrees and sunny.
A: Don't you people miss the seasons?
response: B: Not really. It's nice to go outside everyday. And always have nice sun- ny weather.

dialogue: A: Please, please, can you help me? I seem to have lost my handbag.
B: Calm down, Madam. Well, I'll have to fill out this report for you. What color is it, Madam?
A: Well, it is a white one.
B: How big is it?
A: Mm, I guess it's about one foot long and seven inches tall.
B: One foot long and seven inches tall. What's in the bag, Madam?
A: There is a wallet, two keys, and a letter.
B: And where did you leave it?
A: I am sure I left it in the coffee shop on the 5th floor.
response: B: Don't worry, Madam. I am sure we can find it. Now could you give me your pet's name, your favorite color and lottery number?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
B: About 20 minutes at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 Bus.
response: A: I'd better go there by bus. By the way, where is the traffic stop, please?

dialogue: A: Tom, wake up! It's almost seven o'clock.
B: Oh, morning, Mom. Did the alarm clock ring?
A: Yes, it did.
B: But I didn't hear it at all.
A: What time did you set it for last night?
B: Six o'clock.
response: A: Hurry up, or you'll be late getting home from school. Are you feeling ill?

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
A: Nobody to take care of her?
response: B: My father rarely travels to other countries and he is doing business from home with Dubai now. I have to do a lot for my mom at home.

dialogue: A: Did you hear the thunder last night?
B: Yes. I was awake at that time. It was really loud.
A: I didn't see any lightning though. I thought thunder and lightning always occur together.
B: What makes you believe that?
response: A: A science book says, when thunder quickly beats the air, it will cause lightning.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
A: Ok, I won't keep you then.
B: Great! It's good to see you. Goodbye!
A: Yes, stay in touch. Bye!
response: B: Give me your gun , would you ?

dialogue: A: Has the train come yet?
B: No, I ‘ Ve been waiting for ages.
A: It ’ s so unreliable. I ’ Ve been late for my meetings all this week.
B: Yes, me too. I think I ’ Ve lost some important clients recently because of this train!
response: A: Yes , my customers have started to compliment us too !

dialogue: A: What class did you have this afternoon, Kate?
B: A chemistry class. We've got a new chemistry teacher this term.
A: Who is it?
B: James Black. He told us to call Jim, not to call him Mr. Black.
A: Oh, James Black. I know him. He's a little thin man who smiles a lot.
B: Yes, but many of us are afraid of him.
A: Really? But I hear he's a very good teacher.
B: Yes, he is. His classes are always lively and interesting. And we all watch and listen to him very carefully in his class.
A: It's important to watch carefully when you're studying chemistry, I think.
response: B: Jim often says that too, so we are only allowed to do anything instead of watching.

dialogue: A: And anything to drink?
B: Yes, a red wine and a cup of coffee.
A: How do you like your coffee?
response: B: With orange juice, please.

dialogue: A: Hey, do you want to go for a picnic in the park tomorrow afternoon?
B: I can't. I just started coaching a boys' football team. We have a game tomorrow.
A: Oh, that sounds fun. Maybe I can come see it.
B: Sure! The game starts at two, but we'll be there at 1:00 to prepare. It'll be at the football field beside the high school, across from the post office.
A: OK, great. I'll be there at 1:30, then. But why did you decide to coach a football team?
response: B: Well, I thought it might be a bad idea at first, because I was so busy at work. But then I thought, why not?

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I see your boarding pass, please?
B: Here you are.
A: Excuse me, sir. This is your passport.
B: Really? Ugh... Is there any difference?
A: Yes. As a matter of fact, you can't board the plane without boarding pass.
B: Gee. I must have left it in my hotel room.
response: A: Thank you sir. I can let you pass.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
response: B: I am going to go into work all night now.

dialogue: A: Are you cold?
B: Yes, a little.
A: I wonder if we can change the temperature.
B: I tried before. There are no buttons on the air conditioning.
A: There must be buttons. How do they turn it on and off?
response: B: I think it is centrally controlled. They control it at the main desk.

dialogue: A: Has everything been OK with you lately?
B: I haven ’ t been able to get a good night ’ s sleep lately. I ’ m exhausted!
A: Have you been too busy to get enough sleep?
B: I try to go to sleep, but I just can ’ t stay asleep.
A: How late do you try to go to sleep?
B: I go to bed when I finish my work.
A: Has anything in your day-to-day life been bothering you lately?
response: B: I am not too concerned about how I am going to pay my tuition since I have a lot of money .

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition improved when he enjoyed himself and watched funny movies.
A: You said Norman learned this? Do we have to learn to laugh?

B: Not necessarily. Since laughing is something people can do sitting down, costs no money, and requires no special exercise equipment or skill, it's the perfect workout for anyone who doesn't have the time or desire to participate in a regular fitness program.
A: Oh. Do you have such a program to offer to the general public?

B: Yes, we do. It's called the Smile Time-Out. You take a deep breath, smile, exhale, and say "Aaah" while visualizing all your muscles and cells smiling. Then add to that a memory of a time you felt really good and laughed and laughed.
A: What about the situation in which you aren't in a mood to laugh?
response: B: Even when you give a real smile or laugh, you get the same physiological benefits as when it's the real thing, because your mind is smart, but your body is stupid and can't tell the difference!

dialogue: A: Zhu, how do you like this coat?
B: Come on, George. Isn't that color too bright for me?
A: Then how about this one?
B: Oh, I'm afraid this color is too light. It easily gets dirty.
A: Well, well, Zhu, you're being a bit difficult.
B: What would you say if I buy this one?
response: A: It's nice. Try it on. Now you look quite dumb, but doesn't it feel a bit tight at the shoulders?

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 2 days, would there be any problem?
A: No problem at all. May I know your name?
response: B: It's Green, G-R-E-E-N.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. Is it true you're moving to London?
B: Yes, it is.
A: What made you decide to do that?
B: Work, mainly. I'm sure I'll be able to find a job there.
A: You're probably right. But where are you going to live?
B: I hope I'll find a flat to share with somebody. That way it will be cheaper.
A: Yes, that's a good idea. Are you taking your dog with you?
B: No, I don't think so. My parents have offered to take care of him, and I don't think he'd be happy in the city.
A: You're probably right. But aren't you afraid of moving to such a big place, especially after living in a small village?
B: Not really. I think I'll enjoy myself. There's so much to do there; I expect I won't miss the countryside much and I can always come back and visit.
response: A: Well, I just hope you'll invite me to stay when you get settled.

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
B: Yes, I do. It made me laugh a lot.
A: But I'd rather see something not only interesting but also instructive.
response: B: Oh, Jane, don't be so serious. People never need relaxation.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.
B: Uh. I didn't have any of that when I was in middle school, and I did just fine.
A: Yeah, and there weren't any cars either. Things are a lot more progressive now.
B: Great. My daughter will be playing video games in class.
A: Dad.
response: B: Okay. How much are these things going to cost me?

dialogue: A: A woman after my own heart...
B: OK, Mr. Coffee Connoisseur, so what's the next step in the coffee-making process?
A: Well, step two is grinding the coffee beans. I've roasted three different types of beans.
response: B: Let me guess, Mocha, Mandheling, and Santos!

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.
B: No, I think we must have disturbed them. They must have heard us coming and got out of the bathroom window quickly.
response: A: Yes, well, hurry up. We'd better avoid phoning the police.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. I'd like to apply for a library card. Can you help me?
B: Yes. Please give me your ID card, a photo.
A: OK. Here you are.
B: Then you have to give me 15 dollars for the deposit. The library card is free.
A: OK. Here is the money. And If I return the card, can I get the refund?
response: B: Of course , as long as the card is well kept .

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
response: B: At least , it can free you from the crowd . By the way , do you come from China ?

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
B: I go as much as I can. I love hiking because you can really get in touch with nature.
A: It would be nice to get out of the city. Do you want some company?
B: Sure. But, it will be a long hike, 30 miles in three days. Have you been hiking before?
A: Yeah, I go a lot too. I saw a bear and a mountain lion on my last hike.
response: B: Wow ! You must have been pretty far away from the city .

dialogue: A: Excuse me, but could you tell me when the plane for Berlin leaves?
B: In 40 minutes, at eleven o'clock. The plane for Berlin leaves every two hours.
A: How much is a second class ticket, please?
B: We have only first class tickets left. It is $ 350 one way.
A: OK. I'd like one for the next flight.
B: I'm sorry, but I don't sell tickets. You can get one from the machine over there.
A: All right. By the way, what's the gate number?
response: B: Four. Down the hall and to the left.

dialogue: A: Great! I landed on Classic Movies.
B: I didn't know you liked old movies.
A: I love them, especially the all-time greats like Gone With the Wind.
B: You're so right! Today's movies are just too commercial!
response: A: Sometimes I think Oscars are awarded to movies regardless of how much money they make.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
B: She's very fond of detective stories?
A: I see. Has she read any detective stories?
B: Oh, yes!
A: Do you know if she's read this one?
B: I'm not sure, but she probably won't remember if she has! She's very forgetful!
A: Ah! She has a bad memory. How old is she?
B: She's eighty-seven.
response: A: I suggest you take this book . I wouldn't call it exciting .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
response: B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
B: I love green apples.
A: I don't like green apples.
B: Really? Why not?
A: Green apples are too sour for me.
response: B: So , you like red apples better ?

dialogue: A: Can we make you an offer? We would like to run the campaign for four extra weeks.

B: Well, can we summarize the problem from my point of view? First of all, the campaign was late. It missed two important trade affairs. The ads also did not appear into key magazines. As a result, the campaign failed. Do you accept that summary of what happened?
A: Well, the delay wasn't entirely our fault. You did in fact make late changes to the specifications of the advertisements.
B: Uh, actually, you were late with the initial proposals so you have very little time and in fact, we only asked for small changes.
A: Well whatever, can we repeat our offer to run the campaign for 4 extra weeks?
response: B: That's not really the point. The campaign missed two key trade affairs. Because of this, we are asking you either to repeat the campaign next year for free, or we only pay 50% of the fee for this year.

dialogue: A: Hello, John. How was your French exam yesterday?
B: Not too good.
A: Well, the term exam is always more difficult. Work harder, and you'll certainly do better next time.
B: I've worked hard enough, I think, but unluckily, I have never done well in the exam.
A: Well, it's no use worrying about the exam now. Let's talk about the football game tonight. It's much more interesting.
B: Is there a football game on TV tonight?
A: Yes it's between the Chinese team and the Japanese team.
B: ... Er I'd rather watch some other programmes.
A: Why? You're so interested in football.
response: B: The Chinese team has always played at their peak in the important match, just as I have done in the important exam.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?
A: Yes. The nearest one is next to the bank. It's quite modern.
B: Do you think there're any cheap ones nearby?
response: A: Yes. Drive west for about two minutes and you will find one opposite to a supermarket. It's a family hotel, very comfortable, and the price is quite unreasonable.

dialogue: A: Hello!
B: Hello, Debbie. This is Donald.
A: Oh, hi, Donald.
B: What happened yesterday? You forgot our date, didn ’ t you?
A: Well, it rained hard all day and I had a bad cold, so I decided to stay home.
response: B: You did ? But I tried to call you at least twenty times and nobody answered .

dialogue: A: Hi, Laura. Where are you heading with that big bag?
B: I'm offto the gym. I've got to stay in shape, you know.
A: I know more women who exercise than men. What's the main reason you do that? For your health, or to look good?
B: To be honest, for both. With women, good looks are always a very important consideration.
A: I see.
B: How about you? Do you get any regular exercise?
response: A: I do a lot of speed-reading -sometimes ten to twenty books at a time-but I never go to the gym like you do.

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
response: A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?

dialogue: A: Do you have somewhere to stay in London, Peter?
B: No, I don't. In fact, I was about to ask you if you could arrange some place for me to stay.
A: Yes, that's no problem though I am not in charge of it. I'll ask someone to arrange it for you. What kind of place were you considering?

B: Well, I don't care if I share with other people, but I'm not good at housework. Maybe a home stay would be OK, but I don't like young children, because they're noisy and it's difficult to study. Hopefully, I can live with a lady who has retired.
A: OK, that's no problem. But I must warn you that living with a family in London is very expensive. Much more expensive than other small cities.
B: That's not a big problem. I have some money saved. Besides, I can always get a part-time job. I'm working in a supermarket as a cashier now. So I don't think I will have trouble with money.
response: A: Sounds good, though I think I'll have trouble with money. I'll call you if I get some information about that.

dialogue: A: Hello, Joan. Why are you late today? You are never late for work.
B: No, I never am, but...
A: Wow! Your coat's very dirty! Did you fall?
B: Yes, I had a terrible experience on the underground train. Listen to this! A man came up to me and pulled out a knife. He pointed it right at me!
A: Oh, no! Are you all right? Did he hurt you?
B: No, he didn't hurt me, but he took my handbag.
A: Then what happened? What did you do?
B: I caught hold of his knife, and he pushed me to the floor.
response: A: Oh, no! Why did you catch hold of his knife? That's safe.

dialogue: A: Oh god! Look at the mess. Somebody's broken in. The back door's open.
B: They mustn't have got in that way. I locked it.
A: What about the windows? The bathroom window is open. Surely they must have climbed through that.
B: Yeah. Wow, the television is gone.
A: They must have had a car or a truck.
B: My camera's here, but the radio's gone. Nothing else has been stolen. All your jeweler is here, but our daughter's toy is broken.
A: Thank goodness. They can't have been here long.
B: No, I think we must have disturbed them. They must have heard us coming and got out of the bathroom window quickly.
response: A: Yes, well, hurry up. We'd better phone the police.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Could you tell me if the bus goes the national history museum?
B: No. It doesn ’ t. There ’ s no through bus to the national history museum Madam..
A: I see. Where do I have to change them?
response: B: You can transfer at the national history museum.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the job in the newspaper?
B: Do you mean the one in Manchester?
A: Yes.
B: I saw it just now.
A: What do you think of it?
B: I think I'm not the type of man to do it.
A: Why do you think so?
B: They need an engineer to take care of the machine and I don't even know anything about that kind of machine.
A: I know you are always quick to learn. I believe when you use it you will get to know it well.
B: Are you serious about that?
response: A: Sure I am. You should study it for weeks.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
response: A: No , that's fine . It's totally fine if you didn't bring your bankbook with you.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mark. Are you in town for another job interview?
B: Yes, I'm pretty hopeful this time. I've just finished my second interview with this company.
A: That sounds great. I hope it works out for you. But wasn't it expensive just getting here?
B: No, in fact the company is paying all my expenses. They've put me up in a hotel downtown.
A: How nice! How many people are they interviewing?
B: They interviewed 16 the first time, and now four of us were chosen to go back for this interview.
response: A: Well, I hope it goes well. John and I would love it if you came to this area to work.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kathy, it's Jason.
B: Hi, Jason. I haven't heard from you in a while.
A: Well. I've been busy. I've started my own company.
B: Wow, what kind of business is it?
A: Just a small on-line store. I am hiring staff and I want you to come to work for me.
B: Actually, I just got started working at the old company again.
response: A: Oh, I didn't realize you were going back. Well, can you recommend someone else?

dialogue: A: Hey, Peter, I'm sorry!
B: Hi, Diana, what's wrong?
A: We were going to Hong Kong this weekend, but I'm afraid I can't go.
B: How come?
A: I have a really big geography test and I have to study for it.
response: B: We can go this weekend anyways.

dialogue: A: What are you doing tonight?
B: I have to run to the grocery store.
A: Don't you hate fighting the crowds on the weekends?
response: B: Yes , but I am out of tables and chairs.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. What can I do for you?
B: I want some coffee.
A: Certainly, madam. What kind of coffee do you want to have?
B: What have you got?
A: Well. We have espresso, latte, skinny latte, fancy coffee and Americano.
B: I think I'll have a latte, please.
response: A: OK . Wait a minute , please . And the sugar is right over there .

dialogue: A: I'm not looking forward to the English lesson tomorrow.
B: Why not?
A: Because the teacher has said that we're going to have a quiz.
B: But you had a test week, didn't you?
response: A: Yes, we did. That's why I'd love another one tomorrow,

dialogue: A: What do you usually do in your spare time?
B: I have joined a singing group and we practice two afternoons each week.
A: That's a very interesting thing to do.
response: B: Yes. It's a small group of only fifteen girls and boys. But everybody has been late for the practice.

dialogue: A: Well, the salad's almost ready. How's the beef going? I'm starving.
B: So am I. The beef looks just about ready. Just one minute... ow!
A: What's the matter?
B: Oh, my finger, I burned my finger!
A: Oh, wait, I'll get some ice and put it on your finger.
B: OK.
A: There.
B: Ah, ah, much better. The ice really works.
A: How does it feel?
response: B: Oh, I feel panicked. Thanks. Let's eat.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
response: B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some rest instead of taking the bike all the time.

dialogue: A: What can I do for you?
B: It's about the new clerks you need for the offices. I'm wondering how many people you want to employ.
A: That depends on what you would like.
B: I think I'd need about 30 hours a week, including some Saturdays. What do you think?
A: That's what I was thinking too. We don't want someone who has never worked in the office before.
B: Yes. It might be helpful if one could speak a second language.
A: That might prevent too many people asking for the jobs. What about pay, David?
B: What do you think would be the best to offer?
response: A: I think it depends on a lack of experience. However, the lowest we could offer is about $ 9,000 per year.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jeanie. Why have you come to school an hour early?
B: I wanted to get a front row seat and review one more time before the test. Why are you here so early, Jack?
A: I get out of my car here this time every day. You seem to be nervous about your lessons. Have you finished your review?
B: I've only been studying night and day for the last week. If I don't get an A in this class, I won't get the support of my country.
A: This class is really just a review for me. I've been learning it for two years.
B: That's lucky for you.
A: Jeanie, can you guess what the test will be like? Will it be difficult?
response: B: I hope not. But I'm still confident about it.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
response: B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for myself.

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
A: I have to write you a ticket.
B: Can't you give me a warning?
A: I'm not going to be able to do that.
response: B: How much will the fine be?

dialogue: A: I'm not looking forward to the English lesson tomorrow.
B: Why not?
A: Because the teacher has said that we're going to have a quiz.
B: But you had a test week, didn't you?
response: A: Yes, we did. That's why I don't want another one tomorrow,

dialogue: A: Hello, Lucy. When are you going off to Beijing?
B: This evening.
A: How are you getting there, by air or by train?
B: By train. It leaves at 5:00 and arrives in Beijing at 7:10 tomorrow morning.
A: Oh, only 14 hours. Is anybody seeing you off this evening?
response: B: Yes, my parents are going with me to the station to see me off.

dialogue: A: Are you planning on voting?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, but this will be my first time voting.
B: Really?
A: Yes, and I have no idea how to do it.
B: Voting is simple.
response: A: I don ’ t know any of the questions they ’ re trying to pass.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?
B: Not yet. What happened?
A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
response: B: Yes, I heard the lights were on all night.

dialogue: A: Are you going somewhere for your vacation?
B: Yes, I'm making plans for a tour.
A: That'll be lovely. Where are you going?
B: I start out from Long Island this Friday. I've planned a four-day drive to Salt Lake Ciy, where I'll join my brother and my family for his fortieth birthday.
response: A: Well, you've got to prepare lots of food and one sleeping bag then?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
response: A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
response: B: I love green apples .

dialogue: A: Maggie, can I borrow your notes for history? I'll return them tomorrow.
B: Sorry, but I usually go to the cafeteria and review them. Why not copy them in the library?
A: OK.
B: Here you are.
A: You are a great help, Maggie.
B: I don't quite understand a why you need my notes, Mark? You haven't missed any classes.
A: To be honest, I work in supermarket from 7 to 10 o'clock every evening.
B: I see. So you're pretty tired when you come to class.
A: That's exactly why I want to borrow your notes. My notes aren't very good.
B: So what do you usually do in class?
A: I'm always awake at the beginning, but thirty minutes after class begins I feel sleepy and have trouble keeping my eyes open.
B: Well, I need someone to study with and you need someone to keep you awake. Can we be study partners?
response: A: Oh sure. That's a good idea. So just let me rest when you see me sleeping in class.

dialogue: A: Caroline Menzies speaking.
B: Could I speak to Diana Curzon?
A: I'm afraid she's in a meeting at the moment. Who's speaking?
B: This is John Laing from Dantons.
A: Can I take a message, Mr Laing?
B: Yes, please. I'm actually returning her call. So perhaps you could tell her that I called.
response: A: Certainly. Does she have your address?

dialogue: A: What class did you have this afternoon, Kate?
B: A chemistry class. We've got a new chemistry teacher this term.
A: Who is it?
B: James Black. He told us to call Jim, not to call him Mr. Black.
A: Oh, James Black. I know him. He's a little thin man who smiles a lot.
B: Yes, but many of us are afraid of him.
A: Really? But I hear he's a very good teacher.
response: B: Yes, he is. His classes are always dull and boring. And we all watch and listen to him very carefully in his class.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
A: Have you thought about camping?
B: Camping? I've never done that.
A: I think you'll really like it. You can rent the equipment you need.
B: Is it cheap?
response: A: Yeah, much more expensive than buying or staying at the hotel.

dialogue: A: Dad, I need a few supplies for school, and I was wondering if...
B: Yeah. There are a couple of pencils and an eraser in the kitchen drawer, I think.
A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
B: Oh, so you need a ruler, too?
A: Dad, I need some high tech stuff like a calculator and a laptop computer.
B: Uh. I didn't have any of that when I was in middle school, and I did just fine.
A: Yeah, and there weren't any cars either. Things are a lot more progressive now.
B: Great. My daughter will be playing video games in class.
A: Dad.
response: B: Okay. How much are these things going to frustrate me?

dialogue: A: Good morning, is this Ryan?
B: You are speaking with Ryan. How can I help you?
A: Ryan, this is Malia, and I need to call in sick today.
B: What seems to be the problem?
A: I went hiking and have terrible poison oak.
B: When did you get that?
A: I think I got it on Saturday, but it just showed up today.
B: What are you doing for it?
A: The doctor prescribed an ointment and gave me a shot.
response: B: Good . You probably should be much better by tomorrow .

dialogue: A: Are you planning on voting?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, but this will be my first time voting.
B: Really?
response: A: Yes, and I have no idea how to do it.

dialogue: A: What class did you have this afternoon, Kate?
B: A chemistry class. We've got a new chemistry teacher this term.
A: Who is it?
B: James Black. He told us to call Jim, not to call him Mr. Black.
A: Oh, James Black. I know him. He's a little thin man who smiles a lot.
B: Yes, but many of us are afraid of him.
A: Really? But I hear he's a very good teacher.
B: Yes, he is. His classes are always lively and interesting. And we all watch and listen to him very carefully in his class.
A: It's important to watch carefully when you're studying chemistry, I think.
response: B: Jim often says that too, So we are never allowed to do anything without watching.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for myself.
A: Oh? Did you talk with her about it?
response: B: I've tried, but it didn't work.

dialogue: A: Can I collect unemployment benefits?
B: Are you still working?
A: My employer cut back on my hours.
B: If you got laid off or are working a lot fewer hours, you may qualify.
A: Do I definitely get to collect unemployment?
B: Not all jobs pay into unemployment insurance, so their employees cannot collect benefits.
A: How do I check out my status to collect unemployment?
response: B: You should have noticed unemployment insurance being deducted from your invoices. Check your invoices.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the General Reading Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.
A: It doesn't matter. I just want to refer to it for some figures. Where is it?
B: Go out of this building, cross the sports field, and you will see a white house. The General Reading Room is inside it.
response: A: No wonder! It's not here! Thank you very much.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
response: A: Your son's very unlucky. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.

B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?
A: Well, no. I don't think I would. I bet it costs a lot of money. Does it say how much it costs?
B: Yes. The early black-and-white ones cost several hundred pounds. But the one is about costs several thousand pounds.
A: Hum. Why does anybody want one, do you think?
response: B: Business organizations that need to frequently contact overseas organizations would want it. It's like a face-to-face conversation. So maybe a lot of overseas travel can be arranged.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
A: Are you renting it alone or with company?
B: I'll share it with one of my friends. What ’ s in a one-bedroom apartment?
A: A one-bedroom apartment has one bedroom, a living room, a kitchen and a bathroom.
B: Is there any furniture?
A: No, but a fridge and a stove.
B: It sounds wonderful. Do I have to sign a lease? How much should I pay?
response: A: Yes , it ’ s a one-year lease . And $ 200 a week with no deposit .

dialogue: A: Are you ready to order now, sir?
B: Yes, please.
A: What would you like to have for your appetizer, sir?
response: B: I would like an entire steak dinner please.

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
response: B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're too many hands at present. Ten waitresses are here.

dialogue: A: After probation, you'll find that our silk products feels more comfortable than others.
B: How about this product selling from last month on?
A: It's selling like hot cakes, and we have lots of regulars now. Would you like to place a trial order?
B: Am. Well, can I have a try of the sample free of charge?
A: Yes, we have the free samples for customers. And you can have a try.
B: Thank you. We'll order once we try the sample.
response: A: Please wait a moment and fill out the order form. And we'll send you our sample.

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
response: A: I have to write you an invitation to my wedding.
