dialogue: A: Are you alright, child?
B: Hey, I still know my name.
A: What did the nurse say?
B: She said I have a fever but nothing major.
response: A: In that case, you should go home and get plenty of rest.

dialogue: A: Are you busy with your work?
B: Yes. What about you?
A: Yes, I'm very busy, too. Sometimes I work overtime.
B: Then your salary must be high.
response: A: Just so so. But we can travel twice every decade.

dialogue: A: We're having a picnic tomorrow. Why don't you come with us?
B: I'd like to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman says so.
A: I don't think he is right. It hasn't rained for a week and it isn't cloudy, either.
response: B: But he is usually unintelligible in his weather news.

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
A: No, I don't. I mean a general practitioner. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.
response: B: Really, I believe I can quit on my own. But I'll think about it. I will.

dialogue: A: This is Jack speaking. Who is this?
B: This is Jenny, Jack. Could you help me?
A: Certainly. What is the matter?
B: My sister had an argument with me yesterday because I lost her lovely pet cat. She was really mad at me. And she hasn't talked to me for a whole day.
A: Oh, Jenny. In fact, you're the one who made a mistake.
B: Yes, I know that. But what should I do to make her happy?
response: A: If I were you, I'd buy her a new phone. She'll forget all about the cat then.

dialogue: A: Your father and Sally have gone to get the car. Let's wait for them here on the bench.
B: It's nice to sit down. We've been walking for hours.
A: Did you like the White House?
B: Oh, yes. I thought it was beautiful. I wanted to stay longer.
A: I did, too. But we've got a lot of things to see.
B: The line wasn't long this morning, was it?
A: No, it wasn't. We were lucky.
B: I wonder if the president and his family use the rooms we saw. They look more like a museum than somebody's house.
A: Yes. They are the public rooms. The President's family lives upstairs.
B: What do they use the public rooms for?
A: For important affairs. The President usually entertains members of the government and visitors from other countries.
B: I hope I could get a reception at the White House some time.
response: A: Well, if you do something ordinary and mundane when you grow up, maybe you will. Who knows?

dialogue: A: Great. My favorite-soup, soup, soup...
B: Oh, and there's one more thing you have to do every hour on the hour, sweets.
A: Blow my nose?
B: Well, you do that when your nose needs blowing. I was talking about a way to make your throat heal faster.
A: No, please, Mom! Don't make me gargle with saltwater!
response: B: It works better than any medicine , Lily . I'll make you a glass right now , and you'll finish it !

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few days after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?
B: Well, it hurts so much, doctor, especially when I eat.
A: I understand, Mrs. Jackson. It hurts in the beginning, I know. But it's really better to leave it in, except when you clean it of course.
B: Well, I did at first, doctor, but it hurt so much that I just couldn't stand it any longer.
response: A: Well, maybe we can pop it out of joint.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. White. I wonder if you could spare a few minutes. I'd like to ask you a few questions.
B: Well, I can spare you a few minutes, but I'm very busy preparing for our exhibition, you know.
A: Just a few questions. Where is it going to be held?
B: It's going to be held in the art gallery.
A: Who is opening it?
B: It's going to be opened by Mr.Smith.
A: It's quite a big exhibition, isn't it?
response: B: Quite small. Some very tiny sized paintings will be shown.

dialogue: A: What are you going to have for breakfast?
B: I just have some cereal each morning.
A: You're supposed to always have a hearty breakfast.
B: I don't always have time to make breakfast.
A: It's easy to make a quick breakfast.
B: What do you have for breakfast?
response: A: When I need to make a quick late-night snack , I just make some oatmeal , toast , and OJ .

dialogue: A: Wake up. It's almost eight o'clock.
B: No, please. Let me sleep on! I couldn't get to sleep until 3 o'clock this morning.
A: Why? What's wrong with you?
B: I felt pain all over my body. Can you get me some medicine?
response: A: Will aspirin do?

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
B: Not really. But when I was home, I had to start typing a literature paper that was due first thing in the morning.
A: Couldn't you do it today?
response: B: Yes, our professor said she wouldn't accept any late papers.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Burt's Bicycle Rental.
B: Good morning, Miss. A friend of mine suggested I call you to hire some bikes.
A: Oh, yes. A lot of people do this these days.
B: Yes, we're just on holiday here for a few days and they said it would be a good idea to see the island by bicycle.
A: Well, it certainly is. And most people rent a motor bike because you can get around faster and even go to the beach if you like.
response: B: If I wanted to hire 2 motor bikes tomorrow morning for 20 months, would there be any problem?

dialogue: A: Hi, David. I haven't seen you for ages. How are you getting along with your work?
B: Hi, Susan. Not so well as to be expected. I've left my position. I can't bear the rudeness of my boss any longer.
A: What are you going to do then?
response: B: No idea.  Anyway, I'm done thinking about it.  And you?

dialogue: A: Would you like some dessert now, Miss?
B: I'd like to see the menu again, please.
A: Here you are, Miss. The chocolate cake is delicious.
B: No, thanks. I don't like chocolate. I'd rather have a pineapple pie.
A: I'm afraid there isn't any more today.
B: Then I'd like to have an apple pie.
A: I'm sorry, but that's gone, too.
B: How about some fresh fruit?
A: We don't have any fresh fruit today. All we have now is chocolate cake.
response: B: Then I just have a gallon of coffee, please.

dialogue: A: Dad, can I go to a movie this week with Shannon?
B: Let me look at the calendar here. Hmm. When are you thinking about going to a movie?
A: Uh, we're thinking about seeing a movie on Wednesday after school.
B: Well, that's not going to work. You haven't practiced your piano at all for an entire week, so you have to catch up on that.
A: What about Friday?
B: Uh uh. Forget that idea.
A: And Saturday?
response: B: Well, you have to take an English class in the morning. And then, we have to clean out the garage. You said you'd help. Well, that should only take a couple of hours. So then, before that, you can go to the movie.

dialogue: A: Lily, don't you think the scholarship from New York University is something great? Why did you decline this offer?
B: I do realize the value of the scholarship. But, if I could explain, my mother doesn't want me to go overseas.
A: Why?
B: You know, I'm the only child in the family. My mother will be living alone most of the time for three years in my absence. She cannot even think of it.
A: Nobody to take care of her?
response: B: My father travels a lot to many countries and he is doing business in Dubai now. I have to do a lot for my mom at home.

dialogue: A: Have you seen that house?
B: Yes, it looks interesting.
A: You're right. I love it very much.
B: It must be old.
response: A: At least more than 100 years old .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Could I be of any service to you?
B: Have you got any Chinese paintings?
A: Yes, we have landscape paintings, figure paintings and flower-and-bird paintings.
B: I'd like a flower-and-bird painting.
A: Good. How about this picture of cranes with pine trees? It was painted by a famous Chinese painter in King Dynasty.
B: Oh, they look just like live cranes. I like this picture very much. How much is it?
response: A: One dollar.

dialogue: A: Good afternoon, madam. I'm doing some market research and I'm hoping you might have a few minutes to answer some questions.
B: Okay, sure.
A: Great, thank you very much. First of all, do you own a personal computer?
B: Of course! Doesn't everyone?
A: How long have you owned it?
response: B: I bought this particular device last year. But I bought my first camera in 1995.

dialogue: A: It's Alice's birthday tomorrow.
B: Are you sure? I think it should be the day after tomorrow.
A: Well, let me see. Oh, I'm sorry. You're right. It is the day after tomorrow. Shall we buy her a present?
B: Yes, of course. Shall we give her some flowers?
A: Flowers are lovely. But I think it's better to buy her a nice box of chocolates.
B: Alice doesn't like sweet things. Didn't you know that?
A: You're right. Er... I know. We can give her a record. She loves music.
response: B: That's a good idea. Let's go to the music shop and record one for her.

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
A: Are you renting it alone or with company?
B: I'll share it with one of my friends. What ’ s in a one-bedroom apartment?
A: A one-bedroom apartment has one bedroom, a living room, a kitchen and a bathroom.
B: Is there any furniture?
response: A: No , but a bed and a dresser .

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, well, I bought this tie last week for my husband's birthday, and er...well he doesn't like it. Could I change it for something else, such as a shirt or a hat?
A: Certainly, madam, provided that it hasn't been worn, and if you have the receipt.
B: Yes, here it is.
response: A: OK, er... this tie looks as if it were worn. I'm afraid I can easily put that back on the shelf

dialogue: A: Are you aware of the reason why I pulled you over?
B: No, sir.
A: I pulled you over because your brake light is out.
B: I'm sorry. I did not know that.
response: A: I have to write you a speeding ticket.

dialogue: A: Come to my office, Billy. Look at your messy hair. This is the third time you have been late for class within this week. And every time you went in, you disturbed the teacher's class.
B: Sorry, Miss. I didn't mean to do that, but it was my alarm clock that didn't wake me up.
A: That is not a proper excuse. You could set it ahead of the exact time so that you could have got up earlier and not have been late.

B: I did that, but it seemed useless when I found the batteries had run out after I woke up this morning. I rushed to school and luckily, my neighbour Mr. Green gave me a hand and took me to school with his car.
A: So you could have made it. But you were still late for class.

B: The thing is, when I got off, I found I had left my bag in his car. And it was too late to get it back when I realized that. I went straight to the nearest shop and gave him a call. I waited for five minutes before Mr. Green drove back.
response: A: Finally, he gave you your bag and you came to the classroom and you were already 30 minutes early for class at that time. Is that all?

dialogue: A: After probation, you'll find that our silk products feels more comfortable than others.
B: How about this product selling from last month on?
A: It's selling like hot cakes, and we have lots of regulars now. Would you like to place a trial order?
B: Am. Well, can I have a try of the sample free of charge?
A: Yes, we have the free samples for customers. And you can have a try.
B: Thank you. We'll order once we try the sample.
response: A: Please wait a moment you don't need to fill out the order form. And we'll send you our sample.

dialogue: A: When can we expect you for dinner? Can you come tonight?
B: Not tonight. I promised to go to a concert with my sister.
A: Well... How about Friday then?
B: That sounds fine.
A: Good. Shall we say seven o'clock?
B: I'll be there. You're still a fabulous cook, aren't you?
A: That'll be for you to decide. I've got a new dish that I want to try out on you.
response: B: I'm ready . I'll look forward to it all Friday !

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. Is it true you're moving to London?
B: Yes, it is.
A: What made you decide to do that?
B: Work, mainly. I'm sure I'll be able to find a job there.
response: A: You're probably right. But where are you going to work?

dialogue: A: Ah, ah, ah...
B: All right, Bill.Here ' s your daily exercise schedule. You are to jog before breakfast.
A: Jog?
B: Then, you are to walk to work.
A: Walk?
response: B: Thirty minutes in gym at lunch time.

dialogue: A: Did you start your new job this week?
B: Yes, I did. I started it the day before yesterday.
A: How do you like your new job? And how about your boss?
B: Well, it's demanding, but it's very interesting. The boss seems to be very considerate. It is said that he is kind and friendly to the employees.
response: A: So you really despise the job, don't you?

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
response: B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit sort of hands at present. Two waitresses are ill.

dialogue: A: Do you have a driver's license?
B: No. I am going to take the test in a couple of weeks.
A: Didn't you drive in your own country?
B: Yes. But I have to be more skilled.
response: A: And you have to study the traffic rules too.

dialogue: A: Are you going to the party on Saturday?
B: I was thinking about it. Are you?
A: Yeah, I heard it's going to be a lot of fun.
B: Really? Well, what time does it start?
A: It starts at 8
B: Well, who all is going to be there?
A: Everyone from school.
B: How do you know it's going to be so fun?
response: A: This party is not going to have a DJ, food, and drinks.

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
response: B: We thought we'd have that at head office and use the football stadium, because there is enough room for everyone there.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
response: B: Thanks , they are rather attractive . But I think there is nothing better than seeing things when they're out of operation.

dialogue: A: You wanted to see me, Mr Strunk?
B: Yes, Lorraine,I did. I'd like to talk to you for a moment. I'm very pleased with your work.
A: Thank you, Mr Strunk. I like to do my best.
B: I've certainly noticed. You're a very good employee. All your assignments are finished in a timely manner, and you're a team player.
A: Well, Mr Strunk, I enjoy my work very much.
response: B: To show that I appreciate all your efforts, I'm going to fire you. I hope you don't object.

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent three hours on it.
A: By the way, what time did you go home?
B: I left the office at nine o'clock. I got home at ten.
A: What did have for dinner?
response: B: I sent out for a sandwich and ate at my desk.

dialogue: A: Why don't you sit down? Now, there are several questions I must ask you if you don't mind.
B: Not at all. Go ahead.
A: What is the purpose of your visit to the States?
B: I'm going to attend a conference on air pollution.
A: When and where is this conference being held?
B: It's being held in the first two weeks of February at the University of Stanford in California.
response: A: Who will wash your clothes?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few days after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?
B: Well, it hurts so much, doctor, especially when I eat.
A: I understand, Mrs. Jackson. It hurts in the beginning, I know. But it's really better to leave it in, except when you clean it of course.
B: Well, I did at first, doctor, but it hurt so much that I just couldn't stand it any longer.
response: A: Well, maybe we can set it a little more.

dialogue: A: Hello, Tom. I haven't seen you for some time. How are you doing?
B: Oh! Not too bad. I have been busy writing an article.
A: Really? Have you finished it?
B: Yes. I finished it yesterday.
A: Congratulations! Are you doing something this evening?
B: No, nothing important. Why?
A: Well, do you feel like going to a concert? I have two tickets.
response: B: Oh. Good idea. I want to do something very engaging, and I like music very much.

dialogue: A: Have you taken the written test yet?
B: No, I haven't.
A: You should study before you take it.
B: I have been studying.
A: Why don't you take the test?
B: Do you know if it costs any money to take it?
A: Since you already paid for your permit, you don't have to pay again.
B: All right. Do you know if the test covers the whole book?
response: A: No , the test skips a lot of things in the book .

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: It's our anniversary today. I am looking for the same flowers as the ones in her wedding bouquet.
A: What do they look like?
B: White.
A: How tall are they?
B: They are short, I guess. About the same height as those short flowers over there.
A: Do they look like roses?
B: No, they look like little bells.
response: A: Oh , tulips . No , I am sorry . We are all out of those tall flowers right now .

dialogue: A: We've all heard the saying "Laughter is the best medicine." How important is it to our health, Dr. Berk?

B: This saying has been scientifically proven! A year-long study of heart attack victims done at the Oakhurst Health Research Institute in California found that of those patients who spent half an hour a day watching comedy videos, 10 percent had a second heart attack, whereas 30 percent of those who did not watch had a second attack.
A: Wow! Laughter is really a good medicine to patients. Can you give us another example?
B: Sure! Norman Cousins, editor of the Saturday Review, learned this during a battle with an illness. He discovered that his condition improved when he enjoyed himself and watched funny movies.
A: You said Norman learned this? Do we have to learn to laugh?

B: Not necessarily. Since laughing is something people can do sitting down, costs no money, and requires no special exercise equipment or skill, it's the perfect workout for anyone who doesn't have the time or desire to participate in a regular fitness program.
A: Oh. Do you have such a program to offer to the general public?

B: Yes, we do. It's called the Smile Time-Out. You take a deep breath, smile, exhale, and say "Aaah" while visualizing all your muscles and cells smiling. Then add to that a memory of a time you felt really good and laughed and laughed.
A: What about the situation in which you aren't in a mood to laugh?
response: B: Even when you give a sincere smile or laugh, you get the same physiological benefits as when it's the real thing, because your mind is smart, but your body is stupid and can't tell the difference!

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
B: Well, there's a coffee shop on the next corner. It serves good food.
A: OK. I'll try it. Can I get you something?
B: No, I think I'll come with you. I'm longing for a nice salad.
A: Do you often have lunch at this coffee shop?
response: B: No, I usually bring my lunch from my desk and eat at home.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Are you waiting to buy today's film tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: Have you been here long?
response: B: About 45 minutes. I've moved forward a total about 3 feet.

dialogue: A: Are you going home now?
B: No, I'm not.
A: What are you going to do? Are you going to work late?
B: No, I'm not. I'm going to look for an apartment.
A: An apartment? Why?
B: I'm going to try to find a place near the office.
A: Where are you living now?
B: Out in the suburbs. It's a long trip to work every day.
A: How are you going to find an apartment?
response: B: I'm going to buy a children's story book and check the classified ads.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam.
B: Good morning. I wonder if you can help. I've lost my coat.
A: Where did you lose it, madam?
response: B: Er... I purchased it yesterday morning.

dialogue: A: Good morning, this is Ann broadcasting from university radio and in the studio we have Robin, president of the Martha Bicycle Club with us.
B: Good morning, everyone.
A: Robin, can you tell us what the mountain lake cycle tour is all about?
response: B: Well, Ann, the tour today is a race. People do it solely to try to better their time every year.

dialogue: A: Good evening, sir, ma'am. A table for two?
B: No, thank you. But we have a small problem. Can you help us?
A: Sure.
response: B: We are looking for a hotel. Are there any hotels near here?

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?
B: Well, I've got a lot of work to do. I ought to stay at home and study, really.
A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?
A: There is nothing on that I want to see.
B: Oh, all right. Well, we could rent a video and watch that.
response: A: Neither of us has a video player.

dialogue: A: Am I late?
B: No, you've got an hour and a quarter. Your flight leaves at 9:30.
A: I'm so excited.
B: Have you got everything?
response: A: Yes, my concert tickets and my pay checks.

dialogue: A: Did you get the injury playing football, Jim?
B: Yes. One of the boys kicked my foot instead of the ball.
A: The best thing for you to do is to rest your leg for 48 hours.
B: When can I go back to school?
response: A: You can go back this afternoon, but you'll need to avoid sports until tomorrow.

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit sort of hands at present. Two waitresses are ill.

A: All right, but that's no excuse. My husband asked for goose and he was brought chicken instead. It's just unbelievable! And my beans weren't cooked properly. It wasn't a very enjoyable meal at all.
B: This is most regrettable.
response: A: Look at this bill. We've been overcharged. We only had one dessert, not two. Can you check the bill again, please?

dialogue: A: Hi, Jenny. Is it true you're moving to London?
B: Yes, it is.
A: What made you decide to do that?
response: B: Pets, mainly. I'm sure I'll be able to find a job there.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mr. Tim. It's a long time since I had the pleasure of a visit from you.
B: Yes, it must be three or four years. I haven't visited you since I called about my will. You helped me with that, you remember?
A: Yes, I remember. Do you want to make any changes in your will?

B: I don't think that will be necessary, but you'll tell me if it is. I left everything, you remember, to my wife, and, after her death, to my son Jerry. I've about $ 15 000 in shares of industrial companies. These bring in, after paying tax, about $ 1 125 a year. Well, I'm earning a good salary now, and I shall get a good pension from my employers, so my wife and I can live fairly comfortably with this extra income. I want to buy some land and build a house for my son. It's time he get married, and he needs a house. I'm thinking of building one and giving it to him.
A: Your son's fortunate. So you want my help buying the land and building the house.
B: Yes, that's right. As soon as you've done what's necessary for buying the land, Jerry and I will see an architect.
A: Have you found a plot yet?
B: Jerry was in Edinburgh last Saturday and saw a plot he likes. My wife and I went there two days ago, and we liked it, too. I'd like you to make the necessary inquiries for me.
response: A: I'd be dreading having to do that. I shall have to write to the Local Authority and inquire whether it is allowed to build a house on your piece of land. You're not even allowed to build a house without permission from the Planning Authority! And sometimes the Authority decides that a house must be built of stone, and not of brick, so that it doesn't spoil the surrounding village.

dialogue: A: Hello, I need to come in and see the doctor.
B: Are you scheduling a check-up, or are you ill?
A: I have really itchy skin and think I may have to have it looked at.
B: Have you been feeling any joint aches with that rash?
A: No, but I have a low fever.
B: I have times available for Tuesday or Wednesday. Which one would work best for you?
A: I want to come in on Wednesday.
B: I can fit you in on that day at 10
A: I would prefer Dr. Smith.
response: B: You can see the doctor of your choice then, and we will see you whenever you want.

dialogue: A: Hi, Ben, we're having a party tonight. Do you want to come and join us? You can bring your girlfriend.
B: Well, actually, Camilla and I are breaking up.
A: What happened? Did you have an argument?
B: No. She is really a very nice girl.
A: Yeah, she is. She is pretty, caring, and easy-going. And she's a great cook!
B: Well, you are right. But sometimes she's too caring... well, no... she's just possessive... and... a kind of control, you know... I need some space for myself.
A: Oh? Did you talk with her about it?
B: I've tried, but it didn't work.
A: Oh, so, when are you going to tell her?
B: Maybe tonight. I don't know. I don't know how to tell her.
response: A: I know she is head over heels in love with you. She'll be badly hurt!

dialogue: A: My mother got really annoyed with my father yesterday evening.
B: Why? Did she complain about his cooking?
A: Oh no. It was about watching television.
response: B: Don't tell me he fell asleep in front of the television.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
B: Oh, she can't help you either. She's making a phone call now.
A: Oh? Who's she calling?
B: She's calling her boyfriend.
A: Then where is Jack? Can I ask for help from him?
B: He hasn't been home yet...Why? You're asking a lot of questions tonight, Paul.
response: A: Am I?...Well, I'm practicing my musical skills.

dialogue: A: Hey, Karen, it looks like you've got some sun this weekend.
B: Yeah, I guess so. I spent the weekend at the beach.
A: Oh, yeah, that's great. Where did you stay?
B: Some friends of my parents' live out there and they invited me for as long as I wanted to stay.
A: So what are you doing back here already?
response: B: Oh, I have a paper to work on, and I just couldn't do any serious studying at my house.

dialogue: A: Where do you want to go, Madam?
B: Hilton Hotel, please. Brrr! It's cold, eh? I'm freezing.
A: Come in. San Francisco is usually cold in winter, you know. It's often very rainy, which makes the weather colder and it sometimes....
B: Well, it gets very hot in summer, doesn't it?
A: Not really. It gets warm in July and August. That's the best time to visit the city. Uh, oh. Here comes the rain!
B: It's raining hard. By the way, how long does it take to reach the hotel, do you think?
response: A: About half an hour if there is no traffic jam. Would you like to listen to some light music?

dialogue: A: Hi, Lily. Great graduation party, isn't it?
B: Yes, everyone here is having a good time. Any ideas for the future?
A: Well, I'm interested in finance and my uncle runs a company in Hong Kong, so I decided to go to Hong Kong University.
response: B: Sounds great. Hong Kong is an international financial center. You will surely go far there.

dialogue: A: How come David is always so full of energy?
B: He has a strange but highly effective way of sleeping.
A: What is that?
B: He takes a short sleep for an hour every six hours and has a total of four hours of sleep each day.
A: Where did he get that strange idea?
response: B: He read flora a book which said it was the best way for human beings, and he believed it.

dialogue: A: How do you pay at the shops, Mary?
B: Why? By cash or card, of course.
A: Ever thought of your mobile phone?
B: Is it possible?
response: A: This time next year, perhaps. It's efficient. Everything is done in 0.2 second, to be exact.

dialogue: A: A lovely day, isn't it?
B: It is.
A: It seems it will be a fine all day.
B: I think it will be a dry day. There's hardly a cloud in the sky.
A: We'll have a heat wave in the afternoon. I'm afraid.
response: B: It's very cool today. No wind at alt.

dialogue: A: Excuse me, madam. I'm wondering if you could tell me the place where I can repair my shoes.
B: There's one on Fifth Street.
A: Thank you, but how far is it to that store?
response: B: Not very far and not difficult to find. Just keep walking and after two blocks you will see a supermarket on your left. The store is next to the supermarket.

dialogue: A: Welcome to Youth Hotel, can I help you?
B: I'd like a room for a night.
A: Would you like a single room, a double room or a room for three?
B: Oh, a single room please. Can I pay by check?
response: A: Sure, disregard this cash-payment form please.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
response: A: One moment while I go and apply for my ID .

dialogue: A: Good morning. Mrs.Smith.
B: Good morning! Can you help me, please? I'm looking for some books for my mother.
A: Well, what kind of books does she like?
B: She's very fond of detective stories?
A: I see. Has she read any detective stories?
B: Oh, yes!
A: Do you know if she's read this one?
B: I'm not sure, but she probably won't remember if she has! She's very forgetful!
A: Ah! She has a bad memory. How old is she?
B: She's eighty-seven.
response: A: I suggest you take this book . It's very exciting .

dialogue: A: Hi, Jack. Who are you writing to?
B: I'm writing to my parents telling them I'll stay here this summer.
A: You're not going home? I thought you were going on a trip to Japan with your family.
B: Well, I intended to go with them, but I thought again and changed my mind.
A: Tell me. I'm interested in knowing what keeps you from joining your beloved family and staying here. It certainly is not studying.
response: B: No, certainly not. Michael arranged for me to study at his uncle's institution.

dialogue: A: Have you had enough time to look over the menu?
B: Yes, we are almost ready to order.
A: Let me remind you of the specials of the day, which are posted on the board.
B: Oh, that all sounds so good! Can we get the sauce on the side?
A: Yes, we would be happy to prepare the food to meet your special needs.
B: I was wondering if you have any vegetarian choices.
A: Yes, the roasted vegetable salad is good, and the portabella mushroom burger is also a good choice.
B: I think that I would like to order the broccoli noodles, please.
A: That is an excellent choice, and I could bring you your salads now or bring them with your dinner.
response: B: Please bring our salads to us now . We are hungry !

dialogue: A: And anything to drink?
B: Yes, a red wine and a cup of coffee.
A: How do you like your coffee?
response: B: With milk but without sugar, please.

dialogue: A: Don't tell me you're studying for another exam!
B: That's exactly what I am doing.
A: What subject is it this time?
B: Biology, and it's going to be a hard one.
A: Don't you get tired of studying all the time?
response: B: Yes, I do. But I would never want to throw all of them right out of the window.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
response: A: You can ask someone that can't switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kevin. How is it going?
B: Ah, not so great.
A: What's wrong?
B: I've got a big problem with the Shakespeare course which is required for my major.
A: Is that all filled up?
B: No, there's plenty of room, but I have to take the starter course before I can take Professor Miller's Shakespeare course. It is only offered in the evening.
A: You don't like evening classes?
B: That's not the point. I work in the cafe every evening. I need the money to pay my tuition.
A: You can ask someone that could switch hours with you. Maybe just switch a couple of evenings since the course probably only meets two times a week.
response: B: I'm more than happy to. My boss just did me a favor by putting me on evenings. And he'll hit the ceiling if I ask to change again.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Is there anything I can do for you?
B: I would like to buy two bottles of brandy.
A: How about this one? It's the special local product.
B: Can I buy these tax free?
response: A: Yes . This is a duty-free shop .

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Do you know where I can find a pay phone?
B: There is one around the corner.
A: Can I make an international call from that pay phone?
response: B: Yes, but you have to get a satellite dish first.

dialogue: A: Hi, John.
B: Oh! Hi, Laura. What are you doing here?
A: Uh, I'm usually here on weekends. It's my uncle's shop. So you are looking for a bike?
B: Yeah. Now that the weather is warming up, I thought I should get some exercise instead of taking the bus all the time.
A: Well, that's a good idea and you come to the right place. Do you know what you like?
B: Well, I don't want a racer or a touring bike or anything like that. Mostly I'll just be using it to get me back and forth from work.
A: How far is that?
B: About four miles.
A: Are there a lot of hills on the way?
B: Some, I guess. But maybe I should tell you at first that I only got 150 dollars. Can I get anything decent for that?
A: Well, you are not going to get anything on the top of the line. But we do have a few trade-ins in the back that are in good condition.
B: That sounds good.
response: A: And you are right. For the kind of ride you are going to be doing, the most important thing is to maximize pain. You want to make sure it's the right height for you? Follow me and I'll show you what we've got.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Are you waiting to buy today's film tickets?
B: Yes, I am. So are all these people in front of me.
A: Have you been here long?
response: B: About 45 minutes. I've moved forward a total of 500 miles.

dialogue: A: Hi, why do you look so depressed today, Mike?
B: I had a terrible quarrel with my neighbor yesterday.
A: How come?
response: B: It is a long story . Basically , she and I had a great time.

dialogue: A: Good morning.
B: Good morning. Er, I'm phoning about the job that was in the paper last night.
A: Oh, yes. Could you tell me your name?
B: Oh, Jerry Lynn.
A: Well, what exactly is it that interests you about the job?
B: I just thought that it was right up my street, you know.
A: Really? Could you tell me a little about yourself?
B: I've been working abroad doing secretarial work. Previous to that I was at university. I've got a degree in English.
A: Do you have any special skills?
response: B: Well, I'm terrible at speaking foreign languages.

dialogue: A: Do you know much about computers?
B: Not a great deal. Why?
A: I've been reading an article about computers. They are strange and are being used for almost everything.
B: Yes. But have you learned how to use one?
A: No. But I'm about to take a course on computers next term.
B: That's good. You have to know about computers. Computer knowledge is a must whatever you do. You should learn quickly or you will be left behind.
A: That's true. But first I want to learn the basics. In the library, there are computers. But it's a pity that I could not make use of them.
B: Well, I can teach you the ABCs, if you like.
response: A: That's very kind of you.

dialogue: A: Hi, Mark. Are you in town for another job interview?
B: Yes, I'm pretty hopeful this time. I've just finished my second interview with this company.
A: That sounds great. I hope it works out for you. But wasn't it expensive just getting here?
B: No, in fact the company is paying all my expenses. They've put me up in a hotel downtown.
A: How nice! How many people are they interviewing?
B: They interviewed 16 the first time, and now four of us were chosen to go back for this interview.
A: Well, I hope it goes well. John and I would love it if you came to this area to work.
response: B: I would too. But my girlfriend wants to leave her family. She hopes I find a job close to this area.

dialogue: A: Charlotte, have you had your supper?
B: No, I don ’ t want to eat anything.
A: Why? Don't you feel well?
B: I ’ m down in spirits.
A: What's up?
B: My manager jumped on me for my mistake today.
response: A: You must not feel depressed about such a trivial thing.

dialogue: A: Caroline Menzies speaking.
B: Could I speak to Diana Curzon?
A: I'm afraid she's in a meeting at the moment. Who's speaking?
B: This is John Laing from Dantons.
A: Can I take a message, Mr Laing?
response: B: Yes, please. I'm actually returning my dad's call. So perhaps you could tell her that I called.

dialogue: A: Have any plans for the weekend, Tom?
B: Yeah, I ’ m going for a hike in the southern Rocky Mountains.
A: Oh, do you go hiking often?
response: B: I go as much as I can . I love hiding and seeking because you can really get in touch with nature .

dialogue: A: Did you hear what Fred did last night?
B: No,not yet. What happened to him?
A: I guess he was a little drunk and he had a fight with his brother. Well, he got so mad that he drove his car straight into the front of a drugstore.
B: What do you mean?
A: I mean he drove inside. The front of the store was completely destroyed. I actually saw it just now as I walked by. The car is still inside the store.
B: I'm afraid Fred is in trouble. Where is he now?
response: A: I hear he's in the car. It's lucky no one was hurt.

dialogue: A: Good morning, madam. I'd like to apply for a library card. Can you help me?
B: Yes. Please give me your ID card, a photo.
A: OK. Here you are.
B: Then you have to give me 15 dollars for the deposit. The library card is free.
A: OK. Here is the money. And If I return the card, can I get the refund?
response: B: Of course, as long as the card is in poor condition.

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
A: You mean you know how to farm?
B: Yes. I did that every summer during holidays.
A: I didn't know that a city boy can do farm work. Can I go there with you? I'd like to learn to do some farming.
B: Sure, my grandparents would be very happy to see you.
A: Are you sure?
response: B: I'm sure. They are very kind but totally reclusive people.

dialogue: A: Did you finish typing that report?
B: Yes, I did, but I worked late.
A: But it must be a long report, I guess.
B: Exactly. Twelve pages. I spent three hours on it.
A: By the way, what time did you go home?
response: B: I left the office at nine o'clock. I got home at ten.

dialogue: A: Hi, honey. Do you need any help with your luggage?
B: No, thanks, dad. I just brought one carry-on in my backpack.
A: Great. I wish your mother would take some packing lessons from you. OK, let's go home.
B: Hm...It's cold here.
A: Yes, the weatherman says that it might snow tonight. What temperature was it when you took off from California this morning?
response: B: Sixty thousand degrees and sunny.

dialogue: A: Now, Mr White, did you see the accident clearly?
B: Oh, yes, I was standing outside my house.
A: Do you remember what time it happened?
B: Yes, it was 4: 30 by my watch.
A: Good. Now, was the truck going fast?
B: Yes. Well, perhaps the driver thought the light was changing to green. But it was red.
A: Are you sure, Mr. White?
B: Yes, absolutely sure.
response: A: Then the truck hit the taxi, did it?

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was killed in that bombing.
response: A: I'm sorry to hear that. War left many people favorite memories.

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
response: B: No, never. I want to mark my desk.

dialogue: A: Would you mind taking your feet off the desk, Bill?
B: Sorry, but I was very comfortable.
A: But do you put your feet on your own desk?
response: B: No, never. I don't want to mark my desk.

dialogue: A: Did you hear what Fred did last night?
B: No,not yet. What happened to him?
A: I guess he was a little drunk and he had a fight with his brother. Well, he got so mad that he drove his car straight into the front of a drugstore.
B: What do you mean?
response: A: I mean he drilled inside. The front of the store was completely destroyed. I actually saw it just now as I walked by. The car is still inside the store.

dialogue: A: Emily, what do you do as a trendspotter?
B: Very simple. Take digital photos of youth culture and send them to my company. It's called Look-Look.
A: What kind of company is it?
B: It's a youth culture marketing and trend forecasting firm in Hollywood. I'm one of Look-Look's 65,000 trendspotters worldwide.
A: Look-Look gets a lot of information about the ever-shifting tastes of the youth market by these images.

B: Yes, its clients are mostly companies. They get information about trends from Look-Look and develop their products. They also use the images of Look-Look on their websites to impress young people and promote their newly designed products.
A: But are there any people who don't like their pictures to be used on the website?
response: B: I always take my subject's pictures and put up their images onto Look-Look.com without consent.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
B: What for? For the party, of course.
A: Party? What party?
B: We ’ re having a Valentine ’ s Day Party.
A: Oh, I forget. Who ’ s invited?
B: We ’ Ve invited all our sophomore friends from school.
A: Can I help you get ready?
response: B: That ’ ll be a big help . Well , here ’ s a list of some of the Christmas gifts you could buy .

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
response: B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It fits perfectly.

dialogue: A: Are you packing for another trip?
B: Yeah. On Saturday, I'm flying to Toronto.
A: Is this another engineering conference for work?
B: No. I'm meeting with friends. But I earned so many miles by traveling for work that the ticket was free.
A: That's impressive. You fly a lot. I've only been on a plane a few times.
B: Really? Don't you travel with your dad?
A: No. He travels a lot because he is a banker,and he has an office in Japan. When he's working in New York, we take the train to visit him.
B: Oh, I thought you drove.
response: A: No, my mom dislikes my dad, even though the train is super relaxing.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. but I think you made a wrong turn. You are supposed to turn left on Rosen Boulevard.
B: Oh. I'm sorry. Didn't you say 1323 Willson?
A: No, 3023. It's OK though. You don't have to take me there, I can walk from here.
B: Why don't I just make a U turn at the corner?
A: Well, you shouldn't make a U turn there. It's the one-way, street. See the sign up the head?
B: Well, maybe if I turn left here I can comedown the next street,
response: A: You can't do that either during the lunch hour. Really though, don't go to any trouble. Sometimes one can wait 30 minutes for a taxi. So I'm happy to get this close,

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
A: I see. Would you be interested in seeing the audio-visual products? They are made by our company.
B: Thanks, they are rather attractive. But I think there is nothing better than seeing things In actual operation.
A: Yes, of course. Would you like to make an inspection tour of some factories?
response: B: Yes , very much , if it wouldn't add inconvenience to you . Third hand information is always more valuable than reading pamphlets .

dialogue: A: Mary, tomorrow is your mom's fiftieth birthday. Do you know?
B: Of course I do. How shall we celebrate it?
A: First of all a birthday present. What about buying her a beautiful skirt?
B: That's a good idea. It would make her look younger. And a big birthday cake too, with fifty candles.
response: A: That's right. Shall we have a special dinner?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
response: B: It's very far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.

dialogue: A: Hello, Ann! Is that you?
B: Yes, it is. Hi, Tom! It's a real surprise to see you here.
A: It's been a long time! What's new?
B: Nothing much. What about you? Is everything going well?
A: Not bad I guess. I just got back from Hawaii.
B: How was it?
A: I had a good time. You seem to be in a hurry. Don't let me hold you up.
B: Sorry, I've got a meeting in half an hour.
A: Ok, I won't keep you then.
B: Great! It's good to see you. Goodbye!
response: A: Yes , but we don't need to stay in touch . Bye !

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?
B: What's your problem?
A: I just can not find the right place here. I've never been here before.
B: You must be a freshman. What do you want anyway?
A: I want to find a book that I need for my term paper, but I cannot find it anywhere.
response: B: The library has five reading rooms. You may try the Video Game Room. You can find almost all the books there. But you can not take the book out of the reading room.

dialogue: A: Hi, David. I haven't seen you for ages. How are you getting along with your work?
B: Hi, Susan. Not so well as to be expected. I've left my position. I can't bear the rudeness of my boss any longer.
A: What are you going to do then?
B: No idea. Anyway, I've got to think about it seriously. And you?
A: I've been very successful as a dancer. I like this kind of life. It is so exciting.
B: You can't do that forever.
A: No. But I've decided to open a dance school once I've moved to the top. A lot of young dancers need better training.
response: B: That's a horrific idea.

dialogue: A: Do you have a plan for your holidays?
B: Yes. I'll go back to my hometown.
A: To see your grandparents?
B: Yes, and also do some farming.
response: A: You mean you don't know how to farm?

dialogue: A: Still feeling ill?
B: Yes. And that medicine hasn't helped. Not a good start to our vacation, I'm afraid.
A: Do you have any idea what caused it?
B: Well, I thought it might be last night's dinner.
A: But I am fine. Could it be the heat? It's enough to make anyone ill.
B: I know. But we've been here a week now. Anyway, I've been careful in the sun and I've been drinking bottled water.
response: A: Then we'd better stay in the hotel today.

dialogue: A: Would you like another piece of chicken?
B: Yes, please. It's delicious. Did you cook it in Qianmen. How about some sandwiches?
A: Oh, no. It's Kentucky Fried Chicken. I bought it in Qianmen. How about some sandwiches?
B: Well, just one, please. Hmm, it's nice! You bought them in Kentucky Restau-rant al- so, didn't you?
response: A: No, I did. Let me give you some more chicken. There's no more left.

dialogue: A: Hey, Louise, where can I get some lunch around here?
B: There are several places. What would you like to eat?
A: I'd really like a cheeseburger and some French fries.
response: B: Well, there's a vegetarian shop on the next corner. It serves good food.

dialogue: A: Hello! How can I help you, sir?
B: I want to take out a loan for school. What kind of interest rate do you offer?
A: Do you qualify for any of the Federal loan programs?
B: Yes, but I need to borrow some more money.
A: Well. In that case we can offer you a private educational loan.
B: What's the interest rate?
A: It's 7.2 %, fixed-rate loan.
B: How do I go about taking it out?
response: A: Just fill out this application . We can let you know right away if you qualify .

dialogue: A: Welcome to this idition of writers. Tonight we have Steven Das with us. Congratulations on your book. It's such a success.
B: Thank you.
A: This is your first time to that poetry? Did you ever try before? Did you ever take any classes in poetry?

B: Well. My only real experience was writing business plans. Other than that. I've experience. We're writing with concerned. I've always had the good grass of the writing with the English language. Thanks to my mom who studied my reading when I was very little.
A: What's the hardest thing that in the world?
response: B: Definitely finding the most obscure words to fit what I wanted to say.  They're always work word two that I might to rewrite if given the chance.

dialogue: A: Hello, Mrs. Taylor. Can you help me? I'm doing my homework and I can't understand this word.
B: Which one? Oh, I can't help you right away...I'm watching something on TV.
A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's reading.
A: What is he reading?
B: He's reading a magazine.
A: What about Kate?
response: B: Oh, she can't help you either. She just finished a phone call now.

dialogue: A: Good morning, Madam. Can I help you?
B: Yes, er...I want to see the West End.
A: How much time do you have?
B: Just one day.
A: Well, what do you particularly want to do?
B: I want to visit museums, art galleries, Buckingham Palace, do some shopping, and go to the theaters.
A: But you only have one day.
B: That's right.
A: Well. Why not do some shopping first?
B: Where can I do that?
A: In Oxford Street.
B: How can I get there?
response: A: You can walk through Hyde Park. It's quite near.

dialogue: A: Could I have a word with you, Madam?
B: Is that you, Janice? Just speaking.
A: I have to tell you that I can't be in today and tomorrow.
response: B: So sorry to hear that. What's wrong with you?

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
A: Did you go back home very late?
B: Not really. But when I was home, I had to start typing a literature paper that was due first thing in the morning.
A: Couldn't you do it today?
B: No, our professor said she wouldn't accept any late papers.
A: Then how did you manage it?
response: B: Well, I just turned my paper in, and now I'm headed to the library to study. See you!

dialogue: A: Discoveries is looking for a reporter to travel all over the world and write adventure articles.
B: Oh, it's a good job, I think.
A: So you are interested in working for Discoveries?
B: That's right. write adventure articles, but I'm sure I could. I've written lots of articles for a newspaper.
A: Oh? What newspaper have you written for?
B: Well, so far I've sold articles to the chicago Star and a few other newspaper.
response: A: Have you ever written an adventure article?

dialogue: A: Where were you yesterday?
B: I was at home asleep.
A: Asleep! I thought that you had to take an exam.
B: I was sick. I had a fever. I couldn't get out of bed.
A: You still look a little sick. You couldn't go back to bed.
B: I'm going now. I just came here to speak to my professor.
A: What did he tell you?
B: He said that I'd be able to take a make-up.
A: Well, that's all right then. Are you going straight home?
response: B: I have to stop at the bookstore on the way. I need some aspirin.

dialogue: A: Look! It's snowing. Winter is here at last.
B: It's really cold today.
A: Yes, you have to get used to it. The weather's going to be like this for the next three months.
B: Then I'm going to Florida. Can you tell me about your weather diary? Why do you make notes about the different types of weather?
response: A: Because it's redundant and useless to see what the weather is like at different times and on different days. For example, we had very boring weather on the 28th of April.

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
A: And you have a stomachache now?
B: Yes, I think so.
A: Can you walk to the school clinic? Or shall I send for the doctor?
response: B: No, thanks. It doesn't matter too much. I will go to the hardware store after class.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kangkang.
B: Hi, Jane.
A: What are you going to do this Saturday evening?
B: I'm going to a concert.
A: How exciting! Who is going to sing at the concert?
B: Xu Song. He is my favorite pop singer.
A: Where is he going to give the concert?
B: In the gym.
A: What time is it going to start?
B: At 7:30 p. m. Would you like to go with me?
response: A: I'd love to, but I'm not doing anything tonight.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
B: Yes, I want to deposit 1000 Yuan in my bank account.
A: Please fill out this deposit form, first.
B: OK... Here you are. Any problem on that?
A: No, that's fine. Do you bring your bankbook with you?
B: Yes, I do. Here it is, and the cash.
A: Wait a moment, please.
B: Sure.
A: Is there anything else I can do for you?
B: Yes. Can you tell me what the interest rate is now?
response: A: The deposit rate is 250 % every month .

dialogue: A: Are you ready for your big interview tomorrow?
B: What ’ s to get ready?
A: Lots! Have you done any research about the company?
B: Nope.
response: A: Have you updated your CV?

dialogue: A: Hello, I'm returning your phone call.
B: I'm glad that you could get back to me so fast.
A: No problem, but what were you calling about?
B: I needed to talk to you about your son.
A: Is he messing up in school?
B: He was acting up in class one day last week.
A: What was he doing?
response: B: He would mute it throughout the class

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir.
B: Good morning.
A: How do you want it, sir?
B: Just take a little off on the top and shorten the back. But please don't make it too short.
A: How about your sideburns?
response: B: Just to the bottom of my ears . By the way , I'd like a shave , too .

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
response: B: Yes, I do. It made me vomit a lot.

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Mary?
B: I am cooking the dinner, John.
A: Oh. Look! The Capital Building caught on a big fire today.
B: What? How about the people in the building?
A: More than 220 people were killed and the building was destroyed.
B: It must have taken the fire fighters a long time to put it out.
A: Yes, they spent about five hours putting it out. Hm, what a strange smell!
response: B: Oh, I forgot the food cooking on the fire!

dialogue: A: What can I do for you?
B: It's about the new clerks you need for the offices. I'm wondering how many people you want to employ.
A: That depends on what you would like.
B: I think I'd need about 30 hours a week, including some Saturdays. What do you think?
A: That's what I was thinking too. We don't want someone who has never worked in the office before.
B: Yes. It might be helpful if one could speak a second language.
A: That might prevent too many people asking for the jobs. What about pay, David?
B: What do you think would be the best to offer?
response: A: I think it depends on experience. However, the lowest we could offer is about $ 9,000 per year.

dialogue: A: Now some doctors are strongly encouraging arm exercises.
B: Arm exercises? Is that because arms are too fat or too soft?
A: Actually that's not the main reason. They say that arm exercises can make you physically healthy.
B: But I was told that arm exercises could raise your blood pressure.
A: Yes, but the article I read suggests some ways to make up for that.
B: Really? How?
response: A: By adding leg exercises, so that the arms don't do all the work.

dialogue: A: Hello, Louise. Have you seen my new supermarket yet?
B: Yes. I've heard of it actually. I suppose you must like it.
A: Yes, I mean it's marvelous.
B: Oh, Jeff. I really can't agree. I don't like it at all. My shop is much better.
A: You must be mad. I think it's really...you know...so easy to buy everything in one place.
B: Yes, it's easy. But don't you think the food isn't...I mean small shops usually have much fresher food.
A: Maybe, but you pay for it. Small shops are more expensive, aren't they?
response: B: Yes, I agree with you, but supermarket staff are badly paid and they are really...but you get better service in small shops. They are much less friendly, but more knowledgeable.

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
B: You can get wine and beer in most pubs. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.
A: When do people go to the pubs?
response: B: Pubs open 24 hours a day. They can't decide when to open. Most are open at lunchtime and again all night. Pubs may stay open from 11:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. Are there pubs in China?

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you tell me which is the way to the nearest shoe shop?
B: There's one on Queen's Road.
A: Thank you, but how can I get there?
B: It's not far from here. Walk along this road and after three blocks you'll see a post office on your right. The shop is just behind it.
A: How long do you think it will take me to get there?
response: B: About 20 hours at the most. Anyway, you can take the No.102 airplane.

dialogue: A: Today in the studio we have Alberto Cortez, the well-known Brazilian advocate of the anti-global movement. He's here to talk about the recent report, stating that by 2050 Brazil will be the one ot the word's wealthiest and most successful countries. Alberto, what do you say to the report?
B: You know this isn't the first time that people are saying Brazil will be a great economic power. The same thing was said over a hundred year ago. But it didn't happen.
A: Yes, but you must admit the world's a very different place now.
B: Of course. In fact I believe there's maybe some truth in the prediction this time around. First of all, though, we must remember the problems facing Brazil at the moment.
A: Such as...?

B: There's an enormous gap between the rich and the poor in this country. In Sal Paulo, you can see shopping malls full of designer goods right next door to the slam areas without proper water and electricity supplies. A lot of work needs to be done to help people in those areas improve their lives.
A: What needs to be done?
response: B: Education, for example. For Brazil to be successful, we need to offer housing to all Brazilians. Successful countries like South Korea and Singapore have excellent education systems. Brazil needs to learn from these countries.

dialogue: A: Gosh, another stop. It seems the cars ahead of us have to stop every two minutes, It's no quicker than a bus.
B: That's true. During rush hours, taxis are just as quick as buses.
A: It was silly of me to have taken a taxi.
B: At least, it can free you from the crowd. By the way, do you come from China?
A: No, from New Zealand, sir. I visited New Zealand and saw lots of overseas people there.
B: Wow, like America. It receives a great number of visitors every year.
response: A: The more the world becomes open , the more people become international !

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
response: A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a TV set. Some can be made smaller than a book.
A: Why is a computer so useful?
B: It can keep much information and work very fast.
A: Then they can do a lot of work for us.
response: B: You are right. They have greaty diminished our lives.

dialogue: A: What are you going to eat with your sandwich?
B: I think I'm going to eat a piece of fruit.
A: What kind do you like?
B: I really like apples and grapes.
A: What kind of apples do you like?
response: B: I love yellow bananas.

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
B: I need to review my English.
A: So that's what keeps you so busy recently!
response: B: Yes, I've had little problem with my studies. Now, what worries me the least is my English.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
response: B: Oh, No, I don't have a horse.

dialogue: A: Hello?
B: Hello. Is that Dr. Bean?
A: Yes, it is.
B: Dr. Bean, I'm making a survey for the National Research Company. I'd like to ask you a few questions about your health habits.
A: OK.
B: First question: How often do you take medicine?
A: I sometimes take aspirin, but that's all.
response: B: Do you take vitamins?

dialogue: A: David, why didn ’ t you clean the room?
B: I ’ m not in the mood.
A: Why are you feeling depressed?
B: I was told my girlfriend was speaking ill of me. That ’ s a real let-down.
A: I don ’ t think she will do such a thing.
response: B: But she did and made me happy.

dialogue: A: You look upset these days. Anything wrong?
B: Not really, I'm just worried about my daughter.
A: Oh, you mean Susan. Why? She's such a nice girl.
B: Yeah I know. But somehow she's become different recently.
A: In what ways? What has she done?
B: Oh, no, you don't really want to hear it.
A: Come on. I am a mother of two girls.
B: Ok. I'm worried because she often hides in her room and sends messages to her friends.
A: Come on. It's not a big deal. She needs friends at this age. You can talk with her if you are really concerned.
response: B: I guess so. Anyway, she is dressing up.

dialogue: A: Has the train come yet?
B: No, I ‘ Ve been waiting for ages.
A: It ’ s so unreliable. I ’ Ve been late for my meetings all this week.
B: Yes, me too. I think I ’ Ve lost some important clients recently because of this train!
response: A: Yes , my customers have started to recommend the trip too !

dialogue: A: Catherine, you look great in these photos.
B: Oh, thanks. I got into that wedding dress with great difficulty. It was too small.
A: Why didn't you get one your size?
B: Oh, it was my grandmother's - my mother wore it on her wedding day, and I really wanted to wear it on mine. I suffered for six months so I could wear it.
A: How did you do it?
response: B: Do you know this binge that many actors are doing?  I don't think it's very healthy if you do it for a long time, but it really works.

dialogue: A: Hello, I would like to apply for a permit.
B: Can I see your ID?
A: No, I left it in the car.
B: I'm going to need to see your ID and $ 27 for your permit.
A: One moment while I go and get my ID.
B: Make it quick.
A: Okay, here's my ID and the $ 27.
B: Thanks. Now fill this out.
response: A: Do you have a pen that I can use ?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Mrs. Wong. How are you? I haven't seen you around the building for the last couple of weeks. Is everything alright?
B: Morning, Mr. Jones. No, I haven't been out much recently. I've been feeling a bit under the weather.

A: I'm sorry to hear that. I hope you don't mind me saying, but you don't look very well. Your face is very pale. Perhaps you need some fresh air to bring the color back to your cheeks. It's a lovely day outside today.
B: That's just what I thought. I'm going to go for a walk in the park and then pop into the supermarket.
A: You look as if you've lost weight as well.
B: I haven't been eating like I usually do. Usually, I love my food, but these last two weeks I just haven't felt cooking and I've eaten very little. Most unlike me.
A: Have you been to the doctor? What did she say?
B: I didn't bother going to the doctor. It's nothing serious.
response: A: You never know. If you've been feeling like this for two weeks, it's worth getting checked out by a hottie just to be sure.

dialogue: A: Is there anything else that you would like to buy?
B: No, thank you. I guess that's it. By the way, in case there's a flaw in this CD player. Can I return it?
A: Yes. But you must return it within 30 days.
B: Is there a charge for that?I know other stores have a restocking fee.
A: There will be no charge at all.
B: I'm glad to hear that.
A: However,you must show us the receipt. Could you sign it here, please?
B: OK.
A: All right. Keep your receipt. If something comes up. you can show it to us and We'll give you a refund.
response: B: Thanks. I'll put it in the trash bin.

dialogue: A: Hello, I bought a China dress in your shop this morning.
B: Yes?
A: I bought one size up by mistake.
B: Oh, did you?
response: A: I wonder if you can change it to another size up?

dialogue: A: We seem to be having this conversation over and over again.
B: You're fight.
A: Look, I know how you feel about my smoking. You don't have to tell me every day.
B: I'm sorry. I worry about you.
A: Let's be honest. There's always going to be a reason. After you graduate, it's going to be hard to find a job, then there will be the stress from just starting a job.
B: OK, I get your point. It's just so hard. You don't really understand because you have never smoked.
A: You need some help. Why don't you go to a doctor?
B: You mean a psychiatrist?
A: No, I don't. I mean a general practitioner. Maybe you can get a patch, or some pills, well, I don't know, something to help you with the withdrawal.
response: B: Really, I don't believe I can quit on my own. But I'll think about it.

dialogue: A: Hi, Jim. I haven't seen you for a few weeks.
B: Oh, hi, Mary. I have been studying a lot for my final exam.
A: Well, this semester is about over now.
B: Yeah. My brother is coming for a visit this summer, and we'd like to see some of the country, but traveling is so expensive.
response: A: Have you thought about making campfire s'mores?

dialogue: A: Am I late?
B: No, you've got an hour and a quarter. Your flight leaves at 9:30.
A: I'm so excited.
B: Have you got everything?
A: Yes, my tickets and my traveler's checks.
response: B: and your car?

dialogue: A: Hello, is this Professor Clark?
B: Yes, I am Professor Clark.
A: Hello, Professor, this is Kalina, and I am in your literature class on Monday mornings.
B: Yes, how are you doing?
A: I was partying hard over the weekend, fell down the stairs, and need time to recuperate.
B: That sounds painful. Are you going to be OK?
A: I sprained my wrist, but the doctor says it will be fine.
B: How many days will you be out of school?
response: A: The doctor said I should be good enough to return this afternoon .

dialogue: A: What are you doing, Victor?
B: I ’ m making a list of food and drinks.
A: What for?
B: What for? For the party, of course.

response: B: We ’ re skipping Valentine ’ s Day .

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?
B: It was built in 1944.
A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.
A: But computers have become smaller, and worked faster now.
response: B: Yes. Most computers are as small as a closet. Some can be made smaller than a bookshelf.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir, can I help you?
B: Yes, I was wondering if you had the time to show me around this exhibition?
A: I'd be glad to, sir. But may I ask what line of business you are in?
B: I'm in the electrical appliances.
response: A: I see . Would you be interested in seeing the paper products ? They are made by our company .

dialogue: A: It seems you've burned yourself out.
B: Pardon. I'm afraid I didn't quite catch you.
A: You look tired. You must have overworked yourself.
B: Yes, a little bit. I've been hitting the books all these days.
A: Why have you been studying so hard?
B: I need to review my English.
A: So that's what keeps you so busy recently!
response: B: Yes, I've been tied up with my studies. Now, what worries me a lot is my English.

dialogue: A: Excuse me.
B: Yes?
A: I'm in a hurry. How long will it take?
B: About half an hour, if there's no traffic jam.
A: Do you think the traffic will be heavy?
B: I doubt it. It's not rush hour.
response: A: That's an annoyance.

dialogue: A: Why are you interested in our company?
B: Your company is world-famous. So, I think there will be better chances for persona development.
A: You're right. Do you think you have the qualifications for this job?
B: Sure. My qualifications meet your job description.
A: But you have no experience for this job.
B: That's true. But I am eager to learn, and also quick at learning.
A: Since you need further training, are you familiar with training salary?
B: No. What is the monthly salary?
A: 800 yuan per month.
response: B: Do you mind if I give you an answer in three years?

dialogue: A: Good morning, Dr. Ellis' Office.
B: This is Mrs. Jackson. May I speak to the doctor?
A: Mrs. Jackson, Dr. Ellis is here. How's that new tooth?
B: Not so good, doctor. That's what I'm calling about. It just doesn't seem to fit right.
A: Well, that's to be expected during the first few days after it has been put in. Have you been leaving it in as I told you?
response: B: Well, it feels better with it, doctor, especially when I eat

dialogue: A: Hi, Bill, you look happy.
B: Yes, I've just seen a very funny film on TV.
A: What was it about?
B: It was about a careless man who got into trouble wherever he went. He couldn't do anything right.
A: So you like it?
B: Yes, I do. It made me laugh a lot.
A: But I'd rather see something not only interesting but also instructive.
response: B: Oh, Jane, don't be so serious. People sometimes need relaxation.

dialogue: A: Excuse me. Can you do me a favor?

response: B: You must be the principal.  what do you want anyway?

response: B: Actually, I just got started working at the old company again.

dialogue: A: Hi.
B: Hi, Mary, Hi, Ken I hate to bring this up, but that new stereo, system you got...
A: Yeah?
response: B: You were playing it very late last morning .

dialogue: A: An interesting meeting, isn't it?
B: Yes, very. I thought the last speaker was especially good.
A: Let me introduce myself, by the way. My name's Thomas Bradley.

A: Sorry, what was your last name again?
B: It's Nugent, N-U-G-E-N-T, but just call me Ted.
A: Ok, I'm Tom.
B: Glad to meet you.
A: And what do you do, Ted?

response: A: Modeling?

dialogue: A: Has everything been OK with you lately?

A: Have you been too busy to get enough sleep?
response: B: I try to go to sleep , and I fall asleep right away.

dialogue: A: Why, Ann, I haven't seen you for ages. How have you been?
B: Bob, it has been a long time, hasn't it? It must be at least a year.
A: No. We talked at the Johnson's Christmas party last December. Don't you remember?
B: That's right. Well, how are you? Still working for the Germen company?
A: No. I changed my job about 4 months ago. I'm with the World Bank now. How about you?
response: B: I'm still working at the University, but I transferred from the German Department to the Spanish Department.

dialogue: A: Hi, Robert, what happened to your face? It looks swollen.
B: I have to go and get my teeth filled.
A: Did it hurt?
B: I don't even want to talk about it. It killed me!
A: Well, I guess you've learned a good lesson, huh! You have to take good care of your teeth.
B: No kidding. I can't stand the pain, but the bill is too large!
A: Don't you have a dental insurance?
response: B: I do. but it covers everything.

dialogue: A: Do you know how to play tennis?
B: Not very well. But I'd love to learn.
A: Would you like to play with me tomorrow morning?
B: Certainly, but I'm not very good.
response: A: We'll see about that. Anyway, you know that practice doesn't guarantee perfection.

dialogue: A: Bill, do you know when did the Chinese begin to celebrate Teachers ' Day?
B: I know the Chinese teachers had their first festival in 1985.
A: So, it is the 27th Teachers ' Day.
B: What will you do on Teachers ' Day?
A: I am going to send Mr. Li some flowers. What about you?
response: B: I intend to invite him to dinner next year.

dialogue: A: When was the first computer built?

A: Is it the same as the computers that we use now?
response: B: No, it was as large as a room and worked very slow.

A: Hmm. I hate working on weekends.

B: That sounds interesting.
A: Yes.
B: Let's see.
response: A: You need to have a driver's license. And you never have to work.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?

A: Please fill out this form.

A: Yes. You must put on her name and address.
B: OK, I see. Here you are. Is that OK now?
A: Let me check. Yes. Your 1,000 remittance, please.
B: Here you are. What is the rate?
A: This rate is one percent. That will be 10 yuan.
B: OK. When will this remittance arrive?
response: A: Generally it will arrive within three days .

dialogue: A: Now, can anyone summarize the main idea of the passage? Yes, Jessie, please?
B: I'm sorry.
A: You look pale, Jessie. Are you all right?
B: No, I'm not feeling well. Mr. Brown.
A: What seems to be the problem?
B: I guess I ate something bad at lunch.
response: A: And you feel great now?

A: Oh? What are you watching?
B: I'm watching a cowboy film.
A: Can Mr. Taylor help me?
response: B: No, he can't now, Paul. He's doing nothing right now.

response: B: Actually, that's not true. Acknowledgments can help you leave a bad impression on others, especially in the public places.

dialogue: A: Hello! Is your taxi engaged?

A: Please take me to the Honging Hotel.
response: B: OK . Please get in . I'm glad to serve you .

dialogue: A: Anna, that outfit looks wonderful on you! The color goes with your trousers perfectly.
B: Thanks, Carla. That's quite a compliment coming from you. You always dress so tastefully.
A: Well, that dress certainly shows your good taste. It must have cost a lot.
B: No, not much. I got it on sale at the mall - 60 % off.
response: A: Really? You're a terrible bargain hunter! Next time there's a sale, promise you'll let me tag along with you.

A: Is that right?
response: B: I also agree with all his policies.

dialogue: A: Good morning, I'm one of the students who rented your flat. It's 55 Park Road.

A: Not exactly. I'm afraid there are a couple of problems.
B: Oh! I'm sorry to hear that. What kind of problems?
response: A: Well, we haven't had any hot water for a couple of days now. I wonder if you could send someone to have a look at it.

dialogue: A: Have you seen the news today?

A: Did you know there was a blackout last night?
response: B: Yes , I heard the lights were on all night .

dialogue: A: What are you doing this evening?

A: Oh, come on. It's Saturday.
response: B: Well, how about going to the cinema, then?

A: Dad, I'm in Grade 8 now, and I need real supplies for my demanding classes.
response: B: Oh, so you need a grenade, too?

dialogue: A: Honey, how long have we been living here?

response: B: That would cost a lot of money. But we do need to do some changes to the house.

dialogue: A: Did you have your television repaired?
