A: Why not? The repair is very good and thecharges are so reasonable.
response: B: That may be, but i was able to find it

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman said it will.
B: I don't think he's right. It hasn't rained for a week.
A: But he is usually right in his weather news.
response: B: I'm sure we'll have poor weather for our picnic.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Will you please book tickets to Sanya for me?
A: Yes, sir. When will you intend to leave?
B: Next Wednesday.
A: That will be July 13. There are two flight available that day: one at 9:00 a.m., the other one at 3:30 p.m.
B: Fine. I'd like the 3:30 one.
A: 3:30 p.m. How many tickets do you need?
B: Two.
A: Wish you a wonderful trip to Sanya.
response: B: They say Sanya does not have beautiful scenery. To tell the truth, my wife has been dying to go there.

dialogue: A: Good morning, may I help you?
B: Good morning. I want to remit 1,000 yuan to my sister in Shanghai.
A: Please fill out this form.
B: OK... Do I need to put on my sister's name for the receiver?
A: Yes. You must put on her name and address.
B: OK, I see. Here you are. Is that OK now?
A: Let me check. Yes. Your 1,000 remittance, please.
B: Here you are. What is the rate?
A: This rate is one percent. That will be 10 yuan.
B: OK. When will this remittance arrive?
response: A: Generally it will arrive within three decades.

dialogue: A: Hello, Dora, I haven't seen you for a long time. Where have you been?
B: I didn ’ t go anywhere. I stayed at home.
A: What's up? You look unhappy.
B: Nothing. I just feel very lonely in this city. I miss my family.
A: Oh, I know. Sometimes I have the same feeling with you. But you'd better not be so emotional.
B: Can you stay and accompany me for a while?
response: A: Sure , no problem . You can call me any time you are alone from now on .

dialogue: A: Have you booked the airplane tickets to spain yet?
B: Well, I thought we should go traveling by ship for a change, so I booked two ship tickets instead.
A: You should have told me or discussed it with me.
B: I wanted to give you a surprise. Don't you like the idea?
A: I like it all right, but it takes much more time to travel by ship than by plane.
B: We have time, don't we? Every time we went on a trip, we were always tied down by schedules. This time will be different. We don't have to rush.
A: You're right. This is our first trip since you retired. We can travel as long as we like.
B: We'll have an easy trip and enjoy every minute.
response: A: Have you bought your mom's cheques yet?

dialogue: A: What are your hobbies, Mr. Green?
B: I like collecting stamps.
A: But it's an expensive hobby, isn't it?
B: Yes, you're right. What do you like to do in your spare time?
response: A: I usually do work with my coworkers . But I like filing taxes best .

dialogue: A: Hello, Happy Time Catering Services, Vitoria speaking. How can I help you?

B: Hello, Victoria. This is Joe Smith from country holidays. I wondered if you could do some catering for us next week, we are having a small reception. It's to launch our summer holiday advertising campaign. Will you be free?
A: When exactly is it? Mr. Smith?
B: April 21st, that's Thursday. Oh, sorry, no. It should be Friday.
A: Oh, yes I can do that where will you be holding it?
response: B: We thought we'd have that at head office and use the conference room, because there is enough room for everyone there.

dialogue: A: How is the weather today?
B: It's very hot and humid.
A: Quite different from the forecast.
B: The weather changes often at this time of the year. It's possible to cool down in the late afternoon.
A: How are the summers here generally?
response: B: They are usually salty and clear.

dialogue: A: Waiter! I'd like to speak to the manager please... immediately if possible.
B: Is anything wrong, Madam?
A: I'm afraid there is. The service here has been terrible. We had to wait twenty minutes for a glass of mineral water.
B: I see. Well I'm sorry to hear that. The trouble is that we're a bit sort of hands at present. Two waitresses are ill.

A: All right, but that's no excuse. My husband asked for goose and he was brought chicken instead. It's just unbelievable! And my beans weren't cooked properly. It wasn't a very enjoyable meal at all.
B: This is most regrettable.
A: Look at this bill. We've been overcharged. We only had one dessert, not two. Can you check the bill again, please?
B: I do apologize, Madam.
response: A: I'm afraid I'm not going to pay the service charge, or give a tip, as I don't feel satisfied with it. I'm quite disappointed as a matter of fact.

dialogue: A: Are you ready for a second?
B: No, I'm afraid we'll have to cancel the order. I'm not sure whether it agrees with me.
A: Would you like anything else?
B: I'd prefer swordfish steak.
response: A: I'm sorry.It ' s out of season now.

dialogue: A: Did you hear about the air crash that occurred in South America recently? It was quite a tragic accident!
B: No, I didn't see anything in the news about it. What happened?
A: A foreign airliner was attempting to land at night in a mountainous area in Argentina and flew into a hill!
B: That sounds really terrible! Did anyone survive?
response: A: No, everyone aboard, including the crew, was instantly interviewed.

dialogue: A: : Excuse me. I'd like to find out about flights to New York.
B: an: Well, let's see. One just left about five minutes ago; and there's another one at ten.
A: : What time is it, please?
B: an: It's five to eight.
A: : So the plane leaves in about two hours.
B: an: That's right. Have you bought your ticket?
A: : No, I haven't, Can I buy one here?
response: B: I'm afraid you can't. You'd better go to the restaurant.

B: Thank you indeed.
A: Is everything settled?
B: Almost.
A: What else can I do for you?
B: I suppose I should look for a bigger house. But I don't see how I can afford one right now.
A: If only you hadn't spent so much money on your vacation!
response: B: You're right. But I really had a crappy vacation at least.

dialogue: A: What are you working on?
B: I'm figuring out my budget.
A: What budget?
response: B: I'm making a shopping budget , so that I don't spend too much money .

dialogue: A: Did you watch the TV special about barnacles last night?
B: No, I missed it. What did you learn about them?
A: That they glue themselves to rocks in the ocean, shortly after birth. They also stay in the same place forever.
B: Right, have you ever tried removing one of those things? It would be easier to chip the rock away than to get the barnacles off.
A: Exactly, and that's why scientists are trying to figure out what the barnacles glue is made of. It's considered one of the strongest adhesives in nature.
B: And it would have the advantage of being able to work on wet surfaces too.
A: Precisely, and because it's natural protein, it probably wouldn't be harmful to people like so many synthetic glues in use today.
response: B: Think of all the ways doctors and dentists could use such a glue, making scrapbooks and gluing pieces of paper together.

dialogue: A: United Development Company. May I help you?
B: I'd like to speak to Mr. Hailer, please.
A: Who shall I say is calling, please?
B: This is Mr. Dewey from the IM Company.
A: I'm sorry, Mr. Dewey, but Mr. Halley is not in at the moment.
response: B: When will he be home, do you know?

dialogue: A: Can I help you?

A: Professor Gilers's class?

A: Let's just say you are not the first person.

A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.

response: A: I've asked professor Gilers twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them in the garbage can than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for these same articles to be returned.

dialogue: A: Doctor! Doctor! Help me, please!
B: Take it easy, please! Sit here, now, what's the matter with you? And can I help you?
A: I feel sick. I have a bad stomach-ache, and my head troubles me a lot.
response: B: Well, let me have a check. Open your mouth please. And say "Ah".

dialogue: A: Diana's Flowers, Diana Lin's office, may I help you?
B: Is Diana in?
A: No, she's out for lunch. May I take a message?
B: Yes, please ask her to call John Smith.
response: A: Ok, I'll make sure she gets the message.

dialogue: A: Good morning, sir. May I help you?
B: Good morning. I need a new identification card.
A: Why?
response: B: My ID card is in my bedroom.

dialogue: A: Are you feeling all right, Mary? You look a little tired.
B: My brother and I had a birthday for my sister last night. So I didn't have much sleep.
A: Where did you have the party?
B: It was at my uncle's house.
response: A: Is it right that you got back home very early?

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.

response: A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and yellow.

B: That ’ s in one month, and besides, this is a group date with all of our friends.

response: B: I'm going fishing alone.

B: No, thank you. Just the check.

response: B: Yes, you owed me for last time

response: B: No. I'm meeting with friends. But I earned so many miles by traveling for work that the ticket was free.

dialogue: A: Where do you want to go, Madam?
B: Hilton Hotel, please. Brrr! It's cold, eh? I'm freezing.
A: Come in. San Francisco is usually cold in winter, you know. It's often very rainy, which makes the weather colder and it sometimes....
B: Well, it gets very hot in summer, doesn't it?
response: A: Not really. It gets warm in July and August. That's the best time to visit the city. Uh, oh. Here comes the rain!

A: That'll be lovely. Where are you going?
B: I start out from Long Island this Friday. I've planned a four-day drive to Salt Lake Ciy, where I'll join my brother and my family for his fortieth birthday.
response: A: Well, you've got to donate lots of food and enough sleeping bags then?

dialogue: A: Can I help you?
B: Yes, I'd like to read some articles that are on reserve about British culture.
A: Professor Grand's class?
B: That's right. How could you know?
A: Let's just say you are not the first person coming in asking for those articles.
B: Oh, well, seeing as how I haven't read any of them yet, it doesn't really matterwhich one you give me first.
A: I'm afraid I can't give you any of them at the moment. They've all been checked out.
B: You're joking, all of them?

A: Every month. I've asked professor Grand twice already to bring in additional copies of the articles, but no sooner do I place them on the shelves than they are gone. See that girl in the black sweater? She's been waiting for half an hour for those same articles to be returned.
B: And here's me. I went out of my way to free out the whole afternoon to read.
response: A: I'm sorry, but there is a whole lot I can do about it. All I can suggest is that you come in first thing tomorrow evening and try again. We open at eight.

dialogue: A: It's a beautiful day, isn't it?
B: Yes, nice and sunny.
A: It's much better than last week. It was too warm then.
B: I'm glad summer is over. I like autumn best.
A: So do I. It's neither too hot nor too cold. The sky is clear and blue.
B: It's a good time to have a picnic. Do you want to have one this weekend.
response: A: I'd love to, but I think it's going to rain. The weatherman said it will.

dialogue: A: Hi, Kathy, it's Jason.
B: Hi, Jason. I haven't heard from you in a while.
A: Well. I've been busy. I've started my own company.
B: Wow, what kind of business is it?
A: Just a small on-line store. I am hiring staff and I want you to come to work for me.
B: Actually, I just got started working at the old company again.
response: A: Oh, I didn't realize you were going back. Well, can you recommend me?

dialogue: A: What are you here for today?
B: I need to fight this ticket that I got.
A: Is the arresting officer here?
B: Yes, he is, Your Honor.
A: Plead your case.
B: I was told by the officer that I ran a red light. That information isn't true.
A: Why would the officer lie?
B: I'm not sure, but the signal had a camera on it.
response: A: Did the camera take a picture of yourself in the car ?

dialogue: A: What are pubs?
B: Pubs in England are friendly and warm places where you can have a drink and usually a simple meal.
A: What kind of drinks do people get?
response: B: You can get wine and beer in most cafes. Many also serve coffee. You go to the counter to order and pay for your drinks.

dialogue: A: Look at this picture. It might have been taken many years ago.
B: You're right. It was taken 71 years ago, during the Second World War. I was just 6 years old then.
A: Is this little girl you?
B: Yes. And the little boy is my younger brother. The couple standing behind us is our parents. It is the only picture of my family.
A: Hadn't you taken any pictures together before you took this one?
B: Of course we did. But all the pictures were destroyed when a bomb destroyed our house. This picture survived because I always took it with me.
A: Didn't you taken any picture after the bomb?
B: Well, it was a sad story. My father was killed in that bombing.
response: A: I'm sorry to hear that. War left many people happy memories.

dialogue: A: Hi! Nice to meet you, Nancy! Where were you yesterday?
B: I didn't come because I was sick.
A: You still look a little sick. You ought to go back to bed.
B: I am going home now.
A: Did you drive today?
B: Oh, No, I don't have a car.
response: A: I can take you home. Would you like a ride?

dialogue: A: What are you reading, Bill?
B: It's this week's New Scientist. Why?
A: I was just wondering. It looks interesting, but I've never actually read it myself. It's for real scientists, or can ordinary people like me understand it?

B: Oh, it's for anyone really. It usually has articles and stories about current affairs about science, as well as papers about new developments in research, I'm reading about a new telephone that allows you to see the person you are speaking to, as well as hear him.
A: Oh, I've heard about it. Is it on the market yet? Can I buy one?
B: No, not this one. But the company has made other models to try out on business. This one is special because of its color, and the images moving.
A: Oh, that's interesting.

B: You see, the first videophones--that's what they are called--were made in Japan. But they can only show a still black-and-white image, so this videophone is much better than that. Mind you, I'm not sure I'd want one, would you?
response: A: Well, no. I don't think I would. I bet it costs a lot of money. Does it say how much it costs?

dialogue: A: Have we sold out all the newspapers for today?
B: Yes. What a good job we have done!
A: Why are so many extra gifts left here?
B: Many customers didn't want them.
response: A: How about throwing them down the toilet?

dialogue: A: How are you getting on, White? Are you still working for the Merry Lynch Bank?
B: Yes, Kitty, that's right.
A: I suppose you know quite a lot about banking by now, don't you?
B: Oh, yes. To tell you the truth, I'm a bit tired of it.
A: Really? Isn't it good to work in a bank?
B: You know I've been working for the Merry Lynch Bank for over 15 years.
A: So you are thinking of making a change,are you?
B: Yes, I am. Actually, you know, I'm thinking of beginning my own business.
A: That sounds great.
B: Yes, I think it over, but the problem is money. If I had enough money, I'd leave the bank tomorrow.
A: What are you going to do to solve the problem?
response: B: I'll steal some money from a bank, of course, but not from the one I've been working for.

dialogue: A: What time is it now?
B: It's half past seven. I think we will be late for the film.
A: Don't worry. There is still twenty minutes to go.
response: B: But it's three kilometers from here to the grocery store. How can we get there in such a short time?

dialogue: A: Good morning. Venus Real Estate Agency.
B: Good morning. I'm calling to ask if you have a vacant apartment.
A: Do you have any particular type of apartment in mind?
B: I prefer a one-bedroom apartment.
A: Are you renting it alone or with company?
B: I'll share it with one of my friends. What ’ s in a one-bedroom apartment?
A: A one-bedroom apartment has one bedroom, a living room, a kitchen and a bathroom.
B: Is there any furniture?
response: A: No , but a fridge and a stove .
